With a grin I grabbed her up and rubbed my face against hers, causing her to giggle before she wrapped her own arms around my neck.

“So you’ve finally decided to break out of your shell huh? I’m glad you were able to overcome the aliens. Now they have one lest person to take over the world with.”

Her mouth was close to my ear as she gave another giggle and answered me. Her voice was just a whisper, but I could hear the light musical tones in it. And the cheer.

“Aliens don’t exist silly! But thank you. You made me feel a whole lot better. You can stop now.”

She gave me a small kiss on the cheek as she hugged me tighter. Even as I stroked her hair I felt the tears dripping onto my shoulder. With a small smile I turned my head slightly so my whisper would tickle her own ears.

“But I don’t want to stop. Losing someone hurts, there is no doubt about that. But people can still care about you. You can still find things to make you happy. If you want to cry then cry. If you want to laugh then laugh. I’ll be here if you need me and I won’t let you out of my sight. Right now it makes me happy being able to make you happy. Besides, do you have any proof aliens don’t exist? If not, then I will have to protect you from them too.”

Her arms tightened a little more as the water soaking into my shirt increased. While I was busy comforting her Sue slipped into the dressing room to gather up and discreetly throw away the diaper the girl had been wearing. She gave me a wink as she slipped off to dispose of it and I winked back. The girl finally started to get control of herself after a few moments, giving a sniff before wiping her nose on my shoulder.

“Can I really keep all these pretty dresses? You didn’t just do this to make me feel better?”

“Yes they are all yours. If you want a few more then make sure you say something. I wasn’t lying when I said you are a cute little girl. Cute little girls deserve to wear pretty and cute things. I might only be watching over you for a few days, but I want you to feel like you are home here. I bet you my best artifact that teddy bear is the only thing you were able to take with you when you left your home. Not having things to call your own just isn’t right.”

“But isn’t it going to be expensive?”

“And who’s idea of expensive are we talking about huh? To a millionaire a thousand Reul is like one Senz coin to the rest of us. To my way of thinking, right now your happiness is worth any price. So don’t you worry about how much this or that costs. You leave that to me to decide when enough is enough.”

With another squeeze she finally let go and slid to the ground, picking out another dress before going into the changing room on her own. While she was inside Sue came back as silent as a shadow to stand by my side.

“I squelched the whispers from the other girls already. Told them this was Hunter business so they should forget it all if they knew what was good for them. By the way, care to tell me what that whole diaper thing was all about? Not that I need to know, just curious.”

“It was someone’s idea of dealing with her trauma without dealing with her trauma. But now that it has disappeared it never existed.”

“What never existed? I told you before, I have a pretty bad memory sometimes.”

I slipped her five hundred Reul with a grin which she pocketed just as Asala came back out twirling around in the black dress she was wearing. We spent another hour or so in the store until Asala was satisfied with everything we had gotten. She helped me carry some of the bags out as I paid the bill, giving Sue a final conspiratorial wink.

“So Asala. What do you want for dinner? You feel like eating out or going home and having me make you something?”

“Can we go home? I’m a bit sleepy. And do you know how to make spaghetti? Mom makes, I mean made, that all the time.”

I saw her quickly wipe away a few tears that escaped her eyes as I grinned down at her.

“Aye I know how to make that. And I know I have all the ingredients too. In fact some people call me the noodle master.”

“Really?”

“No not really. But they could.”

“She giggled as we walked on in silence for a bit. I saw her glancing up at me a moment before quickly looking away with a small flush to her cheeks. Finally she spoke up like I knew she wanted to, the hesitation clear in her voice.”

“U-um Riktal? Would you… would you carry me again. Daddy used to always carry me like that.”

Before she knew what was happening I had scooped her up and hardened my arm to act as her seat. This time though she wrapped her arms around my neck and laid her head against me as we walked. I felt the tears beginning to soak in even though her sobs were silent. I couldn’t hug her or stroke her hair because my hands were full but she knew I was there for her and that was all she needed right now.

*****
It seems our time grows short again. Or is this yet again? It is so hard to tell sometimes. Are you satisfied with this day? Dissatisfied? For what reasons? Observing you has been enlightening, but I fear you must come again. I need more information before I can answer my own curiosity. Only through observing you multiple times will I get my answers. So until then fair traveler, I will be watching you.
111121112111111.title: Shopping spree

11112111211112.content:
“As ill conceived as I think mothers demand that I continue to go to class is, I’ll accept. I’m in a pretty good mood right now so I’m willing to go along with one of mothers harebrained ideas.”

Jara chuckled a bit as she let her foot slide off the table to the floor with a thump.

“Don’t sell your father that short lad. He already figured you wouldn’t like that concession much. He spoke to the office before I even got you to let them know you wouldn’t be coming for a few days.”

My father looked at Jara with a slightly raised eyebrow but said nothing to refute her statement. Jara returned his stare with an uplifted eyebrow of her own and a small wink. Their silent conversation only took a few seconds but whatever Jara had been trying to tell him he understood. At least the small dip of his head in her direction made me think he understood. I was a bit surprised that my father had actually thought of me and my desires enough to do such a thing. I looked down at my hands which I clasped in front of me on the table, unsure of how exactly to handle my father actually acting a bit fatherly. My words wanted to catch in my throat, feeling foreign to my ears

“Uh thanks dad. I guess.”

“It was nothing son. The least I could do really. Listen, for the record I didn’t want to hold you back from taking the Exams. I disagreed with your mother on that front but I lost the argument. I know it might not make much of a difference for you to know that but I do think you are more than capable and qualified.”

He looked to the left and right a moment, as if unsure of his next words while his clasped hands tightened together until the knuckles turned white.

“Say son. I know this might be a bit out of the blue and all, but would you be interested in doing something after this job is over? Me and your mother will be in Bornica for about a week, maybe a little longer. But when we get back do you think it would be too much to ask? Just you and me. Frankly I’m not even sure what we could do, but nothing Hunter related. Maybe fishing, or go out and see a movie or something. I’d like… I’d like to get to know you a little better. Not Riktal the Hunter, but Riktal the man.”

I had to use all my will to keep my jaw from dropping to the floor as Jara gave my father a small nod. What was this all of a sudden? Had my father become possessed by a new breed of monster? He had never been interested in being fatherly before. Always putting his work first. Always treating me like a Hunter. Perhaps he was going through one of those mid life crisis things. I heard when men got to be around forty like him they sometimes had such attacks. Added on top of his previous actions on my behalf I didn’t know what to do.

“Uh… sure. I guess that would be ok. But won’t your schedule be busy like it always is?”

“I’ll free it up for you. I realize I’ve missed out on a lot of things and you grew into a young man before I even noticed. I’d like to learn a bit about the man you grew up to be while my back was turned. I can’t change the past, but I’d like to start in the present if I can.”

My father levered himself to his feet, giving me a small nod of the head as Jara stood as well. He strode over to the door and opened it before turning to look at me again.

“Well you think on what you want to do when we come back. I’ve still got a few places to go before I meet up with your mother and we go catch the next flight. I’ll let you get to your work safe in the knowledge that she is in good hands for the next few days.”

He looked down at the ground a moment as he turned away, his voice echoing a bit as he left the room pulling the door closed behind him with a soft click.

“I’m sorry son.”

I looked from the door to the girl, letting my shock finally show on my face as I got up shaking my head. A few steps around the table and I was able to grab the chair my father was sitting in, spinning it around before sitting down with a slouch. Propping my arms on the table behind me I glanced over at the girl with another shake of my head.

“Do you believe that? Because I barely can. It feels so strange having him actually talk to me like that. Normally our conversations are limited to Hunter business and not much else. I actually get kind of crept out when he starts treating me as anything but a Hunter. I get this feeling like the world is going to end or something.

“Now my mother, my mother tries too hard and you can tell she’s all fake. Fake smiles, fake greetings, fake feelings of caring. She’s all about what she can get from others and how to most effectively get what she wants. Whenever I am around her I can’t help but get angry just on principal. Actually just thinking about her most of the time can get my blood boiling. You’ve probably met her so you might know what I am talking about.”

“But you know, as strange as this sounds, especially after everything I just said, I still love them both. Isn’t that weird? I really don’t have any memories of either one of them being actual parents. I’m not just saying that or speaking while blocking out those memories. My parents, well they never had time for me period. It was always work, work, and more work with them. They would stay at the house for a few days sometimes to train me to be a Hunter, then go running off to some far off place to fight monsters. I’d be left with baby-sitters and other Hunter’s to continue my training on my own until they came back. Sometimes that would be a month or two later.

“You know how they usually greeted me when they came home? Do you think it was with hugs and kisses or big smiles? No. They’d come swinging a sword or their fist without even a word of warning. Not because they were angry or anything, but to test me. To see if I had continued to become stronger while they were away. I never got toys or anything either. Every present I got was either a weapon, a book on warfare or magic, or armor. Them being around for holidays and birthdays? You’d have better luck suddenly transforming into a boy.”

The girls face didn’t change at all, but her hand tightened around her bear a bit more. I had noticed that small movement while talking to my father as well. At first I hadn’t been sure if that was some involuntary reaction of her body while she hid in her mind or her reacting to the words being spoken. Now I was sure it was the latter and not the former.

“You are lucky you had a mother and father who cared about you.”

Her eyes began to tear up slightly even though there was no other sign of an expression on her face. I nodded my head slowly as I pulled her into an embrace.

“I was right. They are dead aren’t they? I hadn’t been sure honestly, but it would explain why you are here now. It was a toss up between that or they rejected you once they found out about your powers, kicking you out of the house and disowning you. But I would like to think the best of people most of the time. I would like to believe that most mothers and father’s aren’t like mine. That they wouldn’t sell out their own child so easily. Especially a cute little girl like you.”

As I began to stroke her hair I felt the tears getting my tunic all damp. Though I didn’t hear any sound at all, a fact I found a bit eerie. Still, this was only the beginning.

“They were precious to you weren’t they? I know how it feels to lose something precious too. Someone precious. What’s worse is when people tell you to “get over it” or to “man up”. they act like it’s wrong to grieve. That it’s wrong to cry. Girls can get away with it a little more than boys can, since people have this idea that girls are supposed to be weaker. I think it’s all quite silly actually. Both men and women have the same kinds of feelings don’t we? Even if men have been taught to hide them better. Love is still love, fear is still fear, and grief is still grief.

“When I lost the people who were most precious to me I’m not ashamed to say that I cried. I bawled my eyes out and soaked my pillow night after night all alone. It’s not a sin to cry, no matter what anyone might say. It is a natural reaction and a natural function of the body. Telling someone it is a sin to cry when their body wants to is like telling them to stop breathing. Some people are made of sterner stuff, but everybody has something that can get to them. There is no reason to be ashamed of who you are and what gets to you.”

Her arms came up around me then, squeezing me tightly around the middle as a soft mewling escaped her throat. The small pitiful wail grew louder and louder until her entire four and a half foot frame was shaking and her arms were crushing me as hard as they could. I let her cry herself out as I softly stroked her hair, cooing words of comfort into her ear while rocking her back and forth a bit. When she finally pulled herself away to rub her nose with the back of her arm I planted a kiss on her forehead.

“Do you feel a bit better now sweetie?”

When she nodded her head I let the small curve of my lips spread into a much bigger grin.

“Good. Now we need to do something about those clothes. Time for you to drown away some of that sorrow with a good old fashioned shopping spree. It’s not a cure for the grief, but it can help.”

When I stood up to get my bag from the floor on the other side of the table she latched onto my tunic and followed me while refusing to let go. Slipping the bag onto my back so I could carry it more easily I offered her my hand to take instead. She looked at the offered palm and then at the floor, squeezing her teddy bear tightly before opening her arms and motioning to be picked up with pleading eyes. With a lopsided grin I scooped her up and propped her against my side. She wasted no time in wrapping her arms around my neck and resting her head against me with a sigh of contentment. Opening the door I stepped out into the hall, making a left to head for the front entrance.
11112111211112.title: Take job without negotiating

111121112111121.content:
People stared at me as I walked down the street with Asala in my arms. But neither me nor Asala cared about such watching eyes. For me, this was part of my duty as a Hunter. The mission, whether self imposed or given, was paramount. I had made it my mission to help this little girl return to the land of the living. Let them stare or whisper behind their hands all they wanted.

But for Asala, I doubt she even realized they were looking at her. When I had glanced out of the corner of my eye, there had been a small smile on her face while she rested her head on my shoulder. From her closed lids and her even breathing I could almost believe she was asleep. Even the way she tightened her hands around my neck from time to time made me think that. But I knew. She was in her own little world right now. Not the same world she had run to while hiding from reality, but one made up of memories in happier times. A world where she was able to imagine it was someone else’s neck she was clinging too.

The only small blessing right now was the fact that the streets were pretty empty. With most people either at work or still in school, even if she did open her eyes she wouldn’t be assaulted by so many stares of disapproval. As I turned the corner onto another near empty street Asala let out a small whimper next to my ear, her arms tightening around my neck reflexively out of fear. I saw the reason immediately, a red summoning portal was opening up on the wall to my right. Only my body separated the little girl from the monster she was summoning.

I stopped walking, making some soft sounds of comfort as a big green melon of a head with scraggly black hair began to emerge. The hobgoblins red eyes glowed malevolently from under his thick Neanderthal brows. Without even looking I backhanded the monster before it could make a sound, sending it reeling back into the hole seconds before the portal winked out of existence. A moment later her eyes popped open as she looked around in terror, her gaze moving around wildly for the monster she knew she had summoned. A small mewl of fear escaping her lips.

“Shhh. It’s ok Asala. It was just a bad dream. You fell asleep on my shoulder you know. You were even letting out this little wheezing snore. I think I even felt a bit of drool soaking into my tunic.”

Quickly she wiped at her mouth to get rid of the bit of nonexistent drool while I chuckled slightly at her expense. I had a feeling it wouldn’t be good if she knew the truth right now. Part of the reason she had probably run away into her mind was because of her powers. Thinking in some way she could control them. Not that she was wrong exactly, it was well documented that magical ability was linked with conscious thought. So it was logical to assume special magic like monster summoning worked on the same principals. But running away into her mind again was not going to help her in the long run.

After another moment of looking around for a monster that wasn’t there she gave me a small smile before laying her head on my shoulder again. This time though I saw her large crimson orbs watching the sidewalk along with me.

“Did your daddy carry you like this all the time before?”

Her head nodded up and down, scraping against the fabric of my tunic as the smile spread a bit more on her face.

“Then you remember that. They might be gone, but they aren’t forgotten. Even if you are the only one who remembers them, that makes all those memories that much more important. Because their life is not measured in how they died, but in the sum of how they lived. Even small things like your daddy carrying you in his arms, or your mom tucking you in at night or any one of a hundred things paint the picture of who they were.”

It only took another couple minutes of walking before we came to the store I wanted. Their clothes might not have been the cheapest, but I was paying for more than just fabric today. I was paying for silence. The woman who met us shortly after entering was a bit pudgy, though she still cut a fine figure even after giving birth to three daughters. Her eyes sparkled with mischief as Asala slid to the ground and I inconspicuously shook the numbness out of my arm behind her back. Walking around for almost twenty minutes with such a weight on my muscles was tiring. Even if I had used an augmentation spell and the girl really hadn’t weighed that much.

“Riktal honey! I hope you aren’t going to tell me this is some secret child of yours.”

“Please. Do you think anything this cute could come from a mug this ugly? Besides, I’m not that old. I’d have to have had her when I was six. I might have grown up a bit faster than most, but not that fast.”

“You’re right. Something this cute could never have come from someone as ugly as you.”

“Sue! You hurt my feelings!”

“Ha! You started it. Besides I’m not sure if you have feelings sometimes.”

“What about the customer is always right and all that other stuff?”

“You’re not a customer, your just a rascal that happens to enter the store from time to time to give us money.”

I grinned at the woman, quickly explaining what I wanted before pushing the girl towards Sue with a gentle pat on the back. Sue lost no time in sweeping the girl up into her pace, chatting away while guiding the girl towards a dressing room. Her hand slipping a white dress off a rack without even looking in a smooth motion while she walked. She knew her job and how to make someone feel at ease in the matter of moments. She also knew how to keep her mouth shut on anything she saw or heard. Sue would be able to do some of the things for Asala that I couldn’t because she was a mother and a woman.

Asala came out of the dressing room blushing but I ignored it, gushing over her instead before Sue pulled her back inside with some undergarments and another dress. It took a few changes of clothes but the girl finally started to get into the spirit of it, seeking out dresses on her own and posing both for me and in the mirror when she came out. Sue called Rima, her oldest daughter, over from the make-up section of the store to work on the girl as well.

At first the girl was a bit frightened by the new arrival, but Rima was like her mother, having the knack of putting people at ease in the space of a few heartbeats when she put her mind to it. She was nowhere as good as her mother though, still I could see where she would be given time and practice. Her mother did have almost twenty years more experience after all. Rima treated Asala like a little sister, and the little girl blossomed under the attention. I simply sat back and did almost nothing at all except make some whistling sounds and grin like a fool when Asala looked my way, something she did almost constantly.

After almost two hours of this treatment she danced around a bit before running off to the bathroom. I stood guard outside the door as Sue and her daughter giggled at my protective attitude. Slipping five hundred Reul from my wallet I handed it to them with a wink. We all knew it was payment for the help they had provided. It wasn’t a bribe though, they both knew that much. Still it didn’t hurt to tip when people went above and beyond what they had to do. It was one of the reasons they made sure to be so good at this job, because people like me tended to gravitate towards such shops for the extra services alone. It was a cycle that worked.

They both gave me a conspiratorial wink and lopsided grin that momentarily made them look like twins before hauling all the goods to the counter to ring me up. By the time Asala came out of the bathroom the two of them had already stuffed everything into six bags ready to be taken. Asala looked up at me with those soft eyes of hers as if asking what next. I saw hints of her sorrow hiding behind the bright crimson but as I had planned from the start, it was no longer all consuming. This was only a band-aid solution of course but it bought me a little more time to get her home where she would feel safe letting it all out. By that time I hoped to have shown her there were other things she could live for.

“So, do you want to go out to eat someplace? Or do you want to go home and I can make you something? I bet after all this you are probably pretty hungry. The last of the magic should be wearing off shortly if it hasn’t already.”

Even as I said that a loud grumbling filled the air, causing her to reach down and clutch at her stomach with a blush. Letting out a belly laugh I ruffled her hair as she brought the stuffed animal in her left hand up to her face to hide it in embarrassment.

“You decide.”

Her words were muffled by the fabric, but I could still make them out despite that fact. Her voice was slightly low and musical, having a soft quality to it. She covered it well, but I still heard the hesitation behind those two words.
111121112111121.title: Shopping

1111211121111211.content:
“I think you could handle a little more excitement. Besides, now that we have all these new clothes you should show them off.”

Going over I dug into the bags, pulling out a soft blue dress that felt like silk between my fingers. It was trimmed in darker blue with a pocket in the front big enough to stuff her bear in like a kangaroo pouch if she wished. I shoved them into her hand along with a pair of shoes that went with them before pushing her off to the bathroom again. She didn’t hesitate in scampering off with her treasure to change as I turned back to Sue and her daughter.

“Think I could talk either one of you into getting these things to my house somehow?”

“Riktal honey you know we don’t offer home deliveries. Our shop isn’t that big and the boss doesn’t have insurance to cover something like that.”

I gave Sue my best puppy dog face. The one my sister gave to me all the time.

“Please? You don’t know someone who might be willing to do it for like a hundred Reul?”

“Well, I think Tommy over in stocking might be interested in something like that. No promises though, since if he took such a job he could get fired. I’m not sure if one hundred Reul would be enough to entice him into doing something like that.”

“How much would he be willing to do it for Rima? If he was willing at all. I don’t have all that much left now.”

Rima tapped her chin thoughtfully before getting a playful smile on her face. She glanced at me coyly out of one eye as she looked off to the side.

“Well Riktal…. I could probably get him to agree to taking only a hundred Reul if I were persuaded to. He has a bit of a crush on me you see.”

“And how could I persuade you to do such a thing Rima?”

“Well, I suppose I could do it for a kiss. Just a small peck on the cheek.”

I grinned as I shook my head.

“That’s your price for everything. Though don’t try to turn your head this time to get it on the lips.”

“That was a total accident that time honest!”

“Sure it was. And the way you tried to slip your tongue into my mouth at the time was an accident as well?”

“Well no. I simply took advantage of the opportunity presented.”

“Right. Well as long as it was just an accident.”

She giggled a bit as she leaned over the counter while turning her head to the side for me to kiss her cheek. With another lopsided grin I leaned over the counter as well. Right before my lips touched her skin she turned her head quickly, getting my kiss on her mouth instead. She danced back laughing playfully, her eyes sparkling in merriment.

“Another accident?”

“Of course! And I didn’t try to take advantage of it this time.”

I simply shook my head as I slid a hundred Reul bill across the counter for her to pick up laughingly. Her mother was just grinning from the sidelines even as Asala came back out, skipping up and down a bit while her teddy bear rode in the front pocket. I offered the girl my hand which she took instantly with a smile that lit up her face. Rima blew me a kiss as we walked out the door together, getting in a parting shot before the door closed.

“Pleasure doing business with you Riktal darling. Come again soon!”

With another small chuckle that caused Asala to look up at me questioningly I turned away from the door to head to my next destination. Rima really was incorrigible. But that was part of the charm that had attracted me to her in the first place. Though she was a year older than me, she was one of the few people my age I didn’t think of as being alien. Though admittedly she could be a bit alien in a different way.

We had gone out a few times and had a brief fling in the shadows. I didn’t care if anyone knew, but Rima had wanted to keep it a secret. It was hard to believe she had been so much shyer back then. Her mother knew, or at least she suspected but she never said anything. I had been Rima’s first just like she had been mine. I couldn’t say I was actually very good the first time we slept together, but at least I knew I wasn’t horrible. Like with anything, the skills had come with time and practice. Why had we broken up anyway? Oh yeah that was right, she had found someone else that she hadn’t been afraid to admit she was going out with. Of course that had lasted only a few months until he had dropped her for another girl.

Now that guy had been a real piece of work. Normally I would have let it go. Liaisons’ and breakups happened all the time. But he had left Rima, a normally cheerful girl that no one could damper, in a pile of a weeping mess. Even someone as dense as I was sometimes could tell she had really loved him. I hadn’t got the full story of how he had humiliated her in front of the entire school, but I had heard enough. When I had caught him in that dark alley shortly after I knew it had been revenge pure and simple. But it had been one of the few times I hadn’t acted as a Hunter, I had been acting as a friend.

Biff had never been the same after that. I knew I had gone overboard, turning him into little more than a functioning vegetable. I really hadn’t meant to hit his head so many times, but my anger had gotten the best of me. Now I had to live with the fact that I had turned a promising young man into a total retard that couldn’t tie his shoes on his own. It would have been better if I had killed him in my anger, at least then he would have been better off. Now I just didn’t have the heart to go finish the job in cold blood.

Rima suspected of course, but without proof she wouldn’t say anything. We never had got back together after that but that was fine for both of us. We liked our arrangement. Whenever the loneliness of the house got too much for me to bear, or whenever Rima had the need, we got together for a date or just a few hours of exertion. We had both realized we lived in different worlds in more than one way. Perhaps that was why she had kept our coupling a secret from the beginning. Still, she had helped pull me out of my depression after Siera had died. She hadn’t been annoyed that I had turned her into a bit of a rebound girl. For those things alone, I would be eternally grateful to her.

Seeing my destination up ahead I let my hand rise up to stroke Asala’s soft locks absently.

“I hope you like pasta, because where I am taking you is the best place in town.”

“Can… Can I have spaghetti?”

“You can have whatever you want.”

I opened up the door to the Pasta Palace as her face split into a grin and the fingers in my hand squeezed slightly. I squeezed back reassuringly, giving her the comfort of knowing I was there.
1111211121111211.title: Eat in town

11112111211112111.content:
Shortly after the waitress brought our plates of spaghetti the door jangled open again as a slightly balding man came in. His stomach showed just the hint of a paunch the same way the wrinkles on his face hinted at his age. He saw me sitting there as he looked around and waved good naturedly before heading in my direction. Asala saw him coming as well from her seat next to me and clutched my shirt a bit under cover of the table but otherwise didn’t do anything else. Giving her leg a small squeeze I whispered that it was all right before focusing my attention on my sudden guest.

“Hey! It’s rare to see you here! And eating before me no less! Your mother was just in the shop a few minutes ago, did you come with her?”

“No Nerval, that is just a coincidence. Honestly I would rather not see her right now.”

“Still not seeing eye to eye huh? Well I’m not one to get in the middle of a family dispute. Especially not when I get so much business from that family. By the way, word has it there has been a mass monster migration from the north. Apparently the Forest of Shadows became deserted in the space of a night. No one knows where all the monsters actually went, just that they are no longer in their normal nesting grounds. I doubt we will have to worry about any of them this far south, what with the weather changing and all. Still, thought it was an interesting bit of information a Hunter like you might be able to do something with.”

“Thanks for the tip Nerval.”

“No prob, no prob. By the way, don’t you think that girl is a bit young for you? Not that I’m saying anything mind you. If that’s your thing then more power too you.”

“Don’t be crude Nerval. I’m on a protection job right now. She’s my client. Besides, you don’t have any right to be talking about girls being too young for people.”

He grinned a bit even as a small flush came to his cheeks. With a wave he turned to take a seat a few tables down even as the waitress brought him a plate of stuffed mushrooms and linguino. He rubbed his hands together in glee as she turned away, not noticing the way he stared at her butt as she walked. Shaking my head I went back to my meal, listening to Asala slurp up the noodles happily while her feet kicked back and forth.

I could see the waitresses giving us glances, probably thinking how adorable the girl was. And I had to admit, I would agree with them. Taking her out on the town like this made me feel like a big brother again, reminding me of the days I used to take Olia out. Out of the corner of my eye I saw her slurp up a noodle, getting sauce all over her face and a small bit on her new dress. With a sigh I grabbed up some napkins to clean her cheeks before dabbing at the fabric before it stained.

“Be a little more careful. These are still new clothes you know. Sure it can come out in the wash but still.”

She squirmed a bit under my ministrations but suffered my manhandling with good grace. When I was finished she grinned, motioning me closer with her fingers. When I leaned over she kissed me on the cheek instead of whispering something in my ear like I thought she was going to. She blushed a bit before hiding her face with both hands and looking at the ground. After a moment she went back to eating but refused to look at me, her face still burning a bright red.

I paid our tab once we both had our fill and ended the meal with some cheesecake. Once back on the streets I wrapped my arm around her shoulder in order to steer her back to the house. If I was right she would be getting a bit tired by now. The magic would all be out of her system and her body would be screaming for some real sleep now that her stomach was full. She leaned her head against my side with a small sigh before her voice wafted up to my ears. It was low and soft, taking me a moment to realize I had heard anything.

“Would you be my family? Is it ok if I call you my brother?”

“Of course it’s ok. Who wouldn’t want to have a little sister as cute and pretty as you?”

“Then… would you come with me when I have to leave?”

“I’m sorry, I can’t do that. But we can keep in contact. You can cast a communication spell right? If so I can give you my magical id so you can call me wherever and whenever. And if you are too far away for the spell to reach, well you can always write me a letter.”

Even though she didn’t look at me I could hear the small pout in her voice while her hand clenched against my shirt.

“I can’t do a communication spell. I haven’t learned how yet.”

“Well then we have at least two days together. It’s simple enough to learn, so I will teach it to you.”

“Really?”

“Cross my heart.”

She was silent for a little bit as the two of us walked through town. Finally she looked up at me with eyes on the verge of tears. I could see some of the sadness she had been keeping at bay until now creeping back in.

“Would you carry me again? Please?”

I didn’t answer with words, simply scooped her up in my arms before settling her against my side and wrapping my free arm around her in a hug. She returned it before hiding her face in my shoulder and starting to cry in earnest. I didn’t say anything, just kept walking. Offering her what comfort I could at the moment with just my presence.

“I don’t want to leave again!”

“I know.”

“I miss my mommy and daddy!”

“I know.”

“I’m going to miss you too!”

“I know.”

“I love you!”

“I love you too little one.”

I knew that feeling of love was just her latching onto me as the person who had pulled her out of the darkness. She would have felt that way about anyone who had treated her as I had today. It had nothing to do with being a Hunter, since anyone could have done it. But I had been the one to anchor her in reality. To make her feel wanted and needed again. Feel less lost without her parents. So I had become the object of her affection.

She sniffed a bit before another round of tears began dripping onto my shoulder. I simply let her have her tears without saying a word. Sometimes everybody needed a good cry.

*******

The day is done and your choices made. As you look back do you wonder that ever present question of what if? Do you imagine the way the day could have gone if you had picked a different path? Are you satisfied with this day though? Is it possible to be satisfied with a day and yet still regret it at the same time I wonder? That is a curiosity of a question I would like an answer to. You humans are interesting creatures indeed.

But one timeline is not enough for me. You must come again and redo this day over and over. Only then will my curiosity be sated, my answers found. Only through you making different choices will I find what I want. So come again traveler and decide upon the possibilities.

That is, if you really have a choice.
11112111211112111.title: Pasta Palace

1111211121111212.content:
“As much as I think you would enjoy eating here in town, I think a nice home cooked meal would do you good. Besides, it’s not often I get to show off my cooking skills for someone besides myself. Ever have stuffed Papilla peppers before?”

She shook her head no behind the teddy bear as I reached down to pull her into my side while I turned towards the front counter.

“Well then I think I know what we will have tonight.”

She gave me a small nod as she lowered the stuffed animal, a small smile curving her lips. With a grin of my own I began grabbing the shopping bags, juggling them a bit to grab all six of them. With a quick glance down at the girl I shoved one of the bags at her absently.

“Well these are your clothes not mine. It’s only fair that you carry at least one of the bags.”

I saw the small smile grow a bit bigger as she straightened up a bit to take the bag with her right hand. With a nod to the two women who were giggling at me behind upraised hands I led Asala out into the street. As we walked I noticed her continuing to glance up at me out of the corner of her eye and smiling a bit every time.

“You don’t need to answer if you don’t want to, but did you go shopping with your mom often? I’m just a bit curious.”

She was silent as we walked and I didn’t push her. This was just another part of the plans to let her deal with her grief. I simply kept my eyes straight ahead and didn’t turn to look her way, giving her the feeling of distance if she wanted it without feeling pressured. After a few blocks she finally answered in a voice I could tell was holding back some pain.

“Sometimes. Most of the time she went while I was in school. She’d always let me help her carry bags too when she did take me. My daddy never did though. He didn’t do much shopping but he would take me once in a while. But he always carried everything. Said it was a man’s duty.”

“Do you have any brothers or sisters?”

“No. Mommy said I was going to have a little sister soon before… before it happened.”

“Before she died. It won’t help you to ignore it like that. I know it might hurt, but if you use words like “passed on” or “went away” or talking about her death in such vague terms it will always hurt. When you can say it like that you can begin the healing process and move forward with your life. It doesn’t mean you forget them if you accept the truth. You don’t have to do that now, but I wanted you to realize that so when you are ready you can move on.”

“Daddy used to say stuff like that too. I really didn’t understand him sometimes but he always had a way of making things make sense.”

“It will get better. I know it doesn’t feel that way right now, but it will. Tell you what. How would you feel about me calling you my little sister?”

“Then would it be ok if I called you big brother?”

“Well obviously. Isn’t that what a little sister is supposed to call her big brother? Family is what you make and sometimes who you choose. You don’t get a choice in who your parents are, sometimes not even in having brothers and sisters. But it is my belief you have a choice in everything else. Even if they aren’t blood related, that doesn’t mean they can’t be family.”

We both fell silent as we continued to walk along. I could see her lost in thought as she walked. She might be a young girl, but I could tell she was no dummy. I could guess at what was going on in her mind based on past experience while dealing with shock and trauma victims but that was about it. To an extent their reactions were the same, but at the same time they were all unique because of their personalities and pasts.

Shortly after we left the bridge over the river and got onto the road a few blocks from my house a red summoning portal opened in front of us. Asala let out a small whimper, hiding behind my leg as a small blur shot into the air and the portal closed again. The bags were already dropping from my hands and reaching up into the duffle bag on my back by the time I got a good look at the monster. With a laugh I uncurled my fingers from the two guns I had grabbed, letting them stay inside the bag for the moment.

“There’s nothing to worry about. It’s just a Cassilion.”

I let out a meow against the evening air, causing the Cassilion to land on the ground in front of me. Barely bigger than a normal black cat, the six legs and the pair of eagle wings on it’s back made sure no one mistook it for anything but a monster. When I held out my hand the creature came forward to sniff my fingers a moment before rubbing against them. Once introductions were over between us I scratched the monster behind the ears and between his wings, getting a very cat like purr in response.

“Cassilion’s were once regular domesticated cat’s you know. They were originally created to serve as Hunter companions. This was around six hundred years or so ago mind you. Back then Hunter’s didn’t have as high of standards and morels as they do today. It was a very brutal and chaotic world back then, the lands were more wild and the fighting harsher. But time moves on like it always does and the lands became quieter. There was no more need for Hunter’s to have fierce battle companions like the Cassilion.

“But after so many years of breeding and augmenting them using magic and Alchemy, they had become a self sustaining construct that was able to pass it’s abilities down to it’s litter’s without need of Hunter’s as a middle man. Funny don’t you think? We Hunter’s who kill monsters, created this one ourselves. We tamed them and fought with them just like summoners do. Yet today we can easily forget their past, simply calling them a monster. Just like people can so easily hate summoners for their ability to summon and control monsters.”

I motioned her over to kneel next to me, holding her hand as I held it out for the beast to sniff. Once it rubbed against her fingers I guided it to the creatures head, helping her pet it a few times before letting go. She continued to stroke the monster as it rubbed up against her, twining around her legs like any normal cat.

“Cassilions are very loveable and loyal for the most part, but they still retain much of the cat mentality they are descended from. They can go feral, they can eat anything a cat can, and they are still fierce protectors and fighters. Once they enter into a contract they are bonded for life. They will protect their companion with everything they have. Before, only Hunter’s could make these bonds. Now though, anyone can if the Cassilion accepts the person. Would you like to make a contract with him? If you do he will never leave you and he will fight for you faithfully. Just treat him like a regular cat and you will be fine.”

“Do… do you think he would accept me?”

“Ask him. He is quite intelligent and he understands human speech even if he can’t speak it. Hold out your hand palm up while you ask.”

She did as I instructed as the monster stopped rubbing against her to stare into her eyes.

“Um. Mr. Cassilion? Do you want to be friends with me?”

I saw the yellow cat eyes glow slightly, giving off a small flash of light as they watched her. Finally it lowered its head and nipped her pointing finger, drawing a single spot of blood. It’s tongue darted out to lap up the spot, healing the puncture in the process. The yellow eyes flashed again, settling into the same crimson color as the girls. Proof that they had bonded. Asala got a slightly slack jawed look for a moment before a foolish grin split her face.

“She says her name is Memoeth but I can call her Meme for short. She’s talking in my head!”

“And only you can hear her. That is part of the sacred bond you now share. How old is she?”

Asala was silent a moment before answering.

“She says she is only two years old.”

“Ah, that’s good. The two of you can grow into your powers together. If she had been much older she would not have been able to use your power as effectively.”

Just then yet another summoning portal opened and a large four foot tall brown hairy spider climbed out. Even as I started pulling a sword and pistol from behind my back the Cassilion expanded in size as it leapt towards the monster. By the time it brought it’s paw around it had grown to be six feet tall. With a single strike it severed four of the legs before twisting and smashing it’s tail into the body. The spider was slammed to the ground moments before the Cassilion’s teeth sank into it. The spider monster burst into dust to float away into nothing while the Cassilion shrank back down to normal size again.

“And that is why they made great Hunter companions. I’m sure she has a few more tricks up her sleeve, but you can trust you are in good hands, or I should say paws. Come on, let’s get back to the house and see about finding a nice treat for Meme as thanks for her hard work today.”

As we started walking towards the house again Asala giggled a bit at something only she heard. I had a feeling her new companion would help her recover faster than I could alone. Or at least speed up the process. As I pulled the girl into my side with a one handed hug the Cassilion’s wings shrunk and folded against it’s body to be hidden by the black fur. The way it walked along beside her made you think it really was a regular cat.

That is of course until it turned its head to wink a single crimson orb at me.
1111211121111212.title: Eat at home

11112111211112121.content:
“Hand me that pepper would you?”

I pointed at the spice with a finger, causing Asala to run over and pick it up. She was back at my side in seconds holding out the shaker with a grin. I simply shook my head before pointing at the pan of meat I was cooking.

“Sprinkle it on yourself. Not a lot though, just enough to give it a little bit of a bite.”

As she began shaking out some of the pepper Meme jumped onto the counter next to the stove and snagged a small piece of beef crumb with a claw before hopping away again. Asala giggled at whatever the creature said in her mind as I continued to point out spices for her to add. Once the meat was cooked and drained I showed her how to stuff the peppers before having her help me make six of them. Once the meal was in the oven to cook for the next ten minutes, I grabbed a few homemade cookies from the refrigerator for her to snack on.

“People say having desert or sweets before eating will ruin your appetite. But you know what, I don’t believe that. One or two sweets won’t hurt any.”

Asala sat at the table munching on the cookies happily as Meme jumped onto her lap. Asala began to absently pet the monster as I cleaned the few dishes we had dirtied.

“Mommy used to let me help her cook too sometimes. But daddy never cooked.”

“What did they do?”

“Mommy stayed at home most of the time but she did odd jobs helping people sometimes. Daddy worked with wood. He made furniture and carved designs into it to make it look all pretty.”

I sat down across from her as the Cassilion stood up on her lap to lick the few tears running down her cheeks, causing the girl to hug the cat in comfort.

“You don’t need to push yourself if you don’t want to.”

She shook her head back and forth as she squeezed the cat again.

“No, I want to. Meme says you are only trying to help me and that I should answer. She says she will share my pain with me because she is my partner.”

After that Asala began telling me about her parents and her life before this while holding onto the monster in her lap. I simply sat and listened until the buzzer went off to let us know the peppers were done. I could only assume the Cassilion was talking to her in her mind, doing much of my work for me. Asala seemed to enjoy the food as we ate, grinning a bit foolishly as she fed bits of it to the beast who had jumped to the floor next to her.

“Meme says when I become stronger I will be able to summon other monsters she can use to transform into different forms. Is that true?”

“Well I really wouldn’t know first hand. I’ve heard tales of such things of course, but if she said so I would say it is true.”

She got another far off look as a slow smile spread across her lips. With Meme around I didn’t have to worry about her going back into her comatose like state. I would still have random monsters to deal with but I could handle it. So could Meme if it wasn’t too strong.

Once dinner was over I told her to go get a bath and clean up. She didn’t put up a fuss, simply nodded her head before grabbing out a change of clothes from the bags still sitting on the floor by the doorway. I heard her pattering feet as she ran upstairs and then the water echoing through the pipes as she turned the knobs. After a moment I heard the unmistakable meow of surprise and faint laughter. In my mind’s eye I could see Asala splashing a bit of water on the cat playfully. Cassilions, like normal cats, were not fond of water.

I finished cleaning the dishes before going into the living room, settling onto the couch after picking up the newest issue of Swords and Sorcery. The house creaked and settled like it always did, but that empty feeling wasn’t there at the moment. It was as if the house knew there was someone aside from myself inside of it right now. It had been three years since the house had last felt like this. It made me think back on all I had missed out on and all I had lost, making it almost impossible to pay attention to the articles in the magazine.

“You’re always lonely aren’t you big brother?”

I looked over to where Asala was walking into the room rubbing her eyes sleepily. She wore some light pink pajamas with cats printed on it that she herself had picked out earlier. The Cassilion padded silently next to her as she crawled onto the couch and under my arm to snuggle against me.

“Why do you say that?”

“Because there is only enough for one person everywhere. Meme says yours is the only smell that’s in the house. There are faint traces of others but they don’t coat everything like yours does.”

“Yes, I pretty much live her by myself. I have for a very long time. My family life is really complicated, but it boils down to my parents never sticking around for very long. Big sis lives by herself, even though she works almost as much as my parents do so her house is usually empty as well. She does come over every once in a while to visit but for the most part it’s just me.”

“I won’t let you be lonely while I’m here.”

She wrapped her arms around me even tighter as she settled more comfortably into the crook by my side.

“I’m still lonely too since mommy and daddy… since they died.”

She began to cry then as she buried her face in my tunic. I pulled her into a tight embrace as I let her cry herself to sleep. Meme jumped into my lap as her breathing began to even out and the exhaustion of being kept awake for three days by magic overcame her. The monster looked up at me with a knowing gaze before giving me a small head bow and curling up right where she was. I absently stroked the cat monster with my free hand the same way I stroked the girls hair.

“You make sure to protect her well Meme. I already know you will but I have a feeling this girl is special. Well more special than simply being a summoner. She is going to need your help in more than just protection, she is going to need you for support as well. The two of you have a long road ahead of you and it’s not going to be easy. I hope you know what you are getting into.”

The monster let out a soft meow before nipping my finger as if to say I didn’t need to tell her what she already knew. With a chuckle I went back to scratching behind her ears while she stretched out a bit.

“All right, all right I hear you. I won’t say anymore. But if she ever needs any help, you make sure to come find me all right? I’ll drop everything to answer such a call. After all that’s what family is supposed to do right?”

The girl let out a small mumble as the Cassilion began to purr contentedly. I couldn’t help but chuckle one more time as I continued to pet them both.

*******

What knowledge might you have gained if you had gone down another path? What tidbit of information would have popped up? Would such information make the things you have learned mean something else? Would it have made you change your mind on what decision you would have made earlier?

No one can know everything at once. Not unless they are like me, able to see every possibility. But then they would not really be considered human anymore would they? Humans choose the path they think is best, they do not know information they do not have. That is why they regret after the fact. It is why they seem to believe curiosity is one of the greatest traits. Though admittedly I have found many people do not like those who are curious. Seeking to profess knowledge is a good thing while keeping secret everything they possibly can. Truly you humans are fascinating creatures.

But I digress. Such musing is for my benefit alone. Neither here nor there. Come again traveler if you wish and see what else the day holds. See what new information you can glean and see if it changes your outlook or your choices.
11112111211112121.title: Into the house

111121112112.content:
“As much as I am tempted, I think I need to assess the skills of everyone here. These are the people I need to trust with my back after all. I want to know exactly what they can and cannot do in case the proverbial Yeti skat hit’s the fan. Perhaps next time though.”

She gave a shrug while sitting down next to me to watch the two combat floors that came into existence when the teacher raised a wall cutting the main floor in half. I really did want to spar with her, but I also had a feeling she was playing at some game of her own. I wasn’t afraid of her, even if I had almost killed her a little over an hour ago. Sometimes, that was just Hunter politics at work, a cutthroat world on the inside while civilians on the outside thought us shining heroes of justice.

Not that we weren’t by and large heroes upholding honorable ideals, but as with most things, the truth was rarely so glamorous. If she was plotting to retaliate against me she was welcome to try. I wasn’t about to let my guard down anytime soon. Being born a Zelkov had taught me to never let my guard drop, if I did I was taken advantage of or hurt in some way. So while the two of us watched the groups down below fighting some mid level D class monsters in silence, I kept an eye on her covertly.

“You don’t need to worry about retaliation you know, you were right to give me a bit of a wake up call like that.”

“I don’t know what you are talking about.”

“Don’t play dumb. I might not be a tenth generation Hunter like you but even I have eyes. My parents trained me well enough to read body language and notice the covert stares you are sending my way. You’re probably thinking along the lines of I must be plotting something to get back at you for stabbing me.”

“Are you?”

“No. You want me to?”

“No.”

“All right then. A Hunter should be alert and aware of their surroundings at all times. Even when they are bored to tears. I’d had that fact pounded into me but I forgot it while being forced to go to school here. I got lax and you got the drop on me. Granted you might still have been able to get the drop on me, I don’t know, but it wouldn’t have been that easy if I had been paying attention like I was supposed to. My brother would have done the same as you and called it a warning.”

“So you expect me to suddenly trust you?”

“Of course not, you don’t strike me as being that stupid. Just wanted to let you know I wasn’t planning anything.”

The first groups finally defeated their monsters and two more groups of four took their place, going up against some Sanderlings’, giant worm creatures whose mouths were covered by three flaps of skin most of the time. They had flimsy membrane wings that unfolded from their body to flap and create small whirlwinds, even allowing them to glide in the right environments. They were like the illegitimate step children of Sandworms and Slag Wyvern’s. The groups should have no problems if they were around the same skill level as the last two. As long as they kept their heads and worked together they would be fine.

“So then what is your game? Why you sitting next to me like we are friends or something?”

“No game. Though I suppose I wouldn’t mind if we were friends. I’m just looking for some company. Someone who knows what I am talking about and understands the hassles of being from an older family. You know, like the first monster you slew alone, or how everyone thinks being from an old family is some sort of instant access to the big leagues. When I talk about the first heart crystal I earned and the different phases of my favorite weapon I don’t want to be met by the blank stares the rest of the class gives me. Or that uneasy look in their eye when I talk about Hunter stuff.”

She let out a sigh, pulling her foot up onto the bleacher and wrapping her arms around her knee. She let her gaze wander down to the floor where one of the two groups fighting the Sanderlings’ were rolling out of the way of a sand tornado it sent their way before coming up throwing magic in it’s direction.

“The girls just want to talk about boys or jewelry or the hottest clothes and the guys just ogle your breasts while whispering about girls. You can tell they usually have only one thing on their mind. They pass around porn magazines and I know they have some sort of secret ranking system for all the girls in the class and the school. They aren’t really behaving or thinking like Hunter’s most of the time. They get serious about the lessons, but they don’t take anything else seriously. They haven’t figured out that being a Hunter is more than just learning the book stuff, that’s why they find it hard to understand me. But I don’t think you would have that problem.”

“Well I guess I’ve got no problem with that. You make a valid argument and truth be told I’d probably get bored to tears over such useless chatter as well. I don’t mind talking to you like this. Doesn’t mean I trust you yet though, but I’ll give you the benefit of the doubt.”

She grinned at me as she reached out to shake my extended hand. I had to wonder if this was how people made friends. I really had no experience in this kind of thing, I just knew how to deal with people on a business basis. I knew the niceties and courtesies you were supposed to say, but it was all impersonal for the most part. Before I knew it most of them were friends or acquaintances. But people my own age? I was completely clueless as to how to handle them for the most part. Especially when they seemed to be the ones that got on my nerves the most.

The two groups killed their Sanderlings’ and one group even got a wing for their trouble. They carried the prize out like it was worth a few thousand Reuls, pumping it into the air excitedly. The truth was it would probably sell for maybe eighty Knutz, netting them all a whopping twenty each. Enough to buy them a nice shirt or two if they were on sale. Then again this might be the first time anything ever dropped for them from a monster. At least it wasn’t completely worthless and they would get something from it. I’d gotten a few drops that weren’t even worth a handful of red Senz coins.

The last group to go out went up against a Glif so I knew these five had to be a step up from the rest of the class since the monster was a low to mid range C class. I recognized Gregory and Lilia by name and one of the other boys as the one who had been with Gregory by sight but not any of the other’s. Liz nodded her head slightly at the match up.

“Yeah that’s about right for their skill levels. Gregory, the one with the guns is a bit of an ego tripper, but I’ll admit he has some skill with his dual guns. Daniel, the hand specialist is also pretty good. Probably one of the best in this class excluding us of course.”

She pointed at the brown head of the boy who had been with Gregory, giving me a name to a face. I made sure to commit it to memory. She then pointed at the tank of the group, a boy wearing full plate armor and wielding a giant templar’s shield like a toy.

“Jethic is a beast of a tank. He’s a natural and out of all of them he is the one I would want shielding me in a crisis. What he lacks in magical power he makes up for in pure strength and determination. A few weeks ago him and Marsa, the caster of the group, took on a small goblin horde. You know the whole few versus many idea? Goblins might be weak D class monster’s but enough can overrun even the best Hunter. Anyways, he charged in there and grabbed agro on all of them like a champ. Marsa was able to go wild with her spells and they didn’t even look at her once. It’s like some sort of trigger gets turned on in his head when he sees a monster. And Lilia is a decent healer. They all need more training of course, but I’ll freely admit they are the best of the lot.”

Even as she finished saying that Jethic ran forward to bash his shield into the unprotected right side of the creature. When it brought its right fist around he stabbed upwards with his short sword before launching into the air and flipping over the fist. His sword which had sunk a few inches into the flesh cut a huge gash in the creatures underarm as the boy’s feet landed on the seven foot tall giant’s shoulder. He brought his right arm up again, catching the creature under the chin with the thin edge of his shield, causing blood to spray out of the mouth even as it toppled backwards.

The boy had already twisted and planted his shield by the time the Glif spun back to it’s feet, attempting a leg sweep in the process. The monster was like a hand-to-hand fighter. It was resistant to magic like all sub classes of giant were and it had a fast healing ability until after it came out of second phase. But it’s fighting skills were just a pale imitation of a real fighters since the skill had been implanted in them by a mage long ago in an attempt to turn them into a fighting force. An attempt that ultimately backfired, but the knowledge was then subsequently passed down to each new generation.

The beast attacked Jethic with a flurry of blows which the boy took on his shield without moving. It totally ignored the other four who were pounding away on it from behind. Even as fireballs crashed into it and set it’s fine hair on fire. After a few moments it did a few back flips before putting up its dukes and motioning the group to attack. This was it’s second phase, meaning it was almost dead. Any external spells cast would be sucked up by the monster and sent back at the caster. Any physical attack would be blocked and countered. But it wouldn’t actually do anything for these next three minutes.

Even as the group began to gather together to wait out the beast, I saw Gregory lifting one of his dual pistol's and knew in my gut he was about to do something stupid.
111121112112.title: Observe

1111211121121.content:
As he fired his gun, Jethic was suddenly between him and the monster, the bullet pinging harmlessly off the shield. Even from here I could hear the tank’s angry words.

“You’re supposed to be the leader of the group today so act like it! Did you forget what the teacher told us? Do you want to have it come chasing after you right now? Put your balls back in your pant’s and quit ego trippin’. This ain’t a macho game here! If you want to fire that weapon again be my guest, but I’m not going to lift a finger to help. I’ll let it pound the snot out of you and then Lilia can heal you up after we finish killing it. If you are still alive after it get’s through with you that is!”

Jethic moved out of the way, returning to the group and planting his shield on the ground defiantly while spreading his legs and waiting for the beast to lower it’s hands like an immovable brick wall. Gregory looked from Jethic to the monster and then at the rest of the group before lowering his weapon and going to join the others.

“That’s Gregory for you. Told you he has an ego. First time I saw Jethic step up like that though. Must have finally got tired of putting up with Gregory’s crap and having to help clean up afterwards. Can’t say I blame him though, almost every time they work together Gregory does something stupid to make the fight a tad bit harder. At least he didn’t try casting a spell or something. Worst that would have happen in this case was the Glif would have countered and Jethic would have taken it on his shield.”

The beast finally lowered it’s fists and charged again. Jethic waited a moment before sending out a wave of magical energy like a fog that wrapped around the monster’s head. As the others spread out a bit.

“Nice use of a provoking sight. Good time to use it too.”

Liz nodded absently even as the monster began swinging wildly with both hands, the booming of it’s knuckles on the shield could be heard even from where I was. But Jethic didn’t budge an inch, shifting his shoulder into the shield and anchoring his leg behind him. Daniel came in from the side as Marsa cast a spell that made flames lick around his fists like gloves. This was a second tier fire spell, the power of magma, burning at least a hundred degrees hotter then the tier one version.

Daniel began swinging just as wildly, only his blows were controlled and focused on one spot. Faster and faster they went until his fists were a blur and hitting with the speed of jackhammers. The skin at the small of the beasts back suddenly split wide open like some grape that got squeezed too hard. Daniel spun out of the way as Lilia sent some divine power to wrap around Gregory’s two gun’s second before he shoved them into the gaping hole and fired. The beast bulged outwards like a balloon for a second before a hole exploded out from his chest showering the shield with blue blood and bone fragments.

The beast blinked a moment, not yet realizing it was dead before crumpling to the ground. Even as it hit the floor it began to break up into little white motes of energy that disappeared into the air.

“You ever wonder why monster’s do that? Just disintegrate like that I mean. Why don’t their bodies stick around? Where do those white motes go and what are they?”

I shook my head absently at Liz’s question while watching the five cheering like the other groups had. Well four of them were cheering together, I could see Gregory was being left out of the celebration.

“Nope never wondered about it. That’s just the way things are. They wouldn’t be monster’s if they didn’t die that way right? It’s magic. Perhaps those white motes are where our magic comes from. If we stopped killing monster’s would we lose our magic abilities? Such question’s aren’t for me. I leave that kind of thing to the scientist and theorist who would be happy to spend a month on just that one question. If it was important for us to know such things those answers would have been found already and been taught to us.”

As the first two groups went back onto the field to face off against two new D class monsters I was shocked to see my father walking into the room with a little girl in tow. Her crimson eyes and white hair stood out like a sore thumb against the lime green dress she wore. Her outfit making her pale white skin seem even paler. I was already making my way down to the side floor as he headed for the teacher. By the time I got there my father was just finishing his whispered conversation and the teacher was motioning for me.

“Your father wants to speak with you Zelkov. You can use one of the locker rooms if you want.”

My father shook his head slightly, saying that this might take a while and he wouldn’t hold up the class. With a nod of the head the Arena Master turned his attention back to the two groups as me and my father left the room. I glanced over at him as we walked, seeing the black circles under his eyes and a few more wrinkles on his sun tanned face. It had only been a month since I last saw him but I was sure there were a few more strands of gray sprinkling his black hair. He wore a simple blue pullover shirt that accentuated his lean frame and baggy black pants I knew hid powerful legs.

“So how are you son? I haven’t seen you in a while.”

“Same old, same old. I thought you were still taking care of that Sandworm infestation.”

“I was. Got some unexpected help though, seems another Hunter had been contracted for the same job and we ended up meeting during the extermination. Was able to clear it out with his help a lot sooner than expected. We agreed to split the profits, a fact that he was grateful for since honestly he wasn’t exactly up to dealing with it alone. I think he was trying to make a name for himself or he was hard up for money, that’s why he took the job in the first place.”

We both fell silent then, neither one of us really knowing what to say. I was on better terms with my father than with my mother but he was still little more than a stranger to me. We rarely saw each other, since like my mother, he was always out on one job or another. Coming home once, maybe twice a month if I was lucky. It was almost a special holiday when both my parents were home at the same time. But as always, they rarely stayed more than twelve hours before they were off again. I tried to remember the last time either one of them had been home for my birthday or one of the many holidays like Thanksgiving or Christmas and failed. But that was just how my life was, one solitude filled day after another.

He led me to a room that looked like it was used for student council meetings. A single bookshelf with some tomes in it, a table with six chairs scattered around and a single window looking out on a running track. He offered me a seat and I took it while he gently guided the girl to another one pushing her into it lightly. The only reason I knew she wasn’t some lifelike doll was the slight rise and fall of her chest and the miniscule movements as her fingers squeezed the teddy bear she was holding to her chest.

“So what’s this about?”

“I was hoping you could take this girl for a few days. Your mother has been taking care of her the last three days since her parents died. But she is going to be heading off to Bornica on another job and I will be going with her to help so neither of us can guard her. She’s special. You see her parent’s were actually murdered, assassinated in front of her. Because of that her powers as a monster summoner manifested. Now she can’t control them and she has hidden inside herself as you can see. As far as they can tell, her powers trigger more often when she gets emotional, so in a way her retreating inside herself has slowed it down a bit.”

“So if mother was taking care of her then why are you here? Shouldn’t she be the one to ask me to do this?”

“Just between you and me? I think she didn’t want to get into another argument with you. I think she might have been afraid you wouldn’t be able to objectively look at the problem and would refuse the job simply to spite her. Plus we both know she’s not good with kids, I think she was uncomfortable with the girl as well.”

“I take it there is someone else coming to pick her up in a few days?”

“Yes a summoner your mother knows.”

“And I bet she would prefer this to be under the table.”

“If possible.”

“You know this is a real putnak move on her part don’t you? Using you instead of coming to face me herself. Not to mention asking me to do a high level Hunter job while not wanting me to take the Exams.”

“I know. I really don’t fully agree with it either but it is what it is.”

I nibbled on my thumbnail as I looked at the girl for a little bit. Watching as my father absently put his hand on top of her head. He sucked at being a father, but at least he wasn’t as bad with children as my mother was.

“Four thousand Reul. That will mainly cover expenses and a little extra for me. That’s on top of my regular living allowance of course. As much as I hate to admit it, her ploy to send you worked. I don’t have that small urge to drive a harder bargain and am willing to do this more as a favor than a job.”

“Thanks Riktal.”

“Yeah, yeah. Don’t get used to this though. I’m in a good mood today.”

My father gave me a lopsided grin as he chuckled a bit.

“You sound like that’s a rare occurrence.”
1111211121121.title: Continue to watch

11112111211211.content:
I didn’t even bother to try and sweeten my words since it was just the unvarnished truth. I usually wasn’t in a good mood too often, merely a state of neutrality at best. My father didn’t seem to know how to respond to that so simply kept his mouth shut. At least he wouldn’t try say something in an attempt to disagree with me like my mother would have. He knew as well as I that he didn’t know much about me at all so couldn’t deny or confirm the truth of my words.

“So is their anything else mother wanted you to try and get out of me?”

“Yeah there was actually. She wanted you to continue to go to school while you are protecting her.”

“Is she mad! You know how little love most people have for summoners! What if someone in this school found out! Within the hour I would have just about everyone after her!”

“I know that son. That’s why I’m going to tell her you bargained with me to get the next few days off until she get’s taken off your hands. If you really feel it safe to bring her to school then you are more than welcome too, but I wouldn’t bring her either. I’ll be letting them know in the office, so you can leave once this meeting is over. And just for the record, I didn’t agree with your mother’s idea to send you to this school. It was my opinion that you should be able to take the Exams. But in the end your mother won out.”

“Well at least one of you believed in me and my strength I take it you will be leaving soon?”

“A little later on today actually. Your mother is in town gathering some things at the moment. We will probably be gone for about a week, maybe two. But after that I’d really like to stay home and spend a little time with you if that’s possible. Maybe go fishing or something.”

“We’ve never gone fishing before.”

“First time for everything right? I know I’m not a very good father, but I thought it was high time I at least tried to be something resembling one.”

“I’ll have to see if I have time in my busy schedule. But I might be able to work you in for something like that.”

He gave me a smile as he pushed his chair back and stood up. He nodded his head slightly to the side before heading towards the door.

“I suppose that’s the best I can hope for. I guess you’ve got a life too now. It was good seeing you again son. I’ll leave you to work your magic with the girl, I know you will be able to help her more than I can.”

“Be safe dad. Don’t let any monster’s get the best of you. Oh and tell mother big sis Ulicia sends her love.”

“But not you?”

“No.”

He looked at me with slightly sad eyes before nodding slowly and closing the door behind him. Once he was gone I walked around the table to sit next to the little girl, giving her hair a small stroke as I smiled at her.

“You can quit playing the whole deaf and dumb game if you want. I’ve been watching your fingers twitching and squeezing that bear the whole time we were talking so I know you could hear what we were saying. I’m not going to force you to talk though, since I really don’t blame you for running away inside your head. I have a cousin that’s mute you know. He was in a bad accident when he was really young and lost the use of his voice. I used to spend a lot of time with him when I was younger, so we came up with a way of communicating using only our hands and body language. He could have written everything down but where’s the fun in that?”

I waggled my eyes while letting my tongue pass in and out through puckered lips quickly like a lizards in front of her face.

“That was our way of saying we wanted to talk privately. Though admittedly one of us usually ended up cracking up into laughing fits since the other usually also added weird faces into the mix.”

I saw her lip twitch just a fraction at the face I had made and knew my bet had paid off. Even if she didn’t look it, I couldn’t imagine that she had blocked all her senses off to be truly blind to the world.

“You know what? I don’t even know your name! Hmm you look like a Suzy. No, a Paladias. Wait no, Paladias was the name of a dog I once knew, doesn’t really seem fit for a human now does it? Hmm, you aren’t one of those strange ones with a guy’s name like Jack are you? Or one of those pretentious ones that use stage names like Tootsie Roll or Candy Cane I hope.”

She finally let a little giggle escape her lips while letting a small smile touch her face and shaking her head. It was that point I knew I had won at least a little bit of her trust. I had gotten through that small wall she had put up against the world and been allowed into her little bubble. Even if I wasn’t allowed access to the secret places in her heart yet this was a start.

“Well what is it then? I could teach you the alphabet me and my cousin came up with but that would take time.”

She slowly raised her right hand and began spelling out letters on the tabletop. A-S-A-L-A. I grinned even more as I stroked her hair.

“That’s a very pretty name. I bet your voice is just as pretty. I hope to hear it sometime. That is if you can speak.”

Just then there was a knock on the door and my father came back into the room quickly.

“Oh son, I almost forgot to tell you the most important parts. Her name is..”

“Asala.”

“How’d you know that?”

The little girl turned her head as I pointed at her and told him she had told me herself. He had a small look of surprise on his face before shaking his head with a half grin.

“I suppose I shouldn’t be too surprised. You always did have a way with kids. Your mother also said they have been sustaining her with doses of magic since she refused to eat or sleep. I guess that is a little moot as well with you looking after her. You’ll get her body back into equalibrium again.”
