He reached behind him for a moment, picking something up off the floor outside before plopping my duffle bag down just inside the door.

“I took the liberty of grabbing this for you. I didn’t think you would want to expose her to more danger than you had to right now.”

“Thanks dad.”

He gave me another nod before looking at Asala with a small smile.

“You’ve got nothing to worry about. My son is good at his job. He is as good if not better than many Hunter’s I know. What he lacks in experience he makes up for in smarts. Plus he has no problem with people like you. Those with special abilities that is. Don‘t know where he gets it from because I‘ll admit, I can‘t see it the same way. I‘ve had my ups and downs with summoners and puppeteers and a few other unique abilities like corpse jumpers. I‘ve learned to live with and tolerate them but I just can‘t quite trust them anymore like he can.”

Asala smiled tentatively at my father moments before a small red circle began to appear on the table top in front of us. She whimpered a bit in fear even as I absently lifted my fist and pounded it down on the small head beginning to emerge like a hammer hitting a nail. The Gremlin toppled back through the hole and it closed up again a second later. The whole time I never let the smile drop form my face as Asala watched the summoning circle.

“If that’s all you got then I really don’t have anything to worry about. Though if you bring out something really big and scary I guess I’ll have to actually do some work for a change huh? But no matter how big and scary it is I’ll send it back where it came from just like I did that little beastie.”

My father gave me another farewell and left again even as I stood up dusting invisible dirt off my pants.

“So Asala, what do you say about going out and doing a little shopping? Because quite honestly, that dress is making my eyes want to go blind from looking at it. But you see, the thing is, I’m not really all that good with this fashion stuff. I wouldn’t know where to start. So it’s going to be up to you to pick out your own dresses and shoes. Perhaps even a few pieces of jewelry to go with them. Think you can handle that?”

She nodded her head up and down as I offered her my hand and she took it. I stopped for only a moment to shrug my bag onto my back so it was out of the way before heading out the door and towards the entrance. Asala stuck close to me, moving in even closer once we were out on the street and heading towards town. I simply gave her silent support by squeezing her hand gently to let her know I was there. Between that and the way she crushed the teddy bear to her chest, she seemed to gain more confidence.

Every so often I noticed her looking up at me covertly, her thoughts a complete mystery to me. But the only thing she ever saw was the constant smile of contentment and the aura of comfort I tried to give off while staring straight ahead. At those times I would see a smile curve her lips, as if she had been seeking reassurance and had found it.
11112111211211.title: "It is."

111121112112111.content:
“If I had known you would spend that much I would have asked for more money! What is it with girls and shopping anyway? Is it like some secret gene you are born with?”

She grinned at me over her bowl of beef stew from across the table. After two hours of shopping and her acting like the proverbial kid in a candy store she was sporting a new canary yellow dress that still looked a bit eye watering but she seemed to like. She hadn’t said a word, simply laughed and giggled a few times. Though she was free with her smiles if nothing else.

That wasn’t to say she had forgotten about her grief for her parents. Those emotions were still written all over her face. But I had tried hard to make her push them to the side for now in a careful attempt to show her there were still good things in this world that she was allowed to appreciate. That just because the people she loved the most in the world were dead didn’t mean there was nothing left. I had learned that lesson the hard way without anyone else helping me. No, there had been one person, but I hadn’t allowed her to help for the longest time.

As we ate our meal I taught her a few more simple hand signs and motions of the secret language me and my cousin had come up with. Everything from a simple please and thank you to asking how are you. This unique way of talking seemed to amuse her, making her focus on learning and mastering it. I lost track of time as the two of us sat there, my duffle bag and her shopping bags on the floor and the seat next to us. When the clock tower outside rang six o’clock I started in surprise, realizing we had been at this for almost three hours while absently eating sweets.

Finishing off the drink in front of me I began gathering our stuff while motioning for Asala to follow me. Even though she couldn’t hold my hand because my own were full, she stuck close, grabbing onto my tunic with her left hand.

“Hey Asala, I’d like you to meet someone before we go home ok? Think you are up for a bit of a walk?”

When she gave me another nod of affirmation I headed off down the street deeper into the city. We wouldn’t exactly be going to the far side of town, but it was slightly farther than I normally went and in all honesty I didn’t always like going here. I stopped at a pastry shop to pick up a Lemon-Melon bar for only a moment before heading on my way again. After about thirty minutes of walking I turned into the graveyard, walking through all the neat rows of tombstones until I found the one in the back I wanted. Kneeling in front of the grave I bowed my head and gave a short prayer to The One God before standing up again.

“Asala I’d like you to meet Olia Zelkov, my little sister. She’d be fourteen now if she hadn’t died. Three years ago I failed to protect her like a big brother should and because of that she paid the price. She was a bit of a crybaby but I loved her dearly. Almost like she was my own child instead of my sister. When she died… when she died I felt a part of myself had been ripped out. As if I would fall into this bottomless hole and never be able to climb out.”

Softly I rubbed the top of the granite monument, feeling my eyes moisten up and my vision go a bit blurry.

“At the time I was alone. Or at least, I thought I was alone. My parents mourned for a few days, but then they were running off to some foreign country overseas acting like they were over it. As if it had never happened. As if her life had meant nothing! My mother burned all of her stuff. Every picture, every stuffed animal, every stitch of fabric she had ever worn or used. But through great effort I saved a few things. A few precious animals and pictures. But what I saved was only a fraction of the memories she had left behind to prove she had been alive.

“I’m not ashamed to say there were nights I cried myself to sleep. Nights where I just wanted to end it all. Even nights where I wanted to rampage around destroying everything. I saw nothing good in the world. Nothing to make living have any meaning if I kept going. That’s how deep into my own pain and despair I was.”

Squatting down I traced the letters engraved down the tombstones sides. Originally there had only been her name, date of birth and the day she died chiseled in. But the grave had seemed too impersonal to me that way. She had deserved better than what she had gotten. So I had carved these words out with my power. Every jagged edge, every curve, every extra word had been my farewell to her.

For the little girl who always dreamed big, may this sleep try to contain them.

“I was finally helped out of my darkness by someone I was proud to call a friend. She was a monster summoner like you. But back then I was like everyone else, blindly hating and fearing that which I didn’t understand. Yet still she helped me find myself again. At no little danger to herself I might add. She showed me how I could keep living on despite my loss.”

“Who was she?”

The voice was soft and sweet, almost musical. I could hear the sadness in the words even as I saw the tears in Asala’s eyes. I got to my feet and went to the grave on the right before pulling out the sickly sweet pastry, unwrapping it and placing it at the base of the marker. My finger’s traced the words engraved there.

To a loving daughter who’s caring knew no bounds. The world is a darker place for your loss.

Below those words were engraved a more personal note from me to her.

To the first girl I loved, you will forever live on in every breath I take. Your deeds shall never be forgotten.

“Her name was Siera. Siera Masanafill. She died protecting me. Took a giant’s club that was meant for me full in the stomach after pushing me out of the way. I tried to get her to a hospital or a priest as fast as I could. I really did. But it was too late, she died before they could do anything. I lost her a year after I lost Olia. Almost to the day.”

I felt the snot running down my nose and the tears flowing down my cheers, letting them free reign.

“She loved sweet things. The sweeter the better. Sometimes I thought her teeth would instantly rot out of her mouth because of how sweet the candy was. It hurts Asala. Even now it still hurts. But it does get better over time. That pain inside is like a big gapping open wound. Time heals it, but it will continue to ache, continue to make you feel like it is still fresh. Memories of them, both good and the bad, keep them alive and help you deal with that pain. I know how you feel right now, but I can help you if you let me. Just like Siera helped me once I let her.

“I’m not asking you to forget your parents, or telling you everything will be all right. Because the truth is, for a while it won’t be. Nightmares, regrets, the desire to die yourself, wanting to curl into a ball and not get out of bed. They will all be there at some point. Even if things are good like they were today, it won’t last forever. Sometimes that sorrow will creep in and taint even the happiest moments for you. But it’s how you handle these things that’s important. Do you allow them to take over, living in the past, regretting everything and wasting your life away? Or do you stand up, look forward, and begin to move despite all of that?”

I turned to look at her in time for the four foot six inch frame to slam into me, wrapping her arms around my neck and bawling her eyes out. I embraced her as well as I stroked her hair gently.

“You’ll get lost along the way, you will backtrack and second guess your decision. But you will grow strong. You will grow confident. But most of all you will live. You will appreciate life and you will recognize how precious it is. You are a monster summoner now whether you like it or not. With your power you can hurt millions of people if you want to. And if you remain stuck in the past, that’s probably what will happen as your pain and hurt controls your power. But if you walk forward with your head held high it will be you who controls that power and not your pain. And you who decides how it will be used. Running away into your head won’t give you that kind of control, it only lets the pain take over. I’m no expert on this kind of stuff, but that’s what I believe.”

She cried herself to sleep in my arms there in the graveyard while I offered her what comfort I could. Gathering her light frame up, I levitated the bags around me with a bit of magic. I took a few steps away on my way home before turning and looking a the two graves.

“Sleep well little sisters.”

********

Strength comes from the oddest places and affects people in different ways. Not just the path they take but the way they interact with others as well. This I have found while observing you humans. You put much stock in strength, throwing the word around almost casually sometimes. But I have to wonder, when you say strength, do you sometimes mean character? Moral dilemmas put a test to these strengths I have found. And sometimes those dilemmas aren’t even all that great. Sometimes it comes from something as simple as telling a group of strangers your last name or not.

Would this day have turned out like it had if you had simply told the class your full name from the start? What series of events, thoughts, and or actions led up to this outcome? Did the shock of learning who he really was when they did have anything to do with it? Would they have not had certain thoughts or desires pop into their mind at just the right time if they had not been surprised by the revelation? Would the one known as Gregory have rummaged through his bag if he had known who’s bag it was to begin with? And if he hadn’t, would Riktal have ever met Lilia?

With such infinite possibilities for a single day, was their any point in all of this. That, my traveler, is for you to decide. Come again and explore another possibility and see how else this day may have gone.
111121112112111.title: Into town

11112111211212.content:
“Sounds like something your mother would say.”

“I really don’t take that as a compliment.”

“No I guess you wouldn’t. but at least you can say you have some good days right?”

He gave me a small smile that seemed a bit forced before lapsing into silence, not really sure of what to say. We had never really had what one would call a father-son relationship. We had played chess or some other strategy game a few times when he was home from one job or another, but on the whole he was gone just as much as my mother. Staying for twelve hours at the most before running off again to do some new mission or other. As such I was sometimes surprised to know he even remembered my name. he really didn’t know how to deal with me as his son, just as I didn’t know how to deal with him as my father. So we dealt with each other as Hunter’s, keeping our conversation mainly on business.

“So, was there anything else mother wanted you to try to get me to agree to?”

“There was. She wanted you to continue coming to school.”

“What! Do you know how crazy that is? What if someone found out about her power? I’d be fighting off the entire building within an hour!”

“I know, that’s why you drove a hard bargain. in exchange for taking the job for so little pay and doing it under the table, you got me to agree to letting you have a few days off until the girl is gone. Your mother will be mad at me for letting you skip school, but I’ll deal with it. It’s not the first time I’ve been on her bad side, and it won’t be the last.”

He let out a small chuckle at some private joke only he understood, perhaps a memory of another time he had been on mother’s bad side. He shook his head slightly before looking at the girl and then back at me suddenly.

“Oh before I forget! Her name is Asala and your mother has been dosing her with magic to keep her body functioning. From what she said, Asala here refuses to eat or sleep, just keeps staring off at nothing. I know you’re really good with kids, do you think you could help her? If she stays like this too much longer, her body will eat itself up without real nutrition and rest. It’s not something your mother asked me to ask you, it’s something I am asking.”

“Of course mother wouldn’t ask something like that. That would require her to care about someone other than herself. You know, like most other people. But don’t worry, I was already planning on it.”

“Thanks Riktal. So…. When me and your mother get done with this mission, you want to do something together? Like go fishing?”

“What’s this? Trying to act like a real father? We’ve never gone fishing before. In fact we’ve never done anything together before really.”

“I’m getting old, pushing forty you know? I’ve been thinking a lot lately and I thought perhaps it was time I try something new. I can’t make up for the past, but perhaps I can learn a few new tricks and try being a father for real instead of just on paper.”

“We’ll see. I’m pretty busy you know.”

“I suppose you are. I bet you have your own little business going around here under the table. After all I did the same when I was younger than you and had made a name for myself by the time I was your age. I told your mother you should be allowed to take the Exams but I lost the argument.”

He stood up and headed for the door, giving me a parting smile as he stood in the doorway.

“Take care son and see you in maybe a week or two.”

“You too dad. Don’t let any monster’s kill you. Also tell mother big sis Ulicia sends her love.”

“But not you?”

“You already know the answer to that one.”

He nodded his head sadly, his eyes watching me softly for a moment before his Hunter face snapped back into place and he walked out the door. I waited a moment after he left before walking around the table to sit next to the girl.

“So your name is Asala huh? It’s a pretty name. By the way I know you can at least hear me. You want to know how I know? That bear you are holding in your left hand told me so. It’s been talking to me this entire time. Or should I say the way your hand has been twitching and squeezing it this entire time told me so. You don’t believe me do you? Well then I will just be taking your bear from you.”

I slowly reached out for the bear, having no real intention of taking it, simply trying to get a reaction out of her. My ploy worked better then I expected though as her right hand shot up to quickly ensconce the bear in her grasp as she jerked away from my reaching arm. With a grin I let my fingers drop back in my lap.

“See you just proved my point. You also proved you can see what I am doing and recognize what my movements mean. Though I would like to know where you learned the trick of disconnecting yourself from your senses like that. Is it something one of your parents taught you or did you just naturally learn it by yourself? Well, no matter. It’s worked for you so far and it’s a useful skill to have. I won’t force you to come out of it, but I bet you will by the time this day is over. You should know, no one has ever won a bet against me yet.”

She didn’t react at all to my words after that first swift movement. I didn’t push her though, people dealt with grief in their own ways. That bear held great importance to her and it was part of how she was coping. Once I wasn’t actively going after her bear she returned to the near comatose state she had been in before. There were many different ways I could handle this, from a straightforward approach to a comical one. Long winded talking or only a few words spoken. I’d play this one by ear though.

So when I stood up I offered her my hand but she didn’t move or even acknowledge my presence. With a small smile I gently pulled her up by the arm and led her out the door. I stopped in on the combat arena only long enough to pick up my duffle bag from the locker before heading for the front doors.

“You and me girl, we are going to have a bit of fun right now. Buy some clothes, see some sights, meet some people, and generally make you feel like a kid. I’m not going to listen to any of your complaining either. You see, I think your problem right now is you don’t trust me. There are dozens of ways I can get you to do that. But I think you will enjoy what I have in mind.”

I glanced back to see that her only response was to tighten her grip on the bear just a fraction.
11112111211212.title: "Rare enough."

111121112112121.content:
I slipped a thousand Reul bill across the counter, making sure to look both ways to confirm we wouldn’t be overheard.

“I can count on you to deliver them to my house can’t I Shizu? Just leave the bags outside the door and close the gate once you leave.”

“You know if you were anyone else Riktal, I’d flat out refuse. We don’t do house drops because there are too many potentials for lawsuits.”

“I know.”

“But you’re you. You’ve helped us out so many times this store owes you more than one. I’ll make sure to send one of the stock boys who could use a bit of extra pay and knows how to keep his mouth shut about such things.”

“Don’t worry Shizu, this is Hunter business. If crap hit’s the fan and it comes down to your backside on the line you let me know. I’ll smooth it over, no matter how much I have to bribe to do it.”

“I’ll hold you to that.”

I grinned at the woman as I turned to leave the store, taking a last look at the five bags I had managed to buy. I hadn’t actually meant to spend that much but I had seen the spark of interest in Asala’s eyes as I held up clothes against her body before she quickly suppressed it. I might not be up on the latest fashions or what the trendy new anything was, but that didn’t mean I was totally clueless. When you simply observed people and listened with your ears more than you moved your mouth there was tons of information you picked up even if you didn’t want to. I would have normally carried the bags, but I would rather be unhindered at the moment.

Out on the street I looked around quickly, judging it to be almost three o’clock. Indeed one of the many clock towers rang out that it was three even as I thought that. We were on the east side of town, much farther than I usually went on a regular basis since it was completely opposite of where I lived. But there were things in this city that could only be found here. Things like the mini amusement park where we were headed now.

At first she didn’t react, simply allowed me to pull her along like she had been doing. But as soon as I entered the little area where they had the circus show I knew I had made the right choice. Even though the actual show was closed for the moment, I was known here so given free reign of the park whenever I wanted.

One of the clowns waved at me moments before he got shot in the face by a fire hose. He began to splutter and cough as he tried to get away. I was pretty sure this hadn’t been planned though based on the way he began to yell at the other clown afterwards. But it did elicit a small chuckle from Asala before she suppressed it. I kept my grin under wraps as I continued on to the back where I had a feeling her walls would break down completely.

“Hey Riktal! It’s been a while since I last saw you around here!”

“What’s up Mavrick?”

“Same old, same old. That girl you recommended to us is working out wonders. Took to the acrobatics like a fish to water. Tonight will actually be her first performance. After all the training she did I think she is more than ready.”

I shook the guys hand with a grin before pulling Asala forward a little. Mavrick looked every inch the cliché ringleader, with long red coat with penguin tails to the absurdly large black top hat. He even sported a curly black handlebar mustache. Coupled with his seven foot twig like frame he always seemed a bit comical to me. Mavrick took off his top hat and bowed dramatically to the little girl, showcasing his slightly balding head of black hair. I could see her grin foolishly for a moment as her eyes sparkled. Mavrick had that kind of effect on people.

“Mavrick here runs this little circus. And if he is willing I hoped he might give us a small tour of the place. Let you get an inside look at the animals and some of the things they do to practice.”

“For you, anything Riktal.”

He pulled his hat off again and reached inside. Even though the hat wasn’t all that long his arm went all the way up to the shoulder as he stuck his tongue out of the side of his mouth while a look of concentration covered his face. Finally he pulled his arm out, bringing out a whistle carved into the shape of a cat which he offered to the little girl. When she didn’t move to take it Mavrick looked at me questioningly and I shook my head slightly, telling him with my eyes not to move.

“You know we aren’t going to move on until you take the gift. If you want to see anything more that is. If not then do nothing and we will turn around right now.”

For a moment nothing happened then her hand came up and took the whistle hesitantly. I stroked her hair while grinning, telling her she was a good girl.

“So what do you want to see first?”
111121112112121.title: Fun on the town

1111211121121211.content:
“Lets start off with the clowns and magicians. That should put her in a good mood to see the rest.”

“Your wish, is my command!”

As he said this he spun around in a circle over and over until a cape popped into existence out of nowhere which he then hid himself with for only a moment. When he flung it away his ringleader outfit was gone, replaced with a flamboyant pink tutu. He looked down at himself feigning shock before covering himself with his cape again, returning to his normal wear, eliciting another giggle from Asala.

“You still doing your two-bit slight of hand Mavrick? Why don’t you leave the trickery to the professionals?”

“Hey the people who come here know we don’t use real magic in our tricks. They come because they want to be entertained and wrack their brains figuring out how we did it. Why shouldn’t the boss also have a few tricks up his sleeves for them to be confounded over? Besides, they are fun to do.”

I shook my head with a grin.

“You’re just a big kid Mavrick.”

“And don’t you forget it!”

He motioned for us to follow and we did. Though I noticed Asala was now walking under her own power instead of being dragged behind me. Her steps quickened and her head shifted from side to side as we passed some of the attractions like the strong man and the knife juggler. Tony the juggler saw Asala staring and grinned before giving her a wink, lunging forward to catch a knife handle in his teeth before juggling two more blades on the tip of the caught knife.

Asala’s eyes went wide with surprise and delight as she looked back at me open mouthed. I laughed at her look of shock as I ruffled her hair.

“I told you didn’t I? No one has ever won a bet against me. Just because you’ve come out of your shell doesn’t mean something bad will happen. Even if it does I will protect you. Just enjoy being a kid right now, deal with the rest later. Understand what I’m saying?”

She blinked a moment but finally nodded slowly as she slipped her fingers into my hand. Mavrick glanced back with a knowing look and a roguish half grin.

“Hunter business?”

“Hunter business.”

“Figured. I’ll let everyone know”

“Appreciated.”

Soon enough we came to a little makeshift circus ring where the magicians and clowns were sitting around on upturned boxes or stools around the outside. While the majority were shooting the breeze or sipping drinks, there were a few clowns going over a routine inside involving seltzer water and a hidden fire hose. It was your basic run of the mill low brow slapstick humor for the most part, but it could still be funny for all of that.

Even as we came on the group one of the magicians pulled out a deck of cards, getting another magician to pick one. By the time we were on them the first magician had the card in hand, placing a one Senz coin on the face of it for a moment before flicking it with his finger. When he showed the back of the card there was a red circle with the coins markings on it right where the coin had been on the other side. The second magician took the card and inspected it, finally admitting he was stumped, at which point both of them began to laugh.

“As you can see these are the fine backbone of our group. Everything they do is illusion and slight of hand. No matter how fantastical or mundane you may think it, they don’t use real magic to pull it off. It is a dying art form in this day and age where people are learning how to use their magic to accomplish more and more things. But that’s part of the wonder isn’t it? Knowing we are using no magic.”

Mavrick pointed at the clowns.

“And of course we got clowns. What can I say? Their clowns.”

“Hey Mavrick! Tell ‘em the truth! You only praise the magicians so highly cause you’ve got a few tricks of your own!”

“It’s true.”

Everyone began to chuckle at that because everybody knew the banter was good natured and the comical face Mavrick made when he had answered elicited such a reaction. A few of the people sitting around who had been with the circus for a while raised a hand and greeted me jovially, quickly filling in the newer ones as to who I was. After a few minutes Asala had been integrated into the group like she was a long lost friend. Within the span of fifteen minutes they had her laughing at their antics or staring fascinated as the magicians boggled her mind with their illusions.

She even got to learn a few simple slight of hand moves, such as how to make a coin seem to disappear from the palm of her hand by slipping it between her fingers at the right time. She didn’t perfect it but I could see she was having fun trying. At best she was able to half hide it between her fingers by the time we moved on. But the glow of glee that suffused her face said everything I needed to know. I could still see some signs of grief but for the most part it had taken a backseat to her excitement and wonder.

Mavrick led us to the acrobats next who were busy flying through the air on trapezes or walking on tightropes or even just contorting their body into impossible looking positions. Some of them greeted me just like the others had when they weren’t doing anything else and even offered to let Asala jump on the trampoline with them. She pleaded with me using only her eyes, still refusing to actually talk but I didn’t need to hear words to understand her. With a small shove I sent her running off to two girls in one piece suits that I knew were particularly good at what they did. Grinning at how the teddy bear flapped in the air as she ran and then refusing to put it down while bouncing up and down.

“She’s special somehow isn’t she Riktal?”

“Yep.”

“I might not got much of the mind reading power, but from what little I picked up when we met I could tell.”

“She’s like Minerva.”

“Then she is in good hands. Don’t worry like I said earlier, I’ll pass the word around. You were never here and nobody saw or heard anything. Well most of the old crew know that already, it will mainly be the new faces I have to talk to.”

“Thanks Mavrick.”

“Thanks nothing. You’ve been good to me and mine Riktal. Always looking out for us little guys. And not looking down on the few of us with unique abilities. You’re like family to us here. Well those of us that have been here a while. Don’t be such a stranger all right?”

“I’ll try.”

We both put on grins as Asala came running up breathing quickly with the edges of her lips almost touching her ears.

“Thanks for bringing me! I’m having a lot of fun!”

Her voice was soft, light and almost musical with that slightly high pitch of youth. As she stood panting I knelt in front of her, giving her head a rub.

“Your welcome Asala. But we aren’t done yet.”

Just then there was a scream above us. I looked up in time to see one of the trapeze ropes break, sending a little boy high into the air. Already there was an older woman shoving off from the opposite side in an attempt to catch him when he fell past, but I could tell she had misjudged the timing. She would be on the backswing by the time he came down and out of her reach. There was a net beneath them so ultimately he would bounce off of that. But there was still a chance he would fall wrong.

I felt my legs bunching to save him but held myself back. My duty was to protect this girl. I couldn’t leave her side that easily. What would happen if I saved the boy and left the girl open to attack? At worst the boy would break an arm or a leg and be bruised up for a while. These things happened in this kind of business after all. But I still wanted to save him.
1111211121121211.title: Clowns and Magicians

11112111211212111.content:
She’d be safe for just a few minutes. Mavrick would keep an eye on her for me. With that thought in mind I shoved off towards the trampolines. My eyes never left the boy as I jumped high into the air using a small gust of wind to throw me aloft and then another gust to shove me back down quickly. My feet hit the stretched fabric folding slightly before spring boarding me like a missile towards the boy.

Just as the woman got to the lowest point in her arc I was grabbing the boys arms. Rolling over top of him I used my own weight to shove him back down while straightening out his body. In those few seconds my back was against his as I used the back of my legs to swing his downward towards the ground first. The woman came to the highest part of her swing, grabbing the boys legs as they came in range just in time for me to let go. As the woman swung back along her arc with the boy safely in her grasp I spread my arms and legs, allowing myself to freefall until my back bounced on the net. There were cheers as the boy bounced onto the net as well a moment later.

“Look out!”

I turned my head in time to see a sandbag tied to the end of a rope swinging right for Asala’s head. I threw out a wall of wind to stop it but knew even before I let the spell leave my fingers I was going to be too late. The bag was coming too fast and I was just too far away.

Mavrick lunged forward, grabbing the girl up and carrying her out of the way, the bag missing him by millimeters. It passed so close the wind of it actually lifted his penguin tails. My wall of wind hit the bag, causing it to explode. The rope went flying into the air as a heavy fabric backdrop fell from the ceiling a short distance away to lay in a heap on the floor.

By the time I had rolled off the net back to the floor and run over to grab Asala up in a hug making calming noises, Mavrick was already yelling angrily at the stagehands who were bowing and scraping in apology.

“Sorry about that Riktal. My daughter convinced me that stage backdrops and light shows were all the rage overseas and that I should incorporate them into our acts. We still aren’t completely used to all of it yet.”

I ignored him for the moment, stroking the girls hair as she clung to me tightly shaking a little.

“Are you ok Asala?”

“You lied to me. You said you wouldn’t let anything bad happen.”

“You’re right I did say that. I got a bit careless. I let my desire to help that boy overcome my mission to protect you. I’ve got no excuses. I brought you here so you could see that you could trust me and this one little act ruined all of that.”

She looked up at me, blinking a few times as she tried to keep from crying.

“You aren’t going to deny it? Not going to say things like it won’t happen again or I’m sorry or all the things other grown ups say?”

“Seems you got me mistaken for someone else. I never said I was grown up yet. I don’t know what kind of adults you’ve dealt with but I’m a Hunter first and foremost. And a Zelkov at that. Granted my parents were pretty crappy ones and my big sister is definitely a weird one, but they taught me to own up to my mistakes. I can’t say for sure that it won’t happen again, all I can do is be on guard against letting such desires override interfering in your safety. I can say I’m sorry all I want, but that doesn’t mean I should be forgiven for my actions. Apologies aren’t really for the person wronged, it’s for a persons own desires. Because they are looking for forgiveness to make themselves feel better as a sort of justification for their mistake or sin. Words are just that, words. It’s actions that mean something in the end. And my actions almost got you hurt.”

“So you aren’t sorry?”

“Of course I’m sorry. But I don’t want to hear you saying you accept my apology like you are all right with my mistake. This accident shouldn’t be so easily forgiven or forgotten.”

She blinked at me again before burying her face in my chest and squeezing me around the waist tightly.

“You aren’t like everyone else. I do forgive you though. Just don’t leave me again ok?”

“As you wish. I won’t leave your side again. Do you want to continue on with the tour? We will probably be going to see the animals next.”

“Nu-uh. I’ve had enough for today and I’m hungry.”

“Understood. Then lets go find something to eat ok?”

As she nodded her head I turned to Mavrick who gave me a wink and a nod of the head. He accepted my farewell, giving one of his own before heading off to where the stagehands working on the backdrops were. It took a moment to extract her from my waist but when I did she clutched my hand and wouldn’t let go. As we walked through the backstage areas heading for the public stage I grinned down at her.

“Really is a shame you didn’t get to see the animals. They have a cat that can play the piano you know. And she is a super cat, able to do kung-fu moves.”

“Yeah right.”

“It’s true. And they have a giant black bear that will shake your hand.”

“That’s impossible.”

“Perhaps you are right. Perhaps I’m just pulling your leg.”

We walked on in silence for a few minutes until we finally got back into the main area of the amusement park before I grinned even wider while staring off into the distance.

“But what if I’m not?”

*********

Small actions lead to big consequences. But every situation has both good and bad aspects to it. What one would consider the good and the bad of it though is debatable. Because each person sees things differently. Hence why there are thousands of scenarios for each action and reaction. Why people recognize some choices but not others. Perhaps even why they don’t realize they have a choice.

This day was a series of choices. Did you look at it and say well why didn’t he say this? Or why didn’t he do that when he had the chance? Do you wonder why Riktal only felt he had a choice over certain matters in his day? Those choices that you decided? Or perhaps you wonder why the other people in this world did what they did when they did it. It all comes back to that thing called perception. Of each individuals ability to weigh the good and the bad of a situation and form thoughts based on those perceptions.

So then, I must wonder, how did you decide the choices you did? Was it on your perceptions of the situation? Or perhaps Riktal’s perceptions. Did you feel when your perception and his conflicted? If so did that make you second guess yourself, or hesitate in your choice? It seems in observing you I have found more questions I seek answers to. Feel free to come again and answer them for me as you return to this day to live it over. Making new decisions unclouded by your previous experience. Or perhaps they will be clouded, altering your perception of events with your future knowledge.

That is an interesting question to be answered indeed.
11112111211212111.title: Save the boy

11112111211212112.content:
Resisting the urge to dash off to help the boy I could only watch the accident unfold. The woman swung to the end of the swing’s arc while the boy was still slightly too high over her head. She made a wild grab for him as she swung backwards but as I had predicted her hands missed his outreaching ones by inches. He tried to maneuver his body to hit the net properly on his back but he was in a bad position to begin with. As he spun he overcompensated, ending up slamming into the net on his side.

His hand got caught in one of the small holes as his body bounced back up in the air and he continued his flip. The wrist resisted for a moment before finally snapping. He let out a cry of pain as people hurried onto the net to disentangle him and get him to the on-site healer. Mavrick let out a small sigh and shook his head.

“That will keep him from practicing for at least a month. And I had been hoping to add him into the show soon. It’s a shame but what can you do?”

“Look out!”

I had seen the movement out of the corner of my eye and was already grabbing Asala’s arm to yank her out of the way. One of the sandbags tied to the end of a rope swung harmlessly past seconds after I had done so. Scanning the direction the bag had come from I looked for any more trouble. Assuming the accident hadn’t been deliberate would be a mistake. But I saw no one trying to hide or sneak away so figured it was my paranoia talking. Maverick yelled at the stage hands to be more careful, getting quick apologies from all of them.

“Sorry about that Riktal. We’ve been trying to implement backdrops and a few other props into our performances lately. My daughter says it’s all the rage overseas and convinced me to give it a shot. The staff isn’t quite used to the weighted pulley system yet, so we get these mess ups from time to time.”

“You know there are easier ways to do that kind of thing right? With modern technology you don’t have to go so old school.”

“I know. But that kind of thing costs money. Money we really don’t have quite yet. Besides, don’t you think there is something to be said for such old school things? That relies more on the skill of the people than just the push of a button?”

I didn’t answer him as I looked down at Asala who was clutching me around the waist. I could feel her heart beating rapidly as I stroked her hair to calm her down.

“You ok?”

“Yeah. Thanks for saving me.”

“That’s what I’m here for. So are you ready to continue with the tour or do you want to call it a day for now?”

She shook her head back and forth quickly while replying.

“No! I want to see more! I’m ok honest!”

I ruffled her hair as Mavrick moved on to the animal handlers area. Asala watched as two men and a woman worked with the animals in their own separate areas. There was your standard lion taming, another one was working with a bear wearing a silly hat and letting the tamer touch it. Even shaking hands like it was a human. The woman was putting a seal through the motions of playing “Twinkle Twinkle” on a xylophone. I thought Asala’s head would come right off the way she was twisting it trying to see everything at once.

“This is only a small number of the animals we use in our shows of course. We have to keep it a bit fresh each time so we use different animal acts in a rotation. Why don’t you try giving that whistle I gave you earlier a try?”

The girl looked up at Mavrick before pulling it out of her pocket and blowing into it. The whistle emitted no sound, but instantly a large black cat with a white star shaped patch on it’s forehead jumped down off a pile of boxes and came over to sit at her feet.

“Meet Felicia. She is one of our oldest members. Though don’t tell her that, she can be a bit… catty sometimes.”

“Please spare the girl your corny jokes Mavrick. They make even the clowns weep.”

“You just don’t have a funny bone.”

“If that’s the kind of jokes I’d laugh at if I did then I don’t need one!”

The woman who had been working with the seal came over grinning from ear to ear. I took her extended hand, being pulled into a bear hug before she planted a kiss on my lips.

“Riktal darling! It has been way too long! I’ve missed you!”

“With a welcome like that you don’t wonder why I try to avoid you Minerva?”

“Posh! That’s just a friendly greeting you know that!”

“Then why don’t you ever greet me like that?”

“Because your wife would be angry at me if I did Maverick. Besides, I don’t like you that much.”

“I thought you said it was only a friendly greeting.”

Minerva looked at me with a raised eyebrow at my comment.

“I never said only.”

I chuckled along with Maverick and Minerva while Asala looked on with wide eyes, wondering what the joke was. I knew Minerva had a bit of a crush on me, but I didn’t have any feelings for her. It had nothing to do with the fact that she was eight years older than me either. She knew how I felt and she was fine with the relationship we had now. This was just the way she was. Minerva looked down at the girl and suddenly did a double take before looking up at me. I nodded my head slightly in response to her unspoken question, it wasn’t often I got to surprise her. Minirve gave me a raised eyebrow before talking to Asala directly.

“Felicia here is our resident ninja. Watch.”

With that Minerva kicked at the cat who did a backflip away with the ease of long practice. Minerva brought her foot around again in a side swipe and the cat flipped forward, balancing on the leg even as it swung through the air. As it started to come down the cat flipped forward again and jumped off, landing on Minerva’s head sitting proudly. Asala began clapping her hands in glee.

“She can also play the keyboard, but we don’t have it set up right now to show you. Think you can hold still for a little bit and not move?”

“Yeah.”

Minerva whistled a small little tune and Felicia jumped off her head as Minerva raised her left arm in front of her. The cat did a handstand on the arm before twisting on her paws and pushing off to land on Asala’s hair. Asala flinched a little reflexively but the cat compensated for the movement. After a moment it stepped down onto the shoulder and draped itself there contentedly. A slight hesitation before Asala reached up to pet it, soon having the cat purring.

“She likes you. You’ve got a gift with animals it seems.”

“Don’t let Minerva fool you. Felicia likes everybody.”

“Then why does she always scratch you when you try to pick her up Maverick?”

“Because I like dogs more than cats.”

“Yeah, I really don’t think that’s the reason.”

The three of us continued to chat for a bit as Asala held the cat in her arms, cradling it on top of her teddy bear. Asala asked a few questions about the animals and Minerva answered them as best she could. Before we knew it, a stagehand was yelling that the next show would be starting within the hour. Mavrick gave a small start and left with a quick word of apology.

“Hey Asala, want to stick around and see the real show now that you’ve gotten to see behind the scenes a bit?”

“Yeah!”

Felicia jumped out of Asala’s hands before the girl could set her down and we turned to go back to the front. Asala stopped suddenly, pulling the whistle out of her pocket again and holding it out to Minerva. Minerva smiled while shaking her head.

“You keep it. A memento of your time here. Besides the boss gave it to you as a present so it’s your’s now.”

With another sparkling smile that showed almost all her teeth she said thank you and pocketed the small wooden whistle. When I offered her my hand she took it with a small squeeze before looking up at me with those large crimson eyes of hers, directing that smile only at me.

“You’re the best! You aren’t like everyone else who just wanted to poke and prod me and stick wires all over. You’re nice and your hands are warm.”

“I’m glad I got your approval.”

She reached around and gave me another hug before humming to herself while we continued on, eventually finding ourselves some seats.

******

The day ends and another story closes. But this is but one of many possible stories. Just one of many possible outcomes. This is the truth, and yet it is not. This day, while real, has not and may not happen. Because time here has no meaning. Does that mean your decisions were meaningless? That the course you chose was pointless? Those questions are entirely up to you to decide. Only you humans have the capacity to attach meaning where there is none or infer a different meaning than was intended. Come again and play with young Riktal’s fate. See what else this day may have, will have, and has had, in store for him.
11112111211212112.title: Stay with the girl

1111211121121212.content:
“Let’s hit up the acrobat’s and animals. I think she would enjoy the experience.”

“As you wish. If you two would follow me please?”

After he said this he jumped high in the air while doing a back flip, spinning upside down to land a few inches away with his back to us. He looked over his shoulder with a half grin and a raised eyebrow as I simply shook my head and followed. Asala was walking on her own now, actively holding my hand instead of me dragging her by the arm. I didn’t push my pace so she could keep up with me easily while she looked around surreptitiously.

“Seems an old dog learned a new trick.”

“Well the boss should know a thing or two about every aspect of his show don’t you think? Besides, it’s fun.”

“You’re never going to grow up are you?”

“Not until the day I die!”

When she saw Tony the knife juggler catch a knife in his mouth before juggling two more daggers on the tip of the blade she stared at me in shock. With a grin I laid my hand on her head while raising one of my eyebrows in her direction.

“Didn’t I tell you it wasn’t wise to bet against me? Just enjoy being a kid right now ok? Leave all the bad stuff for later. I’m not saying it will go away, but that doesn’t mean you can’t enjoy this brief moment. You understand what I am saying?”

She stared at me with those big crimson eyes before finally nodding her head and giving my hand a squeeze. Mavrick looked over his shoulder at us a moment before catching my eyes.

“Hunter business?”

“Aye.”

“I understand. I’ll spread the word.”

“Thanks.”

A few moments later we came to the area where three handlers were working with some of the animals. One was in a large cage with a tiger who was standing on it’s hind legs and doing a simple ballroom dance with the guy. The second guy was working with a group of dogs who were doing a line dance of some description. The third was a woman who was working with ten birds sitting on perches who were singing in tune what sounded like an opera song. Even as we watched one of the birds began beat boxing, making a sort of booming click sound with it’s beak. The bird next to it began wagging its tongue out of it’s mouth making a weird counterpoint that seemed to fit, the two sounds merging together to make one.

The woman turned and flicked the beak of the offending bird, making it stop. Staring into it’s eyes she began to make the single note over and over until the bird mimicked her. With a nod she scratched under it’s chin, making it croon in pleasure before kissing it’s beak. She turned when she heard us approach, her eyes lighting up as she ran over to meet us. The full head of blue hair bouncing up and down as if it had a life of it’s own. When she extended her hand I shook it, being pulled into a bear hug moments before she kissed me on the lips.

“Riktal! It’s been forever! I was getting lonely!”

“What? Mavrick doesn’t keep you busy enough?”

“Posh! Training beasties aint work! It’s what I love to do!”

“I’m sure I could find some real work for you to do then Minerva.”

“You do that and I’ll tell your wife about your desire to do a bit of animal training yourself. She’s fine with you breaking your bones learning the acrobatics and the magic tricks, but I doubt she wants to see you coming home with bite marks.”

“Fine, fine. Though you’re enough of an animal as it is, I don’t need to learn how to tame any others.”

The three of us began to chuckle as Asala stared up at us with those wide eyes of hers. Minerva looked down at the child, her greenish yellow eyes meeting the girls crimson ones. There was a spark of recognition as she did a double take and looked back up at me, her eyes going almost as big as the girls. I gave her a small nod of confirmation, getting a half grin and a wink in return.

“Hey Asala. Remember that whistle Mavrick gave you? Why don’t you try blowing it?”

The girl pulled the little wooden whistle from her pocket and blew. Even though it didn’t make an audible sound a large black cat laying on top of a pile of boxes jumped to the floor, sauntering over before sitting at the girls feet looking up expectantly. Maverick held out his hand to the cat theatrically while giving Asala a small bow.

“This is Felicia. She’s retired now, but it’s not too much of a stretch to say she helped build this animal show into what it is today. Back in the day she was one of our only animal acts and she has earned her spot in all of our hearts.”

Minerva gave a quick whistle as she held her hand palm up towards the cat while spreading her legs. The can leapt onto the palm before doing a few front flips up the length of the arm to curl around the woman’s shoulders. The cat watched Asala with a knowing intelligence as her tail swished back and forth over Minerva’s chest.

“As you can see, she still got a few tricks in her.”

Asala’s eyes sparkled as she tentatively reached out to pet the cat. Her fingers hesitated a moment before Minerva nodded that it was all right, but soon she was petting it under the chin and behind the ears. The cat disentangled herself from Minerva and jumped down onto Asala’s head, balancing there as the girl jerked reflexively before stepping down to her shoulders and then into her arms where she nestled contentedly. The girl got a stupid grin on her face as she pet the cat, listening to the purring sound.

“Are you glad we came Asala?”

She looked up at me and nodded. “Yes.”

I was a bit surprised to hear her voice. It was soft and a bit musical with that slight high pitch of youth. But it was another step in the right direction. The three of us talked a few more moments until there was a roaring sound from behind us. We all turned to look, seeing a fourth handler bringing a lion into the cage with the tiger. Minerva yelled at the new trainer even as the lion and tiger lunged at each other. Asala gave a whimper as a red summoning circle appeared on the far wall and a eight foot tall troll clambered out welding it’s signature spiked club. It was one of the red variety so at least a high B class, perhaps even an A class monster.

It looked around a moment at all the confusion as the birds flew off to the safety of their roosts and the trainer whistled quickly to send the dogs away as well. The two trainers in the cage called out halt, power lacing their voices, making the two fighting beasts stop attacking and come to heel. The troll smashed it’s club into the cage as the two trainers escaped back through the door, leading their animals like trained house pets.

I was off and running at the troll, slipping my duffle bag off my back in one smooth motion and pulling out a small anvil hammer, the sharp blade on the back of the flat head glistening under the light. Letting a bit of my power flow into the weapon it enlarged in my hand until its head became as big as my own and the handle almost as long as my arm. With red trolls blunt was the way to go. Piercing worked well but not slicing. Guns were effective but I wanted both attack and defense. I threw the hammer at the creature, lacing it with an aura of magic and tethering it to my arm with a string. The weighted lump of iron smashed into the face right before I yanked back on my arm, bringing the hammer back to me.

“Yo! Big red and stupid! Over here!”

With a roar the monster turned to me and charged.
1111211121121212.title: Animals and Acrobats

11112111211212121.content:
“Legs!”

With that single shouted word I dodged out of the way of the club trying to smash down on my head by simply sidestepping. With a yell I brought the hammer around with all my might, smashing into the trolls kneecap and buckling the leg for a moment. It let out a roar just as a blue circle appeared on the floor next to me. A big meaty blue fist shot out of the hole and grabbed the club as it swung around to swipe at my head.

A six foot tall mountain troll jumped out of the hole and gave the red one an uppercut with it’s own club even as I spun around to smash my hammer into the back of the trolls other knee. A second circle appeared in the wall as Felicia ran towards me. From out of the second summoning circle a small Picu bird appeared. They were constructs of magic and not alive in the sense of other animals, but they did have a special purpose. Felicia leapt into the air chomping down on the bird and swallowing it whole.

“From powers born to power return! Construct to construct! Fusion!”

Minerva’s voice rang out as the cat gave a howl, growing four feet taller and standing on two feet. This was the purpose of the Picu bird. To enhance and temporarily transform other creatures, be they animal, human or monster, imbuing them with the magic that kept them alive.

I continued to smash my hammer into the troll, slowly breaking the bones through the tough skin while the blue one kept its hands busy. Even though the blue one was smaller, of a lower class and less powerful, those weaknesses were offset by both me and Felicia attacking as well.

“Felicia! Cyclone claws! Troll! Body blow!”

Minerva’s voice belted out the commands quickly, even as I slammed the kneecaps one more time to make the troll buckle backwards. The blue troll turned his shoulder into the red one and shoved while I jumped into the air. Felicia spun in a circle quickly as her claws each grew a foot long. Soon she was nothing but a black spinning ball of death, with claws poking out everywhere. She slammed into the troll as it was falling, tearing huge gaping wounds in it’s flesh.

“Phase two activate. Judgment spike.”

The blade on the end grew into two, while a large spike appeared on the end of the handle. As I fell I planted my foot on the top of the hammer, getting it in place moments before the spike landed in the large gash Felicia had put on the trolls forehead. The spike went through the skull like butter, impaling it into the floor. The monster didn’t even have time to let out a death roar before exploding into the small white motes all monsters dissolved into.

Returning the hammer to it’s original size and shape I headed back to Minerva and the group. Minerva gave the troll a bow and a thank you before opening another blue circle for it to walk docilely through. Once it was gone she looked at Felicia who looked more like a human crouching on the floor.

“From construct to construct and power to power. I bid you release.”

There was a small wind as the excess power still in the cat’s body swirled around. But after only a second she shrunk back to the plain old black cat with a white marking on it’s head. Asala was staring at Minerva in surprise as I grinned and knelt in front of her.

“Shocked? Well I guess you would be. Yes she is a summoner like you. But unlike you she’s not as powerful. You want to know a secret? Everyone here knows about her power and accepts her. She protects this circus when it’s in trouble, and she’s able to bring her skills at taming monsters into her ability to tame and train animals. Those two tamers with the lion and the tiger? They both have a unique gift too. They can connect with the emotions of animals. Not everyone here has special abilities, but there are a few. They were all able to find a place where they felt like they belonged and people wouldn’t hate them blindly.”

“Will… will I be able to do stuff like that too one day?”

“I’m sure you will be able to do that and more. Right now you can’t control your power and things just pop out whenever you don’t want them to. But someday it will be you who controls when and where they pop out. And what monster comes as well. The question will then become, what will you do with that power once you have it?”

Minerva knelt down next to the girl as Felicia jumped up on Minerva’s shoulder. The woman absently scratched the cat under the chin as she stared into Asala’s eyes.

“Felicia here was the first animal I ever trained. Years before I joined the circus. She’s old. Older than any cat has a right to be. Back when I first started learning about being a summoner, she was my only friend. I learned how to use my unique skill to summon Picu birds to fuse with her like you saw. Because of that she’s grown as intelligent as many humans and been granted a much longer lifespan. But she is still a regular animal for all of that.

“Your road ahead is going to be hard. People are going to hate you and try to kill you simply because you can summon monsters. You will have few friends and you will sometimes live in fear that someone will find out. But you will also know a joy that no one else will be able to understand. Being able to summon the most ferocious of monsters and have it acting like a puppy to your touch. Or being able to command a monster you haven’t summoned with but a few words. You will see things and do things no one else will. It is a magic all it’s own.”

Minerva stared silently at the girl for a moment before nodding her head and reaching up to pull her gold necklace off. The blue gem in the middle seemed to give off a sparkle of its own.

“I come from far to the west, across another great sea. A place where those with unique abilities are a bit more common but still no less tolerated. But there is a custom among my people. When one is about to embark upon a great journey they are gifted with a good luck charm. One imbued with the thoughts of those who came before them. This necklace was given to me by my teacher when I finished my training and decided to come across the seas. In the summoner world gold represents pliability and promise. It is flexible and soft, yet when tempered with other materials it can exhibit a hardness it cannot obtain otherwise. Just as your will needs to be in order to control your powers.

“Blue is a symbol of life and love to a summoner. Because when you are a summoner it is not just your life you take into your hands, but the lives of thousands. Both human and monster. Just because you can control them does not mean you shouldn’t respect them. I’ve worn that necklace everyday for the last ten years. I came into my power when I was about your age and left to make it on my own when I was only sixteen. Now I think it’s time it moves on with you as you set off on your own journey as a summoner. Knowing it is filled with my hopes that you become an amazing summoner that you can be proud of.”

Minerva slipped the necklace over Asala’s head before giving her a grin from ear to ear and wrapping her arm around my neck.

“Well you got Riktal here to look out for you for now so you don’t have anything to worry about. He’s one of the good ones and I’m sure if you were ever in any great need he would come running no matter where you were. Even if he had to swim across the ocean to do it.”

Asala nodded her head gravely at the woman’s words, taking everything she said to heart.

“I know. I can tell. I don’t know how exactly but he’s not like everyone else. His hands are warm and his smile isn’t fake. I decided I’m going to marry him when I am done training.”

Minirva began to bust out laughing along with Mavrick who had been standing in the background. I simply rubbed my eyes under my glasses and shook my head. Where had that come from?

“Well you’ll have to fight me for him because I saw him first! I’ve been trying to get into his pants for the last two years but he is more slippery than an oiled eel.”

“That’s because your old! My momma said men like them younger. That’s what she talked about with aunt Jesamine when she thought I wasn’t listening anyway.”

That cracked all of us up, even Minerva who gave a small pouting face before letting the laughter out.

“You’re too much for me Asala. I’d never be able to keep up with you if I were your husband.”

“I won’t let you get out of it. I’ve decided and momma used to say you need to stick with something if you really believe it!”

That set us all off in another bout of laughter as I told her we would just have to see what happened in four or five years. I offered her my hand as we got up off the floor and I spoke with the two for a bit longer. I let Maverick know I would pay for repairs, even when he said it wasn’t necessary. I knew he was just being polite in refusing and really would appreciate my payment. Asala kept glancing up at Minerva in awe and a little bit of hero worship. Minerva saw the looks and smiled at the child whenever she could.

“So do you want to continue on with the tour or call it quits? I doubt anything else will happen, but if you want to be a bit cautious it’s up to you.”

When I looked down at Asala to see what she thought she gave me big saucer eyes, pleading with me not to stop now. Her lower lip was pouting a little bit, giving her a real puppy dog look. If her powers acted up again Minerva wouldn’t be around to help and people might actually get hurt. Perhaps it would be best to call it a day.
11112111211212121.title: Go for the legs

111121112112121211.content:
“I think it would be ok to keep going. If something like this happens again I’ll be around to stop it anyway. If there are any more damages I’ll pay for them also. As long as you can keep all this under wraps for me that is Mavrick.”

“Not a problem. The old heads won’t even need to be told, just got to worry about the new guys. After all, you’re practically family here.”

Asala jumped up and down a bit in joy as the three of us talked a little while more. Asala asked questions about animal handling and Minerva answered as best she could. Soon enough we were on our way again to see the acrobats. Asala was soon enthralled by the way a man and a woman were doing back flips on a tightrope while a boy was skipping rope on another one. Many of the acrobats waved to me or called out good natured jokes at my expense. When two of the trampoline artists asked if Asala wanted to try it out, I agreed before she had a chance to respond. I could see her eagerness and desire without her having to look at me. Clutching her bear even tighter she ran off a short distance to the two.

“You are probably one of the best people she could have around her right now. Her mind is all messed up, you know that right? I’ve only gotten a few fragments here and there, nothing more than surface flashes but she’s not as stable as she seems. My ability is pretty weak and not always that reliable but her thoughts are strong enough to come in loud and clear when they do so that should say something.”

“I figured it was pretty messed up. I don’t claim to understand it all, but I really don’t need to understand completely to help her. Grief is grief no matter how it comes about. I’ve been able to put it on the backburner for now, but it will all have to come out eventually. Hopeful I can get her to see that she can continue on with life before that time comes. Otherwise I have a feeling she will want to end her own life.”

“Your feelings aren’t unfounded. During that monster attack I saw it. Her desire to die because of her power. She’s just on this side of the line I think.”

“But she reminds me a lot of Olia as well. Take good care of her.”

“I’d planned on it. You think you could see your way to giving Minirva the next few days off? I’d like her to spend it with me and the girl. Perhaps stabilize her a bit. It would be a big help having another monster summoner around her, someone who knows what she’s going to have to look forward to.”

“That was your aim from the beginning wasn’t it? That’s why you brought her here.”

“I’d be lying if I said that wasn’t one of the reasons. But I also thought she’d enjoy herself.”

“Well she has tomorrow off but I can work around opening up a day or two more. It’s Hunter business after all.”

“Thank Jonrick.”

“Ha! I haven’t been called that for years! Surprised you even knew my real name.”

“Please, I got a bit suspicious around the time we first met so did a background check on you.”

“Yet you still befriended an escaped convict like me huh?”

“No I befriended Mavrick, a slightly disreputable circus owner who has dedicated his life to making people happy. Besides, I had your case looked into. Like you claimed at your trial, you were wrongly accused. It was all a set up with you as the scapegoat. Your problem was your enemy had more money and connections than you.”

“Then how did you find out?”

I grinned as I slapped him on the back, watching as the two girls on the trampoline held onto Asala while making her do flips.

“I’m a Zelkov. There’s not many who have more access to connections and money then me. Don’t worry, your secrets are safe with me. Unless of course you want to go back to your old life. I can make that happen.”

“After almost twenty years? No thanks. I left it all behind me long ago. I’ve got it good here and I’m content.”

“As you wish Mavrick.”

He gave me a sideways grin as Asala came running up panting but full of excitement. Jumping up and down asking if I had been watching over and over. I told her I had been and was impressed how quickly she had picked up on it. She seemed to shine even brighter as her eyes sparkled with dreams of being an acrobat. I could almost see them reflected in her crimson orbs. Wrapping my arm around her, the three of us turned and headed on, coming to where the clowns and magicians were practicing in between eating some ham sandwiches.

Mavrick introduced Asala to the crowd and after a few minutes of bantering, the group had made her one of their own just like everyone else had. They shoved sandwiches and juice on her, saying she was a growing girl and needed to eat. While she wolfed the offerings down the clowns put on an impromptu slapstick show that had her laughing along with everyone else. Even though they had probably seen some of the routines done a hundred times they were still the type that could get a chuckle if executed with the proper timing. The magicians did their sleight of hand, confounding her with their magic that used no magic. They even showed her how to do some of the simplest tricks involving a Senz coin or foam balls.

We spent another good hour or so in this fashion, until a stage hand came yelling that the next show started within the hour. Mavrick gave a start and begged leave of us as he went off to prepare. After that our little party broke up as Asala came over to wrap her arms around my neck, squeezing tightly.

“Thank you for today! It was awesome and I had lots of fun!”

“You’re welcome sweetie. But you know, I don’t think the days over. Now that you’ve got a inside peek at what they do here, you want to stick around for the real show? You can see it all put together with all the flashy lights and death defying action.”

“Yeah!”

“Oh wait never mind. We can’t do that.”

“Awww! Why not!”

“Because we are sitting back here at the moment. We need to go back out front and find us some good seats before they are all taken!”

Scooping her up I shifted her to my right side while carrying her back the way we had come. She giggled as she wrapped her arms even more tightly around my neck and gave me a kiss on the cheek.

“Think we can get a seat for Mr. Cuddles too?”

“Who’s Mr. Cuddles?”

“My bear silly!”

“Well you never introduced us so how was I supposed to know! For all I knew, that could have been the name of your invisible friend.”

“There’s no such thing as invisible friends!”

“How do you know? Have you ever seen one.”

“No! That’s how I know they don’t exist!”

She giggled a bit at my words as I raised my eyebrow at her.

“Really? That just tells me no one has proven they exist or not. So until I get proof that they don’t exist, that must mean that they do!”

She began to laugh and squirm in my arms as I reached around and began tickling her sides until she finally slid down to the floor and skipped out of my reach. We only stopped outside long enough to grab some popcorn and cotton candy before heading back into the giant tent to find ourselves a seat. Once we were settled in she leaned her head against my side contentedly.

“Hey, is it ok if I call you big brother?”

“Sure, if that’s what you want.”

“Ok. I love you big brother. Don’t ever leave my side.”

“I won’t. At least not until your new master gets here.”

“Can’t I just stay here and train with that animal trainer lady?”

“Minerva? No. She’s not as strong as you so if you summoned something really powerful she wouldn’t be able to stop it alone. And training you would be a full time job. She doesn’t have the kind of money to live off of while she did that.”

“Then can you come with me?”

“I can’t do that either. But I’ll give you my communication id and we can call each other whenever we want. And I can come visit you when I have time.”

“I’d like that. Just promise you won’t die like momma and papa.”

“I don’t plan on dying for a very long time. Besides, I can’t die if you plan on marrying me right?”

“Yeah!”

Even though her voice sounded cheerful I felt her hand clench on my tunic as she buried her face in it. Soon enough I felt the fabric moisten as I gently wrapped my arm around her, stroking her hair softly.

************

Even in the worst conditions you humans find a ray of light. You are flexible and resilient even in the face of the unexpected. Your lives are full of ups and downs, regrets and choices. Perhaps it is because you have choices that you have regrets. But it is also those choices that make you so resilient and flexible. They exist in a harmony of balance I find most interesting.

111121112112121211.title: Keep going

111121112112121212.content:
“I think… I think maybe we should call it a day.”

“Awww!”

Asala pouted a bit harder as I grinned and ruffled her hair.

“You can pout and go aww all you want. But the fact still remains that this might happen again. Mavrick can keep this under wraps and no one here will say anything. But what will happen if you summon another monster and people get hurt? Or it destroys one of these areas? What if people out in the park get hurt? I’ve got a duty to not only protect you but also everyone else as well. You understand?”

She pouted little more but finally nodded her head in agreement. Minerva squatted in front of Asala, flicking her forehead lightly with two fingers. When Asala put her hands up to the spot the woman let out a deep chuckle.

“Don’t get all sulky girl. The look doesn’t suit you. Besides I’m the only one allowed to pout like that. You listen to Riktal all right? He knows what he’s doing and if he thinks it’s unwise to stay then I’d trust him. Even if nothing happens and everything would be fine it’s better safe than sorry. Besides, I bet if you asked him he would be more than willing to bring you again. Maybe tomorrow even since I have the day off. If he does I could teach you a few small tricks that will make it easier to control your power. You decided you were going to marry him right? Well I doubt he would be much interested in a waif of a girl who didn’t know how to smile.”

Asala’s lips began to twitch before finally breaking out into a grin the equal of Minerva’s. I shared a silent exchange of thanks with my eyes over Asala’s head, getting a slight wink in return.

“I think that won’t be a problem at all. She will be with me for the next few days and I don’t have anything better to do. So we can spend it here if you want Asala.”

“I’d like that.”

She looked down at her feet for a moment, shuffling them on the floor before looking back up at me.

“Can’t I just stay here and learn from her instead of having to go away? I don’t want to leave again.”

Minerva shook her head slowly and answered before I could.

“Sorry girl. This might sound mean but I can’t teach you. It’s not that I don’t have the skill. It’s because I don’t have the power to hold yours in check if something really goes wrong. Plus I’ve got a simple life here I am happy with. I don’t have the kind of connections or money for bribes I would need to be your teacher. Teaching you would be a full time job and I’m not willing to quit the circus for you. This is just one of the many hardships you are going to have to face on your journey.”

Her face fell for a moment as she nodded her head in understanding. But her sadness didn’t last long as she wiped her eyes and left Minerva with a smile. I wrapped my arm around her, hugging her to my side as we left the circus area and entered the amusement park proper.

“You can cry if you want to. It’s the bodies way of helping you cope.”

Her head shook back and forth slowly.

“No. I’m sad but I could tell she was telling the truth. I need to become strong like her and like you. So I can’t cry all the time.”

She was silent the rest of the way home, content to simply hold my hand and stay close to me. It took only a moment to unlock the door and pull the bags inside. From there I lead her to the kitchen where I prepared some peanut butter and jelly sandwiches.

“Can you cut them in half diagonally? My mom used to make them like that for me.”

“Not a problem.”

I set the plate in front of her after running a knife through the bread quickly. She picked up one of the halves and stared at it a moment without actually eating.

“Hey, Riktal?”

“Yeah?”

“I’m still allowed to cry for my mom and dad right?”

“Yeah.”

As she took a bite of the sandwich her tears began to flow. She didn’t make a sound, just ate and cried. Setting the knife down I went over and wrapped my arms around her from behind, resting my cheek on the top of her head.

“Let it all out. I’m here. It will still hurt afterwards but you’ll feel better.”

I simply held her like that as she finished the sandwich and really let the waterworks come.

********
