11112111211212122.content:
“Head!”

Even as I shouted that out I sidestepped the downwards strike of the club, jumping onto the thick slab of wood and running up the arm. By the time I brought the flat head of the hammer around a blue summoning circle was appearing along the wall and a small army of goblins came running out wielding small hammers of their own. My weapon smashed into the troll’s jaw as the twenty little goblins whacked at the knees and legs. Another portal opened, letting a Picu bird fly out.

Launching off the arm as it tried to throw me I spun in front of it’s face, bringing the hammer in my left hand around even as Felicia jumped onto the club as well and ran towards the troll’s head. The spiked end of my weapon slammed into the right ear as Felicia leapt high into the air to eat the little Picu bird.

“From powers born to powers return! Construct to construct! Fusion!”

Felicia gave a small howl as the magical energy that made up the little bird infused itself in the cat’s body. The cat began to stretch, it’s paws becoming more hand like as it grew to be four feet tall.

“Felicia! Claw Cyclone! Goblins! Suicide Blitz!”

Dislodging the spike from the Troll’s ear I leapt away, grabbing the handle in both hands. The goblins ran headlong at the monsters legs, smashing them even harder than before, not even trying to avoid it’s kicking feet this time. Their relentless assault made the knees buckle and the troll sink to the floor. Felicia’s claws meanwhile had each grown a foot long as she spin faster and faster in the air, creating her own personal cyclone as she fell. Gravity and her own ability landed her on the trolls face, ripping deep gouges in it’s flesh. The creature gave a roar as a claw took out it’s eye and another one caught in its lip, ripping its cheek wide open. As the cat continued down the front of the body opening deep wounds, I dashed in again, blocking the club with my hammer before it could hit the cat.

“Phase two activate: Judgment spike!”

A second spike began to grow along the backside of the hammer head, giving it a slightly demonic look of horns even as a bit of metal flowed down the length of the handle to create a third needle-sharp spike. Even as I danced backwards from the other arm that came around to try and grab me I threw the hammer like a Frisbee, sending it end over end right into the wide gaping hole in its cheek. The head jerked to the side as the weapon hit the inside of the other cheek before the hammer tore out through the flesh causing it to fall to the floor. The goblins were all over the troll in seconds. Beating on every inch of the monster with their hammers, focusing on the skull until it caved in and the monster disappeared in motes of white light.

By the time I had retrieved my weapon, reverted it to it’s travel form, and returned to the group, Minerva was already opening another blue portal to return the goblins to their original place. The goblins, who were now down to about a third of the numbers they had been originally, gave the woman a small bow and left quietly. Once they were gone Minerva broke the spell on Felicia, returning her to a regular cat again. Asala stared at Minerva and Felicia in shock, her eyes so large I thought the orbs would just roll right out of the sockets.

“Shocked? Well I guess you would be. Yes she is a summoner like you. But unlike you she’s not as powerful. You want to know a secret? Everyone here knows about her power and accepts her. She protects this circus when it’s in trouble, and she’s able to bring her skills at taming monsters into her ability to tame and train animals. Those two tamers with the lion and the tiger? They both have a unique gift too. They can connect with the emotions of animals. Not everyone here has special abilities, but there are a few. They were all able to find a place where they felt like they belonged and people wouldn’t hate them blindly.”

“Will… will I be able to do stuff like that too one day?”

“I’m sure you will be able to do that and more. Right now you can’t control your power and things just pop out whenever you don’t want them to. But someday it will be you who controls when and where they pop out. And what monster comes as well. The question will then become, what will you do with that power once you have it?”

Minerva knelt down next to the girl as Felicia jumped up on Minerva’s shoulder. The woman absently scratched the cat under the chin as she stared into Asala’s eyes.

“Felicia here was the first animal I ever trained. Years before I joined the circus. She’s old. Older than any cat has a right to be. Back when I first started learning about being a summoner, she was my only friend. I learned how to use my unique skill to summon Picu birds to fuse with her like you saw. Because of that she’s grown as intelligent as many humans and been granted a much longer lifespan. But she is still a regular animal for all of that.

“Your road ahead is going to be hard. People are going to hate you and try to kill you simply because you can summon monsters. You will have few friends and you will sometimes live in fear that someone will find out. But you will also know a joy that no one else will be able to understand. Being able to summon the most ferocious of monsters and have it acting like a puppy to your touch. Or being able to command a monster you haven’t summoned with but a few words. You will see things and do things no one else will. It is a magic all it’s own.”

Minerva stared silently at the girl for a moment before nodding her head and reaching up to pull her gold necklace off. The blue gem in the middle seemed to give off a sparkle of its own.

“I come from far to the west, across another great sea. A place where those with unique abilities are a bit more common but still no less tolerated. But there is a custom among my people. When one is about to embark upon a great journey they are gifted with a good luck charm. One imbued with the thoughts of those who came before them. This necklace was given to me by my teacher when I finished my training and decided to come across the seas. In the summoner world gold represents pliability and promise. It is flexible and soft, yet when tempered with other materials it can exhibit a hardness it cannot obtain otherwise. Just as your will needs to be in order to control your powers.

“Blue is a symbol of life and love to a summoner. Because when you are a summoner it is not just your life you take into your hands, but the lives of thousands. Both human and monster. Just because you can control them does not mean you shouldn’t respect them. I’ve worn that necklace everyday for the last ten years. I came into my power when I was about your age and left to make it on my own when I was only sixteen. Now I think it’s time it moves on with you as you set off on your own journey as a summoner. Knowing it is filled with my hopes that you become an amazing summoner that you can be proud of.”

Minerva slipped the necklace over Asala’s head before giving her a grin from ear to ear and wrapping her arm around my neck.

“Well you got Riktal here to look out for you for now so you don’t have anything to worry about. He’s one of the good ones and I’m sure if you were ever in any great need he would come running no matter where you were. Even if he had to swim across the ocean to do it.”

Asala nodded her head gravely at the woman’s words, taking everything she said to heart.

“I know. I can tell. I don’t know how exactly but he’s not like everyone else. His hands are warm and his smile isn’t fake. I decided I’m going to marry him when I am done training.”

Minirva began to bust out laughing along with Mavrick who had been standing in the background. I simply rubbed my eyes under my glasses and shook my head. Where had that come from?

“Well you’ll have to fight me for him because I saw him first! I’ve been trying to get into his pants for the last two years but he is more slippery than an oiled eel.”

“That’s because your old! My momma said men like them younger. That’s what she talked about with aunt Jesamine when she thought I wasn’t listening anyway.”

That cracked all of us up, even Minerva who gave a small pouting face before letting the laughter out.

“You’re too much for me Asala. I’d never be able to keep up with you if I were your husband.”

“I won’t let you get out of it. I’ve decided and momma used to say you need to stick with something if you really believe it!”

That set us all off in another bout of laughter as I told her we would just have to see what happened in four or five years. I offered her my hand as we got up off the floor and I spoke with the two for a bit longer. I let Maverick know I would pay for repairs, even when he said it wasn’t necessary. I knew he was just being polite in refusing and really would appreciate my payment. Asala kept glancing up at Minerva in awe and a little bit of hero worship. Minerva saw the looks and smiled at the child whenever she could.

“So do you want to continue on with the tour or call it quits? I doubt anything else will happen, but if you want to be a bit cautious it’s up to you.”

When I looked down at Asala to see what she thought she gave me big saucer eyes, pleading with me not to stop now. Her lower lip was pouting a little bit, giving her a real puppy dog look. If her powers acted up again Minerva wouldn’t be around to help and people might actually get hurt. Perhaps it would be best to call it a day.

111121112112121222.content:
“I think it would be ok to keep going. If something like this happens again I’ll be around to stop it anyway. If there are any more damages I’ll pay for them also. As long as you can keep all this under wraps for me that is Mavrick.”

“Not a problem. The old heads won’t even need to be told, just got to worry about the new guys. After all, you’re practically family here.”

Asala jumped up and down a bit in joy as the three of us talked a little while more. Asala asked questions about animal handling and Minerva answered as best she could. Soon enough we were on our way again to see the acrobats. Asala was soon enthralled by the way a man and a woman were doing back flips on a tightrope while a boy was skipping rope on another one. Many of the acrobats waved to me or called out good natured jokes at my expense. When two of the trampoline artists asked if Asala wanted to try it out, I agreed before she had a chance to respond. I could see her eagerness and desire without her having to look at me. Clutching her bear even tighter she ran off a short distance to the two.

“You are probably one of the best people she could have around her right now. Her mind is all messed up, you know that right? I’ve only gotten a few fragments here and there, nothing more than surface flashes but she’s not as stable as she seems. My ability is pretty weak and not always that reliable but her thoughts are strong enough to come in loud and clear when they do so that should say something.”

“I figured it was pretty messed up. I don’t claim to understand it all, but I really don’t need to understand completely to help her. Grief is grief no matter how it comes about. I’ve been able to put it on the backburner for now, but it will all have to come out eventually. Hopeful I can get her to see that she can continue on with life before that time comes. Otherwise I have a feeling she will want to end her own life.”

“Your feelings aren’t unfounded. During that monster attack I saw it. Her desire to die because of her power. She’s just on this side of the line I think.”

“But she reminds me a lot of Olia as well. Take good care of her.”

“I’d planned on it. You think you could see your way to giving Minirva the next few days off? I’d like her to spend it with me and the girl. Perhaps stabilize her a bit. It would be a big help having another monster summoner around her, someone who knows what she’s going to have to look forward to.”

“That was your aim from the beginning wasn’t it? That’s why you brought her here.”

“I’d be lying if I said that wasn’t one of the reasons. But I also thought she’d enjoy herself.”

“Well she has tomorrow off but I can work around opening up a day or two more. It’s Hunter business after all.”

“Thank Jonrick.”

“Ha! I haven’t been called that for years! Surprised you even knew my real name.”

“Please, I got a bit suspicious around the time we first met so did a background check on you.”

“Yet you still befriended an escaped convict like me huh?”

“No I befriended Mavrick, a slightly disreputable circus owner who has dedicated his life to making people happy. Besides, I had your case looked into. Like you claimed at your trial, you were wrongly accused. It was all a set up with you as the scapegoat. Your problem was your enemy had more money and connections than you.”

“Then how did you find out?”

I grinned as I slapped him on the back, watching as the two girls on the trampoline held onto Asala while making her do flips.

“I’m a Zelkov. There’s not many who have more access to connections and money then me. Don’t worry, your secrets are safe with me. Unless of course you want to go back to your old life. I can make that happen.”

“After almost twenty years? No thanks. I left it all behind me long ago. I’ve got it good here and I’m content.”

“As you wish Mavrick.”

He gave me a sideways grin as Asala came running up panting but full of excitement. Jumping up and down asking if I had been watching over and over. I told her I had been and was impressed how quickly she had picked up on it. She seemed to shine even brighter as her eyes sparkled with dreams of being an acrobat. I could almost see them reflected in her crimson orbs. Wrapping my arm around her, the three of us turned and headed on, coming to where the clowns and magicians were practicing in between eating some ham sandwiches.

Mavrick introduced Asala to the crowd and after a few minutes of bantering, the group had made her one of their own just like everyone else had. They shoved sandwiches and juice on her, saying she was a growing girl and needed to eat. While she wolfed the offerings down the clowns put on an impromptu slapstick show that had her laughing along with everyone else. Even though they had probably seen some of the routines done a hundred times they were still the type that could get a chuckle if executed with the proper timing. The magicians did their sleight of hand, confounding her with their magic that used no magic. They even showed her how to do some of the simplest tricks involving a Senz coin or foam balls.

We spent another good hour or so in this fashion, until a stage hand came yelling that the next show started within the hour. Mavrick gave a start and begged leave of us as he went off to prepare. After that our little party broke up as Asala came over to wrap her arms around my neck, squeezing tightly.

“Thank you for today! It was awesome and I had lots of fun!”

“You’re welcome sweetie. But you know, I don’t think the days over. Now that you’ve got a inside peek at what they do here, you want to stick around for the real show? You can see it all put together with all the flashy lights and death defying action.”

“Yeah!”

“Oh wait never mind. We can’t do that.”

“Awww! Why not!”

“Because we are sitting back here at the moment. We need to go back out front and find us some good seats before they are all taken!”

Scooping her up I shifted her to my right side while carrying her back the way we had come. She giggled as she wrapped her arms even more tightly around my neck and gave me a kiss on the cheek.

“Think we can get a seat for Mr. Cuddles too?”

“Who’s Mr. Cuddles?”

“My bear silly!”

“Well you never introduced us so how was I supposed to know! For all I knew, that could have been the name of your invisible friend.”

“There’s no such thing as invisible friends!”

“How do you know? Have you ever seen one.”

“No! That’s how I know they don’t exist!”

She giggled a bit at my words as I raised my eyebrow at her.

“Really? That just tells me no one has proven they exist or not. So until I get proof that they don’t exist, that must mean that they do!”

She began to laugh and squirm in my arms as I reached around and began tickling her sides until she finally slid down to the floor and skipped out of my reach. We only stopped outside long enough to grab some popcorn and cotton candy before heading back into the giant tent to find ourselves a seat. Once we were settled in she leaned her head against my side contentedly.

“Hey, is it ok if I call you big brother?”

“Sure, if that’s what you want.”

“Ok. I love you big brother. Don’t ever leave my side.”

“I won’t. At least not until your new master gets here.”

“Can’t I just stay here and train with that animal trainer lady?”

“Minerva? No. She’s not as strong as you so if you summoned something really powerful she wouldn’t be able to stop it alone. And training you would be a full time job. She doesn’t have the kind of money to live off of while she did that.”

“Then can you come with me?”

“I can’t do that either. But I’ll give you my communication id and we can call each other whenever we want. And I can come visit you when I have time.”

“I’d like that. Just promise you won’t die like momma and papa.”

“I don’t plan on dying for a very long time. Besides, I can’t die if you plan on marrying me right?”

“Yeah!”

Even though her voice sounded cheerful I felt her hand clench on my tunic as she buried her face in it. Soon enough I felt the fabric moisten as I gently wrapped my arm around her, stroking her hair softly.

************

Even in the worst conditions you humans find a ray of light. You are flexible and resilient even in the face of the unexpected. Your lives are full of ups and downs, regrets and choices. Perhaps it is because you have choices that you have regrets. But it is also those choices that make you so resilient and flexible. They exist in a harmony of balance I find most interesting.

Did you make choices you regret today? Did you wonder what else might have happened if you had done something even slightly different? Were there things about this day you would wish to change? Are you satisfied with the outcome? This window is closed for now, but come again and it shall open once more. Letting you relive this day and see where else your decisions might take you. What other things you might regret or second guess. Please continue to help me obtain the information I seek by riding this rollercoaster called life.
111121112112121222.title: Keep going

1111211121122.content:
I was jumping off the bleacher and vaulting over the low banister even as Gregory fired his weapon. That was as far as I got though since Jethic suddenly appeared between Gregory and the monster, blocking the bullet on his shield. I stood their standing a bit foolishly as Jethic chewed the boy out, saying the next time he would let the monster smack him around. As the tank returned to the rest of the group who were looking at Gregory shaking their heads I jumped back over the banister to sit down again.

Gregory finally lowered his weapon, going to stand next to the rest as Liz began to chuckle at my actions a bit.

“You’re a better person than me. I would have let the Glif get at least one good hit in before going out to the rescue. That is if the Arena Master didn’t get there first. I don’t blame you though, I did the same thing when I first got here. Back before I just became bored of all of this. But that’s Gregory for you, always getting ahead of himself. At least he didn’t try anything stupid like casting magic on the monster while it was in this phase.”

I didn’t say anything, not wanting to admit I felt a bit foolish for my actions but also knowing it was what any good Hunter would have done.

“I’m kind of surprised though, Jethic wouldn’t usually chew anyone out like that. He has a bit of a fear of confrontation. Not with monsters of course, just with other people.”

“You know what they say, even a mouse.”

“Actually I never heard that before, what does it mean?”

“The full saying is even a mouse can turn into a lion. It means there is a limit to what everybody can take. And when backed into a corner or they finally get tired of running they will turn around and transform into a ferocious animal. Even shy timid people will have their moments. So it seems this was one of his.”

“Even a mouse. I like that. I’ll have to remember that for the future.”

We watched as the group finally finished off the monster, getting a scrap of Glif skin for their troubles. Jethic held it high in the air as they all cheered. Though I did notice that Gregory was left out of the small celebration, left to cheer alone. That scrap of skin would probably net them around two Reul each, since the going rate was around ten Reul fifty Knutz. Not a lot honestly but it was still a bit of pocket change. Perhaps the first they had earned so far as Hunter’s in training. The Arena Master would sell it for them before splitting the profit, that was just how the system worked.

Once they were off the field the first two groups went back out again to fight some Spindler’s. a type of construct creature that looked like giant crystallized rocks with six legs growing out of the back of the body. They had no mouths and no eyes that were obvious, relying mostly on echo location like a bat. That and their speed were the biggest things they had going for them. Their crystallized bodies acted as a slight deterrent to most slashing weapons, even bouncing weak spells off harmlessly. The way to go was blunt and piercing. But neither group had such weapons, making this fight more even to their skill levels.

I saw movement out of the corner of my eye as the two groups began fighting and was surprised to see my father walking towards the teacher holding the hand of a little girl. I was already heading down the steps to the floor by the time my father began speaking in a low tone with the Arena Master.

“Zelkov, your father wants to talk with you privately. You are welcome to use the locker room if you wish. No thanks Henry, I’ve already got a room set aside. I don’t want to hold up your classes if things take long. Thanks for the offer though.”

The teacher shrugged as I followed my father back out into the hall. As we walked I studied him out of the corner of my eye. The first thing I noticed was the dark circles, telling me he hadn’t had much sleep lately. The next thing I noticed was the gray in his hair. There was more of it then I last remembered when I had seen him almost a month ago. The blue shirt he wore barely hid his impressive physique, even for a man pushing forty. He didn’t say anything as we walked, his sun tanned skin seeming to soak up the artificial light.

My gaze strayed down to the little girl walking between us. No, on closer inspection I realized she wasn’t walking on her own, it was more like her body moved reflexively because my father was pulling her forward. Her eyes had the empty look I had seen on a few other shock victims. There was no sense of life in those scarlet irises at all. A face as expressive as stone to go with the blank eyes. If I hadn’t noticed the light rise and fall of her chest as she breathed I would have thought her a puppet. Her silver white hair coupled with those scarlet eyes made me instantly think albino, but her skin, while white, was still the same peach tone as everyone else. So those colors must be her natural ones.

She held a teddy bear close to her chest with her left hand, crushing the slightly ratty stuffed animal to a lime green dress that I personally found quite disgusting. When my father opened the door to a simple whitewashed room with a single table and six chairs inside, I saw her fingers squeeze the bear a little tighter. She was scared. But of who or what I didn’t know.

Spinning one of the chairs around I rested my chin on top of the hands I folded along the back while watching my father and the girl. He carefully pushed her down into a seat across the table from me before and positioned her just like a doll before sitting next to her. He looked from the girl to me and then at the table where he clasped his hands.

“So… how are things with you son?”

“Same old, same old. Weren’t you on a job and not supposed to come back for like another three or four days?”

“Some things came up and I managed to get it done early.”

We fell silent then, having exhausted our knowledge of the other’s life after our greeting. Honestly he was barely more than a name on paper saying he was my father. I had closer relationships with near strangers than I did with him and my mother. We had played a few strategy games when I was a kid but that was about it. He scratched the back of his head, trying to find something to say so I decided to get down to business.

“So what do you want? I’ll assume it is a job of some sort, since that is the only reason I can think of that you would come here. It’s a fifty-fifty bet that mother put you up to it too, thinking to milk more out of me by using you instead of coming herself.”

“Well I won’t deny it. Your mother did send me. Though it is more because she didn’t want to fight with you than anything else.”

“I don’t believe that for a second.”

My father looked like he was about to say something but shook his head after taking a small breath.

“Anyway, your mother wanted to know if you would protect this girl for a few days. Only until someone your mother knows can come pick her up.”

“What’s so special about her that she needs a Hunter protecting her? Political refugee? Some foreign dignitaries daughter? And why me? Any Hunter would do in that case. Especially since she didn’t want me getting my license in the first place.”

“She’s a monster summoner with unstable powers. Not any Hunter would do, unless we were looking to get her killed. You are one of the few that are both strong enough and wouldn’t kill her out of hand. Asala here lost her parents three days ago. Seeing them die in front of her activated her latent ability, sending it out of control. You can handle anything she might throw out and you are good with kids. Considering she hasn’t eaten or slept in three days, being sustained on magic instead, I thought that would be an important factor.”

“And I suppose neither you nor mother can do it because you are going to be off on another mission?”

“Correct. We leave later on today actually.”

“Why am I not the least bit surprised? What about another Hunter. Surely between the two of you someone else has to come to mind."

"Well there is Pelei and Rinik. Wait, Rinik is off on a mission of his own I think and Pelei… well Pelei is Pelei. Personally he wouldn’t be my first choice.”

“But he is a more experienced Hunter than me. And licensed at that.”

“What, not going to say he is better?”

“No. In straight up skill I am better than him.”

My father grinned at my matter of fact statement.

“Indeed he might have more battle experience than you but unlike your mother, I’d rather the girl go to someone who will take care of her not only physically but mentally and emotionally. Pelei is lacking in two of those three categories. Your mother didn’t take that into account when she sent me of course but I am.”

“I also bet she wants this all under the table.”

“I won’t deny that either.

“This is a pretty slimy way she is handling things . You know that right? She should have come herself to deal with me even if we did end up arguing.”

“Would you have been able to be as objective about your answer if she had?”

I thought about it for a moment before finally shaking my head with a sigh. “No, probably not. Still I don’t like the way she is doing things.”

Glancing at the girl who’s fingers were barely twitching as they squeezed the stuffed animal I wondered what to do. It was true Pelei was a bit of an eccentric, but he would take good care of her. If I took this job I couldn’t help but feel I would be playing into my mother’s hands somehow. I could help her, there was no doubt in my mind about that. Ultimately a part of me really didn’t want the hassle of a full time protection mission like this under these circumstances. Was me taking this job the best choice? Would the safety of everyone in the city and this little girl be best served if I took this job?
1111211121122.title: Head towards them

11112111211221.content:
“Fine you got yourself a deal. Just as long as mother didn’t want you to try and get some ridiculous promise out of me like having to continue to go to classes while protecting her.”

My father looked away at that while rubbing the back of his neck. I had to close my eyes and count to three before I said anything else.

“Please say that’s not the case. She doesn’t really expect me to do that does she?”

“All right, I won’t say that’s the case. That’s why you only agreed to do this as a favor under the table without any other strings attached. And why I will be going to inform the office that you will not be coming the next few days.”

He twiddled his thumbs a moment while looking around the room, not quite sure what else to say or how to end this meeting. I decided I might as well do it myself. Otherwise he’d just make himself look like a fool trying to be a father.

“Well if our business is done, then go run off to do whatever you have to do and leave me to get to work.”

With a nod he got up, a bit of relief flickering across his face before he turned away. He only made it two steps though before turning to face me again.

“Say, son. If you don’t mind, do you think I could hang around for a bit? Our flight doesn’t leave until this evening and I’d like to see how you operate. Maybe learn how to deal with children better.”

“What? Trying to learn a new trick at your age? Don’t you feel ashamed to be learning how to deal with kids from your own son?”

“Never stop learning remember? Even someone as old as me can learn something new. And if you must know, yes I am a bit ashamed to be learning it from you, but I also feel it will be useful information.”

“Suit yourself, just try not to get in my way.”

With that I blocked him out of my mind, focusing all my attention on the little girl as I thought how best to approach this situation. There were numerous ways I could go about this to achieve the same results in the end. Broken down her trouble was a combination of shock and trauma so I needed to deal with both of them. When I finally settled on a course of action I let a smile play over my face before walking around the table and kneeling in front of the girl so I was on eye level with her.

“So your name is Asala huh? I had some Asala once, a bit spicy but it went well with the chips. Wait, no. That was salsa, never mind. Still Asala is a pretty name. I know you can hear me even if you want to deny it. So you can just listen to me ramble for a little bit ok? If you get bored you can always tell me to stop.”

Taking a deep breath I lifted her little hand in mine, giving it a small squeeze while trying to convey comfort to her.

“I can understand why you ran away inside your head. A lot of bad things happened didn’t they? And you saw a lot of scary stuff I bet. Plus right now I bet you are drowning in your sadness, with an empty pit in your stomach where your parents used to be. I bet you feel nothing will ever be able to fill that hole ever again. On top of that you suddenly got this ability to call monsters that you can’t control. I bet they come more often when you think about your parents too. So I don’t blame you for running into your head and shutting down like this.”

I saw her Adam’s apple bob up and down as she suppressed the sorrow I had intentionally invoked. Her hand tightening on the bear even more as the edge of her eyes got wet. With a gentle thumb I wiped them away while cupping her cheek in my palm.

“I know the feelings going on inside of you. But you know what? You’re not alone right now. Being alone makes those feelings harder to bear. It’s not a sin to let those feelings out. And if you summon a monster because of it, so what. I’ll beat it back where it came from lickity-split. You deserve to let the tears come. Because I bet you loved you mom and dad a lot. Those tears are a way of expressing those feelings. That’s part of what they call grief.”

Slowly I reached out, pulling her into my chest and wrapping my arms around her. She didn’t respond at all as I softly stroked her hair and continued in a slightly softer tone.

“That pain you feel is like a big wound. Even though no one can see it and it doesn’t bleed like a normal wound does, it still needs healing. Being able to cry it all out is part of that process. Time will also help, but the fact is, it will hurt for a long time to come. Even when you think you are completely healed, you will hear something that sparks a memory or see something that reminds you of them and it will all come back for a short time. But you know, pain can be a good thing too. Because it proves that you are alive. While you are alive you can remember them and prove that they lived too. It can make you stronger as well. But you should never be afraid to let it all out.”

I continued to stroke her hair while rocking her gently back and forth, making some soothing sounds while repeating that she wasn’t alone over and over. Mainly trying to convey that she was safe and could let it all out without worry. After about four minutes her hands finally came up to grasp me tightly as she buried her face in my tunic. I simply continued to comfort her as her muffled wails made it past the fabric. I let her cry herself out, pulling out my handkerchief to wipe the snot from her nose once she was done.

“There that’s better isn’t it? And look, no monsters appeared. I want you to make me a promise ok? If you ever feel like letting it all out again like that don’t try to hold it in. I don’t care where you are or what anyone else says you let it all out ok? And I’ll be there to hold you through it all. Is that a deal?”

I held up my pinky as she sniffed and nodded her head. She looked at my hand for a moment before linking her own small finger in mine and we shook on it. I gave her a lopsided grin and a mischievous wink, eliciting a hesitant smile from her.

“Now What’s this I hear about you not eating or sleeping huh? We are going to change that whether you like it or not. I’m going to run you ragged today until you will beg for a big soft bed to pass out in. I’ll stuff you with so much food all the new clothes I am going to buy you might not fit in a day or two. And I tell you what little girl, I bet you are going to love every minute of it.”

She let out a small giggle at the way I tilted my head to the side and raised my eyebrow in her direction. Getting to my feet I offered her my hand which she took with only a small bit of hesitation, not yet fully trusting me. But I didn’t expect instant trust, right now I would settle for being a lifeline back to reality. She saw me as safe and that was a start. The rest would come later.

Leaving the room I led the little girl back to the combat arena with my father hovering in the shadows. I had to wait for my class to finish changing and the next class to get done as well before going in and grabbing my duffle bag. Once that was securely riding on my back I made a bee line for the front doors. Asala crowded close to my leg even though she was holding my hand, as if she was afraid of getting too far away from me. When I turned left to head for town my father spoke up and pointed to the car parked across the street.

With a dip of my head in acknowledgment, the three of us headed towards it and got in. Once me and Asala were seated comfortably in the back my father turned around to ask where I wanted to go. Looking down at the skinny little girl sitting next to me in her ugly green dress I wondered what to do first.
11112111211221.title: Take job

111121112112211.content:
“Well since we have a car, head over to Lawson Street on the east side. That was further than I was planning on going but there is a clothing store down there who’s stuff if a bit better than most.”

With a nod my father started the car and we were on our way.

“You mean Chantelle Rouge? I didn’t know you were into stuff like fashion.”

“I’m not. But I’ve learned a thing or two about quality and design. Didn‘t think you would know about a place like the Rouge.”

“When you deal with people like Pelei you learn a thing or two whether you want to or not.”

I grinned at that, since Pelei had been the person I had learned most of what I knew about clothes from. It was kind of hard not to when he got into one of his moods. I kept seeing Asala glancing in my direction, almost as if she was afraid I would disappear if she didn’t keep looking. I made sure to give her a grin and a wink whenever I caught her eye, tightening my fingers around her hand which she still refused to let go of. It didn’t take long for us to get to the east side, the normal thirty to forty minute walk taking only a few moments.

The streets were thankfully a bit deserted at this time of the day, a fact that would no doubt help Asala become more comfortable. The Rouge was an impressive store, taking up a full two block radius. But they also had an impressive selection of men’s and women’s apparel for all sizes to back it up. This was the place I came when I felt the urge to splurge a bit on clothes.

“Hey Riktal! Back so soon? Didn’t think I would see you for another two weeks or so. That new suit not to your liking?”

“No, no It’s fine babe. I’m actually here for this little girl today. Think we could find her something nice? Maybe five or six something’s? With some shoes and jewelry to match of course.”

The woman looked the girl up an down with an expert eye before showing me all her teeth.

“I think we might just have something laying around. What do you think about a light red to go with those eyes? Or an off white to go with the hair?”

“You’re the expert here babe. As long as she likes it is what’s important.”

She motioned me after her, a few of the other shop girls giving me waves of greeting and a few some flirtatious winks. I gave them an empty smile back out of politeness as we wound our way through the racks of clothes until we came to the section dedicated to girls, specifically children. At first Asala was leery, hanging onto my hand with a death grip as the woman held up a few dresses against her front. But after a few whispered words of encouragement from me she finally let go and followed the woman to a dressing room in sight of where I was. As she took the dress inside the stall my father stepped up next to me, talking in a low tone so as not to be overheard.

“Is it really proper for you to be calling her babe? Unless you are in a relationship with her, but she seems a bit older than you.”

“Why? What’s wrong with it?”

“It just seems wrong somehow.”

I grinned at the obvious discomfort my father was in.

“What? Finding it hard to think of me having that kind of relationship?”

“Well… yeah that’s part of it I guess. But it seems too personal. Not at all how a Hunter should be.”

I decided to end his suffering, motioning the woman over from where she was waiting patiently outside of the changing booth.

“Holly, I’d like you to meet my father, Romone Zelkov. Father, I’d like you to meet Holly Babe. I’ve known Holly for what, six years now?”

“At least. I remember you bringing your sister in for a small shopping spree on her eighth birthday. I thought you were already a polite little eleven year old charmer, too grown up for your age.”

“My father here seems to think we have some impure relations going on.”

The woman barked out a laugh, her whole body shaking in mirth. Finally she wiped a tear from her eye as she let out a sigh.

“Me and you? Please, I’ve got kids at least as old as you are! One of them is working the counter now! Besides, my husband might have a thing or two to say about that!”

We both grinned at the look on my father’s face, probably by the fact that the woman didn’t look more than twenty years old with her smooth almond skin and full head of dirty blond hair. I clapped him on the shoulder consolingly.

“Yes, she is much older than the looks. In fact I think she might even be a few years older than you! It’s ok to be shocked. I bet she takes it as a compliment. How old are you now anyway Holly? Forty one?”

“Fourty two. You gave me that warding trinket remember.”

“Oh yeah that’s right! Sorry, it slipped my mind.”

She gave me a wink before going back to the dressing room where Asala was hesitantly stepping out in a light blue dress with white trimming and a little red bow stitched in like a belt. I gave her a once over before offering it my seal of approval with a thumbs up. Her eyes sparkled and her face broke out into a grin that split her face from ear to ear even as Holly offered her another dress, this one a dark satin red with lighter red trimming.

It took a few changes but she slowly got into the shopping like I knew she would. I had to figure the ability to love shopping was coded into female DNA or something. After about the fifth dress she was coming out and posing for me then turning to look at herself in the mirror. Holly knew exactly what to do, sensing the girl needed a bit of a pick-me-up treatment. She was another one of the reasons I had decided to come here, her ability to sense peoples moods and adapt to give the customer the best service possible was incredibly useful.

By the time we left almost two hours later, Asala seemed almost like a regular little girl. Though she still hadn’t actually said anything, she was laughing and smiling like there was no other expression for her face. She even skipped out of the store a step ahead of me, sporting one of her new dresses and shoes. This one was a soft green dress that reminded me of summer meadows, instead of the puke green of the old one.

I tipped Holly generously for her time after setting up arrangements to have the six bags of stuff we had bought delivered to the house. Yet another service this place provided free of charge. Asala was occupied settling her teddy bear in a small harness in front of her originally designed to carry babies. She didn’t seem to care though, since her stuffed animal had it’s own place of honor now.

“So, Asala. Have you enjoyed yourself so far?”

She nodded her head up and down vigorously, reminding me of a bobble head toy.

“And do you like your new threads?”

Again the jackhammer nodding.

“Well then I guess it’s time to go stuff your face like I promised to try to get you to fill them out properly. But I guess I should ask this first, are you hungry?”

Even though she nodded her head, she really didn’t need to say anything. Her stomach chose that moment to grumble demandingly. I grinned a bit as she blushed and looked down at the ground. Giving her hair a quick ruffle I pointed down the street to a family restaurant.

“They can make you anything you want. And I mean anything. They don’t even have a menu. You just tell them and they make it. Plus they have some brownies that are just out of this world. I wouldn’t be surprised if little green aliens came down just to eat them. So here is the deal, we go there and we eat. Then you can have some of those brownies with vanilla ice cream on top. But you must enjoy yourself while eating or I can’t take you. Think you can handle that deal?”

She didn’t even bother nodding her head this time, simply grabbed my hand and pulled me towards the diner with eyes that seemed to sparkle with a light all their own.
111121112112211.title: Shopping for clothes

1111211121122111.content:
The booth I was sitting in was jiggling courtesy of the little girl sitting next to me. Her feet were kicking back and forth, the heels tapping against the wooden baseboard as she ate her meal. It had taken a bit of twenty questions and getting yes and no answers before I was able to order her sunny side up eggs, ham, toast and orange juice. A regular breakfast for lunch. My father sat across from us, silently eating some stuffed peppers looking our way thoughtfully. He had kept silent for the most part and honestly it made me a bit uneasy having him around so much. I wasn’t used to either one of my parents actually being around for more than an hour at the most.

I simply enjoyed my steak and mushroom platter , listening to Asala humming to herself while she stuffed her face. My father chewed another bite of his meal before finally speaking up for the first time in almost two hours.

“Looks like there is a lot about you I don’t know.”

“Looks like.”

“Listen, son. I…”

I cut him off with a wave of the hand before he could utter another word.

“If your planning on saying something like I’m sorry for not being around or some other crap like that don’t bother. The facts are the facts, isn’t that what you taught me? Don’t make excuses and don’t waste your words on empty apologies. You weren’t around and I grew up. That’s just how it is. Not that you should have expected any other outcome. Don’t try acting like a father now when all is said and done. We are both Hunter’s and that’s it.”

“I know I’ve made some choices you don’t understand or agree with, and I can’t change what’s already done. But can’t you see I’m at least trying?”

“What, with these few hours? You think watching me from the shadows in an attempt to learn how to deal with kids means you are trying? It means nothing. It meant nothing to me from the very beginning. I would have dealt with her the same way even if you weren’t watching. Your presence was only for your own benefit not mine.”

I was about to continue but Asala tugged on my tunic gently. When I looked over at her there was a sorrow in her eyes as she shook her head back and forth slowly.

“Don’t fight with your daddy.”

Her voice was soft and hesitant, the almost musical tone of it tinted with the same sadness that showed in her eyes. I let my arm reach out to stroke her hair as I gave her a smile.

“All right sweetie. I’ll just leave it at that for now.”

She grinned at me before going back to eating, seeming to feel the matter was settled. There was more I would have said, but my number one priority was to the little girl. In my mind that covered more than just protecting her, that also covered her mental balance. If she didn’t want me arguing for whatever reason, then I would accede to her wishes. My father dropped the subject as well, a small blessing I thought. At least he seemed to understand I had stopped for the girls sake and did the same.

We spent the rest of the meal in a strained silence. But honestly I was more comfortable with things this way. I knew how to handle my father and mother when things were like this. I didn’t know how to deal with them all that well when they tried acting like parents. That’s why I preferred to treat them as Hunter’s.

Asala didn’t seem to pick up on the undertones floating between us though, simply off in her own thoughts as she happily ate the meal and the promised brownies and ice cream. Once it was all paid for I saw her yawning and suppressed a grin.

“What’s this? Sleepy already? But it’s barely five o’clock! Don’t tell me you are ready for a nice big soft bed! We have so much more day left!”

She tried shaking her head no to say she wasn’t sleepy but I could see by the way she rubbed her eyes and tried hiding another yawn. As we all walked back to the car I pulled her in to my side, giving her a one handed hug. Now that I had broken her self imposed shell and magic was no longer supporting her body, it was all coming crashing in on her. Her body was making demands that she had neglected over the last three days, letting the magic take care of it.

The drive home didn’t take long and my father dropped us off before driving away again with a quick farewell, saying he would see me in a week or so. The shopping bags were all sitting on the front porch already so it only took a few seconds to unlock the spell and shuffle it all inside. Grabbing out the new night dress we had bought for her and her personal kit full of toothbrush and toothpaste among other things, I led her upstairs. It only took a few minutes to show her to my room where she could sleep and the bathroom as well.

I set her toothbrush and other items on the sink, telling her to consider this her home while she was here before handing her the pajamas and pointing at the bath.

“I don’t allow dirty bodies to sleep in my bed. So get yourself cleaned up and get to sleep. Your body needs the rest. I’ll be downstairs if you need me but don’t worry I’ll be sleeping in the same room later to keep away anything scary.”

She gave me a nod as I left the bathroom, shutting the door on her and waiting only a moment until I heard the sound of running water. While she was occupied I quickly slipped out of my school uniform into something more comfortable, dropping them into the hamper for cleaning tomorrow. Once that was done I slipped back downstairs and into the living room, turning on the TV more out of habit of having it on for the noise than because I was interested in watching anything. Picking up the latest edition of Swords and Sorcery I began reading some of the articles.

With one ear I heard the water finally begin to drain, the old house making even that simple sound echo in the silence. There was the creaking of the floorboard outside of my room so I knew she had gone inside. After that there was silence again as I smiled to myself. She had probably passed out the moment she had crawled under the covers.

My head jerked to the right at the sound of the first step creaking, only to find Asala walking into the room rubbing her eyes, struggling to stay awake, her teddy bear almost dragging the ground in her right hand. Without a word she climbed onto the couch next to me, laying her head in my lap as her lips curved upwards in contentment.

“Night.”

Laying my hand on her head I felt my own lips beginning to curl.

“Goodnight Asala.”

*********

What is it that makes a person choose the way they do? Is it his environment? His upbringing? How does he choose when he has two thoughts that are both equally valid? Is it simply a matter of what thought pops into his mind first? Is that the essence of free will that you humans prize? Or are your choices really choices at all? If indeed the way you decide is influenced by the society you live in, the way you are brought up, the environment in which you live, then is that really choice?

1111211121122111.title: Lets eat!

111121112112212.content:
“Well since we have a vehicle, let’s go over to the east side. There is a diner there called The Sunwalker. I think we should fatten this little girl up a bit before we go looking for clothes to fit her.”

With a nod my father pulled out of the parking space and we were on our way. Asala kept glancing over at me as we drove, as if afraid I would suddenly disappear if she wasn’t looking. Every so often her little hand would squeeze mine where she held it between us and I would squeeze back in reassurance, a smile on my lips. I had become a secondary lifeline for her, something she could believe in aside from her teddy bear. It wasn’t that unusual for children who had gone through traumas to latch onto someone or something that made them feel safe. I might have guided her towards needing me like this, but it had been for her own benefit.

“That diner is the one on Lawson street right? The one where they will make anything you want?”

“Yeah.”

“Isn’t that place a bit expensive? Didn’t know you liked that kind of stuff.”

“There is a lot you don’t know about me. I do occasionally like to splurge from time to time. There is nothing wrong with paying for slightly higher quality service. Besides, I think the food and the service there are worth the price of admission.”

I glanced over at Asala who was looking up at me with her big crimson eyes so I gave her a mischievous wink, eliciting a grin.

“Besides, I think Asala will enjoy it and their brownies topped with vanilla ice cream. I doubt she has tasted anything like it.”

It only took around ten minutes to drive over to the restaurant and another moment or two to be seated. I spent a good four of five minutes asking Asala a bunch of simple yes and no questions before I could order for her. The waitress waited patiently for me to continue, not even showing a hint of impatience like others might. Such was the quality of the staff in this place.

As we waited for our food my father sat quietly watching the two of us, trying to soak up every little detail of how I interacted with the girl. I didn’t mind if he wanted to watch, his presence was not required and wouldn’t affect anything I said or did. My priorities were for the girl so thoughts of embarrassment or anything else did not factor in. Both him and mother were rarely around anyway so it was easy to simply forget he was there.

“So Asala, what colors do you like? I picture you in neon yellow. You know, all lit up and glowing like a Christmas light as you walk down the street.”

I wrinkled my nose and made a face at that, letting her know I was joking but she was already shuddering at the thought. She gave me a small giggle though which was a start. I continued to occupy her time until the food came, trying to elicit a bit of information about her without making her focus on her past too much. I hadn’t got her to have enough fun today yet. If she really got to thinking her sorrow would come back full blast. Something I wanted to avoid for now.

My plan seemed to be working quite well until her meal came. It was a simple plate of sunny side up eggs, hash browns, ham and toast along with some juice. The hash browns had been cut in half and arranged along with the rest to make it all look like a giant smiling face. She took one look at it before water started flowing from her eyes. Even as I reached out for her she was already turning to clutch at my tunic. The waitress looked unsure but I waved her away with a shake of my head, getting a nod in return before she left us alone. I stroked her hair gently as I made soothing noises.

“What’s wrong Asala? Does the way the plate looks like a smiling face remind you of your parents?”

Her head nodded up and down as she cried a little harder.

“Is it a good memory?

Again that nod as her arms tightened around me.

“Well then don’t hold it back. Just because they are gone doesn’t mean all the time you spent with them was bad. You had these good times as well that you can remember. Keep those memories close you hear me? They will help you get through the rough times ahead. Don’t focus on how they died, or why they did. Focus on those memories of how they lived. Make that your strength. Make that your proof.”

She continued to cry for a little while longer and I continued to hold her. Finally with another sniff she rubbed her nose along the skin of her arm. With a sigh I grabbed some napkins to clean her up shaking my head a bit.

“We’ve got to teach you some manners girl. Otherwise your skin is going to turn the same ugly shade of green as your dress. You know what else has that color right? Acid. Keep rubbing your snot off like that and your skin will start melting. It’s true. Acid snot. I just made it up.”

She sniffed again but grinned at my bit of humor and the too serious look I had on my face as I kissed her forehead and ruffled her hair affectionately. After a moment more of clinging to me she picked up her fork and stared at the plate, finally stabbing one of the pieces of hash brown. She shoved it into her mouth as a few tears began to roll down her cheeks again. But she refused to cling to me this time. With a smile I stroked her hair gently.

“Good girl Asala. You’re going to become strong, I just know it.”

The rest of the meal went without incident and she did indeed enjoy the brownies with ice cream just as I thought she would. A look of glee spreading across her face with the first bite and continuing until the last.

The staff were too well schooled and paid enough not to comment on what they saw or spread any kind of gossip, yet another point in this places favor. I made sure to tip them well as I paid the bill and we left the diner, just to make sure their eyes forgot what they saw. Once back out on the street I wrapped one arm around the little girls shoulder, heading to a clothing store only a few blocks down.

“Now we will get you some real clothes. I wouldn’t say this place has everything you could ever think of wanting or needing, but I bet that’s not far off the mark. Now I want you to go in there and have fun you hear me? I know all girls seem to love shopping so I want you to enjoy it too. You best not worry about how much it costs or anything like that. You shop and you shop until you are satisfied ok? If that ends up being only thirty Knutz or thirty thousand Reul, you let me worry about that. It might not be a permanent cure to the pain, but I’ve learned even such things as this can be considered needed medicine.”

With that I opened the door to a world of heaven made of fabric instead of clouds. I had a feeling she was really going to enjoy Chantelle Rouge and this would become one of the biggest turning points on her road to recovery.
111121112112212.title: Grab a bite to eat

1111211121122121.content:
“Hey Sugar! I didn’t expect to see you back in here so soon! That suit not fit right or something?”

“No, it fits fine Honey. I’m here for this little girl today, I think she could do with some of the tender loving care that only this place can provide.”

“I’m tickled you thought of us sugar. Hunter business I take it?”

“Aye.”

“I’ll pass it around no worries sugar. But us standing around gabbing won’t put something decent on this child. That dress is so not her. How could you let her walk around in such a dreadful thing?”

“Not really my choice Honey. But she is here now so stop complaining.”

“Such a taskmaster you are! You best tip well for this sugar.”

“Don’t I always?”

With a laugh she motioned us to follow her deeper into the store to where the girls clothing was. Her long blond hair bouncing against her spine, the ends patting her back right over the butt she was swishing playfully for me. Even with her back turned to me I could still almost imagine her deep blue eyes watching my every move. Seeming to read my thoughts she looked over her shoulder, giving me a playful grin along with a wink.

Soon enough though she was holding dresses up against Asala’s front making little grunts of approval or denial. She even held up some shirt and pant combo’s but Asala didn’t seem to like too many of those, preferring the dresses instead. It wasn’t like the old days where it was strange to see women in pants, there were many who wore them regularly. So if Asala wanted to wear dresses, I wouldn’t say anything against it.

When the woman led Asala to a changing room with a deep purple dress lined with a lighter purple that looked like it was made of velvet, my father stepped up next to me to speak for the first time.

“So are you and her a couple? Is that why you are so against the arranged marriages your mother sets up for you?”

“No, why would you think that.”

“Well you call her honey and she calls you sugar. That sounds like a bit of an intimate relationship there.”

I let out a chuckle as I motioned the young woman over.

“My father here seems to think me and you have something going on so I thought I would clear up the misunderstanding. Father, I’d like you to meet Holley Babe. But since that’s also the same name as her mother we all call her Honey.”

“On account of my sweet personality.”

“Ha! Your only sweet when you are getting paid to be. Outside of this store you are about as sweet as sour grapes mixed with vinegar.”

“What’d you say you egotistical overbearing needle nosed…”

“I’m a paying customer right now.”

“…Sweet man you?”

We both grinned and began to laugh, having a bit of fun with each other like we normally did.

“Seriously though, she is sweet inside and outside of the store, but there’s nothing between us.”

“Not that I haven’t tried.”

“You’re just too sweet for me. I’d die of sugar overdose within a day.”

“Ah but what a day that would be sugar!”

The door to the dressing room opened then and Asala came out wearing the new dress. She seemed a bit unsure about how she looked but Honey gushed over her and I let out a low whistle of appreciation when she glanced my way. My approval seemed to mean more than Honey’s words as she grinned and did a little pirouette for my benefit. Honey pushed another dress into her hands, this one a shiny black with no sleeves, before turning her around to put it on.

I left Honey to her work, only making small sounds of approval and a few catcalls as Asala came out in a new dress time after time. After about the fourth such change she seemed to really begin to blossom, posing in the mirror and for me. The smile on her face was so wide and her eyes shone so brightly I wondered why her face didn’t crack. But it was a true look of joy, not one she was putting on for my benefit.

Honey also got her outfitted with new shoes, prettied her up with make-up and even a few pieces of jewelry. With Asala’s consent Honey gave the girl her first ear piercing which seemed to make her even happier. Honey never let her sit around idle for long though, helping her pick out everything from underwear to perfume and even personal bath towels. She also produced a harness from somewhere Asala could strap onto either her front or back to let her stuffed animal have it’s own place, freeing up both her hands.

Though I didn’t have the same eerie ability to read minds as Honey and her mother had, judging from the girl’s body language I knew she was past the crisis point now. Though I wasn’t actually certain if the two of them could actually read minds or if they just read body language like I did. Still their skill to adapt and give their customers a completely enjoyable and satisfying experience was quite amazing. Honey looked at me then as she stuck a hair ornament in Asala’s hair, giving me a playful wink as if in response to my thoughts.

Finally after about two hours Honey led us over to a register to cash us out, leaving Asala with a look of dreamy eyed bliss on her face.

“Let’s see, ten Knutz fifty Senz for the ear studs. Fifty Knutz for the perfume. All told your total comes out to four hundred and one Reul, forty Knutz, and twenty five Senz. Plus your promised tip of course.”

Pulling out my wallet I slipped a five hundred Reul bill from it, starting to hand it over when she gave me another of her mischievous smiles.

“You know, I could forgo a monetary tip in exchange for a physical one. Say a nice long passionate kiss.”

I finished laying the bill on the counter without even batting an eyelash. I was used to such proposals from her so they didn’t even catch me off guard anymore.

“Keep the change as your tip Honey.”

Noticing the way Asala was trying to hide a yawn I grinned more to myself then anyone else.

“Also, think you could send all this over to my place with one of your delivery boys?”

“No problem sugar.”

“Thanks Hon.”

We left the store then, with Asala reaching up to touch her new earrings and smiling foolishly to herself; her bear sitting in its place of honor on her chest, watching the world from under her chin. We climbed back into the car as my father asked where to next, driving off after I told him home.

“Well then why did you want them to deliver the packages if you were planning on going there anyway?”

I stroked the little girls hair where she was already asleep nestled in the crook of my arm.

“That way I don’t have to worry about unloading the car and I will have my hands empty to carry her inside. I purposefully ran her ragged today so her body would burn off the last bit of magic that was supporting her. Once it was gone her body reasserted it’s natural needs, and one of those was sleep. If she wakes up I don’t want her to think that I am gone. Right now I’m an anchor point for her in this reality.”

“You really are good with kids son.”

“I know.”

The girl snuggled even deeper into my side as she smiled slightly.

“I love you.”

I didn’t know if she was awake or asleep, or if she was talking to me or a dream phantom. But I hugged her tighter anyway as I replied.

“I love you too little one.”

That made her smile grow a little more.

11112111211222.content:
Cocking my head to the side I looked into the girls expressionless face.

“Well Asala, I’ll be frank with you. I know you can hear me even if you do act like you are completely disconnected from the world. That’s because you are still holding that teddy bear in your hands. Anyone truly disconnected would have dropped it long ago. So you can at least hear what is going on even if you don’t react to it.”

I saw my father do a double take then slap his forehead at overlooking something so obvious.

“How the hell did I not realize that! Or anyone else for that matter!”

I ignored his muttered words as I continued to stare into her eyes.

“I’m sure you know more about this situation than anyone. You have probably overheard everything my father hasn’t told me and put a few things together on your own. So here are the facts, part of me doesn’t want to take this job because I feel I will be falling into one of my mother’s ploys somehow. Like a fly getting caught in the spider’s web. Plus I am not sure if me being the one to guard you would best serve both you and everyone else in this city.

“I do know I could do it though. If you come with me you will be forced to live. I will break you out of that shell and you won’t be able to hide inside your head after that like you are now. I’ll make you eat real food and get real sleep, not relying on magic to do it for me. But if you end up going to Pelei you will die. He will protect you just as well as I can, but he won’t try to pull you out of your shell. He will treat you just like a doll, much like you are being treated now. He will continue to dose you with magic to sustain you.

“In case you don’t know, magic can only keep the body alive for so long without real food and sleep. In a day or two your body will become extremely weak if you don’t feel it happening already. It will eat itself up and kill you. No amount of magical dosing or healing can change that. So my question is, what do you want? Do you want to live? If so I want you to chose me of your own accord. Get up and come over to my side under your own power. But if your desire to die right now is greater than your will to live, then continue to sit there and do nothing. I’ll give you five minutes to decide. If at the end of that five minutes you haven’t moved an inch, then I am going to walk out that door and not come back. Think quickly, the clock begins now.”

“Riktal.” My father looked at the girl for a moment and then at me. “Son, if you really think that is the case and she will die if she goes to Pelei, then you have to take care of her.”

“Why?”

“Because…” His hand twirled in the air as he sought an answer.”

“Because she has to live.”

“Say’s who? Living is a choice. Perhaps the ultimate choice. Who are we to say it is wrong to want to die? To have the desire to take their own life?”

“But they were given the gift of life by The One God! They can’t just throw that away! He has a plan for them.”

“So what? They still have the option of accepting the gift given to them or not. Saying they will go to one of the eight circles of Hell if they commit suicide is idiotic. The teachings state The One God loves all his children without stipulation. I might not be a religious fanatic or anything but I do know the basic gospel. Saying she has to live for the sake of living is simply you trying to push your own morels and your own beliefs onto her. Trying to make her conform to this standard society has set as to what is right and wrong.”

“But it’s not right!”

“Says who? You? The Priests? Some random stranger out on the street? If you want to go into a theological debate about right and wrong then I can accommodate you. Do you think it’s right that I know more about the waitress’ down at The Pipe than I do you or mother? Do you think it’s right I’m not allowed to become a licensed Hunter? Or that both mother and you decided to bring this problem to me, trying to get me to accept a job that should be handled by someone with a license?”

I was getting mad now. I could feel the heat rising to my face as I raised my voice and stared my father down.

“What about me huh? Do you think it’s right that I’m always alone at home while you and mother are off god knows where doing god knows what for any untold amount of time? Or is it right that I turn every TV and radio in the house on every night so I can close my eyes and pretend there is someone else there? You want me to continue? I can go on for days! Because I am damn sure you think every single one of those things are right because those are all the choices you both made. If you had any qualms it never stopped you from shoving them to the side and doing it anyway!

“But do you think I think those were the right choices? Hell no I don’t. I think every single one of the choices you have ever made in your lives where I was concerned was wrong. I grew up without parents! I had to learn what I did from other people! Learn what you and mother should have taught me as parents and not as Hunters! So which one of us is right then huh? You or me? You think she should live simply because she is alive right now? I call bull on that. If she want’s to die then let her die.”

“You don’t believe that son.”

“Like hell I don’t! Do I think it’s the right choice if she decides to die? No I don’t. I don’t agree with it at all. But do I understand it and will I accept her decision? Of course, because that is what she thinks is right. That is the decision she can live with so to speak. But I suppose someone like you wouldn’t understand that. After all you barely batted an eye when mother murdered Olia. A murder you helped perpetrate with your own inactions and blind eyes. A week! Only eight days did you stay home then. The longest you have probable ever been in that house in your life! Just long enough to see to the funeral arrangements and the burial then it was off to some corner of the world on another job for some third world country. I’m sure you thought that was the right decision too, even though I thought it just proved you were unfit to be called parents! There is no black and white in this world father. So don’t presume to tell me what is right and what isn’t!”

I glanced over at the girl who still hadn’t moved a muscle during that entire exchange.

“One minute left girl. Last chance to change your mind.”

The seconds seemed to go by in slow motion as the small magical timer counting down at the corner of my left eye that only I could see made their way to zero. I saw my father staring at me sadly, as if he wanted to refute my arguments. But he knew I was right. There was no counterargument he could make to justify himself or prove me wrong. At least he had the good sense to keep his mouth shut when he knew he had lost. The timer finally hit zero and the girl still hadn’t budged an inch, with a nod I headed for the door.

“I hope you don’t suffer too much girl. But you made your decision and I respect that.”

I glanced at my father one last time as I opened the door.

“Take her to Pelei and then run off to do whatever it is you think is so important like you always do. If you really think she should live or want to force your views onto her then cancel your job and protect her yourself. Though we both know you won’t do that. Work has always taken top priority over everything else hasn’t it? Plus you are almost as bad with kids as mother is so you wouldn’t be able to do anything to help her anyway.”

I headed for the combat arena, making it back to class just as the bell rang. It took only a moment to grab my duffle bag from the locker and sling it over my shoulder. So I was one of the first ones out the door, marching straight back to the classroom on the second floor. Before I got far though the principal wheeled herself up alongside me quietly.

“Would you talk with me for a bit boy?”

“Is that an order?”

“No. Merely an old woman seeking a bit of company. You are free to refuse if you want.”

“Did my father put you up to this?”

“Romone? No. I just feel like rambling for a bit that’s all.”

“Then why me? I’m sure you could ramble to anyone you feel like.”

“Because, the other teachers who are free have listened to me ramble often enough and I won’t take any of the other students out of class where they need to learn. You on the other hand don’t need to know any of this so I thought you might like a bit of fresh air and out of the classroom for a bit.”

“You’re up to something old woman. Rambling or not this is out of the ordinary.”

She chuckled a bit and I saw a sparkle of mischief in her eyes.

“You really are a lot like him. But that’s no surprise. Yes I might be up to something. Then again I might not be. Who knows? But if you come with me I’ll let you ask one question and I will answer it honestly. After you listen to my rambling of course.”

With a sigh I flung out my hand dramatically, gesturing for her to go ahead of me.

“Lead the way old woman.”
11112111211222.title: Ask Asala what she wants
