111121112112221.content:
She led me down a side hall and out through one of the many side doors. We passed student’s hurrying from one place to the next, probably having spent a study hall outside or sneaking a bit of make-out with their girlfriend or boyfriend. She led me to a large old gnarled oak tree planted behind the school building near the running tracks where a bench rested under the boughs. Even as she stared up at it in silence a group was leaving the building and heading for the track with a gym teacher.

“This tree has been alive for as long as this school has been open, did you know that? Two hundred and fifty seven years. By all rights it should have died long ago, but with all the magic that has leaked out of the building day after day and year after year it has been given a much longer life. It’s protected this school as a silent sentinel and seen almost as much hardships as any Hunter will face. It’s survived two lightning strikes, a monster infestation, three different plagues, countless alchemy explosions and weathered the hazards of this schools many expansions and additions. The body of the first principal, the one who founded this school, is even laid to rest under it’s roots.

“But as tough a nut as it is to crack, it’s seen it’s fair share of the good times too. Such as countless graduations, tearful farewells, and confessions of love. I had my first kiss under this tree, back when I was around your age. And my first breakup. Back then mortality rates were much lower than they are now and we all knew that. That’s why we all fell in and out of love so quickly and were a bit free with our passions back then. I made a vow with my three best friends the day we graduated under the eaves of this tree too. That we would all meet back up here a year from that day under these same branches.

“I was the only one to make it to that meeting. One died a month after that vow and the other two within six months of that. Not uncommon in our line of work true, but I thought we would each last at least a year. That vow was also the last time I ever saw any of them again. Alive at least.”

She stopped staring up at the tree as she spun to face me, a smile and a distant look in her eyes. A small dog came running up out of nowhere to jump into her lap where she proceeded to pet it absently. I didn’t know what breed it was but it reminded me of a fox with it’s russet coat and white face markings.

“As Hunter’s we make choices. Ones that seem inconsequential and ones that can tip the scales of the very world. Our words carry weight and sometimes more power than our physical bodies do. On our command kings have been overthrown and countries wiped out within a night. We serve the greater good, not any one country, or person. We are an ideal, an image that normal citizen strive to emulate.

“But we aren’t infallible. We are human like everyone else. We have our quirks, our strengths and weaknesses. We make mistakes and we struggle to survive as best we can. Sometimes the choices we make end up hurting others. Be they loved one’s, the impoverished or maybe even the wealthy. But it is up to use to make the hard choices in serving the best interest of the most number of people.”

Wheeling past me she watched the group running around the track. Only sixteen kids in all, but each and every one had the hard eyed look of a Hunter ready for battle. The tense wariness about them of a Hunter on the alert for danger.

“That’s one of the next graduating classes right there. They started out with twenty five of them you know. They watched as nine of their fellows died or dropped out over the last two years. People they called friends, perhaps even family. Look at them. They know the risks they take. They know that within five years their numbers will have dwindled even more. When they have their five year reunion, how many of them will be left? Ten? More than that? Less? Yet even knowing that. Even knowing their families will mourn for them they still chose this path.

“Do you think every one of their families was supportive of them? That some of them haven’t been disowned or kicked out or pressured into giving up? They put aside their own feelings, their own families because they believe they will make a difference. And they are right. Each and every one of them will make a difference. Whether they know it or not they will all make a difference. Even in their deaths will they make a difference. Mistakes, human frailties, quirky personalities and all. They will take jobs they won’t be able to talk about even with their lovers. They will hold secrets inside until the day they die and they will make the world a better place. Because they are Hunter’s. That’s what they do.”

The dog jumped off her lap then after licking her face and ran off barking happily. We both watched it round the corner in silence while the gym teacher’s whistle cut the air nearby.

“So what exactly was your point old lady? I know all that already. I’ve grown up getting that kind of thing pounded into my head. What my job as a Hunter is has never been in question. Or my priorities if it came down to it.”

“Do you really? Then why did you get so angry at your father earlier? You don’t know his circumstances. He is a Hunter too after all. Did you ever consider that even though he felt his decisions were the right ones that he also understood he was hurting you as well? That perhaps there were secrets and missions he couldn’t tell you about that were vitally important to the first directive of the Hunter? That he put you to the side to benefit the citizens?”

“So he did put you up to this.”

“Not at all. He has no idea I am talking to you. In fact he took that little girl and left the room shortly after you did.”

“So you were eavesdropping on us.”

“I found having eyes and ears everywhere is a good way of keeping students out of too much trouble. And when a meeting between two Zelkov’s is involved, I find myself more interested in those eyes and ears. I told you, Hunter’s sometimes keep secrets they take to the grave. How many such secrets do you think I have in this head of mine? But none of them will pass my lips.”

“So you know why my father and mother are never around? Why they were never a part of my life?”

“Yes.”

1111211121122211.content:
“Tut, tut child. You already asked your question. Two of them in fact, though the answer was the same for both. Now run along, I don’t want to keep you from your classes.”

I watched as she wheeled herself off out of sight before turning around and heading back towards the school. I couldn’t help but feel I had been played. That she had never intended to give me any useful information. Just what great secret were they all hiding from me? And why wouldn’t anyone tell me? With a growl of disgust I opened the door into History class. There was a bit of a stir as I made my sullen apologies for being late and took my seat before the teacher started talking again.

It was an old story. The History of Nesta Highwill and her future husband Gint Jervin. I had read the tale of how they stopped the first great war between Hunter’s and the world governments to pave the way for the creation of the Hunter Association. Even though I had read it countless time I still got caught up in the story, perhaps because of the way the teacher told it. Or perhaps it simply felt different because someone was speaking it out loud.

“…..Nesta and Gint began their journey in 0040, three years after the start of the war. As Ronin they had no support from the main Hunter forces. Though in those days we were called Yinshin, a word that meant overpowered in the old tongue of the time. For five years they traveled from one government to the next, putting themselves in great danger but also paving the way for future peace talks. Some governments tried to use them for their own personal schemes, but between the two of them they outwitted all plots. It was almost as if The One God was guiding their movements himself. Indeed some scholars believe this actually was the case.

“Together they were unstoppable. Each making up for the others weaknesses., not even the strongest monsters or the toughest Hunter’s of the time could match them. Is it any wonder then that they eventually became lovers as well? Still, it took them five years to stop the fighting and many lives were lost in the process from both sides, as well as the citizens attacked by monsters. And then another five years to hash out all the details that in the end created the Hunter Union. Many of the rules and ideals we uphold as Hunter’s came down from these two. In a way they were truly the first real Hunter’s.”

The teacher continued on, going into more details about the Hunter Union and the many changes it had gone through over the years. He briefly touched upon the Second Purge, the first being what had sparked the First Uprising in the first place. Before he could talk too much about the Second Purge, or any of the events leading up to the Second Uprising, the bell rang signaling the end of class.

When two boys and two girls came over to chat me up, I simply held up my hand and shook my head, forcing them to stop in confusion.

“I’m sure you are all very interested in me and are plotting your own little schemes to get into my good graces but I am not in the mood right now. So just do an about face and walk away.”

I saw the fake smiles fading from all four faces before they hesitantly turned around. I hadn’t been lying to them just to get them off my back though. Dealing with the principal had left a bad taste in my mouth and a slightly foul mood. Even an entire period of History and listening to one of my favorite stories hadn’t made it go away. Dealing with people just wasn’t high on my priorities right now. When I glanced over towards the windows I saw Liz catch my eye, tapping her finger rapidly on the desk in a basic code all Hunter’s learned.

Now you see why I got bored of this class. To much political jockeying for my taste.

With a sly grin I quickly tapped a reply.

You just need mental strength. You are the type that says they don’t care about other’s feelings but they actually do.

Aren’t you the same way?

Perhaps. But I keep the good of all in mind. I don’t have to play nice with people all the time to make that happen.

She shook her head slightly before calling me a liar with a small smile on her face before turning and looking out the window, ending our conversation. Maybe I was lying to myself, but I was who I was and dealing with my peers was not one of my strong suites. I just didn’t know how to deal with them like I did children and adults. It was like they suddenly became aliens once they hit fourteen or so and didn’t return to normal until around twenty four. Granted there were some adults I still thought were alien that I couldn’t deal well with but they were much fewer and farther apart.

The Monster Tactics teacher came in and took role call before he started in on his lesson. While interesting enough, he said nothing new about the strengths and weaknesses of monsters that I didn’t already know. He did omit the fact that healing magic and potions were effective against Cadaver Dogs, but I really didn’t feel like pointing that out since that information was really only helpful for priests. Not many people would waste a healing potion on a monster.

By the time the bell rang I was ready to go home. I was tired of the constant glances in my direction and the calculating looks. I wanted to tell them all to go screw themselves but I knew that wasn’t proper. Slipping my bag on my back I headed out of the classroom before any of them could try to corner me. I just didn’t want to get into the whole twenty questions I knew they would deluge me with while the girls shamelessly flirted and the guys tried to become instant best friends.

Once I was outside the school gates I stared up at the sky, wondering what to do now. I could go back home, but there was no one and nothing there really. I did want to investigate an artifact shop here on the south side I had been meaning to find for a while to see if the owner could handle level three trinket renewals. But it really wasn’t a pressing matter since I knew the price for such a renewal would be quite high. Perhaps make my rounds of the downtown to keep up with all my contacts there? I hadn’t seen many of them lately.

A whistle behind me made me turn in time to see a group of three boys making catcalls at Lilia from where they were leaning against a tree. The two on the sides were common and forgettable, your average henchmen material. But the one in the middle looked like he was trying to stand out as having a bad boy image with his blue died hair and studded leather jacket. I shook my head at such foolishness, bullies wouldn’t survive long at this or any other Hunter academy. Playing such a role was like admitting you were one step away from dropping out or you were just a loser all around.

When Lilia didn’t respond to their catcalling they converged around her like hyenas sensing a meal. for her part Lilia had that disinterested faraway look on her face, seeming not to notice the three boys circling her trying to either flirt or bully. I couldn’t tell which from their low tones. After a moment a burst of pale light expanded around Lilia, sending all three of them flying. The two henchmen flew off to either side to land a few feet away while the leader of the group sailed through the open gate right towards me.

I briefly considered stopping his fall but decided against it, simple taking one large step to the left. He twisted slightly, trying to break his fall with one hand but only succeeded in breaking his hand instead when it smashed into the cement. The bone snapping and breaking the skin by the time his butt touched down. He began to yell even as Lilia calmly walked up and laid her hands on his. Within a few moments his bones were back inside his skin and even the scars were fading fast. Letting the faint smile that had been constantly on her face curve upwards a little more she patted him on the head as if he were a little child before turning to walk past me.

I watched her go while nibbling my lip. Something told me I should follow her, if for nothing else than because I felt she was a bit lonely just like me. On the other hand something was also suddenly telling me to go check out the artifact store. Which was I supposed to choose?
1111211121122211.title: "Why are my father and mother never around?...

11112111211222111.content:
The feeling of following Lilia won out as I turned after her. It only took a few long strides before I was walking at her side. She didn’t seem to notice I was there though as she hummed to herself, sometimes stopping to smell a flower or squat to watch some ants. When she stepped into the street to cross against the light I held her back with a hand on her shoulder. She gave me a startled look, seeming to see me for the first time as a car sped past where she would have been if I hadn’t stopped her.

“Oh Riktal! How long have you been there?”

“Since we left school.”

“Oh. Ok.”

That seemed to be the extent of her interest as she went back to humming and ignoring me. I could see why people might think her strange and avoid her. But oddly I didn’t feel uncomfortable around her at all. Perhaps it had to do with the fact that she was God-touched. Or maybe because she just didn’t act like everyone else so seemed less alien.

I didn’t even question it when my feet continued going north along with her when I should have headed west to go home. She spoke up then, cocking her head to the side as she looked at me with those slightly dreamy eyes.

“Why are you following me?”

“I don’t know really.”

“Ah, Ok.”

That seemed to satisfy her as we continued on in silence until we came to the cloister. There was a woman wearing a light green cape and a small gnarled staff tucked into her belt standing in front of the gate looking left and right frantically. I noted the slight disdain that flickered in her eyes as she saw Lilia approaching before she clamped it down.

“Good day trainee Lilia.”

“Good evening priestess Ur.”

I didn’t miss the slight bit of disgust in her greeting either, though only someone trained to catch the nuances of speech would notice. I wondered why this woman had a problem with Lilia. Could it be because the girl had chosen to become a Hunter and not a priestess?

“You didn’t happen to see Nim and the other’s did you? They ran off someplace and I can’t find them anywhere in the complex.”

“No I’m sorry priestess, I didn’t see them on my way back from school.”

She chewed on her lower lip, lost in thought for a moment before sizing me up and down. Noting not only my uniform but also my presence. I could see she recognized me as a Hunter even if I wasn’t official yet.

“You! Hunter! Help me find those kids now.”

“Priestess Ur right? Begging your pardon, but go blow yourself. I have no obligation to help you, especially when there is no sign that they are in danger. Plus I don’t take kindly to people giving me such orders when they are asking for my help and aren’t paying me to boot.”

“Then what good are you Hunter’s!”

“Quite good if you are ever halfway considerate of us. We might protect the citizens but we are still human and deserve to be treated like one. You don’t like it when Hunter’s demand that you heal them, even when you were already so inclined to do so. Have some respect for us as well in that regard. I don’t like having demands made of me even if I might have been so inclined to help to begin with.”

I gave Lilia a small bow, purposefully snubbing the older woman by not bowing to her as well before turning to walk away. Out of the corner of my eye I could see the woman in the green cape grit her teeth and open her mouth to yell something angrily at me. I really didn’t care, I wasn’t one of the devoted even if I did believe in The One God like most other people.

“Peace priestess Ur. Sir Hunter would you wait but a moment longer?”

I turned back around in time to see a woman around her mid to late thirties with long pale brown hair come walking out of the gate. She wore a crown of white vadivin flowers on her head, the petals wilting slightly but not a hint of brown showing. Around her shoulders rested a cape embroidered to look like folded wings. Her pale golden eyes had the same dreamlike quality to them that I had noted in Lilia’s while an almost visible aura surrounded her. Both the woman named Ur and Lilia bent down on one knew and bowed their head for a second before returning to their feet. Even if I had never seen her before, I knew who this was. There was only one person allowed to wear such a cloak, the Holy Mother herself. The head of the entire religion.

The Holy Mother bowed deeply to me before offering me a smile. I found myself offering her a small one in return without realizing it.

“Please excuse the priestess. I am sure she is worried about her charges and has let her emotions rule her words. I am sure she meant no disrespect. But I humbly apologize that one of mine has offended you so sir Hunter. It is true that Hunter’s are not unfeeling tools just as we priests and priestesses are not. Would you please consent to helping Keeper Ur find her lost children? I too am worried about them and wish not to see either they or the priestess here suffer for our inaction.”

“Holy Mother! You shouldn’t have to apologize for me!”

The Holy Mother gave the priestess a warm smile and put her finger on her lips to quiet her. Letting the smile on my face widen even more I gave her a small bow, ignoring the priestesses words which still sounded rude to my ears.

“After such an apology from the Holy Mother herself how could I refuse to help? Priestess Ur, are you sure they are not inside?”

“Y-yes. I checked everywhere for them but they were nowhere to be found.”

“Well it would be useless to waste time trying to go up and down every street searching for them. That would take at least two days or more in a city this size. You could always just wait for them to return. Unless they have been missing for a very long time now.”

“I’ve been searching for about thirty minutes now and I have this bad feeling that they might be in trouble.”

“Well then the simplest thing to do is send out some scout constructs.”

“Oh I can make constructs too!”

Lilia grinned excitedly as she pulled two origami cranes out of her pouch and made them fly around. I let her have her moment excitedly before I sadly shook my head.

“That’s not a construct. That’s just temporary transference. They last only as long as your magic is still in them. Without you supplying it constantly the magic bleeds out. A true construct holds that power in forever until it’s duty is done or you take it out. In the end it’s basically just wind magic. But since you are able to control wind I can easily teach you how to make a true construct. At least one of the very basic ones.”

“I can control wind a little bit too. Do you think you would be able to teach me as well? I want to help find the children also.”

I looked at priestess Ur who was blushing a bit as she lowered her head. It had probably cost her a bit to ask me. I waited until she lifted her head to look at me from lowered lashes before offering a grin and handing her one of the paper cranes.

“If you can make this float with your wind you have enough skill for what I have to show you.”

She took the crane in her hand and stared at it a moment before it lifted off her palm and zoomed around. With a nod I slipped my bag off my back and dug into the side pocket, coming out with a large spool of gold wire. Quickly I began snipping off strands of it the length of my palm until it was all gone and I had twenty strips. I began bending each strip into the rough outline of a butterfly with spread wings while I talked.

“For the most basic of constructs there is only three things you need aside from basic mastery over the elements that is. Each type of construct needs a certain mastery. For example these will be flying scouts so you need wind mastery. If you want a guardian type you need to know earth mastery. The first thing you need is your shape, or the form that will hold the power in. That’s why I am bending this wire into a butterfly shape. You already have a form in your origami cranes so that is no problem.”

As I set the ninth form on the ground Lilia pulled four more cranes from her pouch. The priestess Ur raised an eyebrow at that.

“Do you always carry such things wherever you go trainee?”

“Yes. I think they are pretty and they look cute when they fly around.”

The priestess simply shook her head as I continued to fold.

“The second thing a simple construct needs is a link between you and it so that your desires come through. The easiest way to do this is to sprinkle it with your blood. You can tie hair onto it as well if you want and that will give you a stronger link, but that also requires a bit more control over your abilities.”

Quickly I pulled the dagger out of it’s sheath at my side and flicked my finger, letting a few drops well up and drip over the twenty small forms I had created. Once I was done I cleaned the blade on my pants and handed it to the priestess. She hesitated a moment and cut her own finger, staining two of the white cranes red. Lilia had already used her own knife to put a few droplets onto the last four paper birds.

“And last you need an incantation that binds it to your service. You must call upon the base elements of the material you are working with. In your case you cant just say paper, you got to go even farther back. Paper is made from trees, trees are creatures of wind, water, and earth. Fire is used in the creation of paper. That is how your paper is connected to the elements. There is no set incantation, it can be different every time if you so desire. Though if you can remember one that works easily it makes things easier as you concentrate instead of making up something on the fly. Last of all you must imbue your magic into the form as you incant, this becomes the constructs life force. Watch me.”
11112111211222111.title: After Lilia

111121112112221111.content:
Gently I held my hand over the forms on the ground, letting my purple aura sink onto them, filling the gold wiring. Gold was a great conductor of magical powers and held it well. The purer the gold, the better. That was why this wire was almost pure gold, to make it easy to create things such as this.

“From earth you were born, by fire you were purged and by water were you formed. You who wears the age of time cut by the wind, take upon you my power to be your inner fire. Spring forth to do my bidding creatures of soil and know the freedom of the air! Be my eyes in the sky and fly on wings of your own creation!”

The twenty butterflies jumped into life, beating their wings and hovering in the air awaiting my command.

“Go. Spread out. Seek the children.”

There was a flurry as sunlight glittered off all the gold in the sky before the area was suddenly clear again. Both Lilia and the priestess looked at me unsure for a moment and did what I had done. Lilia was better at it then Keeper Ur because that was part of her training at the academy, but the priestess did a respectable job. Both of them stuttered a bit as they uttered their incantation but in the end Keeper Ur’s two birds were circling around her and three of Lilia’s four were doing the same.

“Now give them simple commands to follow. They won’t understand anything too complicated. But since you linked them to you with your blood, they will know who you speak of without naming names. Just picture them in your head.”

In the end they simply gave the same commands I had and the birds shot off without a seconds hesitation. Lilia lifted the lone origami crane she hadn’t been able to bring to life with a sad look on her face.

“It didn’t come to life because your power isn’t strong enough yet. It takes skill to master and the stronger you get the more you can control. Three is your limit right now. But I can still make use of it. Having that will save me some time.”

I held out my hand and she handed it over slowly as I gave her a small smile. I asked the priestess to put one or two drops of her blood on it before she healed her finger up, getting the required liquid. With that done I smeared a bit of my own on it as well.

“Creature of the four elements of fire, earth, water and wind. Formed by the hand of man head my call to arms.”

Quickly I stuck a finger in my mouth and ran the saliva over the beak.

“I give you the gift of speech that you may relay the information I wish.”

Touching the paper to my eyes for a second before breathing on it I continued.

“I give you sight so you may know me and breath life into you so you may have a voice with which to use the gift of speech. Awaken now creature of the elements.”

The bird jerked its head to the side as it fluttered its wings, sitting on my palm awaiting my orders.

“What is your command master?”

“You can touch the other search constructs yes? Through the link of blood?”

“Yes master.”

“Good. Then tell me when they are found. If I am not nearby tell either one who’s blood is linked with them. Understood?”

“Yes master.”

The bird flew up a moment before settling on top of my head looking out at everybody who was watching in surprise. Even the Holy Mother who had been quiet through it all seemed impressed. With a quick thought I healed my finger, the other two having already done so. There was a moment of awkward silence before the Holy Mother invited me inside the gates. I graciously accepted, having nothing better to do while we waited.

Though people referred to this area as the cloister, it really wasn’t anything like the sparse living conditions of monks in a monastery. It was more like a small town walled off from the rest of the city. Spanning fifteen miles all told, it had apartment houses you might find anywhere else along with its own stores selling clothes and food. This was simply a sort of haven for the devoted who wished to be kept away from the foul language outside or any other number of constant “evils of man” as they called them. Entry and exit into this area was closely monitored, a fact I silently disapproved of. Children born inside these walls rarely got to leave them until they were almost sixteen and even then it was usually under heavy supervision. Some grew up, got married and died without ever leaving these walls.

This wasn’t the only place such cloisters existed either. They could be found in just about any major city. The Holy Mother or Father made their home in whatever cloister they wished and could move to another one whenever they wished as well. The last Holy Parent had lived in Mavill and the one before that Bodicum. Though most of the people living in these cloisters trained to be priests wilding the divine healing powers, not all of them were. Some were just regular citizens who wanted to get away from the outside world. Or those who were just this far away from being called zealots. I just couldn’t understand the concept of giving up all material possessions and being provided everything by the cloister. I knew the basics of their history, the basic rules they lived by and the teachings, but overall their religion was a complete mystery to me. One I was fine with not learning more about.

“So you said anyone can learn how to make these simple constructs?”

“Yes Holy Mother. As long as they follow the guidelines and meet the requirements.”

“Then I have a feeling there will be a surge of people learning this new skill. If for nothing else then to have a pet they don’t need to feed, bath, or clean up after. It will be useful in the future as well, to have such eyes in the sky.”

We walked around the sprawling little community as people bowed respectfully to the Holy Mother and she asked me a few questions about constructed magic. Sometimes she would stop to stare up at the sky with her head tilted before beginning to laugh at something only she heard. One time Lilia also looked up at the sky at the same time, both her and the Holy mother just standing in the middle of the street while people walked around them as if there was nothing unusual about it. They both broke out smiling at the same time sharing a look between them before moving on.

After about ten minutes of the three of them showing me the sights and telling me a bit about how they lived the bird on my head broke into the conversation.

“Target’s found master.”

“Where are they now?”

“North by north-west of your current position.”

“Describe the area.”

“Lots of buildings. A road. A bridge. Green trees behind them. Flickers of magic between them and the trees.”

“They are by the shield next to the Whispering Woods. That’s the only forest I can think of in that direction.”

“Where are they headed!”

The bird looked over at priestess Ur and cocked it’s head to the side as if thinking. I knew it was simply watching through one of the scouts to give information. I held up my hand, keeping her from asking the question again or getting impatient. This was still a simple construct and couldn’t process complicated things or multiple things at once outside the bounds of it’s programming.

“Headed in your direction. Approximate time until meeting seven minutes.”

“Recall all scouts from the sky. Leave only one to follow them and inform if situation changes.”

“Yes master.”

Soon enough all but one of my butterflies had returned to us. The origami cranes bursting into flames and crumbling since their mission was completed. My butterflies also all turned into melted gold which I caught and hardened into a large nugget for reuse later. Lilia seemed sad her cranes had died until I reminded her they had never been alive to begin with. They had simply moved with magic and that magic had broken them once the job was done.

After almost ten minutes the five initiates came through the gates only to be met by the four of us. Their faces fell a bit along with the vadivin flowers in their hands as they tried to explain why they had snuck out. Keeper Ur started to give them a lecture but the Holy Mother stopped her, smiling at the children and saying they had only tried to do something nice and no harm had come to them so she should drop it. Their faces lit up at those words as the bird on my head crumbled to ash and the last butterfly also became a nugget in my pocket. With a small bow I headed out the gates, my assistance no longer needed.

******

And so ends the day for young Riktal. Was it the best day? Or perhaps you consider it the worst one? Maybe in the end it was neither good nor bad, it simply was. Who can say for sure.

Well actually you can if you come again. With the ability tomake different choices while reliving this day you can judge for yourself what kind of day this was. That is, if you are interested. The choice of course, is yours.
111121112112221111.title: Demonstrate

11112111211222112.content:
The urge to find the shop won out as my feet turned to the right away from Lilia. I was drawn to her, there was no doubt about it. But it had more to do with the fact that she was so much different than everyone else. Her very strangeness made her less alien and more easy to deal with. After all, I dealt with a lot of strange and eccentric people on a fairly regular basis.

I simply let my mind continue to wander as I stalked the streets. I had a bit of an uneasy feeling in my stomach because of the choices I had made today. No, not exactly an uneasy feeling, more like I had missed something important. As if something about this whole day wasn’t quite right. Even though I couldn’t put my finger on it exactly and I had no basis for such a belief, still that thought nagged me.

It took almost an hour to find the place where it sat on a side road slightly off the beaten track. The sign over the door proclaiming its name as Heart-to-Arts was slightly weathered and chipped. Under the words was a picture of a stylized heart with an arrow pointing at a weapon. A visual name for those who either couldn’t read or didn’t know the language.

A tinkling bell went off over my head as I stepped inside the slightly cool room. Around me was the comforting sight of many artifacts on display. Having grown up using weapons and trinkets from the time I could crawl, they didn’t scare me or make me anxious. They were one of the few things I could understand completely. They had no minds of their own and didn’t act outside the bounds of their design. They didn’t talk back or do anything nonsensical. They would never betray you either, it was the hand that wielded them that did the betrayal.

From out of the back room came a slightly balding man around forty, perhaps slightly older. He had the hint of a paunch in his belly and some excess fat along his arms, proof that he was no fighter. His hair and eyes were both a light brown that matched his lightly sunburned skin, making the white teeth he showed me stand out even more.

“Welcome sir! How may I help you today?”

“I was wondering if you are able to renew the magic in a level three artifact trinket.”

Reaching up under my sleeve as I talked I unhooked the brass band around my right bicep, pulling it into view to slide across the countertop. With expert and practiced ease he began inspecting it, using high definition magnifying glasses, scales, even examining it with his own magical power. While he was examining the armband the bell chimed again, letting in a pretty young woman around my age who was also wearing the school uniform. She was slender, with an almost childish face made more prominent by the small nose and big brown eyes. She was also well endowed, making her look somehow slightly disproportionate in my eyes. Her long black locks seemed to shine slightly as she turned her head to look at me. With a nod of my head in her direction she smiled, showing white teeth against her pale peach skin. It took me a moment but I vaguely remembered seeing her in my class.

The shopkeeper leaned back, setting his tools down with a sigh. The girl didn’t even hesitate to go behind the counter and into the room the owner had come out of earlier. So I had to surmise she worked here after school. The shopkeeper sucked on his lower lip a moment before turning his gaze on me and shaking his head slightly.

“Well I can do it. I’ve got my certification if you want proof that I can work on level three stuff. The problem is I don’t have the proper equipment for something so well crafted. In all honesty this is almost level four work. I can get the craftsman’s guild to send over what I need but that would be a bit of an extra expense I’d tack on to the final amount. I’m not so big a business that I can offer such things free of charge.”

“How much would I be looking at?”

“At a guess? Around forty thousand Reul. That’s not counting if I have to patch up the matrix inside or replace some of the components. That is including labor costs of course.”

That was a bit steep for my wallet right now. I had about fifteen thousand between what I had saved up and what was in my pocket. I really didn’t want to ask my parents for any money, then I would feel like I owed them a debt. I could borrow it from someone else, I did know a few who would loan it to me. I could even do a bit of gambling to make up that amount, or go out monster slaying and hope for some decent drops I could sell.

Before I could answer him though there was a muffled scream as the back door burst open and the girl came out with her head covered by a slime. I could see her holding her breath through the green gelatin body even as her hands burst into flames, punching at the monster. Her attacks didn’t do much good though, since her fire wasn’t hot enough to burn the liquid creature. As she continued to struggle and the shopkeeper tried hitting it with fists of fire as well, I calmly took the few steps needed to stand by her side.

With two fingers I touched the monster, causing the body to harden. From the original point of contact cracks began to zoom around the outer shell seconds before the body turned white and the air became noticeably colder. Within two seconds the entire body was encased in ice and I gave it a hard rap, shattering the monster into pieces and letting the little bit of liquid still around her face fall to the floor. She gave a gasp of fresh air as the creature began to dissipate, leaving behind a vial of slime oil. While I was picking up the vial the shopkeeper wrapped his big arms around the girl in a protective way. I realized then that the girl was his daughter.

“Thank you for saving my little girl sir Hunter.”

“Call me Riktal. I’m not an official Hunter yet. Or if you insist call me Mr. Zelkov. But that’s my father’s name and I honestly prefer being called Riktal instead.”

“Thank you Riktal.”

I shrugged, putting the slime oil on the counter for him to take. I had no use for it and I knew such an item was useful in making artifacts, even if it didn’t sell for more than three or four Reul.

“It’s my job. Besides, it wouldn’t do to let another Hunter in training die to such a low level creature. It would tarnish my good name. Word of advice though, if your fire isn’t enough to overcome a water based creature, simply freeze it. It doesn’t take much, simply use wind magic to create an absolute vacuumed around what you want to freeze. Just like in deep space the lack of air will solidify water as long as you apply enough pressure. Or you can boil it all away simply by not applying as much pressure while in that vacuum.”

The shopkeeper hugged his daughter again before asking her what had happened.

“I was opening some of the crates in the back to put the stuff away when it suddenly popped out of one of them and latched onto my face. Before I knew it my head was engulfed.”

The shopkeeper gave me some more thanks which I waved away. I was a bit uncomfortable being thanked for doing my job. There had been nothing special or noteworthy about what I had done after all. Especially since slimes were barely considered a threat, being only an E class mob. He even offered to renew my trinket for a vastly reduced cost as thanks.

“No. You need to make a living as well. I shouldn’t be given such treatment for doing what I trained to do. Though I would like you to renew it for me. I can get you fifteen thousand Reul by the end of the day if that will be enough of a down payment to get the tools you need. I’ll pay you the rest after the job is done.”

“I can live with that.”

I shook the hand he extended to me as the girl picked up the trinket on the counter out of curiosity. She gave it a quick once over just like her father had, using fingers and magic as well as a few of the tools before her eyes went wide in surprise.

“This is a level three band of Treasure Seeking isn’t it!”

"Yes it’s a level three band of Treasure Seeking.”

She set the trinket down before heading off into the back room again, presumably to unpack more crates. Her father watched her go with a slightly worried look on his face before looking over at me.

“Judging by your uniform you go to the same school as her. Would you mind keeping an eye on her for me.? She’s a good kid, and smart too. It’s just, sometimes she gets a bit too focused on things and flustered easily over little stuff. I’d feel safer knowing someone is watching out for her if she gets in trouble. I don’t want to be one of the parents that has to bury their child within five years of her graduating.”

“Then why let her become a Hunter?”

“Because that’s what she wanted. Isn’t it a parent’s duty to support their children? Even if that means they will be putting themselves in danger? Hunter’s are heroes. And I am proud that she is willing to risk her life as she is, even if I am afraid for her as well.”

I turned towards the door but didn’t start walking yet.

“By the way, what’s her name? She’s actually in my class but I didn’t catch it.”

“Kiki.”

“Kiki huh? I’ll remember that. Just don’t go ordering any headstones anytime soon you hear?”

“Thanks.”

I held up my hand in farewell as I walked out the door back into the street.

*******

Any regrets or second guessing? I’ve learned a bit about what I wish to know, yet I still desire to learn more. So come again if you wish and relive this day again. Make new choices so that I might observe and grow my knowledge. Until then traveler.

choices: "I'd rather not associate with people like you"
"Better not let the girls find out about it."
1111211121122212.content:
“Your grandfather, Miktal Zelkov. He was a bit of a hard head in certain respects just like you. Don’t get me wrong, it served him well and he was a great Monster Hunter because of it. It’s just… well, he wasn’t much of what you would call a people person. He cared about them in his own way, he just didn’t know how to talk and interact with them without being rude and abrupt most times. Now run along, I’ve wasted enough of your time with my ramblings. Besides I’m sure you don’t want to be around an old woman like me.”

As I walked away I couldn’t help but feel I had somehow been played. I couldn’t put my finger on why though. I had been the one to ask the question and she had answered just like she promised. But I felt as if I had asked the wrong question. Or didn’t word it the right way. Scratching my thatch of red hair in frustration I let out a small growl before heading off to the classroom.

“… Hunter’s have acted autonomously since the year 0035, when the Hunter’s of that day banded together, clearing out two thousand miles of land in three days where the city of Malandis Dae now stands. They formed the Union, also known as the Association at the end of the third day, realizing that governments would try to use them in power plays if they swore allegiance to any one nation. Until that moment they had not realized the full potential and power that they held.”

The teacher gave me a nod as I closed the door quietly, heading for my seat in the back while he returned his attention to the rest of the class.

“There was a lot of contention in those days as nations banded together to stop what they saw as a revolt by their citizens. They thought us their property if we were born within their lands. There was a great bloody war, that what we call the First Uprising. It lasted from 0037 to 0045, and within that time monsters ran rampant in cities and towns without Hunter’s to protect them. The council at the time let it happen, using the death the monsters were causing as a bargaining chip against the nations they fought against. This caused much contention within the ranks of the Hunter’s, who still believed in the prime directive of our calling.

“Those Hunter’s split off from the main group, continuing to act autonomously, but also continuing to protect the citizens regardless of what nation they were from. These offshoots became known as Ronin, and not given support by the Union. Yet they banded together in their own little Union, watching each other’s backs and supporting each other in times of need. It is from the actions of these Ronin that the Hunter’s fourth rule was created. This war suddenly became a three way vie for dominance with no side wanting to budge. That is until two Ronen, children not even completely Hunter’s yet at barely fourteen years old, decided to step up and do something.”

I sat back and listened as the teacher taught the rest of the class about Nesta Highwill and her future husband Gint Jervin and the ten year journey they went on to negotiate peace treaties and stop the fighting. A journey that some say was a quest given by The One God himself. I had read about it at least fifty times in the books at home, but there was something about hearing it told like this that made it feel different. Perhaps it was the way the teacher told the story, or perhaps because this was the first time I had heard it told aloud. Before I knew it, the class was over and the bell was ringing.

“Hey, Are you really a Zelkov?”

I looked up at the two girls and two boys standing around my desk. I had seen them coming and knew this would happen sooner or later, it was why I hadn’t given my name right off the bat. The jockeying to be recognized, the vying for attention, would now begin. Each of them were first or second generation Hunter’s. Perhaps a third and maybe even a rare forth, but for the most part they were still considered new blood. They didn’t have connections or reputation or any of that. But if they could say they were associated with an old family like mine, they could get such things in an instant. Doors would open and governments would bow to them on that fact alone.

“Yes I am. What of it?”

“That is so cool! Then you must be like super strong and like really good at all this stuff!”

I looked at the girl who was twirling a bit of her short cropped dull brown hair around a finger in an attempt to flirt. It didn’t even move me at all, though I did think she was attractive enough, the blatant way she was pushing herself on me made it more disgusting than alluring. I kept my face a stone mask, making sure my disinterest got through loud and clear before dismissing her as unimportant while I answered her.

“Yes I am.”

I saw her take a small step back as if uncertain how to proceed and kept from smiling to myself. Idiots the lot of them if they though such crude flattery would get them anywhere with me. The blond next to her stepped forward with a slightly haughty grin, as if she was mocking the first girls failure. There was some sort of rivalry going on their that I didn’t understand. Perhaps I never would since I was a guy.

“Well I think Riki tiki is an adorable nickname! Do you mind if I call you that too?”

Instantly the knife was out of the sheath at my side and in my left hand, the tip inches from her throat. I looked up at her with narrowed eyes and gritted teeth as she took a step back.

“No one gets to call me that except my sister. If I hear you uttering it again I will cut your tongue out of your mouth. That goes for anyone else who wants to call me that. Am I clear?”

When she nodded her head up and down quickly I returned the knife to it’s resting place, my eyes never leaving hers. What she saw there must have unnerved her because she turned and walked away quickly, returning to her seat. The brown haired girl grinned at her retreat from the battlefield but soon followed suite after having the same stare leveled on her. As soon as the two girls were gone, the boys came closer, lowering their voices after looking around surreptitiously.

“So Riktal, can I call you Riktal? Who’s your favorite? Oh I’m Bith and this is Wilith by the way.”

Bith was as plain as day, brown hair, brown eyes, tanned skin, but no real distinguishing features. The kind of face you could forget soon after meeting him. Wilith on the other hand stood out because he was one of the few black skinned people in the room. With eyes a shade of green that seemed to almost glow. That topped with the fuzz of yellow hair on his head made him stand out like a sore thumb.

“I don’t understand.”

“Your favorite. You know. Of the girls? You’ve got to have made a few judgments on them by now. After all we have quite a few lookers. Like Lilia and Liz Hawthrope. They are in the top five but well Liz is Liz and Lilia is a bit weird. The top slot right now is Kiki Valenca.”

He pointed to where a long black haired girl with a large rack was giggling with some other girls by the door. Indeed she was quite pretty, with her slender figure and a small nose that accentuated the childish cast to her face. But I also knew how deceiving such looks could be. I had met and knew a lot of good looking women and all of them either had baggage or a personality that was as rotten as they were beautiful.

“She’s got it all, looks, a sweet personality, brains, brawn, and money. Though she doesn’t really throw that fact around. She’s the daughter of a weapons merchant so she has a real eye for artifacts and some monster drops as well. So, you got your eye on anyone? I can give you all their stats if you want.”
1111211121122212.title: "You said I was like him. Him who?"

11112111211222121.content:
“Hey, hey! Don’t be like that mate! We’re all guys here! It’s not like we try to sneak peeks at them while they are undressing or anything. Well ok so maybe I did try that a few times back in middle school, but hasn’t everybody? It’s just a bit of harmless fun.”

“Besides I know the girls grade us the same way even if they won’t admit it. I bet you will quickly rank up there at the top.”

Wilith and Bith gave each other a conspiratorial grin as I looked away shaking my head.

“Still not interested. I don’t have time for such childish things. I’d rather not be thought a part of your gang or whatever you want to call it. I’m not here to make friends, this is nothing more than a prison sentence for me. I just want to do my time and get out of here.”

The grins fell from their faces as the bell rang, giving me a look over their shoulders as they returned to their seats along with everyone else. As the teacher began his lesson I let my eyes rove around the room, noting the ones who were interested and the ones who took the class too lightly. Mentally I began marking off the ones I thought would be dead before they were twenty three. Putting them in categories of who I thought would drop out by the time the year was over, who would die in a training accident by graduation and who would end up maimed or badly hurt. The outlook didn’t seem favorable for many of them right now.

My eyes fell on the girl named Kiki who was paying attention and taking notes. I was interested in her, but not for the reasons those two had thought. Her name sounded familiar but I would have to ask her to make sure. I juggled with the idea of holding off until I got more information before approaching her so as not to create misunderstandings in the class but decided the direct approach was the best. So what if they talked or misunderstood, I didn’t care what they thought.

The bell rang signaling the end of class rather quickly as I only half paid attention to what was being taught, my mind wandering from one thing to another instead. I gathered up my bag and headed out the door after the Kiki girl, intent on getting answers before I lost sight of her. I was surprised at how swiftly she moved, she was at her locker within moments of leaving the classroom.

“I heard your name is Kiki Valenca. Are you related to the Valenca that runs the Hearts-to-Arts shop on the south side of town?”

She turned around after closing her locker to give me an offhand shrug, slipping her bag onto one shoulder as she did so. Her eyes gave me a quick once over, not assessing me as potential lover material, but the knowing eyes of someone who has seen Hunter’s up close all her life. Assessing my strength, my wealth and my skill with the look of a business man, or woman in this case.

“Yeah, he’s my father. Why do you want to know Riktal Zelkov?”

“How good is he at renewing complicated artifact magic? I’m talking level three or higher type stuff?”

“Well he got certified last year but he hasn’t actually done many. Most Hunter’s take such things to a bigger city.”

“Yeah I know. All the dealers I know of can only handle up to level two. Do you mind showing me the way? I know it‘s here on the south side but that’s about it.”

“I don’t mind, I help out after school so I was going there now anyways.”

The two of us walked out the doors side by side, turning right once outside the gates while talking for a bit about artifacts. Well she did most of the talking, getting excited over the how’s and whys of the craft. I knew enough to make some crude basic artifacts but that was about it. Making complex artifacts took years of study that I just wasn’t interested in.

“If you don’t mind me asking, what kind of artifact do you want refreshed?”

“A level three armband of Treasure Seeking.”

I lifted the sleeve of my tunic to show her the band clasped around my right bicep. It was old and weathered, showing it’s age. The silver rune engravings along the outside of the brass ring were slightly turning color at the edges.

“No way! I’ve only heard about these things! They are the ones that increase the drop chances of really rare items from monsters if you get the killing blow right? And the highest level is four where you can actually control when you make it work, almost guaranteeing high end items.”

“Yeah, I found it stored away in one of the boxes up in the attic. I think it belonged to my grandfather but I’m not sure. Now though, this one is out of juice. It has maybe one or two more good uses out of it before the magic is all depleted.”

“Can… can I touch it? I’ve only seen a handful of level three trinket artifacts but nothing like this.”

I slid my finger down the small metal band, breaking the seal holding it together before handing it over to her. She scrutinized it as she walked, holding it at every angle she could think of. She even closed her eyes and ran her fingers over it using a blind mans sight. Finally she handed it back to me shaking her head in awe.

“I’ve never seen such craftsmanship. I can’t even tell where the seams are to get inside or even where the heart crystal might be. I’m sure daddy will be just as delighted. Though honestly I don’t know if he can. Like I said, even though he has his certificate he doesn’t work on them much.”

“Meh it doesn’t hurt to ask. I’ve been meaning to come find this place anyway, I just never got around to it because it’s so far out of the way.”

She returned to talking about different artifacts again, filling the silence as she led me to the store. Once inside she introduced me to her father who was pleased to see me. Part of that was probably because I was a Zelkov, the other part was because I was potential business. And when a Hunter came to do business that meant money, sometimes lots of it. I might be the only customer he had all day, but the money I might bring in could cover costs for the month depending on the circumstances.

Quickly I told him what I wanted, laying the armband on the counter in front of me. His eyes went wide in surprise just as his daughter’s had but then I saw him go into business man mode. He began pulling out all sorts of tools of the trade from magnifying glasses to small screwdrivers, to precision needles and scales. He even ran his fingers over it with his eyes closed the same way Kiki had. I even saw him cover the trinket in a light orange glow, using his magic to assess it as well. Finally he set the things down while leaning back with a sigh, shaking his head slowly.

“Well I can do what you want. The problem is I don’t have the kind of tools I would need here at the shop. I’ve never worked on something so old, and honestly the old stuff is put together better than the newer models. This is master grade craftsmanship and I’ve never touched something so well crafted before, it‘s almost level four work. But I’m one hundred percent confident that it would be just within my range of skill. I could borrow the things I need from the craft halls for a fee and they would be here within a few days, but that would have to be added on to any deal we made. I’m not so rich a business that I can offer such services free of charge.”

“So then how much am I looking at roughly?”

“At a guess? Around thirty five thousand Reul. That’s assuming I don’t need to create a new matrix or replace something once I crack it open. If nothing goes wrong I can have it done within a week and a half.”

“Is that with or without labor?”

“With of course.”

I chewed on my lower lip as I thought about it. Thirty five was a bit rich even for me. I had some saved up that I had tucked away by scraping off the edges of my living allowance. To make up the rest I would have to go do a bit of gambling or borrow it. I could always go out monster slaying and sell the drops, but without the luck from the trinket I wasn’t assured of getting anything for my troubles. Monster drops were never one hundred percent, there was always the chance I would get a string of bad luck where I got nothing at all.

Finally I pulled my wallet out of the pouch hanging at my side and slid five thousand Reul across the countertop, emptying out my on hand cash.

“This is all I have on me right now, will that be enough to send for the supplies you need? I will be back in later today or tomorrow with another ten thousand. You can consider that a down payment for any unforeseen expenses and I’ll pay the rest once it is finished. Is that agreeable?”

“More than agreeable sir Zelkov.”

“Riktal. Call me Riktal.”

He grinned at me as we shook hands over the counter, his fingers hard and calloused from his work. I left him to his devices, seeing Kiki jumping up and down excitedly exclaiming something I couldn’t make out through the closed door. Now how was I going to get the rest of that money? I could use my savings to gamble and make it all, trading risk for reward. Though in my cast I didn’t think it would be much of a risk. Or I could go see Pelei. He was one of the few people I knew who had the money and wouldn’t have much problems loaning it to me without complicated stipulations attached.
