111121112112221211.content:
“Four Sages on the mountain reaching for god!”

I dropped my hidden tiles in front of me to reveal my hand as the other four men groaned in disgust. With a grin I collected the five thousand Reul pot, bringing my total to forty thousand and some change over my starting amount. I glanced at the clock, making sure they all saw me doing so before bowing out from the table. They tried to get me to stay so they could win back some money but I had made sure to overtly watch the time so they didn’t assume I had swindled them and was now running. Packing up my bills, they all gave me a good natured wave of farewell as I left the secret room in the back of a shabby restaurant.

I would have never actually found this place after leaving Hearts-to-Arts if I hadn’t paid a street imp to give me directions. But with a ten thousand Reul starting purse they had been more than happy to let a stranger in on their games, thinking it would be easy to take it. I had lost five thousand on purpose as I let them “teach” me the game of Tops and Tiles. A game I had long ago learned how to play from my sister when she taught me the basics of gambling. But once they felt comfortable in the easy money I began to shark them.

I played it off as beginners luck, giving them a wide eyed surprised attitude as I hesitantly laid out my hand as if I didn’t think it would win. Like any gambler’s game, Tops and Tiles was a game of lies and misdirection. You needed skill, but you could always replace skill if you were good enough. They hadn’t even noticed me palming extra tiles to create the big money hands, while losing a little bit here and there to throw them off the fact that I was cheating. In short, I had swindled them good, and they didn’t even know it.

I ambled along until I came to a men’s clothing store, entering at a leisurely pace. The store clerk didn’t even bat an eyelash as I walked past him into the back room to change out of the baggy blue shirt and ripped jean pants. Hurriedly I donned the school attire of brown leather pants and tunic, stuffing the rest of the gear inside the duffle bag I had also left here. Once done I left the back room again, dropping the clothes off with the clerk along with a thousand Reul, both of which disappeared from sight within seconds.

I only took two steps though before he whistled at me, pointing at his head when I turned around. I grinned sheepishly, pulling the straight black haired wig off my head and tossing it his way before moving on. It wouldn’t do to have the crooks realizing they had been playing against a Hunter. It would ruin our image. But the truth was, we weren’t as pure as regular citizens thought us to be.

A quick look at the sky told me it was roughly five o’clock. The artifact shop should still be open. I could drop off the rest of my down payment and then deposit what remained in my account before the bank closed.

“What are we going to do? We can’t let it just stay back there, I don’t have enough skill to get rid of it and we don’t really have the money for an exterminator.”

I heard Kiki’s voice from the other side of the closed door behind the counter as I walked in, the bell announcing my presence. Both of them came out almost instantly, offering me smiles of welcome before I even took two steps. Mr. Valencia took my money, putting it away for safe keeping even as I looked between both of them.

“Problem?”

“No problems at all.”

“From what I heard when I walked in it didn’t sound like no problem.”

“It’s nothing really. When I opened one of the crates I had ordered a few weeks ago I found we had an uninvited guest as well. It’s just a slime though so it’s no big deal.”

“It is a big deal daddy! If we don’t do something, it will corrode the artifacts back there!”

She looked at me with pleading eyes as she clasped her hands in front of her.

“Will you take care of it for us?”

“If it’s a slime you should be able to handle it by now. It’s only an E class.”

“I can’t. My fire isn’t strong enough to burn it away.”

“Is that the only magic you know?”

“Of course not, I can handle all four of the basic elements. But I’m not able to make my flames hot enough to counter the jelly body.”

I gave a shrug the as I replied.

“Well then there you go, you’ve got enough skill. I heard you are at the top of the class, so use that brain of yours and think. Each of the four basic elements have a secondary name describing their main purpose. Tell me what they are.”

“Earth is also called the defense element, it’s properties are mainly used to strengthen. Fire is the attack element, because of it’s destructive nature. Water is also considered the regenerative element because of its fluid shape. And wind is the supportive element.”

“Why is it the supportive?”

“Because it augments the other elements and their base natures. Making fire stronger turning water into an attack ability and backs up earth. While at the same time being able to stand on its own. It is the most versatile of all the elements followed by water. But I can’t combine two elements yet.”

“And what is a slime made of?”

“Water mostly. Or at least some sort of liquid close enough to water.”

“Well then there you go, use wind on it.”

“I don’t understand.”

With a sigh I rubbed my eyes while giving my head a small shake.

“I guess I have to spell it out for you. Though you need to start thinking if you ever plan on making it as a Hunter. If you really want to get ahead and stand out, don’t wait for someone to tell you all the answers, figure them out yourself. Enclose the slime in a ball of wind and then pull it away, leaving no air at all inside.”

Her eyes lit up suddenly as she finally understood.

“Create a vacuum like in deep space! That will freeze the liquid turning the monster into nothing but a block of ice! Then I could just whack it with a solid blow and destroy it. I don‘t need to use powerful spells then, just use it‘s own nature against it.”

“Bingo.”

Without a word she ran through the door into the back room as her father grinned at me.

“She really is pretty smart you know. Though sometimes she gets these moments where she can’t see past the nose on her face. Just like her mother in that respect. Would you mind watching out for her and helping her out if she needs it? She’s a good girl and I don’t want to be one of the parents going to their child’s funeral within the first few years of them becoming licensed Hunter’s.”

“Then why did you foot the money to send her to the academy?”

“Because that’s what she wanted. Isn’t it a parent’s duty to help their children pursue their dreams?”

“Not if you’re a Zelkov I guess.”

“What was that?”

I shook my head and told him my mumbled words were nothing just as a cold wind blew out of the back room and the sound of cracking ice filled the air. I gave the shopkeeper a wave farewell before heading back out the door. The more I interacted with other people and normal families, the more I wished I hadn’t been born a Zelkov. I could only dream of my parents being even one thousandth of a fraction interested in me and not themselves or their jobs. For all that I hated them and thought them little more than strangers, some programmed gene in my body still made me love them, even if that feeling wasn’t returned.

Shaking off such thoughts as I hitched my bag more snugly onto my back I headed for the center of town to deposit the rest of my winnings. It did no good to dwell on such thoughts and would only make me uselessly angry at them without either one even being around to vent it on. Best to simply ignore it and forget about it, hopefully I would eventually forget about them and the lonelyness as well.

*************

Are you satisfied with the outcome? With the choices you made? Do you wonder at where the road would have taken you if you had made different choices? It is only natural after all. Humans are such creatures that must always wonder at that question of what if and maybe. Your regret is the very essence of this question.

But unlike in your real life, I give you the power to relive this day, to make different choices so you can see what else the future held for young Riktal. Or perhaps I should say holds? Since all this has both happened and has not yet been realized. Perhaps it never shall be realized. Now that is a question is it not? If you never observe a timeline, does that mean it does not exist even though it is all within the possibilities? If you redo this day over making different choices, then what of this day? Will it also not exist or become only a potential again even though it has been observed once?

Truly it is a question that must be pondered and an answer sought. Until next time traveler.
111121112112221211.title: Gamble

111121112112221212.content:
Though I had no problem gambling, and even cheating crooks out of stolen money, I thought it better to hold off on making myself too well known to the underworld crooks on this side of the city. That’s not to say I didn’t know who the kingpins of the four corners were, but the criminals I would be gambling with weren’t affiliated with old one-eye.

Instead I headed off deeper into the south side, mentally preparing myself for dealing with Pelei. He wasn’t a bad guy or anything, I just couldn’t quite handle him like I could most other people. I took the turn to the left when I came to it, following the road into the residential area and the winding path which eventually brought me to the small fenced in yard. Well small compared to the acres of land we owned. The house had an old style feudal feel to it with sliding doors and ornate trimming. It almost looked more like a temple of some sort than a house.

Pelei said he had modeled it after the histories of his homeland, even putting a small pond off to the side with a bamboo contraption under a manmade waterfall that was supposed to keep time. Pushing through the gate I felt the small current as the shields identified me as a non monster. Then one last deep breath before I rang the doorbell.

There was a quick pattering of feet before the door flew open and a tall angular body was suddenly wrapping its long arms around my neck. I felt his lips against my cheeks and heard the smacking sounds before he held me at arms length with a grin. Even though he only stood at six foot, his thin figure made him look taller. Today he was sporting a baggy pink shirt and pants that melded together to almost look like a dress. Both ears were covered in studded earrings, making them almost look silver. He wore three necklaces that dangled from side to side as he shook even as he bounced up and down in excitement. The black makeup he wore around his almond shaped eyes made them look larger than they actually were in an already angular face.

“Oh if it isn’t little Riktal! I was so surprised when I looked through the spell to see who was coming to see me only to find you at my doorstep! It has been too long darling! You’re almost a stranger anymore!”

He gave me a look up and down before shaking his head.

“What terrible, terrible fashion sense you have today darling! It simply won’t do! Come!”

Despite his appearance he was quite strong. I found myself being dragged along after him as he grabbed me by one hand. I had learned how futile it was to try and resist when he got like this. Even if I dug in my heels he would still drag me inch over inch. I had spent many a visit here going all out against him. Sometimes I won, sometimes I didn’t. In the end I found it best to just let him get this urge of his out of his system.

Leading me to the back of the house I found myself in one of his dressing rooms. It was more like a small clothing store tucked away in this single room, with racks and racks of clothes of all shapes and sizes all over the place. I knew through the door at the side of the room would be another just like this one only filled with female clothes instead of male. After yanking my duffle bag off my back and throwing it to the floor with a small tsking sound he tried pulling my shirt off. With a hard shove I pushed him away shaking my head

“Enough Pelei, I can dress and undress myself.”

His face fell for a moment as he wiped nonexistent tears from his eyes with a sniff.

“But Riktal, the struggling is part of the fun! The feeling of ripping off such ugly things and dressing them up again in something beautiful! The feel of silky smoothness under the fingers! There is nothing like it I tell you!”

He let out a soft moan as he hugged himself and wiggled back and forth, a look of bliss on his face. With a sigh I left him to his delusions before going over to the nearest rack and picking out a soft suede black shirt. Even as I began stripping off my tunic he was falling to the floor rolling around with a bit of drool coming out of his mouth. After putting on the new shirt I kicked him in the side lightly to make him snap out of it.

“Hey! Pelei! I’ve changed, are you happy now?”

He looked up at me from the floor, his eyes wild as he began to pant heavily.

“The pants! Oh the pants too! Yes! You must match! Give me your pants!”

“Dream on. The shirt goes well enough with the brown trousers so snap out of it.”

He reached up, grabbing a hold of my belt to try and yank them off. I gave him a swift kick in the face for his troubles.

“Try that again and you lose your fingers.”

It took him a few moments to get himself under control enough to heal his bloody nose. His fingers still twitched like they wanted to rip my pants off but he held himself back. Once his urges didn’t have the best of him he returned to a more normal demeanor. Well normal for him anyway.

“So what can I do for you Riktal darling?”

“I need to borrow some money. About forty thousand to be exact.”

I quickly told him why, saying the extra was just in case expenses came out to be a bit more than planned. With a grin he pulled up his banking information on a magical spell, transferring the money over into my account without a word. He waved away my thanks, like it was bad air.

“You’re good for it darling. And I know I’ll get it back. I take it you want to keep this on the down low so your parents don’t find out?”

“Please.”

“Done and done.”

I looked around the room for a moment at all the clothes. It still boggled my mind how he could have such a fetish. I saw his hand reaching up to grab my belt and slapped it away, making him pout like I little kid as he nursed it.

“So Pelei, out of curiosity, did my father come by asking you to take a job?”

“You mean the little girl? Yeah I took it if that’s what you want to know. She was just too adorable! I couldn’t pass her up!”

“How is she?”

“She’s gorgeous now with a nice pink dress with some to-die-for lace on it.”

“I meant physically and mentally, not fashion.”

“Oh well come see for yourself. She’s like a doll, but otherwise there is nothing wrong with her.”

He led me into the next room, the one that looked like the ladies version of the last one. Asala sat in front of a mirror with curlers in her hair, holding her teddy bear like I had last seen her. Pelei took one look at her and shook his head, walking over and pulling her clothes off without any hesitation. She stood there almost naked as he rummaged among the racks, pulling out an off white dress which he shoved onto her frame.

“Yes that looks much better. It works well with her hair don’t you think? Though don’t try taking the bear from her, a monster gets summoned if you do.”

With that he began to hum while putting makeup on her from the case in front of the mirror. I could tell she had retreated even farther into herself than before and I sadly shook my head. I gave it two days at the most before her body gave out and she died of starvation or thirst. But she had made her choice, I wasn’t going to force something she didn’t want on her. So I said goodbye to Pelei who waved me off absently, consumed in his new project. I stopped in the first room only long enough to gather my tunic and bag before heading back out into the street.

Once I was safely away I let out a sigh of relief. That had gone better then some visits with him and worse than others. But my mission had been a success. Now to find an ATM and pull some of that money out to complete the rest of my down payment and I could go back home. Home to the perpetual silence. Home to a house that had never sheltered a real family.

*******

Are you satisfied with the outcome? With the choices you made? Do you wonder at where the road would have taken you if you had made different choices? It is only natural after all. Humans are such creatures that must always wonder at that question of what if and maybe. Your regret is the very essence of this question.

But unlike in your real life, I give you the power to relive this day, to make different choices so you can see what else the future held for young Riktal. Or perhaps I should say holds? Since all this has both happened and has not yet been realized. Perhaps it never shall be realized. Now that is a question is it not? If you never observe a timeline, does that mean it does not exist even though it is all within the possibilities? If you redo this day over making different choices, then what of this day? Will it also not exist or become only a potential again even though it has been observed once?

Truly it is a question that must be pondered and an answer sought. Until next time traveler.
111121112112221212.title: Borrow

11112111211222122.content:
“Pish I’ve been running this since middle school, I’ve learned how not to get caught. I just look at it as practice for when I become an advisor for some countries government as an Association spy.”

“Hunter’s are autonomous remember? We don’t spy on governments.”

“Yeah right! You can tell me the truth. Even regular citizens know the conspiracy theories and guess at what goes on behind those doors.”

“And that’s all they are, theories and guesses. Baseless words people come up with because they don’t actually know and think it is more glamorous than it is. And if it were the truth, you would do well to keep it to yourself and not spread it around.”

The bell rang then as everyone scurried back to their seats. Bith giving me a wink before turning away and Wilith shooting me a thumbs up. I simply shook my head at the absurdity of it all. I didn’t have time for such childish things. Though that Kiki girl did interest me. Now that I thought about it, wasn’t Valencia the name of the guy who owned the chain of stores called Hearts-to-Arts? I’d never actually been to the one here in Efinbis since it was out of the way on the south side, but perhaps I should check it out.

Monster Tactics went by pretty quickly, the bell ringing for the end of school going off before I knew it. I thought about introducing myself to Kiki and finding out if she was in fact related to that Valencia or not. In the end though I decided against it. It would be better to check the place out and carefully plan how to approach her. If I went about it the wrong way there would be misunderstandings, not only on her side but also from the whole class. I would rather avoid unnecessary trouble if I could help it, I didn’t want to end up in some bad TV sitcom moment after all.

As I walked out the doors I saw three boys making cat calls and suggestive gestures to Lilia who seemed to be in a dreamy eyed world of her own. When none of their whistling or motions seemed to have any effect they gathered around her like a flock of vultures. I saw her cock her head to the side before a bubble of white light expanded outwards, sending the three boys flying. Two of them smashed into the wall running around the outside of the school and third went through the gate to come crashing down on the sidewalk outside.

I could see the blue haired bully who had landed on the sidewalk had fallen wrong, snapping his wrist without breaking the skin. Though the bulge showed where the bone was broken at. Even as he began to yell in pain she walked over and laid her hands on him, healing his wounds before giving him a pat on the head like he was a pet and walking off. I grinned as I followed along behind, shaking my head at the boy who was picking him self up and blushing a brilliant shade of red. It didn’t take long to catch up with her, since she seemed to be wandering a bit aimlessly. Stopping to sniff at a flower or to watch a shaft of sunlight or follow some invisible butterfly only she saw.

“You handled yourself well back there.”

“Back where?” She got a slightly puzzled look as she glanced over at me with her head tilted to the side. Suddenly dawning entered her gaze at what I meant. “Oh! You mean the boys! Yes well It happens from time to time. I’m not sure why they do that though.”

“It’s because they like you.”

“As they should. We are all His creatures and should all be liked.”

“Are you being serious or are you messing with me here?”

“Why? Do I not look like I am serious? If I don’t that’s a problem. I need to make it clear when I am joking.”

I simply shook my head letting the matter drop. I guess having a direct line to The One God himself just made her think differently about such things. People mistook that otherworldly vision of hers as her being weird. When we began heading into the north side of town she cocked her head at me, speaking as if we hadn’t just spent the last ten minutes walking in silence.

“Do you not live on the west side? Why are you following me? Do you have business?”

“Nope. Just didn’t feel like going home. I usually roam the town most days anyway. So I thought I would walk you back to the cloisters.”

“Ah ok.”

Again she returned to her own little world. Taking my words at face value and not thinking there was anything deeper. There really wasn’t, but most people would think there was. It was almost like she had only asked the question to fulfill the conventions of human interactions and politeness more than wanting to know the answer.

Just as we came in view of the cloisters where the priests and priestesses lived, a gaggle of boys and girls around fourteen or so ran up to meet Lilia, circling around her excitedly. They each sported the double black bands around the cuffs of their white robes that signified they were initiates in training.

“Hey Lilia! We’re going to go get some vadivin flowers for the Holy Mother! You want to come?”

“I don’t know, doesn’t she usually get them herself?”

“Yeah but it’s a surprise! She’s really busy right now and the old ones have begun to wilt. Boris knows where there is a whole field of them out in the Whispering Woods.”

“Then you shouldn’t go. The Holy Mother told us not to go outside the shield without her approval.”

“Oh come on Lilia! The Whispering Woods are right outside the shields. The only monsters inside it anymore are Snaal’s and even we can beat them off. Rumor is, the city council is planning on expanding the perimeter to encompass the woods because of how safe they are. They are just waiting for the seniors at the academies to graduate so they have enough Hunter’s to power the spell. Weren’t you just saying you wanted to help the Holy Mother out the other day because you thought she looked tired?”

Lilia nibbled on her lower lip for a moment before finally nodding her head and saying she’d go. The five younger initiates all cheered and grinned at each other while Lilia turned and looked my way.

“If you are doing nothing do you want to go too?”

“Did you get a message from Him saying to ask me?”

She gave me a puzzled look, cocking her head to the side as if wondering if I was joking or not.

“No. He doesn’t tell me everything. That’s not his way. He only lets me know some things, the rest he leaves up to me to decide. It’s not like I have no free will you know. But you had said you usually roam the town so that means you don‘t have anything to do. I simply thought you might like to come to fill your time.”

I thought about it for a moment before shaking my head and declining the offer. The initiates where right, the Whispering Woods were almost completely safe. The last time anything higher than an E class monster showed up there had been almost two years ago. One side of it was already butted up against the shields, so extending the spell to encompass that four miles of territory wouldn’t be that difficult. I mainly didn’t want to go with them because I knew they would chatter on about things I had no interest in, and would most likely try to convert me. I knew The One God existed like everybody else, and I knew some of the teachings. But the whole devout believer thing just wasn’t for me.

“You’ll keep this a secret won’t you Mr. Hunter? We really aren’t supposed to go outside the shield and we will get in big trouble if the Keepers find out. Promise you won’t tell please?”
11112111211222122.title: "Better not let the girls find out about it...

111121112112221221.content:
“Yeah whatever, I’ll promise. I doubt you have anything to worry about though. It’s not like I talk to the Holy Mother or the Keepers or even any priests and priestesses on a regular basis. I don’t plan on sticking around anyway, I do plan on getting something to eat though and then going home.”

“Thank you so much Mr. Hunter!”

I gave the pink haired girl a small smile before heading off deeper into the north side to find a restaurant. Looking over my shoulder I saw Lilia give me a wave of farewell before heading back the way we had come with the five initiates. Honestly I felt a bit awkward promising such a thing. I had been taught never to make promises if I could help it, because sometimes they could come back to bite you. If my promise were to ever conflict with the first rule of Hunter’s to protect people, I would end up doing harm no matter what. Keeping the promise might endanger the people, breaking the promise would bring the credibility of my word into question.

But as I had already said, in this instance I didn’t have much to worry about. The woods were safe, and I wasn’t one of the religious devotees so I had no business at the cloisters or hanging around any of the priests. The only time I dealt with them was on monster hunts and the few festivals the city held every year.

The diner I ate at was nice enough I guess. I didn’t remember seeing it the last time I found myself in this part of the city, so it must be new. It featured a small outdoor eating area which allowed me to watch the people going past, but the prices were slightly steep for the quality of the fare. Still I tipped them well and left, heading back towards the center of town at a sedate pace.

As I came up on the cloisters again I saw a woman seeming to just be loitering around on the sidewalk waiting. But I knew this wasn’t just any woman. She wore the pure white robes of a priestess, but unlike the rest she also sported a small cape embroidered to look like white wings. She also wore a wreath of flowers on her head, the tips of the petals slightly brittle looking but still pristine white. If these signs of office were not enough, the almost visible aura of power she was sheathed in would have given it away as she looked around with the same dreamy eyed gaze as Lilia. Even though I had never met her before I knew who she was.

“Ah Riktal! How are you!”

“I am doing well Holy Mother. What brings you outside of the cloisters today?”

She looked at me puzzled, as if I had just asked if she believed The One God was real. After asking the question I realized the answer. It was the same reason she knew my name.”

“Why waiting for you of course. He told me you would come.”

“And what would He want with me Holy Mother?”

“Actually I am not quite sure. He simply said you could answer my questions.”

“And what would those be if I might ask.”

“Have you seen some initiates? Keeper Ur has been searching for them for around thirty minutes now but they are nowhere to be found on the grounds. She can be a bit of a worry wart, but she came to me with a sense of unease about her five charges. There are three girls and two boys, all of them around thirteen and fourteen.”

1111211121122212211.content:
“I’m sorry Holy Mother, I have no idea where they are.”

She looked up at the sky a moment with her head tilted to the side just a bit. I watched as she blinked in the evening light, nodding her head slightly before returning her gaze to me.

“He says he is glad you feel the need to honor your commitments but he is deeply hurt that one of his children would lie so blatantly to one of his chosen.”

“Well if he knows where they are then why does he not tell you himself? After all he is all knowing and you have a direct line to him.”

“He only guides, rarely does he tell child. He can advise and he can bring together the people who can help one another, but he will not impeach upon the free will he gave us all. Even now it is your decision to tell me or not, even when I now know you know something. I will not fault you child if you wish to still stay quiet. Promises made should not be so easily broken. But would you please tell me? I am worried for my flock, as is Keeper Ur. The world outside these walls are dangerous and they are not yet ready to face them without supervision.”
1111211121122212211.title: Keep promise

11112111211222122111.content:
“I’m sorry Holy Mother. I made a promise. Based on what I know I deemed there was no danger to them. A Hunter is trusted because of his words among other things. I cannot in good conscious tell you what I know unless there is a very good reason to or the safety of the citizens are in danger. Neither of which I believe to be the case. I believe in the truth of The One God and I respect both you and the teachings, but I am not bound by the rules you live by. In the end I must stand by my morals and personal code of honor.”

“I respect your decision Riktal Zelkov. Though it pains my heart that one of His children has gone astray, unable to tell me the truth even when it is obvious that is His desire.”

“I’m sorry ma’am but I don’t talk to him like you do. If it really is His desire that I tell you then he can tell me directly. Or better yet, He can tell you directly if He really wants you to know so badly. Otherwise I must believe that it is simply your free will talking trying to guilt me into speaking. You are still human for all that you are his mouthpiece and not above such sweet talking.”

“Are you insinuating that I would do such a thing!”

Her face took on a look of surprise, as if the thought had never crossed her mind. I actually believed it hadn’t, but that didn’t mean I wasn’t suspicious of such actions having dealt with them before.

“Not at all Holy Mother. I truly believe you are as holy as you look. But that doesn’t mean I have not dealt with priests and priestesses before who were not above such trickery. You may call me paranoid if you wish, but any Hunter looking to live past the age of twenty three has to be. Good day to you ma’am, I’m sorry I could not help you out.”

I left then, heading off towards the center of town again with every intention of going straight home. But when I came in sight of the Whispering Woods next to the road across one of the bridges out of town I changed my mind. I really didn’t think anything would happen to them, but if God had directed the Holy Mother herself to wait on the sidewalk for me to come back past, I had better keep an eye on them just to be on the safe side.

Once inside the woods I made a few constructed beasts out of the gold wiring in my duffle bag and a bit of magic. These golems were only useful as scouts, looking like little hummingbirds so would not be noted unless one looked closely. I sent them out searching for the party before making another slightly more complex construct of the same type. This one I left perched on my shoulder so it could relay mental images to me from the four lesser minions. I wasn’t good enough yet to make such constructs speak verbally into my mind, but pictures were universal even if language wasn’t.

My magic birds soon found and led me to the field where the six were cheerfully picking flowers and romping around, acting like birds that had been let out of their cages for a little bit. They chased each other around and made garlands to wear on their heads. I heard snatches of a story Lilia was telling the younger children from where I was hiding in the tree line. I sent my little birds to scout out the area around the meadow and to relay any signs of trouble while I remained hidden.

I wouldn’t spoil their fun, and coming out into the open after having declined their offer previously might make them think something was wrong. If there was something big mean and scary out here, I would make sure it didn’t even come in sight of them.

After about five minutes of leaning against the tree in the shadows, one of my eyes in the sky relayed an image through the construct on my shoulder. At first I didn’t see what was wrong, just a quiet stretch of woods devoid of any wildlife with dead leaves littering the ground along with some fallen branches. Then I saw one of the branches rise and fall ever so slightly. More like a mirage than anything definite, but the construct had noted it first so I knew it wasn’t my inner eye playing tricks. Judging by the position of the sun it was almost directly north from my position across the field and heading directly towards Lilia and the other’s.

Only monsters of the worm family would be able to burrow underground and leave that unique ripple pattern. If it was coming from the north then it was one of thee subclasses, all three of them were D class or lower. Picking up a bit of speed, I skirted the edge of the open area and headed towards the spot in question, letting the mental image guide me. I didn’t get far past the field though when I finally found it, the ripple more pronounced now that I saw it with my real eyes. Judging by the size of the ripple the beast was two feet underground.

Digging into my bag I picked over the small selection of swords at my disposal. I needed something sharp enough to slice through the tough skin of a Wurmling, the highest of the three subclasses. Until I found out otherwise I would assume this was the strongest of the three heading my way. I found one that was almost perfect for my needs, it didn’t have the length I needed, but the edge was almost paper thin, allowing it to cut through almost anything if used right. What’s more, though it was straight along the length, it curved at the very tip, ensuring it wouldn’t catch in bones or cartilage.

Standing right in the middle of the oncoming wave I shoved the blade into the ground up to the hilt. That was only a foot and a half to the target but that was fine, it was the essence of the blade I needed. Pouring my power through my hand and into the hilt I forged a blade of pure purple power extending down another three feet with all the same properties as the base blade. Grabbing the handle in both hands I waited until the ripple was inches from the hilt before yanking back with one hand and pushing forward with the other.

I was met by resistance at first and then it slid through easily as the momentum began to pick up. The four and a half foot blade popped out of the ground, leaving a thin scar in the dirt as evidence of it’s passage. The ground heaved up slightly as it contained the explosion of the body below before settling down again. Letting the blade return to normal I put it back in my duffle bag before returning to the meadow to continue my vigil from the shadows.

It was another ten minutes before they left, their arms and little baskets full of the vadivin flowers. I followed behind silently, watching their backs while my birds scouted ahead and to the sides. But aside from that one monster nothing else came even close to them. That worm had probably been on the move for weeks, since they didn’t live in these woods naturally. Just a freak coincidence.

I waited at the edge of the woods until they were out of sight on their way back to the conclave before leaving myself and finally heading home. I had been able to keep my promise and protect the innocent at the same time. This time at least. I needed to be more careful with my words from now on, because there was no guarantee I could always do both.

*******

11112111211222122111.title: Stick to your morels and say nothing

11112111211222122112.content:
“Fine, though it isn’t anything all that dangerous. They just went to the Whispering woods to pick vadivin flowers as a surprise for you. They said you were busy and they noticed your other ones were wilting. Even though it’s just outside the shield, it’s tamed land.”

“Oh dear. Those children shouldn’t have. Even if those woods are safe, I won’t be able to use those flowers. They need to be picked at the right time for the spell to work. Thank you for telling me child. I’m sure it was a difficult decision for you to make. But I really must send someone to go pick them up.”

“Why? Let them have a bit of fun. It’s not healthy to be cooped up behind these walls all the time. I’ve always believed that. I might not be one of you priests, or a diehard devotee, or even know and understand all your rules. But I do know keeping them cooped up like that is little more than being in a prison cell for them.”

“But the world outside is dangerous! They aren’t ready to handle it yet!”

“The world outside will always be dangerous. Keeping them from experiencing it isn’t going to make them more prepared. If anything it will make them less prepared. Unless you are aiming to make them cling to The One God and their faith out of fear of the outside world and not out of true belief. Then keeping them imprisoned behind the walls of the cloisters will do that job nicely.”

“That is not my intent at all! Do you think I would really do such a thing? Or that is what He desires?”

“I’m just telling you as I see it Holy Mother. Not to be too rude but though I do not think that is your intent, or the intent of The One God, that is what you are doing. You may be the Holy Mother but I’m not one of your acolytes. I respect what you say and I am a bit in awe of you for being able to talk to Him directly, but you are still human. Not all the Holy Mothers and Holy Father’s that came before you were able to talk directly to him. Humans are greedy people who seek power. Priests and priestesses are not exempt from this desire. Power through fear or power through faith, in the end it is still power. If you are simply following rules passed down by the previous Holy Parents, then you cannot say what there intentions were in making those rules with one hundred percent confidence. But if such a decree was passed down to you directly by God himself, that is a different matter.”

Her head tilted to the side as she stared at me thoughtfully. Her brow furrowing in contemplation as she silently stared.

“Your words have some merit and ring of the truth. Indeed such rules were passed down by the previous Holy Parents. I must contemplate upon this and seek His guidance. Perhaps you are right and it is time for some changes. Though I am still worried about my flock. I fear something might happen to them.”

“Would not God have told you if that were the case?”

“No, he rarely tells us the answers directly, he only guides and advices. He gave us free will, he would not take it away so easily. That is why I needed to stand out here. I was worried and he advised me to do so, saying I might be able to get the answers I seek from you. But He left the asking and the persuading up to me.”

With a sigh I slipped my duffle bag off my back, dropping it to the ground and pulling out my coil of gold wire along with a short sword and shield. After a moment of thought I also pulled out my Roller Knuckles.

“Tell you what, if it makes you feel better I will go guard them in case anything shows up. I don’t think it will and I have a feeling neither do you. It will take me a while to find them but I will send a guardian to watch over them until I get there.”

“Would you?”

“Only if you can promise they won’t get in too much trouble when they get back. I’m sure they will be in for a small scolding or two for running off, but such actions are a risk reward deal. Even if I don’t agree with all your rules, in the end they are still your rules and the ones they must abide by. They shouldn’t be punished harshly for trying to do a good deed.”

“I can easily grant that request child. For I am in agreement with you on that point.”

With a nod I began cutting long strips of gold, creating a magical nexus network from the sword and shield to the gem inset into the Knuckles where the heart crystal was. This would be a jury rigged artifact construct and nothing like any half respected artesian could create, but it didn’t have to be pretty, just functional. The Holy Mother watched on in fascination as I finished bending the wires and connecting them all together. While I began the incantation of creation I pulled out my belt knife, cutting my finger open to sprinkle blood on the items laying on the ground and imbuing them all with a good portion of my magic.

“Born of the heart of a monster and constructed of the weapons of war. Infused with the power of life by my inner fire. Be given shape and form by the rocks of the ground and bound by my will. Let the wind be your home as well as the earth. And let my blood be your core, binding you to my service.”

Quickly I slathered the blade with my life fluid, flinging it into the middle of the small whirlwind that was standing the weapons up and giving it a vaguely man sized outline complete with limbs. The dagger floated in the air as the cement below us began flowing upwards building the golem from the ground up, making the windy outline more solid until a construct as tall as I was stood before me. He wore my gloves on his hands, or more accurately my gloves were his hands. The shield sat on his left arm while the sword was gripped in his right.

“I bind you to my service with a name. You are Innouso the warrior of blades.”

The construct knelt in front of me, putting his shielded arm across his knee while bowing his head.

“What is your desire master?”

“Go. Fly. Seek out Lilia and the five initiates. Watch over and protect them but do not be seen. If there is danger take care of it before it gets to them. If it is already upon them, do not let them come to harm. Understood?”

“As you command master, I will obey.”

It stood up then, two small whirlwinds appearing on it’s back as it leapt into the air and flew off towards the Whispering Woods. Once Innouso was gone I dropped to my knees panting. Such a complicated constructed magic was almost too much for me. I had barely learned how to create such a creature four months ago. It didn’t hold a candle to a true master of the art, but it was more than my parents could do.

The Holy Mother knelt next to me, gently taking my cut finger and healing it with but a touch. She then laid her hand on my head moments before I felt some energy returning to me.

“I sense that magic was almost beyond you Hunter Zelkov. But I am impressed nevertheless. I have never seen a golem made before, though I have seen the finished products.”

“Never stop learning and trying to surpass yourself. That’s the Zelkov motto. Now if you will excuse me I must go after it. I did say I would after all. Don’t worry, I will make sure they come back safe and sound.”

With that I got to my feet and gave her a small bow before picking up my bag and heading off towards the woods at a jog. I simply followed the link I had with my construct through the forest, navigating the landscape with ease. It didn’t take long to come to the edge of the field where the six were playing around and gathering flowers happily. I sent my construct to the other side of the meadow to stand watch while I leaned against the tree in the shadows on this side.

They finally left after about fifteen minutes without even the hint of a monster poking it’s nose into the air. But still I tailed them while my golem took point. Only after they were safely back in the cloister walls did I finally recall my golem and break down the magic, returning it to the weapons it was made of and returning the earth to the ground. With a final sigh I turned to head home, catching sight of Lilia half turning her head to wink at me.

Then again, that might have been my imagination.

11112111211222122112.title: Break your morels and tell her the truth

1111211121122212212.content:
With a sigh I told her what I knew. Yes I was breaking my promise to those children, but I really couldn’t lie to the Holy Mother herself. That was akin to lying to The One God’s face. She was his spokesperson and vessel on this earth for a reason. Like Lilia she had him whispering in her ear all the time. But unlike Lilia she was also the leader of the god’s religion. I didn’t want to make an enemy of her. If I did, she could deny me healing from her priests or any number of other things. Not that she was likely too, since the religion was all about helping people, but she still had that power. Her word was law among the believers.

She looked up into the sky a moment after letting out a small exclamation of surprise at my news. She nodded her head slightly with a smile on her face before returning her gaze to mine.

“He thanks you child for the difficult choice you made. He knows your heart was uneasy making such a promise to begin with but you have held up well.”

“If He already knows what’s going on then why doesn’t he just tell you personally. You have his ear, or he has yours, however you want to look at it. Why even bother with me?”

“He doe not work like that. He can advise and guide but rarely does he straight out tell. He has given us all free will to do with as we wish, if he told us everything he would take that free will away. Even I can ignore and go against that which he tells me if I so desire. But I have found the folly of such actions when he does give me information. Only rarely does he spell everything out for us, or commands us to action.”

“Yeah I’ve heard that before but I never understood why.”

“Because each choice is a trial. A test that he has laid before us in a grand scheme that even I cannot comprehend. Only He has the capacity to know. I thank you Riktal Zelkov for the information you gave me. If you will excuse me I must go find some priests to go retrieve them. Their thoughtfulness is sweet, but I will not be able to use the flowers they will bring back. The timing is all wrong. I must also speak with Keeper Ur to not come down too hard on them. Yes they broke the rules, but it was for a kind cause. And those woods are not all that dangerous to begin with.”

Shaking my head slightly I continued down the road as she went back through the gates surrounding the cloisters. In only a few minutes I came upon the bridge that lead out of the city to the north, seeing the edges of the woods in question just outside the shield. Almost of their own accord my feet veered over the bridge and down the road, taking me into the tree line before I fully realized what I was doing.

Nothing would go wrong, these woods were safe after all. But there was also no harm in double checking on their safety. Even the Holy Mother didn’t seem too concerned. I mean wouldn’t The One God himself give her a heads up if something was going to go wrong? And that Keeper Ur’s uneasiness could just be regular worry. Still, if they ended up needing a Hunter for whatever reason, I could be there. I wasn’t sure how good Lilia was yet, but I had a feeling her combat skill wasn’t as strong as her skill in healing.

I would never find them if I simply wandered around aimlessly though, so I quickly made a few birds out of gold wire. Imbuing them with my magic I sent my new temporary constructs on a scouting mission. Within a few moments one of them came flying back to lead me to an open meadow with bushes of the white flowers all around. It’s job done the construct destroyed itself, the gold wire melting while in mid flight to rain bits of gold down on the ground.

Absently I caught the falling liquid by making a bowl of wind. The little pieces all merged together before hardening again, allowing me to pocket the small nugget. Gold was still precious after all and being able to save even a little bit could come in handy later. The other three constructs I had made would have already melted from the sky since the four had been linked, their gold returned to the earth it had come from.

Leaning against a tree I watched the group from the shadows, unwilling to announce my presence if I didn’t need to. If I were to show up they would think something was wrong, or want me to partake in their merriment. But this kind of thing wasn’t for me. I might believe in their religion, but I didn’t practice it the way they did. If I were to go out there it would be like trying to put a square peg in a round hole, I just wouldn’t fit in.

About fifteen minutes later two priests came into the clearing, handing out some admonishments before saying they were leaving. Looking a bit downcast the five initiates followed the two adults. Lilia seemed to have brushed their words off, that is if she even heard them to begin with. She followed too, but with that small smile and dreamy gaze that seemed to be her normal. Just as I was turning to leave I saw the ground out in the field surge upwards slightly.

Even as I watched, the head of a Sanderling poked up, looking left and right as if seeking something. After a moment it dropped its head back underground and kept moving. I saw the small ripple of disturbed ground as it headed off towards the group that had just left. With a sigh I slipped the duffle bag off my back and pulled out my Lexington before walking towards the slow moving ripple at a sedate pace.

“Phase two activate. Phantom shot.”

As I twisted the upper barrel off the gun I reattached it onto the main barrel like a silencer. Standing in the path of the slow moving ripple I pointed the two foot long muzzle at the ground and waited. As soon as the ripple was underneath me I fired, using the extra force from the magic to counteract the barrier of rock and stone between us. Even as I flicked my wrist, making the muzzle I had attached flip back up into position over top the main weapon, the ground heaved upwards like a depth charge going off. Slipping the weapon into my belt I left the meadow to follow the group back into the city.

*******

An interesting end to the day. But tell me, what are your thoughts on all the possibilities that now no longer exist because of this timeline? Oh it is true that this day, while it has happened has also not yet happened and may never happen. But because you observed it, does that make this timeline more real than all the others? More valid? Does it deny the possibilities of all the other timelines, making them all false or fake? Can you really say this is the true and real timeline simply because you observed it?

What then would happen if you observe this day again, only making different choices and creating a different ending? Would that too be considered truth? How then would there be two endings to the same day that are both truth? Is their any day that could be considered canon? That is, the one timeline that is widely recognized as the truth.

If on multiple timelines he fell in love with Liz, or Lilia, or even the little girl, ending up marrying them. Which of those timelines would be the canon truth that would be accepted? All of them? None of them? Or does it simply come down to the one which you observed first? These are interesting questions that I hope you will help me answer by returning again to watch this day unfold. An outside perspective such as yours would be most beneficial, since I fear I am too close to the subject matter at hand. Being able to see all the possibilities of every second at once as I can. Until then traveler.
1111211121122212212.title: Break promise

choices: "They went to the Whispering Woods to pick vadivin flowers."
"I saw them, but I'm not sure where they are right now."
111121112112221222.content:
“Sorry I can’t promise such a thing. Though I don’t plan on sticking around here so I doubt I will meet anyone who might ask. It’s your decision to go sneaking off, that has to come with risks. If I promised not to say anything where would the risk be?”

Raising my hand I waved at all of them before heading deeper into the north side. I was getting a bit hungry so I might as well get something to eat before heading home. Lilia returned my wave with a head bob before her and the other five headed off the way we had come. Personally I thought it was a good thing the initiates were going against the teachings. Both because they would never grow without breaking the rules and because I thought the rules of the cloisters were a bit harsh and stifling to begin with. They shouldn’t feel like prisoners, only let out when the wardens deemed it necessary.

I found myself sitting outside at a small diner that looked new. I didn’t remember seeing it the last time I had come to the north side at least. The food was good, but not worth the price they asked in my opinion. I tipped generously anyway before heading back home.

As I passed the cloister entrance again I saw a woman in a pure white gown, sporting a cape that seemed to be made out of feathers and wearing a wreath of snow white flowers on her head. I noted the flowers had a slightly withered look to them, a bit shriveled at the tips of the petals but otherwise unblemished. She was standing out on the sidewalk looking around with the same dreamy eyed stare as Lilia sported. Even though I had never met her I knew who this was. Even if I hadn’t known what that cape of office represented, the almost visible aura of power that sheathed her body from head to toe would have told me this was someone important. This was the Holy Mother herself.

“You boy, your name is Riktal right?”

“Yes.”

I didn’t even question how she knew my name or why she happened to be standing out here. She had a direct line to The One God just like Lilia did. I was as sure as the sun rose in the morning that she had been directed and told by the god himself.

“Have you seen some initiates around lately? Keeper Ur has been looking for them but has been unable to find them for the last thirty minutes.”
111121112112221222.title: Don't promise

choices: Into the forest at a run
Into the forest at a walk
1111211121122212221.content:
“Oh dear. That’s sweet of them but I won’t be able to use those flowers. They must be picked on the night of a full moon to make the spell keeping them from wilting for six months work. I’ll have to send someone to go collect them before they get into trouble. It’s dangerous outside the shields you know. Even in a safe place like those woods. Thank you for telling me young man and may His wisdom and light guide your path.”

With that she turned, gliding more than walking back through the gates around the cloister. Shaking my head I continued walking. Today had been a strange day indeed. It wasn’t every day one got to talk to the Holy Mother herself. Or meet not one but two people who truly had The One God talking in their ear sometimes.

As I passed one of the bridges heading off to the left my eyes were drawn to the lush green forest just across the bridge and off to the side of the road. I hoped those kids wouldn’t get in too much trouble when they got back. I had only taken a few steps passed that point when something made me stop and look at the woods again. It was just my paranoia talking. My overactive mind that expected the worst case scenario in everything. But I just couldn’t shake that little nagging question of what if.
1111211121122212221.title: "They went to the Whispering Woods to pick ...

11112111211222122211.content:
Paranoid or not a Hunter shouldn’t ignore such gut instincts. If in the end I looked foolish because nothing happened then so be it. The prime directive of a Hunter was to keep people safe. If someone got hurt because I walked instead of ran I would be failing in that directive.

I had no clue where to find them, there was four miles of forest to search through after all. That didn’t mean I couldn’t find them. I just needed to take a little bit of time. Slipping the bag off my back I reached into one of the side pockets until I found the fine gold wire I had coiled there. I stood there in the middle of the woods cutting strips of wire the length of my palm. Four should be enough for what I wanted.

Carefully I twisted the bits of metal, shaping them into the very basic shapes of small birds. More a suggestion of wings against an ovoid blob, but it met the requirements of constructed magic. Pulling out my knife I cut open my thumb, slathering my blood on the gold wire while shoving my magic into it.

“Oh gods above and below. You who control the soil from which the gold was born. The fire from which it was forged, the water in which it was cooled grant life to this your lifeless vessel for but a short moment. That it might show unto me that which I seek. Grant this to me oh gods who dwell above and below.”

The head section of the gold birds lifted up from where they rested on my palm twitching from side to side. With a jerk I tossed them all into the air where they hovered around my head for a moment.

“Go.”

The darted off into the woods, veering to the cardinal directions while I slipped the duffel bag back on my back and started running again. Barely a minute later one of the birds zipped back, circling above my head before zooming off back the way it had come. I followed, coming upon an open meadow filled with white flowers just as one of the young girls let out a scream of terror.

A Sanderling burst out of the ground under the feet of one of the boy’s throwing him through the air. His hard scales grated against the leg of the second boy who had been standing right next to him. I saw the flesh get rubbed off on the small scales and begin bleeding profusely even as Lilia sent an arrow of light in it’s direction. The giant worm beast fell backwards for just a second before squirming around to right itself again. But Lilia had taken that time to step in front of the five initiates, throwing a bubble barrier around their little group while the girls worked on healing the boys.

I let my right hand drop to my waist as I ran, pulling the dagger back out of it’s sheath just as the monster attacked the shield. It took only another second to get in throwing range. Once I was though I stopped and flipped the knife, holding it by the tip only long enough to chuck it at the monster with a sideways flick. The blade sunk into the hard skin only a few inches but that was all I needed.

Essence of fire, super compressed by wind. Make the arm a conduit and the fingers the barrel. Up out of the core and shoot like a bullet. The lightning shot from my extended two fingers, making a beeline for the knife stuck in the monsters flesh. I felt the vibrations of my body as I was shocked by some of the feedback but I kept pouring in the magic down that connection between us until the Sanderling exploded into little chunks that dissipated into the air.

The little bird I had made of wire melted while in mid flight, it’s job done. Little droplets of gold raining from the sky to be absorbed into the ground. Making my way over to the little group I tried hard not to clutch at my chest and the slightly erratic way my heart was pounding. I hadn’t quite mastered lightning yet, it being a slightly higher tier of fire a normal Combat Hunter like me didn’t really have an aptitude for. A full blown caster type Hunter would have no problems with it though.

“Are you guys all right?”

“Yeah we’re fine. Thanks for saving us.”

Lilia finished healing the skinned leg of the one boy as I smiled at the girl who had thanked me with a small bow. She stood up and held out her hand to me expectantly. I simply raised my eyebrow as if to ask what she wanted. With a sigh she grabbed my left arm and yanked it into view, cradling it in both hands while she cast her healing onto my blackened fingers.

“Why wouldn’t you want me to heal your fingers? And why would you use a magic you haven’t mastered yet?”

“Save your healing for someone who needs it more. This is nothing, my own ability can take care of it tonight. As to why I used it, well it was just the first thing I thought of that would bridge the distance the fastest.”

“I bet your heart is skipping erratically too.”

Without even waiting for me to say anything she planted her hand on my chest and sent her power in to even out my heartbeat so I didn’t have a mini heart attack.

“I think it best if we all go back, the Holy Mother is looking for all of you so you had best be prepared for some punishment. I’m sure she will be grateful though to find out you are all safe. Don’t worry too much, I don’t think even she thought anything would happen by the way she acted when I talked to her earlier.”

The five initiates all agreed a bit dejectedly, but followed me and Lilia out of the open meadow anyway. One of the girls, the one that had thanked me for saving them, handed me one of the vadivin flowers with a smile and a blush. I smiled back before sticking the flower into my hair over my ear which seemed to make her even happier. We were just leaving the forest when two priest came running up slightly out of breath.

They started to scold the children but I caught their eyes over all the heads, giving it a small shake that made them shut up. After a bit of explaining they thanked me for my help and took charge of the children. I was about to head on home when something made me decide to walk with them. I probably wouldn’t be allowed in the cloisters, and they would still get a lecture, but they didn’t need these two scolding them all the way home as well. Maybe I was being a bit meddlesome in the politics of their religion, but they still deserved a little leeway and freedom. As our little group walked back to the cloisters I had to wonder what else might happen today. Or tomorrow for that matter.

******

Oh what a tangled web we weave. Is that not what one of your great writers once said? Indeed, life truly is a tangled web. Normally you only live one life, go down one path at each choice you make and so do not see the different possibilities of where you might have ended up. But through this window you have the power to see what alterations a simple choice can make in someone’s life.

It is interesting to see is it not? The farther back one goes the more the differences are sometimes pronounced. Of course this does not take into account the choices that other people make, only the choices you as Riktal were able to control. Still, this is an interesting experiment of mine, as I get to see just what kind of human you are. I find each one of you humans that I have given this power to is different. You each make different choices for different reasons. Sometimes even the same choice for different reasons.

Why, there was one guy who made choices based solely on the desire to create his own harem. With the thought that if he did this or that, the girl or girls would fall in love with him. He was quite an interesting fellow, though his lusts did not bear fruit in the end. Whatever happened to the person he had been controlling? Oh yes he died horrible over and over. But I digress, such reminiscing bears no spot in my mind. Some of my one’s and zeroe’s must be crossed. Come again traveler, take up the mantle of god and continue to see what else this day holds.
11112111211222122211.title: Into the forest at a run

11112111211222122212.content:
Paranoia or not I should still investigate. If nothing was wrong all well and good. But if something were to happen and I wasn’t there to stop it or lend a hand when I could have been I would be a failure as a Hunter. There was no need to run though. I didn’t know where in the woods they were and running around wildly would just tire me out without getting me any closer. I needed to come at this logically, solving the problem with an efficient use of magic.

Slipping my duffel off my back I scrounged around in one of the side pockets until I found the gold wire I kept in there. Gold was a great conductor for magic, plus it was pliable. This wire was almost one hundred percent gold, ideal for what I had in mind. I thought about making birds, but instead decided to make miniature Furies. It wouldn’t hurt to have some talking eyes in the sky.

So after cutting four strips about as long as the length of my elbow to the tip of my fingers I began to twist and bend the gold into four vaguely humanoid shapes with wings. By the time I was done I had the skeletons of four Furies a little smaller than my palm laying on the ground. A quick nick of my finger with my belt knife and a few drops of blood over top of each of them and I was ready to begin.

“From earth you are born to create the base. The skeleton that upholds the body. Bring forth the rocks, the soil, the clay to become that body. Use my fire as your sustaining force and let the wind be your home.”

While I chanted the spell I let my magic flow into each bit of gold. To sustain the form I desired. The earth melted, letting the gold sink inside. There was a second of stillness before four mounds of earth bulged up where the wire had been. The ground broke open like cracked eggs to release small half human half bird forms. Furies, an offshoot of Harpies, though with razor sharp claws that could cut anything like a knife. Even if they were only slightly larger than the palm of my hand they were still dangerous constructs.

“Fly. Report to me immediately. Do you understand?”

“Yes. Squawk!”

The four Furies shoved off, creating great gouges in the ground as their claws sliced through hard stone and dirt. Soon they were out of sight, heading in the four cardinal directions as I packed up my things and returned my bag to my back. Once secured I began walking again, though my searching was rather aimless. The Furies were linked to each other, able to communicate amongst themselves across great distances but not with me. This made them ideal search constructs, able to scour a large area in little time without crossing into one another’s territory or searching an already looked at spot.

It was only a few minutes of wandering when one of my Furies came streaking out of nowhere to hover in front of me.

“Danger! Folow! Follow! Squawk!”

The Fury went pelting off away from the direction it had come and I chased after. While I ran I gave the Fury the order to attack and defend to pass along to the others. Otherwise they would simply hover in the air doing nothing with no other orders after they found their target. That was the downfall of such simple temporary constructed magic’s. They couldn’t take complicated orders or adapt to a situation like the a human or a more complicated construct.

The Fury lead me to a meadow with white vadivan flowers growing from bushes all around. A Sanderling was rampaging around the meadow while the other three Furies attacked it from the air. The Fury I had followed flew to assist it’s comrades. Lilia was trying to lure it away from the initiates, the two boys were down, one bleeding from his leg, the other looked like he was just unconscious. There was one girl trying to heal the bloody leg, the other two were nowhere to be seen. No, that wasn’t true. There at the edge of the meadow, the blood streak on the tree telling the tale of how she had been flung into it and slid down where she was now laying unmoving.

The other girl was by her side trying desperately to heal her with her limited ability. Even as I dropped the bag to one shoulder and shoved my hand inside the giant worm smacked Lilia with the end of it’s tail, sending her flying as well. She was able to cushion her landing by encasing herself in her white yellow light so she didn’t end up smacking her head into a tree as well. I didn’t let it get any farther as it began to slither towards her.

“Furies! Attach!”

The constructs dive bombed from the air, grabbing onto the monster’s hard flesh and cutting deep gouges in it just like they had the rocks.

“Furies! Explode!”

All four released the magic holding them together making a smokescreen that threw the monster backwards with a roar. Even as I pulled out my Lexington I could see the great holes the explosions had left in the creatures sides. As I leveled the weapon and pulled the trigger I sent even more of my power to coat the bullet, sending the projectile speeding forward with a green and purple outer shell, the two colors spinning in opposite directions.

The bullet hit the unmarred underbelly, the skin refusing to yield for a moment before finally giving way, the twin aura’s coating the slug expanded outward on impact, ripping the beast apart and sending chunks of it flying in all directions. Even as those chunks were falling from the sky along with strips of flesh it all turned into white particles that floated away into nothingness. Shoving the weapon into my belt I assessed the area for any more threats. There was the hole in the ground the monster must have come from, but nothing else.

Lilia was already running over to work on the girl with the head injury by the time I got closer. They all thanked me and I absently told them it wasn’t a problem while I kept watch around the meadow for any other monsters that might show up. I noticed the two unharmed girls stuck close by me even as Lilia lifted the one she was working on to bring her towards our little group. Setting her down she worked on the boys leg, adding her skill to the healing he was already applying to himself.

“I think it best if we leave. I know the Holy Mother said she would send someone to come get you, but the less time we spend in this forest right now the better. I doubt there is anything else out there, but I would rather be safe than sorry.”

“But where did it come from Mr. Hunter?”

I put my hand on the girls head as she got a slightly worried look, trying to pass on my reassurance and confidence.

“Farther north most likely. They burrow underground like the worms they look like. Their natural habitat is warmer climates than this normally so that means north. It was probably migrating south out of necessity, such as a scarcity of prey. Since there is little between here and the Shadow Forest where it is normally found, it’s probably been on the move for at least a week. You just happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time.”

Lilia agreed with my assessment of the situation and seconded my opinion that we should leave. While she picked up the girl again, I scooped up the still unconscious boy before heading back out of the woods. We stayed in a tight pack, the three initiates not wanting to stray far from my side. It took about ten minutes to get back out of the woods but when we did we were met by two priests running down the road out of breath. They offered to take my burden from me but I refused, telling them I would deliver the boy to the cloisters personally.

It wasn’t that I thought they wouldn’t take care of him or anything, but I noticed the glares they aimed at the children but were too in control of themselves to say anything with me around. It wasn’t my place to interfere in the religious politics and rules they abided by, but I also didn’t think these children needed to be needlessly scolded when even the Holy Mother hadn’t seemed too concerned. This was just a freak accident, nothing more. If I could shield them from that until they got to the cloisters then I would. Though I was sure they would still be lectured and reprimanded after I left, but I couldn’t help that. At least this gave them time to collect themselves and get ready for it.

I didn’t know what else this day had in store for me, or what repercussions all this might have on my immediate future. But I had a feeling I would be spending more time with Lilia than I originally thought.

**********

So ends the day. A day? Another day? With so many possibilities for just a single day, I sometimes get confused as to what to call it. Perhaps I should say so ends another possibility. I find the choices you made interesting. Though I do not quite understand the reasoning behind all of them. Such knowledge yet eludes me. Further observation is required.

You will assist me in that won’t you traveler? You will come again and watch this day unfold over and over? I will of course grant you the power of choice again, so that you might create another possibility. It is only through constant observation can one truly find the answers they desire. Using this days many infinite possibilities as a control will greatly help out. Why jumping from a day like this to a fast action space battle just wouldn’t do.

After all, are your choices the next time going to be altered by what you now know? Are your perceptions of events going to be different now that you know a little bit about Liz and Lilia? This I would very much like to find out along with everything else. So come again fair traveler! I am always here and always watching.
11112111211222122212.title: Into the forest at a walk

1111211121122212222.content:
“Oh dear, I hope they aren’t getting into any trouble. And I really hope they didn’t go outside the shields. It’s not safe out there you know.”

She turned, taking a single step back towards the gate when she suddenly stopped and stared up at the sky. Finally she turned around again to face me shaking her head.

“Oh you naughty boy you! You know it’s not nice to lie like that. He doesn’t approve of such fibs.”

With a suppressed sigh I told her what little I knew. I should have figured I wouldn’t be able to get away with deflecting like that. Even though I hadn’t promised them I wouldn’t tell, I had also been under no obligation to actually say anything to anyone either. After I was done explaining things to her she shook her head slightly before patting my head like a little child.

“There there, I forgive you for trying to lie to me. I understand why you did it, but those children shouldn’t have gone. Even if the woods are safe enough, those flowers need to be picked at a specific time of the month for the spells to preserve them for six months to work. I suppose I should send someone after them before they get into too much more trouble.”

She again looked up at the sky, as if having a conversation with God. Indeed she probably was. The slight smile that had constantly been on her face suddenly drooped as her fingers lifted to hide her lips.

“Oh no.”

Her eyes dropped to me, losing that dreamy state as the brunt of her power caught mine.

“You must go save them. They will be beset upon by a Sanderling soon. Lilia cannot take that thing on her own yet. Her attack spells aren’t that strong. Two of the initiates will die if you do not go now.”

Her gaze wasn’t pleading, nor was it demanding. But there was an expectation about her as if she had no doubt I would go because The One God had said I had to if the initiates were to be saved. I didn’t even say goodbye, enhancing my legs with the power of wind and strength before dashing off down the sidewalk. I wasn’t going because God had said I needed to go, I was going because it was my job as a Hunter to protect people.

Dodging in and out of other pedestrians on my way past, I was little more than a blur. I had no way to gauge my speed but I guessed I was going at perhaps forty five or fifty miles an hour. I was wasting a lot of magic to keep up this pace and would be almost empty by the time I found them, but if it was only a Sanderling. I didn’t need magic; my own skill was enough for such a low D class creature.

Within the space of two minutes I was inside the woods, ducking under and jumping over low hanging branches and ground clutter. I imagined dead leaves and sticks being picked up and pulled in my wake but didn’t bother to look back. I had no clue where to go in this four miles of woods, all I could do was run and search.

At four minutes there was a scream to my right so I veered in that direction, almost slamming into a tree as I made the sharp ninety degree pivot. Sliding my left hand over my shoulder while I ran, I dug into my duffle bag for a weapon, grabbing the first thing I could. My fingers pulled out what looked like the hilt of two daggers joined together. Activating the artifact, twin curved blades sprang out of the simple leather wrapped handles. A war-glaive. Not a bad weapon for a Sanderling at all.

The trees suddenly parted to reveal a meadow with white flowers all around. Lilia was holding off the Sanderling with a bubble shield while the three female initiates were trying to heal the bleeding legs of the two boys. I knew the shield wouldn’t last much longer, I could already see it flickering. Running past the bubble I brought my war-glaive up in an underhanded strike while shoving off from the ground. My blade sank in, ripping the six foot tall worm creature in half right down the middle just as the shield gave way. It let out a small scream before breaking into little white particles that drifted off.

While Lilia bent down and helped heal the two boys I looked at the other three girls, assessing them for any overt signs of damage. I didn’t see anything obvious though. A glance around the field showed me the hole the worm had probably come from, the vibrations of their footsteps above it had probably attracted it’s attention. I had to wonder from just how far away this monster had come, Sanderlings had never been native to these woods to begin with.

Once the two boys were up and walking again I looked at all of them as they gave me bows and words of thanks.

“I’m glad I was able to make it in time. But now I think it’s time to head back. You had also best be prepared for your punishment since it was the Holy Mother herself who asked me to come save you. Your absence did not go unnoticed. Just be grateful nothing worse happened than some minor injuries.”

They all agreed, giving thanks to The One God for watching over them. I didn’t think it would do to tell them what the Holy Mother had said would happen if I hadn’t shown up. It would accomplish nothing except to make them wonder and undermine their faith. Lilia gave me a small smile of thanks when the others weren’t looking before lapsing into her own little world again. But I did notice the initiates all stayed close to me until two priests came hurrying down the road just as we left the woods and reentered the safety of the shields.

Once I was sure they were all safely handed over with yet more thanks from both the priests and the initiates, I turned and headed home, wondering if anything else was going to happen today.

*******

Interesting is it not? Choices that range from the simple to the complex alter the outcome to such a degree. Sometimes the correct path is not always the most obvious one. And always are you left to wonder about what could have happened if you had chosen differently. Even a simple play on words can alter the outcome. Afterwards it is easy to see where you went wrong or what you could have done better, but in the heat of the moment such things are not so easy.

I thank you traveler for helping me answer a bit of the questions I seek. Please come again, replay this day over with new choices so that I might learn even more. Until then traveler, may the choices you make be the ones you desire.
1111211121122212222.title: "I saw them, but I'm not sure where the...

11112111212.content:
