“Not interested sis. If I were to help you, you would be more interested in hanging all over me than you would in the class. They need to learn what you have to teach so go do it. Besides I’m not a recognized Hunter yet so me helping you would be opening both the school and the union up for a lawsuit.”

“Awwww! Why do you have to be such a downer Riki tiki? No one will say anything!”

“You can’t guarantee that. And don’t call me Riki tiki! Now go. You’ve already caused a big enough scene and wasted enough of the classes time.”

With a sigh and a small pout she finally turned around to address the rest of the class. Grabbing a mini lab kit from the back of the room I returned to my seat while she discussed a bit about Alchemy. By the time the rest of the students began pulling out their own mini labs and stock of ingredients I already had my desk set up. My sister started walking around the room answering questions, pointing out different tricks and tips and telling them exactly when to add an item or when to stir it.

I simply focused on making a translocation potion while they worked on their basic healing ones. In order to make it really worth making though I would need to get it added into an artifact of some sort so it could be used multiple times. Right now it was a one time use item that wouldn’t justify the cost of making it if it was used as is. But I had decided if I was going to somehow help Lilia as she said I was going to, she needed some reliable way of getting me. Being able to make a summoning portal that would either take her to my location or me to hers was the best thing I could think of right now.

A ring or a necklace, perhaps with a light purple gem inset into it. That would be easy for her to wear while being able to use the artifact at anytime. It would go well with her purplish blue hair and light brown skin. I could make the artifact myself with the materials I had on me, but I was no master. At most she would get two uses out of it, almost as bad as the single use potion it was now. I knew a good artificer that would set it up to work at least six or seven times before it needed refilled. I could get it done tonight and give it to her tomorrow.

I finished the brew and was just capping it up with wax when the bell rang. I looked up a bit surprised, having lost track of time while focusing on what I was doing. Quickly I put my stuff away along with everyone else as my sister blew me a kiss and left again using a teleportation potion, telling me she would be on a job for a while before she did.

As I picked up the translocation potion I noticed Lilia was one of the last ones still in the room putting her things away. Shouldering my duffle bag I headed for the door but something made me stop and look down at the potion in my hand. I had a feeling I should give it to her now instead of later. I knew that could just be my paranoia talking, I tended to expect the worst all the time and nothing ever really happened to prove it. What would she really need my help for between now and tomorrow? We would be in classes the rest of the day together and then she would most likely go home and be safely ensconced in the divine cloisters.

I had used my stock of supplies in making this and didn't have enough on hand to make another one at the moment. Giving her this one now with the plans of making another one for the artifact was out of the question. The help I was most likely going to be giving her was going to happen in the far future, such divinations and seer seeing rarely showed the immediate future. In fact I couldn’t recall any I had heard right off the top of my head. So yes, the more I thought about it the more likely it was just me making a mountain out of a molehill. Lilia walked past me with a small smile as she headed on her way to Combat class and I closed my fist over the potion.
11112111212.title: Don't help her teach

1111211122.content:
Even as she was jumping towards me over the heads of the two boys in front of my desk I was tipping backwards onto one leg of the chair. Balancing on that single leg I spun around quickly before falling towards the floor, using the back of my seat as a shield as I kicked it her way. Even as I sent it flying I rolled to the side so when she shoved it back in my direction it hit the floor harmlessly.

As I came out of my rolled I did a handstand, spinning quickly towards the left and shooting out my leg as I bent my waist in an arc. My sister caught the blow on her forearms, blocking just in time to keep my shoe from connecting with her face and sending her flying away from me. It took only a second for her to plant a hand on the floor and come spinning to a stop crouched in front of me ready to leap again.

“Riki tiki! Why won’t you let me fill up my tiki tank! And what are you doing here anyways? Why didn’t mother and father take you slaying with them!”

She leapt towards me again, doing a little flip in the air to try and distract me, but she had used that tactic on me before. I acted like I was caught off guard before catching the hands she stretched out to wrap around my neck and shoving them to the side as I did a half circle around her body, snagging a low level paralysis potion from her waist, breaking the wax and throwing it onto her back in one smooth motion.

Her body locked up as she hit the floor, skidding to a stop. Casually I bent over her, grabbing the antidote and holding it out for her to see.

“Sis really, how many times have I told you to act your age? I haven’t been your Riki tiki for almost ten years now. You’re a Hunter, act like it at least. Now if you promise to be good I’ll release you from the potion. Blink twice if you understand and agree.”

She blinked twice, unable to actually do anything else except breath. With a nod of the head I broke the wax with my thumb and poured the liquid inside of it out. As it hit the air it turned into a gas that surrounded her, allowing the fumes to be breathed in and breaking the spell. I held out a hand, helping her to her feet as she pouted and tried to embrace me again. I held out my hand, wagging my finger at her before pointing towards the front of the room.

“No. You’ve got a class to teach so teach it. Quit making more of a scene then you already are.”

Letting out a drawn out sigh she dropped her head before turning to teach the class at large. She began her lesson as I picked up the chair and replaced it, sitting down as unobtrusively as I could and ignoring the wide eyed shock in the faces looking my way. I had figured I couldn’t hide who I was for very long. I was just thankful my name wasn’t on the role call yet. But I had been hoping to get at least another day or two out of it before they found out I was a tenth generation Hunter.

Even as I got up to get a lab kit from the back of the room and my sister started instructing them on how to make healing potions, I could feel the calculating eyes on me. The sudden interest in me as more than just a transfer student. Wondering how they could weasel their way into my life and good graces for their own benefit. With a name like Zelkov so many doors could be opened for them they would not otherwise have access to. Just saying they knew me could be the difference between them getting a thousand Reul or five thousand Reul for a monster drop.

I only listened with half an ear as my sister told them when to stir and when to heat it up. Talking about the importance of following the instructions exactly or they would wind up with a mess on their hands. She had already taught all of this to me years ago. And I had graduated from simple health potions long ago. Instead I worked on my own, making a paralysis potion and antidote to replace the ones I had used on my sister. I might have my problems with all of them, but big sis was the only one I thought of as family. She had raised me for a good portion of my life while my parents were out saving some part of the world or another.

I also made a third potion. It would be useless right now but later I could get someone I knew to put it into a magical artifact. Then Lilia could create a summoning gateway between me and her if she absolutely needed to. I couldn’t do an instant teleportation spell where she could pull me to her since there was no magic that could do that, and regular teleportation spells only worked on the person who made them since it used their magic. But a translocation portal could bring me to her or her to me so had more utility. A gold necklace artifact with a purple gem might look nice on her. Or a ring. But girls liked necklaces more than rings right?”

My sister stayed away and let me work as she pointed out different tips and tricks the rest of the class could use to make their potions more effective, or how to set up the area around them for ease of access. The bell finally rang, signaling the end of class. I was a bit surprised as I finished sealing the wax around my potions, it hadn’t felt like an hour already. Big sis came over to me and I handed her the two potions as she looked at me with those big puppy dog eyes and everyone else in the room lingered to watch.

“Saves you the trouble of making them yourself.”

“You really are the best brother!”

She tried to wrap her arms around me and I held her off. She gave me more sad puppy eyes as she pouted, begging without words. With a sigh I took my hand away and she gave a small squeal of joy, hugging me around the neck while rubbing her face against mine. She let out a sigh of pleasure as she squeezed and shook me back and forth.

“I really can’t go on without my tiki juice! I love this feeling! Just squeezing you makes me feel like I can face the world again! I love you so much Riki tiki!”

Finally she let me go with another sigh of contentment putting up her fists and bouncing around slightly.

“Ok! Tiki tank’s fully recharged! I’m ready to face my next mission cause I know my lucky tiki juice will protect me. I won’t be back home for about a week so give mother my love when you see her next!”

With that she pulled a teleportation potion from her waist and threw it to the ground, stepping into the green smoke that ushered out. The gas billowed up a second longer before sinking into itself, leaving nothing behind, not even a pile of broken glass. Glaring around the room I heard a few snickers from those who had witnessed the exchange.

“What? You got a problem? If you do speak up and I will be ever so happy to correct it for you. And I warn you now, if I hear anyone calling me Riki tiki I will personally rip out your tongue. Big sis is the only one allowed to call me that and get away with it. You have been warned.”

As I picked up my bag and left the room ahead of everyone else I tried to mentally compose myself. I could still hear the whispering and even a few giggles, but only at the faintest edges of my hearing. Next was Combat class, so perhaps I could get the Arena Master to give me a small floor to myself so I could work off some of this annoyance.

The rest of the boys began gearing up more fully based on their specialized weapon of choice. Those who used their fists wore special gloves and added extra padding onto their forearms. Those who used shields wore extra padding all over and one boy even wore full plate mail armor. Gunners had wrist braces, staff wielders had finger guards. Just watching what pieces they put on gave me a good idea of whether they specialized in one weapon or many.

I didn’t need any of that extra gear though. There was probably nothing I really needed it for. I doubted they had any A class monsters I would have to go all out on anyways. At the most they might have some B class that wouldn’t even make me break out a second phase on one of my weapons. I could just use some of the stock items the Arena Master could provide instead of my augmented weapons if I really needed to.

I was about to close the locker on my duffle bag when something stopped me. I wasn’t sure what it was but I had a feeling I should take at least one of my own weapons out with me. When I opened the bag up, the first two I saw were the ones those boys had been handling. Well they would do as well as any others. But which one to take?
1111211122.title: Avoid her

choices: “Hey big blue and ugly! Can I have this next dance?”
11112111221.content:
Pulling on my Knuckles I touched the small yellow gem stud on the back of my left wrist. I watched with one eye as both open fingered gloves seemed to break up into separate fibers while the blades shrank away, all of it getting sucked into the yellow gem. By the time I had my bag zipped up and secured in my locker, the weapons only looked like two thin black bands wrapped around my wrists. The single jewel on the back of the left one the only indication they weren’t just useless ornamentation.

The Arena Master stood in front of the class once everyone had gathered and awaited instructions, informing everyone that today was going to be live combat training instead of sparring matches. I could see the excitement on the faces around me as he explained what was going to happen. He told me and someone named Hawthrope to sit out even as he began splitting the class off into teams. It took me a moment to remember that Hathrope was the last name of the girl I had knifed earlier even as she followed me up into the bleachers.

I considered asking the teacher if there was a spare monster I could fight just for something to do but he seemed busy with the rest of the class and I felt it unwise to bother him. This class was one of the most important in their academy training. What they learned here could very well mean life or death, and distracting the teacher could prove fatal.

So I sat down in the middle where a wall rose out of the floor to split the combat area into two. As the first two groups marched excitedly out onto the field with their stock set of weapons to meet the magically caged monster’s that were rising up to meet them, Liz plopped down onto the bench an arms length away. She didn’t say anything at first, simply watched as the battles below commenced.

“So you’re a Zelkov. That explains how you were able to get the best of me earlier. I knew you had to be from an old family, fifth or sixth generation at least. But never expected a tenth generation.”

I grunted but otherwise didn’t comment. I didn’t know what she was playing at, but it was best to give nothing away I didn’t have to. Being a Hunter was just a bunch of politics, and old families were especially dangerous since they had more time to hone tweak and tighten their skills to pass on to the next generation.

“I don’t hold the whole stabbing thing against you by the way. You were perfectly in your right to do so. My brother would have done the same in that position. And like you he would have given me a healing potion. Though I admit, it was the first time I thought I was really going to die.”

Again I remained silent, simply letting her chat away a bit. She told me a little about her family until I finally sighed and asked her point blank what it was she wanted. She blinked at me as if the answer was fairly obvious.

“Want? I just want to talk. This is the first time since I moved to this city that I really got to talk with someone who understands what being a Hunter is all about. Well at this school anyway. I’ve met a few Hunter’s out in town but they usually want to reminisce about the “good old days.” I don’t really fit in well around here in case you couldn’t tell. Not much of what they call a people person. I just don’t get the whole fascination with fashion, or the newest boy band or what celebrity is hot. I know enough about that stuff as I need to but it’s just not my thing.”

As the first group finished their match and the next group slipped into the ring to face their own monster I nodded my head slowly.

“I guess I can understand that. Doesn’t mean I completely believe you of course but I can understand the desire at least. I’m not much of a people person either. Well not much of a peer person is more like it. I can deal with kids and I can deal with older people, but between like fourteen and twenty five? Totally clueless. It’s like they are alien or something.”

“I know right! Though I’m more of the twenty three and below category of clueless. I know a bit about how to deal with kids, but you could fit that information into my side pouch. I can deal with traumas of the mind and body on them, but ask me to interact with them on a more personal level? You’d have better luck teaching a troll basic math higher than counting to five.”

I couldn’t help but grin at that, making her grin back as we both chuckled a bit. I found myself liking her if for no other reason than she did seem to be a lot like me. I still didn’t completely trust her though, there was still a possibility she was playing a longer ranging game. We chatted a bit more about small things, feeling each other out as to likes and dislikes. I supposed this was what it was like to make a friend, though I really didn’t have much experience at such things.

When the two groups on the field killed their monster a group of five walked onto the field to meet a Glif. I recognized Gregory and Lilia by name and the tank wearing full plate armor and the boy who had been with Gregory earlier by sight. The second girl I didn’t even remember seeing her face. I commented to Liz how this group must be a higher level since they were fighting a C class monster instead of D class like the rest.

“Yeah they are all good in their own way. Jethic is a natural tank. First generation and almost no magic to speak of but I could see him taking on a few B class monsters soon with the right grouping. Marsa, the one with the casting staff, has a lot more magic than most. Her spells might not be the strongest yet but she has already mastered a few of the second tier spells. Lilia is a great healer. A bit absentminded at times when not in combat situations, but put her in front of a beastie and it’s like a flip gets switched on in her head. Daniel is the best fister out of the three main ones in this group. First generation as well, but his grandfather was also a Hunter even though his parents aren‘t, so I guess a 1.5 generation Hunter?”

She was silent a moment as the five jumped around dodging the swinging fists of the seven foot tall light blue creature. The Glif was a subclass of giant that had a resistance to magic and stuck to mainly physical attacks until it was on it’s last leg. Then it would put up its dukes, countering any attack sent against it while eating any magic cast during that time to throw back in it’s opponents face.

“Then there is Gregory. I’ll give him credit, he is really good with guns. I wouldn’t say he is a natural, but he has good intuitions and he learns quickly. I’ve never seen a faster and more accurate hipshot before. But for all of that he is still a little weasel. Bit of the sticky fingers and he has an ego. Nothing is ever his fault and he has this need to show off all the time. I bet this fight is going to be the same. Probably going to do something stupid during second phase like attack it. Daniel tries to curb his stupidity, but isn’t always successful. But you know what they say, there is no cure for stupid.”

“Yes I already found out what a slimy rat he is. I’m surprised steps haven’t been taken against him yet. Maybe not Lapiiree but something.”

“Well just about everyone knows so they keep an eye on their things while putting a bit of distance between him and them. It will happen eventually though, he just hasn’t done something stupid enough yet. I’ll personally be surprised if he doesn’t drop out by his senior year. Get himself killed if he is really unlucky.”

Below the Glif went into it’s defensive phase, putting it’s massive fists up in front of it’s face while spreading it’s legs and motioning for the group to attack. As Daniel and Lilia ran towards Jethic to regroup Marsa began casting a magma ball. At first I thought it was a stupid move because the beast sucked it up, throwing it right back at her. But the magma ball bounced off the reflective shield I hadn’t even noticed she had cast, hurtling back along it’s course and slamming back into the monster instead. I nodded my head with a grin, commenting on how smart that had been and Liz agreeing.

Gregory seemed to want to also show off, casting an enhancment spell to increase all his abilities, but having that spell stolen instead. The beast cast it on itself, growing another foot before running towards Gregory at twice it’s normal speed. I was already vaulting over the banister and onto the dividing wall as Jethic shoulder tackled Gregory out of the way, taking the massive augmented fist on his shield which crumpled like paper.

The Glif brought his leg around from the opposite direction in a sideways kick even as Jethic managed to move his near useless shield around to block. The attack hit the shield and I could hear the boys arm snap as he was flung across the arena to slam into the wall hard. The beast brought his leg down, aiming a heel drop at Gregory’s head. At the last moment the boy who seemed to be unconscious suddenly slid across the floor as Marsa used a force pull spell to grab him. Unfortunately she wasn’t fast enough as the heel smashed into his hip, shattering the pelvic bone and blood splattered everwhere.

The monster turned towards Marsa but Daniels was there punching it to grab it’s attention before jumping out of the way of the retaliation attack. By that time I was already jumping off the wall, using a bit of energy to push off while activating my Roller Knuckles. Depressing the hidden triggers on my palms I let the blades spin with a dangerous whirling sound as I punched both sides of the creatures head, rotating sideways and dragging the blades through it’s flesh to score a few deep wounds and tearing off an ear.

I jumped out of the way of it’s counter attack, turning the beast away from the rest of the group before grinning evilly and licking my lips.
11112111221.title: Roller Knuckles

111121112211.content:
The monster roared at my taunt, swinging it’s fists and feet in my direction fast enough to make the air whistle as it sliced through. I simply kept dodging out of the way, tagging it a few times to keep it focused on me while leading it farther and farther from the group. Liz began ushering them all away, dragging Gregory by the armpits. Once I felt they were all at a safe distance I cracked my neck without using my hands and bounced on the balls of my feet while taking a boxing pose.

“You Glif’s might be pretty good natural martial artist, but you ain’t got nothing on anyone with a bit of training. You’ve got two more minutes on your augmentation, do you feel big and bad? Like a real B class monster with all that extra power? Well then as a special treat just for you I will send you off in style.”

The monster put it’s dukes back up in front of its face as it swayed back and forth, motioning for me to attack it. I just gave it a lopsided grin as I touched the yellow gem on the back of my left hand.

“Phase two activate. Jack the Ripper’s.”

The gloves began to extend until they covered my elbow, two thin tracks making a loop from my elbow to my knuckles. Black material wrapped around my legs as well, also creating two thin tracks going from knees to ankles. One of the three saw blades from each fist popped off and floated down to my legs, locking into place along a track in the kneecap. Two more popped off, floating over my head as the last pair rotated into the tracks along the back of my arms.

“Thirty seconds left on your second phase ugly, then we can dance for real. You creatures are pretty stupid, following a set pattern without fail as if you were programmed robots. If you had a bigger brain in there you would have continued to attack, or turned around to go after someone else. But I suppose we Hunter’s should be thankful you monsters are so predictable ninety percent of the time.”

With a roar the beast lowered his hands and charged me. Pushing off I ran forward to meet him, activating the trigger and hearing all the blades coming to life dangerously. Each one spinning round and round in their tracks so fast it looked like there were ten of them instead of one in each.

“Ripper‘s Eulogy! Sing the song of death!”

As he brought his right fist around I brought my right leg up in an arc, meeting it on the spinning blade. The chainsaw like effect tore through flesh and bone even as I jumped and spun, backhanding the monster in the back of the head to tear off huge chunks of flesh right down to the bone and muscle. Reaching up I hooked one of the spare saw blades with a strand of magic. As I came around the side of his head I flung it at the creatures neck like a spinning yo-yo wrapping around it seconds before I pulled myself back towards the monster. The saw blade unwound scoring a deep wound all around the Glif’s neck before returning to it’s position. I brought my left foot up and crossed my right arm over my chest while I prepared for the impact.

My arm slammed into the creatures face just as my leg smashed into it’s chest. I heard the blades screaming as it met resistance in the form of cartilage and bone before the already weakened neck gave way first, my forearm shoving the head right off it’s shoulders in an unrecognizable mess of shredded flesh and blood.

Even as my feet finally touched the floor and I returned my weapon to phase one the body began to break up into dust, disappearing into nothingness to leave behind a vial of it’s blood. I knew it had been overkill, my ripper blades hadn’t seen enough use to really justify going to second phase, but I had said I would give it a worthy death.

Picking up the vial of blood I hurried over to where Lilia was trying desperately to heal both Jethic and Gregory. But both of them had wounds that anyone who had any experience could tell were job ending. Gregory would never walk again, even if she or someone else somehow managed to fix him up completely. And Jethic’s career as a tank was over, his arm would probably need to be amputated and he would have a perpetual stoop from his broken back.

Jethic was barely conscious as he leaned against the wall where he had fallen. He was looking down at his arm knowing the truth even though Lilia and the others were telling him it would be all right. The Arena Master shared a look with me and shook his head slightly. We both knew and Liz knew the severity of things.

Looking down at the vial of Glif blood in my hand I knew I could save one of them. Glif blood had properties that could heal any wound if mixed correctly, and I had all the other ingredients I needed on me. But I could only save one, it would take all the blood from the vial for such serious wounds.

When I looked up I saw both the Arena Master and Liz watching me. They both saw the vial in my hands and knew what I could do with it. They also knew what a difficult choice this could be. Yes Gregory had caused this mess and angered me earlier, but people deserved a chance for redemption. At least Jethic could still walk at the moment and with intense training and some really good healers he could still become a Hunter with one arm. Right now Gregory’s life was over, gunners needed speed and mobility, neither of which he would have without the use of his legs.

I could always not use it on either one of them but that wasn’t even really a choice in my mind. I might not be able to stand most people my age but these people were all still Hunter’s. they all signed up for this knowing the risks yet still wanting to help people anyway. Hunter’s helped one another when they could. That was part of the code we all lived by.

Hefting the blood in my hands while looking between the two I was about to leave the decision up to the Arena Master when he caught my eye. He shook his head again, telling me without words that it was my choice. I had risked my life and defeated the monster, the blood was mine by right of victory so the decision was also mine by right. With a sigh I closed my eyes, gripping the vial in my hand tightly wondering what to do.
111121112211.title: “Hey big blue and ugly! Can I have this next da...

1111211122111.content:
Out of the two of them Jethic would be the better Hunter in the future. With Gregory’s personality using the blood on him would be a waste in the long run as he would just end up either dying or screwing over someone else. My decision made, I walked over and squatted down in front of Jethic, looking him in the face.

“Your going to be all right Jethic. You did your shield proud and upheld your status as a real tank. Right now though I need to borrow some of your blood.”

He barked a small laugh but stopped quickly, clutching at his side where no doubt his ribs were at the least cracked. After a moment he waved his hand all over his body where he was oozing blood from many different cuts.

“Take your pick of exit wounds. As you can see I got a lot to spare. But you don’t need to lie to me, I know the deal. My life as a Hunter is over. Short of The One God coming down and laying his hands on me I’m not getting fixed.”

“I said you are going to be all right and I mean it. You got the promise of a Zelkov on that. Just hang in there for a little bit.”

I pointed at the caster as the Arena Master ordered everyone to back off a bit to give me room.

“You! Marsa right? I saw your second tier magma ball earlier, can you cast and hold that at an even three hundred degrees without throwing it? Five to ten minutes at most?”

“I-I think so. I’ve never really tried to just hold it but if I concentrate I probably could.”

“Good then get ready to do so when I tell you to.”

Setting the vial carefully on the ground I pulled off my gloves, setting them down next to the monster blood. As I knelt there on my legs I took a few deep breaths, preparing myself for the next few steps. Jethic saw the vial of blood and let out another painful chuckle.

“Never did understand how it is monsters can drop their blood and body parts in vials like that. You would think it would be spilled all over the ground and you would have to scrape it up or something. But no, their livers or intestines or brains or whatever come in those nice little neat prepackaged cases for our pleasure. Same with raw slabs of meat all cut up nice and neat. And why is it ever only like one or two small slabs when you just killed this giant monster over six feet tall? Shouldn’t you get like pounds of the stuff? Why does it only ever drop like one or two items too? Why not some meat, the fur, claws and everything else?”

Absently I waved him to silence, my mind settling into the mindset I needed.

“Save your breath. That’s the blood loss talking. They are magical creatures and that’s just the way things work. Save your theological debates and theories for a scholar. I just know that I kill them and it drops the items as I find them. That’s all I need to know.”

Once I was ready I let out another deep breath, picking up my Roller Knuckles.

“It’s been a good run old friend, but it’s time for you to do one last duty. Phase three activate: Ripper’s memories. Sing your final battle hymn.”

As the gloves began their transformation into phase three I shot the magic flowing into me back into the yellow gem, causing a feedback loop and short circuiting the transformation. As the magic fed on itself I ripped the gem from it’s socket and smashed it on the ground hard enough to split the shell in half to reveal the piece of heart crystal inside.

“Give me that magma now!”

Popping the cork on the vial I gathered a bit of Jethic’s blood with it, throwing both it and the heart crystal into the flaming ball of magma before channeling all the power flowing through me from the feedback loop in after it. I had to keep my mind blank, ignoring the heat singeing the hairs on my arm or the smell of cooking flesh. This was a jury rigged alchemic concoction without benefit of burners or real equipment. I had to regulate it all with magic, holding them inside the fire with pure power while I tried to shield myself from the brunt of the flames.

A soothing shield enveloped me, probably from the Arena Master but I didn’t dare look away right now to see. In my minds eye I saw what was happening in the depths of the flames. How the blood, magic and crystal were all melting and fusing together to create a heal-all elixir. Any heart crystal would do, but time was also of the essence before Jethic passed the point of no return and his body rejected the treatment. Constantly I twirled the brew, stiring it with magic instead of a glass rod. Ignoring the sweat dripping from my face or the empty feeling in the pit of my stomach telling me my magic was almost gone.

Finally it reached the optimal point where everything was bonded perfectly. With the last of my magic I summoned forth a freezing wind and frigid water, circling it around the ball of magma until it was completely encased before crushing my hands together and letting the two opposing forces meet.

There was a small implosion as it sank in on itself for a second, moments before hot steam exploded outward and a small tinkling noise could be heard in the mist. Reaching inside the fog I felt around until my fingers found the neck of the elixir bottle. Pulling out the shiny silver casing I could see the almost clear liquid inside, knowing it had been a success.

Standing right now would be out of the question, I would just fall over or stagger around a bit. So I simple crawled over to Jethic, putting the edge to his lip and telling him to drink.

“It might taste like stinky goblin armpit sweat mixed with troll toe jam, but I didn’t exactly have some of the normal extra ingredients you would use to hide those tastes. I used all the bare minimum of ingredients though. Also I will warn you, after you drink it, your body is going to hurt. Feel free to scream.”

He stared into my eyes a moment as if wondering if I was joking or not before holding it with his good left hand and chugging it down quickly. His face contorted at the taste and he gave a small gag, looking like he was keeping himself from vomiting by force of will. After a moment of silence I heard the grating noise. That would be his bones putting themselves back together in the span of seconds without any magic buffering the pain. He gritted his teeth against the pain and I slapped him lightly on the cheek.

“Don’t do that. Soon enough you are going to convulse. If you grit your teeth you are going to hurt yourself. Better to loosen up if you can and simply scream it out.”

Sure enough, his broken and pulped up right arm began to spasm and twist disgustingly. The bone shards could be seen moving around under the skin, tearing through muscle to get back into place before that muscle was healed up again. And Jethic began to scream. Tears came down his eyes as his back suddenly popped back into place and the rest of his internal injuries righted themselves. Finally it was all over and he sat there with his head hanging into his chest, panting heavily. But not even a bruise marked his skin.

Using the wall to steady myself I climbed to my feet, offering Jethic a hand up. After a moment he took it, staggering into a standing position. He experimented by walking around and rotating his shoulders before finally grinning at me with tears in his eyes. I waved off his profuse words of thanks before the world grew dark around me and I collapsed back against the wall, letting unconsciousness take me.
1111211122111.title: Save Jethic

choices: Say you're fine and leave anyway
Listen and get back in bed
11112111221111.content:
“But ma’am if such things exist why isn’t it more common?”

I cracked open my eyes to see a white ceiling staring back at me. The cool sheet and the slightly hard bed told me I was most likely in the nurses office. Looking down the length of my body at the sound of the voice confirmed that it was indeed Jethic talking. Standing next to him were the other three I had saved and all of them were looking at the principal intently. A glance to my left showed the nurse hard at work on a still unconscious Gregory. The principal looked up at Jethic from her wheelchair and shook her head sadly.

“Because the ingredients are so rare. You can get the vial of blood from any subclass of giant C class or higher, but the drop rate is really low. Even at it’s best it is somewhere around like one in twenty kills on an A class. I’m astonished one dropped from a mere Glif. In case you don’t realize how precious it is, you could probably outfit yourself with a new top of the line set of armor from Alves and still have a bit left over. Second, it takes a lot of magical power that needs to be constantly added in a steady stream.

“Most Hunter’s don’t have that kind of magic though, only caster specialist like this girl here could pull it off normally. But he used the power given off by his weapons heart crystal when he released his phase three to get around that fact. And since heart crystal’s are used to create artifacts, people don’t usually use them for heal-all’s. They would rather have an artifact weapon that can be used over and over instead of an elixir that is only used once. I’m actually surprised he was able to pull off making one in such a jury-rigged alchemist lab. But I guess that’s a Zelkov for you.”

“What about my blood? It seems a bit weird he would need that too.”

“Normally heal-all’s are made without DNA from the imbiber so it can be sold to anyone. Usually the person spits into the potion before they drink it since it wasn’t necessarily your blood he was after, just your DNA. But I think he added it in beforehand to try and lower the chances of your body rejecting the healing. Since like with all healing potions, one must use it shortly after the damage is done or it won’t work. The body sets at a certain point if you will and refuses the quick healing of the potion.”

I had heard enough, from the look on Jethic’s face as he began to realize just how much I had given up, both monetary wise and weapon wise and at the principals explanation I was getting a bit embarrassed. So shoving off with my hand I sat up in bed.

“You speak too much old lady. I can’t even get a decent sleep around here with all that yakking. Don’t go putting silly ideas into their heads making them think they owe me or anything. I simply helped another Hunter out in his time of need, upholding the code as is my duty. Being the example of what a Hunter is as a Zelkov should.”

“Yeah, yeah. You Zelkov’s are all the same, doing good deeds and hiding behind the whole duty shtick. It’s like you think it’s some sort of disease to do something good.”

I simply shook my head, ignoring her comment as I got to my feet only slightly unsteadily. I could feel my reserves were still pretty low even as I suddenly sat back down from getting light headed. Not surprising considering that I had just done the mental equivalent of fighting three A class monsters alone while juiced up to the max. The nurse finally dropped her glowing hands from where they were hovering over the unconscious boys hips with a sigh. She looked over at the principal with a shake of her head.

“’That’s it, I’m tapped out. I did what I could but I’m sure you know he is never going to walk again. That monster just messed him up too much. Getting knocked out from your shield bash might have been a blessing to him. He didn’t feel his bones getting pulverized.”

“And it might be the cause of all of this too. If he wasn’t unconscious he might have been able to avoid it.”

Before I could say anything the principal spoke up, saying the same thing I was going to say.

“Perhaps. Or perhaps he would have tried to block it and gotten worse damage. That’s the problem when bad things happen, we always ask that insidious question, what if. Wondering if our course was the best one or the right one. Not all decisions are easy ones to make and in the heat of the moment we tend to just do what seems best at that time.”

The nurse looked down at the boy in the bed before absently shoving me back into a sitting position when I tried to get up again. She glared at me in the no nonsense way of a priestess doing her job before breaking off some ration bread and handing it to me with the order to eat. Only once she was sure I was nibbling on the compressed fruit bread did she turn her attention back to the group by the door.

“So how did it happen anyway? I heard a bunch of babbling when you came in but I had other things to worry about.”

“A Glif ate a self enhancement magic.”

I stopped chewing on the rations to shake my head and point at Daniel’s simple explanation.

“Call it like it is. That idiot tried to be cocky and show off, not wanting to be one upped by Marsa over there. At least her tactic I understood, a reflective shield doesn’t last long and she didn’t want to waste it. She knew all that before casting her flame spell, knowing it would be eaten and thrown back at her. But that idiot’s ego got in the way of his common sense when he tried casting that spell on himself to be taken. Even supposing he didn’t know it would suck up non-attack type spells, I doubt the Arena Master would have sent you out there without letting you know the dangers and informing him.”

“Well you’re right, the teacher did tell us exactly what to expect. He said it would suck up any spells once it put it’s hands up.”

“In the end this mess was his fault more than anyone’s. Now I’m not saying the idiot deserved what he got, but he really can’t complain when he wakes up about the outcome.”

None of my classmates had anything to say to that even as the principal sighed in silent agreement. More things like this would happen over the next three years until they graduated. Gregory wouldn’t be the only casualty of either a training accident or something else. There was a reason classes started off between twenty and twenty five kids their freshman years only to dwindle down to between sixteen and twenty by their senior year. And why transfer students were rare. The people they were in class with now would be the ones they graduated with if they got that far.

Jethic looked at me a moment before lowering his head to scratch his neck. I could see him trying to come up with some words to thank me but I cut him off before he said anything.

“Your planning on thanking me and saying something stupid about how much it cost me or I gave up my weapon. Don’t bother. I said before, it’s a Hunter’s job to help out his comrades if and when he can. Weapons are just weapons. No matter how long I might have had them or what memories they may have held, they were still not more important than your life. I can always get a new heart crystal to put in the gloves. I might have to retune the magic to synchronize with me but it’s not like it is the end of the world for me to put in a bit of effort.”

He shook his head back and forth as he clenched his fist.

“It’s not that. I am thankful and everything and I sort of understand. But how did you choose? Between me and him? I mean I know he caused this and all and he really isn’t a very likeable person sometimes, but the choice must have still been difficult.”

“The truth? It came down to the people. Not the ones in here, but the ones out there. The ones we swore an oath to protect as Hunter’s. I felt you would be a more valuable asset to our ranks than he would. I prioritized your life over his for that reason alone. Yes it would have been easy to make the decision based on my dislike for him, or the feeling that he got what he deserved. But such thoughts have no place in the decisions we must make as Hunter’s out in the field. Protecting the people isn’t always so cut and dry as good and bad.

“He might have a bit of a bad attitude or an ego, but even Liz recognizes his skills with his dual guns. The world can use good Hunter’s even if they have such quirks. The One God knows I’ve got my drawbacks personality wise, does that mean I wouldn’t be a good Hunter? That’s why I chose as I did. Even though he might have been better then you skill wise, you have more potential than he does. So I bet on the chance that you will live up to that potential.”

The bell rang and the four looked up at the ceiling before looking at me again. With a few nods they headed for the door to get to their next class now that they had verified I was all right and the nurse had released them.A moment later the principal wheeled herself out the door as well, probably to do whatever she did all day. I started to stand up as well, I really didn’t want to follow them but I didn’t feel like staying here either. The nurse pushed me back down again with a shake of her head.

“Bed rest for a bit longer young man.”
11112111221111.title: Hey wake up!
