Settle in to fall asleep here.
111121112211111.content:
“I’m fine really. This isn’t the first time I’ve drained my magic after all. I’d rather sit around in a classroom listening to information I already know while doing nothing than lay around in bed doing nothing without even a book to read.”

“Yeah you’re a Hunter all right. All of you people are the same way, always insisting nothings wrong even when you look like you are going to let out your last breath any moment. Fine, but you aren’t going back to class. Go home and rest, that’s an order. Then you can sit around doing nothing while reading a book. I hope. Just wait a moment while I see about getting a hold of one of your parents.”

“Good luck with that. My father is off fighting Sandworms and I’d be surprised if my mother hasn’t run off to some country or another already.”

I waited, sitting on the side of the bed and finishing the ration bread while she pulled the proper contact id card and linked it to her communication spell. I couldn’t hear what she said but it seemed she was actually able to get a hold of my mother, since my father was too far away for a com spell without a booster. After a moment she turned to me, waving towards the door.

“Looks like you are on your own.”

“You didn’t need to waste your magic to find that out. I was already planning on that outcome.”

Standing up I began to walk slowly towards the door shoving down the slight light headed feeling. Once I started getting my blood flowing that feeling would stop. The first thing I did was head for the Arena to pick up my bag. I wasn’t about to leave those here overnight. Slipping in and out without anyone realizing I was even there I finally headed for the door. The principal wheeling up next to me as I walked, a small smile on her face.

“You really did do a good thing. Despite your insistence that you don’t need to be thanked I’m still going to thank you anyway for helping one of my students. I know the choice wasn’t an easy one for you but I think you chose well. Stay safe on your way home Riktal Zelkov. Rest up and brace yourself for the hero worship tomorrow. If you are a real Zelkov I’m sure you will just love that.”

She chuckled a bit as she wheeled away without another word. The sarcasm of her last words would probably be plain to even the most thickheaded of people. I simply shook my head, not in negation, but because I knew her words were true. As much as I didn’t want them to shower me with praise and thanks or be looked upon with worship, they would still do so.

I didn’t waste any time once I hit the front gate, simply turning into town to head right home. I had some frozen dinners in the freezer I could heat up and then I could go to sleep early. That still sounded like the best plan as I got home, raising my hand to unlock the spell on the building. My fingers faltered a moment before reaching into my bag and grabbing a short sword, pushing open the already unlocked door.

Silently setting my bag on the floor I began hunting through the house for the intruder. They had to be pretty good spell smiths to break that magic lock and not set off the houses defenses. I heard a clanking coming from the kitchen so crept over in that direction while keeping my body pressed to the wall. Using the flat part of my sword as a mirror I could just make out an indistinct blob with dark hair rummaging through the refrigerator. Sliding my knife out of it’s sheath at my side I flipped it and spun, throwing it at the burglar. It was only a warning shot that would hit the refrigerator next to his head, but he caught it in mid air without looking before turning to face me.

“Who taught you to greet your father like that?”

“My father.”

“Smart man. How you doing son?”

“I’ve had worse days. I thought you were still taking care of that Sandworm infestation for the next few days.”

“I was able to get done a lot sooner then I thought. Got a bit of help from another Hunter in the area. I actually just got back this morning and your mother asked me to help her on a job in Bornica. We will be leaving again in a bit once she takes care of some business. I was just grabbing a bite to eat before heading off into town to stock up on supplies.”

Leaning my swords against the wall I walked over and grabbed the dagger from his hand when he offered it, sliding it home while opening the freezer. With practiced ease I pulled out one of the frozen dinners, hitting the buttons on the microwave and poking holes in the film before tapping the start button. As the artifact came to life I planted my hands on the counter and closed my eyes, resisting the urge to rub them.

“You look like you need a drink.”

“I’m underage.”

“Still, I’ve seen drunken sailors that looked better than you do right now. Care to fill me in?”

He waited until the microwave dinged before following me to the table eating some of the leftover pasta I had made yesterday. After taking the first bite of the meat that claimed to be hamburger steak I recounted what had happened. I really didn’t have much of a relationship with my father, but at least I was slightly closer to him than I was to my mother. I didn’t get the urge to strangle him after only a few moments in his presence. Still he was barely more than a father to me in more than name. Like my mother he was never around and almost never dealt with me as more than one Hunter to another.

Probably the only reason we were able to get along like we did was because interaction between guys was different than that between a man and a woman. There was something about him that let me feel more at ease talking to him than to my mother to begin with. And I knew sometimes there were things you could only say to another guy. I finished my story and my meal as he nodded his head in understanding.

“Yep that would definitely do it. I’m impressed you pulled it off. These stuffed shells are really good by the way. Did you make them?”

“For lunch yesterday yeah.”

“Surprised your mother didn’t find them last night.”

“She came in late, said she was home then crashed on the couch. Don’t know why she even bothered coming home if she is just going to be leaving again.”

“I’m sure she was just eager to see you.”

I let out a snort of derision as I threw my fork in the sink and my plastic tray in the garbage.

“That would be a first.”

My father followed me out of the room carrying his plate of pasta even as I ignored him. My feet took me to the living room of their own accord where I plopped onto the couch and rested my head against the back. Now that I had some food in me, my body was telling me how tired it was. And how much it didn’t want to walk up the stairs. Not really too interested I still asked my father what kind of business my mother had.

“Seems she has been looking after a little girl for the last three days. But she can’t take her with us so she is looking for someone else to take care of her until someone she knows can come pick her up.”

“I didn’t see any little girl when she came in last night.”

“Apparently she has a unique magic that some people wanted to study so she stayed at a lab all night with your mother’s aides.”

“Unique magic huh? Surprised anyone with a special power would submit to being poked and prodded the way most people hate and fear them.”

“Yeah well I guess she is a bit of a special case.”

“Still she failed as a Hunter if she let her client out of her sight when it was her duty to protect her at all times.”

“That’s really not a fair thing to say without knowing all the circumstances.”

“I don’t need to know any of the circumstances. Hunter code states that the client is the priority at all times. More important than personal safety, possessions, or image. Until such a time as the client leaves your protection. Isn’t that what you taught me? The only circumstances I could accept are if such a code conflicted with the code we live by that upholds the safety of the many.”
111121112211111.title: Say you're fine and leave anyway

1111211122111111.content:
“Well it was good talking to you dad. But I think I am going to go pass out upstairs now. Just leave the plate in the sink, it will give me something to do later. I’ll see you in a week or two. Or whenever this job is over.”

“Later son. Get some rest, you don’t look like you will last much longer.”

I gave him a small wave, mustering enough energy to stand up and head for the stairs. My legs felt a bit like lead as I climbed to the second floor, my body prioritizing a lethargic state for healing using the food I had just ate. Even though my eyes were burning, sleep eluded me for some reason as I simply fell onto my bed without even kicking off my shoes. That was fine, sleep would come soon, my body would see to that. I would just lie here with my eyes closed until it did.

I hadn’t been in bed long before I heard the door downstairs opening and closing. I thought it was my father finally leaving but his voice proved that wasn’t the case.

“Marian! What are you doing here? I thought we were going to meet down at Nerval’s in about ten minutes.”

“The school called and said Riktal wasn’t feeling well. I was a bit busy at the time working out a deal with Pelei so they agreed to send him home alone. I came as soon as I could to see how he is.”

“He’s fine. Just a bit of burn out.”

My father quickly recounted what I had told him and my mother responded with surprise much as my father had.

“I guess I shouldn’t be surprised though, Ulicia did teach him everything she knows.”

There was a moment of silence before I heard the distinctive sound of the first step creaking. But only the first step before my father’s voice rang out. I could well imagine my father’s arm on my mother’s, keeping her from going any farther up the stairs.

“Leave it Marian. We both know how things will end if you go up there. In the best case he is passed out on his bed. He looked ready to fall over on the steps after all. Any show of compassion you might make he isn’t going to appreciate or believe, thinking it some deeper plot. Worse case he is still awake and the two of you get into an argument, putting you both in a foul mood for no good reason.”

“But…”

“I know, I know. But we both know how you are. You have these feelings of motherly affection but as soon as you are actually around a child of any kind, especially your own, it all goes out the window like a switch in your head got flipped. You fumble with your words and actions so much you simply fall back on what you know, treating them all impersonally and like faceless Hunter’s. All those desires of yours get’s all jumbled up as you try your best to connect with them. In the end it just makes it all look and feel fake. That’s the mask Riktal see’s, and too be fair you haven’t done much to help your cause.”

“Don’t you think I know all that! But still…”

“But still nothing honey. He seems to have grown up just fine without us even looking. I’m sure when all this is over we can set things right. It’s going to take more than a day to fix seventeen years of neglect. Here, have a stuffed shell.”

There was another moment of silence before my mother let out another exclamation of surprise.

“When did you make it down to the Pasta Palace to buy these?”

“I didn’t. Riktal made them.”

“When did he learn how to cook like this?”

“Who knows? But considering we are never around, I suspect there are a lot of things he can do that we don’t know about.”

I couldn’t help but smile a bit as I lay on my side listening to the conversation. Ursa, the chef down at the Palace, had been the one to teach me most of what I knew about cooking. I was no master chef like her, but I had learned a thing or two about making more complicated dishes like the stuffed shells.

“Well at the least we need to buy him another heart crystal to replace the one he used. I might not know him all that well but I know he loves those Roller Knuckles. Olia got them for him three years ago right before she died.”

“No honey, we shouldn’t. I’ve spent a bit more time with him than you so I know that would only make him resent you even more. He needs to earn a new crystal on his own. He won’t feel he accomplished anything if it’s just given to him. You forget, he’s not a boy anymore, he’s a man now. But don’t feel bad, I had forgotten that fact too until I saw him today. Now let’s go, our flight leaves in a few hours and we still have some shopping to do.”

I heard the front door open again and their voices fading but I could still hear them through my window faintly.

“So Pelei took the job of protecting the girl?”

“Yeah, though I still have a few misgivings about it. I had been thinking of asking Riktal but after getting that call I decided against it.”

The rest of their conversation was lost in the breeze as they got out of range of even my acute hearing. A moment later the sounds of one of the cars starting and then pulling away drifted up to me. This new information put my mother in a slightly new light, but I still couldn’t entirely believe it. A large part of me still said she was just being her, playing even my father and pretending like she always did. Working off the assumption that I was awake and could hear her. After all, she had no problems using her own family to achieve her own ends and she was the one who had taught me the most about the political aspects of being a Hunter. Of how to play the game and devise plots within plots. She was and always would be much better at it than I was, but I was still aware enough of those facts to consider the possibility.

Such hard thinking seemed to be exactly what I had needed as I let out a yawn and felt the natural darkness of sleep closing in. In the end, only time would tell if what I had overheard was all truth or just another devious plot of some kind. For now I just wanted to rest.

************

Truth and half truth. Lies, deceit, judgments, assumptions, opinions. Each word has a different meaning yet at the same time they share much in common. They can mean different things to different people, but in the end they are simply words. Simply concepts that humans have attached meaning to in their attempt to bring order to the world. To create a system of morals which are in themselves something that humans have created to define the box they live in.

But in this world where millions upon millions of possibilities exist at the same time what is truth? Is this day truth? Does it define who Riktal is? What then is the Riktal that lives on the other timelines? The other choices you didn’t make? Are those half truth Riktal’s? Or outright lies?

How did you make your choices? Did you base them on judgments you have made or opinions of what you have seen? Did you make assumptions as to what the outcome might be and base your choice on that? In the end did you simply deceive yourself, choosing as you would choose thinking Riktal would naturally take the same course?

The choices had no feelings though. No morals, no concepts of any of that. They too were just mere words or unformed thoughts until you made them reality. It was you who brought concept and weight to them. So too is it you who must decide if this day was good or bad, since this day just was, much like the choices were before you came along.

I have enjoyed our time together human and these theological thoughts we have exchanged. These food for thoughts if you will. I know you shall come again to redo this day and live in Riktal’s shoes, making different choices and attaching importance to different things. Until we meet again traveler.
1111211122111111.title: Say you are tired and go upstairs

1111211122111112.content:
“Well I suppose it’s been good talking with you father, but I think I’m going to just close my eyes and go to sleep right here. Just throw the plate in the sink when you are done, it will give me something to do when I wake up.”

“You do that. You look like you are about to pass out any second anyway.”

With a sigh I closed my eyes, waiting for sleep to take over. Even though my eyes burned, I just couldn’t force myself to fall asleep, doing so only made it harder to actually do so. But my body would make me sleep soon enough as long as I relaxed a bit.

It seemed fate was conspiring against me though as the door opened a few minutes later before I had a chance to relax enough. At first I thought it was just my father leaving, but his voice out in the hallway dispelled that notion.

“Marian! What are you doing here? I thought we were going to meet up down at Nerval’s in about ten minutes.”

“The school called and said Riktal wasn’t feeling well and needed to go home. Since I was busy at the time I told them to send him home alone. But I finished up and came over straight away to see how he is.”

“He’s fine, just a bit of burn out. He’s in the living room right now trying to get some sleep.”

Pounding feet followed as I cracked open my eye in the direction of the door. I probably should have gone upstairs after all, since I really didn’t need to deal with my mother right now. She came into the room, a false look of worry written plainly on her features. I could see her mouth opening and closing a few times before the familiar mask of her Hunter face dropped into place.

“You look like hell.”

“Brilliant observation mother. Is burn out supposed to look any other way?”

“What fool thing did you do to get into this state? I thought we taught you better than that.”

“I created a heal-all elixir in the equivalent of doing brain surgery with a hammer and nails while blindfolded to save one of my classmates. I’m sorry if I didn’t live up to your expectations of looking out only for myself by actually helping someone else. And I am sure the great Marian Zelkov never burned out at all in her life either.”

I began to get a headache then as she shook her head slightly while clamping down on whatever she was going to say in response to that. With a quick breath she finally spoke again.

“That’s not what I meant or how I meant it. I don’t want to argue, it just came out wrong. Are you ok?”

“What’s this? Feigning worry for my well being? What game are you playing at now? We both know you don’t really care if I am fine or not. You are just going through the motions to make it seem like you are a real mother. But I will answer your question anyway so we can meet the minimum requirement of interaction of parent and child, freeing you to go on your way again with the feeling that you aren’t such a horrible person. Aside from a small headache that started the moment you came into the room, I’m fine. Now go away.”

“Riktal darling, can’t we just for once talk without turning it into an argument?”

“Short answer, no. Long answer, perhaps when you stop faking real emotions and actually care about someone besides yourself without trying to manipulate and control everything and everyone around you however you can.”

My father came back into the room then, gently grabbing my mother’s arm and tugging her back into the hall.

“Come on Marian, we will miss our flight if we don’t hurry. We still have things to pick up remember.”

“But…”

“Leave it. We will talk on the way all right? You already knew it would turn out like this so just give him space.”

“But he’s only sixteen!”

“He’s seventeen Marian. His birthday was last month remember?”

“Actually it was two months ago father, Olia’s death day was last month. Two occasions by the way you both missed again this year. But at least you know how old I am so that scores you a few points.”

My father looked at me a bit sadly, saying a quite apology but not trying to offer an explanation. With another tug he pulled my mother away until I heard the door opening and closing again. A few moments later I heard one of the cars pulling out of the garage and speeding away. The headache had grown stronger in just those few moments and I knew it would be impossible to get to sleep with it pounding in my head.

With a sigh I found some energy to stand up again, heading for the kitchen on legs that felt like they weighed a ton. Once there I grabbed a coffee mug from the cupboard, setting it down at the table before going to the cupboards by the stove. Pushing aside the vinegars and wines I sometimes used for cooking I reached into the back and pulled out the strong stuff. Casavian Fire brew. Guaranteed to get you drunk in three shots or less and good for what troubles you. It had been a gift for my birthday a year ago but this was the first time I felt like I really needed a drink.

Sitting at the table I broke the wax seal and poured myself a hefty dollop, at least two shots worth. I downed it quickly, feeling the burn as it slid down my throat and the sudden lightheadedness as it started to work. My headache went away almost instantly as I crossed my arms on the table, resting my head on top of them. Well this wasn’t exactly a natural way to fall asleep but it still worked. My body would get the rest it needed.

The alcohol took a few more minutes to really kick in but suddenly the world began to go dark as I slipped into sleep.

*********

Truth and half truth. Lies, deceit, judgments, assumptions, opinions. Each word has a different meaning yet at the same time they share much in common. They can mean different things to different people, but in the end they are simply words. Simply concepts that humans have attached meaning to in their attempt to bring order to the world. To create a system of morals which are in themselves something that humans have created to define the box they live in.

But in this world where millions upon millions of possibilities exist at the same time what is truth? Is this day truth? Does it define who Riktal is? What then is the Riktal that lives on the other timelines? The other choices you didn’t make? Are those half truth Riktal’s? Or outright lies?

How did you make your choices? Did you base them on judgments you have made or opinions of what you have seen? Did you make assumptions as to what the outcome might be and base your choice on that? In the end did you simply deceive yourself, choosing as you would choose thinking Riktal would naturally take the same course?

The choices had no feelings though. No morals, no concepts of any of that. They too were just mere words or unformed thoughts until you made them reality. It was you who brought concept and weight to them. So too is it you who must decide if this day was good or bad, since this day just was, much like the choices were before you came along.

I have enjoyed our time together human and these theological thoughts we have exchanged. These food for thoughts if you will. I know you shall come again to redo this day and live in Riktal’s shoes, making different choices and attaching importance to different things. Until we meet again traveler.
1111211122111112.title: Settle in to fall asleep here.

111121112211112.content:
With a heavy sigh I slid back onto the bed, propping myself up a bit so I wasn’t laying completely flat. The nurse looked a bit surprised that I was actually listening before turning away. She sat at a desk and began to write, probably a small incident report or something.

“You happen to have something I can read while I sit around here doing nothing?”

“My romance novel, but that’s it.”

She held up a book where a half naked man was locking lips with a well endowed woman with bright pink hair. I shook my head, waving it away quickly.

“I’ll pass.”

Giving me a half grin and a shrug she turned back to her paperwork, jotting down a few more notes before leaning back in her chair to read the romance herself. For my part I simply closed my eyes, hoping I would perhaps fall asleep. I knew I would eventually as my body suddenly realized the fact that I was tapped out and needed to recharge and recover.

The principal came back about ten minutes later with my bag sitting in her lap, offering me thanks for what I had done even as she sat it on the floor next to me. I waved it off like I had when Jethic had offered them and she didn’t push the issue. Simply said her bit before leaving again. Reaching into the bag I pulled out the remnants of my Roller Knuckles. They still had the saw blades on them but without the heart crystal they wouldn’t spin at all. They were simply glorified gloves right now.

“You sang a fine final song old friend. Your sacrifice wasn’t in vain, you did good. Just wait, I’ll find another heart crystal that matches you just as well as the old one. Even if I have to go out slaying the monsters myself until I get the drop. You won’t be forgotten.”

I looked up in time to see the nurse watching me quietly a moment before returning to her reading. I didn’t miss the small nod of acknowledgement she sent my way though. As I bent over the side of the bed to drop the gloves back into the bag, Gregory began to moan as he woke up. I glanced over in time to see him jerk awake trying to move for a moment as the realization he couldn’t move from the waist down came over him.

“What happened! Why can’t I move my legs! Where am I? How did I get here! What’s going on! Why can’t I move my legs!”
As he began to flail around, managing to pull himself into a reclined sitting position, the nurse hurried over, trying to calm him down. She tried explaining what had happened and that he would never walk again, but her words seemed to just make him more hysteric. Throwing off his covers he looked down at his legs, saying they looked normal and accusing her of putting some kind of spell on them as a bad joke.

His constant accusations and hysterical outbursts were getting on my nerves. Not once did he seem to think he had done anything wrong, or think that this was his reality now. Refusing to believe what the nurse was saying. Swinging out of bed I took the two steps to his side, pushing the nurse out of the way before slapping him as hard as I could across the face to shut him up. With a grunt I looked at the nurse shaking my head.

“Seriously, you priestesses need to learn to take a more direct approach. I know your oaths of service make you a bit pacifistic, but you work as a nurse in a Monster Combat Hunter academy, you need to get a bit violent sometimes.”

Turning back to the boy who was glaring up at me I glared back until he finally lowered his eyes.

“This isn’t some game or lie. Do you think anyone would waste magic on making you think you will never walk again like you are someone important? Newsflash, you aren’t that important. This is the outcome of your poor choice to cast a magic to stoke your own ego. You were warned not to do so before you even stepped out onto the field and yet you did it anyway. Perhaps the unconsciousness wasn’t your fault but your teammates did the best they could to save your worthless hide. Jethic took the hits meant for you, the only reason he wasn’t killed outright was because he was armored up for heavy blows. And if it hadn’t been for Marsa’s quick thinking it would have been your skull that was crushed and not your legs.”

“Why didn’t you heal me then! Lilia is a priestess and so is the nurse! Those two combined must have been able to!”

“Lilia did heal you as soon as she could. She spent herself, almost burning out to lessen the damage and reconstructing the bones from splinters. The same with the nurse here. But you should already know by now that no matter how good the priest or priestess or how touched they are by The One God, they can’t fix everything. When something gets too badly damaged, it’s just not possible to fix it all in time. They do what they can and we as Hunter’s have to accept that fact. What good would fixing your nerves have done if your bones never had a chance to heal and set right? Or healing your muscles when they know they are going to rip them apart again while shifting fragments around? They have their own set of priorities when healing even if you don’t understand it. You might never be able to walk again but at least be grateful they didn’t have to cut anything off.”

Having said my piece I turned and climbed back into my own bed, turning on my side so I didn’t have to see either one of them looking at me. The nurse went back to explaining things to Gregory who continued to sulk, but at least now he was listening and not making wild accusations. Finally he told her to just leave him alone and she did so, going back to her desk quietly. When I glanced over my shoulder I saw Gregory looking away at the far wall, which was probably the best he could do right now since he couldn’t turn on his side.

A few minutes later the nurse picked up her paperwork and headed for the door, excusing herself for a little bit. The silence that descended after she left was welcome. I hadn’t realized how loud the scratching of her pencil had been as I had tried to fall asleep for even a little bit. Or how much it had tickled at my nerves, preventing me from relaxing. But now I felt that relaxation starting to seep in as my eyes became suddenly heavy and sleep started creeping nearer.

“Hey, are you awake?”
111121112211112.title: Listen and get back in bed

choices: "Is that the strength of your convictions?"
1111211122111121.content:
I ignored him. I was in no mood to talk right now and in even less of a mood to hear him whining about his situation or fishing for pity.

“I guess I screwed up pretty big this time huh? You’re right, this was my fault. I can complain and blame all I want but in the end it comes back to me. I always wanted to be a Hunter you know. I grew up poor, and I mean dirt poor. I lived with my parents in this two room little hovel that had more holes than walls it seemed. But I was happy you know. Then a monster came and destroyed the placed. Killed my parents in front of me too. Would have killed me as well but then this Hunter came out of nowhere and smashed it up. Even though I was only four I knew that I wanted to be that guy. The one coming to the rescue and saving the day.”

I glanced at him covertly as I heard the choking of his voice, seeing tears coming down his face as he stared at the ceiling. It seemed like he had forgotten I was even there or that he was talking to me, lost in his own memories.

“They sent me to live with my aunt and uncle in Verindis city, but I ran away from there when I was seven. They were really mean and so was my cousin. I was just an extra mouth to feed to them and their precious little boy could do no wrong while I was treated like I was the monster. Fell in with a bunch of street imps, a man named Orsik lead the little gang. We were all still dirt poor, but we survived. Orsik was like a second father to me. We weren’t all noble or anything though, I stole and picked pockets to survive just like everyone else. Even though we didn’t have much, every year for Christmas and our birthday we managed to have a small feast or party and a few gifts. Gifts and food that we had bought ourselves, not stolen.

“And still my dream never died. Even when my fingers were slipping into someone’s pockets to take their hard earned Reul, I still remembered the figure of that Hunter with two guns blazing in and killing that monster. Our little territory was eventually taken over. Normally we were able to stay out of turf wars since we were such a small group. But one of the bigger groups made a power play to become a king of the north side of town. They didn’t want to absorb us, they wanted to eradicate us. Orsik stayed behind to fight alone, giving us time to get away. As I left the hideout I looked back and saw the resignation on his face. He knew he was going to die yet he was still going to hold them off for us.

“Even though I was only nine I had already learned a lot from him and a lot about how the world works. I wasn’t the oldest but I also wasn’t the youngest. The youngest of our group were two six year olds. But we ran and they chased us. The only other time I had ever been so scared was when that monster had killed my parents. The older ones kept pushing us on, sometimes staying behind to hold them off, sacrificing themselves as Orsik had. By the time we escaped into the wilds it was just me and four others, the two six year olds and two seven year olds.

“I pushed them on, as the oldest it fell to me to do what the others had done. I was the one that had to protect them like everyone else had protected us before. We traveled for days, living on the land, getting sick on some mushrooms and berries because we didn’t know any better, but pushing on nonetheless. We were just a day outside this city and we thought we were home free when a monster attacked us. I was scared and I froze. I knew what I was supposed to do. It was my job to let them get away. But instead I ran. I left them all to fend for themselves and I ran for the city shields. I heard their screams as they were caught and killed. Screams that even now still haunt me sometimes.

“Safe inside the city shields I ran into the nearest alley and hid. Berating myself for being all kinds of a fool. For being a coward for running away from my own death when everyone else had run towards it. A couple found me in that ally crying and shivering from the slight chilly air. A bunch of things happened but in the end they adopted me and took me into their home as their own son. Even gave me their last name. They were normal people, but their parents had both been Hunter’s. I thought long and hard about my life then, and decided I would never run away again. I needed to get stronger and learn all I could if I wanted to be that guy. The one blazing in to the rescue. That’s why I enrolled in the academy when I got the chance.

“I try to forget about my past you know. Where I come from and the skills I learned as a street imp. But I can’t. My fingers seem to move on their own even when my brain says to leave it alone. I know I’m a pretty horrible person and people don’t like me much. I do some pretty stupid things and have a bit of an attitude. But what am I supposed to do now? Without my legs I can’t be a Hunter. I can‘t be the only thing I ever really wanted to be.”
1111211122111121.title: Stay silent

11112111221111211.content:
“Figure it out for yourself. You got into this, now you have to find a way to live with it. Just because you gave me some sob story about your past doesn’t mean you will get any pity from me. Everyone has some reason or another they want to become Hunter’s. You aren’t the first street imp to claw your way into a Hunter academy. Or the first person to have their dreams shattered either. But we all find a way to move on or not. If you are so weak willed that you can’t figure out a way to move forward then die. Take one of your guns and put a bullet in your own head. Because if all you plan on doing is moping around then you are worse than useless.”

I didn’t even bother turning over to look at him, simply showed him my back the entire time. What good did feeling such self pity accomplish anyway? I knew myself how useless it was. Compassion had a place, but pity helped no one. It only allowed a person to be weak. No matter what kind of past he had it didn’t negate or make the way he had acted in the present ok. Not that I didn’t have some understanding or feelings for what he was going through. I simply didn’t know how else to express it.

I heard him sigh a bit as the sheets rustled and I assumed he turned his face away. We both lay in silence for a while until a commotion out in the hall caused me to turn my head in that direction.

“… See my son!”

“Mrs. Zelkov, please. He’s suffering from burn out and needs a bit of rest.”

The door was shoved open as my mother strode inside, pulling a white haired girl with crimson eyes and wearing an ugly lime green dress behind her. The girl stood around four and a half feet tall and had the empty eyed expression of shock that made her look like a doll. My mother opened her mouth to say something when she saw me but the words seemed to catch in her throat. After a moment I saw her Hunter mask drop into place over top of the worry that had been there. I knew that open look of worry had been a calculated play of some sort, she was incapable of showing real emotions, simply using them to achieve her own ends.

“You look like hell Riktal darling.”

“I’m sure I do. So what do you want mother.”

She looked from me to the little girl and then back again, shaking her head slightly.

“Nothing, I just wanted to make sure you were all right.”

“Right. I’ll let you think I believe that. As you can see I’m fine, is their anything else?”

Again she opened and closed her mouth as she tried to formulate words that just wouldn’t come. Finally with another small shake of her head she turned away.

“No. Get well soon darling. I’m going to be going on another mission with your father to Bornica. We will be gone for about a week or so.”

“Great. Have fun.”

Pulling the girl out after her, she left the room again. The nurse gave us both a small bow before leaving as well. Letting out another sigh I closed my eyes again, hoping sleep would come soon.

“I guess you’ve got problems of your own huh?”

` “Don’t act like you care. I don’t even know you. Besides you tried to steal from me remember.”

“I suppose I deserve that. After you ran me off I realized how stupid I had been. My body sort of acted on it’s own and a small part of my mind was telling me I was being stupid, but the rest just wouldn’t listen. For what it’s worth I am sorry for what I almost did.”

“Whatever. Words mean little, actions mean more. You can be sorry all you want but if you continue to act counter to that it makes a lie of that apology.”

“Little chance I will get to act like that ever again now is there?”

“Then you had best learn to make your words count if that’s what you really believe. Now leave me alone please, I’d like to get some rest if I can.”

Even as I said that I felt the fatigue fall in on me all at once. As if my body suddenly figured out what my brain had known for a while, it needed rest. My eyes burned even as I yawned, turning on my side away from Gregory and relaxing my muscles to make sleep come easier. A short nap until the end of school would revive me enough to pull me through the rest of the day and then a good night sleep would finish up the recovery process. I felt the darkness of sleep closing in even as I gave another yawn, burying my head deeper into the pillow.

**********

Twists and turns along the paths of fate. Decision and consequence, regrets and judgments. This is life in a nutshell is it not? For every choice you make there are a million that you don’t. Whether because you simply decide not to take them or you don’t even realize they are there. And once a choice is made it is set in stone, closing the doors to some possibilities while opening the doors to others that had never existed until that choice was made. And always that ever present question of what if.

What about this day do you regret? What about this day do you wonder about? While most people do not have the chance to go back and do it over, you are not in that position. You were simply an observer into this single life. One with the power to alter the path he walked true, but an observer through a window nonetheless. In a place like this where time is meaningless, you have the option of reliving this day over and over. Making new and different choices to see where else Riktal might end up. To learn new truths about the world, answer questions and come up with new ones. So join me again whenever you wish traveler and I shall again bestow upon you the power of choice.
11112111221111211.title: "Figure it out yourself."

11112111221111212.content:
“So that’s it? That’s all there is to the strength of your convictions? Now that you can’t walk there’s nothing left? You think telling me your life story means anything? The only person it means anything to is you. It might pull at someone’s heartstrings or bring you pity from the right people but those are your memories and your convictions not mine. Those are the reasons you are who you are and why you do what you do. So you will never walk again, big deal. You’ve still got that mass of meat in your head you call a mind. Your legs may never move again but that doesn’t mean your mind stopped moving. You want to be a Hunter so badly? What’s stopping you?”

“But my legs…”

Letting out a frustrated growl I rolled out of bed and strode over to him, grabbing him up by his shirtfront and pulling him towards me until I was inches from his face.

“What about your legs? Your legs didn’t make you a Hunter. Your legs aren’t the ones that dreamed of being the guy that saves the day! Your leg’s didn’t make the decision to enroll in this academy. From what you’ve just said your legs have only allowed you to run away!. If you really want to be a Hunter then do it! Find a way to make it work, useless legs, wheelchair and all. “

“But how?”

I heard the pleading tone of his voice. The sound of someone lost with no clear path in front of him. I shook him hard before slapping his face again.

“What is the oath of the Hunter? What are the rules that we live by? Answer me! Rule number one!”

“A Hunter puts the safety of the people above all else. He will not balk at sacrificing his life for the good of all.”

“Rule number two!”

“A Hunter never gives up. He fights until his last breath for the things he believes in.”

“Rule number three!”

He seemed to gain confidence then, his head coming up and his chest sticking out as he stared directly into my eyes. His voice became more sure, stronger. That note of pleading gone.

“A Hunter is not his weapon. He is not his arms or his legs. A Hunter is his mind. He is an idea and an ideal. He is an example for the people in everything he does. He brings comfort to those who need it, hope to the hopeless and justice to those who have been wronged.”

“Now tell me. Where in those rules does it say you can’t become a Hunter? Will it be hard? Damn straight it will be hard! Will it be impossible? Only if you think it’s impossible. So you might not be able to go out into the field slaying monsters anymore! There are still things you can do to uphold those things we live by. Become a top class alchemist and discover newer better potions, or learn how to create artifacts. Just because you can’t walk doesn’t prevent you from helping citizens in need of you.

“So you’ve made some bad choices in life. Everyone has done that at some point in time. If they say differently they are a liar. You beat yourself up over running away when you wanted to be a Hunter. You’re right that was a dirt bag move to do, even if you were only nine years old. That doesn’t mean I don’t understand why you did it. Those deaths will be on your head for the rest of your life. Are you going to let them be in vain? You ran to survive. You ran so you could realize your dream! Are you going to waste it all now over something like this? I ask again, is this the strength of your convictions? Because if it is then I’m glad you are never going to be a Hunter. I wouldn’t want someone like you watching my back or protecting my citizens.”

I let go of his shirt, shoving him back down onto the bed before climbing back into mine and laying with my back to him. There was silence for a moment as I heard him shuffling around before he spoke up again.

“You’re right. I need to make the decisions I made mean something. I need to make up for the mistakes I made. Do you really think I can do it though?”

Sliding up into a reclining position with the pillow propping up my back I looked over at him.

“I’ll throw that question back at you. Do you think you can do it?”

“I don’t know.”

“Then you are going to fail. If you really want this then you have to be one thousand percent committed. Becoming deaf to those who tell you that you can’t and blind to those who will mock you. You must become so mentally strong that nothing, not even the end of the world can break you. Expect to fail more than you succeed and be ready to pick yourself back up to try again. That is what it will take.”

I saw him look down at his hands silently as he reclined in the bed like me. He twiddled his thumbs a few times before taking a deep breath.

“How can you be so strong? Able to have such conviction? Is it because you are from an old family?”

“In part, because this is what I have trained to do from day one. I was wielding toy sword and shields in my hands in my crib. Instead of action figures I played with suits of armor and learned how to take apart and put weapons back together for fun. But I figured out long ago that this is what I was born to do. Even if I had been born a first generation I would still become a Hunter. That strength comes from my convictions. Because I decided long ago that nothing and no one is going to stop me. That I was willing to do anything to make my dream of becoming a Hunter a reality.”

“Will… will you help me?”

I could hear the hesitation in his voice. Hear how much it cost him to ask for help. He was putting aside his own ego to lower himself into asking for assistance. Something he probably wasn’t used to doing. Slowly I shook my head.

“No. We aren’t friends and I’m not going to become your crutch. If you really want to do this then you need to walk it alone for now until your convictions are unbreakable. Friends and those who will encourage you are helpful, but you need to get rid of that ego first. Otherwise you will fail. It sounds cruel but it’s the truth. Kindness for you right now is a crutch that you will find easy to fall back on and slack off because of. But I’ll be glad to slap you around some more if you lose sight of your desires. If you prove to me this is really the path you wish to take of course. Otherwise I won’t waste my energy.”

Just then there was a commotion out in the hall. I turned to the door in time to see it fly open and my mother come storming in followed by the nurse.

“…See my son!”

She looked at me and suddenly seemed to deflate a bit, looking at a loss for words. The crimson eyed girl with white hair she was dragging behind her just stared blankly, seeming to be barely alive. I saw my mother’s work face come crashing down over top of the false worry as she suddenly found her voice.

“You look like hell.”

“Burnout tends to have that affect on most people mother. So what do you want?”

She looked from me to the girl and then at me, searching for what to say next. Finally she shook her head slightly.

“Nothing. I just wanted to make sure you were ok.”

“Sure I totally believe that one. But I’ll let it slide. As you can see I am fine, is there anything else?”

She gave another shake of her head before turning to leave.

“No. Get well soon darling. Me and your father are going on a mission to Bornica and won’t be back for a week or so.”

“Whatever. It doesn’t affect me any.”

She hesitated at the door for a moment longer, as if she expected me to say goodbye or something before letting out a sigh and leaving, dragging the girl behind her. The nurse gave us a small nod before closing the door and leaving again as well. I took off my glasses and rubbed my eyes with two fingers, resisting the urge to let out a long breath.

“I guess you got your own problems too huh?”
11112111221111212.title: "Is that the strength of your convictions?&...

111121112211112121.content:
“I said before we aren’t friends. My problems are my problems just like your problems are your problems. Just because I gave you some advice don’t think that means I like you or anything. I still think you’re a pretty scummy person overall. Now I need to try and get a quick nap to recover from this burnout.”

I turned on my side, facing my back towards him so it was clear our conversation was over. Closing my eyes I began a few meditation techniques to relax my body. Right now I was so tense my body wouldn’t be able to fall asleep even though it needed it badly. Just as I was starting to feel the tension draining away and the edges of tiredness creeping in Gregory spoke up again.

“I guess I deserve that. I really didn’t make a good first impression did I? I know I’m not a very good person. And I get blinded by fame and fortune more than I should. But whether or not you believe me, I am sorry about what I did earlier. My greed got in the way of my common sense.”

“Would you have stolen it if I hadn’t come back?”

“I want to say no, but the truth is I probably would have.”

“If you can admit to that then I think you have what it takes to overcome your ego. Only time will prove if you can overcome everything else as well. Now let me get some rest.”

As sleep began to engulf me I thought I heard him say something else. But his voice was so low I wasn’t sure in my half awake state.

“Thanks Zelkov.”

**********

So ends another day, another timeline full of possibilities made reality. I wonder, would this reality still exist if you were not there to see it with your own eyes? It is true that all realities and possibilities exist in this place between realities. So in a sense yes it would still exist, but at the same time it did not exist. It was simply stuck in that limbo of what if’s and maybe’s that make up that thing called possibilities.

So was it you, an outside observer, that made it real? Or could it be considered real without you ever seeing it? Such questions are what keep me going here in this space where time and space have no meaning just like everything else. Perhaps you, an outside observer, can answer them for me. Perhaps I who am the guardian of these infinite possibilities and infinite worlds am how do you say… too close, to the subject matter.

Come again human if you wish to see what other possibilities this day had to offer. Perhaps you can help me answer those questions I have and amuse me again. I wonder though, next time what kind of god shall you be?
111121112211112121.title: Brush him off

111121112211112122.content:
“Everyone has problems. What you saw was simply my normal interaction with my mother. Being from an old family isn’t all it’s cracked up to be. But don’t let this little insight into my personal life go to your head. We aren’t friends now just because I gave you some advice.”

“I guess I sort of deserve the cold shoulder. I didn’t exactly make a good first impression did I? I hate to admit it but I tend to let my desire for fame and fortune override my common sense more than I care for. It’s really not an excuse for why I did what I did but I do regret it. Not because I was caught out but because I should have been able to stop myself in the first place. It’s like a switch in my head just gets flipped sometimes you know?”

“Would you have stolen it if I hadn’t come around?”

“I don’t know, probably. When I get like that I’m not able to make the best judgments and just sort of let my desires take over.”

“Then for what it’s worth, I accept your apology. If you can overcome your ego enough to tell me all of this and admit your intents like that then I think you have what it takes to be a Hunter. Whether you can overcome the obstacles in your path and have that unbreakable conviction remains to be seen.”

He looked at his lap for a moment before returning his gaze to me. There was a small smile on his lips and confidence tinted with a bit of fear in his eyes.

“Hey Zelkov. Thanks for saying all that to me. I know I’m a bit of a jerk and you are totally in your right to hate me. But it gave me confidence and it helped me remember why I wanted to be a Hunter in the first place. Perhaps if things had been different we could have been friends.”

“No we wouldn’t. I’d never be friends with someone like you. Personally I think you are the kind of person that gives Hunter’s a bad name. Normally I would never associate with someone like you more than I had to.”

Reaching over the side of the bed I dug in my bag until I found the packet of business cards in one of the side pockets. Riffling through them I quickly found the one I wanted before flicking it across the space to land on his lap. He picked it up and looked at it curiously.

“Arganov Electronics?”

“They are based out of Falandis city but he has an office down by the river on Hoffer road. Talk to Dimetrov Arganov. Him and his brother run the company together. They specialize in revolutionary electronics and artifacts. Pushing the boundary of merging magical artifacts with science. They make other things too of course, but that’s what they sink most of their money into. They are the ones that came out with the artifact wheelchairs and exoskeleton limbs you see around. Last I heard they were designing a wheelchair artifact that will transform into a pair of legs to help paraplegic’s walk. It’s still in a prototype stage mind but if you tell them I sent you they might be able to give you a deal on something that can help you. I doubt you will be lucky enough to become a tester, but if you drop my name you are guaranteed something high quality at a cheaper price than normal.”

“This sounds like something a friend would do.”

“If you are serious about this, you will need the best equipment to help you. The Gregory I met in the classroom coveting my things is the person I could never be friends with. But the Gregory that would be willing to shell out a lot of money for such equipment simply to pursue a dream despite his setbacks and shortcomings. Now that Gregory, the one who is proving the strength of his convictions, I could see myself being friends with.”

“But I don’t have that kind of money!”

“Not my problem. You don’t need such a thing to press forward, it will simply make things easier on you to have it. This is just one of the many problems you will face if you want to make your dream a reality. If this is truly what you desire then you will find a way to overcome it. Or overcome it without such equipment. Either way it will prove your convictions and I could see myself being friends with someone like that.”

He looked down at the card in his hand, wiping away a tear that tickled his eye. His finger ran over the lettering on the card before he spoke again, still staring at the bit of hope I had given him.

“Would having something they made really make it easier for me to become a Hunter?”

“I guarantee it. They’ve been able to create a fully flexible hand that runs on a heart crystal being constantly supplied power from the user. It can’t do anything fancy like go into a second phase or anything. But the Hunter has two fully functional hands and is currently fighting in the field as a tank.”

“Then I’ll find a way. I don’t know how I will make that kind of money but I will find a way. Thanks Zelkov.”

“Just doing my job. Rule number three remember.”

“And rule number four. A Hunter will help other Hunter’s if and when he or she can. Because we are all in the same business. I know that doesn’t take into account deals between Hunter’s, simply a general rule of thumb. But I also know I really didn’t deserve this either. I haven’t done anything worthwhile lately to get such a piece of fortune.”

I yawned as I rolled over on my side away from him. My body suddenly feeling the effects of the burnout as it told me it needed sleep.

“Then you had best change your life to make such a piece of fortune worth it. Consider it an advance payment on my belief in the person you want to be, not the person you are now. Now I need to get some sleep since the burnout just caught up to me with a vengeance.”

As I closed my eyes and felt the darkness closing in on me I heard him whispering to himself before I finally passed out.

“Advanced payment of who I want to be. I like that.”

1111211122111122.content:
“Unfortunately.”

“I guess I screwed up pretty big this time huh? You’re right, this was my fault. I can complain and blame all I want but in the end it comes back to me. I always wanted to be a Hunter you know. I grew up poor, and I mean dirt poor. I lived with my parents in this two room little hovel that had more holes than walls it seemed. But I was happy you know. Then a monster came and destroyed the placed. Killed my parents in front of me too. Would have killed me as well but then this Hunter came out of nowhere and smashed it up. Even though I was only four I knew that I wanted to be that guy. The one coming to the rescue and saving the day.”

I glanced at him covertly as I heard the choking of his voice, seeing tears coming down his face as he stared at the ceiling. It seemed like he had forgotten I was even there or that he was talking to me, lost in his own memories.

“They sent me to live with my aunt and uncle in Verindis city, but I ran away from there when I was seven. They were really mean and so was my cousin. I was just an extra mouth to feed to them and their precious little boy could do no wrong while I was treated like I was the monster. Fell in with a bunch of street imps, a man named Orsik lead the little gang. We were all still dirt poor, but we survived. Orsik was like a second father to me. We weren’t all noble or anything though, I stole and picked pockets to survive just like everyone else. Even though we didn’t have much, every year for Christmas and our birthday we managed to have a small feast or party and a few gifts. Gifts and food that we had bought ourselves, not stolen.

“And still my dream never died. Even when my fingers were slipping into someone’s pockets to take their hard earned Reul, I still remembered the figure of that Hunter with two guns blazing in and killing that monster. Our little territory was eventually taken over. Normally we were able to stay out of turf wars since we were such a small group. But one of the bigger groups made a power play to become a king of the north side of town. They didn’t want to absorb us, they wanted to eradicate us. Orsik stayed behind to fight alone, giving us time to get away. As I left the hideout I looked back and saw the resignation on his face. He knew he was going to die yet he was still going to hold them off for us.

“Even though I was only nine I had already learned a lot from him and a lot about how the world works. I wasn’t the oldest but I also wasn’t the youngest. The youngest of our group were two six year olds. But we ran and they chased us. The only other time I had ever been so scared was when that monster had killed my parents. The older ones kept pushing us on, sometimes staying behind to hold them off, sacrificing themselves as Orsik had. By the time we escaped into the wilds it was just me and four others, the two six year olds and two seven year olds.

“I pushed them on, as the oldest it fell to me to do what the others had done. I was the one that had to protect them like everyone else had protected us before. We traveled for days, living on the land, getting sick on some mushrooms and berries because we didn’t know any better, but pushing on nonetheless. We were just a day outside this city and we thought we were home free when a monster attacked us. I was scared and I froze. I knew what I was supposed to do. It was my job to let them get away. But instead I ran. I left them all to fend for themselves and I ran for the city shields. I heard their screams as they were caught and killed. Screams that even now still haunt me sometimes.

“Safe inside the city shields I ran into the nearest alley and hid. Berating myself for being all kinds of a fool. For being a coward for running away from my own death when everyone else had run towards it. A couple found me in that ally crying and shivering from the slight chilly air. A bunch of things happened but in the end they adopted me and took me into their home as their own son. Even gave me their last name. They were normal people, but their parents had both been Hunter’s. I thought long and hard about my life then, and decided I would never run away again. I needed to get stronger and learn all I could if I wanted to be that guy. The one blazing in to the rescue. That’s why I enrolled in the academy when I got the chance.

“I try to forget about my past you know. Where I come from and the skills I learned as a street imp. But I can’t. My fingers seem to move on their own even when my brain says to leave it alone. I know I’m a pretty horrible person and people don’t like me much. I do some pretty stupid things and have a bit of an attitude. But what am I supposed to do now? Without my legs I can’t be a Hunter. I can‘t be the only thing I ever really wanted to be.”

11112111221111221.content:
“Figure it out for yourself. You got into this, now you have to find a way to live with it. Just because you gave me some sob story about your past doesn’t mean you will get any pity from me. Everyone has some reason or another they want to become Hunter’s. You aren’t the first street imp to claw your way into a Hunter academy. Or the first person to have their dreams shattered either. But we all find a way to move on or not. If you are so weak willed that you can’t figure out a way to move forward then die. Take one of your guns and put a bullet in your own head. Because if all you plan on doing is moping around then you are worse than useless.”

I didn’t even bother turning over to look at him, simply showed him my back the entire time. What good did feeling such self pity accomplish anyway? I knew myself how useless it was. Compassion had a place, but pity helped no one. It only allowed a person to be weak. No matter what kind of past he had it didn’t negate or make the way he had acted in the present ok. Not that I didn’t have some understanding or feelings for what he was going through. I simply didn’t know how else to express it.

I heard him sigh a bit as the sheets rustled and I assumed he turned his face away. We both lay in silence for a while until a commotion out in the hall caused me to turn my head in that direction.

“… See my son!”

“Mrs. Zelkov, please. He’s suffering from burn out and needs a bit of rest.”

The door was shoved open as my mother strode inside, pulling a white haired girl with crimson eyes and wearing an ugly lime green dress behind her. The girl stood around four and a half feet tall and had the empty eyed expression of shock that made her look like a doll. My mother opened her mouth to say something when she saw me but the words seemed to catch in her throat. After a moment I saw her Hunter mask drop into place over top of the worry that had been there. I knew that open look of worry had been a calculated play of some sort, she was incapable of showing real emotions, simply using them to achieve her own ends.

“You look like hell Riktal darling.”

“I’m sure I do. So what do you want mother.”

She looked from me to the little girl and then back again, shaking her head slightly.

“Nothing, I just wanted to make sure you were all right.”

“Right. I’ll let you think I believe that. As you can see I’m fine, is their anything else?”

Again she opened and closed her mouth as she tried to formulate words that just wouldn’t come. Finally with another small shake of her head she turned away.

“No. Get well soon darling. I’m going to be going on another mission with your father to Bornica. We will be gone for about a week or so.”

“Great. Have fun.”

Pulling the girl out after her, she left the room again. The nurse gave us both a small bow before leaving as well. Letting out another sigh I closed my eyes again, hoping sleep would come soon.

“I guess you’ve got problems of your own huh?”

` “Don’t act like you care. I don’t even know you. Besides you tried to steal from me remember.”

“I suppose I deserve that. After you ran me off I realized how stupid I had been. My body sort of acted on it’s own and a small part of my mind was telling me I was being stupid, but the rest just wouldn’t listen. For what it’s worth I am sorry for what I almost did.”

“Whatever. Words mean little, actions mean more. You can be sorry all you want but if you continue to act counter to that it makes a lie of that apology.”

“Little chance I will get to act like that ever again now is there?”

“Then you had best learn to make your words count if that’s what you really believe. Now leave me alone please, I’d like to get some rest if I can.”

Even as I said that I felt the fatigue fall in on me all at once. As if my body suddenly figured out what my brain had known for a while, it needed rest. My eyes burned even as I yawned, turning on my side away from Gregory and relaxing my muscles to make sleep come easier. A short nap until the end of school would revive me enough to pull me through the rest of the day and then a good night sleep would finish up the recovery process. I felt the darkness of sleep closing in even as I gave another yawn, burying my head deeper into the pillow.

**********

Twists and turns along the paths of fate. Decision and consequence, regrets and judgments. This is life in a nutshell is it not? For every choice you make there are a million that you don’t. Whether because you simply decide not to take them or you don’t even realize they are there. And once a choice is made it is set in stone, closing the doors to some possibilities while opening the doors to others that had never existed until that choice was made. And always that ever present question of what if.

What about this day do you regret? What about this day do you wonder about? While most people do not have the chance to go back and do it over, you are not in that position. You were simply an observer into this single life. One with the power to alter the path he walked true, but an observer through a window nonetheless. In a place like this where time is meaningless, you have the option of reliving this day over and over. Making new and different choices to see where else Riktal might end up. To learn new truths about the world, answer questions and come up with new ones. So join me again whenever you wish traveler and I shall again bestow upon you the power of choice.

11112111221111222.content:
“So that’s it? That’s all there is to the strength of your convictions? Now that you can’t walk there’s nothing left? You think telling me your life story means anything? The only person it means anything to is you. It might pull at someone’s heartstrings or bring you pity from the right people but those are your memories and your convictions not mine. Those are the reasons you are who you are and why you do what you do. So you will never walk again, big deal. You’ve still got that mass of meat in your head you call a mind. Your legs may never move again but that doesn’t mean your mind stopped moving. You want to be a Hunter so badly? What’s stopping you?”

“But my legs…”

Letting out a frustrated growl I rolled out of bed and strode over to him, grabbing him up by his shirtfront and pulling him towards me until I was inches from his face.

“What about your legs! Your legs didn’t make you a Hunter! Your legs aren’t the ones that dreamed of being the guy that saves the day! Your leg’s didn’t make the decision to enroll in this academy! From what you’ve just said your legs have only allowed you to run away!. If you really want to be a Hunter then do it! Find a way to make it work, useless legs, wheelchair and all. “

“But how?”

I heard the pleading tone of his voice. The sound of someone lost with no clear path in front of him. I shook him hard before slapping his face again.

“What is the oath of the Hunter? What are the rules that we live by? Answer me! Rule number one!”

“A Hunter puts the safety of the people above all else. He will not balk at sacrificing his life for the good of all.”

“Rule number two!”

“A Hunter never gives up. He fights until his last breath for the things he believes in.”

“Rule number three!”

He seemed to gain confidence then, his head coming up and his chest sticking out as he stared directly into my eyes. His voice became more sure, stronger. That note of pleading gone.

“A Hunter is not his weapon. He is not his arms or his legs. A Hunter is his mind. He is an idea and an ideal. He is an example for the people in everything he does. He brings comfort to those who need it, hope to the hopeless and justice to those who have been wronged.”

“Now tell me. Where in those rules does it say you can’t become a Hunter? Will it be hard? Damn straight it will be hard! Will it be impossible? Only if you think it’s impossible. So you might not be able to go out into the field slaying monsters anymore! There are still things you can do to uphold those things we live by. Become a top class alchemist and discover newer better potions, or learn how to create artifacts. Just because you can’t walk doesn’t prevent you from helping citizens in need of you.

“So you’ve made some bad choices in life. Everyone has done that at some point in time. If they say differently they are a liar. You beat yourself up over running away when you wanted to be a Hunter. You’re right that was a dirt bag move to do, even if you were only nine years old. That doesn’t mean I don’t understand why you did it. Those deaths will be on your head for the rest of your life. Are you going to let them be in vain? You ran to survive. You ran so you could realize your dream! Are you going to waste it all now over something like this? I ask again, is this the strength of your convictions? Because if it is then I’m glad you are never going to be a Hunter. I wouldn’t want someone like you watching my back or protecting my citizens.”

I let go of his shirt, shoving him back down onto the bed before climbing back into mine and laying with my back to him. There was silence for a moment as I heard him shuffling around before he spoke up again.

“You’re right. I need to make the decisions I made mean something. I need to make up for the mistakes I made. Do you really think I can do it though?”

Sliding up into a reclining position with the pillow propping up my back I looked over at him.

“I’ll throw that question back at you. Do you think you can do it?”

“I don’t know.”

“Then you are going to fail. If you really want this then you have to be one thousand percent committed. Becoming deaf to those who tell you that you can’t and blind to those who will mock you. You must become so mentally strong that nothing, not even the end of the world can break you. Expect to fail more than you succeed and be ready to pick yourself back up to try again. That is what it will take.”

I saw him look down at his hands silently as he reclined in the bed like me. He twiddled his thumbs a few times before taking a deep breath.

“How can you be so strong? Able to have such conviction? Is it because you are from an old family?”

“In part, because this is what I have trained to do from day one. I was wielding toy sword and shields in my hands in my crib. Instead of action figures I played with suits of armor and learned how to take apart and put weapons back together for fun. But I figured out long ago that this is what I was born to do. Even if I had been born a first generation I would still become a Hunter. That strength comes from my convictions. Because I decided long ago that nothing and no one is going to stop me. That I was willing to do anything to make my dream of becoming a Hunter a reality.”

“Will… will you help me?”

I could hear the hesitation in his voice. Hear how much it cost him to ask for help. He was putting aside his own ego to lower himself into asking for assistance. Something he probably wasn’t used to doing. Slowly I shook my head.

“No. We aren’t friends and I’m not going to become your crutch. If you really want to do this then you need to walk it alone for now until your convictions are unbreakable. Friends and those who will encourage you are helpful, but you need to get rid of that ego first. Otherwise you will fail. It sounds cruel but it’s the truth. Kindness for you right now is a crutch that you will find easy to fall back on and slack off because of. But I’ll be glad to slap you around some more if you lose sight of your desires. If you prove to me this is really the path you wish to take of course. Otherwise I won’t waste my energy.”

Just then there was a commotion out in the hall. I turned to the door in time to see it fly open and my mother come storming in followed by the nurse.

“…See my son!”

She looked at me and suddenly seemed to deflate a bit, looking at a loss for words. The crimson eyed girl with white hair she was dragging behind her just stared blankly, seeming to be barely alive. I saw my mother’s work face come crashing down over top of the false worry as she suddenly found her voice.

“You look like hell.”

“Burnout tends to have that affect on most people mother. So what do you want?”

She looked from me to the girl and then at me, searching for what to say next. Finally she shook her head slightly.

“Nothing. I just wanted to make sure you were ok.”

“Sure I totally believe that one. But I’ll let it slide. As you can see I am fine, is there anything else?”

She gave another shake of her head before turning to leave.

“No. Get well soon darling. Me and your father are going on a mission to Bornica and won’t be back for a week or so.”

“Whatever. It doesn’t affect me any.”

She hesitated at the door for a moment longer, as if she expected me to say goodbye or something before letting out a sigh and leaving, dragging the girl behind her. The nurse gave us a small nod before closing the door and leaving again as well. I took off my glasses and rubbed my eyes with two fingers, resisting the urge to let out a long breath.

“I guess you got your own problems too huh?”

1111211122112.content:
Damnit! He might be a bit of a douche with an ego but that was no reason to completely disregard his injuries. If I looked at it only as which of the two was worse off then Gregory won out. Even if inwardly I felt he didn’t deserve it, that was just my personal feelings coming into play. And for a decision like this such feelings had no place.

Pushing Lilia, who’s hands were covered in Gregory’s blood as she tried desperately to heal him to the side, I took a kneeling position next to the boy.

“Back off Lilia, I can see you are almost at your limit. No need to get burned out completely. Focus on patching Jethic up so he can make it to the nurses office, I’ll take care of Gregory.”

“But how? You can’t heal like I can!”

“Don’t worry, I’m a Zelkov. The way everyone seems to believe, us Zelkov’s can do anything. Even pull the moon from the sky if we wanted to. Beside’s I’ve got a few tricks up my sleeve.”

I gave her a big grin and a wink to show her how confident I was. As she slowly moved away to take care of Jethic I pointed at the caster I had saved while the Arena Master told everyone to get back and give me some space.

“You! Marsa right? That magma ball you made earlier against the Glif. Can you make another one? But this time hold it for five or ten minutes without actually casting it away.”

“I…I think so. I haven’t tried holding a second tier for a prolonged period of time but if that’s all I have to do without fighting I could probably manage.”

“Good enough. Get ready to make it when I give the signal.”

I began to breath evenly, going into a meditative state and drowning out all outside interference as I set the vial of blood on the ground in front of me. Slowly I took my gloves off and laid them down carefully next to the vial. My mind needed to be incredibly focused for what I was about to do since it would be the equivalent of brain surgery with a hammer and nails. When I was ready I picked up the vial, breaking the seal before using the blade on a glove to cut open Gregory’s re-healed flesh, taking a few drops of blood as it came out. I told Marsa to summon forth the flames even as I clutched the gloves in my hand waiting on her.

“You’ve had a good run old friend and you have served me well. Now sing a final song for me. Sing your own eulogy. Phase three activate. Ripper’s memories.”

The energy began to flow into me as the heart crystal released it all in one shot. I felt as if my skin would explode from the amount of magic coursing in my veins. As the ball of magma burst into existence floating at the end of the girl’s staff I threw the vial inside of it seconds before ripping the yellow gem out of the gloves and smashing it against the ground before the gloves could finish transforming.

The magic began to go out of control as it’s connection to the magical circuit’s regulating it was destroyed. Within seconds I had the fragment of heart crystal that had been safely ensconced inside the gem flying into the magma after the vial of blood. I held out my hands, plunging them deep into the magma ball as well while shoving that wild energy in after it, keeping just enough so I didn’t burn alive myself.

Even so I could smell singed hair and burnt flesh as I focused in on what was going on inside the ball with my mind. Ignoring the heat licking at my arms. Since I couldn’t actually see the ingredients I had to play it by instinct and intuition. Constantly mixing it with magic instead of a glass rod. Counting out the seconds in my head instead of watching for the color changes. A few seconds off could make all of this for nothing. Producing little more then toxic chemicals.

My magic was draining fast and I had to pull more and more away from what I was using to protect my arms, the heat slowly becoming more than just a distant annoyance in my mind. Sweat dripped down my face and my head began to throb from the sheer focus this took. Suddenly a cooling shield wrapped over me as someone else took up the task, allowing me to dedicate myself completely to the potion.

The last minute began counting down in my head as my magic almost hit it’s limit. In my minds eye it was ready so I pulled my hands out, summoning freezing water and winds to surround the magma with the last of my strength. I made sure it was completely surrounded before crushing my hands together when the mental timer hit zero. The two opposing forces warred with each other before there was an implosion, all that magic falling in on itself. Seconds latter it exploded outward again creating a warm steam cloud that obscured everything inside of it.

But I reached in anyway after hearing the faint tinkling sound of glass hitting the floor. When I pulled it out I grinned to myself upon seeing the near clear liquid inside of a silvery, almost reflective, vial. Popping off the cork I turned to the unconscious Gregory and pushed down on the sides of his mouth, making it open automatically.

“Sorry about this but you should be glad you’re unconscious so you don’t have to taste it.”

Slowly pouring the liquid into his mouth I massaged his throat, making him reflexively drink. Once that was done I sat back and waited. At first it seemed like nothing was happening. Then his body began to spasm like some mad puppeteer was jerking him around. I heard sickening crunching and grinding noises as his legs flopped and twisted every which way. His back arched moments before he sat bolt upright screaming at the top of his lungs. He looked around wildly while his breath quickened.

“What happened! Where am I?”

“You’re still in the arena and I just saved your sorry hide. You’re welcome.”

Lilia Looked over at me in shock, hope written all over her face.

“Hurry and do that again for Jethic!”

Even as I shook my head sadly the Arena Master spoke up for me.

“He can’t. Even if he had another heart crystal on him right now he has no more giant’s blood, only one vial dropped. And even if he did have another vial he’s tapped out. It took all his magic to create just that one heal-all elixir.
