Besides even if you don’t want to admit it, you know he has passed the point of no return where healing potions of any type just won’t work on him anymore. At least not as effectively.”

I got slowly to my feet, feeling a bit shaky as Gregory stood up as well. He looked a bit confused about what was happening but seemed to understand I had somehow made a choice to save his life. With a grin he held his hand out to me.

“I don’t really get it but I guess I owe you my thanks.”

I simply glared at him before slapping his hand away, not even bothering to hide my disdain.

“This doesn’t make us friends. I made my decision on purely impersonal reasons. I still think you are scum and all of this was your fault.”

I heard some of the whispers from the class then. Words such as why I had chosen Gregory over Jethic when Jethic deserved it more. The grumblings of how Gregory must have somehow won me over or had some dirt on me. It never took long for rumors and wild theories to emerge no matter where you went. Gregory heard those whispers too as a cocky look came over his face and his chest puffed out a bit while he looked around at the rest of the class.

“Well it’s obvious he saved me because he knows I’m better then Jethic. That I’m going to be the greatest Hunter and he wants to give me that chance.”

Gritting my teeth I brought my fist around just as he turned to face me, connecting solidly with his temple as I bore him back to the ground, making his head bounce off the treated wood. He was unconscious again before I even pulled my fist away. With a sneer I spit on him.

“Go back to sleep. I liked you better that way.”

I managed to take a few steps away from him, making it to the wall before the headache and light headed feeling of burnout washed over me. Sliding down the wall I closed my eyes, letting the darkness of oblivion take me with a sigh.
1111211122112.title: Save Gregory

choices: Offer to help him find a job
11112111221121.content:
White washed walls and ceiling, that’s what met my eyes when I managed to crack them open against the burning sensation that wanted me to keep them closed. I knew I had to be in the nurses office, it just had that hospital feel to it. Letting my head roll to the left I saw the nurse applying her healing powers on Jethic who was sitting quietly propped up in bed with a somber look on his face. Marsa, Daniel, and Lilia were all talking to the principal in low voices by the door but I couldn’t catch more than a random word or two of their conversation.

When the three noticed I was awake they stopped talking, Marsa giving me a bit of a glare before walking out of the room. Daniel also gave me a speculative look, not one of condemnation, but not one of approval either. Perhaps he was wondering what he would have done in my shoes and couldn’t tell if I had made the right call or not. Whatever the case he nodded his head in my direction slightly before saying he needed to go or he would be late for class.

Lilia just gave me a soft sad expression tinted with a bit of anger. Probably because I hadn’t been able to save both of them. But her eyes didn’t say she blamed me too much for my choice. She too gave me a small head bow, offering me a small smile before leaving the room. The principal wheeled over to the right side of the bed, dumping my duffle bag on the floor before offering me a smile of consolation.

“I know it must have been a hard decision for you. I also know that not many could have done what you did. Even among top class Hunter’s making a Heal-all elixir like that is difficult. Of the teachers at this school I would guess maybe seven or eight others might have been able to pull that off. For what it’s worth I don’t blame you for the choice you made. You helped save my students and for that I am grateful.”

She gave my hand a quick pat before spinning her wheelchair around to head for the door. She opened it expertly while backing out, letting it swing shut behind her with a small thud. Next to me the nurse finally sat back on her stool with a sigh, looking at Jethic with a small smile.

“Well I did what I could. You shouldn’t have much problems with your back as long as you don’t try doing anything too strenuous. The arm is going to have to come off, I’m sure you knew that already though. I’m not equipped to do something like that here though, you need to go to the hospital for that. I can cauterize battle stumps but fine cutting like that is beyond me. Your insides are still a bit of a mess but I stopped the internal bleeding and shored up your immune system to help fight off the infections. Take it easy for a while to let your ribs heal naturally. Thankfully I only had to re-break two of them to get them to set right.”

“You don’t need to beat around the bush nurse. I know what this means even if you are too nice to say it directly. My life as a tank is over. Hell my life as a Hunter that goes out to slay monster’s is over.”

The nurse sighed as she nodded her head, getting up to go over to her desk where she sat again, beginning to write something on a paper.

“You’re right. Wearing plate armor and swinging around a heavy sword or shield is beyond you now. You try any of that and your back will give out on you. And if it does there’s going to be no putting it back in place. You will be a hunchback from then on. I think about thirty pounds will be about your limit. You will have to test and learn it yourself, but your body should warn you when it’s too much.”

He nodded his head, looking down at his lap as he clenched and unclenched his left fist slowly. He didn’t seem inclined to talking and I wasn’t inclined to begin a conversation or see any accusation in his eyes so it worked out. The nurse finished writing whatever it was, probably a report of some kind, before excusing herself and leaving the room. Jethic continued to stare at his hand as I turned on my side away from him, closing my eyes and trying to get some natural sleep to regain a bit of energy. Personally I would rather leave, but I knew the nurse would be against that idea. I knew my body needed rest, even if it didn’t feel like it right now.

“I’d be lying if I said I didn’t feel a bit of resentment at your choice. But I also realize it was probably a hard decision to make. Part of me wonders why you chose him over me. What it was you saw in him that I didn’t have. At the same time I figure you made the choice on factors I couldn’t even comprehend. The principal told us about the Heal-all elixir while you were unconscious so I know how much you gave up for Gregory, even if he was a bit ungrateful for it.

“But I want you to know that this isn’t going to stop me. In the end it’s just an arm. I might never be able to pick up a shield again or go out into the field wearing my plate armor, but I’m going to become a Hunter. There are all kinds of Hunter’s right? I mean alchemist that make potion’s, ones that search out new applications of heart crystal. Those who strategize and advise government officials. Perhaps I could even become a teacher and train the next generation of Hunter’s.”

I turned over, pulling myself into a reclining position before looking at him.

“Why are you telling me this?”

He shrugged absently while continuing to look at his hand.

“I’m not really sure. I suppose I thought you would want to know. In case it was on your mind or something. Old Markus, he is the Hunter that taught me much of what I know by the way, he said things like this can happen to a Hunter. That it happens more often then one might think. But he said how a person handles such setbacks is the mark of a true Hunter. Rule number three you know? He also said Hunter’s end up making some hard choices and they usually wonder if they made the right one. We can’t know for sure the outcome of our choices, we simply do what we think is best and deal with the outcomes.”

Reaching over the side of the bed I dug through the side pockets of my duffle bag until I found the small packet of business cards. I searched through them quickly before flicking the one I wanted across the space between us to land on his bed. He picked it up, reading the name one the card.

“Arganov Electronics? Isn’t that the Hunter brother’s who try to merge science items with artifacts in unique ways?”

“You know of them?”

“Only a little. A regular of my uncles talks about them sometimes. Even gave me a few old magazines with some articles about them.”

“Well they have a sub office down on Hoffer road that the younger brother Demitrov Arganov runs. If you go down there and drop my name I’m sure you can get a good deal on an artifact arm. As far as I know they haven’t made an entire arm before, but they have had some success with fully articulated hands. Even if it’s just a bunch of pistons and gears from shoulder to wrist and a fully functional hand, that’s something. I’m sure they would enjoy the challenge.”

“Thanks for the offer, but I don’t have that kind of money. My aunt and uncle aren’t exactly poor, but we don’t have much to spare. And my family up north broke what little savings they had to send me to the academy.”

He awkwardly flung the card back to me with his left hand but still managed to land it on my lap. Picking it up I looked at the gold embossed lettering, running my finger over the indents for a moment before looking back up at him.
11112111221121.title: You can't sleep yet! Wake up!

111121112211211.content:
“If you’d like, you can work for the money. I’ve got a lot of old dusty rooms in my house that could use a good cleaning. And a bunch of old things that need rearranged or gone through. I’m the only one there most of the time and honestly, I just can’t be bothered to do it all myself. You can take your time learning your limits and getting used to your new center of balance. Plus if there is anything you want to keep of the stuff I plan on throwing out you can have it.”

“That sounds a bit like you are taking pity on me. I might not be as good as you but I still have my own pride.”

“Please I’m not the type to give other people pity if I can help it. If you take the job I will pay you well but not extravagantly, since it will be coming out of my living allowance. I won’t purposefully throw out good weapons, armor, or items just for you to take. A lot of it really will most likely be junk. That’s not to say old pieces of gear I outgrew or broken artifacts won’t find their way into the pile. Still such things can fetch a bit of extra money if sold to the right people who know how to refurbish or fix them. It will be work, real honest sweat inducing work. And it will take you a while to make the kind of money you need for an artifact arm, even if you drop my name for a discount. At least six months or more for a good down payment.”

“You being real with me here? This isn’t just something to make me feel better or make me feel like I am earning the money when I really aint?”

“Totally real. My decision to save Gregory over you was purely impersonal. But that doesn’t mean I didn’t want to save you too. I admit I can be a bit of a Donglemeister, but I’m human like everyone else. I have feelings of my own and I can be moved by the plights of others.”

“How expensive we talking?”

“Well, let’s find out.”

I quickly pulled up my communication spell, swiping the small imprint square on the business card to temporarily link me up with the business. I got one of the receptionist on the third buzz and then a direct line to Demetrov once I told her my name.

“Hey Riktal! What a pleasant surprise! I was just thinking of calling you! We got a few new artifacts we’d like you to field test for us if you can. We’ve already gotten data from some lower classed Hunter’s and even a good bit from civilians and the military. But we haven’t had any chance to get feedback from higher ranked Hunter’s that can push them to their limits. Me and my brother could do it, but we are afraid we won’t have an impartial eye since it is our products. So what do you say? Interested?”

“Good to hear from you too Demetrov. Same as always I see.”

Indeed on the spell in front of me was a flat image of Demetrov in his white lab coat and black rubber gloves up to his elbows. His hair stuck out in all directions as if someone had just zapped him with lightning. His eyes looked three times larger than they actually were from behind the magnification goggles as he blinked at me and grinned, a single tooth missing from a small explosion last year.

“Not the same Riktal, we are never the same as the day before or even the second before. Our bodies are constantly evolving and dying, changing with each breath. Have you forgotten what I taught you?”

I held up my hands, patting them in the air to stop him. If I let him go off on one of his lectures he could go on for hours.

“Enough! Spare me the scientific psychobabble!”

“Fine fine. So what do you want?”

I grinned at the sudden change in topic. This was just like Demetrov. His brother was a bit better but could jump around just as much from subject to subject with a drop of the hat. I quickly explained what was going on, twisting the spell so he could get a look at Jethic’s useless right arm while he rubbed his chin thoughtfully.

“Hmm. It probably won’t be too hard. We did make that hand, and we’ve had some success with partially mobile arms. Granted the arms were attached to artifacts and not a human body, but the concept of linking it to the magic shouldn’t be much different. I can’t promise full articulation but there would be enough movement for most normal everyday things.”

“And what kind of price would he be looking at?”

I could see Demetrov thinking for a moment, his fingers making numbers in the air while his other one moved rapidly in nonsense patterns, probably counting and imagining the parts he would need.

“Full price would be around a hundred thousand Reul for such an artifact. That’s low end of course, using the bare minimum of supplies. But if you are referring him we could probably drop it down to seventy thousand.”

“Come on Dem! You can do better then that right? What if I tested those products for you? Think you could drop it a bit more?”

“Most I could drop it down to even at that is sixty thousand. That will let me clear costs and make a small profit as well.”

“How many of these kinds of artifacts have you made before Dem?”

“Well none of course. That hand was the only thing that comes close.”

“Then how do we know it would work well? Normally you would have to go through a bunch of red tape to get something like this approved through the business administration right?”

“Well yes now that you mention it that is true. Even if we made an arm for the boy it would still be two years minimum before it was considered safe. That hand took a year and it was just a bunch of servo fingers manipulated by the hosts own magic.”

“Then what if you got it passed the administration quicker saying he is one of the first testers? You already have proof of concept and function in the hand you made for Horris, and you’ve created working arms with the AZ-100 series of wheelchairs. It’s not a stretch for them to give you a go ahead for such a project when all you are really doing is merging the two together. If you do that couldn’t you offset some of your costs with funding the administration would provide?”

“You are one devious little monster you know that Riktal? That’s why I never play poker with you anymore.”

“Simply good business strategy.”

“Well you’re right. We could get away with that. Would still be at least six months before we could get the go ahead though. With the funding from the association backing such a project I could probably go as low as thirty thousand, twenty five tops. And he would have to be willing to keep in touch on a regular basis, at least twice a year checkups for five years minimum.”

“And you would pay for those visits as well as any maintenance on the artifact?”

“Of course. It would still be considered a prototype, so we would have no idea what may or may not go wrong with it.”

I looked over at Jethic who’s mouth was opening and closing in surprise while his eyes stared at me as big as saucers. I grinned as I raised my eyebrow at him.

“Well how does that sound Jethic? I’m sure in six months or so we can make you around thirty thousand Reul. And you will be guaranteed maintenance on it for the next five years or so. You won’t be getting it for free and you will have to work for it, but you will have earned it in the end.”

“I…I… yes, I accept.”

He rubbed at his face to wipe away the tears forming in his eyes as his voice caught in his throat. My grin grew wider as I said my goodbyes to Demetrov who promised to get to work on the arm right away. Turning on my side away from him I pulled the covers over my shoulder.

“Now that we have things straightened out, I am going to pass into oblivion now. The burnout just caught up to me with a vengeance and I am finding it hard to stay awake. We will hash out the details of your job tomorrow.”

His voice was all choked up and I could barely make out his soft words through his emotions, but I still understood what he was saying. With a bit of a grumble I closed my eyes, letting the darkness begin to descend as I answered him.

“Don’t thank me yet. I’m going to make you work for that money. I’m sure you will be cursing me soon enough as you wonder why you ever agreed to working for me. I’m the worst monster you will ever face.”

*********

So, the day ends on a high note I suppose. Was this the best ending to the day though? Could things have ended better? I know they could have ended worse. Are you questioning any of the choices you made? Perhaps questioning why you made them. Were you impersonal in your decision making, or were you influenced by events? Did you simply save Gregory because you believed things would turn out all right for Jethic? If that’s true, then what does that say about you? How would you have felt if it hadn’t turned out so well?

You humans have a very strange and varied way of looking at things I have found. You are not the first I have given this temporary power to and you will not be the last. Each one of you use it in most interesting ways and for the most interesting of reasons. Why I remember this one girl who purposefully took her person down the most dangerous routes because she hated men. But I digress, such things are not for you to know, lest they taint your perception of things in the future. Come again mortal, and test your powers as a god.
111121112211211.title: Offer him a job

111121112211212.content:
“If you really want something like this, I can help you find a job. I’ve got a few connections around the city that would hire you on my say so. Nothing strenuous or grand, but also nothing you wouldn’t be able to do one handed. It’s not pity or anything if that’s what you are thinking, but even I’m human and feel for other peoples plights. Sure the actual job might be a bit of a handout but it will be you who has to do the job right or get fired if you don’t. You won’t get a larger paycheck just because you know me, but it’s something you can do to earn your new arm.”

“Why would you go out of your way for me like that?”

“Because, I wanted to help you too. Just because I saved Gregory doesn’t mean I can’t do something to try and make your life a bit better. Hunter’s help other Hunters if and when they can remember. Besides, do I really need a reason to help you out?”

“Well honestly, you kind of struck me as the type that would rarely do something like this. A bit standoffish you know?”

“Well it’s true I can be a bit aloof and I’m really not what one would call a people person. But I still have my moments. This just happens to be one of them. Who knows, perhaps I would have offered Gregory the same kind of help if the situations were reversed. But don’t think this makes us friends. This is simply one Hunter helping another out. A one time deal.”

He looked down at his hand for a moment longer before returning his gaze to me with a small nod.

“I’ll accept your offer. You’re all right in my book Zelkov. Even if it takes me a few years to make the money it still gives me something to work towards.”

“Good. Now that that is settled, I need to get some sleep. The burnout is catching up to me and my body is crying out for some real rest. A few hours should do it for now. We can hash out all the details tomorrow, if you are still in the hospital then I’ll come visit.”

I rolled on my side away from him, pulling the sheet over my shoulder as I left him to his own thoughts. I had to remember to contact Demetrov later to see about making sure Jethic got a good deal on his artifact arm. Perhaps even pull it off to make him a prototype tester for it so Demetrov and his brother got the association to pay for a large chunk of it. But all of that could be behind the scenes dealings that Jethic didn’t need to see or worry about. If he did he might get the wrong idea or have second thoughts about accepting this offer. Refusing it simply because he felt it was some sort of handout.

As sleep began to creep in closer and closer I heard Jethic’s soft voice from the other bed.

“Thank’s Zelkov.”

“Don’t thank me, I really haven’t done anything. And call me Riktal, it’s easier on the ears.”

***********

So ends another timeline of many possible timelines. Where possibility meets possibility and a simple word or two can alter things completely. Where choices seem easy at first glance yet make you second guess yourself. Where you question the morality of who you are and why you chose the way you did. Are these some of the feelings broiling around inside you? Do you wonder where else the day might have led? What else might have happened if you chose differently?

Come again traveler and find out. For here time is meaningless and anything but linear. Where the choices made are simply what if’s and not set in stone. All you saw today has happened true, but it is also true that it has not happened yet and may never happen at all. Such is the paradox of possibilities.
111121112211212.title: Offer to help him find a job

11112111222.content:
I replaced the bullets that had been fired into the six shooter before grabbing three re-loaders. If I couldn’t handle anything with eighteen shots I wasn’t worth my name as a Hunter. Slipping it into my belt and the extra bullets into my pouch I left the rest locked up tightly to go wait in the arena, stretching out a little bit as everyone else filed in.

It would be interesting to find out what kind of skill level these people were at. Judging from first impressions and the amount of extra armor they had put on, I’d guess at around a middle D class overall. Some of them had their own weapons to use, but most of them began equipping up using the standard fair the Arena Master provided on the racks against the wall. Weapons with nothing extra or special about them. Not even a chip of heart crystal to help imbue the weapons with a bit of magic.

One of the boys slapped his wrist and a templar shield that stood almost as tall as he was expanded from the small circle of metal wrapped around his gauntlet even as the Arena Master took the floor to address the class.

“Today will be a bit different. Instead of pairing you up in sparring bouts, you will be applying what you have so far learned against real monsters. These are not fakes but ones that were captured alive and brought here. If you are scared to face them or are unable to handle them it is best to face it now instead of out there where your life is in serious danger. I’ve graded you all on your skills already and will pit you and three or four others against a creature you can handle. It will be challenging but not too difficult as long as you keep your heads about you and do as you were taught. I will assign leaders for each party who’s job it will be to issue orders and make the team work as you take down your given monster.”

“Zelkov! Hawthrope! You two can sit this one out today since you are both already past this point.”

The Arena Master began splitting the groups into teams while I waited patiently for him to get done. Once he was free I asked if I could have a small area to myself with a B class monster to spar against.

“Sorry, highest I got is C class. No one in here is ready yet for a B class and the ones I do have for the other classes I don’t have any extra.”

“That’s fine, I didn’t need the practice anyway, it was more for personal reasons.”

He nodded his head and returned to overseeing the class, fiddling with a magical box to make a wall split the floor into two areas. I climbed the bleachers and sat in the center so I could look down into both places. The girl I had stabbed earlier got up from where she was sitting a few feet away and plopped down on the bench next to me. I eyed her cautiously, on the alert for any retaliation but I didn’t stop her.

“So you’re a Zelkov huh? Well that explains a lot. I’m Liz Hawthrope by the way. Want to thank you for stabbing me earlier. And for giving me that healing potion. I’m being totally serious by the way, I really am grateful for both those things. My brother would have done the same thing if he had caught me napping like that. Saying something like a Hunter should always be alert to his surroundings no matter what.”

“Then after almost killing me like you did he would have also given me a potion. Though I will admit, that was the first time in a long while I felt like I really would die. Last time I felt like that was when my brother pitted me against a Crrazz when I was thirteen years old. So what is your first name really?”

I studied her for a minute but didn’t sense any kind of deception in her voice or body language. But that didn’t mean much if she had any skill as a Hunter.

“Riktal.”

“Tenth generation huh? I bet it sucks worse then being a fifth generation like me. People were always trying to get close to me at the beginning until I got them to leave me alone. Doing the whole yes man routine and trying to push their friendship on me as if I wanted to associate with them. Everyone here was just so shallow it seemed. Girls going on about boys and fashion like it really mattered and the boys were almost as bad.”

I only gave a grunt in reply as I watched the groups below switch out against D class monsters, confirming my thoughts of their skill level. I still couldn’t trust her even if she sounded sincere. History had told me not to take anything at face value.

“You don’t trust me do you?”

“What was your first clue?”

“Well I guess I really don’t blame you, but honestly I just want someone to talk to that understands me. Everyone else here seems to think this is some kind of game. They haven’t figured out how serious it is yet. My father told me to give them some leeway because they just switched over from going to a regular school to going to an academy to become Hunter’s. But I just can’t do that easily. So why are you here and not out monster slaying”

“Reasons. What about you? If your so good why are you here?”

“Reasons.”

We lapsed into silence as the fifth and last group stepped into the arena. Though I didn’t say so I really didn’t mind her company. I’d still be a bit leery of her but if she was speaking true I could understand where she was coming from. She seemed to have a feel of when not to push an issue and simply let a companionable quiet fall.

The last group of five seemed to be of a slightly higher caliber. They were pitted against a C class Glif, a subclass of blue giant with a resistance to magic but was otherwise pretty easy to deal with. I recognized Gregory who was dual wielding pistols and Lilia healing them all. Even though I didn’t know their names I also recognized the boy who had been in the classroom with Gregory and the tank with the templar shield of his own wearing full plate armor.

“A hundred Reul says that idiot Gregory tries to show off on the finishing blow.”

“I learned never to bet against the house, the cards are always stacked in their favor. But I guess he has already made himself disliked by more than just me.”

“Got on your bad side the first day did he? What he do? Try to steal something of yours?”

“Got it in one.”

“Yeah he has a bit of the sticky fingers. Daniel, the hand-to-hand fighting with him, can usually keep him in check or get him to give back whatever he’s stolen. But everyone has learned to keep tabs on their things.”

“And he hasn’t been given Lapiiree yet?”

“No. He hasn’t really taken anything too valuable yet so most people just give him a bit of distance. A bit of the forgive and forget mentality.”

“Well as long as he doesn’t do anything too foolish when it goes into it’s second phase he can make a fool of himself all he wants. Perhaps a good thrashing from a beastie will knock some sense into him.”

Even as I was saying that the monster went into it’s second phase, spreading it’s legs and putting up it’s dukes while taunting the group to attack with one hand. In this mode it would counter anything and everything thrown at it, but it would also absorb any magic cast and throw it back in their faces. The smart move was to just wait it out, regroup and get ready for the last push since the monster wouldn’t do anything while he had his fists up.

But true to Liz’s prediction Gregory cast an amplification spell on himself to augment his abilities. The Glif sucked in it’s breath, eating his augmentation magic and casting it on itself instead. It grew a foot taller to stand at a staggering eight feet, with arms and legs like blue mini trees. It’s power, speed and agility suddenly doubled by the spell it had eaten.

“Damn stupid idiot.”

I was up and running across the dividing wall with Liz close behind me. Even as I watched the beast charged towards Gregory who lost his cool and fired his pistols at it before shooting a fireball in it’s direction. The tank charged towards the boy as well, shoulder tackling him out of the way and raising his shield in time to take a massive fist on it. The shield crumpled in half even as the next right fist smashed into the side of his head. The caster had pulled him away at the last moment so the blow only clipped him instead of taking his face off like it could have.

Quick as thought he was dashing forward to punch downwards on the unmoving boy. The one named Daniel was suddenly standing over Gregory to meet the fist with his own. I could see the thick coating of magic he had around his hand. Even at that, the monster sucked up the aura as the boys hand snapped in half, the bone breaking through the skin at the elbow. The caster lobbed a low level ice spell at it to grab it’s attention.

As the monster turned towards the caster and Lilia who was standing next to her I pulled out my Lexington and fired while shoving off from the side of the wall at the same time. The wall absorbed the initial kickback even as magic oozed from the top barrel to coat the bullet coming out of the bottom one. The projectile smashed into the back of the creatures head, making a small cut in it’s hardened skin and letting blue blood trickle out.

The monster stopped it’s advance on the two girls to turn and face me as I landed on the floor, my weapon out to the side and still smoking. It was a good thing most giants were stupid and would attack the last thing that hurt them.”

“Yo ugly! How about playing a game with me. It’s called I’m going to smash your face in. The rules are simple, I beat the crap out of you and you die.”

The beast charged at me as Liz took the opportunity I had created to pick up the unmoving tank and the two girls helped the injured boys towards the exit after her. As the beast smashed it’s fist down towards me I jumped out of the way, firing another round at almost point blank range into it’s face and letting the kickback throw me to safety. Once I saw they had cleared the arena I cracked my neck and rotated my shoulders.
11112111222.title: Lexington double barrel

111121112221.content:
“Ok time to get serious and play big boy. Show me what you got.”

He roared at me and put up his dukes, motioning for me to attack him. I smiled but did nothing as I grabbed a hold of the top barrel on my Lexington with my right hand.

“”You feel all big and bad? Like a B class with that augmentation spell on? Well then just for you I will give you a proper sendoff. Phase two activate. Phantom shot.”

With a twist I detached the top muzzle of my weapon before crossing my arms together. The single barrel stuck to the back of my left hand like glue, the end of it resting just behind my knuckles. I felt tendrils flowing along the underside of my arm as a trigger button appeared in my palm. The main body of the gun sat sideways on the back of my right hand, another trigger button flowing into my palm. I began speaking to the Glif for the benefit of the class, perhaps they would learn something.

“Glif’s are creatures of habit you know. Some programmed gene in them makes them react to certain stimuli the same way every time. Your second phase lasts for three minutes, and though you can eat and use cast spells, you cannot do the same to internal enhancements. He would have been fine if the idiot had augmented his own body internally instead of going for a doubling spell. It’s been about two minutes forty seconds since you went into second phase, and the augmentation you stole lasts for four minutes.”

With a roar he lowered his hands and charged me, swinging his meaty fist coated in magic at my face. I jumped, planting my hands on his fist and flipping over his head before mule kicking him in the back of his neck, causing him to crash to the floor while I alighted on the ground easily.

As he began to lumber to his feet he threw out his right arm, sending a giant fireball hurtling my way. Lifting my left hand I sucked the magic up with the tube on the back of it.

“Two can play the magic eating game. But all you do is store the magic and imitate what’s cast on you. Once you cast it you can’t use it again unlike us. So you can’t keep recasting that doubling spell. Thirty seconds left on it by the way.”

His left hand shot out and a shard of ice came screaming towards me. Negligently I held up my left hand and depressed the button on my palm, sending out a flamethrower to melt it in mid air so I only got misted with warm water. He charged again with his left fist cocked back and I smiled at him.

“And it will wear off right about… now.”

Even as I cocked back my right arm and threw it forward to meet his, he began to shrink in size and his fist grew smaller. I fired off the four remaining rounds into the center of his fist seconds before mine smashed into it. The arm ballooned out and then exploded into bits that flew in every direction all the way up to the elbow. My left hand was already in my pouch grabbing a re-loader as he staggered backwards with another roar of pain.

Lifting my right hand I twitched it slightly to open the clip and let the spent bullets drop to the floor even as my left was coming around and thrusting upwards. Time seemed to move in slow motion as I pumped my arm downwards at the same time as the round re-loader came upwards, the new bullets sliding into place even as I pressed the release button on the holder. With another flick the rounds were locked back into place before gravity took control again. As I began to drop my hand back down from that few seconds or reloading, time resumed it’s normal speed.

The Glif charged me again, seeming not to care it was now missing an arm as it hauled back with it’s right fist. I jumped and spun, smashing my foot into the side of it’s face as I dodged the attack. It went flying and tumbling over the ground a good ten feet even as I crossed my hands to grab the two pieces of my weapon.

While it struggled to get to it’s feet I placed the tube in my right hand against the end of the Lexington in my left, creating a super long muzzle. I stood sideways, sliding my left foot forward and bent my knees as I aimed the gun at the creature who had managed to stand again

“In the end, you’re still just a C class monster. Explosive shot.”

Pulling the trigger the cement beneath my feet cracked and small craters formed as I shunted the power of the kickback through my body. The bullet slammed into the center of the monster’s chest before detonating in every direction. The body was blown in half, starting to fly through the air before it broke up into dust and disappeared like all monsters did.

With a flick upwards the second barrel flipped over top of the weapon and resumed it’s normal resting place in phase one. Sticking it back into my belt I turned and went over to the rest of the class who was coming out to congratulate me along with the Arena Master. I pushed passed them all to continue to the sidelines since I didn’t see Liz or the other five.

I found Lilia doing her best to heal the injured as Liz and the other caster fed her their power. She might get her divine healing from The One God, but her magic was limited just like everyone else’s. She was just finishing up laying her hands on Gregory when I came upon them, the other two were nursing their wounds and the tank even had a bandage over his left eye. Lilia sat back with a sigh as her divine power puttered out.

“Well I did all I can, they will probably have to see the nurse but at least they are in no danger of dying or having their wounds heal wrong. “

I put my hand on her shoulder and gave her a nod.

“You did good. No one expects you to be a master healer just yet.”

I looked over at the hand-to hand specialist who was rubbing his left arm where Lilia had put the bone back in as if he still felt the pain.

“That was a good idea you had. Though next time make a rounded shield of solid air around your knuckles. When the blow comes a rounded shield will shunt the force of the attack to the left and right like shoving aside water. That means it will require less straight up strength to match the monsters.”

“I’ll remember that for next time. Thanks.”

I looked at the caster who was sitting back on a bench with closed eyes as if she just wanted to fall asleep.

“That was quick thinking with the force pull spell. It was probably the only thing you could have done to save the tanks life. And it was too quick for him to absorb while in the middle of a counter attack. What’s your name?”

“Marsa. And thanks. Though I wasn’t sure if it was going to work or not.”

“Marsa. I’ll remember that. You earned a bit of respect from me today. Even if it hadn’t worked, at least you didn’t freeze up, that’s what’s important.”

Turning my attention to the tank who was touching the bandage gently I gave him a small nod.

“And what’s your name?”

“Jethic.”

“Will you be able to see out of it again?”

“Lilia says I will. I just need to keep it covered for a day or two so the light doesn’t aggravate it. I don’t really understand but I’ll trust her. I’ll have a scar though.”

“Well Jethic. I must say what you did was foolish. But it was also incredibly brave. You did your shield proud and you have earned my respect. I’ll introduce you to someone I know who can fix your shield for you. He’ll do it free of charge too if I ask him. Such an act as what you did is the mark of a true Hunter and deserves a bit of compensation.”

He stuttered his thanks as I looked down on the unconscious Gregory.

“An idiot like this doesn’t deserve to be a Hunter. You should have just left him Liz.”

“I was tempted to believe me. But even idiots deserve a chance.”

The Arena Master came up then and took a look around before saying anything.

“Well they all need to go to the nurses office before I will let them back onto the floor. Lilia you did a great job with initial field healing, but the fact is you still aren’t completely trained yet. I’d like a professional second opinion.”

“I understand sir.”

“Do I have any volunteers to go with them?”

I could volunteer myself, I had nothing else to do. On the other hand perhaps it was best if I not go. If Gregory woke up I might not be able to contain my anger at him. It wouldn’t do to kill him out of hand. Especially not in front of so many other people. Not to mention something like this could happen again. Like this time, the Arena Master might not be able to respond in time since he was busy with something else.
111121112221.title: Time to play!

1111211122211.content:
“I’ll go. It will do me good to take a little walk to cool my head.”

The teacher gave me a nod as I hefted Gregory none to gently onto my shoulder and headed for the door with the other’s close behind. Once out in the hall I slowed down a fraction so the others could catch up. And also because I didn’t know how to get to the nurses office yet. Glancing over at Lilia I saw she had that unfocused stare again, though I didn’t get the sense she was communing with her god or anything, she simply wasn’t in the here and now.

“Well Lilia, it looks like your prediction was true, I was fated to help you.”

She shook her head absently before turning her gold flecked purple eyes on me. Giving me a look of knowing that managed to send a shiver down my spine.

“No. That comes later. Whether you had helped or not today does not affect that moment. I might not know when or how, but I do know that. Your actions simply minimized the damage and kept anyone from dying.”

“I see. Good to know I guess. Makes me feel useful knowing my actions don’t matter in the grand scheme of things.”

“Yes. All our actions do not matter when looked at on the grand scheme God has planned for all of us.”

“I was being a bit sarcastic.”

“Oh. Why would you be sarcastic when you speak the truth?”

“Give it up. She’s gone into her own little world. I’m surprised you’re not crept out by the way she is.”

I looked over at Marsa and gave her a puzzled frown at her comment.

“You find her creepy? Why?”

“How can you not? She always has that weird stare that seems to see through you. She makes predictions that always seem to come true and you can’t avoid. She seems to have no sense when you are joking or anything and she’s always doing nonsensical things. I don’t know about you but knowing things like the fact I will fall down the stairs and break my arm no matter what I do to avoid it makes you feel pretty weak.”

“Ah so you are just like everyone else then. Afraid of those things that you do not understand or can’t control. You’re right that knowing such things can make you feel a bit insignificant, but so what? How many other things happen in your life that no one told you about that made you feel the same way? Were you able to control them any more than when you know it’s going to happen? People are all different, that’s part of being a Hunter. So is learning to work as a team as well as individually. Learning to adapt and accept those differences.”

“She can speak directly to The One God, is it any wonder she has a faraway look? Or that she has the ability to tell the future because of it? You fear her because of her powers, but if you strip all of them away, would you still think she was so weird? And even if you did, would you still be afraid of her? Personally I prefer associating with people like her instead of idiots like this guy here who does things to show off and inflate his own ego. Things that almost kill his teammates simply to fulfill his own desires I might add.”

She didn’t seem to know how to answer that, getting a thoughtful look on her face as we continued down the hall. When we got to the nurses office the others filed in ahead of me but before I could go in though Marsa put a hand out to stop me.

“Thanks.”

That was all she said before turning and entering the room but I understood she wasn’t thanking me for saving her earlier. Feeling like I had accomplished something I felt my lips curving upwards as I entered the room. I wasn’t even sure why I was so worried about trying to help Lilia in this way, that wasn’t who I normally was. Perhaps the knowledge that I was supposed to help her sometime in the future had altered the way I would normally act. I didn’t know but it felt right somehow.

The nurse was a priestess of The One God who also had knowledge of non magical healing. At first I had thought it weird when I had learned some priests and priestesses went to school for medical training like a normal person but then I realized it really wasn’t strange at all. Even divine power was not unlimited, so knowing how to treat a wound without magic would be as beneficial to them as learning to break things with my fists without augmenting my strength was to me. They could save their magic for when they really needed it.

She stood about my height at five foot ten with raven black hair that seemed to glisten under the lights of the room. A pair of light gold framed glasses sat on a small nose as her mocha colored skin seemed to accent them. She looked at all of us with those brown eyes even as I dumped my burden unceremoniously on a cot. It only took a few minutes to relay to her what had happened and why we were here.

With a quick nod she wasted no time in checking each person out one by one. I saw her hands glowing faintly while she did her inspection and slightly brighter as she added a bit more healing to what had already been done.

“Well you did good work Lilia. I only had to do a little touch up. But nothing a little extra training and experience wouldn’t solve. Daniel your arm will be fine, just no hitting anything with it for the rest of the day and eat a hearty meal for dinner. Jethic, Lilia probably might have said this already but your down to light training for the next few days. You don’t have much magic to help speed heal your body a little faster so you just got to wait it out. You’ll have a nice scar there too, but she got to it fast enough that there won’t be any vision loss or anything.”

The nurse then went over to the bed and looked down at the unconscious boy with a sigh.

“Every year we seem to get a few of these types. I know it is uncharitable of me to say I wish the principal would deny them entrance into the academy, but there would be less accidents if she did.”

She quickly inspected Gregory, proclaiming him fit with just a minor blow to the head.

“Though I don’t see where he took it from, the monster would have done more damage to him by the sounds and looks of things.”

“It was probably my fault. When I shouldered him out of the way I think I face checked him with my shield in my haste.”

“Well you saved his life by the sounds of things so he shouldn’t have anything to complain about.”

The nurse turned to me then, reaching forward to lay a hand on my arm and sending out her magical probes like she had with the rest.

“Nothing wrong with me, you’re just wasting your magic.”

“Then where did all these small cuts and bruises come from?”

I shrugged absently as I gave her a roguish grin.

“Private training. I learned long ago not to waste magic healing such small things. They can heal normally just as well. When you come from a tenth generation family they become part of the normal everyday life you just don’t notice anymore. Honestly I don’t even feel them.”

She made a tsking sound before sending out a bit more power to heal them all up. I only let out a mental shrug of my own as I kept my mouth shut. It would do no good to argue with her use of healing on me, servants of the Church had some funny ideas about healing sometimes. Once she was done she told us to leave the boy here and go back to our class, which we did. I privately hoped the boy never woke up again but I knew that was unlikely.

Once back in class the others reported the nurses ruling and the Arena Master nodded, jotting something down in his log book. As the others took a seat on the benches next to the racks of weapons I glanced up into the bleachers to see Liz watching us.
1111211122211.title: Volunteer

11112111222111.content:
I gave Lilia a small nod before heading up into the bleachers to sit with Liz. It wasn’t anything against this group but I felt a bit more comfortable being around someone who was also from an older family. The only one in this group I didn’t feel awkward around was Lilia and that wasn’t enough to stick around dealing with the eyes watching me.

“That was some nice work on the Glif. Though I really didn’t expect anything less.”

“Why because I’m a Zelkov?”

“In part. But the other part is you had the confidence of every Hunter I have ever known. That surety that it wasn’t a challenge at all, even if you are up against something you know is stronger than you.”

“Yeah well it really was no challenge. I’ve fought tougher things for breakfast.”

“And somehow I don’t think you meant that figuratively.”

“Hazards of being a Zelkov.”

“My parents got it into their head that now that we are a fifth generation we have to emulate the older ones. Like there is this sort of elite club we are now a part of. They keep forcing arranged marriage meetings on me even though they never attended any. They simply ended up falling in love while out doing their jobs. So why do I have to have boys forced on me?”

“I feel you. My mother is the one who forces them on me. I usually just skip out, leaving the girl hanging. It might be a bit mean but I never agreed to it to begin with and it saves them from having me blow up at them. My mother seems to think I need to marry someone from another old family or at least another respected Hunter house. So much political BS in being an old family, I hate it.”

“Skipping out on them huh? I’ll have to remember that. I’ve got another of those stupid meetings next week but my mother refused to tell me who it is, only saying that she thinks I will like him because he is a lot like me.”

“I’ve heard that line before, what they are really saying is I’m not going to tell you because then you will go in with more preconceived judgments then you already have. Ignore what he looks like since he isn’t handsome at all.”

She let out a chuckle at that and I grinned in return.

“There was this one girl my mother forced me to meet after saying those exact words to me that….”

The bell rang then and I started in surprise. I had actually been enjoying talking to Liz to the point of forgetting my surroundings. I couldn’t remember the last time something like that had happened. But dealing with her felt natural and easy. With a sigh of regret I got up and gave her a small wave as we parted company and I went to pick up my things from the locker room. Two more hours and this day would be done. History class and Monster Tactics and Theory.

By the time I entered the classroom I noticed Gregory still hadn’t come back. That was all to the good in my opinion. Perhaps the principal would kick him out for his stupidity, though that was probably too much to hope. I also noticed the shifts in power. Most of them were giving me stares of respect and a few of starry eyed hero worship. A few of those eyes were also calculating how best to make connections with me. I could see the thoughts as the girls sized me up and wondered how best to make me their boyfriend and the guys sized me up wondering how best to simply become a friend. Or at least perceived to be my friend and close to me.

I saw Marsa, Jethic and Daniel all go over and talk to Lilia who seemed surprised they were paying attention to her and I smiled privately. I had a feeling her lonely school life was about to change. I also noticed that her newfound friendship with the three had also been noted by the rest of the class.

The History teacher came in and took attendance before starting into his lesson. He didn’t get far though before a giant of a man came through the door. He stood at least eight inches taller than me at six and a half feet. He wore a simple white cotton shirt that strained against his chest and the muscles of his arms and a pair of black shorts that also seemed to hug his flesh. The sneakers he wore had to be at least a size eleven and were brand new by the looks of them. A military style haircut made the brown hair on his head look nice and neat to compliment the rest of him.

He looked around the room, his gaze seeming to pierce through everyone until his eyes met mine. He pointed at me even as the teacher asked if he needed anything.

“Riktal Zelkov. Your mother requests your presence immediately. You will come with me.”

“I don’t think so Buzz. I don’t know who you are or if my mother really did send you, but if she did then you should know I don’t take kindly to being ordered around like that. If she want’s me she can come get me herself.”

He stormed through the room and stood over me planting a meaty hand on my left shoulder, gripping tightly.

“Children shouldn’t talk back to their betters. They should do as they are told. Now come with me.”

As he pulled up I let him yanked me out of my seat as I reached around and grabbed his thumb, shoving backwards until I heard it snap. At the same time I turned into him, striking him quickly across the throat with a straight edged chop of my left hand before kicking him in the back of the left kneecap with my right leg. As he began to fold I brought my right hand around to grab the back of his head, smashing his face into the desk before wrapping my arms around his neck in a chokehold.

“So just who is better Buzz? From where I am standing I think I am your better. Now I was in a pretty good mood which you just ruined. So how about we play a game? It’s called get the hell out of my face before I kill you. I think you can figure out the rules yourself right?”

I released him from the chokehold before stepping back and kicking him away, sitting back down while he tried to catch his breath on the floor.

“As I said, if my mother wants me she can come for me herself. If I see you again today I’ll kill you do you understand Buzz?”

He stood up the anger seething from him in waves as he rubbed his neck and popped his thumb back into it’s socket. I could see he wanted to attack me but I could also see he realized I was stronger than him.

“The name is Henry kid. And your mother will hear about this.”

“Good. And your name is whatever I feel like calling you. If you want you can be called dog skat. Just be glad I decided on Buzz. You got a problem with that Buzz?”

I saw his jaw clenching along with his fists, his knuckles turning white. Finally he took a deep breath and tipped his head to the side in a mock bow.

“No. No problems with that.”

With that he stalked out of the room and was gone. Everyone was staring at me but my glare made them all avert their eyes. The teacher took a moment to collect himself before returning to his lesson. This kind of thing was normal in a Monster Combat Hunter academy. We were only about ten minutes in when the door opened again and my mother walked into the room with a petite silver haired girl in an ugly green dress and crimson eyes. She clutched a tattered brown bear to her chest tightly, that being the only indication she was aware of anything. The girl reminded me of a doll the way she stared blankly and just walked when my mother pulled her along behind.

My mother’s raven hair with streaks of grey was a stark contrast to the silver of the girls, and her hazel eyes seemed to pierce me with their gaze when she found me. She was wearing a simple black shirt and pants loose enough to move around in yet with enough pockets to carry her tools. The belt at her waist held a single dagger though I knew it could hold more. With a sigh I grabbed my bag as I got up and headed for the door without a word being spoken. Even if I would only be out of the room for a few minutes, I felt better having a weapon or two at my side. But knowing my mother, whatever she wanted wasn't going to take just a few minutes away from my day. Once outside and the door was closed I faced my mother with a hand on my hip.

“What do you want? Here to tell me you are off on another mission? Surprised you even bothered.”

“Well I will be going on another mission, but I want to speak to you, privately if I could. Can we go someplace else to talk?”
11112111222111.title: Sit with Liz

111121112221111.content:
“Fine let’s go someplace else mother.”

As she turned and headed off down the hallway pulling the girl by the arm I fell into step beside her.

“So who was Buzz anyway? One of your new aides?”

“Buzz? Oh you mean Henry. Yes he is. Just started about four days ago. You really shouldn’t have done that to him you know. He was only following orders.”

“You really scraped the bottom of the barrel to find him didn’t you? I bet they are getting wise to what a crummy employer you are and won’t work for you just out of principal. As for what I did, I only corrected his mistake. There is a way to go about things and he chose poorly. I’d say you know that I don’t take well to threats or commands but you are you so I’m not so sure.”

“Well I hope you’re happy because you scared him off. He told me what happened then he hightailed it out of here saying he wasn’t going to be killed by you for me.”

“Least he had some brains.”

“I have a feeling I am going to have to find another aide now. Why do you make things so difficult for me?”

“I’m in tears here. Perish the thought that I make my mother’s life so difficult when that’s the only thing she ever seems to want to do with mine. As if she wasn’t happy unless my life was miserable.”

“You really are ungrateful.”

“I’m the way you taught me to be. And do you really want to do this? I assume you want something from me and this kind of talk is making it easier and easier for me to say no out of hand.”

She fell silent as we finished our walk to an empty room on the first floor that looked like it was used for student council meetings. I knew she wanted something from me, that was the only time she ever dealt with me it seemed. Never dealt with me as a mother, only as a Hunter. Stuck around home long enough to give me some training and then left me with babysitters. My father had been a little better but not by much. That was my childhood as a Zelkov in a nutshell.

She offered me a seat at the table as she manually sat the girl down, taking a chair next to her across from me and folding her hands on the table. I noticed the little girl give the bear a slight squeeze before resuming her near comatose state.

“So what do you want?”

“I want you to protect this girl for a few days. Her name is Asala and she just lost her parents three days ago. She’s been like this ever since. Won’t eat, won’t sleep, won’t even bath or take care of her basic urges. Just letting her bladder go whenever she feels like it. She ruined two dresses before we just began treating her like an infant and putting diapers on her. We’ve been sustaining her with magic even as we continued to try to get her to interact with the world, but with no success.”

“So what is so special about her? If she was any other little girl you would let some relative or friend of the family take her. What warrants you personally taking her under your wing?”

“She’s a monster summoner with unstable powers. You are one of the few I know that has no problems with summoners. And one of the fewer still I could trust being able to take care of anything she summons. It will just be for two or three days until someone I know can come pick her up. And since you are good with kids I was hoping you could break her out of this state she is in. You always did have a knack for that kind of thing.”

“Mother, there is nothing special about what I do. Anyone can do it with just a little patience and not acting like the child had no brain in their head. Even someone as crappy with kids as you are could manage it if you tried. You don’t even need to be a Hunter for it.”

I studied the little girl for a bit. With her petite four and a half foot frame I could probably bench-press with one hand, she didn’t seem like she had the ability to summon monsters. But I knew how looks could be deceiving.

“What’s the highest level monster she has summoned so far?”

“An A class, but she fainted right afterwards, cutting off it’s foot as the portal closed. Most of the time she summons C class and lower. Only one other time did she summon something bigger, a B class.”

“Will I have Hunter immunity?”

“I’d prefer this be under the table, just from one family member to another.”

“For something like this? I’d like to have a bit of insurance if I need it. The Zelkov name won’t protect me from everything. If I have to kill people to protect her I want it covered.”

“Fine I’ll have a Hunter by proxy under my name made up for you if you agree.”

Nibbling my lower lip I narrowed my gaze on my mother. She was worried about something though she hid it well. She wouldn’t have so easily given into my demand for a proxy paper without at least a bit more resistance to the idea.

“Fourteen thousand Reul. I would have asked for less but your meat brain aide put me in a bad mood.”

“Fine. But only if you continue to attend classes. I’ve got my reasons and you going to school here is important.”

“You always have your reasons. But I’ll accept that. Only if doing so doesn’t put her in more danger.”

“Agreed. I’d say I would have my aide write it all up for you but someone ran him off.”

“I wonder who that could be.”

“I have no idea. But that does mean I will have to send you the paperwork over the communication spell for you to copy into reality.”

“That’s fine. Get Hilda to do it, I trust her work over anyone else you might have.”

I heard a small sound out in the hall by the door so jumped out of my seat and crossed the room to open it up. I spotted a figure turning the corner at a run down at the end of the hall but couldn’t catch a glimpse of who it might be. Had he heard our conversation? Or was it just some random student getting back to class? Or coming from a class for that matter. Seeing running students in a place like this wasn’t that unusual after all.

With a shake of my head I closed the door again and told my mother she could leave even as I knelt on the floor next to the girl.

“It will probably go better if you weren’t here anyway.”

She gave me a nod, opening the door and stepping out into the hall silently. Before she closed it however she looked back at me with a fake smile I knew was the prelude to something I wouldn’t like.

“Oh before I forget, you have a marriage meeting next week. I’m sure you will like her, she’s a lot like you after all.”

She shut the door before I had a chance to tell her I wasn’t going. Instead I simply shook my head before turning my attention to the girl.

“I know you can hear me. I’ve seen you gripping that bear a few times. No one else might have noticed but I did. So I want you to answer a few questions with yes or no nods of the head. If you don’t my left hand will become a tickle monster and find your ticklish spots until you do. Do you understand?”

She simply stared ahead blankly without replying so I shot out my left hand and began tickling her side. She lasted a good thirty seconds before giggling and squirming away.

“Let’s try this again. Do you understand?”

At first she didn’t do anything but when I lifted my left hand and waggled my fingers she giggled again before nodding her head.

“Good girl.”

I asked her a few questions such as if she had any other clothes and if she liked being treated like an infant. She answered no to both of them, confirming what I had suspected already. When I asked if she was able to deal with crowds of people she shrunk into herself a bit, again answering no. The bell signaling the end of the period rang as I nibbled my lip again wondering what to do.
111121112221111.title: Go someplace else

1111211122211111.content:
“You know what? Right now I don’t think it would be a good idea to take you to class and see all those eyes staring at you. I bet you are still pretty scared right now and I doubt you trust me too much yet. So we are going to ditch a little early, have a good time on the town where we will buy lots of clothes for you to call your own and get you thinking you are a real little girl again. I know you are sad because you lost your parents, but that doesn’t mean you can’t enjoy and appreciate things in life still. That might be hard to understand, but it’s not a sin against them if you giggle or smile once in a while. Bad things happen, but good things happen too.”

“But I will warn you, I don’t take kindly to little girls I take on dates into town not eating if we stop at a restaurant. My left hand might be a tickle monster to make you come alive but you don’t want to see what my right hand can do.”

I raised my eyebrow in her direction while pretending to squeeze something with my right hand. She smiled and squirmed a bit, making me wink at her.

“So if we stop at a quiet place to eat do you think you would have a problem with that?”

A quick shake of the head elicited another grin from me as I stood up and offered her my hand.

“I have to wonder what they were thinking if they couldn’t get you out of your head like I did. I bet they just told you what they expected and pulled you around by the arm didn’t they?”

A nod up and down as I led her into the hall and to the left towards the front of the building.

“I bet that big guy also scared you something fierce as well. With all those muscles and that mean looking face.”

Again a bob of the head.

“So do I scare you?”

She didn’t do anything, just sort of hunched her shoulders.”

“Maybe a little? Because you think I am going to hurt you for being a summoner?”

Finally just the barest dip of the head as she crushed her bear against her chest again.

“Well I’m not going to. I’m not like most other people who think summoners should all die or something. I once had a friend who was a summoner. She’s dead now, but she taught me that summoners are people just like everyone else. I won’t get mad if you summon a monster. You can’t help it at the moment right? Your power is unstable after all. I’m going to do everything and anything I have to in order to protect you. And I’m going to help you deal with your grief over your parents death. That’s a promise from me to you.”

I turned and held up my pinky for her to shake as we left the school gates. She looked at my finger and then at my face before reaching out and hooking it with her own. I gave it a quick shake up and down while reciting the oath before continuing on my way.

I kept up a bit of small talk, mainly to make her feel more at ease around me. That was the trick to all of this, making the child feel at ease. Feel like they are safe or have some amount of safety when you are around. Slowly she began to warm up to me. Even though she might not look it outwardly, I could feel the change in the air. The way she actively stuck close to me and gave my hand small squeezes. I would take it easy with her. There were a lot of different routes I could go down to help her, from acting like a total idiot to get her to laugh and have fun to just pulling her around behind me and forcing things on her without giving her a chance to decide on her own.

I figured this pace would be best for now. Let her come to grips with her grief on her own without me forcing it on her with kind words and a soft voice. If I did things right she would release that pent up sadness soon enough. I had a feeling that was part of the reason her power was unstable, she was holding too much inside.

We shopped for two hours or so, as I helped her pick out a few dresses she liked and some extras such as undergarments and some jewelry. Dinner was also uneventful as I extracted a few nuggets of information about her without her realizing it. She did slip off to put on some real underwear, which did seem to improver her mood even more. Whoever had thought putting a diaper on her was a good idea was a real idiot.

After dinner we walked home, her confidence growing by leaps and bounds as no monsters or summoning circles even hinted at showing their faces, further confirming my belief as to why her power was unstable. She still hadn’t said a word though, just a few smiles and giggles. That was fine, at this rate I would probably get her to say a few words by tomorrow evening.

Once inside the house I handed her the new pajamas we had bought and showed her the bathroom, telling her to get cleaned up. I left her in the bathroom, hearing the water being turned on before heading off to my room. Pulling out an old box from my closet, I began taking out the stuffed animals inside. One by one I laid a trail from the bathroom to my bed with them, setting a tattered blue rabbit missing an eye on the pillow at the end. Once that was done I sat at my small desk and waited.

Soon enough the girl came in the room following the trail, her wet hair going in multiple directions as she carried her bear in one hand and a purple elephant in the other. She looked at me with wide eyes and I grinned, pulling a comb from behind my back and telling her to sit on the bed. She did so without question and my smile broadened. So my plan to make her lose all fear of me had worked. Sitting down behind her I began to comb out her hair as I talked to her.

“I used to have a little sister who was a bit like you. She loved stuffed animals and I would always comb her hair like this after she took a bath. She would tell me about her dreams and about how her day went at school and every little thing that came into her head. She was pretty popular you know. Had all the boys chasing after her. Well at least according to her. She was sweet and kindhearted, nothing at all like me. I can’t get along with people too well, the only ones I am really good with are kids. So I have no clue how she turned out the way she did.”

“But out of all her stuffed animals, this rabbit here was the one she loved the most. It was like your bear there, she was never anywhere without it. Whenever it needed washed she would give it a bath just like a real person, soap and all. Then I usually had to dry it out with magic because she wouldn’t let go of it even then. She’d even be willing to sleep with that soaked and sodden thing if I had let her.”

Picking up the rabbit I held it out to the girl who put down the elephant and held it in her hands while I continued to brush.

“His name is Mr. Snuggles, and she prized him above all else because I put a special magic on him just for her. See, she was a crybaby, but she was always trying to hide it from me. Said she wanted to become strong and not always cry. That she wouldn’t be a good wife to me if she was always crying. That magic made it possible for her to cry all she wanted as long as she was holding it. No one could see her tears or hear her wails no matter how loud she was. She would look like she had on her normal everyday face.”

“Now, I can’t give Mr. Snuggles to you forever, but if you want to hold onto him for the next few days until you have to leave, then I don’t mind. If you’re really good I can cast that same spell on your bear as well before you leave. It takes a lot of magic though so I don’t offer that lightly. Now, your hair is all combed out, and you haven’t had any proper sleep for three days. So I want you to be a good girl and go to sleep for me. I know it’s a bit early, but your body needs the rest even if you don’t think it does.”

As I slid off the bed, she slid under the covers, gripping both the bear and the rabbit in a death lock. After tucking her in I kissed her forehead with a soft goodnight, turning off the light and leaving the door open a crack before going downstairs. My bag stared at me from where I dropped it next to the door, telling me to do something with it. I was tempted to move it but in the end left it sitting there. I would just be taking it to school tomorrow anyways. Instead I turned down the hall into the living room, sitting on the couch before leaning my head back and closing my eyes.

What a day so far. Who would have thought this is how it would have ended. But oddly, I didn’t mind. It had felt like I was a big brother again. Like I had family. There was a slight creaking of wood and my eyes cracked open, being drawn to the sound by the door. Asala came hesitantly into the room with both animals clutched tightly to her chest. I motioned her over and she quickly settled her head on my lap before closing her eyes. As I absently began to stroke her hair while she fell asleep I heard her muffled crying but ignored it like I had always ignored Olia’s. Magic rabbit indeed. There was no such magic like that. But she had thought there was, that was all that had mattered. Lilia’s words popped into my mind and I smiled. It seemed there really had been a girl in my future.

***********

Another day draws to a close and so does this window. Choice and consequence. Action and reaction. One thought popping into the head before another, eliciting one action or choice over others. What decides those thoughts though? What choices bring forth the series of thoughts that dictate the actions? Would Riktal have even considered taking the job if Lilia had never given him that prediction? Would the meeting with his mother have gone differently if he had not decided he was having a good day? From what decision did his good day start? Was it the first second he opened his mouth? Or was it later than that? What would have happened if he had never met Lilia? Come again fair traveler and alter this day once more, find out the answers to these questions and others. Will you regret the decisions you make or will Riktal be the one to regret them?
1111211122211111.title: Leave school

1111211122211112.content:
“Do you think you could deal with a few eyes staring at you for an hour if I’m next to you? I’m tempted to just leave right now, but I did sort of agree to keep going to class. Unfortunately I don’t feel there is a good enough reason not to at this time. I know it might be a bit uncomfortable for you but do you think you could manage for me?”

She was still for the longest time, not going back into her mind but deep in thought. Finally a slow bob of the head and I gave her a reassuring grin.

“Good girl. After school we will get you all prettied up with some new clothes and maybe a few trinkets. Never met a girl yet that didn’t like her a few rings and necklaces. Get you some real underwear, I’m sure you really don’t like wearing that thing do you?”

When she shook her head no I gave her a wink and stood up, offering my hand which she hesitantly took.

“I’m sure you don’t trust me too much right now but that’s ok. I will keep you safe until my last breath, no matter what or who I have to hurt. Because I once knew a monster summoner, and she taught me that you are people just like everyone else. Having that power doesn’t make you any less human.”

As I led her out the door and turned right I gave her hand a squeeze of assurance.

“Though I’m not going to keep you running with magic like my mother did. Your body needs food and sleep and everything else. Even if you don’t feel that way because the magic blocks your perception of those needs, it doesn’t fill up your belly like real food will. And using magic to keep yourself awake makes your brain go all loopy after too long. So I expect you to eat and sleep when given the chance you understand?”

She nodded her head in agreement as we came up on a point where another hall shot off to the side. I sensed the presence before we got there so wasn’t surprised when the principal came into view. Asala squeezed my hand in surprise though but didn’t do anything else.

“So what do you want old woman? I take it you’ve been eavesdropping from the beginning so you already know about the girl and my job. Not even you will be exempt if you try to hurt her.”

“No like you, I have no problems with summoners. I’ve lived a long time boy, and seen a lot of things. I long ago got rid of my notions of having blind hatred for things I don’t understand. I’m actually here to help you. I think it best if you leave for the day. There was some overlarge ears at the door that were quick to run back to your classroom with the news of that little girl. I fear there might be some problems if you were to go back there now.”

“Would those overlarge ears be attached to a boy named Gregory?”

“I could not say exactly but the face and body did indeed look like such a boy.”

I gritted my teeth as my anger boiled under the surface. Taking a few deep breaths I tried to calm myself down with no avail.

“I’m going to have to deal with this one way or another, whether it be today or tomorrow. Knowing how little love most people have for summoners though I am not willing to take the girl into the lion’s den so to speak. I’m not sure what is going to go down but I have to deal with this now. If I wait it will only get worse as the rumors and the fear has time to seep and spread.”

Kneeling in front of the girl I looked at the principal and then back at her.

“Asala, do you think you would be able to stay with the principal here for a little bit while I take care of some business? I’ll be right back I promise.”

She finally nodded her head after clutching my hand tightly. Ruffling her hair I turned to the principal.
“You will look after her for me won’t you? If you have no problems with summoners then I am sure you can keep her safe.”

“I can and I will, only if you promise me not to kill anyone.”

“I can’t make that promise. I won’t put my life or the life of this little girl in danger just to save a few people for your sake. If you don’t want to help me then that’s fine I’ll take her with me and probably cause more of a riot then there will already be. I will make the concession that I will try not to kill anyone I don’t have to.”

With a sigh she nodded her head as she held out her hand to the little girl.

“Fine, come pick her up in my office when you are done. And god have mercy on that classroom.”

As she wheeled away with the little girl following her she began telling Asala a story to keep her occupied. I turned and headed for the classroom, unzipping my bag just in case even as I hiked the strap farther up on my shoulder. This really was different from other academies I had seen and heard about. It might seem strange to most that the principal was so accepting of the possible bloodshed that might ensue. But considering these kind of things would rear up when they became true Hunter’s, it was best for them to deal with such ideas and decisions now.

This was a violent world, and humanity accepted that they were violent creatures by nature. Some kingdoms had tried to go the pacifistic route and it had failed miserably against the threat of monsters. Democracies, dictatorships, everything and everything had been tried. Sometimes they worked, sometime they didn’t. It was only when humanity tried to be purely civilized while denying their violent nature did they fail the worst. So the world had come to accept that violence was a part of life and we had formed a fine middle ground between that part of ourselves and a civilization of peace. Granted most of the violence was left in the hands of Hunter’s, leaving regular people to enjoy the peace we created for them.

Before opening the door I dug into my duffle until I found the small box with the button on the side I was looking for. Carefully I shoved it in between my belt and body, tying it in place with a few strands of magic. Once I was ready I entered the classroom to a small bit of chaos.

All eyes turned on me, but where before those eyes had been calculating and conniving, now there was fear and anger in many of them.
