An overwhelming number of people had hatred for summoners, fearing what they could do. Indeed, until about a hundred or so years ago summoners had actively went out of their way to try and destroy civilization with the monsters they summoned and controlled. Such old hatreds were slow to die.

“So Gregory, I hear your ears got a bit too long for your head and you heard things you shouldn’t have. Didn’t anyone ever teach you not to go blabbing on peoples private matters? Especially when it is Hunter’s business?”

“They have a right to know what kind of monster your protecting! What kind of monster will be coming into this room with us! How can you even protect a freak like that?”

I could see the unrest growing. The teacher wasn’t even trying to stop it. In fact he even seemed to be in agreement with what Gregory was saying. If this continued there was a possibility of a full blown riot. I had two choices in front of me right now and both of them could go south quickly. There was danger of a riot breaking out on both of them but if I let this go on even I would have difficulty controlling the situation.
1111211122211112.title: Go to class

11112111222111121.content:
“They don’t have a right to know squat! Hunter business is Hunter business! Not everyone and their mothers! When was the first time you played with yourself? When did you stop wetting the bed? Who was the first person you kissed? Who do you have wet dreams about at night? Everyone has secrets they don’t want to get out! No one has a right to know everything about everyone else! We have a right to our privacy!”

“You will be a Hunter! A poor one but a Hunter nonetheless. You will take jobs you find questionable, ones you don’t agree with or find distasteful all to do your main job, and that is to help people! To save innocent lives and the greatest number of them at that! I already took the safety of everyone in this room into consideration before accepting this job! You would kill a little girl no more than eleven or twelve for a power she can’t control yet?”

“That’s all the more reason to kill her! You never know when or what she will call forth! And you want to bring that kind of thing into this room? Into this school! Allow it to run amok in this city! What are you? A CAMPer?”

“A CAMPer? A CAMPer! I’m I bloody Hunter! I kill monsters for a living! I killed one earlier to save your ungrateful worthless hide if you don’t remember!”

I looked to the left at the teacher and at the rest of the class in front of me. My words seemed to be getting to a few of them but I could see the fear of the unknown had already gotten to many of them. They were close to the mob point and had been before I had even come in the room. I could see my words really weren’t having the affect I had hoped. Perhaps if I had killed Gregory at the very beginning I could have shocked the rest of the class into breaking out of this near riot mode. But I had said I would try not to kill anyone.

There was a still moment when nobody seemed to move or say anything. A moment where even time seemed to stop. Then the fear and madness that had been lurking in Gregory’s eyes reared up as he shouted at me.

“You should die too for protecting a monster like that!”

His hand reached for his waist, touching a blue gem that made a gun materialize. As he began to draw it I summoned a gust of air and shoved it like a wall towards all of them, picking up all the desks and throwing them into the crowd and against the back wall. His first shot went wildly up into the air as he was hit with a desk, some of the class got out of the way while others were caught up in the wave of tables. It was easier to fight in an open space instead of a crowded one anyway.

Other people had pulled out weapons or came at me with their fists. Reaching into my duffle bag hanging at my right side with my left hand I grabbed the first thing I felt, pulling it out even as I threw the bag at the oncoming mob. Blocking an overhead chop of one girls sword with my own I slid it to the side and punched her in the head with my left fist, taking a kneeling position as I spun in a circle, avoiding the staff that had been coming for my head.

Launching myself upwards I uppercut the boy who had swung the staff , catching him under the chin as I dashed forward through the throng. My right hand reached into the bag as I caught another sword on mine and shoved it to the ground, coming up with another blade half as long as the one in my left hand. I got my right hand up in time to catch the blade of a glaive on the edge, bringing my left around to punch the girl in the head like I had the last one. Suddenly Daniel was there blocking my fist with his own.

“Make a curved shield of air isn’t that what you said? Seems you were right.”

“Glad you remembered. But you’re still years too early to face me.”

Shoving his fist to the side I brought the blade around level with his eyes too fast for him to dodge. At the last moment I twisted the sword so the flat of the blade smashed into the side of his head knocking him out. I continued my pivot to block two strikes coming from opposite directions seconds before jumping and doing a back flip in the air. Liz barreled under me as I landed and dashed towards her back. Dropping to my knees in a slide while avoiding the blades passing over my head as I spun, I cut into the back of her knees. As I came back to a standing position I swung the blade in my right hand upwards as hard as I could, cutting off the arm of one of the sword wielders.

I felt the power hurtling towards my back more than saw it, slapping the box I had placed under my belt even as I brought my left blade up in a diagonal slash to meet yet another blade. The orange shield popped up around me, taking the magical fireball. I turned just in time to see the teacher with his hand out towards me. Letting my magic coat my blades, I slashed the air quickly in his direction, sending out lines of fire rapidly. He blocked the first five but the sixth one tagged him before he could counter. Four more times I lashed him with flames, not enough to kill but enough to blister and burn his skin until he fell to the ground moaning.

After that it was simple to knock the last three attackers out as they beat uselessly on my artifact shield. The ones who hadn’t attacked because I had knocked the fight out of them with a desk or because they hadn’t wanted to fight to begin with I left alone. I stalked over to Gregory who was moaning a bit while trapped under some tables.

“You are a worthless pile of trash you know that you piece of scum? This world is not kind to people like you and neither will I be. This is strike three, I hope you find hell comfortable.”

With a quick backhanded swipe I severed his head from his body while he lay there trapped, my sword sliding through flesh and bone as easily as butter. The look of surprise permanently etched onto his face even as the blood began to spray. I went and picked up my bag, ignoring the blood coating my face and clothes as I put my weapons away and looked around one last time.

“You don’t need to worry about me coming to class. Consider this my drop out letter. I feel sick associating with closed minded pigs like all of you. Learn to grow up and learn some tolerance for people different than you.”

With that I left the room, striding down the halls until I got to the principals office. When the secretary tried to stop me I ignored her and shoved through the inner doors. The angry words on my lips died off as I saw Asala sitting on the old woman’s lap listening raptly to a story about a talking fox that could steal dreams. The principal saw me even if Asala didn’t, noting my blood splattered clothes and motioning with her eyes to clean myself up.

I understood. It wouldn’t help Asala at all to see me like this. I should have thought of that but I had been filled with too much anger and battle lust. As quick as I could I used a bit of magic to burn the blood away, returning to looking respectable by the time the story was done. I quickly told her what had happened, making sure she knew the only person I had killed had been Gregory.

“Better send the nurse up there though, Lilia won’t be able to handle it all. And I don’t care what my mother wants or her reasons for me being at this school, I’m never coming back. Take me off the records.”

“I was afraid things would turn out like this. I guess I should be grateful you did such little damage. Would it be ok if I saw this sweet little girl again before she leaves though?”

“As long as she doesn’t mind. It will do her good to see not everyone hates her because of her power. Would you like to see the old lady again Asala?”

The girl nodded her head energetically as she slid off the woman’s lap and came over to me, taking my hand when I offered it. It didn’t take long to exchange magical id’s with her for our communication spells before we were out the door and heading towards the front entrance.

“Well now, off to town for some snazzy new clothes, maybe some jewelry. A bite to eat wouldn’t hurt either. Then we will settle you in to your new home for the remainder of your stay. I’ve got a few bedtime stories I could tell you if you want. That old lady isn’t the only one who knows a few tales. Do you like the sound of all that Asala?”

She grinned up at me with a smile that seemed to give her entire face a divine glow as she nodded her head up and down. That smile and those big eyes made my heart melt, remembering a long lost feeling of being a big brother to another little girl who used to smile like that. I had a feeling it was going to be hard for me to let her go when her new master came to get her.

***********

So do you feel your choices were the correct ones? Do you think you should have done something different? Would you have handled things differently than Riktal did? If so do you think he was wrong? Such words as judgment and regret are labels you put on things after all is said and done. Just because one does not think like you or act like you would, does not make their thoughts and actions any less valid. Yet you humans seem to think in this fashion. That if it is not done the way you think it should be done then it is wrong. Immoral, barbaric, or any other number of labels you put on such things.

That was one of the reasons I gave you this power to control his life. In an attempt to learn the how’s and why’s of your minds. To figure out what it is that makes you tick. I think I have learned a bit of what I wish to know, but there is yet more I am left wanting. The window closes for now and it is your destiny to return here to my realm between realms. Perhaps next time you shall answer more of those questions for me by again playing god for young Riktal. Come again traveler, to a world made of dreams and possibilities.
11112111222111121.title: Try to reason with them

11112111222111122.content:
I let the anger show clearly on my face as I strode towards the little snitch. He was the instigator of all of this. If I let him live he would keep inciting everyone into a higher fury than was needed until they all turned into a mindless mob. With him out of the way I could hopefully talk some sense into everyone else.

He saw the anger in my eyes and backed up but it was already too late for him. With one smooth motion I grabbed the knife in the sheath at my right side with my right hand and swung it up in an arc, shoving it deep into his heart. The deft twirl to settle the handle in my palm had taken a fraction of a second while I grabbed his shoulder with my left hand and pulled him in close to me at the same time.

“Revealing my personal business to everyone else is strike three. Say hello to the devil for me.”

With a quick twist of the knife I ripped the blade out and kicked him away, turning to face the rest of the room who stared in shock. Now I needed to take command of the situation while their minds were reeling as to what had just happened. Using their fear as a controller.

“If anyone else has any objections to me taking this job feel free to speak up! A job I might add is of no concern to everyone else. I already took into consideration your safety before even accepting it. Just who the hell do you think any of you are anyway to determine if someone has a right to live or die based solely on what magic they may have! Her magic is different than ours, but what if it was you! What if you had the power to summon monsters? Would you want someone killing you no matter how nice you might be or how much you might want to help and protect?”

“This pile of garbage deserved what he got! If he had become a Hunter would you really have trusted him at your back? Would you want someone who would so easily let everyone else know about any job you did be that close to you? This is the reality of being a Hunter! You sometimes take jobs you don’t agree with, have qualms about, or are shady in nature because they will help innocent people in the long run! You want me to kill a little girl who just lost her parents! A girl who is only eleven or twelve years old without even seeing her!”

“A Hunter is only as respectable as the things he does! We aren’t always pure and clean and the shining heroes everyone thinks we are! But we hide that from the world so they can live in peace! So they can live their lives in ignorance believing nothing will ever go wrong as long as we are around! A Hunter prevents riots and supports his comrades in times of trouble and need! He does not, I repeat does not, purposefully try to incite them as this rat did! He does not go blabbing his mouth over every little thing he hears!”

“If you really want to kill that girl then expect me to slit your throat before the day is over! Because I made a promise that I would protect her no matter what! I will keep that promise or die trying! Just as I would do for any one of you if you were in that position, whether I thought you deserved it or not. She is human just like any one of you! Now do any of you have a problem with that!”

I glared around the room, my eyes burning holes into each and every person until they looked away. I made note of the ones who stared back defiantly, who still wanted me to kill the girl but were unwilling to say anything. I noticed Liz was one of those people with a bit of a sinking heart. I had begun to like her too. Without taking my eyes off them I called forth a giant ball of fire and threw it at Gregory’s corpse, turning it to dust in a matter of seconds.

“You don’t have to worry about the girl being a nuisance to you in this class, I won’t be back to school until she is gone. Perhaps I’ll never return to this school where there are so many blind bigots unworthy of the title of Hunter.”

With a flick of my wrist I imbedded the dagger into the wall next to Liz’s face before spitting in her direction.

“If I had known you were such a worthless bigot as well I would have made sure to kill you earlier. Don’t bother coming near me again. I have no need for friends like you.”

With that I backed out of the room, never taking my eyes off any of them or giving them a chance to sneak attack me when I wasn’t looking. Once back in the hall I strode quickly to the principals office without once looking back. The girl was sitting on the old woman’s lap entranced by the story of a talking fox she was telling. I didn’t interrupt as the girl giggled a bit at the funny parts, looking nothing like the lifeless thing she had been.

When the story was over she regretfully came to my side when I told her we were going to be leaving. The principal wheeled herself closer to me and put her hand on the silver head, saying she would tell her a story another time.

“If you want to keep that promise then it will be outside of the school because I’m not coming back until she is gone, if at all.”

“I figured that might be how things would end up. You didn’t hurt too many of them did you?”

“Only Gregory. Though I did leave enough ashes for his parents to have a proper funeral. People like that don’t deserve to live.”

“I figured that would be the outcome for him as well. It’s regrettable but you’re right, he would have made a horrible Hunter with actions like that. If you hadn’t killed him he would have ended up dying some other way or to someone else’s blade. Well get going, I’ll clean up the mess somehow.”

As I turned away with Asala’s hand in mine she called out to me again.

“If it isn’t too much trouble, do you think I could spend more time with the girl before she leaves?”

“I’ve got no problem with that. You can come over to my house whenever you want if that’s ok. Or we can meet out in town someplace. It will do her good to have more interactions than just me. To see that not everyone wants to hurt her because of who and what she is.”

“Thank you.”

It only took a moment to imprint her communication spell with my magical id and my spell with hers. I gave her another farewell before heading out of school with the girl in tow.

“So you like the old lady huh?”

A quick head nod and a smile that lit up her face.

“That’s good. Now lets go get you some new clothes, some food in your tummy, and get you settled into your new home. And then when you are up to it you can cry all you want over your mom and dad. Because in the end your still just a little girl who lost her family and you deserve to mourn for them.”

I saw a bit of the sorrow creep back into her face as she nodded her head in agreement and squeezed my hand. I gave her a squeeze back while we walked along in silence.

************

So do you feel your choices were the correct ones? Do you think you should have done something different? Would you have handled things differently than Riktal did? If so do you think he was wrong? Such words as judgment and regret are labels you put on things after all is said and done. Just because one does not think like you or act like you would, does not make their thoughts and actions any less valid. Yet you humans seem to think in this fashion. That if it is not done the way you think it should be done then it is wrong. Immoral, barbaric, or any other number of labels you put on such things.

That was one of the reasons I gave you this power to control his life. In an attempt to learn the how’s and why’s of your minds. To figure out what it is that makes you tick. I think I have learned a bit of what I wish to know, but there is yet more I am left wanting. The window closes for now and it is your destiny to return here to my realm between realms. Perhaps next time you shall answer more of those questions for me by again playing god for young Riktal. Come again traveler, to a world made of dreams and possibilities.
11112111222111122.title: Kill Gregory

111121112221112.content:
“Here’s fine mother. Your gorilla put me in a bad mood so I’m not too keen on dealing with you for too long. Granted I never like dealing with you anyway since you seem to know how to get my blood boiling. So I would just as soon get this over and done with so you can go off to wherever you find more important than being with your son. Unless you are too afraid that the class might overhear the fact that all is not roses and sunshine in the Zelkov household, tarnishing the family name.”

She let out a sigh while rubbing her eyes.

“I don’t remember raising you to be like this.”

“You’re right. You didn’t raise me. Now can we get on with this?”

“Fine, fine, just keep it down will you? This is sensitive Hunter business. To make it short and simple I want you to protect this little girl for the next few days. Preferably an under the table job.”

“What is she? Some dignitaries daughter?”

My mother looked both ways before leaning in and lowering her voice even further. As if afraid even this low tone would be overheard.

“Her parents were killed three days ago in front of her, causing her monster summoning powers to activate. She’s unstable right now and you are one of the few I know of who has no problems with special people like her. And one of the fewer still who could deal with any problems that might arise. Though I warn you, you will have to sustain her with magic since she refuses to eat or sleep or do anything at all. We’ve just resorted to putting a diaper on her and treating her like an infant since she will just go to the bathroom wherever and whenever.”

“That must have been your bright idea wasn’t it? Because dealing with her problems would take too much time out of your busy schedule. Heaven forbid if you actually thought of someone else for a change.”

“That’s not fair. My work really is important. More important than you know!”

“I won’t even get into the topic of fair with you right now. But you are right, I don’t know, because you in your oh so infinite wisdom haven’t decided to tell me a bloody thing.”

“It’s not like I wanted to put her in a diaper! Since she’s been sustained on magic for the last three days there is nothing in there anymore to come out. I was considering putting on some regular underwear but I didn’t want her to mess herself while we were here so erred on the side of caution.”

“You keep telling yourself that mother. Who knows, perhaps I’ll even believe you one of these days.”

She was about to say something else in that hushed whisper we were using when Gregory came down the hall from the stairwell looking a bit haggard from being unconscious. He eyed the three of us but didn’t say anything before opening the door and going into the classroom. I looked from the door to the little girl and then my mother. Pulling my glasses off and rubbing my eyes with a drawn out sigh.

“Give me proxy Hunter status at least. The Zelkov name won’t protect me from everything. And thirteen thousand Reul for my time and expenses.”

“Deal. But I also want you to keep going to classes.”

“What! It’s going to be hard enough protecting her and keeping anything she might summon on the down low. What if she summons something here in the school? I might have no problems with summoners but the same can’t be said for most other people!”

“I believe you can handle it. I have faith in you.”

“Yet not enough faith to let me take the Hunter Exams huh?”

“Please Riktal darling, this is important. Your great with kids. You have a knack with them. And you continuing to go to school is also important.”

“There is no one else? No one at all?”

“Well there is Pelei, but he isn’t a guaranteed yes and you know how he is to begin with. I know you don’t think much of me and I’ll admit I am horrible around kids. But even I realize how iffy leaving her with Pelei would be. Please darling, I swear I’ll tell you everything eventually, but not right now.”

I was beginning to get a headache as I shoved down the anger rising up inside. This always happened when I dealt with my mother. Just being in her presence could get me hot under the collar. But I had to keep in mind I was a Hunter. Even if I didn’t have my license. I needed to do what was best for the girl, not for myself. The question was, what was best for the girl? The obvious answer was to protect her. But was I the best one for that job and more to the point, did she want to be protected? Kneeling in front of the girl I stared into her crimson eyes. I didn’t see any intelligence in them but I knew she could see and hear what was going on.

“What’s her name?”

“Asala.”

“Well Asala, I know you can hear me. You might have everyone else fooled but not me. So I am going to let you decide what is going to happen to you. I’ll freely admit that Pelei is more experienced than I am. He has about twenty more years under his belt than I do. And he is an A class Hunter just like I am, or I should say as I should be. But he has this little quirk, he likes to dress pretty things up. He has an entire room filled with dolls and such he dresses up all the time. Personally I think it is creepy, but to each his own. If you go to Pelei he will dress you up like one of his dolls. He will put makeup on you and treat you well.”

“But he won’t really care about you or your problems. He will probably keep you locked up in his house until you leave, playing dress up all day long. Nothing will change from how things stand right now. The way you feel and act, it will all stay the same. He will continue to sustain you with magic and your body will slowly eat itself up from the inside until you whither away and die as nothing but a shell. I think a part of you want’s that. A part of you wants to die because you think you have nothing left.”

“But I won’t let you get away with any of that stuff. If you come with me, I will force you to eat and sleep properly, I will dress you up in clothes that you like and you pick out. You will be required to answer simple yes and no questions with a nod or shake of your head. I will treat you like an eleven year old girl instead of as a doll or a baby. I won’t blame you for anything you do that isn’t under your own control or tell you not to feel sad for your parents. I will in fact require that you grieve for them. I will hold you and comfort you as you cry for them and I will let you do so as often as you want.”

“But I won’t lie. If you chose to come with me you will be in slightly more danger than if you go to Pelei. I will protect you until my dying breath just like he would though. He will only offer you the death you seek, I offer you the chance at a life. So my question to you is, which of those is more important to you right now? I will count to ten, if you want to come with me then take my hand, otherwise do nothing and my mother can take you to Pelei.”

I held out my hand palm up, making sure to lock my gaze with hers.

“One. Two. Three.”

“I counted slowly, giving her a limited amount of time to respond. When faced with a difficult decision like this with only a short amount of time the mind would invariably answer with the greatest desire even if the person themselves didn’t know what to do. It based its answers and responses in this manner on prior experience, personality, environment, and many other factors that made each person unique. If her desire to die was greater than her desire to live, it wasn’t my place to deny her. Well intentioned kindness could do more harm than good. People seemed to think everyone had to live no matter what, but the truth was they didn’t. That was only other people shoving their views and values onto someone else. For all I knew, she needed to go to the brink of death to appreciate life or learn to control her powers. If I forced her to live now it might stunt that growth.

When I got to nine she slowly lifted her hand and put it in my waiting one with a small shudder of fear. I grinned at her as I pulled her in close to stroke her hair.

“Asala, that might have been the most important decision of your life. I honestly can’t tell you if it was the right one or not, only time will answer that. But it was your choice and it was the one that you decided you could make without regret. That shows that you’re a brave little girl.”

The bell rang signaling the end of period and I looked over at the door and then at the girl before looking up at my mother. My eyes were drawn back to the girl who was still shaking slightly while clutching her teddy bear so hard I was surprised the stuffing didn’t explode from it.
111121112221112.title: Here is fine

1111211122211121.content:
“Come on Asala, let’s get out of here. I know my mother want’s me to keep going to class, but that can start tomorrow. I can see you barely trust me and you’re scared. Going to class right now might be worse for you in the long run so I’m not going to chance it.”

The door opened and the teacher came out, gaving us both a nod before heading off down the hallway. As I stood up with Asala’s hand in mine and started down the corridor after him I noticed the door creaking open and inquisitive eyes peeking out at us. Yes this definitely was the right call. My mother came trotting after me as we left the prying eyes and ears behind.

“Darling, Are you sure about this?”

“Yes mother I am sure. You thought I was good enough to protect this girl and that is what I am doing. She doesn’t need to be thrown into that den of wolves right now. In her state of mind it is entirely possible she could summon something without meaning to, putting the class and her in danger. I can avoid that outcome by simply skipping out an hour and spending this day with her so she becomes comfortable around me and believes in the fact that I won’t let any harm come to her.”

“Riktal darling. Do you think… would you mind if I tagged along with you for a while?”

“What, get an attack of motherly affection all of a sudden? My words actually get to you? Don’t you have someplace important to be that’s not here? Actually don’t bother answering any of those. You’ll probably give me one of your stock replies like I have my reasons and then lock your lips on actually giving me those reasons.”

She closed her mouth on the reply she was going to make and gave me a look of such sadness that if it had been anyone other than my mother I would have thought it was real. But she was fake from beginning to end. The only person she cared about was herself. Such looks were only meant to deceive and get what she wanted. I gave a disgusted tsk, refraining from spitting on the floor.

“Do whatever you want. You always do anyway. I don’t know why you even bothered asking. If I had said no you would still follow me around.”

She gave me a small smile which I ignored while heading down the stairs to the first floor. I could hear her on the spell with my father saying he didn’t need to pick her up at the school. I was actually surprised she had enough thought and consideration to tell him that much. As we left the front doors a thought struck me.

“Wait, father is back in town? I thought he wasn’t going to be done with that Sandworm infestation for another day or two.”

“Seems he was able to wrap that up earlier than he expected. He agreed to help me on my job in Bornica when I found out.”

With a grunt I headed down the sidewalk into town, my mother trailing along behind me. I decided it would just be best to ignore her, my attention needed to be on the girl right now. Hitching my duffle bag higher on my left shoulder I gave her hand a small squeeze.

“So Asala. Time for a few of those simple yes and no questions I was telling you about. You don’t have to answer if you don’t want to, but then I might have to let my mother pick things out for you. Just between you and me, if that happens you will probably end up with clothes that are uglier than what you are wearing right now. So question one, do you like the color blue and red?”

She nodded her head slowly as if unsure what I was getting at.

“Good because our first order of business will be to buy you some new underwear and then snag a few pretty dresses. I know a place with a really nice set of light blue and light red ones that I think you will love. Unless you prefer pants and shirts over dresses? I know a bunch of girls do.”

She shook her head no, letting me know she liked dresses and I smiled at her again.

“Obviously if you are getting a few new dresses you are going to need some new socks and shoes. Judging by the ones on your feet right now they might not last much longer. Do you have some attachment to them? Like to your teddy bear?”

Another negative shake of the head as I noticed some of the tension draining out of her body. My conversation was mainly meant to calm her down and make her lose her fear of me. It helped force her mind off all the crap she had dealt with so far as she dealt with what I was saying. If I let her just mull over what was in her head she would lock up again, wanting to crawl back into her little shell.

After about six or seven minutes we walked into a clothing store and headed straight for the undergarments. I ignored the shop ladies as I held out a pair of black panties trimmed with lace.

“What do you think? This something you like?”

Her head went back and forth so fast I thought it might detach from her neck. Holding up a pair striped with every color of the rainbow I made a grimace while sticking out my tongue at her.

“I really hope this isn’t your thing. I’m surprised they don’t scare your dress white.”

She also crinkled her nose at the pair I was holding before blushing a bit and looking away.

“Ah I know! Your embarrassed to pick them out with me here aren’t you? I bet you already have your eyes on a few you like but don’t want me to see. Am I right?”

She blushed even redder but nodded her head at my words. With a grin I squatted in front of her so she could look into my face.

“Seems you are a girl like any other after all if you are embarrassed by letting me see your underwear. Well then tell you what. How about I turn around and cover my eyes. You pick what you want and hide them so I can’t see. Then you can go up to the register and pay for them with the money I give you. Will that make you feel better?”

I could see her eyes go up to the side as she thought about it before finally nodding her head. I made a show of standing up, closing my eyes and turning around while covering them with my hands. I made sure to crack my eye open and watch her between my fingers through one of the mirrors though. Even if my mother was here it was my job to protect her, taking my eyes off her was a big no-no, no matter what the circumstances. I watched as she picked out a few pairs with teddy bear prints on them and hid them behind her stuffed animal before poking me in the back.

Turning back around I let my hands drop and opened my eyes before pulling out a thousand Reul bill to hand to her. She took the money and trotted over to the counter while I stayed where I was. The clerk who had witnessed our interaction simply rang her up and took the money, making sure to wrap them and put them in a bag so I couldn’t see. As Asala turned around she glanced up and gave me a smile and a wink of knowing.

We spent a few hours more in the store as she tried on different clothes and began to loosen up more and more. Even though that sorrow was still lurking in the shadows of her face, she was smiling and giggling more at least. I could tell she enjoyed trying on the dresses and looking at herself in the mirror. I even gave a few catcalls and generally made a fool of myself but was rewarded with her blushing and hiding her face in her hands.

My mother kept her distance, not interfering with how I was doing things and simply fading into the background with a thoughtful look on her face. I had no clue what she was thinking or why she had wanted to come, perhaps she actually wanted to learn a thing or two about dealing with children. Though if that was the case I would have to go see if hell had frozen over.

As I was paying for the four bags of stuff we had bought ranging from clothes, to her own toothbrush and toothpaste, I spied a gold necklace with a bear dangling from it. I pointed at it when Asala wasn’t looking and the clerk grinned conspiratorially, placing it on my bill and handing it to me when the girl turned away. Back out on the street I tapped Asala on the shoulder while the necklace dangled from my fingers.

She turned to see the jewelry staring her in the face, her eyes going as big and round as saucers while she followed the slight sway entranced. Carefully I unclasped it and hung it around her neck, giving her forehead a small kiss and her hair a ruffle as I knelt there on the sidewalk.

“So you can remember this day and remember me when you leave. Times will be hard, and you are going to feel like nothing is going right. But I want you to remember that things will get better. That you can always find a bit of joy even in the saddest times. You felt happy today. And it helped push your grief to the side for a little bit. But that doesn’t mean that grief isn’t still there or you aren’t allowed to feel both things at the same time. I’m sure that’s a bit hard for you to understand right now, but you remember that. You are allowed to grieve when you need to and are allowed to feel happy when happy things happen without thinking you are doing something wrong.”

She threw her arms around my neck and began to cry. Whether they were tears of joy or sadness I wasn’t sure. Perhaps a bit of both. I simply rubbed her back and spoke softly that it would be all right.

Her tears didn’t last long as she pushed herself away and sniffed, offering me a small smile as she rubbed her nose. I wondered if I had pushed her far enough for one day, both emotionally and with the crowds here in town.
1111211122211121.title: Leave early

11112111222111211.content:
“Come on Asala, time to get some real food in you. I expect you to eat and enjoy it as well. Eat so much that your tummy feels like it’s going to explode. And then I’ll make sure we get some ice cream for desert. You like banana splits?”

As she wiped her nose with the back of her hand again she nodded her head yes. She reached for my hand before I had a chance to offer it, making me juggle the bags a moment to free up my left for her to take. I took her to a quiet diner across from the bank that served breakfast anytime. It didn’t take long for her to point out what she wanted and slip off to the bathroom with a pair of her new panties while we waited. I kept an eye on the restroom door from my seat. Now that I had gotten this far I needed to give her enough room of her own while being close enough for her if she needed me. If I smothered her too much I might mess up all the work I had done so far.

She came back a few minutes later looking much more confident in herself. I suppose not wearing a diaper and being treated like a real person would have that affect on most people. The food came surprisingly quickly and Asala dug into her scrambled eggs while I stabbed a sausage link. My mother was still quietly observing us even as she ate her Talbar steak and potatoes. Her silence was actually beginning to unnerve me. I had never actually been around my mother for this long without wanting to choke the life out of her. Or ending up in a giant argument. I couldn’t remember the last time I actually kind of enjoyed being around my mother.

Alarm bells went off at the bank across the street just as the clock towers chimed half past five. A masked man cam out with a bag stuffed with money in one hand and shooting back into the building with the other. At least I assumed it was money since it was a bank. As he turned right and began sprinting down the street my mother began to get up to go chase after him.

“Don’t bother, he won’t get far.”

“How do you know?”

“He went straight. He’s going to run into Freddy and get taken down.”

I pointed at a magic bakery down the road where an old man in his early fifties sporting a wooden peg for a left leg was opening the door. Even from here I could see the magical dust speckling his apron mixed with flower. His brown and grey head turned just as the robber raised his weapon. He bent over as if he was simply putting his box of bread and confectionaries on the ground just as the gun went off. Some might have called it luck, but it had been deliberate and calculated. The bullet whizzed harmlessly over him as the robber ran into his head before he could stop himself. Freddy reached up and grabbed the arm with the gun even as he stood back up, lifting the man off his feet and twisting in a half circle as the body fell.

When the robber slammed into the ground he bounced a bit, only to be met by Freddy’s right shoe to the chest. After that the robber lay still. As the police came running up Freddy let go of the man and picked up his box of bread heading to the alley next to his store where a bunch of homeless people were already gathering to receive the meager food. The police thanked the backer and he gave them a wave without looking even as they cuffed the thief and hauled him away. My mother looked at me with a bit of surprise.

“How’d you know he was going to come out right then?”

“He comes out every day at five thirty to give what’s left over of his morning bread to the homeless and needy.”

“He’s a Hunter isn’t he?”

“Ex-Hunter. Aside from the leg he has a bad shoulder that keeps him from fully using his left arm and his ability to touch his magic is weak. He fought a Jikrim and it ate most of his magic along with his leg. Though what he does have he uses to make some of the best magical foods and pastries I have ever tasted. He came up with a way to turn magical potions into dust and mixes it with his other ingredients, turns the food into artifact like creations. Said he wanted to find a way to continue to help Hunter’s even if he can’t fight next to them.”

“You seem to know an awful lot about him.”

I shrugged as I stuffed some scrambled eggs of my own in my mouth.

“I should. I helped him open his shop. Fronted him the money and even funded the initial stocking of supplies.”

“Where’d you get that kind of money! I know you don’t get that much living allowance!”

Again I gave her another shrug as I watched the homeless people thanking Freddy like they always did. For some that was the only real food they got all day. Most of the soup kitchens around the city were small and not well funded so they couldn’t always get fed from one of them.

“Gambling. Big sis taught me the basics and I learned the finer arts of it from some of the best card sharks around. I won’t say I didn’t learn slight of hand and other cheating tactics from them either. Gambled some of my allowance and cheated some crooks out of their stolen Reul’s to pay for it all. He’s still paying me back even though I told him not to worry about it. The money I took from the crooks belonged to the people anyway, it’s only right it got back into their hands somehow.”

“I don’t know if I approve of you gambling Riktal darling.”

“Approve or don’t it won’t stop me from doing it if I need to. Besides, I mainly learned to begin with so I knew what to watch out for so I didn’t get cheated myself. You know what they say, it takes a thief to know a thief. Isn’t part of the Hunter code to assist other Hunter’s in need? Two years ago he was just another homeless on the street. Back then he saved my life. Got into a bit of a rumble with a few other Hunter’s and they were better then I had first thought they were. Four A class and at the time I was only a B. I had thought they were three C’s and a D to my detriment. He happened to be sleeping in the alley they had chased me into and he fought at my back. It’s only natural that I repaid the debt to him.”

“Why didn’t I know about this!”

“There’s a lot about me you don’t know mother. Because you never bothered to find out. The last seventeen years you and father have been off on one job or another for weeks on end, come home for a few hours and then are off again for weeks or months. Just when in that busy schedule of yours did you ever have time for me? So I grew up without you. You think I stay home all day all the time? I learned a lot about the shady side of life, and the many injustices in this world. I’ve made a name for myself around here with many of the Hunter’s and the shopkeepers. Just about every restaurant knows my face by now. And they already consider me a Hunter even if I don’t have a license, contracting me for odd jobs and the like. It‘s not like you ever really cared to know me to begin with.”

“Oh Riktal darling! That’s not true! I admit I’ve been busy, and I haven’t been the best mother but I do care about you! I worry about you all the time!”

“And yet never once do you seem to show it. When was the last time you dealt with me as your son and not as some Hunter you want something from? True or not the facts are still the facts, you were never there in any meaningful way that didn’t involve me training to be a Hunter. But that’s fine, I’ve gotten used to it. I’ve ceased to worry about what you think of me or if you care for me or not. Because the fact is I know you don’t no matter what you might say otherwise. You lie and manipulate to achieve your own ends and your own goals.

“Using everyone, even your own son ruthlessly to get what you want. You care about one person and that is Marian Zelkov, everyone else can just go to hell. Your tears and sad eyes and all those other emotions you show in face and voice are just there to make people do what you want. That is the truth of things as I see it mother. My thoughts and actions are simply the product of the life you gave me.”

A small tug on my tunic made me look over at Asala who was looking up at me with those big round eyes of hers. She clenched the necklace in her hand a moment before blinking at me slowly.

“At least you still got your momma.”

Her voice was soft and light, just a bare whisper of sound, but after those few words she began to cry and I held her for a few moments until she pulled herself together. I wouldn’t tell the girl that her words didn’t mean much to me. She had thought they were important and perhaps to someone else they would have been, but for me that wasn’t enough. I hated to admit to myself that I still cared about my parents, even though they were barely more than titles. Even I didn’t know why I still loved them even a little bit.

“I’m sorry Riktal.”

“You’re always sorry. Yet it never changes anything now does it? I think you’ve overstayed your welcome. I’ll pick up the tab so you go do whatever it is you need to do. I can take Asala home by myself.”

I turned my gaze away and out the window again, dismissing her even as she opened her mouth to say something. But instead of words she closed her mouth as a few tears rolled down her cheek before she got up and left quietly. Asala put her hand on my arm as if to console me, even as I wrapped my arm around her for comfort. We sat there like that in silence as I watched my father eventually pull up in the car and pick my mother up.

“Ready for dessert Asala?”

***********

Come again traveler. Time has no meaning here in my domain, and so you can once again relive this day with young Riktal. Choose a different path, find different answers and learn different questions. Will you make choices based on the information you know now? Or will you not let it taint your decisions? It will be interesting to see the answer to that question.
11112111222111211.title: Eat in town

11112111222111212.content:
“You know, I don’t know about you but I’m a bit tired of running around town like this. So what do you say we go back home and I cook you up something good huh? A bit of home cooked food might be just what your belly needs right now. I think I got some chocolate ice cream in the fridge as well for dessert. Throw on a couple banana slices, a little syrup and you got yourself one tasty dish sure to give your sweet tooth the satisfaction it craves. Does that sound good to you?”

She nodded her head, wiping her nose again on the back of her hand before grinning at me like a fool. I gave her hair another ruffle as I stood up, having to juggle the bags in my hand to take hers when she reached for mine. As we walked back home I inquired as to her likes and dislikes food wise. Thankfully she didn’t seem to be a picky eater, liking just about everything I asked. When we got back to the house and I dropped my bags I whispered that she should get changed and I wouldn’t peek, giving her a wink which she blushed at before giggling.

As I headed towards the kitchen I saw her digging into the bags of clothes I had set down in the hall. Soon enough I heard the patter of feet running up the stairs while I dug into the fridge for all the ingredients I would need for an old fashioned stir fry. My mother sat down at the kitchen table to watch me as I quickly and expertly cleaned the vegetables before cutting them up.

“I didn’t know you could cook.”

“What? Did you think I ate out every single day? Do you have any idea how much free time I have on my hands living here all alone? There’s only so much sparring I can do with practice dummies or running around exploring the town. Sometimes I go outside the shield to do some monster slaying for an odd job or two, but I see no point in slaying for slayings sake. There are people out there who make a living off those monster drops, I wouldn’t want to take that from them.”

“I never knew.”

“No you never cared to know did you?”

I clamped my mouth down on anything else I might have said. I was in a good mood, and I didn’t need to ruin it by getting into yet another fight with my mother. It had actually been nice, spending so much time with her and not wanting to smash a club into her face. For a little while I had thought she had actually cared about me. I had forgotten about what a terrible person she really was.

Asala came into the room just as I was throwing some cut strips of beef into the pan to cook in the oil along with the rest of the ingredients. She wore a light purple dress with a bit of white lining along the hem and some butterflies embroidered in the fabric as well. She did a small twirl as I whistled appreciatively.

“Feeling like a real girl again Asala?”

She bobbed her head as she sat at the table to watch me as well.

“It makes you feel good knowing that those clothes are yours doesn’t it? That you are going to be able to take all that stuff with you.”

Again a quick bob of the head and a grin from ear to ear.

“By the way, where is your teddy bear? You didn’t leave him all alone upstairs did you?”

With a giggle she pulled back a flap on the front I hadn’t even noticed when we had bought it to show the bear nestled in its own little sling. When she closed it back up again I couldn’t even tell there was a bulge.

“Well I’ll be! No wonder that one was so expensive! I didn’t even realize it had its own personal mini space! That’s a nice spot for him too. Keeps him nice and safe and there whenever you want him.”

Again a rapid movement of her head up and down. If she nodded it any harder her head might come off. When I asked if she was afraid because she wasn’t holding it she shook her head no while pointing at me. I raised my eyebrow as I slid some stir-fry onto three plates and handed them out before grabbing three cups of water.

“Well I can’t guarantee I’m as soft and squishy as your bear, but you can squeeze me all you want if that helps.”

I was about to dig in when my lunch with Lilia popped into my head. I set down my fork and clasped my hands. Asala saw what I was doing and nodded as if she agreed, clasping hers as well. We both looked at my mother waiting until she finally folded her fingers together. I said a quick grace and then resumed eating. I made a bit of small talk, telling a few funny stories and making funny faces to make the little girl laugh and feel more at ease. Now that I had brought her this far I had to juggle giving her freedom and staying close enough so she knew I was there if he needed me. I had built the trust, now I had to build a bit of self confidence and self empowerment in her. That would help her with her powers more than anything else right now.

After dinner and the promised chocolate ice cream Asala ran upstairs to take a bath while I cleaned up the dishes. I saw my mother looking at me thoughtfully from her seat at the table.

“You really are amazing with her you know.”

“I know. Isn’t that why you wanted me in the first place?”

“Yes it is. But honestly I didn’t think you would be this good. Most of my information was second hand from your father and sister.”

I locked down the retort I was going to make. Reminding myself not to get dragged into her false sincerity and nice words. I had let myself do that too many times and gotten burned because of it. I could see she wanted to say more but didn’t for whatever reason. That was fine, if she didn’t talk I wouldn’t get angry.

Finished with my cleaning I dried my hands and went into the living room, flicking the TV onto a random cartoon for when Asala came back downstairs. She did so not long after I settled myself onto the couch and my mother in a nearby chair. She wore her new pajamas this time and was toting around her bear in her left hand again. Without hesitation she slid onto the couch next to me and into the crook of my arm while I absently stroked her hair. After only a few minutes her breathing told me she was asleep.

“Riktal. Do you know why I wanted to follow you today?”

“Not the foggiest idea. Probably just one of your whims or to try and get something more out of me to further your own ends.”

“Well I guess in a way you are right. I wanted to learn how to be a better mother. Sadly you seem to be better at it then I ever was. It’s never too late to learn a few new things right? Even if it is your own son that has to teach them to you.”

“And what good does it do you now? I don’t see you going off and finding little kids to be motherly too all that often. Big sis his grown and moved out. And as for me…”

“As for you, you are a man already. You grew up without me ever realizing it. I wasn’t a big part of your life, I know that. I put work ahead of everything else. Added on top of not knowing how to deal with all the crying and screaming and constant need for attention, I found it easier to just not deal with it period. I made mistakes where you were concerned, a lot of them. Just like I made a lot of mistakes where Olia was concerned.

“Don’t for one minute think I don’t regret so many things as a mother. Perhaps if I had been more like you Olia would never have died. No. I know she would never have died. All it would have taken was a little bit of attention, but I was so wrapped up in my own problems and my own little world. I beat myself up all the time over all the things I realize now I should have done, or could have done better. I can’t change the past, no matter how much I wish. But that doesn’t mean I can’t change the future.”

She played with her hands a moment, looking down into her lap as if searching for words she found difficult to say in their depths.

“Your father and I… We decided we are going to quit being Hunter’s soon. Or at least, take a very long vacation from it. We weren’t quite sure how to tell you because there never seemed to be a good time when we could talk like this without fighting. It wasn’t an easy decision for us to make but we both agreed it would be for the best if we were going to have another baby.

“We both want to be there for him or her like we failed to be there for you. And we’d like it if you were able to help us. We know we aren’t going to be good at it at first. We are going to mess up and want to slip back into our old habits. We will be at a loss as to what to do or how to act. But you have that knack with kids that we don’t. You practically raised Olia on your own and I know she thought the world of you. That was something I was always jealous of.

“Your right, today was a bit of a whim. But something told me to put off my trip for just a little while. That this would be a great chance for me to see first hand everything I lack as a mother. To see what it is I can do different. I’m glad I got the chance to spend this time with you. It made me feel like I was actually part of your life for the first time. It made me think I could really change that part of me. I wanted what you were so easily able to obtain with that little girl in one short day that I couldn’t get a fraction of in three days. I really am sorry Riktal. Sorry for not being a part of your life, for not being a better mother, for letting Olia die. I’m sorry for just being me.”

She covered her face with her hands to hide her tears from me. The water still flowing between her fingers to drip into her lap.
11112111222111212.title: Eat at home

111121112221112121.content:
I stared at her for a long time in silence. Part of my mind wanted to believe her while the other part kept telling me not to get sucked into her lies. I didn’t know why she would lie about this but there had to be a reason. She always had reasons for everything that made sense to her and the way she wanted the world to be. Still that small voice kept nagging me saying what if. What if this time she wasn’t lying. What if this time she really meant what she was saying and she really wanted to change?

Stroking Asala’s hair a little longer while my mother continued to cry I fought that fierce internal battle until I was ready to open my mouth.

“It was actually nice. Spending the day with you and not getting into any arguments. Knowing you were there even if you were just in the background. And having Asala next to me made me feel like a big brother again. It felt like we were actually a family.”

My soft words made my mother look up at me in surprise. As if she didn’t expect me to answer so positively if at all. Looking down at the girl sleeping at my side I felt my lips playing up in a smile.

“You’re right. There is no way to change the past. Change the mistakes we made. No one is perfect or able to make all the right choices. Sometimes we don’t even know what the right choices are or even what the choices are to begin with. But as long as you live you can change as long as you are willing to change. And as long as you live you can forgive, both yourself and others.

“I’m not so noble as to be able to forgive you so easily. I’m not the best son and I have my own faults as well. I’ll continue to get angry at you and blow up. I still have a short temper and will probably make my own share of mistakes. But if you really want to give this a shot I’m willing to try.”

“Oh Riktal! Thank you!”

I held up my hand before she could start gushing out more thanks or tears.

“Only on two conditions. The first is that I will take that baby and run off, hiding myself so you will never find us if you do slip back into your old habits. I will not let that baby grow up the way I did.”

“Agreed. We really do want to make this work honey. What’s the second condition?”

“You stop with all the marriage meetings. It is a stupid outdated tradition that only promotes inbreeding of the older houses. In my opinion it is part of the problem with the old houses thinking they are somehow elite and that mindset gets passed on to everyone else. Yes we might be better in combat than most of the other houses because we have had more years to refine training techniques and secret arts to pass down, but we are still Hunter’s like anyone else.”

“Will you at least go to just one more? I promise I will stop but I set this one up for next week and it would be rude to cancel so suddenly.”

“No I never liked them to begin with. Cancel and be rude.”

“Ok but Mrs. Hawthrope will be devastated.”

I began to chuckle from the belly. The chuckle slowly built until I was muffling the laughter to keep from waking Asala.

“I don’t see what’s so funny darling.”

“Is the girl’s name Liz Hawthrope?”

“Yes. How did you know?”

“She’s in my class. She told me she had a meeting next week but didn’t know who. I told her the guy was probably ugly as sin among other things. I didn’t know it was with me! I’ll let her know tomorrow and you can cancel it without being rude to her mother. Say we already met and it won’t work out.”

My mother began to chuckle too at the irony of it all before getting a slightly more serious look on her face.

“So do you like her?”

“Romantically? No. But I do like her as a friend. Or at least I get the feeling I could like her as a friend. I still don’t know her all that well. We really do have a lot in common so it makes it easy to identify with her. If it turns into something more, then it does. I’m not going to force something that isn’t there.”

“You really are a man grown now aren’t you? Able to talk about such things so easily. I really did miss out on a lot. I guess I should stop treating me like a child .”

I saw her eyes misting up again as she looked at the girl sleeping at my side with such longing.

“I don’t mind, as long as you don’t go overboard. The kicker to all of this is I still love you and father even though you were horrible parents. It might be just a small grain but it’s there and it can grow.”

The smile that grew on her face was one untainted by any hidden agenda, seeming to make her five years younger. With a bit of sudden inspiration I told her to sit on the other side of the couch. When she did so I rolled Asala’s head gently over onto her lap. She looked like a deer caught in the headlights as her body stiffened up and her arm went into the air. gently I brought her arm down to rest on the girls head as I knelt on the floor in front of Asala’s face. I softly sang a lullaby to the sleeping girl, one I had sung to Olia countless times to get her to go to sleep. Even though my voice was pretty bad Olia had always wanted to hear me sing. I was rewarded by her snuggling a bit into my mothers lap and whispering one word.

“Momma.”

The look that came to my mothers face was priceless as I told her to wait right there. She held out her hand as I snuck out of the room and upstairs to my own. Digging in my closet I pulled out a stuffed blue rabbit missing an eye and an old shoebox of photo’s. By the time I got back down stairs my mother was hesitantly stroking the little girls hair like I had done with a faraway look in her face. Handing her the shoebox she looked inside curiously, gasping at all the photos of Olia.

“I spent a lot of magic saving these few pictures and a bunch of stuffed animals from the fire. I’ve kept them hidden because I thought you didn’t want anything to remind you of her. This is Mr. Snuggles, her favorite animal of all of them.”

I handed the rabbit over to her as she shifted through the photos and began crying all over again.

“I didn’t want any reminders of her at first. It was just too hard to handle. And then I regretted it ever since. I never thought I would ever see her face again.”

Sitting back down on the other end of the couch I looked at my lap while squeezing my hands together. This next part was going to be hard.

“Mother. What do you think of people with special powers in general? I already know your stance on monster summoners, you tolerate them but you don’t really like them. But what about others?”

“Well I really don’t know. I’ve not met many of them in my time. Most of the ones with what might be called cursed blood don’t usually advertise their existence. I know most people hate them simply because they are different. And the few I have met really aren’t that bad. I guess if I had to say I can tolerate them until they prove otherwise.”

“And if I had cursed blood?”

I felt her gaze on me as her voice softened.

“Do you?”

“Have you ever heard of Imprinters?”

***********

Another day comes to a close and so many questions and answers. What is it with you humans always wanting to know? Always seeking for some answer or another. Is that why you make the choices you do? To pursue the answers you seek? Or do you make choices in order to create more questions? Perhaps these are one and the same. I have learned a bit in my time observing you as you utilized this power of god. Yet I find myself still wanting more. My desires have not yet been completely fulfilled.

So it seems I am not unlike you at all in the end. I myself pursue answers in my own fashion and have made the choice to bring you here and gift you with a gods power. You shall come again will you not? Relive this day making different, perhaps better choices and learning more in your quest for the ultimate truths. Though I ask if you will come again as if you have a choice.
111121112221112121.title: Answer her

1111211122211122.content:
“Well I might as well introduce you to the class now. Just stay close to me and everything will turn out fine. I won’t let anyone hurt you or get too close to you ok? After school we will go out shopping and get something to eat.”

I looked at my mother as I stood up, barely suppressing some of the words I really wanted to say.

“Well you got what you came for. Go off and do whatever it is you find more important. I’m sure your next job will keep you away for another week or two this time as well. So no need to say anything redundant like don’t set a plate out for me tonight because I never do. I’m surprised you even remember where our house is most of the time.”

The door opened and the History teacher walked out, giving us a nod before going on his way. His appearance made my mother shut her mouth on whatever she was going to say in response to my words. Before he got out of earshot and she could say something I gave her a slight nod of my head mockingly and entered the room he had just vacated. All eyes turned towards me, or more precisely, on the little girl who was clutching at my pant legs and trying to hide behind them.

“Oh my god she is so adorable!”

“Is she your sister?”

“How old is she?”

“Why is she here?”

“What’s her name?”

Leave it to the girls to go gushing over her right off the bat and asking such invasive questions. What was it about cute things, babies, and animals that turned them into such mindless idiots. Was it some sort of hidden genetic strand that activated some feminine instinct in them at the sight of such things? If that was the case why was it absent in my mother?

I shoved my way through them, sitting the girl down by the wall at my desk and grabbing a chair for myself. When the girls all began to converge like wild hyenas scenting prey I held up my hand while glaring, forcing them to stop their advance and look at me questioningly. I let my bag drop next to my chair with a loud clank to increase the ominous air I was suddenly giving off.

“Her name is Asala and she will be joining this class for a few days. I’ve been tasked with giving her around the clock protection. Due to a bunch of different circumstances I will still be attending classes and so she will be next to me. She just lost her parents and she is grieving and scared. She doesn’t need a pack of wolves like all of you going after her. I ask that you stay away and ignore her for the time being. She is not my sister and I don’t care how cute you think she is, I will not let anyone get close that she does not want close. Try me if you dare but I will not hesitate to throw any one of you out the window for her sake. This is a job, there is nothing I will not do to fulfill my end of it.”

As I shooed them away and sat next to the girl I saw eyes going to the still broken window and then to Gregory. So there were already rumors flying around about what had happened. I had thought it a bit odd no one had really commented on the window, but I guess they already knew or thought they knew what had happened. As the teacher came in and noticed the girl I gave him a quick rundown of the situation as well. He simply nodded his head and gave the class another warning to respect my wishes to keep away. I leaned over so only Asala could hear my whispered words.

“If you get scared just squeeze my hand. It’s just one hour, that’s all. I wasn’t lying when I told them I will do anything to protect you. Until you leave, you are my number one priority. Just be brave for me ok?”

She shook her head slightly to say she understood as I slipped my hand into hers. Almost immediately she squeezed it for all it was worth and I squeezed back with a smile. Her right hand was squashing the bear almost as hard as her left was squeezing mine. But she didn’t hide away inside her mind again, even listening with a bit of interest as the teacher started his lesson

“The Cawmacaw is a highly intelligent monster that can communicate with humans. It is one of the few species with the ability to do so. Although it can only make simple words and phrases since it’s beak and vocal cords are not as adaptive as our own. They are a gentle creature, more like an animal than a monster. Some theories say they mutated from a parrot while others think they were constructed using magic using a parrot or other similar bird as a base. Who can tell me what the difference between those two theories is?”

No one seemed to know the answer except me and Liz, She gave me a raised eyebrow as if asking if I wanted to answer. I shook my fist at her before throwing a scissors and she nodded. We played a quick game of rock-paper-scissors out of sight and I lost to her paper so I raised my hand.

“A mutation of an existing animal would mean it is natural. That it is simply an evolution of a parrot as humans are believed to be evolved from monkeys. Whereas if they are constructed that means they are unnatural to the order of things. That someone used a lot of magic to create something that never would have existed before by altering the parrot physically, leaving it’s ability to reproduce intact. Thereby distinguishing it from a neuter construct such as a golem that has no natural way of replicating itself.”

“I suppose I should expect nothing less from a Zelkov.”

A girl in the front raised her hand and the teacher pointed at her with a nod.

“Mr. Horris, is that why most monsters leave regular animals alone? Because they are all mutations or constructs?”

“That’s actually a good question. The fact is we aren’t one hundred percent sure of why this is so. There are cases of monsters attacking animals but they are rare. Indeed many monsters are found living in harmony with animals out in the wild, some monsters even disguising themselves as regular animals. Some of the more intelligent monsters, especially those of the humanoid family such as trolls and giants, have been known to have primitive civilizations and colonies that include such things as hunting wild game. We have been able to study these primitive settlements to get an idea of how early man might have lived. I’m sorry I couldn’t give you a better answer.”

I tuned the teacher out after that as my little game with Liz gave me the idea to play some paper and pencil games with Asala. This seemed to help keep her mind off of her surroundings and calm. I drew her a few funny faces on the papers as well, eliciting a couple small smiles that died on her lips quickly. But I could tell they hadn’t been forced so that was a start.

Before I knew it the bell rang and class was over. I gave Asala’s head a quick pet as I grinned in her direction.

“See? That wasn’t too bad now was it? Time to go have some real fun. You like blue? I think you do. You seem like a blue kind of girl. I know a nice little shop with some pretty blue dresses. And it’s close to a quiet little diner where they serve just about anything you could ever want. Their ice cream is really good too. Never met a little girl yet that didn’t like ice cream.”

As I slipped my arms into the straps of my bag and held out my right for Asala to take, a few of the girls seemed to have already forgotten my warning, heading in my direction. Liz intercepted them for me, giving me a quick wink and a head nudge telling me to get going. I mouthed the words thanks and she mouthed back that I owed her even as me and Asala left the room.

She stuck close to me as we left the front entrance and headed for the street. I noticed three boys with the air of those looking for trouble hanging around them standing by the gates. I guess even in a Hunter academy you would find bullies. They wouldn’t last long though, they would get the snot beat out of them soon enough by one or more of the people they picked on. If they didn’t get their act together they would never make it to graduation as Hunters, most likely getting killed or kicked out long before that.

As I got closer the one in the middle with an eye watering shade of neon blue hair grinned and whistled at me.

“Hey that your girlfriend? Looks a little young to me don’t you think?”

As I pass I hauled back my left fist and sucker punched him in the face. I could feel his nose breaking under my knuckles as he flew through the air to land in the street, almost getting hit by a car in the process. I didn’t even bother replying or giving him any more attention, simply turned and headed towards town. Looking down at the girl next to me I gave her another smile.

“Let’s go make you look prettier than you already are.”

The smile she bestowed upon me while tightening her fingers around my hand seemed to make even the sun dim for a moment.

**************

Truly it is amazing is it not? The way each small choice is affected by the ones before it and the ones that others make that you have no control over. How some choices seem so easy at first glance and others feel as if the weight of the very world hangs in the balance. Choices made off of small body cues, whether they be real or imagined, and choices made out of personal preference.

What was the thoughts behind the choices you made? Were you influenced by the way Riktal saw the world? Or by the way you personally view things? Did you make choices as to what you would do in the same situation? Or for entirely different reasons? It has been entertaining to observe you, though your time here draws to a close. Come again and I shall again bestow upon you the power of choice. The power to alter destiny. To redo or undo the mistakes you felt you might have made. Just remember, unlike in this world between worlds, you cannot remake the choices in your own life.
1111211122211122.title: Finish the school day

11112111222112.content:
I took a seat next to Lilia on the bench between her and the girl named Marsa. The other three seemed to give Lilia a bit of space making it easy to find a spot. I wasn’t even sure why I sat down here instead of up in the bleachers, perhaps it was some strange connection between me and Lilia. I felt awkward sitting down here with these people I barely knew. Granted I barely knew Liz as well, but at least I was able to understand her.

“Hey uh, Zelkov?”

“Call me Riktal.”

Marsa smiled at me tentatively as if not sure of the proper response. I could see she had gained a bit of awe for me after witnessing my skill, that was why she was acting a bit hesitant.

“Um, Riktal. What was that thing you did with your gun? You said something about phase two and then it just sort of morphed.”

Pulling my Lexington out of my belt I noticed the others watching as well. Carefully I made sure to unload it before anything else since this was going to be demonstration.

“You all know about artifact weapons having heart crystals inside of them right? And how those crystals store magical energy.”

When they all nodded I continued.

“Well higher grade artifacts with these crystals inside have up to three phases. This is the default phase or phase one. It is basically just a weapon. Those stock swords and shields you use are phase one, so is your templar shield Jethic. Phase two refers to pulling out some of that stored magic and turning the weapon into something else that is still basically the same thing, just used for different purposes.”

Quickly I detached the top barrel and held both parts out for them to see before placing the single shaft on the back of my forearm with my palm up so they could see the magic taking place to create the button.

“Each weapon has a different action when going into phase two, obviously a sword would have attributes pertaining to its nature, such as multiplying one blade into two, or altering its weight to make it faster or sharper. For this weapon in particular, the magic creates two palm triggers I can manipulate. As you saw the single shaft also gained the ability to eat magic similar to the Glif. That’s because the heart crystal used to create this weapon came from a Glif.

“That brings me to the next point. The attributes a weapon can gain from a heart crystal is dependant on the monster that crystal came from. Some crystals are more suited to certain weapons than others. This Glif crystal can be put into say a sword or a shield and also be able to absorb magical attacks, but its effectiveness in returning that magic might not be so great, or the multiple ways to return it might be limited. In the case of this gun, I made the flamethrower but I could have also shot bullets of fire or a big fireball. You also saw how I created an explosive shot by combining the rest of the fire magic with a bullet. That is because the crystal is well suited to this weapon.”

I saw them nodding their head in understanding before looking out over the arena at the different weapons. There was real interest in their eyes, not looks of greed or dreams of power. They wanted to learn this stuff. They had realized this is what they were training for and this too was part of being a Hunter.

“You would probably learn about this later on, perhaps next year after you get the basics down and you are strong enough to handle a second phase. Make no mistake, you need to have a mental and physical strength to use a second phase. The more powerful the weapon the more skill you need to wield it. If you don’t have that internal strength the weapon can eat you alive. Most reasonably priced and medium level weapons only go up to phase two, but there is also a third phase to any higher grade weapon such as this Lexington.

“The thing is, that third phase is usually a last resort kind of deal. Because it draws out and imbues you with the powers of the heart crystal, allowing you to take on the attributes of the beast it came from. Since you are unleashing all the raw magic from the crystal you are able to form and shape it to your will to make your weapon do just about anything you wish it to. This is a sort of overdrive mode that puts a tremendous strain on your body and will usually break the weapon once it is over. In the case of this gun, if I went into phase three I could become a Glif. Able to eat magic at will and counter every attack thrown at me.”

Quietly I reattached the barrel to the top of the weapon, returning it to it’s phase one state. Daniel was the first one to ask anything, a bit of tentativeness in his voice.

“If it puts a strain on the body, is their anything we can do for the person afterwards? Or is there anything we can do as a sort of safety measure to minimize what happens beforehand?”

“Your thinking, I like that. If they are weakened the only thing you can do is give them a bit of your own magic or try to get some food in them quickly. Most good Hunter’s can store a small bit of their magic in a sort of reserve tank so if they ever go into phase three they don’t come out looking like they are going to stop breathing any second. Learn to carry around a bit of ration bread. The fruits and nuts packed into those bars are designed to restore energy and vitality quickly. Even if you can’t handle a phase three, a lot of Hunter’s who can don’t bother carrying such things around, relying on their own skill to pull them through. But that is something you can do even now that can change the outcome of a battle or even save a life.”

On a whim I pulled out a few of the small squares of ration bread I kept in my own pouch and handed them out to the four who took them like I was handing them the key to the city itself. They carefully put the wax wrapped bundles in their own pouches with stuttered thanks.

“They will last about six months before they lose their effectiveness. I just got these the other day so you don’t need to worry about how fresh they are. There is a guy named Freddy Jang that runs a magical confectionary bakery downtown by the Fast Track Bank of Efenbis that makes some of the highest quality rations for really cheap.”

“Do you mean Sweets for Sweets? I love that place! Their bread and pastries are simply amazing! I drop by there at least once a week to treat myself.”
