Marsa began describing the bakery to the others while I sat back and listened. I still felt a bit awkward but this hadn’t been too bad. I had been able to have a real conversation with people without getting annoyed over their trivial thoughts on fashion or relationships or the hot new singers. Maybe it was because I was talking about what I knew, being a Hunter. Perhaps I really could fit into this school.

The bell rang and we all broke up to head back to our respective locker rooms. It didn’t take long to put my weapon away and shoulder my bag before heading back to the classroom. As I settled down to watch the others coming in, I noted the hero worship and awe in many eyes. Also noting the more than passing interest of many of the girls who were no doubt plotting how to make me their boyfriend.

I also didn’t miss the slight change in power as Marsa, Jethic, and Daniel had come into the room chatting with Lilia who seemed to be surprised they were giving her the time of day. The rest of the class didn’t miss this either and yet more speculation ran behind eyes. I had a feeling Lilia’s school days would not be as lonely anymore. I wasn’t sure why I was even bothering helping the girl like that or worried about her so much. Perhaps her divination had gotten to me more than I cared to admit.

The teacher came in, took attendance and then started on his History lesson. He was only about five minutes into it though when a woman with gray speckled through her raven black hair came into the room pulling a girl child clutching a tattered teddy bear. The girl was petite, not more than four and a half feet tall with hair as white as snow and eyes as scarlet as a sunset. The woman’s hazel eyes searched the room and found mine before she walked back out pulling the girl behind her.

With a sigh I picked up my duffle bag and headed for the door telling the teacher it was me the woman wanted. Nodding his head slightly I ignored the stares and the whispers as I left the room, making sure the door was closed firmly behind me. Once in the hall I gave the woman a false smile while crossing my arms in front of me.

“So what do you want mother?”

“Riktal darling, lets go someplace more private.”
11112111222112.title: Sit with Lilia and group

111121112221121.content:
“Fine. Then lead the way.”

As my mother started off down the hall pulling the girl behind her I fell into step next to her. It wasn’t a comfortable or companionable silence, more of a heavy tense one. Even though I kept telling myself not to get angry at her this time I knew that probably wasn’t going to happen. Being around her for any length of time seemed to set me off no matter what I did.

“I would have thought coming for me in person was beneath you. I’m surprised you didn’t send one of your aides to come get me.”

“Yes well I originally had told him to get you so I could talk to Val privately for a few moments. But he got a bit heated, saying he wasn’t some gofer. That if I wanted my son I could get him myself.”

As we came off the steps Gregory came down the hall to go up them holding his head and walking only slightly unsteadily. When he saw us he stared in surprise. Though mostly he stared at my mother, her being a big name Hunter and all. He gave a quick bow before slipping past us and hurrying up the steps. As my mother turned down the way he came I continued our conversation as if we had never been interrupted.

“A guy this time huh? He must not have read the fine print to well that says he is a gofer if he works for you. I bet he’s some well muscled no nonsense type who’s arms are bigger than his brain. It’s fifty-fifty for him being ex military or just a workout junkie.”

“How can you say that when you never met him?”

“Because I know your taste for men. It never hurts to look, isn’t that your motto? You pick strongmen for their muscle not their IQ.”

“Well if I’m going to have a guy around all the time what’s wrong with him being a bit good looking? Your father has a few good looking aides as well you know. But you’re right. He is big in the muscles, and a bit narrow in the brains department. Not ex-military though, but he comes from a military family. He’s not working out quite like I had hoped though.”

“So toss him like you toss all the other aides. I’d refrain from saying you get what you deserve for basing his performance on looks alone but I really don’t care enough about your feelings not to.”

My mother opened the door to a simple room, a single long table in the middle with six chairs around it. Probably a student council room or something by the looks of it. We sat down across from each other, well me and my mother sat down, the girl was pushed into her seat and positioned like a doll. Once she settled the girl my mother turned to me, folding her hands on the table in front of her.

“I’ll get right to the point. I want you to protect this girl until someone can pick her up in a few days. Her name is Asala and she lost her parents a few days ago.”

“That’s sad and all but why me? Any number of people could do this job. Which begs the question why are you personally protecting her and why do you need me to take over? Is she some foreign ambassadors daughter? Secretly the princess of some country in the midst of civil war?”

“She’s a monster summoner. With unstable powers at that. You are one of the few I know and trust that is fine with that and would protect her from anything she summons.”

“That may be true but I’m not interested. I’m already stuck in this god forsaken school you shoved me in so I’ve had my fill of acceding to your whims and requests for a while.”

“Please Riktal? It will be easy. She’s run deep into her mind from the first and shut down all her responses. She mostly just summons little weenies now that you could take out in your sleep. Just give her a dose of magic so she doesn’t feel hunger or the need to sleep and check her diaper every so often in case it needs changed and you’re good to go. As you can see she doesn’t resist. Plus you’re good with kids to begin with.”

“Hold up, hold up! You put a diaper on her! She has to be at least eleven years old! How could you possible think that was a good idea!”

“Well she wouldn’t go to the bathroom on her own, simply let it run down her leg or sit in her underwear without saying anything. She ruined a few good pieces of clothes that way too. So I just decided putting a diaper on was easier all the way round. She hasn’t had an accident in a day or so, mainly because there is just nothing inside for her to expel. I was going to put some panties back on her today but I thought I should err on the side of caution since I was coming to the school.”

“And the thought of, I don’t know, sitting down and trying to help her break out of her shell didn’t cross your mind?”

“Don’t you think we tried! But everything we did just seemed to send her deeper and deeper! Besides, don’t you think it’s better this way? No need to worry about tough monsters popping up and they don’t show up as often. With her like this it’s like her powers are already partially sealed and contained.”

“It’s times like this that I am really glad you had no part in raising me. I doubt I would be as well put together as I am if you had tried being a real mother.”

My mother was about to reply when her head jerked up. I felt the presence as well a fraction of a second later. Even as I was pointing my finger at the door, my mother was still a fraction of a moment ahead of me. The line of purple energy that shot from her finger happened right before mine left my hand. The magic hit the door and drilled through it like it wasn’t there just before mine did the same slightly lower.

Both me and my mother shoved our chairs away from the table and sprinted towards the door. I was slightly faster this time, yanking it open to see Gregory slumped against the far wall bleeding from a hole in his gut and chest where our attacks had hit him. He held his hands over the wounds, his magic coating his hands as he tried to heal himself. My mother narrowed her eyes down at him for a moment.

“He looks familiar. He’s the boy that passed us earlier isn’t he?”

“Yeah he is. His name is Gregory.”

“He’s a sneaky little eavesdropper is what he is.”

She brought her foot up, creating a blade of magic along her sole and stomped down on his neck severing his head from his body.

“Now his name is dead. He should have known better then to snoop around where he doesn’t belong. Sorry about this Val, can you deal with the family?”

The principal wheeled around the corner to look at the body with a sigh.

“It’s regrettable but I understand Marian. I’ll deal with the clean up don’t worry. He must have come down the other stairwell because he didn’t get past me.”

“Not blaming you. He wouldn’t have lived long as a Hunter anyway doing things like this. Better to cull the flock now before he has a chance to hurt anyone.”

I looked from the principal to my mother to the body and finally back into the room where the girl hadn’t moved a muscle.

“Thirteen thousand Reul for the job plus expenses. That is on top of my living allowance since this is something completely separate. I won’t be attending classes with her or something like this might happen again. Unless you don’t care if I kill off everyone in my class if I have to. Plus proxy Hunter papers as well in case I need them for something the Zelkov name won’t get me out of.”

“Can you please do it without the papers? It would really benefit me to no end. I’ll agree to the other things no problem.”

“Fine. Under the table it is. But send me everything you know about the girl with the money.”

“Thank you so much Riktal darling! I swear you’ll understand it all soon enough.”

“Yeah I’ve heard that before. Still not understanding much except how much of a liar you are.”

She gave me a quick hug, kissing me on both cheeks which I suffered through before she said a final farewell and hurried away. The principal gave me a nod of farewell also before spinning her chair in a circle to disappear from whence she came. With a sigh I returned to the room, closing the door behind me as I sat next to the girl. I needed to get to know her first and break her out of her shell. Knowing my mother and the quality of most of the people she hired it was no wonder they couldn’t get her to interact with the world. They probably scared her deeper inside with their cruelly thoughtless words. But I had seen the tells that told me she could at least hear what was going on around her.

“Hey Asala. Looks like me and you will be together for a while. Don’t worry, I’m not like my mother or those other people. I want to know about you and help you. But I’m not going to push. Instead I want to tell you a story about when my little sister died.”

As I picked up her limp left hand I saw her right one squeeze the bear she was holding just a little bit and smiled.

***********

So ends the day, both for the first time and for the millionth time. Only one ending to all the possibilities that exist. As choice and thought clash constantly not only in Riktal’s mind, but in the mind of a thousand others. Every person you interacted with today and every person you didn’t influences those thoughts and choices you have no control over. What makes one thought more prevalent than another? Such as Gregory’s decision to sneak back down and listen or not.

What in his mind made the urge to listen stronger then the urge to not listen? Would he always listen if given the choice? Are the timelines where he does not listen the false timelines then if he were to always listen? And what about Riktal? Over the course of the day he has already made many choices, well you have made them for him but still. Does that mean this Riktal we see before us is the real Riktal? Or is it a fake that has strayed from the true path? Come again as we delve for the answers to these questions. Replay this day over and over, making new choices to find out the truth. And perhaps continue to find out more about yourself in the process.
111121112221121.title: Go someplace else

111121112221122.content:
“Why? I don’t want to deal with you just as much as you don’t want to deal with me longer than necessary. We can talk here. Unless you’re worried about the Zelkov name being tarnished by having any argument we have overheard by the class.”

“Why do you always have to be so difficult?”

“Why do you have to be my mother? I’m simply the product of how you raised me, or more specifically the lack thereof. I’m sure you have more important places to be, perhaps some nation to save from the ravages of monsters that only the great Marian Zelkov can handle. So why don’t we just get this over with?”

Rubbing her eyes lightly she expelled gustily.

“I don’t want to start with you. I never want to argue with you but every time we get together that’s just how it ends up. Fine we can talk here. This girls name is Asala and I want you to guard her for the next few days until someone I know can come pick her up.”

“Must be special or you wouldn’t have even bothered giving her a single glance, since we both know how great you are with kids. So what is she? A diplomat’s daughter? Some rich person you are sucking up to right now?”

“You really don’t think much of me do you?”

“Is it really that obvious?”

With another sigh my mother looked both ways down the hall to make sure no one was nearby before leaning in to whisper so only I heard.

“She’s a summoner. Her parents died in front of her three days ago and that activated her powers. They are unstable, seeming to activate more often when she has extreme emotions. She shut down on us and turned into this doll like thing you see before you. She won’t eat, won’t sleep, won’t even go to the bathroom for herself. She will just let her bowels or bladder go whenever she feels like it without warning. We ended up just sustaining her with magic and putting a diaper on her.”

“A diaper? What, talking to her and trying to help her with her problems was too much for you?”

“Don’t you think we tried getting her to come out of her shell? Do you think I really liked treating her like an infant? She soiled two dresses before this one and it took forever to clean up!”

“And how did you help exactly? Told her to just get over it? That it wasn’t the end of the world or something like that? Treated her like her feelings didn’t matter in the slightest? I bet she summoned something when you told her crap like that too. Bet you used many of the same words you used when I was broken up over Olia dying. Suck it up and move on.”

I clamped my lips on the rest of what I was going to say. I was in a good mood right now and I didn’t want to ruin it. Not with yet another argument with my mother. I needed to keep what was best for the girl in mind here, not let my feelings for my mother taint my decision. As I looked down at the girl my mother suddenly jerked her head up with narrowed eyes like she had heard some subsonic sound. I felt the presence as well moments before she whipped out her hand to throw a knife down the hall to stick into the wall by the stairwell.

“Come out little rat or I might have to do more than just give you such a small warning!”

Gregory came around the corner slowly, walking over to my mother when she beckoned. She looked down at the boy who kept his gaze averted.

“And just how much did you hear you little sneak?”

“Nothing really.”

“Then why were you hiding and trying to suppress your presence?”

“I-I just didn’t want to interrupt that’s all.”

He looked at the girl and I saw the fear and hatred in his eyes. My mother noticed it too as she scowled.

“Yes I totally believe that. Stay right where you are for now boy until my business with my son is done. Then me and you will have a nice long private chat about just how much you didn’t here.”

She looked at me expectantly, as if saying this was my fault. And part of it was I would admit. She had wanted to go someplace more private but I had been stubborn. Looking at the girl again I sighed.

“Thirteen thousand Reul, for Hunter fee and expenses. I’m in a good mood right now and I’m not going to fail to protect an innocent because of my feelings towards you. I also want Hunter proxy papers since I don’t have my license yet.”

“Could you please do this as an under the table deal? It would really help me out immensely.”

“Then fifteen thousand in that case.”

“And I want you to continue to go to classes. It’s really important.”

“What! Do you have any idea…”

I looked from Gregory to the girl before clamping down on what I was going to say. I saw he was trying to unobtrusively back away and escape but a glance from my mother stopped him. Running my fingers through my flaming head of hair I took a deep breath.

“Fine, but only if I feel it doesn’t endanger her or the class. Plus I want you to send me everything you know about her over the com spell.”

“I can live with that. I’ll have the papers drawn up and sent over later. The money will be in your account by tonight as well. Thanks Riktal darling. This really is important and I really do appreciate it.”

“Yeah, yeah.”

Kneeling in front of the little girl who didn’t even seem to register I was there, I studied her closely, noting the slight clenching of her bear as I smiled a bit. So she wasn’t completely unaware even if everyone else thought she was. That gave me something to work with at least. A glance back at the classroom door before giving her and my mother another thoughtful look. What was best for this little girl right now? And best for everyone? I had said I would go to classes still, but was now the best time to start?
111121112221122.title: Stay here

1111211122211221.content:
“I suppose we should head off to class. Even though it might be against my better judgment there really isn’t any reason not to. I did sort of agree to attending classes still after all.”

“What! You can’t take that…!”

“Take that what boy?”

My mother beat me to the words by only a fraction of a second, making my voice sound like an echo as we cut off and drowned out Gregory. I saw my mother reach up and grab a hold of one of her earrings in preparation of bringing a weapon into existence even as I placed my right hand on the knife at my side. Gregory looked between both of us, the fear evident on his face as he began to stammer.

“That… that little girl. I was going to say you can’t take that little girl into the classroom.”

“And I am sure you are worried about her safety just as much as we are aren’t you boy?”

“Yes ma’am.”

“Right. Well I trust my son I’ll have you know. If he thinks it’s safe enough to take the girl into the class right now then it is safe enough. After all she is just a little girl, right boy?”

“Yes. Yes she is nothing but a normal little girl Mrs. Zelkov.”

“I’ll see you in a week or so Riktal darling.”

“I won’t hold my breath on that.”

As I took the girls unresisting left hand and turned towards the classroom door I clamped my right on Gregory’s shoulder, digging in with my fingers as I leaned in close to whisper in his ear.

“My suggestion is you find a reason not to come to school for the next few days. I can’t guarantee your safety if you were to come. There might just be a few unfortunate accidents if you catch my drift. I have no love for wagging tongues, especially when they wag over my private business and would endanger someone I am protecting. I dare you to let a word of anything you might or might not of heard today past those lips. No matter where you run or hide I will find you because I have that kind of power and reach. Keep in mind that I won’t limit my tender eyes on just you. I have no problems going after your family as well. Just a bit of friendly advise you can listen to or not.”

I let go of his shoulder to open the door, my mother grabbing him by the arm and marching him away seconds later. The look of fear that had been in his eyes was now open terror written all over his face. With a thin smile I entered the lions den with my new charge coming behind me. Instantly all eyes were on me and the whispering started. The girls went all feminine in the blink of an eye.

“Oh she is so adorable!”

“Look at that hair! And those eyes!” I just want to grab her up and squeeze her because she is so small!”

“Is she your sister?”

“Was that your mother? That was Marian Zelkov right? She’s the reason I became a Hunter! I actually got to meet her!”

“Quiet!”

My single shouted word shut everybody up as I cleared my throat and looked around the room to meet everyone’s eyes.

“Her name is Asala. She will be joining us for the next few days because of a bunch of different reasons. I’ve taken on the job of protecting her from everyone and everything. Ignore the both of us for the next few days and don’t get too close. She will be gone soon enough and she doesn’t need people crowding her. Need I remind you that a Hunter on a job values the contract of the job over anything else, including personal relationships. I will not hesitate to bring harm to any one of you if it is necessary to protect my client. That is all. Respect my wishes and ignore them at your peril.”

As I walked the girl to my desk, snagging an empty one for myself the teacher cleared his throat and got the attention of the class back on him before continuing with his lesson. This wasn’t the strangest of things they would see as Hunter’s. In the grand design it was actually relatively normal.

The bell finally rang ending class as the other students all eyed the two of us with interest. But they respected my wishes and kept their distance. Asala continued to sit and act like a doll, barely breathing or blinking. Simply holding on tightly to the bear. I would have liked to spend a bit of time talking to her and putting her at ease with me while trying to get her out of her shell. I knew she could hear and perhaps see what was going on around her even if she didn’t react. Her lifeless shell routine might have my mother and everyone else fooled, but not anyone who actually paid a bit of attention to her.

But I couldn’t and wouldn’t talk to her now. Everyone else didn’t need to know that much about her and I wasn’t about to let anything of her true nature slip. I resigned myself to sitting her down and talking with her later once we got home. I had a feeling some of the instability of her powers stemmed from her feeling her whole world was unstable. Having lost everything and having a power she didn’t understand on top of that. I just had to power through this last hour and everything would be good.

The teacher came in, taking role call after I let him know about Asala joining us for the next couple days. He simply nodded and went into his lesson on the Cawmacaw bird. Everything was going well when a red circle suddenly appeared on the floor in the middle of the aisle and a goblin pyromancer climbed out. The class froze for a moment as the two foot tall wart covered monster with grey-green skin looked around a bit dazed. The bulbous nose bobbing back and forth as it’s gnarled and bent body began to lift a hand with a fireball in it. Then after that single split second the two boys and girls on either side of it pulled out their daggers or summoned swords from thin air to skewer the thing before it could throw any fire around.

Almost as one all eyes seemed to be drawn to the girl. As if they all somehow knew it was her that had called the goblin forth.
1111211122211221.title: Return to class

11112111222112211.content:
“She’s a summoner! Kill her!”

Even as Liz was shouting that I threw out my hand, creating a wall of wind to throw the kids that were already jumping out of chairs and leaping over desks towards us back. With one hand I grabbed up Asala, yanking her towards me without caring if I hurt her or not, bringing my other arm around to scoop her up under the legs.

I created a shield of magic around us as I ran straight for the broken window. Using some fancy footwork to dodge sword strikes and arrows. My shield could take about ten hits from gunfire, but that number would rapidly decrease if I took unnecessary blows from other weapons. As Liz swung at me with her dagger Jethic was suddenly in the way, deflecting her blow with the edge of his crumpled shield.

“Go!”

A wall of flames on either side of me rose up, burning the two arrows that came shooting towards me as I saw Marsa give me a nod. Making the leap from the top of a desk I sailed out the window, transferring my power from my shield to my legs so they wouldn’t break on impact. Still as my feet hit I felt the shudder of enhanced muscles straining against the force. Without looking back I began to run for the front gates right ahead of me. Just as I passed through the gates I felt the piercing pain of a knife in my back on the left side. It hadn’t hit any vital organs, but it still hurt like hell.

Ignoring the blade for the moment I ran, augmenting my speed and stamina with my rapidly dwindling magic. Most of my power going towards minimizing the damage from the knife so I wouldn’t bleed out. Through town and over the river I went carrying the girl, passing untold numbers of people who stared at me in surprise even as I leaked blood all the way. Finally after about ten minutes I got to my house, unlocking the front door spell and slipping inside before activating the defense spells around the estate.

Only then after sitting the girl on the couch did I pull the knife from my back, sealing the wound quickly. Even with my quick actions I felt a bit dizzy from blood loss and exerting my body as I had. Throwing a quick spell on the girl so she wouldn’t feel hunger or the need to sleep I sat on the floor and closed my eyes. I knew I would pass out any moment. I’d been here before so I knew the feeling. Just a short rest was all I needed to get my reserves back. The defenses would hold out any pursuers so Asala was safe for now.

Looking at the blade still in my hand I saw the poison coating it. It wasn’t lethal, just a common leeching poison. No wonder my energy and strength were all sapped. And why I was already on the verge of unconsciousness from such a small attack and run through town.

Just a small rest was all I needed. With that the darkness took me.

*********

Well, that turned out a bit unexpected did it not? Was the ending of the day to your liking? Are you already asking yourself what if? Wondering if you had done something different if things would have changed? Or what if I had grabbed for a weapon instead is crossing your mind.

Which brings me to wonder, why did you make the choices you did? Your own personal ideals? You thought that is what Riktal himself would have chosen if he had not been controlled by you? Perhaps a mixture of the two. Or perhaps you simply took the road less traveled so to speak? Going against what you wanted to do simply to see what would happen.

Do you regret your choices? How do you think this day ended for Riktal? Poorly? Well? Come again and relive this day at your pleasure. Make new choices, see new things, learn new truths. Perhaps even make new friends. Until then traveler, may the doors of possibilities be opened to you.
11112111222112211.title: Grab girl and run

11112111222112212.content:
“She’s a summoner! Kill her!”

Even as Liz was shouting that I threw out a quick wall of wind to throw the boys and girls already leaping out of seats and over desks back. In that split second I reached down into my bag, pulling out the first thing that came to hand which happened to be my Lexington. With but a thought I activated phase two of the weapon and had it resting on the back of my hands. I raised my left to suck up the ball of ice hurtling my way but the attack was stopped by a swirl of fire from Marsa’s staff as she jumped in front of me. Jethic, Lilia, and Daniel all appeared next to her as a wall between me and the rest of the class. Marsa looked back at me quickly and grinned.

“Don’t get me wrong, I don’t like summoners much either, but what you said to me earlier about Lilia applies to that girl too right? I fear what I don’t understand without thinking. Perhaps it’s time I change that and give it a chance eh?”

She sent out a torrent of water to break a volley of arrows even as Lilia threw out her hand, blinding everyone in front of her with a flash of light.

“You have a good heart. I trust you, that’s all I need to know.”

With that Lilia drew back her hand like she was holding a bow and arrow, releasing her fingers to shoot a shaft of pure divine power to smash into the shield bearer leading a charge and shoving desks to the side. Daniels leapt forward, punching and kicking to break up the small V-formation after the arrow of light. He stuck to mostly kicks, mindful of his still healing arms, jumping back behind the lines seconds later before anyone could attack him back. He gave me a thumbs up and a grin.

“You gave me the benefit of the doubt at lunch and you saved my life earlier. Not to mention you tried to teach me how to be a better fist fighter. I’m not doing this for the girl, though I have nothing against summoners personally. I’m doing this because I owe you a debt. My father always told me a man needs to repay his debts.”

He punched forward quickly, sending out a fist of air to knock a handful of daggers from the sky seconds before Marsa called forth tree roots from the ground to bind up the offending throwers. Jethic jumped out in front of the rest of them, hitting his wrist and making his crumpled shield come into existence.

“I owe you a debt too. I redeemer what old Markus told me about being a Hunter. He said sometimes when you don’t know what’s right just follow your gut instinct. And my instinct says to help you and that girl. On me you slugs!”

I felt the wave pulse out from Jethic as he spread his legs. Everyone in the class had no choice but to turn and attack him. He used his nearly useless shield to great effect, blocking and dodging the attacks without a weapon. Lilia kept him healed up while the other two stayed back to protect Asala. I saw Liz jump up to the ceiling with a half flip, shoving off with her legs and hurtling right towards us like a bullet with her knife held out.

I jumped and met her in mid air, taking her attack on the tube sitting on my left hand. She flipped backwards, landing on a desk while eyeing me warily, madness in her eyes. I knew she wouldn’t be stupid enough to cast magic on me for my barrel to eat, but that didn’t mean I couldn’t shoot my own power through it if needed.

“Why do you protect such filth! She’s a summoner! They should all be eradicated! Phase two activate.”

Her dagger became two, glowing with an intense blue light. The blades became longer and curved. She flipped her grip, holding them both against her forearm before coming at me. I blocked her blows with my Lexington, kicking her away before shooting a few purple bullets in her direction. She sliced them from the air even as she spun out of the way of the real bullet I sent her way. We exchanged a flurry of blows, neither one of us giving an inch, blocking the others strike.

“Don’t do this Liz! I’m better then you and you know it!”

“Never! Summoners all need to die! I was like you once! And then one of those freaks killed my little sister! That’s when I learned how filthy they really are! She’ll do it to you too! She will take away everything you care about! That’s all they are good for! Destroying everything around them! Phase three. Thorns of Desire.”

The two blades I had blocked on my crossed forearms began to pulse even as I shoved her forcefully away. Her body began to sprout knives from all over the place. Shoulders, fingers, elbows, knees. Some even sprouted from her chest and sides, each growing to be at least six or seven inches long to match the ones in her hands.

We charged each other at the same time me silently committed and her yelling madly. She swung at me with her right hand, the dagger in it sweeping in an arc towards my face. I stepped inside the swing, bringing my right over to grab her right below the elbow. Bringing my left arm upwards I fired a magical bullet into her joint, blowing her arm clean off. With her severed arm I backhanded her across the face, sending her staggering backwards even as I brought my left fist down, firing another magical projectile into the joint of her other arm and blowing it off as well.

With a grunt I slammed her underneath the chin with a hard right uppercut, piercing her flesh with the barrel of my Lexington. I stared into her mad eyes as she began to choke on her own blood. I let my voice drop to a whisper so only she could hear me.

“That’s not going to happen. Because the last person I ever really cared about died two years ago. For your information she was a monster summoner as well and she saved my life. It’s a shame, I was beginning to like you.”

With that I pulled the trigger, sending a bullet up into her brain to explode on impact, sending skull fragments and brain bits everywhere. Nothing was left of the top of her head past the nose as I yanked my gun out and kicked her body to the floor. I turned to see everyone had stopped fighting to stare in shock and surprise.

“I said I would not hesitate to do anything to keep this girl safe! Did you think I wouldn’t kill all you sorry ignorant idiots who blindly hate anything that’s different! Stand down or I will blow the brains out of every single one of you maggots!”

They all lowered their weapons and stepped back as I returned to my seat to slip my arms through my duffle bag and shrug it on my back without a word. Unhooking my Lexington I connected the barrel’s together, not yet willing to take it out of phase two as I took the girls unresisting hand. When I began marching towards the door the four who had helped me became a rearguard, protecting me from attack.

As I hit the door I saw the teacher raising his hands with fire lances in them from the corner of my eye. Without looking I raised my weapon and fired, ripping him in half before he had a chance to throw them.

“God damn idiot. Sorry Lilia.”

“He was an idiot. You warned him. But thank you for not taking His name in vain.”

“You all know where I live. Feel free to come over anytime. I’d like to thank you all properly.”

“Then I think we might come over now. I have a feeling we aren’t very welcome in this class right now. Perhaps not even in this school after today.”

“You regret it Jethic?”

“Not for a moment. I feel what I did was the right thing.”

The other three agreed with the shield bearer as we walked down the hall on the alert for any more attacks. But none came as we left the front door and then the front gates. We didn’t let our guards down though until we were all safely back at my house. And through it all the little girl remained as lifeless and unresponsive as ever.

****************

Well, that turned out a bit unexpected did it not? Was the ending of the day to your liking? Are you already asking yourself what if? Wondering if you had done something different if things would have changed? Or what if I had run away instead is crossing your mind.

Which brings me to wonder, why did you make the choices you did? Your own personal ideals? You thought that is what Riktal himself would have chosen if he had not been controlled by you? Perhaps a mixture of the two. Or perhaps you simply took the road less traveled so to speak? Going against what you wanted to do simply to see what would happen.

Do you regret your choices? How do you think this day ended for Riktal? Poorly? Well? Come again and relive this day at your pleasure. Make new choices, see new things, learn new truths. Perhaps even make new friends. Until then traveler, may the doors of possibilities be opened to you.
11112111222112212.title: Grab for a weapon

1111211122211222.content:
“Well for now I think it is best if I take her out of this place. I need to get to know her before I introduce her to the class.”

I eyeballed Gregory sideways before going on.

“That will also give you time to find out just how much he doesn’t know about all of this. I suggest you make it so he finds a reason to not come to school for the next few days.”

As I took the little girl by the hand to lead her down the hall away from my mother I gripped his shoulder tightly, letting my fingers crush his flesh as I leaned in to whisper in his ear.

“If I have even an inkling you opened your mouth and told anyone else about the things you didn’t hear, I will not hesitate to slit your throat from ear to ear. This is Hunter business and private to boot, don’t forget how little tolerance we have for snitches in our midst. I have little love for the Zelkov name but I will crush you and your family with it if you dare cross me.”

Squeezing the girls hand lightly I let the boy go, heading off down the hall with a smile on my face as if I had said nothing to the boy at all. I saw my mother grabbing Gregory roughly by the arm and pulling him after her in the opposite direction, a look of fear written plainly on his features. She let me lead her unresistingly out the front doors and the gates onto the street. Normally I would have headed left to go into town and then home but this time I turned right.

It only took a few minutes of walking to get to the small playground where I used to take Olia all the time. Coming here still made my heart hurt but there was something about the place that kept pulling me back from time to time. I sat her down on one of the benches before sitting next to her and throwing my arms over the back with a sigh. She simply stared unmoving off into space as I let my gaze span the little park area. We sat like that for a good three or four minutes, only the slight rise and fall of our chests showing anyone we were alive.

“I used to have a younger sister you know. She died three years ago. Olia and I, we were really close. She was the one out of all my family that I loved the most. I practically raised her because mother and father were never around and neither was big sis most of the time. Oh we had baby-sitters and nannies, but usually they were just there to make sure we didn’t kill ourselves. Just in it for the money I guess you could say.

“So whenever Olia was afraid of something, or she got hurt, or her favorite toy got broken, she came running to me. I couldn’t tell you how many times she crawled into my bed because she had a nightmare or bawled into my chest as I stroked her hair. She was a really sweet girl too. She had this smile that seemed to make the very sun dim in comparison. The thing was, she wasn’t suited to being a Hunter. Didn’t have the kind of innate skills at it that me or big sis did. But my mother couldn’t accept that, pushing the training onto her like she had me. In the end that’s what killed her.”

I let my hand drop onto the girls head and began absently stroking her hair as I pictured Olia’s face in my mind. The blond hair, the big blue eyes the ever present smile missing a tooth off to the side on top.

“But she loved to come to this playground. We could sometimes spend hours here. I think when she came here she was able to forget all her worries, because in this park it was just me and her. Our own private little world. Why am I telling you all this you might ask? Because when she died I was in a really bad way just like you. I felt like my entire world had been ripped out from under me and I was falling into this bottomless black pit of despair and grief. As if part of my very soul had just been taken from me and lost forever.

“I bet that’s kind of how you are feeling right now isn’t it? Lost and alone in the word with no one and nothing familiar left to you except maybe that bear. Nothing to call your own and no place to call your home anymore. I don’t blame you for running away into your head. But you know, even big strong men like me needed to cry when my sister died. You should have seen the snot coming out of my nose and how red my eyes got. But I was all alone in my grief. My parents and sister were all off doing jobs as if nothing had happened and I was left in the cold empty house all by myself just like I always am.

“So if even a person like me needed to cry and let it all out then I know a little girl like you needs to do the same. It doesn’t make them come back to life and it doesn’t change any of the facts, but a good long cry can still make you feel better. And right now you, unlike me, are not alone. I’m right here for you. You can let it all out and I will hold you and comfort you and not tell anyone a single word about it if you don’t want me to. We are in the private little world where only me and my sister existed. Where we could let go of all the other worries in the world that we had. Let go of all the fears in our minds and simply be free.”

I stopped talking then, feeling I had said what I needed to, simply continuing to stroke her hair as I watched the empty park ahead of us. It started as a small sniffle and then she was clutching my shirt as I pulled her into my chest while she went into a full blown crying spree. I made soft sounds like I had when Olia used to cry like this, rocking her back and forth while petting her hair. She cried until she began to hiccup out her wails. Cried until she began to cough and choke. Finally she stopped, but didn’t pull away as I continued to rock her gently.

“It will hurt for a long time sweetie. For many, many years to come. You will look back and say to yourself you should have told them this or you shouldn’t have acted like that. Wishing to change the past and knowing you will never see them again. Sometimes it’s going to be hard to get through the days. Each breath will seem like a struggle. But you need to remember the good things about the time you spent with them instead of focusing on only how they died or the bad moments. That’s what’s going to get you through this right now. Later on you can remember those bad moments and not feel such sorrow. Because all those moments both good and bad are now precious memories you have to hold onto. It’s proof that they lived and you loved them.”

“You feel warm.”

Her voice was soft and hesitant. Almost a whisper of sound that had a light musical quality to it.

“You aren’t afraid of my power?”

“Not in the slightest. I don’t see a monster summoner here right now, I see a little girl grieving for her parents that just got her snot all over my uniform. No matter what you summon I will protect you from it. And I am in the minority of Hunters who see those with special powers as people, not cursed in any way. I’m sure you had a tough time of it while my mother took care of you because she and most of the aides she hires barely tolerate summoners to begin with.”

She nodded her head up and down as the arms she had wrapped around me tightened and she let out a sigh of contentment.

“Yeah they were really scary. They felt cold. Not like you. Telling me to move on and pulling me around. When they tried to be nice it felt fake. Like they didn’t really care. They were always up in my face and monsters came out of nowhere. So I just ran deeper into my head than I was before.”

“But you couldn’t run away completely could you? You had to have enough recognition of the outside world so as not to lose your teddy bear. But other than that you just didn’t care.”

“Uh-huh. His name is Mr. Cuddles and mommy and daddy gave him to me for my birthday when I was six. He’s been with me ever since.”

“So how old are you now?”

“Eleven. I’ll turn twelve next month.”

“Well then Asala who is eleven and will turn twelve next month. How about me and you go into town and have ourselves a bit of a pre-birthday party? Since I won’t be able to go with you when my mothers acquaintance comes to pick you up, I won’t be able to celebrate your birthday with you on the proper day either. I must warn you, I plan on showering you with a bunch of presents of clothes and jewelry and anything else I feel like. And we are going to go eat and have a birthday cake and everything. Of course we have to buy you new underwear and you have to wear them because no twelve year old I know is allowed to wear diapers. Think you could handle all of that?”

She hugged my tightly again as she snuggled her head against my chest.

“As long as you are there. You’ll stay with me the whole time won’t you? You won’t leave?”

“Never. My job is to guard you twenty four hours a day, eight days a week. I’m going to stick to you like a piece of old food between your teeth until you leave. You are going to get so disgusted with me being around all the time you will be glad to go.”

She giggled a bit at my words before saying she would never get tired of me. The clock rang out that it was three o’clock as I grabbed her around the waist and stood up. I swung her frail little frame back and forth a few time before setting her down. A small part of my mind noting that she couldn’t weigh more than a hundred pounds if that.
1111211122211222.title: Leave for the day

11112111222112221.content:
“We definitely got to get you some clothes first. Unless you like that ugly looking dress that makes my eyes want to bleed.”

Another giggle at my raised eyebrow and the look of horror on my face.

“No. I think your momma picked it out for me.”

“Well that explains the fashion sense. Well then let’s go find something more fitting for you. I warn you I won‘t let you get away without buying three, no wait four new sets of clothes! Oh and a new pair of shoes of course. And they better be slightly expensive. You better not get the plainest, cheapest thing because you think I‘m not willing to spend money on you. You understand me missy?”

“Yeah I understand.”

She grinned at me as I bent to pick up my bag of weapons. As I offered her my hand a red circle appeared in front of us. I saw a skinny three fingered insect like hand reach out and grab a hold of the edge seconds before another one come into view. Asala began to whimper even as I pulled out a sword, dropping my bag again before stalking forward.

“It’s just an E class, no need to be afraid. Nothing I can’t handle blindfolded.”

As I raised my sword in preparation to shove it down into the pit before the beast could emerge Asala cried out for me to stop.

“Don’t hurt it!”

Immediately I held off my thrust, instead stomping down on one pair of fingers making it let go before shoving my foot through the hole to boot the monster in the head. As it fell back into the pit I took my foot away seconds before the hole closed. Putting my weapon away I slid my arms through the straps and walked off hand in hand with the girl.

“Why didn’t you want me to kill it? You aren’t one of those CAMPers are you?”

“Camper?”

“It’s an acronym. It stands for Citizens Advocating Monster Protection. Basically they are a group of people who think monsters should be protected because they are no different from animals. That they only do the things they do because it is their nature and we shouldn’t kill them for the way god made them. Personally I think they are nut jobs. I’d like to see them keep up their do no harm to monsters mentality when one of them is rampaging around destroying their house or has them in it’s claws and is about to eat them. Now CETA I can get behind to an extent since there really are a lot of non aggressive animals out there and animal abuse isn’t really something I go for.”

“No I’m not a CAMPer. It’s just, why does it have to die for something I can’t control? It didn’t hurt anybody and it didn’t ask to be summoned just like I didn’t ask for this power. If it had gotten out and started hurting people that’s a different story, but it was still helpless and hadn’t done any harm.”

“Well it was only a Ski’ter. If it had gotten loose it would have only been an annoyance anyway, eating dead things on the side of the road and rooting through garbage. It’s a scavenger but it rarely attacks humans unless cornered. If it had gotten loose there was a fifty-fifty chance a Hunter would have captured it and released it into the wild anyway. So returning it before it got summoned is no big deal.”

“But aren’t Hunter’s supposed to kill all monsters? That’s what my momma said.”

Her voice choked for a moment when she mentioned her mother and I pulled her in close, wrapping my arm around her shoulder to hug her against my side.

“Some Hunter’s do live by that philosophy. Because there are a lot of dangerous monsters out there and even the ones that aren’t dangerous are still monsters in their eyes. But there are just as many if not more Hunter’s that believe in only killing the monster if it becomes a danger to humans. Yes something like a troll might be big mean and scary, and dangerous to humans to boot. But if it stays to it’s caves in the mountains and doesn’t come down to terrorize the citizens, why should we go out of our way to kill it?

“Besides monster slaying is dangerous for us Hunter’s as well. Not all monsters are easy E class like that Ski’ter. I’m an A class Hunter but even I can have trouble with a B class or even if I get into a fight with a few C class at once depending on what they are. And if I were to go up against another A class level monster there is a good chance I’m coming out missing a body part or two if I am not really careful. That’s why we Hunter’s have such a high mortality rate. For every Hunter living right now, at least three others have died. There are a little over two hundred kids in my school, but within the first five years of them graduating at least a third of them will be dead.”

“Then why do you all become Hunter’s if you know you’re probably going to die?”

“Because our desire to protect the people is greater then our fear of death. Some do it for glory and money, but still at the core we want to make the lives of the citizens peaceful. Protect innocent people like you so you can grow up without worrying about having to live in hiding. Able to enjoy the civilization we humans have built.”

“You’re not going to die too are you?”

“One day I eventually will. But I don’t plan on dying for a long time. I guess every Hunter thinks that, but I am a tenth generation Zelkov. I’ve been trained from the day I took my first breath to be a Hunter. It’s programmed into ever fiber of my being. I’m not that easy to kill. I suppose I’m lucky. As much a I hate my parents, I at least still have them. They are pushing forty you know. That’s old for a Hunter. Most don’t live past thirty-five. There is a reason you don’t see a lot of active old Hunter’s around. Age slows us down. We can use our magic to help with that, but there is only so much we can do to slow the onset of time on our bodies. That’s why we marry young and have children early, because there is no guarantee we will be alive later to carry on our family lines.”

She was quiet as we finished our walk into town and I took her to a reasonably priced clothing store I knew of. At first she seemed unsure and then I reminder her of what I had said earlier. That seemed to be all the incentive she needed, trying on dresses and chatting away happily. I simply let her go to town, let her forget about her grief for just a little bit. She did tell me to turn around when she went to pick out some new undergarments, blushing a bit as she did so. I grinned but complied, hiding my eyes with my fingers but peeking out through cracked lids to watch her in the mirror anyway.

As the clock bells announced it was six o’clock we finally finished our shopping with Asala in a much better mood. She had slipped into the bathroom of the store and come out wearing a light red dress that complimented her eyes and some ruby shoes that matched, giving me a small twirl of exhibition. She had bought one pair of shirt and pants but she said she liked dresses more. I whistled appreciatively before we left the store and headed deeper into town.

“Is it ok if I call you big brother Riktal?”

“I don’t mind that squirt. If it makes you feel more comfortable then by all means. Besides, it kind of feels like I have a little sister again.”

She grinned as I ruffled her hair with my one free hand. After a moment she said she wanted to carry some of the bags too, so I gave her the two lightest out of the four bags, which made her grin even more. After a few moments of silence she began to speak again.

“Big brother, am I a bad girl for being happy right now?”

“No you’re not sweetie. It’s ok to feel happy when you’re happy, and sad when you are sad. Just because you are sad over your parents doesn’t mean you aren’t allowed to feel anything else. Life will go on no matter what you are feeling, that means you have to go on along with it. I know you are still going to cry over them again and again, and you are still going to feel empty inside over their loss. But you can’t be sad all the time just like you can’t be happy all the time. Life is all about ups and downs, being able to appreciate those moments and seize them when they happen is part of living life.”

“Then it’s ok to keep having fun?”

“Yes it’s perfectly all right to keep having fun.”

She grinned again as if some burden had been lifted from her shoulder before hugging me around the waist.

“I love you!”

I didn’t know how to answer her. I knew I needed to keep a bit of distance between us so that it would be easier to part ways in a few days. I couldn’t go with her and she couldn’t stay. As I stroked her hair I simply kept quiet, that seemed the best course of action to take. After a moment she let go and we continued walking.
11112111222112221.title: Shopping first

111121112221122211.content:
“Hey Riktal! How you doing honey! We were wondering when you were going to be coming back!”

“What’s up Patricia. How’s your husband?”

“Much better. It was just a small cold that had lingered a little longer than normal. That apothecary you suggested worked wonders.”

“Glad to hear it. Can I get a birthday special? Twelve candles mind you and the works of sides.”

The middle aged woman looked at the girl and grinned, giving her a wink before telling me it would be a few minutes. She led us to a booth by the window that gave me a good view of the room. There were only a few other customers even though this was still technically dinner service. It was one of the reasons I liked Milly’s, they were almost never crowded.

“Are you sure you can’t come with me when I leave?”

“Sorry, that’s just not going to be possible.”

“Then I’ll make sure to learn everything I have to and become strong that way I can come back here.”

“And why would you want to come back for me? Once you get to your new place and settled in I’ll become just another happy memory. You will be there for a few years and make new friends and have a new life.”

“Because I love you and I decided that I’m going to marry you.”

“Oh really? That’s a bit of a tall statement. What are you going to do if you get to your new place and find a boy you like and he likes you? A lot can happen in a few years you know.”

“Nuh-uh. I decided it’s going to be you and only you.”

Before I could respond four waitresses came out carrying a small round chocolate cake with twelve candles along with bowls of ice cream and trays filled with chips, dips, and assorted finger snacks like pretzels. As they set them all out on the table Joey, the big rotund cook came out and began to sing “Happy Birthday” in an operatic voice. He made all eyes turn towards us as Asala hid her face in embarrassment. Finally she blew out the candles and everyone in the place clapped and congratulated her.

As the workers dispersed I made her cut the first piece as the birthday girl should and heaped her plate with all the snacks around before we began to eat. She had a bit of a glow about her, all traces of her sorrow gone for the moment as she ate happily. As I took a bite of ice cream I pointed my fork at her.

“So let’s just suppose you don’t fall for anyone else and you come back to find me in say four or five years. What will you do if I’m already married? I‘m seventeen after all, I really do have to start thinking about such things even if I don‘t like it.”

She looked up into the sky deep in thought for a moment before giving me a shrug.

“I suppose I’ll let you keep her as a mistress.”

I nearly choked on my ice cream as I kept from laughing, the grin on my face refusing to go away.

“And if I refused? What if I didn’t want to divorce her?”

“I guess I’d be ok with being the mistress. As long as you spent more time with me than with her.”

This time I let the chuckle escape from my lips as I shook my head.

“You’re too much you know that? I’m afraid I wouldn’t be able to keep up with you if we got married. So I’ll quietly step back and let some other poor soul take my place.”

“Nope. I won’t allow you. I choose you and I’m not going to change my mind. Oh and you will have to change your name to Heinfield because I won’t change mine to Zelkov.”

I began to laugh again, simply shaking my head as I ate another potato chip. So was this what Asala had been like before her parents had died? Or was this just another coping mechanism. I knew part of it was because I had reached out to her in her time of need. She had latched onto me like a drowning man clutches a life preserver. She found comfort and safety around me, but anyone could have made her feel the same way if they had really tried. I just happened to be the one to do it. Perhaps I had gone a bit overboard in making her feel safe, but feeling like a big brother again had made me want to go overboard.

We finished the little party while making a few jokes and her telling me how she wanted to be a wood worker when she grew up because that’s what her father had been. We left the diner and headed home, with Asala telling me bits and pieces of what her life had been like before as I asked leading questions. It was more of the process of grieving as I made her remember the good times over the bad ones.

Once home I quickly showed her around the house before scooting her off to take a bath with a reminder to brush her teeth. While she was in the bathroom I pulled out the old shoebox from my closet, slipping out the pile of photos and looking through them. They were all of Olia spread out across her baby pictures up until two weeks before she died. Showing all the different phases she had gone through, with pigtails, and curls, and even coloring her hair. Funny faces, happy faces, sad faces, each one captured a fragment of her. I wiped at my eyes when a drop of water hit the picture that looked like she was going to reach through the camera any second to grab you around the neck.

“She was pretty.”

“Yes she was.”

I looked up to see Asala standing in front of me with her pajamas on and carrying her teddy bear in her right hand.

“Does it really get better? Will it stop hurting so much?”

“It really does. It never completely goes away though. Sometimes some small thing sets you off remembering and you feel their loss all over again.”

“At least you have pictures to remember her by. I’m afraid I will forget what they look like.”

I pulled her in as she began to cry again, letting her work the tears out of her system. Her bout didn’t last long this time before she pulled away sniffing and rubbing her eyes. Setting the photos to the side I pulled back the covers of the bed, telling her to hop in. as I tucked her and the bear in she grabbed my hand.

“You're not going to leave are you?”

“Didn’t I say I was going to be right next to you? I’m going to get myself a bath of my own and then I will be right back in here. I’ll make myself a little bed on the floor in case you need me.”

“Will you sleep with me? I don’t want to be alone.”

“Sure if that’s what you want.”

She let me go, watching me silently as I grabbed a fresh set of clothes and headed out the door. I didn’t have any fear of someone getting to her in this house. There were so many protection spells and artifacts on and around the place it was like a fortress. Still I finished quickly, just in case another monster got summoned or she needed me. She was still staring at the door when I came back in, as if she had been afraid to blink in case that kept me from coming back. I saw a shadow of fear she had been holding in disappear at the sight of me.

“Big brother, why don’t you hate me or my powers?”

“Do you want me to hate you?”

“No.”

“Then isn’t that enough? I’ve got my reasons, but they aren’t that important. The fact is I don’t hate you so that’s good enough.”

“Ok.”

As I draped the towel I had been using to dry my hair over the back of the chair my fingers stilled. Wasn’t that one of the very reasons I hated my mother so much? She was always saying she had reasons but never saying what those reasons were? Always putting me off whenever I asked? Going over to the bed I looked down at the girl a moment as she stared back at me with those big trusting eyes.

“Can I see Mr. Cuddles for a moment?”

With a nod she handed me the bear, only a hint of reluctance at letting it go. I coated it in my purple magic, imagining what it was I wanted to do and then made the unique twist of the mind to activate my ability. I continued to concentrate even as I felt a bit of blood coming down my nose until I was done and the bears black eyes were as crimson as the girls. With a sigh I handed it back to her while wiping my nosebleed. Pulling back the covers I slid into bed next to her with a grin.

“You wanted to know why I don’t hate you or your powers. Well that is one of the reasons. It’s because I’m just like you. Well not exactly of course since I can’t summon monsters. But I have a special power others might call cursed. It’s a bit complicated to explain and I won’t go into the details but basically I imprinted your parents onto that bear. Now whenever you go to sleep thinking about them with that bear in your hands you will see them like they are still alive. They will talk and act just like you remember them. The more information I get the more I can add to the bear to increase the things they say or their movements or the thousands of other little things that made them your parents. Now get some sleep, your parents are waiting for you.”

I leaned forward and kissed her forehead as she blinked at me, her mouth opening in a round O of surprise. Clutching the bear tighter she snuggled closer to me while closing her eyes, a smile almost wrapping around her head. Sending out a bit of magic I flicked off the overhead light before draping my arm over her small body.

“Thank you big brother. This is the best present of them all.”

***********

So ends another day. Even if it is the same day over and over it is still another day. How do you feel about your choices? Do you wonder what other paths might have been taken? If so then come again and play god. Pursue different choices as you relive this day. See just how different the day could be depending on all the important and unimportant choices not only you but everyone else makes in the course of a single day.
111121112221122211.title: Off to eat

11112111222112222.content:
“We need to go eat out first. After all in a real birthday party you always get your presents after the cake. You like that idea?”

“Yeah!”

I was about to pick up my bag when a red circle appeared on the ground in front of us. Even as Asala began to whimper a little bit I noted the small form shooting into the air so didn’t even bother grabbing a weapon. The circle closed up only seconds after opening, leaving Asala clutching at my leg in terror. With a gentle hand on her head I reached into my pouch and pulled out some of my ration bread. Breaking off a small bit and using magic to moisten it I told her to hold out her hand. When she did so I dropped the crumbs and fruits into it, holding her wrist so she wouldn’t jerk it away.

“Keep very still for right now ok? I’m right here so nothing is going to go wrong. I want you to meet the monster you just summoned.”

Whistling a quick tune before clucking my tongue like I was calling a dog I waited. We didn’t wait long before what looked like a green mini dragon came swooping down towards us, hovering for a moment as it eyed both us and the offering before alighting on her hand and beginning to eat. It’s tiny hind claws gripped her flesh gently as his front ones picked up the fruit and ate it daintily.

“This is a Dagal. Some call them midget dragons or mini dragons because that’s what they look like. They can get aggressive just like any monster, but they are normally quite tame and peaceful as you can see. They eat just about anything but they prefer fruits. Well except for apples, those mess with their systems. Do you want to tame him? Make him your first monster tame?”

“Y-yes.”

There was such awe and wonderment in her eyes and voice as she spoke in a bare whisper. As if she would frighten it away. I grinned as I told her to scratch it under the chin, an act she did with slight hesitation. The Dagal cooed in pleasure while flapping its wings before picking up the last slice of apricot and flying into the air. It circled quickly before landing on her shoulder, giving her face a nuzzle and going back to eating.

“They only need about half their body weight twice a day. They are smart so they won’t glutton themselves if they are full. You’ll learn how to communicate with him, or perhaps it’s a her, in time. Only the red ones like hot water so keep your friend away from such things. They don’t mind hot weather or hot steam, just not direct contact with hot water. There are five main colors of Dagal, each with their own specialty of magic that they know and can learn. Since your’s is green it will focus on earth skills.

“If your friend there has an aversion to a person, drink or food trust it’s instincts over your own because they have a good sixth sense and incredible sense of smell. Those two things allow them to detect just about any kind of poison known to man and let you know if a person is trustworthy or not. You might want to think of a name for it as well, unless you just want to call it Dagal.”

“How do I know if it is boy or a girl?”

“Ask it to fly to either me or you to tell us if it is male or female. I told you they are smart and they can understand human tongue.”

Asala asked the creature, probably feeling a bit foolish for doing so. But the creature flapped it’s wings and circled a few times before landing back on her shoulder.

“Well now you know.”

“Then I am going to name her Etoile.”

“Why that name?”

“Because I remember my mother used to call me that. She would say I was her little etoile.”

“Do you even know what it means?”

“No. but I thought it sounded pretty.”

“It means star. As in a dazzling light to brighten the darkness. I think it’s a good name for your new friend. Now come on, lets go show her off to the world.”

I shrugged my arms into the bag, wearing it like a backpack before taking her hand and heading off towards town.

“Won’t people know I’m a monster summoner if they see her?”

“Nah, anyone can tame a Dagal if they want, it’s just incredibly hard to either find them or get them to come to you if you don’t know how to deal with them. I’ve seen a few Hunter’s and even a few regular people with them.”

“Oh. I thought all monsters were bad.”

“Most of them are. But like with everything, you get good things mixed with the bad as well. Some Hunter’s think they need to kill every monster simply because it’s a monster, but most of us have an unspoken rule that we kill only the ones that threaten humanity. Even if it’s a big nasty creature like a troll or a giant. If the troll or giant or whatever stays in it’s part of the wilds and doesn’t harm humans why go out of the way to find and kill it? This job is dangerous for us Hunter’s too you know.”

“Then why do you do it?”

“So people like you can live safe and free. Able to enjoy life and all the things we have managed to create in this civilization of ours. people go to sleep easy at night knowing no monster is lurking right outside their door. Or not afraid they have to run and hide in a cave because something big mean and scary comes crashing through town. That’s because the people know we Hunter’s are protecting them from all of that. That’s why we do it, for the people.”

“When I learn to control my powers will I be able to help people like that?”

“I’m sure you will be able to. And I’m sure you will be amazing at it if that is what you want to do.”

As we passed the movie theater she pointed up at it excitedly. When I looked I saw the highlighted title film called Freedom Pony.

“I want to see that one! The first one was about this horse that got captured in the wild but refused to be broken. Then when she finally got free she came back to captivity and allowed herself to be tamed because she bonded with a little boy. The second one was bout her fowl growing up in captivity wanting to be free and finally got his wish at the very end. That’s the third in the series!”

“Whoa there! Hold your horses! I have no clue what you are talking about. Last time I went to see a movie was about six months ago and that was because I was bored and not because I was really interested. So tell you what, we can come see it tomorrow if you want.”

“Really!”

“Yes really. But first we need to have your birthday party and your present opening. So come on scoot yourself onward! You got a cake to cut missy.”

She began to hum happily and the Dagal on her shoulder stretched out her neck to croon along as well. I grinned to myself as we rounded the corner and entered one of the many diners I frequented to be greeted with hearty hello’s and few exclamations of surprise at the tamed monster on her shoulder. The creature seemed to preen under the attention, eliciting laughs from both me and the little girl. Watching Asala I felt like a big brother again. For the first time I felt like I wasn’t alone in the world and had a real family.
11112111222112222.title: Eat first

111121112221122221.content:
“So you filled with all that sugary goodness?”

“Yeah..”

“Did you enjoy yourself?”

“Yeah.”

“So tell me, are you as afraid of your powers now?”

“Nuh-uh. How’d you know I was afraid of them?”

“A lucky guess.”

“Hey, um Riktal, can I call you big brother? Because you feel and act kind of like daddy but not as old.”

“Well I guess I should be grateful for that. I don’t know if I want to be seen or felt as old for a while yet. But if you want you can. Because being with you makes me feel like I’m a big brother again.”

“I love you!”

She suddenly stopped walking to wrap her arms around my waist, burying her head in my stomach. Etoile gave a small squawk of indignation as she balanced herself on Asala’s shoulder. I could see a few eyes from random passerby’s turning and smiling at us but I ignored them as unimportant. Gently I stroked her hair as I let a small smile creep onto my face.

“I love you too little one. Now on to the next place.”

“So adorable!”

I turned at the high pitched squeal to find two of the girls from my class standing there watching us. I knew them by face if not by name, wishing I was better with people my own age so I could get them to go away nicely. I really didn’t want to deal with this right now. Asala clung to me as the two girls came closer, a slight tremor showing she was still a little afraid.

“I thought you looked pretty mean at school but you’re really a big softie aren’t you! She’s so cute! Is she your little sister? And look she has a Dagal for a pet! Ohhh I want one too! They look so adorable!”

“I’m on a job now ladies. Her name is Asala and you will meet her formally tomorrow since she will be wherever I go. But for now could you please go away? This is a special private time for just me and her. She’s unused to this area and scared of people, you are not helping her right now.”

“Then wouldn’t being around more people help her get over her fear?”

“You know what? Let me make it more plain since my attempt at being nice failed. Go away. This is not a request, it is an order. I am not a big softie like you think I am. I will not hesitate to hurt you to get you to leave. Your presence is not required nor wanted here. Is that plain enough for even simpletons like you to understand? Come on Asala, time to go shopping.”

I took her hand, crossing the street and leaving the two girls to stare after us in shock. Rubbing my eyes under my glasses I let out a sigh as they faded from sight. What was it about people around my age that made them so stupid? Girls seemed to be especially prone to these bouts of intense stupidity when babies, animals or cute things were involved. It was like all their common sense just shot out the window.

“Just so you know Asala, if you ever grow up to be like those girls in five or six years, I’m not going to admit to knowing you.”

“They were just trying to be nice.”

“Ah Asala, I envy you your innocence. If they were regular people that might be the case. Vapid, sappy and stupid perhaps, but still with only good intentions. But that’s not the way the world of Hunter’s works. There is always hidden agenda’s behind everything. Who you become friends with is more important than actually having friends. Because who you know can make or break you as a Hunter. They were going all sappy over you but they were also doing it in the hopes of spending time with us, or more specifically me. Thinking I will fall for one of them, meaning their status would shoot sky high because they were dating a Zelkov. It’s a bunch of politics.”

“If that’s the case I don’t allow you to go out with any of them!”

“I wasn’t planning on it shrimp. But why so vehement about it all of a sudden?”

“Because you’re going to marry me when I get older!”

“Oh and just who decided this now? And when?”

“I did just now.”

“Well isn’t that against the rules? I mean if I’m your big brother and all.”

“We aren’t blood related so it’s fine. Besides you are only like a big brother, not my real big brother.”

“You’re too quick for me, I just can’t keep up. But we shall see if you still feel that way in four or five years once you get done with your training. That is four or five years you will be away from me mind you. And time where you will make new friends and meet new boys.”

“Nope. I decided and no one is changing my mind!”

“You’re a brat.”

She grinned up at me with a smile that lit up her entire face as I ruffled her hair and continued walking. Soon enough we came to the clothing store and I told her to go to town. She was bit hesitant at first, picking out a plain white dress from the half off rack.

“Is that really something you want?”

“Y-yeah.”

“I don’t think it is. Excuse me Sales lady! Can you show us some of your nicest dresses in a red color? Something to match her eyes. Oh and shoes to match as well. If they are on sale that’s fine but if not I’ve got no problems. Money is not a question, just don’t try to rip me off too badly ok?”

“Of course sir Hunter. If you and the young lady would follow me I’ll show you some things you might like.”

After that it didn’t take long for Asala to get into the shopping mood I had found almost all girls seemed to love. She tried on dress after dress as I commented on each and made appreciative sounds. She made me turn round though when she bought new underwear, but I watched her in the mirror anyway. After a few hours of shopping we left the store with four bags loaded with stuff. The sales lady had also gotten a nice tip from me for her services, a fact that seemed to make her extra happy.

The clock was striking eight and Asala was yawning by the time we got back to the house. I wasted no time in shooing her up to take a bath and get ready for bed even as I followed a moment later to get the room ready. As the water began to run in the bathroom I stripped off my clothes, throwing on some fresh ones before hanging my school uniform up. I could take a bath tomorrow, right now it would be best to spend as much time with the girl as possible to further cement that bond of trust between us.

It would be hard to see her leave in a few days, but tomorrow I would need to start gently creating a bit of distance to make that easier on the both of us. I hadn’t meant to get so close to begin with, but feeling like a big brother again had made spoiling her so much easier. In the end she was just a job. When she left I needed to simply fade away as a happy memory for her so she could get on with her life instead of chasing after a dream and getting hurt.

“Brother, is it wrong that I’m happy right now?”

Turning towards the door I saw Etoile rubbing against Asala’s face as the girl hugged her teddy bear tightly. Sitting on the bed I patted the covers next to me with a grin. She hurried over and sat down, snuggling into the crook of my arm.

“Do you not want to be happy right now? It’s fine to be happy if your happy and sad when you are sad. That’s just how life is. You can’t be sad all the time or happy all the time or angry or scared. If you aren’t happy isn’t that like you are saying you had wished this day had never happened? Or that it was all pointless? It doesn’t mean your parents should have died or makes your feelings for them any less real because you enjoyed yourself today. It simply means you are able to appreciate the good things that have happened to you. Not every day is going to be like this one. Just like not every day is going to be as bad as the day your parents died. You understand what I’m saying?”

She nodded her head against me as she clutched me tightly her voice dropping down a notch.

“I miss them. Am I going to forget them?”

“No sweetie. You will never forget them. It will get easier with time, but as long as you live you will remember them. Here give me your bear for a moment.”

She handed me her bear slowly, as if afraid to let it go.

“Your parents gave this to you didn’t they?”

“Yeah”

With a nod I coated it in my magic, using my special ability to imprint her parents into the bear. I could feel the blood running down my nose by the time I was finished but ignored it. Once done I handed it back to her while wiping the liquid from my face.

“Go to sleep thinking of your parents while holding that bear and you will see them. I’ll explain it all to you tomorrow. Just know that it is a special magic similar to your summoning ability.”

She climbed under the covers while the Dagal settled herself on the headrest. After turning out the lights I slipped in beside her, pulling her in close a she closed her eyes.

“No touching me inappropriately until we are married.”

With a grin I kissed her on the forehead while she chuckled at her joke.

“Goodnight shrimp.”

**********

Our tale draws to a close yet again. Or perhaps this is the first time for you? You have been here so many times in so many possibilities it is hard for even I to keep track of them all. Again and again you relive this day over and over. Each time making new choices, walking different paths. Tell me? Have you found the answers you are looking for? Have you gained insight into who you are and the way you view the world?

On my part I have learned much while watching you. Many of my personal questions have been answered, yet still more arise to the surface. Is this the nature of you humans? Constantly in a spiral of wanting to know more and seeking the answers to those questions you have? If so then this is an intriguing turn of events. Perhaps next time I shall delve into the concepts behind these emotion things you have. Adios traveler, until you come again to relive this day.
111121112221122221.title: After the party

1111211122212.content:
