It was best if I just kept my mouth shut and my head down. With my quick temper and my lack of any real social skills when it came to kids my own age, volunteering was just asking for trouble.

“I’ll go. It gets me out of doing nothing. Besides if the creep wakes up I can sock him in the face hard enough to put him back under. That will be for my own personal desires though, not for his betterment.”

The Arena Master nodded at Liz as she headed out the door with the still unconscious Gregory slung over her shoulder like a sack of flour and the other four close behind. The teacher got everyone regrouped and reorganized, sending two more groups out onto the field to continue practicing after giving them a small heads up on what they were going to face and how to handle it. I stood next to him, watching as the battles began and he manipulated his magical box, recording data and other statistics.

“Thanks for assisting back there. I was a bit far away to react in time. I took my eyes off them for only a moment to answer a question. I even warned them what they would fight and what not to do. I thought they were all ready for something easy like that. I guess I was wrong.”

“Not your fault. They would have been fine if you hadn’t paired them with Gregory. But you know what they say, there’s no cure for stupid. You can teach those who lack knowledge, and enlighten those who are misinformed. But being stupid like that is a choice. You can’t cure it if they don’t want to be cured.”

“Unfortunately that’s true. He’s not the first one like that I’ve seen come through here. Nor is he the first Hunter I’ve fought beside like that. It’s my job to train it out of them if I can, but some just don’t want to learn. Just between you and me, I give him another year, maybe two tops before he winds up getting himself or one of his comrades killed. I really don’t see him graduating though. By the way, is it true what your file says? You passed the mock Exams as an A class?”

“It’s true. And got about half the points I would have needed to hit S class. Though I never really thought I would get it anyway. Only one in fifty ever make S class.”

“Still that’s some feat. I capped out at the low end of the A spectrum before I began working here. Worked with your dad years ago, he saved my life back then. I’m actually honored to have his son in my class. Though don’t think that will get you any special privileges.”

“Never crossed my mind. You are the Arena Master. You have to be impartial and strict because you are the one who decides if the students are ready or not. If you play favorites that could end up with one or hundreds dying. Your job isn’t to send them out to die, but to send them out to survive.”

“Glad you understand. Think you could lend a hand in the Arena as a deputy instructor of sorts from time to time? Mostly just combat demonstration and the like but if something like this happens again I’d like another set of eyes and hands if possible. I’ve asked Hawthrop but she declined. I’m actually supposed to have a real one but because of funding cuts no one seems to want the job.”

“I don’t mind. Hunter’s helping each other out from time to time is part of the code after all. It will keep me in shape as well. Only so much sparring I can do alone at home.”

“Glad to hear it. Think you could stick around for next period? I’ve got a group of seniors coming in and I plan on pitting them against some A class mobs. With another A class Hunter here I can split them into two groups at once instead of one group at a time.”

The two groups on the field killed their monster and switched out for the next two groups. I waited until the teacher was done fiddling with his black box and adjusting whatever it was he was doing before continuing on.

“Somehow I feel like I just got suckered into something here but I don’t mind. Next class is History and I really won’t learn anything new there.”

“Yeah from what’s in your file you wouldn’t. I’m actually a bit surprised you are even in this academy. I would have thought with your record you would have taken the real Exams by now and got your license. Why are you here anyway if you don’t mind my asking?”

“It’s complicated.”

“Fair enough. I’ll let your History teacher know where you are. Who is it? Mr. Ghetz or Holiday?”

“Ghetz.”

“I’ll send him a quick text after this.”

I walked away, taking a seat on the empty benches against the wall as I continued to watch what was going on. Making a mental skill chart for each person in the class. Such things were just near automatic for me anymore. After about three or four more minutes as the two groups finally killed their monster, Liz and the others came back without Gregory. They told the Arena Master the nurses verdicts to bench them all for a day or two as Liz came to sit next to me. The teacher nodded his head a moment before the four sat on benches nearby as well.

“Unfortunately the little bugger didn’t wake up.”

“Well from his perspective it seems fortunate.”

We sat in silence for a bit watching the groups, the two of us having our own little bubble space no one wanted to intrude upon.

“The teacher asked me to be a sub instructor. Said he asked you but you declined.”

“Yeah, seemed like too much hassle at the time. I didn’t want to be here at this school to begin with so I felt no need to play nice so to speak. Now I’m regretting not taking him up on the offer. I see I’ve gotten more than a bit lax after watching you. I need to get back into shape and catch up.”

“Want me to let him know you’re willing to sub in for me sometimes?”

“Would he go for it?”

“Don’t see why not. If most of the time it is just a knowledgeable partner to showcase combat moves, you would do as well as I. Plus it gives him a wider array of options and experiences to chose from.”

“Well if he’s agreeable then I’ll do it. I’ve got a feeling school will be a lot more interesting with you around.”

“Be careful what you wish for.”

The bell rang then, and everyone headed off back to the locker rooms. I threw my Lexington back in the bag. If there were going to be A class monsters I wanted something with a bit more oomph. My gun was nice and all but it wasn’t the best for A class beasts. My Roller Knuckles would do the job, but I would prefer something that had both short range and long range utility. Only the third phase of my fist weapons would apply there. Reaching inside I pulled out a sword handle with a large green stone inset into the pommel with a grin.

As the other boys began to file out I quickly sent a jolt of magic into the stone, activating the artifact which grew from the end until it was a six foot long double sided barbarian blade I slung on my back and kept there with a touch of magic. It had been a while since I had used this sword I had affectionately named The Eviscerater. It was nothing like the ten foot long version my father swung around, but it got the job done. Locking up my other weapons I strode out the door to wait in the Arena just as the first few seniors came walking in. They gave me a few sideways looks but otherwise ignored me. That was fine, I’d see what they were made of soon enough.
1111211122212.title: Don't volunteer

11112111222121.content:
“Tank! Get that shield up! Don’t wait for it to attack! Be there before it does and brace! Caster! Push the damage a little more! Don’t be afraid of grabbing agro from the thing! That’s what the tank is there for! To keep it’s eyes off you while you push out the pain! Dual swords! Where the hell are you looking? As a melee you need to be aware of your surroundings! Otherwise you might get in the way of someone else!”

I threw up my right hand, placing the palm against the flat of the blade while bracing my leg to catch the swipe of one of the Spidlar’s six claws. Even digging in it still pushed me back, sending dust flying from my heels.

“Sonic Shock!”

The tank raised his shield and smashed it into the ground, sending out a wave against the monster that looked like a giant black widow spider had attached itself to the back of a seven foot grey troll. It’s rear abdomen twitched as it rocked backwards to squirt acidic web at us. The tank’s shockwave hit the attack in mid flight, sending it back at the creature seconds before the wave hit it.

“Magma Eruption!”

The caster’s spell brought a mini volcano into existence that shot out flaming balls of magma as if they were launched from a mortar. The four shells fell from the sky even as the beast created a shield with his webs and held it over his head. The dual sword wielder took that opportunity to jump forward with both swords crossed in front of him in preparation for a double cross slash.

“Mana!”

“On it!”

Already the female gunner was throwing out a lasso of magic to grab the guy in mid air, yanking him back seconds before the beast would have impaled him on a sword of acidic webbing.

Damnit what did I say! Fall back and cool your head! Gorin! Get in here! You too Sally! Take over for the tank! Caster and gunner! Lay down suppressing fire!”

As the boy with the two swords ran off the field a boy that looked like a linebacker for a football team came running in, a crossbow attached to the back of his left arm. He had a loader attached to the inner area of his right arm filled with small rocks. As he placed his right hand over his left a rock dropped in, turning into an arrow even as he cocked back the string and sent it flying. Arrow after arrow he sent in rapid succession at the monster, hitting the web shield a few times before he snapped his fingers causing the tips to explode, shattering the shield. The caster and gunner then began attacking in earnest now that the shield was gone.

The new tank Sally flung her buckler at the beast smacking it in the head before it returned to her like a boomerang. The beast turned it’s attention on her even as she flicked her sword, turning it into a whip and sending the tip towards the Spidlar. The tip impaled itself in the creatures chest as the girl jumped and retracted the extended sword, flinging towards the beast at an amazing speed. At the last moment she spun in the air, dodging a claw strike to smash her shield into the side of it’s face while pulling the tip out and scoring a shallow gash across the chest as she landed behind it. The other tank backed off, retreating to the sidelines with a bit of sweat on his face.

“Gunner! Caster! Fall back! You should be at about your limit right now. Get the other Caster in here and the Halberd user! We’ll finish it off!”

As the two girls ran off the field another two guys ran on, one with metal clawed hands he used to cast his spells and one with a giant staff with an overlarge blade on one end.

“Halberd! On me! Hit it from the top! Tank get ready to pull it back to you! Caster start hitting it with a glacier! Crossbow! Unleash your strongest attack right before Halberd hits! Phase two activate! Triple juggler!”

As the guy with the staff ran towards me I grabbed the hilt in both hands, sliding it down and splitting the weapon in two down the middle but not pulling it apart yet. Bracing my legs I held the flat of the blade towards the boy. He leapt, planting his foot on the sword face as I heaved upward, throwing him as high as I could into the air as he sailed over the monster. The creature spit more webbing upwards to attack him but I had already flung one part of my blade into the path, blocking the attack before yanking it back towards me with a rope of magic.

The third foot long blade that had been hidden inside the two halves of the sword began to drop as if in slow motion. Flinging the six foot long half of the blade in my left hand after the boy in the air I kicked the dagger back upwards, grabbing it with my now empty left hand on the backswing just as the half I had used to block the spit with smacked into my right palm. Throwing the dagger a fraction of a second after the other part of the sword I spun and flung the last piece as well just as the boy began his decent towards the face.

“Crossbow now!”

“Harpies Fury!”

A rain of at least ten arrows, each one coated with a different element sped towards the beast, smashing into it seconds before the boy came down, slicing deeply into the hard flesh. My three swords which had stopped and floated where the boy had been began to circle, awaiting my commands.

“Mimicry!”

The three blades bent downwards, morphing into halberds that sped to the ground with the same force and speed as the original, creating three more deep wounds, one even severing two arms on the right side.

“Heaven’s vengeance!”

A bright orange light shot from the tanks shield, hitting the beast before getting sucked back in, causing it to resume it’s attack on the woman. The ability transferred all the agro from everyone else over to her for a short period of time. Meaning everything we had just done, the monster thought the tank had done it all. Just as she raised her shield to block three swords made of acid web the air around the creature began to condense as everyone backed away.

Blocks of ice began to form then merge on either side, creating two huge walls of clear frozen water. They slid across the floor, closing together with the Spidlar caught between them. They smashed together with a loud boom before melting away and disappearing. The beast wasn’t dead yet though. It’s insides were hanging out of the deep cuts, the skull and most of its bones were crushed, yet still it had some fight in it. Such was the power and difficulty of an A class.

“Phase two! Shell Cracker! Pierce the heavens! Tiger shot!”

A blinding bolt of pure power whizzed from the crossbowman. As it flew it split into three and then three again, before swirling around each other, taking on the face of a giant tiger with mouth wide open. The attack hit and the tiger bit down, eating a giant hole through the Spidlar before vanishing. The monster let out a cry before toppling over, breaking up and dissolving into thin air before it finished hitting the ground. It left behind a shell in the shape of the black widow abdomen, the item as hard as steel.

The tank picked it up and held it up high as wild cheering broke out not only from the group I was helping but also the group the Arena Master had been training. The treasure from such a high level monster would be taken by the teacher to be appraised and the rewards split between those who had helped defeat it. One of the reasons I had made sure to switch out so everyone got a chance to fight a little bit. With a flick of my fingers my three blades flew back through the air towards me, returning to their phase one by the time I grabbed it and swung it over my shoulder. In high spirits and fist pounding each other we returned to the sidelines.

“Nice work out there Zelkov. We finished ours a few moments ago. Just in time to see your group give it the finishing blow. I think this class has a newfound respect for you and your abilities.”

The sixteen kids all around nodded their heads in agreement of the teachers words. The group I had been leading all looked at each other before stepping forward and bowing to me deeply. Sally took another step forward with a grin.

“I think I speak for all of our group when I say it was an honor being led by you. I was able to learn a lot from that fight. Please teach us again next time.”

“Hey no fair! I want to be in his group next time!”

“Yeah me too! Don’t hog all the fun!”

As I nodded my head to all of them I saw my mother walking towards me with a four and a half foot tall girl trailing long white hair and crimson eyes being pulled along behind her. The girl seemed unaware of her surrounding’s with her blank look but she was still clutching an old teddy bear to her lime green dress that didn’t look good on her at all.

“Riktal darling, can we talk privately for a bit?”

The Arena Master gave her a nod of respect when he noticed her.

“Mrs. Zelkov, you can use one of the locker rooms if you wish. I’ll make sure no one bother’s you.”
11112111222121.title: Senior's Combat class

111121112221211.content:
“I think we will take you up on your offer Arena Master. I’m sure my mother has a very busy schedule and would like to get on with her day as soon as possible. Being able to use such a nearby room will facilitate that nicely.”

The teacher gave a nod of his head as I led my mother to the men’s locker room. It honestly didn’t matter which one we used but it was the closest one, that’s why I picked it. My mother pushed the little girl down on one of the benches before doing a quick check of the room for security reasons.

“You looked good out there. You commanded with confidence and you let them do most of the work. You have a knack for teaching.”

“Spare me. You and father trained me in all aspects of how to be a Hunter. From doing the grunt work to leading other slayer’s. You know very well how good I am and what my skills are.”

“Your right. Still that doesn’t make seeing you in action any less impressive.”

“Impressive enough to make you change your mind about letting me take the Exams?”

She didn’t say anything to that, simply got a slightly sad look on her face I dismissed as my mother pretending to care about me in some way.

“I thought not. So really your observation was pointless. Wasn’t that what you taught me? Doing and saying pointless things is a waste of time and breath better put to other things?”

“It’s called conversation and common courtesy.”

“Both of which you never applied to me to begin with so why start now? Just get to the point so you can be off saving the world again in some other country for another week or month or year or whatever it is this time. Finding something to catch your fancy for a day or two before you discard it again. I suppose I should feel honored that you keep coming back to me after I get discarded.”

“Riktal…”

Her voice trailed off as if she didn’t know how to reply to my accusations. It wasn’t like anything I had said was wrong though, it had all been the truth. She had never had time for me, always gone for weeks at a time on some job or another. She would come home for a few hours, half a day at the most, before running off someplace else. She never treated me like her son, even when I was a kid, simply training me as a Hunter before running off again. I couldn’t even remember the last time she or father had actually been around for a holiday or a birthday. The baby-sitters and nannies I had grown up with had only been there to make sure I didn’t kill myself and continued my training regimes when my parents weren’t around. Even at that I felt more for them than I did for my parents.

“No. Never mind. I don’t want to argue with you right now. I do have some important business to discuss and arguing with you won’t make it any easier. I’ve been thinking of how to approach you about this but no way seems to be a good way so I will just come right out and say it. This girl’s name is Asala and she is a monster summoner. I want you to protect her for the next few days until someone I know can come pick her up. She lost her parents three days ago which is what prompted her power to suddenly manifest. They are unstable right now and she can’t control them.

“As you can see, she has run into her head and won’t come out even though me and my aides have tried to coax her. We’ve sustained her on magic since she refuses to eat or sleep even when we force feed her. We can get her to swallow if we massage her throat but she somehow even shut down the reflexive muscles of her body. Even the ones controlling her bladder, which is why we put her in diapers. You’ve got that special way with kids that I don’t. If anyone could get her out of her shell it’s you.”

“It’s not special in any way mother. It’s a skill that anyone can learn and master. Even you if you really cared to try. True it might be fake coming from you, but you’re good at faking things aren’t you? After all you have the world fooled into thinking that you’re a real mother. Take her to Pelei, or even Arven. Both of them have no problems with summoners.”

“I already went to Pelei and he will do it, but my gut said not to hand her over to him if I don‘t have to. Arven’s a good guy and all but he’s not the most stellar of Hunter’s. I at least know you would be able to handle anything she might bring forth and you wouldn’t sell her out for the right price like Arven might. You would protect her with everything you had despite her having cursed blood, even if the entire world turned against you.”

“Their blood isn’t cursed mother. Just like a priest or priestesses blood isn’t cursed. She simply uses her magic in a unique way. She is no different than you or I. I know you tolerate them but I also know you wouldn’t shed a tear if one of them died either. It’s that kind of ignorance and fear from an old generation Hunter that makes other Hunter’s continue to think that way. You need to ask yourself if you would think the same way if it was you with that power. Or what if I had a cursed blood power? If you can’t honestly say you would think the same way as you do now then you need to change your thinking. And you can start by not calling them cursed.”

“I don’t have time to get sucked into a theological debate with you on whether people with special magic’s are cursed or not. Will you do it or not? And if you do it I want you to continue to go to school. Your being here Is very important, though I can’t explain why right now.”

My desire to say no simply to spite my mother warred with my obligation to protect an innocent. I didn’t have to take the job since I was already assured she could and would be taken care of otherwise. If I said no my mother would dump her on Pelei. He wouldn’t focus much on pulling her out of her shell, simply treat her even more like a doll. But she would be safe.

Then there was the fact that she probably wanted to die right now. Or at least a part of her did. If she didn’t come out of her shell soon her body would eat itself up and she would get her wish. But unlike everyone else in the world who seemed to think a person had to live I had no problem with suicide and assisted deaths.

Living was a choice that everyone made. All that crap about life is worth living and there is meaning in existing didn’t mean much in the face of the pain that living could cause. Forcing someone who wanted to die to continue to live was a cruel thing to do. Simply stoking their own ego and pushing their own views onto others. No one had to live for whatever reason someone cared to name. The whole argument of the devout that The One God would send them to hell or wouldn’t love them anymore was another bunch of crock in my opinion. Did not the book say all were his children and he loved all equally? Without exceptions. So did I have any right to pull her out of her shell and force her to live?

What was the best choice for the girl? Coming with me where I would pull her out of her shell and she would live even if she didn’t want to. Where she would also be subjected to greater dangers because of my mother’s insistence on me coming to school, giving her powers more chances to run amok in public and hurt untold number of innocent people. Or going to Pelei where she might get her wish to die but she would be safe from the world. Her chance of summoning monsters from fear or anxiety or anything else of that nature would be greatly reduced, also protecting hundreds of innocents in the process.
111121112221211.title: Use a locker room

1111211122212111.content:
Ignoring my mother for the moment I kneeled in front of the girl, searching her face for any clue as to what she wanted.

“Asala. If you can hear me then I want you to know what this boils down to. If you go to Pelei you will be safe but nothing will change from how it is right now. Your body will break down soon from lack of real food and water and you will die. If that’s what you really want then I won’t stop you by accepting this job. Your desire will come true if you go to Pelei. But if your desire to live is stronger then your desire to die then let me know somehow and I will accept this job. You don’t have to do anything fancy like blink your eyes or nod your head. Just any small reaction will do.”

There was no reaction at all. She continued to stare blankly at me even as I let out a sigh and turned my head to look at my mother.

“Well she decided. She wants to die, send her to Pelei.”

I felt the weight of the sword on my back as I stood up, absently deactivating it with another zap of power into the pommel. As I began to turn the girls arm shot up to grab my tunic, keeping me from moving away. She still had that expressionless face and nothing else about her had moved, as if the right arm had come up on its own to grab me. I kept my face just as expressionless as I turned to my mother again with a shrug.

“Guess she changed her mind, she want’s to live. I’ll take the job. Though if I feel her being here at school is too much of a danger to her or the other kids I won’t come. Twenty thousand Reul as well, on top of my living allowance of course. I assume you want this all done under the table?”

“If possible. Though isn’t twenty thousand a bit steep?”

“It’s the highest I can go for a job like this without a license and a bit extra for being under the table. I still have the option of saying no and you can still take her to Pelei if you don’t like my price. Though knowing him he would probably want almost double that.”

“Geez, I should never have taught you how to bargain. You’re going to bankrupt me.”

“I’m sure the small nation you could start with the family funds is crying right now. Do we have a deal or not?”

“We’ve got a deal. I’ll have the money transferred over into your account by the end of the day. I really appreciate this Riktal darling.”

“Whatever. Now that your business with me is done I’m sure you’ve got to run off someplace else.”

“I really do want to spend more time with you darling. And I promise I will soon. But my schedule is just so busy.”

“Don’t make promises you don’t intend to keep, it’s unbecoming.”

My mother came over and kissed me on each cheek before wrapping me in a hug. I simply stood as solid as a board waiting for her to let me go. I knew this was some ploy for a long ranging scheme. She didn’t show real affection ever. Simply putting on a mask of emotion to fool people and ensnaring them into her plots. Her voice tickled my ear as she whispered into it though while she hugged me.

“You were planning on accepting the job from the beginning. I saw it in your eyes and body language. You simply played it out like that to manipulate the girl for your own ends. You get angry at me for doing things like that but it seems you aren’t so different.”

I let my lips barely move next to her ear, returning her whisper in kind.

“You’re wrong there is a difference. I did it because it will help her in the long run, not for my own personal gain.”

With that I pushed her away from me, returning my attention to the girl who was still holding onto my tunic with her tiny hand. My mother slipped out of the room as I sat next to the girl, pulling her into my side while giving her a small squeeze of reassurance.

“I’m sure a part of you thinks you made the wrong move but it was a choice that you decided on. How many things in your life lately can you say you were able to control? You couldn’t control your parent’s dying, you can’t control your powers, you can’t control being pulled all around to new places and new people. I’m not surprised you hid inside your head, it was one of the few decisions you were able to make to control your own life.

“Living isn’t easy kid. You find there are a lot of things you have no control over that you wish you did. The trick to it though is to make decisions you can accept when you have the chance to do so. I won’t say something as thoughtless as live with no regrets, because there will always be things you regret, even when you believe you made all the best choices. Because there will always be this ever present question floating in the back of your head saying what if.”

I began to absently stroke her hair as I stared off into the empty locker room.

“I had a little sister you know. She died three years ago right in front of me. I think I was the best big brother I could be to her and I loved her more than life itself. But even to this day I ask myself that insidious little question. What if I had acted sooner? What if I had kept her from leaving? What if I had focused more on training her as a Hunter and less on treating her like a little girl? Could I have prevented it from happening? Would she still be alive today? Would it still hurt so much inside? Was I right in loving her as much as I did?”

I looked down when I felt a slight movement at my side to see the girl staring up at me with those big round orbs of hers. She didn’t say anything, simply blinked at me a moment before tears began to well up in her eyes. Reaching around she clung to my chest, burying her face in my tunic and began to cry. I simply stroked her hair and made soft comforting sounds while rocking her gently. The bell rang and a few boys walked in. They saw me sitting there and turned around to walk back out without a word. After that no one interrupted us.

She finally settled down after about five more minutes and pushed away from me slowly. I gave her a small smile which she returned hesitantly while I gave her hair another stroke.

“There, feel a bit better? I think you needed a good cry to let out some of that hurt. It doesn’t make the pain go away, that will stay for a long while to come. But it makes it more bearable for a bit. Now how about we get out of here huh? I think we are holding up classes.”

She gave me a nod of agreement before I went over to my locker to pick up my weapons. Holding out my hand she took it a bit shyly before we headed for the door. Outside the seniors were all waiting around patiently, holding back the next class from entering as well. They bowed their heads respectfully to me and the girl before finally entering the locker room. I let the Arena Master know I would be indisposed of for the next few days and why his next class was behind, a fact he already knew because a senior had told him.

We caused a minor stir when the two of us entered the Monster Tactics class but nothing too major. Asala stuck to me like glue, gripping my hand and her teddy bear so hard I was surprised neither one exploded from the pressure. There were a few sidelong glances at the two of us, but for the most part we were ignored which was just the way I wanted it. Asala even seemed to find the lesson interesting, listening with rapt attention to the teacher talking about Cawmacaw birds and Cadaver Dogs.

When the final bell rang I gathered up my stuff, offering the girl my hand just as four girls began heading towards us. Liz stepped in and caught their attention, nodding with her head for me to leave. I gave her a wink and a nod of thanks of my own as I led the girl away from the gaggle. I could hear Liz telling the girls not to get to close to someone on a job like that. Reminding them how I had asked them to stay away.

Once out in the hall I looked down at the little girl. Those were probably the only clothes she had. Some shopping would do her good, but I also needed to get her more comfortable around me and the town in general. Make her feel a bit like she was a part of this place instead of simply being dragged around and not knowing anything.
1111211122212111.title: Take job

11112111222121111.content:
“Come on Asala, if you’re going to be around for the next few days, I think you need to get a bit familiar with this town. Let you feel like you are really home, even if you aren’t. Just stick close to me and nothing bad will happen, that’s a promise.”

She nodded her head slowly, not quite completely trusting my words but at least willing to give me the benefit of the doubt. We went to the second intersection before turning left to go into town, all the while I pointed out small landmarks and interesting things of note. Such as the old troll hut under one of the bridges over the river and a small shrine to a fox monster people had worshiped as a god hundreds of years ago.

Such things were preserved as reminders of where we had come from as a race, the folly of our pasts and cautions for our future. I told her some stories of the town as it had grown from a simple small farming village into the mini metropolis it was today while she seemed to hang onto every word. People saw us and waved or gave hearty greetings which I returned absently. I was a well known face around town, and even if they didn’t know me personally they recognized me as a Hunter at the least. At first Asala clung closely to me, shivering slightly in fear at the number of people. But when nothing happened and a few of the sidewalk candy stands even offered her free candy she slowly loosened up.

“I’ve got a lot of time on my hands and I don’t always like sitting around in my stuffy old house all alone. So I’m pretty well known around here. I bet just about half the businesses know me on a first name basis if not more. They are seeing that you are with me, so if the worst were to happen and you get lost somehow, they will protect you until I can come get you ok?”

She nodded her head in agreement, though clung even tighter to my shirt as if trying to convey that she wasn’t planning on getting lost. With a grin I ruffled her hair a bit just as I heard a loud shout. I glanced up looking far off down the sidewalk to see a little boy of seven years old running up to me gleefully. He jumped up when he got close enough and I caught him with a grin while he gave me a quick hug. Lifting him up I sat him on my shoulders as his mother and father came over to us with a grin.

“Riktal! It’s a bit of a surprise to see you here.”

The boys father reached over and grabbed his son from his position, placing him on his broad shoulders instead.

“I was just showing Asala here a bit of the town. Asala, I’d like you to meet Mimsy and her husband Markus. The ball of energy on Markus’ shoulders is Bilbin. They own a small restaurant on the other side of town called Whimsical Mimsy’s. They serve some of the best home made cakes in the city.”

Mimsy grinned, squatting down while looking at the girl who shuffled in a bit closer to me.

“Well if you have Riktal looking after you I doubt you have anything to worry about. He might downplay himself at times and he has a bit of a tsundere attitude, but he has a heart of gold. It’s not too much of a stretch to say he single handedly helped me keep my business open when I was in a tight spot. Not to mention when Bilbin got lost in the woods outside the city he was the first Hunter to react, going out in search for him at least an hour before anyone else. And because of that quick action he saved my son from a nasty snake monster.”

“Riktal’s awesome! I’m going to become a Hunter just like him when I grow up!”

The girl’s eyes grew a bit larger as she looked from the boy then back at me as if she couldn’t believe her ears.

“I don’t know what you were thinking about me but I’m not that much of a big bad meanie. You just happened to see and hear me at a bad time.”

We stood there in the street chatting for a few moments and exchanging some random bits of news. This was part of how I kept informed about everything that was happening in the city, gathering these bits of information while I exchanged pleasantries. Just as we said our farewells and we were about to move on, a small red circle appeared on the side of the building next to us. When a green goblin arm reached out I nonchalantly walked over and kicked the monster in the face as it began to climb out, sending it back through the hole before it closed up again.

There was a moment of silence as the three stared in shock at Asala who had run and hid behind my legs. I put a hand comfortingly on her head as Bilbin slid down Markus’ back and ran up to the girl.

“That was awesome! Can you do it again! Can you make something cool appear!”

Mimsy came forward and pulled her son away, telling him to keep his voice down or he would attract attention. She gave Asala another smile as Bilbin finally sank into silence.

“Don’t worry sweetie we will keep your secret. Not everyone blindly hates people like you. I’ll admit we were like that once, but Riktal made us change our minds. You’re just people like me or anyone else. If Riktal is protecting you then you doubly have nothing to fear, He would rather die before letting any harm come to a hair on your head. That’s just the kind of person he is.”

With a parting wave the three of them walked off and Asala watched them go with a look of wonder and surprise all over her face. Pulling her in to my side I gave her a quick rub of reassurance.

“See? Not everyone thinks you are some kind of monster because of your ability. Granted such people are in the minority, but it’s a start right?”

She finally nodded her head as we turned and continued on, grabbing some sweets and finger foods from different stores or stands set up along the sidewalks. As the time passed I saw the tension continue to drain out of her body and a level of comfort replace it. Spotting a bakery down the way I grinned, leading her towards it and opening the door to Sweets for Sweets. The boy behind the counter looked up and saw me giving a grin before calling into the back room that I was here.

An older man in his early fifties came stumping out of the back room, his apron covered in flower and flecks of sparkling magic dust. His wooden peg of a left leg not even slowing him down. With a grin that split his face from ear to ear he brought his big meaty right hand around to meet mine. We clasped each other at the elbow as he greeted me jovially.

“Riktal comrade! Vat a surprise! Vat can I do fer you today!”

Asala let out a little giggle at Freddy’s funny accent. He came from overseas and he hadn’t quite lost all of it. Instead of trying to hide it though he had embraced his difference from everyone else, knowing full well how funny he sounded sometimes. Freddy gave her a sideways look while putting his fists on his hips. But the mock hurt on his face was so obvious even Asala could see he wasn’t offended by her giggle. After a moment he began to chuckle with her.

“Zo little von. You tink my accent iz funny ya? Vell I tink you are looking a bit scrawny. You must eat special donut fer laughing at my accent. I vill not accept any od’er punishment or my name iz not Fredrick Von Lipstinhowzer da third!”

With that he stumped over to one of the racks holding his special magic infused donuts and pulled a cream filled one off the shelf, thrusting it at the girl who took it tentatively and nibbled on it as if afraid of the taste. Both of us began to laugh at her as her eyes lit up and her face transformed into one of pure delight before she bit deeply into the pastry, getting white cream all over her face. Freddy watched her for a moment more before looking back at me.

“Zo Riktal comrade. Vat can I do fer you? You vere just in fer yer new emergency rationz not long ago. I vould like to tink this is just a social vizit but I haf a feeling you are on a job.”

“You’re right, I am on a job. But I’m showing Asala here some of the sights this town has to offer and I thought what better place to bring her than here.”

I nodded my head at the boy behind the counter

“So how is Jarvin over there working out for you?”

“He iz doing fine. He cleanz up well ya? A few good meals in him and a few new clothes and one vould never know he vas once a street imp. I’m glad you found him fer me and I tink he is glad az vell. Though he did not tink so in da beginning ya?”

We both saw Asala sneaking her hand up to grab another donut, grinning to each other as we pretended not to notice, continuing to talk. Freddy told me a few rumors he had heard about the beggar king that ran the east side street imps was making a power play to secure the south side as well. I made a note of this, figuring it was best to send old one-eyed Joe on the south side some help to hold his territory. It wouldn’t due to let one of the four underworld bosses get too strong and control too much of the crime in the city.

“Do you tink da little von vould be interested in seeing how I make da breadz?”

I looked down at Asala who seemed to be in her own personal world of bliss as she savored the donut she had filched. Outside the sun was a bit low in the sky, as the clock rang out that it was four thirty. I still needed to get her some clothes as well today, but I was also sure she would like to learn how he did what he did. She seemed to love learning new things.
11112111222121111.title: Walk around town a bit

111121112221211111.content:
“Sorry Freddy, We still got a few other places to go while there is still light out. Besides, I have a feeling if we stay much longer she will eat you out of business.”

Freddy chuckled as he absently picked out a jelly filled donut and handed it to the girl with a wink. For a moment Asala didn’t know what to do with her bear but finally tucked it down the front of her dress until it’s front paws and head sat under her chin before accepting the second treat.

“If it iz her I vould not mind. She iz vith you after all. I owe you everyting comrade. If you need anyting from me do not hesitate to ask. If it iz in my power I vill do it.”

Just then the bell over the door jangled as Marsa and two other girls from our class came walking in. They all seemed surprised to see me, stopping to stare in surprise for a moment. It was a testament of how much safer Asala felt that she didn’t clutch at me reflexively with her sticky fingers.

“Riktal! I didn’t expect to see you here!”

I gave Marsa a nod of recognition before telling her I was simply showing the girl around. Jarvin blushed when he saw Marsa and hurriedly busied himself behind the counter instead of simply sitting on his stool doing nothing. Marsa didn’t seem to even notice him though as the two girls with her began to gush over how adorable Asala was. When I glanced down I saw she had glaze and cream all around her mouth and a bit on her nose. With a sigh I knelt down and pulled a handkerchief from my side pouch, wetting it with some magic made water and cleaning her up.

“Be a little neater while eating that last donut ok Asala? And it will be your last. I won’t let you get a tummy ache from eating too many of these special pastries. I know they are good and all but that doesn’t mean you can eat as much as you want. You understand?”

She nodded her head as she looked a bit put off that I was cleaning her face but I ignored her look of exasperation. It felt like I was running around town with my little sister again and I didn’t mind at all. I was surprised to find I actually felt really good right now, not even minding the girls making sappy comments about me over my head.

“Riktal are deez young ladiez friends of yours?”

“I wouldn’t call them friends. But they are classmates. I‘m in a good mood right now so treat them well Freddy.”

“Az you vish. Fer today only I shall give dem a half price dizcount on everytink.”

The girls gasped in surprise at the windfall as I put my arm around Asala’s shoulder and led her towards the door. Before I left though I turned around and pointed at Marsa while looking at Freddy.

“Oh this girl here is a pretty good caster. Think you could find your way to getting her some of your special donut holes. You know, the ones that increase magical power? A pack of twelve should last her for a while if she uses them sparingly. She went up against a Glif earlier and she held her own well enough. I was impressed by her performance so I thought she deserved a small token of my respect.”

“Anytink fer you comrade. I shall zee you later.”

I waved off Marsa’s thanks as I left the bakery, feeling better than I had in a long time. As if I was somehow free of an invisible burden I had forgotten I was carrying around. Heading off past the bank that was down the road I made a beeline for a clothing store I knew of a few blocks away with some slightly expensive but good quality clothing. Asala ate the last donut slowly, savoring every last bite as I laughed a bit.

“His pastries and bread are imbued with magic. I’ve seen how he does it but even I’m not sure exactly how he makes it happen. It’s a secret that only he knows and has patented. But there is no denying they are effective. Most of his stuff is like what you just ate, seeming to be a small slice of heaven in every bite. But he has other stuff that can actually help with magic and stamina and such that a Hunter can use in the field. His stuff is usually a bit pricey, but he can get away with selling at a higher price because it is worlds better than anything any other magic cook can do. So did you like that little treat?”

Asala’s head bobbed up and down so hard I thought she would take off into the sky at any moment. But it wasn’t long before she began to fidget around a bit. It took me a moment to figure it out but then I grinned in understanding.

“Ah after three days of your body being sustained on magic, eating real food is doing a number on your digestive system. Think you can hold it for just a few minutes? We’re almost at our destination.”

Her eyes began to tear up as she shook her head no while looking away from me. That was all I needed to know as I scooped her petite four and a half foot frame up in my arms like she weighed nothing to run the last few feet to the store, kicking open the door and dashing to the restroom area. I didn’t even stop at the ladies door, pushing it open and going to the nearest open stall in the empty bathroom before setting her down. Only then did I leave the restroom and stand outside to wait.

“Well that’s certainly one way to make an entrance.”

With a grin I gave the sales lady a wink.

“Hey Sue. I had a bit of an emergency on my hands.”

“Looked more like it was in your hands and not on it. How you doing Riktal honey?”

“Roses and sunshine.”

“Knowing you I bet it’s more like thorns and overcast skies.”

“Surprisingly enough not today. When the little girl comes out we need to outfit her with some new clothes and undergarments. Think you could spare the time to help us?”

“For you honey, anytime.”

“You will keep anything you might see or hear confidential of course. And make sure no one else is near enough to eavesdrop?”

“You wound me if you think I would do any less. I figured you was on a job of some sort. That’s the only time you act like this, disregarding common decency and all.”

Asala came out of the bathroom then and I introduced the two quickly before Sue led us to the women’s section, procuring us a private changing area. Asala had a grand time picking out clothes for the next two hours. She got a bit embarrassed a few times, mainly when I was helping her pick out undergarments until she mimed for me to look away. I teased her a bit but did so while Sue helped her find a few things she liked. Of course I watched her out of the corner of my eye, it wouldn’t do to let my eyes off of her for even a moment.

By the time we left Asala was wearing a new light blue dress and real underclothes, Sue having discreetly discarded the diaper without anyone the wiser. I was loaded down with bags, my duffle riding on my back and five shopping bags juggled between my two hands. She was yawning by the time we got home so I told her to go get a bath and brush her teeth. She nodded her head and grabbed out the pajamas she had chosen before heading up the steps. Setting the things in the hallway for the moment I went into the living room and sat on the couch, listening to the water running upstairs.

I was tired. This was the first time in a long time I could remember being this tired from simply running around town. But then again, this is what it had felt like when I had taken Olia on dates into town. A feeling I didn’t mind at all.

I must have lost track of time a bit and zoned out because next thing I knew Asala was climbing under my arm and snuggling into my side contentedly, her teddy bear clutched tightly in her hand. Combing my fingers through her damp hair I let out a sigh of contentment, one she echoed a moment later. Suddenly she spoke, her voice soft and slightly lilting, almost musical.

“Am I bad for not thinking about momma and papa much today?”

“No sweetie. It just means you were able to enjoy today. You were able to find good things in all the bad that has happened to you lately. The silver lining as they call it. Not everyday is going to be like this. And you are still going to hurt and think about them again and again. And just as it’s ok to feel happy in the happy moments, it’s ok to feel sad in the sad moments. You’ve got your entire life ahead of you right now. There is no reason it all has to be sad. No reason that you need to think that there is nothing more because your parents are gone. You understand what I am trying to say?”

“Uh-huh, I think so. Is it ok if I think of you as family?”

“Sure. I’d like that. You already remind me of my little sister.”

“Good. Because I wish I had a brother like you.”

“Now you do.”

She squeezed me tightly as she closed her eyes with a smile on her face. I continued to stroke her hair as her breathing evened out and she fell asleep in my lap. I stayed awake for a few more moments before I let my head fall backwards and fell asleep as well.

********

What other truths might have been reveled if you had gone down another possibility? Would this day have turned out so well? Would it have turned out better? Or perhaps it was always destined to turn out like this? Context and course of events. Do these things mean anything? If supposing down this path things happen as A goes into B goes into C makes D outcome. Then if the course of events were to change, would it matter in the long run? If C goes into A goes into S would or could the outcome still be D? Would the context of those two timelines matter? That is, the same words, spoken by the same people. Or would their meaning change, resulting in different actions?

Everything you have seen today has happened, but at the same time it has not yet happened and might never happen. Even as it will happen. Come again traveler and delve deeper into the mysteries that is this world of possibilities.
111121112221211111.title: Decline offer

111121112221211112.content:
“I think we can spare a little bit of time for something special like that. It will probably be the only time she will get to see something so unique.”

Freddy grinned as he looked down at Asala who was in her own little world savoring the glazed donut in her left hand and dropping crumbs onto the stuffed animal she clutched in her right.

“Only fer you and your friends comrade vould I offer such an opportunity. Bezides, she reminds me of my little von back in Custanvia. Vell, vhat my little von vas like thirty years ago ya? Zo comrade, ven do you plan to zettle down vith a good bushka and haf little von’s of yer own?”

The door jangled while he was talking but I ignored the intrusion as I gave him a grin and stroked Asala’s head absently.

“Perhaps when I can find a good bushka like your Wilhameina yes? From what you have told me of her she was my kind of woman.”

He broke out in a belly laugh as he clapped me on the shoulder.

“Comrade! I haf much respect for you ya. But I tink even you vould not last vith a bushka like her. I do not know how I lasted twenty-five years with her before Da One God decided he needed her at his side. I bet even now she iz putting Nirvana in order fer him! And tellink him how to do his job to boot!”

I returned his grin before turning to see Marsa and two girls from class staring at us in surprise. As if they had never seen two men acting so close. Looking down at Asala I saw she was eyeballing another pastry on a shelf with glaze and cream all around her mouth. With a sigh I knelt in front of her, pulling a handkerchief from my pouch and wetting it with some water I conjured into existence before grabbing her chin in my hand and cleaning her face.

“No more girl. I think two is enough for you now, otherwise you are going to get a tummy ache. I know they are good, but too many is just as bad for you as only being able to look. Besides, if you get anymore on your face you might turn into a pastry yourself.”

I ignored the gushing of adoration over my head as the two girls I didn’t know by more than face commented on how good I was with her, like I was her father or something. Normally such prattling would have got on my nerves, but I found I really didn’t mind them at the moment. Right now taking care of Asala reminded me of how I had been with Olia. It made me feel like a big brother again. When I thought about that, it was like nothing could dampen my mood.

Asala for her part suffered me cleaning her face rather gracefully. Pouting only a little at my insistence that she couldn’t have another donut. After cleaning her up I playfuly smacked her on the nose with a shake of the head.

“That face might have worked on someone else but not on me. I’m wise to you little girl. So put those lips up.”

She tried keeping the pout going but could only hold it another moment before beginning to grin, showing a full set of teeth. As I stood up I took her hand and began heading towards the back room after Freddy. On a whim I turned to look at the three girls who were still staring at me, two of them almost having little hearts floating around their heads.

“Freddy is going to give us a sneak peek at how he makes his pastries. If it’s ok with him you ladies want to join us? It’s all top secret though so you can’t tell anyone. That is, even if you understand it all. Quite frankly not even I understand how he does it.”

“Can we! Are you sure!”

“If dat iz vat comrade Riktal vishes, I vould be happy to show you as vell.”

“Then yes please!”

The three girls joined us, only Marsa kept quiet, refusing to chatter away like the other two. It wasn’t that she wasn’t interested or anything, I could see her glee plain as day on her face. She was just naturally more reserved and composed. Then again, a good magic caster like her had to be in order to manipulate the magic with a greater skill then a combat oriented Hunter like me. I might have more variety with what I could do right now, but her spells packed more of a punch then any of mine ever could unless I used a lot of energy.

Once in the back Freddy led us all over to an alchemic table where various concoctions were brewing, some of them had probably been steeping all week.

“Here iz vere it all starts. I make potions of all shapes and sizes. Fer the more complicated von’s I get dem elsewhere. Zo I must haf a good knowledge not only of my own skillz but also a good eye fer the skillz of od’ers.”

He led us to the next table in the assembly line, this one with a pressure pot and some fast freezing water.

“Da next step is complicated and da secret of it all. But in a nutshell I take da potion I vish to use and apply great pressure to it, making it boil vith no heat. Vhile it iz pressurized I add a touch of my magik and inject some of this vater that can freeze yer flesh if you touch it.”

He demonstrated by putting on a rubber glove and picking up a small bit of dough from a table behind us. He dipped the gooey dough into the bowl of water that had frost rimming it and vapors swirling like mist over top of the liquid. When he pulled it out he tapped the ball on the table, making it shatter into little pieces. He then lifted the bowl carefully and poured some of its contents it into a small tank attached to the pressurized can with a clear hose.

After setting the bowl back down and carefully covering it with a metal sheet we all saw him encasing the can with a thin film of pink energy. With a grin at us he slowly loosened a knob holding the liquid back. Even though I was expecting it, I still jumped a bit like everyone else when there was a small pop inside the canister and the clear lid was suddenly covered with little rainbow colored dust.

“It iz like the popcorn ya? When da compressed boiling potion meets da freezing water you get da small boom and voilla! Magik sprinkle dust. Da secret iz in how you regulate yer magik. I vill let it set fer an hour to normalize evenly and be ready fer use.”

Turning us around he spread out his hand to show the large table spanning half the length of the room behind us that was clearly sectioned off into four parts. Each one had dough on it as well as bowls of magic dust clearly marked with what potion it came from.

“Dis is vhere da real magik begins. As I make da dough I kneed in what magical properties I vish. Not too much or da bread vill not cook properly and da magik dust vill fail. Not too little or da magik iz not potent, making it a vaste to put it in. Fer the pasteries that make you feel good or haf fun abilities such as bouncy step it takes a special mixing of ingredients, not just von. Since da dust haz much da same properties as da potion ya? Zo I use multiple potions to counter certain effects just like when making a potion to begin vith. Simple no?”

“How do you know how much is the right amount of each dust to use though?”

Freddy winked at the one girl who had spoken while waggling his finger.

“Dat my dear iz trade secret. You are friend of comrade Riktal but not even he is allowed to know dat.”

Moving down the table he explained how each section was set up for different things, and with different magic dusts so there would be no crossover. Telling us all how the breads with specific abilities like increasing magical power or enhancing things like strength and speed were more straightforward, requiring only the dust and the bread to be mixed together in the right portions. Also pointing out that one section was completely dedicated to making normal bread for those who wanted to buy it that way.

All four girls seemed to be interested in the entire process as he explained it to them, a fact which delighted Freddy to no end. He was proud of this specialized cooking that he did with good reason. They hung on to his every word as he finally ended up in front of the array of ovens. Some of them were old fashioned kiln style and other newer models. He told them how certain breads also needed to be cooked certain ways to give it their unique flavors or to pull out the full potency of the magic.

The three girls from school asked a few more questions which Freddy answered for the most part, only being evasive when he needed to be. At the end he pulled out some bread that was cooling to the side and gave it to each of them. Saying that it tasted better when it was still warm. When they popped the bread into their mouths it almost looked like they were all seeing The One God himself. Me and Freddy shared a grin as he led the girls back out into the front of the store where they thanked us profusely for the honor.

Jarvin had a big box of the regular bread sitting on the counter waiting for Freddy who looked at the clock in surprise before nodding his thanks to the boy. He picked up the offering and headed for the door while the girls looked on in confusion.

“Where is he going?”

“He gives the unsold bread he makes in the morning to the homeless at this time everyday. Not the special stuff, since he doesn’t want them to get addicted to it or anything, but the non-magical stuff. Sometimes I think that’s the real reason he makes non-magical bread, since people rarely buy the regular stuff when they come in.”

Just as the door was closing we all heard a gunshot from right outside. Asala jumped a bit and clutched at my leg as the three girls all looked at each other with degrees of shock and fear.
111121112221211112.title: Accept offer

1111211122212111121.content:
As the three girls from school hurried to the door to find out what had happened, I followed at a leisurely pace. By the time I got to the door I was just in time to see Freddy waving off the thanks of two police officers who were pulling a masked man off the ground and cuffing him. I gave the girls another grin as they kept glancing back and forth between Freddy who was already handing out bread to the homeless in the alley next to the bakery and the police.

“He might be old but he is still a Hunter, and a tough old coot to boot. Survived two S class monsters, stood alone against an invasion of trolls for half a day until help could arrive, and lived with a monster for twenty five years. I wouldn’t be surprised if he could give any one of you a run for your money still.”

Freddy overheard my comment, giving a braying laugh as he handed out another small loaf to a thankful woman but didn’t comment further. Asala began to fidget a bit, dancing from foot to foot. It took me a moment to realize what was wrong but when I did I smiled privately, opening the door and leading her back inside. Ignoring Jarvin I lead her through the back of the store to the bathroom where she promptly rushed in.

I shouldn’t be surprised, her body had received no real nutrition for three days. Suddenly being flooded with so much food and drink it was a wonder it hadn’t act up before this. Then again maybe it had but she had been too absorbed in learning about the bread making process to really notice.

She finally came out, nodding her head when I asked if she had washed her hands. With a grin I took her tiny fingers in mine when she reached over for me, leading her back out into the main room where Freddy was sitting behind the counter with Jarvin watching Marsa and her friends browse the wares. Before I left though I pointed at Marsa quickly.

“She’s a competent caster and she impressed me earlier today while in training. Such things deserve a small reward. Think you can spare say a dozen of your donut holes? You know, the ones that boost magical firepower for fifteen minutes at a time. I’m sure she’s smart enough to know how to make them last for a bit.”

“Fer you, anytink.”

“Can we get some too?”

I looked at the two girls who were looking between the two of us with hopeful eyes. Normally such unsolicited greedy desires would make me a little angry, but not today. Nothing seemed to be able to upset me right now. Thinking back to the combat class I finally shook my head no before pointing at the blond on the left and then the black haired girl on the right.

“She’s a fister and she’s an archer. They need something a bit more physical. Give the fister some double attack wafers, those magic induced phantom strikes will do more good for her. And speed cookies to the archer. The ability to feel like your arms are weightless will let her fire more rapidly.”

“Az you vish.”

Opening the door with a little tinkling sound I gave everyone a parting grin while calling over my shoulder.

“Pahkah Freddy.”

“Do svidaniya comrade! Bring da little von again ya!”

Once out in the open I stoked the girls hair as I lead her down the street into the fading light. A lightness to my step as I heard the little girl humming quietly to herself.

“Well Asala, that was a new experience for you wasn’t it? This world has a lot to offer and you have your whole life ahead of you to experience it. Live it to the fullest you hear me? Be sad if you need to be sad. And let yourself feel happy when you are happy. Cry if you feel like crying and smile when you feel like smiling. Don’t be afraid of who or what you are, simply express yourself when you need to and face each day boldly. That’s all any of us can do really. Now, while we still have some light, we got some shopping to do. We won’t spend long, just enough to get you a few things. Tomorrow we can get a bit more until you feel like this is really your home. You like that idea?”

She nodded her head enthusiastically before tugging on my shirt and motioning for me to bend over. When I squatted down in front of her she grabbed me around the neck, squeezing tightly before quickly kissing me on the lips. Her face turned a deep shade to match her eyes as she hid it in her teddy bear, only a small muffled voice emerging from behind the animal.

“I love you.”

She refused to look at me again after that as we continued on our way, a foolish grin plastered on my face. I knew it was only because I had given her stability in her life that she thought she loved me, but I still couldn’t help but feel a bit embarrassed. Even though she refused to look at me, her face still a bright shade of red, she also refused to let go of my hand. Lilia’s prediction floated to the top of my head then and I grinned even wider if that was possible. A girl in my near future indeed.

********

A fitting end to the day I suppose. Was it a good day? A bad day? Or perhaps it was simply another day, unremarkable and as same as the day before or after. But was it the best day I wonder? Could it have turned out better? I’m sure it could have turned out worse.

What other truths might have been reveled if you had gone down another possibility? Would this day have turned out so well? Or perhaps it was always destined to turn out like this? Context and course of events. Do these things mean anything? If supposing down this path things happen as A goes into B goes into C makes D outcome. Then if the course of events were to change, would it matter in the long run? If C goes into A goes into S would or could the outcome still be D?

Would the context of those two timelines matter? That is, the same words, spoken by the same people. Or would their meaning change, resulting in different actions? Or could outcome D still happen if X, Y, and Z happened instead of A, B, and C? It is an interesting thought is it not?

Everything you have seen today has happened, but at the same time it has not yet happened and might never happen. Even as it will happen. Come again traveler and delve deeper into the mysteries that is this world of possibilities.
1111211122212111121.title: Go investigate

11112111222121112.content:
“Come on shrimp, let’s go make you even prettier.”

She looked up at me questioningly as if she didn’t understand what I was talking about. With a grin I squeezed her hand, leading her to the left at the first crossroads to go into town. When we turned into a clothing store I saw her eyes widen in surprise as I chuckled slightly at her expense

“The first thing you need is stuff. Lots and lots of stuff. I’ve yet to meet a girl that didn’t like to shop, especially when it’s someone else’s money. You might be leaving in a few days but while you are here I want you to feel like this is your home. There is no reason you have to run around with nothing of your own.”

She hesitated for a moment, pulling a plain dress off the sales rack claiming it only cost 5 Reul.

“Is that really what you want? If it is that’s fine but I expect you to spend at least a hundred Reul or more before you leave here. That includes shoes, and jewelry.”

I called the sales lady over, asking her to show us the more expensive stuff, following her to another part of the store. As Asala began to slowly pick through the dresses with the woman’s help I simply stood back. This wasn’t my first choice of stores, since many of the clothes were either of a lesser quality or more expensive than most other places. But Asala seemed to look happy as she began running in and out of the changing room to try on clothes.

She blushed a bit, miming for me to look away as she picked out underwear, which made me grin while poking a bit of fun at her. As she went into the changing room to try on another dress I saw the sales lady whispering to another woman. I was able to read a few of the words on her lips as she talked about how Asala was wearing a diaper. Nonchalantly I walked over to the two women, slipping out two five hundred Reul bills and sliding the bills across to both of them.

“I’d be appreciative if you completely forget anything you might have seen concerning that little girl. She is getting over an injury causing her to have to wear some embarrassing things at her age. In fact I would be appreciative if you completely forget we were ever here once we leave. Think I can count on you ladies to do that?”

The woman behind the counter gave me a small smile as she slipped the bill into her pocket casually.

“Of course sir Hunter. It‘s been an unusually slow day without any customers at all.”

The other woman hefted the bill in her hand as I saw the gears turning. Of course she would be a greedy type. I knew she was going to try and get more out of me. Before she could open her mouth though Asala came out of the dressing room and posed for me. I whistled appreciatively and continued to watch her until she pulled another dress off the rack and went back into the dressing room. As soon as the door closed I returned my gaze to the greedy woman with narrowed eyes.

“You don’t have a problem with that deal do you?”

“I’m not sure if a small amount like five hundred is enough to keep my mouth shut. Especially if you are so inclined to have me forget.”

I turned to the woman who had accepted my bribe with a raised eyebrow.

“Excuse me, may I speak with your store manager?”

“That would be me.”

“What is your policy on employees accepting bribes?”

“They aren’t tolerated. They would be fired immediately.”

“Then I would like to inform you that one of your employees took a five hundred Reul bribe and tried to extort more money from the other person to boot. Now I’m just a concerned citizen here and we Zelkov’s have long upheld the standards of this city. I’m sure you would know how to handle this better than I would.”

“Of course Mr. Zelkov. Your family has supported this city for many years and I know how upstanding your name is. I’ll take care of it immediately.”

The woman turned to the sales lady who had tried to get more out of me and smiled sweetly.

“Jody honey. It has come to my attention you accepted a bribe. As you know this store does not tolerate such things. Effective immediately you are fired. Go get your things and get out of this store. And a word to the wise honey, you might want to go to another city if you want to stay in this line of work because I doubt any other clothing store will hire you once they find out you tried to extort money from a Zelkov. Actually most places around here won’t hire you on that basis alone.”

The woman named Jody opened and closed her mouth like a fish for a few moments before I put my hand on her shoulder, leaning forward to whisper in her ear.

“And as an extra warning, if you wish to continue to make trouble for me I will make sure to remove such trouble from my sight if you get what I’m saying.”

Letting her go I walked back to Asala who had come out of the dressing room again to showcase the dress she was wearing. I made sure to shower her with praise and appreciation, trying to boost her confidence more than anything. When I glanced back, only the store manager was in sight, coming over to help us finish up with a smile on her face.

An hour later and a thousand Reul lighter the two of us left the store laden down with four bags stuffed with goods. Asala was looking in a much better mood as we headed for home, the sun low in the sky to the west. She still clutched at her bear like a lifeline, but the overwhelming sadness was gone from her face, only lurking in the shadows of her eyes.

This was only a temporary high of course, it would wear off by tonight as she had a chance to settle down from the day. I figured she would have another good cry tonight before going to bed and I would hold her again while she let it all out. A home cooked meal would evoke some of those memories of her parents without shoving their death in her face, while laying in bed alone with her thoughts would bring the rest of that sorrow to the forefront.

This entire day had all been a calculated ploy to help her deal with her grief in a more healthier way while planting the seeds for her future healing. The biggest thing I felt she needed right now was stability. If she felt her immediate life was stable and she had some measure of power over it, I had a feeling her monster summoning powers would also become a bit more stable and controllable. I didn’t know this for a fact of course, but all the secondhand knowledge I had made this seem likely.

When we got to the house I unlocked the door, juggling the bags in my hand to turn the knob. I had just stepped inside when the little girl tugged on my shirt and motioned for me to bend over. As I set down the bags I leaned in towards her with a smile on my face expecting her to whisper something in my ear.

She wrapped her arms around my neck and squeezed, giving my cheek a quick peck before parting her lips and uttering four words with a soft voice.

“Thank you big brother.”

With that she blushed a deep red that was almost a match for her eyes before running off upstairs. Touching the spot she had kissed lightly I felt my grin widen foolishly. It had been a while since I had been called big brother. It made me feel really good inside in a way I hadn’t felt in a long time. It made me glad I had chosen to protect her. Lilia’s divination popped into my head then as I headed for the kitchen to make dinner. A girl in my near future who would give me back something I had once thought lost indeed.

I began to hum a little tune my sister had always loved as I began pulling out pots, feeling that the house didn’t feel as empty as it normally did for the first time in three years.

************

So ends the day. A relatively eventful day I suppose, though at the same time you could say it was uneventful and normal depending on who’s perspective you speak from. Speaking of perspective, how did you decide the choices you did? Did you view this day through your own eyes? Or did you immerse yourself in Riktal’s life, choosing as you thought he would chose?

Is this one of the other times you have lived this day? Even for me such distinctions are hard to make. With possibilities overlapping each other like fine rice paper sometimes details blend together. But if this is one of the multiple other times you have lived this day, did you alter your decisions based on the information you learned on other possible timelines? Or were you able to put that information to the side and choose with an unbiased mind?

Because that it a fallibility of you humans I have found. You find it difficult to distance yourself from problems and make choices in an unbiased manner. Especially when you have a little extra information. In fact it seems the more information you have the more biased you become, it is a strange phenomenon indeed that I wish to study further. Feel free to come again so that I may observe you as you interact with this day again. Perhaps I will gain new insights while watching you, just as you gain new insights while guiding Riktal’s life.
11112111222121112.title: Go shopping

1111211122212112.content:
“Take her to Pelei. I feel for her, I really do. But I just can’t get over my desire to refuse simply because you are the one asking. If there was no one else then it would be different, but that’s not the case. You didn’t want me to become a licensed professional so you have no business asking me to take a job like this. I’ll see you when you get back from your next job if I’m unlucky. That is if I don’t just get fed up with everything and disappear into obscurity.”

“Riktal you wouldn’t do that!”

“If you really think that mother then you really don’t know me at all. The kicker of it all is it wouldn’t even affect you or faher in any way. You would both continue to act like nothing changed, same as when Olia died. So in case this is the last time we meet, farewell mother.”

The sword on my back bounced a bit as I turned, making me reach up and deactivate the artifact so it was simply a hilt again. I returned to the arena where the Arena Master was on the floor with eight of the sixteen kids fighting an antlion. The ones still on the sidelines gave me a nod of respect as I drew close and then began asking me questions about what they were seeing. Mostly pertaining to reasons why this or that order was given.

I saw my mother look in on me with another pair of forlorn and sad looking eyes but pretended not to notice her while answering their questions until she eventually walked off. The group on the floor finished off their prey, earning an antlion mandible for their troubles before coming back over to us. The teacher gave them all a small lecture before the bell rang a few moments later and the class dispersed. He informed me that he wouldn’t need me until tomorrow if I was available before I returned to the locker room to collect my things.

I got a few thanks from the seniors for teaching them but otherwise they gave me some space out of respect. With weapons in hand I headed for my class on the second floor. I had just gotten into the room when a rumbling shook the entire school. One of the girls pointed out the window and I dashed over in time to see a giant Shoglim emerging from a red summoning circle. I could just make out my mother and the little girl on the other side of the nine foot tall creature.

Shoglim’s were nasty monsters. With the body of a spider, an outer shell as hard as bone, and a slightly humanoid face they were tough to deal with at the best of times. What was worse was they got larger and stronger with age. Since this one was nine feet tall it was at least nine years old. They grew a foot a year and capped out at nine feet, living at most fifteen years. Add in they were as intelligent as humans and you had a fight on your hands that was a challenge for even an S class Hunter even though this was only an A class monster.

“Everyone get out of this classroom now! Head for the basement! Liz! Send out an alarm to the rest of the school to evacuate to the basement! I’m counting on you to help the teachers keep everyone safe!”

I barely heard the assent as I tossed my duffle bag out the broken window, activating the bit of magic that made the weapons fly out to float around me in a stasis field even as I followed the bag a second later. Pulling the sword from my back I reactivated the giant blade, trying to get a preemptive strike on the creature.

It didn’t even turn away from where my mother was holding it off with a buckler made of magic, simply blocking my strike with one of it’s eight legs and throwing me backwards.

“Phase two active. Triple juggler.”

My feet connected with the wall of the school even as I broke the sword in half. As I shoved off I bit down on the hidden blade while throwing the two half swords out to my sides. Speeding towards the creature I swung the sword in my right hand, getting blocked again without it looking at me. But I used that contact to spin in that direction trying to backhand it with the sword in my left hand. It blocked that blow as well even as I manipulated the handle in my mouth until I could spit the dagger at its face using a bit of magic to speed it up.

It saw the dagger coming and jerked it’s head, but I swung the dagger after it using the thread of power connecting the hilt to my tongue, catching it in one of it’s eight eyes. It gave a scream of pain as I landed, throwing my two sword halves at the Shoglim, dodging the attempt to block them with the threads attached to my hands.

“Phase one activate. On the dagger.”

The sword pieces zoomed like arrows to the dagger, ramming deep into the eye before I used my strings to yank it out again and back to my hand.
