My mother had grabbed a shield and short sword from the ones floating around me by the time the Eviscerater was back in my hand. Discarding it into my stasis field I grabbed a collapsible bow with bladed arms, beginning to fire shafts of magic arrows at the thing.

“Phase two activate. Blur.”

Even as the top and bottom of the bow split and settled against the back of each arm before growing out another limb, teachers were emerging from the school to help. Even though no one said anything we worked together like a well oiled machine.

“I need a boost!”

Even as I yelled that the Arena Master was in front of me cupping his hands in front of him. Stepping into his grip he heaved like a strongman, sending me flying to the height of the school roof.

“Phase three activate! Seven levels of Perdition!”

I held out my hands in front of me so the bows were parallel to my body. Five more bows appeared in the air like ghosts of the ones on my hands. I saw three of the teachers setting up a barrier around the creature even as I released the magic suddenly coursing through my veins. Arrow after arrow blasted from each of the seven bows one arrow every second. Each one flaming as hot as magma. The monster deflected most of them by swinging four of its arms wildly through the air, but it couldn’t block all of them. A good fourth of the hundreds upon hundreds of arrows I spammed as I fell hit the carapace and burned through. As I was about to hit I spun, quickly, turning into a cyclone as the five ghost bows did the same. It tried blocking me with its arms but the razor sharp blades of the bow limbs combined with my rotation sliced them up even as I slammed into it’s back.

Quickly I jumped off even as it twisted it’s head to bite at me. I could see that already it was beginning to heal it’s wounds by covering them with webbing which hardened into near bone density. Mr. Yetz the Alchemy teacher lobbed potions at it while another teacher I didn’t know spammed high level magic from a staff. I saw Mr. Yetz warp through a teleportation potion right onto the creatures back to smash a bottle of some sort of acid into it’s mouth when it turned towards him, stepping back through the green gas before it disappeared to be back safely on the ground. The whole move had taken less than four seconds but it had required precise timing and knowing exactly how long a teleportation spell stayed up for.

It spit webbing out of its backside that spread out and attached to the side of the school building. It leapt backwards, standing on the side of the building before leaping off at all of us, its mandibles clacking. As my mother sent out a wave to attract it’s attention and raised her shield, I saw the wall give way as it pulled the building down behind it. Time seemed to slow down as my eyes darted around quickly. It seemed no one had noticed the walls yet, too intent upon the Shoglim. Making a snap decision I expelled all the magic left in my body to create a giant wall of wind that shoved everyone out of the way even as I grabbed the Evicerater for the last time.

“Phase three activate. Pincushion.”

The sword melted onto my body, growing four to six foot long blades from every section of my body. With a yell I jumped up to meet the monster, feeling one of its claws slide in between two of the blades to puncture a kidney. But I ignored it as I slammed into the creature, head butting the two foot blade on my forehead through its mouth just as it landed on top of me. Grabbing it in a bear hug I kept it from moving as I watched the tons of brick fall on top of the both of us.

*********

A tragic end to the day. But at what point did this day go wrong? Was it as simple as not accepting the job from his mother? Perhaps it was a choice before that? Perhaps your decision not to escort the group to the nurses office is to blame for this turn of events. Maybe it was destined from the beginning to turn out this way. Do you regret the choices you made? Do you wonder that ever elusive question of what if?

At least Riktal died the way he wished, a Hunter protecting people like he was trained to do. It is an honorable death I believe. One that deserves praise. But did it have to happen? Was this outcome destined to happen all the time or was there another option that he failed to see? Was this entirely his fault though? What if other people hade made slightly different choices? Such as his mother approaching him with her request differently. Or if the two boys had never gone through his bag during lunch.

If those slight alterations had happened, would he have still made the choice to sacrifice himself like he did? Would this entire scenario have never happened? These are all questions that need answers but as with many things, might never get them. Come again traveler and experience this day anew. Make new choices, perhaps find the answer to these questions while finding and asking new ones. You can of course never return to this place and leave this window forever closed without rewriting it. The choice is yours.
1111211122212112.title: Send her to Pelei

111121112221212.content:
“Let’s go someplace else mother. No offense Arena Master but if what she wants me for lasts overlong I won’t hold up the class.”

“As you wish.”

I mockingly held out my hand for my mother to lead the way as the Arena master tipped his head in our direction. My mother gave the class and the teacher a brief nod before turning and marching away, dragging the unresisting little girl behind her. With a sigh I followed, falling into step beside her once we were out in the hall.

“I saw about the last half of the fight back there. You were impressive.”

“No use trying to flatter me mother. You know very well my level of skill. You and father are the ones who beat it into me after all.”

“Still doesn’t mean I didn’t think you were impressive.”

“Not impressive enough for you to think I was ready for the Exams though huh?”

“It’s not like that you know.”

“No I don’t because you never tell me anything.”

She was quiet after that, not having any real retort that wouldn’t have been a lie. Even though she was my mother I didn’t feel much for her. A bit of love perhaps but nothing I couldn’t ignore most of the time. She was barely more than a stranger to me, since I honestly couldn’t remember once when she had shown any real motherly affection. The only time she had dealt with me was when she had been teaching me Hunter skills. And then she trained me like another Hunter and not her son.

It didn’t take long before my mother opened the door on a small sparse room with a single table, six chairs sitting around it and a window looking out on the track and field where a class was running in circles. After manually pushing the girl into a seat she walked over to the window, staring outside with her hands clasped behind her back. I could see a slightly thoughtful look on her face in the reflection coming off the sheet of glass.

“I’m glad to see you are already making friends on your first day.”

“Don’t be stupid, they aren’t friends. They’re just senior’s I helped teach that’s all. They are my friends like you are my mother, in name only. The only difference is they might actually be a bit closer to me. Now enough of the pointless chatter. We both know the only reason you are here is because you want something from me. It’s the only time you ever come around of your own free will.”

“Well I guess I will leave it at that for now. Everything starts somewhere right? You’re right, I do want something from you. This girls name is Asala and she lost her family a few days ago. I want you to take care of her until someone can pick her up. It will only be two days, three max. I’m going to be heading off to Bornica and I won’t take her into such a war torn place. Your father finished his job early so he will be assisting me.”

“Still see no reason any of this is my problem. Or any compelling one to help you. If you couldn’t deal with protecting her then you should never have taken the job in the first place. Surprised you took it at all seeing how great you are with kids.”

“Yes well, I sort of had no choice. The job sort of fell into my lap. It’s an easy job, as you can see she is like a lifeless doll. If you can get her to do anything, that would be more than me and my aides have been able to do. We’ve kept her alive on magic to fool her body into thinking it’s not hungry or thirsty, but that can’t last more than another day or two at the most before her body eats itself up. She doesn’t sleep, just stares at the ceiling all night long and we’ve supported her with magic on that front too. But again, we both know how prolonged use of magic to keep from resting messes with the head.”

“What’s so special about her? Normally you’d dump her on one of your aides or the first Hunter you could think of after only a few hours if that. I’m sure Hilda could break her out of her shell, or any number of people, Hunter or not for that matter.”

“She’s got cursed blood. Monster summoner to be exact. It’s unstable and she can’t control it. You are one of the few I know who doesn’t have anything against summoners. You’re good with kids, and you can deal with anything she can call forth. I already asked Pelei, who is the only other one I could trust with something like this. He was willing to do it, but to be honest I just didn’t feel right leaving her with him. Especially with his little eccentricities. But if you refuse I’ll go with him.

“I realize this is a large job I’m asking you to do. And unfair to also ask you to keep this under the table if possible. But there are reasons for that as well. I know you are going to ask what reasons and it pains me to say I can’t tell you just like every other time you ask that question. I promise I will reveal it all to you soon, but not right now. I’d also like it if you continue attending classes here if you say yes. That too has important reasons I can’t say yet.”

My mother finally turned away from the window to stare at me with pleading eyes. If it had been anyone else I might have even believed those emotions she had shown in voice and face were real. But my mother was a user. Willing to lie, cheat, steal, or generally do whatever she had to in order to get what she wanted. Even throwing the family name and power around over the smallest things. She did and said nothing that did not somehow benefit her the most. I knew this from growing up. Having been let down and hurt countless times whenever I let my guard down and believed her. So doing the opposite of whatever she wanted was just my natural reaction.

I looked at the girl who hadn’t even twitched in all this time, simple squeezed the bear in her hands a fraction tighter. I hadn’t seen her actually move, but I noted the slight change in the size of the stuffed chest since the last time I looked. She was an innocent. I was bound by the Hunter’s code to help her. So in that respect I should accept my mothers request. But I didn’t need to, since Pelei was sitting on the sidelines already willing to protect her. This wasn’t a clear choice I knew how to make as solely a Hunter. If Pelei had said no or there was no one else then the only choice would be to follow my Hunter training and protect the innocent. But right now that warred with my own personal desire to say no simply because my mother wanted me to accept. I knew there was more to this story, there always was with her, that she would never tell me.

Since I didn’t know what to do I decided to simply answer with the first thing that came to mind when I opened my mouth. So unfolding my arms, I shoved off of the wall next to the door. Taking one last look between my mother and the girl I stared her in the eyes and opened my mouth.
111121112221212.title: Go someplace else

1111211122212121.content:
“Twenty thousand Reul. Twelve thousand for the job itself, three for expenses and five to keep it under the table. I’m only going so low because I don’t have a license.”

“You won’t do this as a favor to me?”

“Please, you taught me better than that. No I should correct that. If you were anyone else I might do it for free, but I really have no desire to do anything for free where you are concerned. Besides that’s probably a much better price then Pelei wanted.”

“Well you’re right, he wanted thirty five thousand. He wouldn’t do it as a favor to me either.”

“Shows he has some brains at least. Have the money transferred over into my account by the end of the day. Is there anything else you need mother? If not I’m sure you have other places more important than here to be. I’m going to spend some time getting to know this girl.”

She opened her mouth as if to say something then shook her head sadly, a sorrowful look in her eyes. I ignored it as just another attempt to make me lower my guard as she crossed the room and left through the door. Kneeling on the floor next to the girl I lifted her limp right hand in mine, staring into her lifeless scarlet eyes.

“I know you can hear me in there. Pretend all you want but I know you can. I’m sure you are more than a little confused right now. Scared, feeling helpless, and this ever present pit of sadness that feels like it is going to swallow you up. Perhaps running into your head is the only way you knew how to cope with everything. You were able to make a lot of that pain go away by simply shutting down. But it didn’t all go away did it? There’s still a small bit of it that keeps haunting you no matter how far you run.

“That’s because such things are not so easy to get rid of. They leave wounds that cut really deep and will last forever and ever. Even after they heal up, those scars are still deep and can still sometimes seem fresh even years and years into the future. Little girls like you aren’t meant to hold it all inside. Even big tough strong men are allowed to let it all out when they need to. Doing so isn’t a sin or wrong in any way. It’s called grief, and everyone deals with it in their own way. For some people holding it in works for them. But I have a feeling you’re a big crybaby and you need to let out a good cry to help you deal with it.”

No reaction. Not even a flicker of the eye to show that she heard me. Well I had no idea what she had been told the last three days under my mothers care. I could guess but it would be foolish to think a few simple words from me without actions might change all of that. Perhaps if things were different my words would sway her, but not this time.

“Well that’s fine if you don’t want to react. I’m going to be here with you all the time. If you want to let it all out I won’t stop you. You probably don’t trust me right now and that’s understandable I guess. You barely know me. But I know what you are going through and all I want to do is help you.”

I let go of her hand and leaned forward, pulling her into a hug and stroking her soft white hair. I let my voice drop to a whisper to talk into her ear. Even though we were alone in the room it was a calculated act to make my words seem more important and special to her.

“You are a very special little girl who deserves to be happy. Even though you are sad right now it will get better I promise. I love you Asala, because you are you, monster summoner powers and all. Because even if you think no one else will, you now know that there is one person in this world that does. Your parents are gone and I can’t change that. But you are not alone in the world. Do you hear me? You are not alone.”

I was about to push her away when her hands came up to grab me around the waist, pulling me back towards her. She began to wail as I gave her comfort. She continued to cry as the bell rang, her tears and snot getting the front of my tunic all wet. Finally after a good fifteen minutes she wound down, pulling away and rubbing her face with the back of her hands. Cupping her cheek and chin in my big palm I smiled at her until she tentatively smiled back.

“Now that’s more like it. I’ll be here whenever you feel like crying again ok? Don’t hold it inside anymore because it’s not healthy. Do you feel a little bit better now?”

A slow nod of the head, as if she was afraid to admit that fact.

“It doesn’t make the pain and sadness disappear though does it? But it does make it slightly more bearable for the moment. That’s because tears are the bodies natural way of cleansing away some of those pains. So holding them in is the unnatural thing to do wouldn’t you say?”

She simply blinked at me, unsure how to respond to that and I grinned before ruffling her hair and standing up. I held out my hand which she took tentatively, as if suddenly afraid of my touch.

“Come on Asala, I need to get my weapons then I will introduce you to the class. I’ll be right here the whole time so you don’t have to be afraid. I won’t let anything bad happen to you. After school, well who knows? We’ll play it by ear. If you feel up to it we can go out and buy new clothes and eat or we can go home for the day. I’ll let you decide what you are comfortable with.”

She stuck to me like a burr, gripping my hand almost as hard a she gripped her teddy bear. It only took a moment to inform the Arena Master of my unavailability to help for the next few days before picking up my bag from the locker and heading up to the classroom. The teacher was in the middle of his lesson on Cadaver Dogs when I came in. getting out Asala’s introduction and ignoring the girls gushing over her I headed for my seat.

“Mr. Zelkov.”

I turned to the teacher, wondering what it was he wanted.

“If you would please put your weapon away?”

“Oh right. Sorry.”

I absently reached my free right hand over my shoulder, placing a finger on the pommel and sending a jolt of power into it. I felt the blade retract back into the hilt, making my back feel a few pounds lighter. I had honestly forgotten it was there, though I would have been reminded of that fact when I tried to sit down.

Asala wrapped her arm around mine while listening to the rest of the lesson, even seeming to be interested in the discussions. I could see heads looking back at us and small smiles on faces. I could almost see the thoughts going through most of the female minds of how adorable she was and how good I was with her. Just as I could see the thoughts going through some of the guy’s minds about how girly I was or weak because I was acting the way I was. I cared for no ones opinions though. My job to protect the girl came before everything. Even personal pride and image. That was just the code of the Hunter.

After class some of the girls converged on us before I had a chance to grab my things and leave. They began bombarding me with useless chatter and words of praise. Things like how cute we looked together and how I seemed to have a knack for little kids. I knew what they were trying to do, they were trying to insinuate themselves into my life while implying they wanted to hook up with me. This was all about politics and future power plays. Asala seemed to sense what was going on too, perhaps through some female radar I didn’t know about. She clutched me around the waist and gave the four girls an evil eye.

“Mine! He loves me! Mine!”

The girls looked at each other a bit shocked then began to chuckle and say how cute. One of the girls finally squatted down in front of Asala with a big smile plastered on her face.

“We aren’t trying to take him from you little one. We just wanted to talk and get to know you both better. We just want to be friends.”

When the girl held out her hand for Asala to shake, Asala slapped it away with a resounding crack before hugging my waist again. With a grin I pushed past the four girls while hiking my bag up higher on my left shoulder.

“Asala has spoken. Your presentation needs work if even a little girl like this can see through your ploys.”

I saw Liz walking over to the group standing in shock as I opened the door, hearing some of her words before getting out of hearing range.

“You got a lot to learn about a Hunter on a job. Rule number one is never try to get between the Hunter and his or her client. You will always come out with the short end of the stick.”

I let my hand fall to the girls head, stroking the hair softly and making her look up at me with those big round eyes of hers.

“Feel up to going into town for some shopping and a bite to eat? If not we can go home for the day and go out tomorrow.”

She nodded up and down in agreement as I led her out the front doors and eventually down the road towards town. She squeezed me again, uttering only one word softly as if it gave her confidence.

“Mine.”

********

A day comes to a close. Should we call it another day? Or simply the day? For this day has ended time and again in thousands of different ways. You have been here multiple times to see many of those different endings. So is it another day, the day, or a day? Does it make a difference? Our time together comes to an end yet again, you are free to return to this world of possibilities whenever you wish to continue to live out this day, to learn something new, perhaps answer something unanswered in this day. But no decision is ever made without regrets of some sort. No choice made without wondering “what if.” So remember that fact well fair traveler, even though you have the power to change the decisions you make in Riktal’s life the next time you relive this day with him; the same cannot be said for your own life.
1111211122212121.title: Yes

1111211122212122.content:
“Sorry, take her to Pelei. He is a licensed Hunter and he has more experience than I do. He might be eccentric but he will get the job done. I’ve been burned too many times by believing you and helping you out of the messes you make. Me not accepting doesn’t put her in danger so I have no feelings of obligation. Now if you decided to give me the whole story and answer all the questions I continually ask that you keep putting off I might change my mind. So how about it? Willing to tell me the full truth?”

My mother just looked at me with those sad eyes of hers, her mouth opening and closing a moment before she shook her head. With a sigh I turned and opened the door before looking back at her.

“I didn’t think so. Goodbye mother. Just remember, you reap what you sow.”

Closing the door with a decisive thud I headed towards the combat arena to pick up my gear, making it there just as the bell rang. A quick stop in with the teacher to find out he didn’t need me and I was on my way again towards my next class. I made it to my seat just before the teacher came in to take role call, noting that Gregory was back from the nurses office as well. As I went to sit down I felt the push of my weapon against the back of the chair, causing me to reach up and zap a bit of power into the pommel to retract the blade. I had forgotten I still had it equipped and active.

The last hour was just as dull and boring as I thought it would be. I learned nothing I didn’t already know and felt like it was all just a waste of time. But I at least pretended to be interested, since the teacher was taking the time to teach. It was just good manners.

As the bell rang I grabbed up my things and headed over to Jethic who was looking down at the small band of metal on his arm with a forlorn look on his face. He was probably thinking about the ruined shield that band would expand into if he activated the artifact.

“Jethic, got some time? If you do then let’s go get your shield fixed. You didn’t think I was just making empty words earlier did you?”

“What! But… no I… are you sure?”

“Completely.”

“O-ok.”

He gathered his stuff quickly and the two of us headed off out of the room. It took only a moment for him to stop at his locker before we were on our way again. When we got to the front door though he looked outside and balked. Stammering that it might be best to do it some other day. Glancing outside and following his line of sight I saw him eyeballing three boys that screamed bully. The one in the middle with the blue hair and leather jacket with metal studs all over it had the unmistakable air of the leader of the group. The two lackeys on either side we so undistinguishable and forgettable as to not even be worth a second glance.

All three had the look of idiots who hadn’t figured out they were no longer in a regular school system where violence between students was unacceptable. This was a Combat Hunter’s academy where violence was encourage to an extent. So such things as bullying, lasted only until their victims fought back and put a serious hurt on them. If they were strong, which might actually be the case, then eventually the students would band together to take them out. They might be able to take on a few, but not the entire student body, or even a bunch of upperclassmen stepping in.

“What, you afraid of those three idiots out there? You’re a tank. You could take them all for breakfast I bet.”
“How’d you…. never mind. I’ve got a bit of a problem when it comes to hitting people. I can beat on monsters all day no problem, but I hesitate when it comes to a real person if it isn‘t a sparring match.”

“Well come on. I’m not about to wait around for hours until they leave and it’s about time you stood up to give them a beat down. It will only get worse if you don’t face them. Just close your eyes when I give you orders and imagine you are fighting the Glif again.”

I saw him let out a shaky breath but nodded his head, following me out of the building as I headed directly for the group of three boys. The one with the blue colored hair pushed off the wall just as I got close enough to grab him by the belt with my right hand and the neck with my left. Hoisting him up over my head I threw him at Jethic.

“Shields out! Mid air takedown!”

Jethic slapped his wrist reflexively, making his broken and crumpled shield expend into reality as he jumped up. He caught the boy in the gut with the jagged edges of the shield as he twisted in air, bringing the boy back to the ground in an arc and smashing the air from his lungs. I was already throwing the next boy at him before he had completed his first attack and grabbing for the third before either bully could react.

“Uppercut shield side!”

He brought his left fist around and up from his kneeling position, catching the second boy I had thrown in the gut just as I kicked the third one in the back, causing him to stumble forward. As the lackey who got gut checked with his uppercut let out a grunt of pain and toppled sideways out of the air I yelled out my final command.

“Backhand shield bash in two… one… now!”

The broken shield pounded into the third bullies face, ripping his cheek open on the jagged parts and breaking his jaw in the process. As he fell to the ground clutching his face I walked over and clapped Jethic on the shoulder as he opened his eyes and looked around in shock. He finally returned the grin I gave him as I walked over to the blue haired boy and stomped down on his stomach. Bending over to stare into his face while pinning him in place with my shoe I made sure I had his full attention.

“People like you are not welcome in this school. Next time he won’t go so easy on you. This is not a regular high school anymore where you can steal peoples milk money with impunity. There are consequences to every action. And I hold a very dim view on bullies to begin with. So consider this your first and final warning. If I ever catch you picking on anyone else again I will kill you no questions asked. This world does not need a Hunter like you. Do I make myself clear?”

He shook his head up and down quickly, too afraid to do anything else. Giving him another evil grin I brought the toe of my boot up into his chin before walking away. I saw a few of the seniors nodding their heads at the spectacle, they had all learned their first years here the way things were. They didn’t interfere though because it was something all new students had to learn, having someone else clean up the mess or step in wouldn’t fix the problem, it would just make the new students think they were weak and lose confidence in themselves. Such was the politics of a Hunter’s academy.

Clapping my hand on Jethic’s shoulder one more time I lead him towards town, leaving the three moaning in pain behind us.

“I’ll help make a real Monster Combat Hunter out of you yet Jethic. You’ll find not all monsters are found in the wild. Sometimes they wear a human skin like those three.”

“Yeah I know, old Markus used to tell me the same thing. He said I would need to get over my fear of hurting people if I wanted to become a good slayer. That sometimes I would take a job that would require me to hurt people.”

“It seems I am in need of a few friends. Think you would be willing to fill one of those slots?”

“Really! I’m honored! But is that really ok?”

“Yeah. I’m a pretty good judge of people and I can tell you are already far ahead of just about everyone else in class in terms of the mentality needed to be a Hunter. Though I warn you, I’m not much of a people person so I don’t really know how to do this whole friends thing. Like how I am supposed to act and stuff like that.”

He began to laugh a bit as we continued on down the road towards town.

“There is no set way to act. You just be yourself. People like you or dislike you because of it and that’s about it. You might be a great Hunter with some amazing skills, but you still got a lot to learn.”

As he continued to chuckle I headed left when we came to the first intersection. What did he mean I had a lot to learn? What was there besides being a Hunter to life? Things like friendships and love was all politics at its core wasn’t it? All about who you know and what you can get out of it. Wasn’t that what dealing with my family and everybody else had taught me over the last seventeen years? My offer of friendship to him was also just a calculated move, since I judged him to be the least harmful for my needs. The principal had said to make friends but not what kind. There was no such thing as something for nothing, friendships were give and take relationships that bound you to feelings of obligation to the other person.

I guess in the end I was no different than my mother, trying to make things go the way I wanted to benefit me the most. That was a most sobering and unpleasant thought.

**********

So do you feel you made the best choices? What did you base those choices on? Your own personal feelings? The situation at hand? Riktal’s view of the world? Did some seem like difficult choices? Or perhaps it seemed like no choice at all. As if there was only ever one correct path or option to take. Was it different choosing the course of someone else’s life over your own? Easy to say things like “oh I would have handled it differently” or “why did he want to make a choice on this thing over that thing?” Such is the way of the outside observer. Able to make such judgments since ultimately it is not you. Come again if you will and relive this day to make different choices. I will not say they would be better for only you could be the judge of that.
1111211122212122.title: No

11112112.content:
My bag would hold for thirty minutes. I wouldn’t be good for anything if I didn’t eat. Keeping up your energy was the most important thing. So I made a quick turn, continuing down the hall until I came to the cafeteria. Nothing too spectacular to chose from but at least it looked both edible and a step up from the slop my last school served. Corn, mashed potatoes and some sort of Salisbury steak in grey gravy.

Looking around I found a good table close to the emergency exit, completely empty with a wall I could place at my back. I was just getting settled in when another tray plopped down across from me. I had seen her coming so wasn’t even the least bit startled. Everyone else seemed to have already decided to avoid me, grouping up in their own little circles. Glancing in our direction as Liz sat down and whispering behind upraised hands.

“Last person who got one over on me good like that was my older brother. Thanks for the potion by the way.”

“Whatever.”

“You were right though. A Hunter should always pay attention to their surroundings. If my brother were here he would have done the same thing and he would have been totally in the right to do so. He would have also healed me after giving me a good thumping. I sort of forgot that basic fact somewhere down the line. Being forced to attend school when I should be out slaying monsters, it just isn‘t right. Everyone here was just so weak or dense or just plain stupid. I guess you must come from an old family too.”

“Why do you say that?”

“These first and second generation Hunters could never pull off what you did. Nothing against them personally, but it was all too precise and calculated. No hesitation in the movements at all. And the speed was at least a match for mine. You only get that from intense training every day. So my guess is you are at least third or forth generation.”

I didn’t say anything, simply took a bite of some potato’s. Being from a long line of Hunters wasn’t always what it as cracked up to be. People assumed things about you and expected things from you. They kissed your feet in hopes of getting in good with you and your family. Whether you had skill or not they all expected you to be just as good as your father or grandmother or great grandparent.

“You really shouldn’t eat that. The steak isn’t too bad but that sauce can mess you up something fierce.”

I lowered the forkful of meat as I looked at her with a bit of surprise.

“Thanks.”

“Don’t mention it. My guess is you don’t like being from an old family just like me. You’re always expected to uphold the traditions and be the best of the best. Having people smother you with fake smiles and groveling in hopes they can worm their way into your life.”

“Something like that.”

“So you pass the qualifications already as well?”

“Yeah.”

“So what are you doing here?”

“I can’t get enough of school.”

“Your parents dumped you here with the whole “you have to finish school” lecture too huh? Saying it will be good for you.”

“Something like that.”

“Bunch of bull isn’t it.”

“Yep.”

“Period after next is combat exercises. Mind partnering with me? I got a feeling you can give me a challenge unlike most of these people.”

“Sure.”

“You don’t talk much do you? Though I guess I can’t blame you. New school, new class, you can’t trust anybody because you don’t know who is being real or not. Less you say the less they have to work with. I know the feeling. Don’t worry about the whole almost killing me thing. It’s not the first time I’ve been so close to death. Though admittedly it was the first time I really thought I was going to die. Well see you later. Oh and might want to think about bringing something from home for lunch from now on. The food here isn’t always edible.”

She gave me a grin and a wave before picking up her empty tray, tossing it in the trash before walking out the doors. Strange girl. Not everyday someone almost kills you and you shrug it off like it was nothing. If it had been me I probably would be plotting revenge as soon as I could. Perhaps that was what she was doing. Maybe that whole exchange was just some small piece of a master plan. I’d have to be on my toes just in case.

Seeing that the room was slowly starting to empty I assumed lunch was almost over. Quickly cleaning up I headed back to the classroom, taking my seat moments before the rest of the class came in. They all looked at me for a moment as I could almost see the thoughts going through their head. Some of them had already labeled me as a trouble maker and others were scheming as to how to buddy up to me because they saw me as strong. School was more about politics then anything else sometimes.

Liz came in with a smile and a nod of greeting which I returned. Our little silent exchange was not lost on the rest of the class as whispers began circulating. Those whispers died down though as soon the teacher entered the room. If the schedule was right this would be the second half of alchemy, hands on application. Mr. Yetz gave role call quickly before closing his book and addressing the room at large.

“We have a special guest today class. She is one of the top alchemist in the nation and she has graciously accepted our request to come teach you. She comes from a long line of Hunters. A tenth generation Hunter in fact ”

No, it couldn’t be. She wouldn’t. Please don’t let it be big sis Ulinia.

“Please welcome Ulinia Zolkov!”

The crowd began whispering excitedly but then looked around in confusion as no one entered the door. Of course she wouldn’t do something as simple as walk through the door. She was a bit crazy after all. A plume of green smoke appeared in front of the desk suddenly and I resisted the urge to cover my face. Always the showoff with the grand entrances. The smoke rose up and thickened until my sister stepped out, throwing her hands wide to an applause only she heard.

Her hair was colored blue and yellow today, and tied in a ponytail. Her shirt only had one long sleeve on it, the other one ripped off to showcase the tribal tattoo running from her wrist to her shoulder. She wore a pair of loose fitting jeans with bottles hanging all over them on spelled wire, the knees ripped to show her skin. She looked around the room at all the wide eyed faces and spotted me, her face splitting into a huge grin.

“Riki tiki!”

She jumped onto the teachers table and lept towards me, running across the desks. I only had a second before she threw herself at me.
11112112.title: Go to cafeteria

111121121.content:
I simply let her launch herself across the last two desks and over the two boys sitting there to wrap her arms around my neck. I suffered her rubbing her face against mine and kissing me on cheek and forehead. It wasn't like there was anything I could do after all. If I had tried to avoid her, we would have probably messed up the room and I would still end up in her clutches like this. She might have even used a potion to immobilize me. No point in make more of a scene then I already was.

"Oh Riki tiki! I missed you so much! Why didn't you tell me you were coming to this school! Why are you even at this school my Riki tiki? I thought for sure mama and papa would have let you go slaying with them. Oh you would have loved the last job I was on! You've got to come with me next time! Say yes!"

I gritted my teeth as I peeled my sister away. She kept grabbing at me until I finally snagged one of the potions from her side and threw it in her face. She stiffened up like a board and fell over on her side. Bending down next to her I grabbed the antidote and dangled it over her head so she could see.

"Sis. Get a hold of yourself. Remember where you are. In case you forgot I'm not the little boy you taught to make potions anymore. If you promise to behave yourself, I will give you the antidote. Blink twice if you understand."

She blinked twice. I nodded and poured the green liquid that turned into smoke the moment it touched the air on her face. She loosened up again and I helped her to her feet. She pouted, but I kept my face blank and stern.

"You big meanie! Doing that to your big sister."

"Yeah yeah, the same old song and dance with you. Don't you have a class to teach?"

She gave me another pout which I ignored, only my mom seemed to have the ability to sway me with her pouts. Finally my sister sighed and turned away, allowing me to return to my seat, ignoring the stares of the rest of the class. Across the way Liz nodded knowingly, giving me a small sympathetic grin before turning her attention to the front of the classroom.

"One of the biggest things you have to remember about Alchemy is the need to be exact in everything. I'm sure you heard it before but it needs to be said over and over. If the formula calls for the liquid to be at 22.3 degrees, it better not be one point over or under that mark or the whole thing can be ruined. That's not to say you can't find some unique potions on accident, but more often then not it will just fizzle, wasting all the time you spent on it."

She continued to give a few instructions before everyone began pulling out their mini chemistry labs. Since I didn't have one yet, I used one of the spares sitting along the back wall. While the rest of the class followed the instructions they were given, and Ulinia walked around pointing out tips to improve what they were doing, I quickly worked on my own. Not waiting to be told to add an ingredient or do any of the small stuff. I had a mid level potion of stasis and the antidote done by the time the rest of the class finished their health potions. When Ulinia came over to me I handed her both sealed vials.

"To replace what I used. I would have made high grade versions but I didn't have the supplies or the time."

Her eyes grew all huge and began to waver like she was going to cry. When she opened her arms to grab me up in a hug I held up my arm to hold her at arms length.

"Stop! Don't even think about it."

Her lower lip quivered slightly.

"Please? Just a little one? I need to fill up my tiki tank. It's only at half full right now since you stopped me earlier. I won't be home for a while so I need it to keep me going!"

With a sigh I lowered my hand, feeling like a fool for doing so. She gave a small squeal of delight before throwing herself on me and rubbing against my face again.

"Thank you Riki! My tiki tank is at one hundred percent power now!"

I heard a few snickers and glared over her shoulder, which quieted them down. The bell rang and everyone began put away their kits.

"Gotta run! Give mom my love!"

She dropped another transportation potion on the ground, stepping through the green mist after blowing me a kiss. I resisted the urge to rub my forehead as I picked up my bag and headed with the rest of the class towards the combat arenas. They kept glancing back at me and talking under their breath but I did my best not to notice. This was why I hadn't given my last name. I could already see the way things would go. Soon enough a few would approach me to be "friends" but in reality they wanted to use me or my family connections. It was just the nature of up and coming Hunter's trying to secure employment in the future at the best jobs they could.

"So you're a tenth generation Zolkov huh? That explains a lot."

"How'd you figure it out?"

"I don't know, I'm a bit of a genius like that."

I kept my face a mask so she wouldn't see the grin trying to break through. She might still be an enemy. I couldn't let myself get too friendly with her.

"You must have it harder then me. Especially with a sister like that."

"She's not that bad once you get to understand her. Personally, I think she's like that because she's sniffed a few too many of her concoctions. Maybe a potion gone wrong or something. But she's been that way ever since I can remember."

"So what is your first name anyway? As you figured I was asleep when you came in and no one talks to me. I really hope it isn't Riki tiki, otherwise I might not be able to keep a straight face."

"Riktal. And only my sister gets to call me that. I won't put up with anyone else using that name."

She looked around to make sure no one was close enough to hear before leaning her head closer while talking in an undertone.

"My big brothers nickname for me is Lizzy Lili. I think it might be an older sibling thing to give embarrassing nicknames. Now you got leverage against me if I am ever tempted to use your pet name."

"What's your angle anyway? You seem a little too friendly for someone I just stabbed a few hours ago."

She simply shrugged and kept walking next to me for a few moments.

"No angle. I told you not to worry about the whole stabbing thing didn't I? It's just-- it's been a long time since I had anyone I could really talk to about Hunter stuff. I'm not talking about schoolroom fluff or amateur stuff like where I want to go when I graduate. I'm talking about things someone from an old family would understand. Like the feeling of the first kill, what training was like and how you handled your first mistakes. It is kind of hard to explain because I'm not good with words but you understand right?"

"Yeah I understand. You want to be able to talk about the hardships of being a fifth generation, always in someone else's shadow and the expectations of you. Just someone who understands where you are coming from and can make you feel better just by lending an ear without the judgments of those who don't know what it's like. In other words, a friend."

"Exactly."

"What the hell. It's part of my punishment for stabbing you anyway."

I held out my hand and she shook it, looking at me a bit quizzically.

"What?"

"Never mind, it's nothing."

She let go of my hand as we came to the arena and split to either side to gear up. It took only a moment to sit my bag in a locker for safekeeping and another to begin digging through it. My hand stopped as I realized I was missing a few weapons. Namely my Lexington double barrel revolver and my Roller Knuckles. Had I left them at home this morning? I wasn't sure. I thought I had packed them, but I had been in a rush. Could one of my new classmates have taken them? It was possible since I had left the bag unattended for lunch.

I needed to get them back. They were dangerous weapons in the hands of someone unqualified in their use. But what was the best way to approach this problem? I wasn't even sure someone had taken them. If I told a teacher there was no telling when or if I would get them back. If I didn't get them back soon, there was no telling what damage someone might cause with them. It wasn't like I didn't trust the teacher's, but in this case quicker action might be better.
111121121.title: Do nothing

1111211211.content:
I’d already caused enough trouble for one day. It would be best if I simply informed one of the teachers and let them take care of it. I wasn’t even sure if anyone had stolen them after all. I’d keep my eyes and ears open of course, but it was best to let someone in authority handle the situation. Especially with my short temper, I was likely to do something I would end up regretting.

So against my better judgment I took a moment to speak privately with the arena master. He assured me he would be on the lookout for anything suspicious and would pass the word on as well. I thanked him before double-checking that my locker was locked and heading out into the combat area.

“Today will be slightly different. We won’t be having sparring practice as normal. Today is a practical application day. You will be split up into five groups of four or five, you will work as a team to take down some monsters. Utilizing what you have learned and the skills you have gathered in hand to hand and weapons combat. These monsters have been deemed a sufficient test of your skills.”

“Hawthrope! Zelkov! Since you two are already past this point you will sit out for now.”

I inclined my head to the arena master before climbing up into the bleachers around the large rectangular room. Liz was right behind me as a wall rose out of the floor to cut the room in half. Two of the chosen groups entered the rings as the remaining ones waited on the sidelines in excitement. The floor opened again and a Screecher Bird came into view. I shook my head as one of the boys ran yelling headlong at the bird with his sword raised. Just as quickly he was flying through the air to land on his butt.

“Stupid. By this time they should know a Screecher reacts to loud noises by emitting a gust of wind from its wings.”

“You can’t tell me the first time you fought a real monster you forgot some of the basics of fighting them in the thrill of the moment.”

I looked over at Liz and blinked.”

“No I didn’t. My father tossed me up against a Gorpal giant as my first kill.”

She gave a low whistle of appreciation. Gorpal giants were mean creatures that were as fast as they were strong. But they were dumb. Still one wrong move against one of them by a novice would turn you into red jelly slathered over their spiked clubs.

“I faced a Fabrooze my first time. The thrill went to my head and I blew it up with an explosive potion. It reconstructed itself, but not before eating my shirt and pants.”

I grinned at the thought of her fighting the thing in her underwear.

“You best not be thinking anything dirty.”

“Oh no not me. I’m imagining them clean and white.”

She smacked me on the arm and I laughed while rubbing the spot. It hadn’t been full force but it had a bit of bite to it. Finally she began to chuckle to.

“Ok so it wasn’t my finest moment. And they were blue by the way not white.”

“I’ll make sure to keep that in mind for when I remember it in the future.”

The two of us watched as the first groups defeated their birds and the next groups stepped up to fight some Overloks, creatures that looked like five foot tall snakes with three heads. As they fought and surrounded the beast, the natural leaders began to stand out. They issued orders on the fly and changed up battle strategies with split second analysis of the situation.

Finally the three headed snakes were downed and the last group was stepping into the ring. So far it had taken each group about seven or eight minutes to kill their prey proving just how low their skill level was compared to mine. It would have taken me a minute or less for such weak creatures. As the last group got ready a Sengwen rose out of the floor, stomping its front hoof menacingly. The silver talon on the other five shone evilly under the light as its human torso and arms flexed in anticipation. The horses head looked around with beady intelligence.

“This group must be slightly better then the last four. That’s a step above the other monsters.”

“Yeah I just hope they don’t do something stupid like use magic on it.”

“You think they would?”

“Gregory might. Just to make it transform and try to show off. He’d get his arms handed back to him separated from his body of course, but he’s the type who doesn’t know when he is outmatched, always trying to prove something.”

The one she pointed out as Gregory pulled something from behind his back and aimed it at the creature. I jumped to my feet in surprise, pointing my finger at him. He had my gun!

“Don’t fire that!”

Either my words didn’t reach his ears or they came too late, I wasn’t sure which one. I could almost see everything happening in slow motion. The bullet exited the bottom barrel as a line of magic left the top. The magic enfolded the bullet , creating a green shroud that would amplify the speed and force of the shot. As the bullet moved forward Gregory was lifted of his feet and thrown backwards by the force of the kickback. As he came down the bullet struck the Sengwen square in the chest. It soaked up the magic which had been increased by the power from the bullet as the projectile stopped as if it had hit an invisible wall.

I was already moving as the slug dropped to the ground without doing any damage. The beast glowing with the green magic it had just absorbed. Vaulting over the side of the banister onto the wall I watched the beast closely. I felt Liz’s presence right behind me as we ran towards the creature. It grew another set of arms and the mouth opened as the human like teeth turned into green tipped fangs.

“I got the head. You get the backside.”

“Roger.”

I leapt off the wall with Liz a second behind me. As I spun to the right I imbued my legs with magic for extra strength. External magic was useless against these creatures, it only made them stronger. My right leg shot out and connected with the side of its head just as Liz’s left foot smashed into its flank on the other side. It twisted and crumpled under our attack, falling on its side and skidding along the ground. But that wouldn’t stop it for long.

Dashing over to Gregory I yanked the weapon from his hand, giving him a look that could have made steel instantly combust.

“I’ll deal with you later idiot. Just answer yes or no. Do you have my knuckles to?”

He shook his head quickly, pointing to another boy close by. I held out my hands and the boy pulled the weapons out so fast I thought his hands would detach from his arms. Snatching them off of him with a growl I pointed to the arena master.

“All of you go! Get out of here now!

They ran like bats out of hell as the Sengwen began clambering to it’s feet, its now black talons leaving gouges in the cement floor.

“Liz you know how to use these?”

She saw the knuckles and nodded.

“Well enough. Never actually had a pair but I know the basics.”

I handed them to her and she put them on quickly. They had mini circular saw blades inset into the knuckles that would spin when activated.

“Switch is in the palm, just clench the fist and they start up. Keep them loose until impact to save on magic usage. “

“Got it.”

“You flank right I go left. I’ll grab its attention first. Switch up when his eyes change color.”

We split up, going our respective direction as I hit the switch on my Lexington to stop the magic from flowing out when I fired. Five bullets. More than enough, I only needed three. As the creature began to turn towards Liz I fired a round, smacking it between the eyes. The bullet didn’t even make a dent since it was using the magic it had stolen to become almost invulnerable until it ran out. But I was just buying time. Physical attacks would chip away at that stolen magic until it could be killed.

I dodged in and out of its swipes, blocking it’s claws with my weapon and keeping it’s attention on me while Liz went to town with the gloves. Jumping over the hind legs when they kicked out, as well as keeping out of reach of the tail that would feel like a whip. The eyes began to flicker from red to blue as the stolen energy began to fade.

“Switch!”

She leapt into the air, coming back down with her right fist leading. I saw the blades spinning as she gave them juice seconds before smashing into the side of the creatures face. I was already rolling backwards out of the way so the beast would focus on her as the primary and closest target. Blood flew everywhere as they ripped through the flesh of its cheek. When it’s two arms swiped at her she twisted in the air, punching down with her left fist to tear up the flesh while she avoided the attack. While it was turning I launched myself forward, hooking the neck as I swung around over its back, the Lexington in my left hand. As I came around the other side I shoved the gun into the open mouth and fired off two shots up into its brain.

I landed on my feet as it fell to the ground, dissolving into thin air and leaving a pouch behind. Bending down I grabbed the spoils and opened it up. Inside was a rare heart crystal. I knew a few dealers that would pay good money or even trade high quality weapons for this little thing. They were used to store magic for artifacts and weapons. Liz pulled off the gloves, handing them back to me as the arena master came running up with the rest of the class.
1111211211.title: Notify a teacher

choices: Give them a few more punches
11112112111.content:
“Here take it, you earned it.”

I held the crystal out Liz who looked at it in surprise.

“What! But those are worth a small fortune! Why?”

“Because you did most of the work. I just kept it’s attention, you beat its shield down. Think of it as my sign of friendship. If you don’t know anyone who will give you a good deal I can introduce you.”

“I thought we were already friends.”

“Maybe. But now I know I can trust you. My uncle Parlin used to say, you can get a feel for the true nature of a person once you fight beside them. I’ll stick by that. So take it, I really don’t need it. If you really don’t want it or can’t use it I’ll keep it. No use wasting a good heart crystal.”

She stared at it a moment longer before finally palming it with a soft thank you.

“Did you mean what you said about knowing a good broker?”

“Aye. If you want I can introduce him to you after school. He’s been a friend of the family for years. He’s the one that made me these Spinning Knuckles. You would be amazed at the things he can do.”

“I’d like that.”

I gave her a quick smile before turning my gaze on the two boys that had stolen my gear. The grin withered from my lips as my blood began to boil. I felt my fist clench and my teeth begin to hurt from clamping them together so hard.

“Arena Master. Am I wrong to believe that stealing another students gear is a grave offence at this school?”

“No, you aren’t wrong. Each students gear is like a part of themselves. We don’t tolerate such things lightly.”

“Then would I be out of line to wish to punish them myself? More importantly, would I be able to without breaking any school rules?”

“Normally not. But right now you are in the arena. This is my domain and my decisions supersede even that of the principals in this area.”

“Then do I have your permission to give them a good thumping if I promise not to kill them or dismember them?”

“Only if you agree to two other conditions.”

“What’s that?”

“You don’t break more than three bones and you use no cutting weapons.”

“Easily agreed. Since I am much better than them, I don’t mind if they use any weapons of their choice. I’ll stick with my own fists and feet.”

Gregory and the other boy I still did not know the name of were both shaking in their boots. Holding up their hands and shaking their heads in negation.

“Look sorry ok! I don’t want no trouble. I don’t want to fight you. Just let us go ok?”

“I’m sorry! It was all Gregory’s idea! I didn’t want to but he talked me into it!”

“First Hunters code, all Hunters are responsible for his or her own actions. No one forces you to do anything. Each choice made is a choice the individual makes of his own will. You allowed him to talk you into it. That means you are just as guilty. And quite frankly I don’t care if you are sorry or not, or if you don’t want to fight or not. You don’t have a choice.”

I lunged forward, snagging them both up by the collar and throwing them behind me.

“Arena Master, please box us in.”

The rest of the class backed away as the Arena Master manipulated an artifact in his hand. Four walls rose around us, turning as clear as glass once they were in place. I simply stood there watching the two after sitting my gear down against the wall.

“Choose your weapons. I’m sure the good Master will be able to provide them for you. I won’t start until you make your decision and I won’t allow you to leave until I beat the snot out of you.”

After a bit more sniveling the one named Gregory asked for a standard sword and board set up. A simple long sword and large circular buckler that attached to the arm and unfolded like a fan appeared from the floor. The other boy got a quick load repeating crossbow that used magic arrows.

“Before we begin, what’s your name boy? It’s only proper to know who it is I am going to pound into the ground.”

“I-I’m Daniel.”

“Pleasure to meet you Daniel. Consider me a monster and give me everything you got.”

With that I began walking towards them. Not even trying to be quick. Daniel fired an arrow at me that I simply sidestepped. It had been halfhearted to begin with. After a moment Gregory charged at me with his shield up and his sword raised.

He feinted with the sword and tried to smash the shield into my face but the move was clumsy. He had put too much commitment into the feint, making him go off balance. Twisting to the left was all it took to avoid the sword strike. Daniel was hesitating because I was so close to his partner, a grievous mistake if I had really been a monster. As I walked past, I smashed my elbow into the side of Gregory’s head, continuing to head towards the shooter.

In a real fight where they knew what they were doing, this wouldn’t be a bad setup. A ranged person being protected by a shield bearer. But right now they were running on fear. Their training and strategy had gone out the window. I made sure to keep myself between the crossbow and the tank. That was all it took to keep him from shooting at me. I gave an evil grin as I slowly got closer and closer.

He finally took another shot when I was almost at point blank range. I saw his finger twitch, that was what I had actually been staring at the whole time. So I knew when it would fire. I did a split, letting it sail harmlessly over my head. Popping back to my feet and continuing to take deliberate steps towards him without missing a beat.

“Crossbow wasn’t a bad choice, but you are inexperienced at it, I can tell. You should have got something you knew how to use. It wouldn’t have done you any good of course, but at least you wouldn’t be so far out of your element.”

I slapped the crossbow out of his hands negligently as I cocked my fist back. His eyes went wide in fright as I dropped to one knee and spun, bringing my fist up into Gregory’s stomach under his sword strike. Spittle went flying from his mouth as the sword clattered to the ground and he fell to his knees clutching his abdomen.

“Come on. Did you really think I didn’t know you were sneaking up behind me? It was a good try though.”

As I turned around I brought my other fist up into Daniel’s gut, making him vomit a bit as he sank to the floor.
11112112111.title: Give Liz the crystal

111121121111.content:
I kicked them both a few more times. not with all my might, but still a few good thrusts of my foot. How dare they steal from me! To touch someone else's property without permission and then to use it as if it was their own! Not even caring that the very person they stole it from was in the very same room as them! I should kill them. They deserved to die. a good solid kick augmented with magic strength would take their heads right off.

But I had promised not to kill them or dismember them. I was allowed to break a few bones though. Three of them each. The thumbs of each hand at least, and maybe a leg bone. That would teach them. I looked down at the two rolling and moaning on the ground. They looked pitiful. Hardly Hunter material. They looked like to normal people I might find on the street on any given day. Seeing that my anger drifted away as suddenly as it had come.

“Arena Master! Drop the walls please. I’m done. They are too weak for me to even stay angry at. Punishing them just isn’t worth it.”

As the walls started to lower I turned, grabbing up my gear and leaving the arena. I was already regretting my hasty action. I knew I was stronger then them. What had that really proved? It had just been me soothing my own rage. Hunter’s weren’t supposed to act like this, they were heroes of the people, protecting those weaker then them. There was enough problems with monsters, people didn’t need to be fighting each other, isn’t that what aunt Ceflia had said? Plus I had to uphold the family name. Even if I didn’t like that name, what I did reflected on the rest of my family.

Big sis could get away with having such a unique personality because she produced results. And while quirky, her personality didn’t really hurt anyone unlike mine. Compared to everyone else in the family, I was just a no name Zelkov.

I sat on the bench, pulling my glasses off my face and rubbing my eyes. Why did I have to be born like this anyway? I was trying to change, I really was. I didn’t want to be the terror of the school this time. The one everyone feared to cross and was looked at like some super powerful monster. But it seemed that personality kept creeping in, no matter what I did. Any good deeds I did or gestures of peace I made would be overshadowed by my rash actions. I would probably be doomed to repeat the same actions over and over so why should I fight it? If I was meant to be some sort of monster who was I to go against that fate?

Replacing my glasses on my nose I stuffed the recovered weapons back into my duffle bag. I had to go back out there. Class wasn’t over yet and I couldn’t make more of a scene then I already had. I had a duty to uphold the family name after all. With a deep breath I let the mask of indifference I had learned to wear drop over my face and returned to the arena, climbing up into the bleachers as unobtrusively as I could. The groups were still sparring against monsters, but there was a bit more caution in their movements now. Liz gave me a small smile as I sat down next to her before returning her attention to the floor below. We sat in a companionable silence for a bit, neither one of us feeling the need to break it.

“For what it’s worth, I probably would have done the same thing. I think you did good. You gave them enough of a beating that they will remember, without going overboard compared to their skill level. You didn’t do anything super crazy or act in any way they couldn’t counter.”

“It wasn’t intentional. I wasn’t even thinking of that.”

“No I didn’t think you were. You kind of remind me of my aunt Winny. She would get angry at the drop of a hat and act on it. Then it would all sort of disappear in an instant and she regretted what she did.”

“Oh and what did she do about it?”

Liz shrugged.

“Nothing. She just accepted she was wired differently than everyone else and went on with her life. Did what she felt like doing and let her anger make her stronger.”

“So where is she now?”

“Dead. She had a bad break up with one of her lovers. She got angry and chased after him.”

“He was stronger than her and killed her huh?”

“No. she massacred him and his new girlfriend as well as his parents. So my mom and dad put her down themselves. She had become a danger to the family and our name.”

“Thanks. That story gives me so much confidence in my own future.”

“Sorry. Guess it was a bad example. But I get the feeling you want to change the way people see you. Curb that anger like my aunt wanted to learn to do before she just accepted it as part of her.”

“You got the right feeling.”

“Well I’m sure you will succeed where she failed.”

“Why’s that?”

“You got something she didn’t have. A friend who’s willing to help you.”

“She didn’t have anyone who tried to help her?”

“She did. But she wouldn’t let them.”

We lapsed into silence again as the groups continued to rotate out against different monsters. Sometimes the members changed or the rules did but otherwise it was all basic procedure. I looked at Liz through the corner of my eye. A friend huh? I’d never really had a friend before. I had spent all my time learning the arts of monster slaying from day one. The only people my own age I had interacted with were cousins who were also in the family business. None of them acted like these high school kids who seemed to think this was all a game.

The first five years after they graduated would be the hardest time for them. As they ended up putting into application everything they learned here and came to realize it wasn’t a game. Out of the twenty boys and girls I saw below me at least half of them would be dead before the first five years was up. The ones that past that first five year hurdle had a good chance of reaching old age. Yet despite all the warnings they received when they entered the academy they all seemed to think it didn’t apply to them. They all seemed to think they were immortal.

The claw marks on my back ached at that thought. I had learned that lesson the hard way. Even I had been like them once, thinking I was immortal. Thinking I was different because I had received such intensive training. The Bulabear had surprised and almost killed me. If big sis Ulinia hadn’t been there I would have died. Perhaps that’s why I had such a low tolerance for these people. Because they wouldn’t listen. They continued to act like they were regular high school kids in a regular high school. Going star eyed over a pretty face and acting all giddy around the person they liked.

Maybe it was because I had never been in love before. I knew the principal of it. The feelings I was supposed to have. It had been part of my lessons in understanding my own reactions that my mother and father had taught me. But that had been so I could lock it down or ignore it and do my job as a Hunter. If I let my emotions carry me away in the middle of a battle I could wind up dead. Sacrificing your own emotions or someone you are trying to protect or care about was also part of monster slaying sometimes.

I glanced at Liz again while pushing my glasses back up my nose. She was pretty enough. I could feel the attraction of my body, but the desire was only a small part. The primal instinct of the human body in that respect. It didn’t affect any decisions I made concerning her or my reasons for thinking of her as a friend. Besides, I couldn’t fall in love with her anyway, I had to marry for the good of the family. Being from old blood was more political hassle than anything else sometimes. My mother would probably try to get me to go to another arranged marriage meeting soon. I had shot down the last three and avoided the first two, but sooner or later I would be pressured into making a commitment. When that time came I wasn’t sure what I would do.

“There something on your mind?”

“What?”

“You keep looking at me, so is there something you want to ask?”

“No. I was just thinking you were pretty that’s all. And not understanding how everyone seems to act like normal high school students.”

“Thanks. For calling me pretty I mean. But I’m not interested in a romantic relationship with you.”

“I wasn’t proposing one. Just making an observation.”

“I figured. You probably have to marry for the family like me. I was just making sure we were clear. But for the record, I think you are pretty handsome as well.”

“Thanks. But I’m not interested in a romantic relationship with you.”

“Just making an observation.”

She grinned at me and I grinned back. This really wasn’t so bad, having someone like me who knew where I was coming from without me having to explain myself. Who didn’t misunderstand anything I said that might sound misleading or suspect. Maybe I really could make a fresh start here. And maybe I could control my anger if she was there to help me.

The bell rang, signaling the end of period. I gave Liz a wave as we split again to go back to the locker rooms. Grabbing my bag out of the locker I headed for the classroom alone. Next group was history. I didn’t think I would get into any trouble there, but I had to be on the lookout just in case. Clamping down on any urges to make a scene I might have. I was a Zelkov after all.
111121121111.title: Give them a few more punches

“Arena Master! Drop the walls please. I’m done. They are too weak for me to even stay angry at. Punishing them just isn’t worth it.”

As the walls started to lower I turned, grabbing up my gear and leaving the arena. I was already regretting my hasty action. I knew I was stronger then them. What had that really proved? It had just been me soothing my own rage. Hunter’s weren’t supposed to act like this, they were heroes of the people, protecting those weaker then them. There was enough problems with monsters, people didn’t need to be fighting each other, isn’t that what aunt Ceflia had said? Plus I had to uphold the family name. Even if I didn’t like that name, what I did reflected on the rest of my family.

Big sis could get away with having such a unique personality because she produced results. And while quirky, her personality didn’t really hurt anyone unlike mine. Compared to everyone else in the family, I was just a no name Zelkov.

I sat on the bench, pulling my glasses off my face and rubbing my eyes. Why did I have to be born like this anyway? I was trying to change, I really was. I didn’t want to be the terror of the school this time. The one everyone feared to cross and was looked at like some super powerful monster. But it seemed that personality kept creeping in, no matter what I did. Any good deeds I did or gestures of peace I made would be overshadowed by my rash actions. I would probably be doomed to repeat the same actions over and over so why should I fight it? If I was meant to be some sort of monster who was I to go against that fate?

Replacing my glasses on my nose I stuffed the recovered weapons back into my duffle bag. I had to go back out there. Class wasn’t over yet and I couldn’t make more of a scene then I already had. I had a duty to uphold the family name after all. With a deep breath I let the mask of indifference I had learned to wear drop over my face and returned to the arena, climbing up into the bleachers as unobtrusively as I could. The groups were still sparring against monsters, but there was a bit more caution in their movements now. Liz gave me a small smile as I sat down next to her before returning her attention to the floor below. We sat in a companionable silence for a bit, neither one of us feeling the need to break it.

“For what it’s worth, I probably would have done the same thing. I think you did good. You gave them just enough beating without going overboard compared to their skill level. You didn’t do anything super crazy or act in any way they couldn’t counter.”

“It wasn’t intentional. I wasn’t even thinking of that.”

“No I didn’t think you were. You kind of remind me of my aunt Winny. She would get angry at the drop of a hat and act on it. Then it would all sort of disappear in an instant and she regretted what she did.”

“Oh and what did she do about it?”

Liz shrugged.

“Nothing. She just accepted she was wired differently than everyone else and went on with her life. Did what she felt like doing and let her anger make her stronger.”

“So where is she now?”

“Dead. She had a bad break up with one of her lovers. She got angry and chased after him.”

“He was stronger than her and killed her huh?”

“No. she massacred him and his new girlfriend as well as his parents. So my mom and dad put her down themselves. She had become a danger to the family and our name.”

“Thanks. That story gives me so much confidence in my own future.”

“Sorry. Guess it was a bad example. But I get the feeling you want to change the way people see you. Curb that anger like my aunt wanted to learn to do before she just accepted it as part of her.”

“You got the right feeling.”

“Well I’m sure you will succeed where she failed.”

“Why’s that?”

“You got something she didn’t have. A friend who’s willing to help you.”

“She didn’t have anyone who tried to help her?”

“She did. But she wouldn’t let them.”

We lapsed into silence again as the groups continued to rotate out against different monsters. Sometimes the members changed or the rules did but otherwise it was all basic procedure. I looked at Liz through the corner of my eye. A friend huh? I’d never really had a friend before. I had spent all my time learning the arts of monster slaying from day one. The only people my own age I had interacted with were cousins who were also in the family business. None of them acted like these high school kids who seemed to think this was all a game.

The first five years after they graduated would be the hardest time for them. As they ended up putting into application everything they learned here and came to realize it wasn’t a game. Out of the twenty boys and girls I saw below me at least half of them would be dead before the first five years was up. The ones that past that first five year hurdle had a good chance of reaching old age. Yet despite all the warnings they received when they entered the academy they all seemed to think it didn’t apply to them. They all seemed to think they were immortal.

“What?”

“No. I was just thinking you were pretty that’s all. And not understanding how everyone seems to act like normal high school students.”

“Thanks. For calling me pretty I mean. But I’m not interested in a romantic relationship with you.”

“I wasn’t proposing one. Just making an observation.”

111121121112.title: Turn and walk away

1111211211121.content:
The bell rang and the teacher left, meaning there was only one more class before this day was finally over. But as soon as he walked out the door the talking started. People moved into their own little groups and talked about some of the most unimportant things, like their favorite band, or which boy or girl was cuter. A few brave souls approached me cautiously, I could see they had already formed an opinion of me but still wanted to be associated with my name.

“So it’s really true? You’re from the Zelkov family?”

“What gave it away? My sister or the Arena Master belting it out?”

Why did they have to ask such stupid questions they already knew the answer to? Did they think they were somehow being clever? The girl who had asked the question sort of looked around for support from her friends at my answer. Finding none, she gave a smile I’m sure was meant to be charming and continued on.

“My name’s Izabelle. I’m a second generation Hunter on my mom’s side. I’d love it if you could teach me how to be a better Hunter.”

“I can teach you something right now. Dedicate your everything to being a Hunter. Act as if every decision you make, ever small thing you learn is crucial. Because it is. This is your life on the line. If you think you are in this for glory, or honor, fame and fortune, then you are dead. Those things are simply side effects of your true purpose. Becoming strong enough to protect the regular people from monsters. If you want to become a top rate hunter you throw everything else away until you accomplish that. Relationships? No need for them. Keeping up to date on the current trends or famous people? Unimportant. Quit treating this as a game. This is your life. You eat, sleep, and breath being a Hunter. Anything less and you will be dead before you know it.”

As her smile faded one of the boys next to her grinned at me.

“Come on quit scaring the poor girl! It’s not that bad. My dad’s a Hunter too and he’s not that serious about it.”

“A Hunter is the first line of defense for a town and a town is only as strong as the Hunter’s willing to protect it. One person alone cannot protect a city this size, no matter how good they are. But as Hunter’s we must also be strong enough to take up the load of others when they are injured or killed. You don’t get that strength by doing things halfway. You must be ready to lay down your life and sacrifice yourself and your body at any moment.”

“He’s right. Just as there are all different types of regular people with different strength’s and weaknesses, there are all different levels of Hunter’s. If you want to be the best, you got to work for it. Giving up everything else in the process. You become hard and you learn the meaning of pain. You learn to ignore it and surpass it. That is what it takes to be a top notch slayer.”

The few gathered around me turned in surprise as Liz came up to stand next to me. Apparently they weren’t used to her interacting with anyone.

“But that’s impossible!”

“It’s not impossible. We did it. What we know is what you are supposed to be learning here. So quit treating it like a normal school and grow up already.”

Before they had a chance to say anything else the teacher came in, forcing everyone to return to their seats. He took role call quickly before starting in on the strengths and weaknesses of different monsters. He was just getting into strategies that could be used against the Cawmacaw when the door opened and a woman in a business suit, thin wire framed glasses and neat black hair came in. She whispered something to the teacher and he nodded his head before pointing at me.

“Riktal! You’re wanted by your mother.”
