With a sigh I grabbed my bag and headed out the door with the woman. What did my mother want now? Couldn’t it have waited until I got home at least? The clacking of her high heels echoed down the hallway as she walked at my side.

“I’m Inga by the way, one of your mother’s aides.”

“And I don’t care. I’m not going to see you all that often and you don’t work for me. I don’t need to know your name for you to do your job.”

Inga fell silent again, escorting me to a private room where she asked me to sit down. I ignored the invitation, instead standing by the window and looking outside. What was my mother up to? Where was she anyway? It was unlike her to be late for a meeting that she herself had set up. I heard the door open finally and turned with a few choice words on my lips.

Words which died out as the small white haired girl with red eyes came in the door after my mother. She stood barely four and a half feet tall and had a body like a stick. She carried around a teddy bear in one hand and had a look of perpetual vacant eyed dreaminess on her face. There was a perfectly logical and reasonable explanation for this. She would not have pulled me out of class on my first day for a marriage meeting. Inside the school no less. Even she wouldn’t do something like that.

“Riktal darling! How are you?”

“The same as when I left this morning mother. Care to tell me why you wanted to see me?”

“Would you be a dear and marry this poor child?”

I sucked in a breath, counting to ten. It was a joke, it had to be.

“You’re telling me you pulled me out of class just for this? Granted I wasn’t thrilled to come to school to begin with but I would think you had more sense then this. So I’m leaving now mother.”

As I started to push past her she grabbed me by the arm, her grip much stronger then she looked.

“Wait dear! What’s your answer! You must answer the poor thing!”

“I’ll let you guess at my answer, you got two tries, and one of them isn’t yes.”

She laid her hand against her cheek while sighing dramatically.

“Oh dear. I was afraid you’d say something like that. It breaks my heart.”

Her grip tightened as her voice lowered while flinging me back into the room like a toy.

“Now sit down, we need to talk.”

Rubbing my arm and using a bit of healing magic, I pulled out a chair with my foot before sitting down in it. My mother and the girl sat across the table from me. The little girl still dreamy eyed and hugging her stuffed animal while my mother had her Hunter face on. The one that said she was being totally serious now and not playing games.

“This isn’t a marriage meeting. I was just teasing you a bit. The real meeting is in a week and you will be attending. I won’t let you duck out of it like you did the last one. You can’t keep shirking this issue. You need to make a decision soon. There aren’t many more eligible girls left of the proper lineage you know.”

“Just shut up and get on with it mother. I don’t need the lecture. You give it to me often enough and like every other time you are saying nothing new. If this isn’t about marriage then what is it about?”

“Watch your tongue or I’ll give you a thrashing.”

“Maybe so, but I’ll give as good as I get. You know how good I am, you trained me after all. Plus I really don’t care all that much about the family name. What will people think if the two of us start going at it and destroying this school building? Perhaps get a few innocent people caught in the crossfire? What will they say about the Zelkov’s then if a few people got killed and a building destroyed over a small family squabble huh? So enough with the friendly threats mother. Let’s get down to business. You got on your work face right now, well then so do I.”

“Spoken like a true Zelkov. Very well. I got a job for you. Protecting Asala here. Me and your father can’t ,we were contracted to clear out some caverns in Bornica, we won’t be back for a few days. Your sister is on a job now for the military so probably wont be back for a few weeks.”

“Why me? I’m sure there are other Hunter’s that are qualified for a simple job like this.”

“Because you are a Zelkov. I trust you and as you said, I know how skilled you are. Plus, despite how bad you are with most people, I also know you do well with children. You’re right there are other qualified hunters, but not many I would trust with this task. Especially once they found out what she is.”

“And that is?”

“A monster summoner. You know as well as I those with the cursed magic aren’t looked upon kindly even in the best circumstances. It doesn’t matter to most people, Hunters included, if they can control the monsters they summon.”

“So what’s the catch?”

“The catch is she can’t always control the monsters’ she summons. She hasn’t fully grown into her power yet because it awakened early.”

“Her parents?”

“Dead. Murdered in front of her. That’s why her power awakened. It will only be for a few days. I’ve got a friend who is also a summoner willing to take her in but she won’t be able to get away from her work until then.”

“Likelihood of danger?”

“Direct threats to her life is minimal. Mostly you will be needed in case she summons a monster that she can’t control. It happens more when she is emotionally unstable, fear, intense sadness, that kind of thing. Plus any dangers once people find out what she can do.”

“There is no one else you trust to do this?”

“Well… there is one other person.”

“Then why come to me first? Especially when you were the one who wanted me to come to school and not work as a Hunter. I mean I assume this is going to be a round the clock thing.”

My mother was quiet a moment, staring at the tabletop before looking back up at me.

“Because you’re family.”
1111211211121.title: On to History class.

11112112111211.content:
I looked from the girl to my mother while chewing on my lower lip. Finally I rubbed my eyes and folded my hands on the table, staring back into my mother’s brown orbs.

“So how much am I getting paid?”

“You won’t do this out of the kindness of your heart?”

“Please. I’d never make it as a Hunter if I gave away freebies. You came making an official request for my help. So I expect you to pay me for it.”

She gave me a tight lipped smile.

“That’s my boy. How does a new set of armor sound?”

“How does ten thousand Reul sound? That’s comparable to what a new set of good armor would cost but I can spend it how I want. I’d ask more but this is my first official mission and I’m not technically a licensed Hunter yet thanks to a certain someone telling me I couldn’t take the official test. Personally I think it’s a small price to pay for around the clock protection for at least two days.”

“Deal. But only if you continue to attend school as well.”

“Really! You really won’t let me cut for two days or so! That means I’ll have to bring her with me.”

“That’s my offer.”

As I rubbed my temple I saw the little girl squeeze her teddy bear a little tighter. It wasn’t much, but it was the first sign she had shown that she heard our conversation. Damn my mother. She was right about me having a knack with little children. Lord knows why they liked and trusted me, especially when I couldn’t even get along with most people my own age. That small sign of fear swayed me and I let out another sigh.

“Fine. You’ve got yourself a deal. I still expect my allowance this month though.”

“Aww, Riktal darling! You’re going to break your poor mother’s purse!”

“I’m in tears over here.”

I got to my feet and shook my mother’s hand to seal the deal. I had enough of my allowance left over to take care of any needs for now. Plus I had my small emergency stash saved up if I really needed it. Two or three days shouldn’t be too hard. My mother came around the table and grabbed me up in a hug, kissing both cheeks before saying she had to run. Her aide Inga detached herself from the wall and headed for the door after my mother. Before they got far I quickly called after her.

“Sis said to give you her love.”

She blew me a final kiss before the door closed on her. With that I turned my attention to the girl who was still sitting there in a silence that was starting to get creepy. I sat in the chair next to her as I saw her arms tighten around the bear again.

“So your name is Asala huh? It’s a pretty name. mind telling me how old you are?”

Nothing. Not even a peep. Not a blink of the eyes or a turn of the head.

“Judging by your size and your face, my guess is maybe ten or eleven? Have any likes or dislikes? Favorite foods?”

Still silence. I could see why my mother had wanted to give her to me. She didn’t do well with the quiet types. This girls silence probably unnerved her. And most Hunters I knew would get angry quickly at not getting answers.

“It’s fine if you don’t want to talk. Perhaps you can’t talk. But right now what’s most important is that I get you to trust me. If I’m going to do my job effectively I need you to let me know if anything is wrong. Even if I don’t perceive anything wrong, what’s important is if you perceive trouble. Because if you do, that might scare you and make your power go out of control. Something we really don’t want to happen now do we?”

I laid my hands on the table, resting my head on top of them and looking at her.

“I have a cousin who doesn’t talk. He used to, but someone blew up his house because they had a grudge against his dad. His mom and dad died, so he lives with another cousin now. But the explosion took his voice away. Not like he can speak if he really wants to took his voice away, but it messed up his throat. I talk to him using my hands and fingers. We spent hours upon hours together coming up with words so we can communicate. He could write what he wanted down of course, but where’s the fun in that he had said. It made him feel better when he talked with his hands. Said it made him feel more normal.”

I lifted my head and moved my hands until I was walking two fingers along the back of my right hand in front of her face.

“This was our word for walk. And this is eat, and this is sleep.”

I mimed poking out my eyes with my left hand before making a wiping motion across my mouth with my pointing finger, finally shoving my fingers in my ears and twisting them back and forth while raising and lowering my eyebrows.

“And that was our special code for I have a secret I’ll tell you if you promise to keep it.”

I gave her a lopsided grin.

“It was a work in progress and we couldn’t think up a better name for it.”

She gave a small smile in return and my grin grew. It wasn’t much but it was a start. I looked both ways as if making sure the room was still empty before repeating the motions that I had a secret, raising my eyebrow as I turned my head to the side and gave her a wink. At first I didn’t think she would respond but finally she nodded her head. I leaned a bit closer and lowered my voice conspiratorially.

“Despite how I look and act I really love my family. Even when they act all crazy like. I don’t mind when my big sister fawns all over me, or when my mother acts all lovey-dovey. Or when my father challenges me to “manly” games like who can lift the most weight. Sometimes I even let him win so he doesn’t feel bad that he is getting old. But most of all, I like stuffed animals. I have a secret box of them in my closet my family doesn’t know about. There is just something about being able to squeeze them that feels so good.”

I put my finger to my lip and made a shushing sound before looking around again suspiciously. She blinked and for the first time her eyes lost that faraway look as she giggled at my antics. Finally she looked around the room herself before mimicking my motions. I nodded my head that I would keep the secret and she leaned forward just like I had.

“I miss my mom and dad.”

She put her finger to her lips before her eyes started to tear up. I pulled her into my arms and rocked her back and forth letting her cry herself out. Whispering that I knew she did softly. Finally she stopped crying and I pushed her away from me.

“Better?”

She nodded her head with another small smile.

“Well if you ever want to talk or just have a shoulder to cry on you come see me ok? Maybe when we get back to the house I can show you my collection of stuffed animals. I think I have a little blue rabbit with your name on it.”

Standing up I offered her my hand. She took it a bit hesitantly as the bell rang signaling the end of school. I picked up my bag and headed for the door. As I opened it I remembered my promise to take Liz to see my broker friend. But protecting this girl was my job. If I wandered around town too much with her in tow it would put her in danger, increasing the chances of triggering her power, putting the citizens in danger from an out of control monster. But I had also been taught to never break promises if I could help it.
11112112111211.title: Accept job

111121121112111.content:
Promises needed to be kept, no matter what. Unless it was absolutely necessary to break them. Because in the end a Hunter had only his word to bind him. A customer or a broker or even an ordinary citizen could trust a Hunter almost instantly because of that fact alone. They gave hope when it was needed most to people who couldn’t defend themselves against attack. I couldn’t prove my words false, especially not to another Hunter.

“Hey Asala, you don’t mind if we take a small side trip through town do you? I made a promise to someone.”

She squeezed my hand a bit while shaking her head no. With that bit of assurance I headed towards the classroom, finding Liz just as she was leaving. She looked down at the girl holding onto my hand and back at me with a raised eyebrow.

“A job. You ready to meet my friend?”

“You sure? If you are on a job I can wait until another day.”

“It’s no problem. And Asala here doesn’t mind, she already said so. Might do her some good to get some fresh air and see a bit of the town.”

Liz shrugged in a “if you say so” sort of way, trusting I knew what I was doing. We walked out of the school after stopping at her locker for just a moment. Most of my stuff was in my bag as I hadn’t been assigned a locker yet so there were no problems there. People looked at us sideways as we left the building. Mostly they were staring at me and the little girl I had in tow. Her hand squeezed mine as she sidled closer to my leg, trying to hide from the looks. I squeezed back to let her know I was right here, which seemed to give her some confidence.

It was about a ten minute walk from the school where we talked about random things like the methods used to train us and weapons we were proficient in. I wondered if my mother would mind if I drove the car to school the next few days to increase security on Asala. Well whether she minded or not I thought it best to just go ahead and do it. She had left the girl in my care after all, she couldn’t complain about how I chose to do my job. As we turned the corner in the middle of town I opened the door to the Pasta Palace.

“Your guy works in a restaurant?”

“No. But this is where you can be sure to find him every day at this time. He orders the stuffed ‘shrooms in sauce with a side of linguino every day as a late lunch. He won’t admit it but he comes here because he likes the waitress. Thinks she is too young for him though.”

“Is she?”

“Yes.”

Nerval saw me and waived, beckoning me over as he stabbed another mushroom and ate it.

“Hey Riktal! Haven’t seen you around for a while! Thought you fell off the map after you helped me out with that Wippal infestation I had. Saved me a bit of money you did. Who’s this? Don’t tell me you gone and finally got yourself a wife and kid!”

“Yes Nerval. I got in my secret time machine and went back through time, found the fountain of youth and drank from it before zipping ahead to the future. I then settled down and got married after giving her some of the magical water. We have since been living happily raising our daughter.”

“Got any of it left? I’d pay top dollar for it.”

“No, I think I poured the last of it down the sink at home yesterday.”

He let out a laugh as he shook my hand.

“So what can I do for you? Got some business with me I take it?”

“My friend here acquired a heart crystal. Told her you were the best I knew and would give her top price for it.”

He looked at Liz who gave a small bow of the head while reaching into her pocket. She handed the item over into his waiting palm and he grinned.

“He’s right. I might cheat a few other Hunters out of a few coins but I know my merchandise. Riktal’s one of the good ones. He may act a bit standoffish but he is ok in my book. And if he vouches for you, then you got my seal of approval as well. What’s your name lass?”

“Liz Hawthrope.”

“Hawthrope huh? As in Wilson Hawthrope?”

“That’s my brother.”

“Heard good things about him. He’s another good one. Never dealt with him though, but a cousin of mine in the big city has.”

Nerval pulled out a magnifying glass that he stuck over his eye and looked at the crystal, turning it over and over in his hand while running his fingers around it. He pulled a small hammer out of nowhere and tapped it lightly while holding it to his ear. He even licked it, cocking his head to the side while examining the taste.

“Well It’s a good one. Not super high quality but still high grade. Come from a Sengwen or some comparable level monster I take it?”

When Liz nodded in surprise Nerval continued with a knowing wink.

“Figured. It has the unique taste of stolen magic mixed with horse musk. Well right offhand without weighing it properly or running a conduit test on it, I’d say I can give you seven thousand Reul for it. Or I will trade a weapon worth that much from my shop. If you want me to make you something with it I’ll go up to five thousand, the extra two being my work fee. But if you go with having me make a weapon out of it I can guarantee it will be worth losing out on the extra two thousand.”

“He does good work. I’ll attest to that.”

Nerval handed the crystal back to Liz who put it back in her pocket.

“If you want to check around for a better offer be my guest. Or you can stop by my store next door for a more thorough evaluation.”

“I’ll do that, thank you.”

“My pleasure Miss Hawthrope. Feel free to bring me any other business you want. I’m sure if I don’t have it I can get it for you. And try to keep this guy out of trouble would you?”

He gave another wave as we turned and left the building. I pointed out his shop to her as we passed, proving it really was literally right next door. She thanked me again for the introduction before saying she needed to get going. I said my farewells as she crossed the street, jogging off out of sight. Asala gave my hand a slight yank and I looked down at her. She was holding her stomach, making me wonder what was wrong when I heard it growl. I gave her a small grin as I gripped her hand a bit tighter.

“You hungry huh?”

She gave me a slight nod in affirmation.

“Well then lets get something to eat. You want to find a restaurant or wait until we get home and I will make you something?”

She sort of shrunk into herself when I mentioned eating out, but if I knew little kids they normally couldn’t hold off on eating. She didn’t answer either way so I assumed her reticence at eating out was because she was afraid of people. It seemed like the decision was up to me.
111121121112111.title: Keep your promise with Liz

1111211211121111.content:
Eating out was quicker and it would do her some good. Let her interact with other people and show her not everyone was scary. I was here to protect her in case anything happened and her power went out of control. With that in mind I lead her to a nearby restaurant, letting her order whatever she wanted. The place wasn’t as secure as I could wish and a bit busier than I’d prefer, but my initial threat assessment was low.

As she began eating I studied her closely. Her green dress really was very unflattering the more I looked at it. With its almost puke shading. Her clothes looked a bit tattered around the edges as well. They had probably yanked her away from her home without bothering to let her pack any extra stuff. That bear was probably the only thing she had left of her past life, that was why she held onto it so tightly. Really, it was no wonder she was a bit leery of crowds and people, being moved from place to place while being stared at by strange eyes. Thrust into the hands of people she didn’t know or barely knew and taken to unfamiliar surroundings.

I had probably been the first person to actually take a bit of time to sit down and really talk to her. Bonding with her and showing I cared about what she wanted. I offered her a small bit of stability, which was the biggest thing she needed right now. Especially if her powers went all wonky because of instability. Perhaps I was the best choice for this job, because what she needed right now wasn’t a guardian and protector, but more of a big brother. And I had experience being a big brother.

Her mood seemed to lift a bit by the time we finished our meal and left the building. Though it was hard to tell, she wasn’t glued close to my leg like when we started which made me think this outing was having the desired effect on her.

As we turned the corner I heard alarm bells going off up ahead. A masked man came running out of the bank shooting a gun back into the building. He turned in our direction, taking only a few steps before seeing us. The man pointed his gun at both of us thinking to take us hostage or kill us I suppose. Before I had a chance to act though Asala screamed, shoving her face into her teddy bear. A large red circle appeared on the ground in front of the robber, giving him only a second to look down before a massive hand shot through the hole to tear his head clean off his body.

The hand was followed by an arm at least two stories tall and then a body proportionate to the rest. I grabbed Asala up, putting a bit of distance between us and the Gog. It was a big nasty creature, one of the toughest class of giants out there. I had never actually fought one before but I knew the weaknesses. By the time I sat the little girl back down the Gog had finally extricated itself from the hole. Standing at a staggering seven stories tall, it was going to be a real pain to stop.

Panic was already setting in as the citizens began to run screaming out of buildings and down the street away from it. The police nearby began unloading their weapons into it but weren’t even making a scratch. It would take at least another five to ten minutes before another hunter or even the military could be mobilized to deal with it. A creature like this could easily destroy half the town if left to its own devices and an untold number of lives would be lost. I wasn’t sure if I could handle it on my own, but I knew I could at least stall it until backup arrived to help me take it down. Minimize the damage and the body count.

Glancing down at the little girl who was cowering in fear and crying into her bear I wondered what I should do. I had taken the job of protecting this little girl. I only needed to fight the monsters she summoned if they attacked her. What was happening to the town might be horrible, but my charge wasn’t in danger. The beast wasn’t attacking her. If I left her side there was a chance she would be killed, either in the crossfire or someone seeking retribution that had figured out she had summoned the giant. The wisest course of action was to pick up the girl and get as far away as possible. If the giant followed us then I would deal with it, but if it didn’t then all the better.

What was I going to do?
1111211211121111.title: Eat out

11112112111211111.content:
Damn it! I just couldn’t let innocent people die. Even if I wasn’t an official Hunter I had still trained for situations like this. My duty was to protect the people. What kind of Hunter would I be if I couldn’t protect both this girl and this town at the same time?

Pulling out a small rectangular box I hit the button on the side before handing it to Asala.

“This is a personal protection field. It will deflect most stray flying rubble and bullets. I want you to go hide ok? I’m going to stall this creature until help arrives. I can’t abandon these people. If you understand then go!”

She ran a bit farther away, hiding behind a car. I was already sprinting towards the Gog, yanking my duffle bag open as far as I could and throwing the contents into the air. The twelve weapons inside flew through the air, hovering in place as I expanded a magical field around myself. The rest of my things fell to the street but I didn’t care. I grabbed the leg braces and chest plate as I ran, strapping them on with a few practiced movements. As I got close enough I snagged a six foot sword from the air as I jumped, using magic to boost myself up. My right hand grabbed a hand cannon.

I spun in the air, bringing the sword around with all my might to strike the creatures arm. Even with as much force as I had put into the swing, it barely made a scratch. When the Gog turned towards me I fired the gun, the bullet that was half the size of a real cannonball blasted from the barrel to smash into the beasts left eye. It roared in anger, swiping at me in its rage, but the kickback from my shot had already thrown me out of its reach. With a quick flip I landed back on the street next to the police.

“Evacuate the streets! Priority on citizen safety you hear me! I want at least a three block radius if you can get it. I’ll keep it occupied until backup arrives!”

“Yes sir!”

They scrambled without another word as the giant punched down towards me. I threw the gun away, shoving my hand into an oversized gauntlet without looking, making a fist and swinging at the oncoming punch.

“The gauntlet of ogre’s might blew back the punch temporarily as the ground cracked beneath me. While the fist was flying backwards I jumped again, running along the arm as I cocked back my right hand yet again.

“Soul of blood and bone! Ogre’s might and unbroken stone! Imbue with power for one last blast! Imbue my fist with an Ogre’s wrath!”

With a great yell I swung a powerful haymaker at the side of the giant’s head. My fist and the weapon glowing a mixture of purple and black. The gauntlet broke apart around my hand but the Gog toppled to the ground. My weapons were still floating around me as I discarded my sword, grabbing some magical throwing knives. As I crossed my arms a purple string connected the handles of the eight daggers seconds before I threw them. The weapons imbedded themselves into the ground, pinning its arms and legs before it had a chance to stand up again.

“Soul of web and burning fire. Creature of darkest desire. Poison runs within your veins. Show me spider your tangled banes!”

The daggers shone with a sickly blue light as a phantom spider began to build itself up from the eight knives. The purple threads spreading out into a net across the Gog’s body. Where the lines touched the thick hide began to smoke and burn. It wouldn’t kill it, only make it uncomfortable. But at least this might buy me three minutes if I was lucky. I landed on top of a car, grabbing another shield and sword from my arsenal as I devoted all my magic into keeping the giant pinned down.

The creature roared as it struggled against it’s bonds, but I roared back, in defiance of it’s threat. The police were working as fast as they could to clear as much space as possible from around the monster from what I could see. I had used up quite a few hard hitting weapons already, breaking the heart crystals on two artifacts in order to call upon the essence of the beast trapped inside. If help didn’t come soon I would probably end up breaking at least three or four more. But none of them would be very effective.

I looked around, some sinking feeling in my gut making me seek out Asala. There coming up behind her was another monster. It looked like her power had summoned another one since I could see the red circle just disappearing. It beat on her shields and I knew they wouldn’t stand up forever. Already I could see them beginning to flicker as magic quickly drained from the battery inside. But if I stopped focusing my attention on the Gog it would break out of my chains and I wouldn’t be able to pin it down again.
11112112111211111.title: Stall the monster

111121121112111111.content:
Asala was in direct danger right now. The choice was clear. My mission to protect the girl had to come first. Breaking my focus on the Gog I jumped off the car, running as fast as I could towards Asala. The Ballersnatch, a man sized green humanoid creature with four arms and black bug eyes, saw me coming and cried out a challenge.

I shoved my sword through its mouth before it had time to finish hissing its defiance. With a great flick of my wrist I pulled the blade out of the side of its head while kicking it away from me. The body twitched once before laying still even as I spun around again to the right, leading with my shield to smack a large chunk of building the Gog had thrown my way. I yelled back a challenge when it opened its huge mouth to utter an almost sonic blast of a roar, the wind from the sound making the car behind me move.

The beast punched a nearby building, ripping off the entire top floor before chucking it at me. I couldn’t block it but I could get out of the way of the projectile. I would have to abandon the little girl to do so though. That was just not something I could do. So closing my eyes and accepting my fate I focused all my magic into the strongest shield I could make as I turned my back on the oncoming building, wrapping Asala protectively in my arms seconds before it smashed into the shield.

The barrier held for just a second, absorbing some of the force before giving way and smashing like a truck into my back. I felt something inside me snap even as I began to topple forward, no longer able to feel my legs. Sticking the sword into the ground I leaned against it, fighting through and channeling that pain into my fading magic to keep a shield around the girl.

It was then I saw a swordsman with a weapon in each hand launch himself from the roof of the car in front of me, his swords glowing a light blue to attack the monster behind me. I could hear the sounds of battle raging as darkness began to envelop me. I couldn’t even turn around, all I could do was focus on one single task. Protecting the girl like I was supposed to.

“Don’t worry Asala. As long as I draw breath I won’t let anything happen to you. I will protect you no matter what. Just stay right here underneath me ok? I’m a Hunter. I’m the sword that protects and the shield that defends. Right now I am your sword and shield. No matter what happens from this point on, do your best to keep your power under control ok? Can you promise me that?”

The little girl nodded her head as tears flowed down her face.

“That’s a good girl.”

With that the darkness overcame me finally and I passed out.


I awoke in a hospital room. That wasn’t surprising considering I had just had my back broken. Looking around the room I didn’t see Asala anywhere. With a groan I hit the button to call for the nurse, waiting impatiently until one came. But she wasn’t alone, three hunters came in, one an old woman, one the swordsman I had seen and one a middle aged female wearing plate mail. The nurse gave me a once over before leaving me alone with the three.

“So who are you and what happened?”

“Is that any way to greet the people that saved your life?”

“Thanks. Now who are you and what happened?”

The swordsman stepped forward with a small bow.

“My name is Mason Fullovia. This old bat next to me is Sulia Canalia and the one in plate is Maria Galsworth.”

“Riktal Zelkov. But you probably know that already.”

“Indeed. As to what happened, we got there in time to see you save the girl. But not in time to stop it’s final attack against you. You did well in stalling it for us. You lived up to your family name. With a bit more experience under your belt I doubt you would be in this position now. I’m sure you already realize this but that last attack paralyzed you from the waist down. There was nothing the Priestess could do.”

The woman named Maria walked over to the left side of the bed and laid her hand gently on my arm.

“You impressed me boy. And I don’t impress easily. You don’t have a license as a Hunter but I would have been glad to have you at my back. Unfortunately, the doctors say any chances of you becoming a Hunter are over. Aside from the paralysis, you overexerted your magic. It’s about half as strong as it once was and you won’t get it back.”

“What about the girl I was protecting?”

The old woman named Sulia picked up the story.

“We found you under the rubble, leaning against your sword and unconscious, refusing to fall no matter what. Your shield still surrounding the girl even as it ate away at your body. It was an amazing sight to behold. Something I had only seen once before that would make any Hunter proud to accomplish. The girl seemed to be in shock, unable to speak to us as she held on to you for dear life. She kicked and screamed as we pulled you away from her so we could transport you here. We told her it would be ok but she wouldn’t listen. In the end she summoned a monster, I think she was trying to protect you.”

“That damn freak was of the cursed blood so I slit her throat.”

“Maria! There was a better way to put it. But yes. It seemed that girl you saved was the cause of all of this, we believe she summoned that Gog. When she summoned another monster, even though it was harmless, Maria put an end to her. I’m sorry that you sacrificed your body for her with nothing to show for it.”

“All those cursed magic users deserve to die. It’s the right thing to do.”

I reached over and put my right hand on top of Maria’s gauntlet that was still resting on my left.”

“Maria Galsworth right?”

She looked down at me with a nod.

“I’ll remember that name. Thank you.”

“Your welcome boy. It was the right thing to do.”

“You misunderstand. Thank you for making what I am about to say and do so much easier.”

I summoned all the magic I had and converted it into electricity, sending it down my arm and into the metal of her armor, as her eyes went wide and her body began to convulse I threw myself out of bed, letting my weight smash her to the floor. I moved my hands around hr neck and began to squeeze.

“I promised that little girl that I would protect her. That I would keep her safe. I knew full well what she was capable of. That’s why I was at the scene and able to minimize the damage so quickly. It was my job to protect her. To guard her for two or three days until a teacher could come and give her the training she needed. Her power was unstable but it wasn’t her fault. She was scared, that’s why she summoned the Gog by mistake.

“Now as my final act to her I am going to kill you. I am going to avenger her death and rid the world of a small minded Hunter that can’t see past her own hatred and self interest. It’s an interesting thing how a couple thousand volts of electricity being sent through full plate armor can lock a body up so it can’t fight back. I am going to look into your eyes as the life drains out of them. I want my face to be the last thing you see before you expire. Knowing you were killed by someone who isn’t even a Hunter yet. Someone you would have trusted at your back with your life. By a seventeen year old with probably less than a quarter of the experience you have.”

“And you are wrong about one other thing. I will become a Combat Hunter. That is what I was born and bred to do. Not being able to use my legs won’t stop me. Not having half the power of other Hunter’s won’t stop me. Nothing is going to ever stop me from doing the only thing I know how to do. Slay monsters. And I will dedicate my life to spreading the art of monster summoning to the world just to spite you. Now please die.”

I gave one final squeeze, adding a bit of magic into my hands until my fingers ripped through her flesh and came together. As I levered myself up I spit in her face before crawling around on the floor to grab onto the bed. Inch over painful inch I hoisted myself back up until I was reclining back on the pillows with my legs dangling over the side. I looked at the other two monster slayers who hadn’t moved an inch.

“Either one of you got a problem with what just happened? If so speak up, otherwise get out of my sight.”

“No, it was in your right to do so. A Hunter see’s their job through to the end no matter the cost. You saw justice for your client served like a true Hunter. I always told her that hatred of hers would get her killed one day. Good day to you Riktal Zelkov. I look forward to seeing what kind of Monster Hunter you turn out to be.”

The two walked out of the room after giving me a quick nod. I simply stared at the glassy eyes of the woman I had just killed. My mind filled with Asala. Yet another little girl I had been unable to save and protect.

***********

Well, that was an interesting first day indeed. Are you proud of the choices you made? Were they easy for you to make? Did any of them make you second guess yourself? What would you do if you had the chance to do it over again? Would you make the same choices? Would you change them all? Do you believe there was only one right answer in all of this? Or do you feel your choices didn’t matter? That the same outcome would happen no matter what?

In this world of possibilities who can say? This is only one possible future of the young Riktal Zelkov. Only one path his life could and has taken. Just as there are an endless number of possibilities, so to is there an endless number of futures for those possibilities. Choices and actions that are further complicated by the choices and actions of other people. So you see, being a god and unraveling this tangled web is not as easy as it seems.

Our time grows short. You have interested me and sated some of my curiosity. I wish you well until next we meet. Then I shall ask again, what kind of god shall you be?
111121121112111111.title: Go to Asala's aid

111121121112111112.content:
“Asala! Run towards me!”

She ran towards me without hesitation. I waited until she was close enough that I wouldn’t miss, holding all my attention on the Gog until the last possible moment. When she was in range I turned, throwing my sword like a javelin and impaling the Ballersnatch through the head. The humanoid like creature with green skin and four arms twitched once as it flew backwards before halting its movements.

I returned to focusing all my attention on the Gog, but that split second that I had pulled my focus away from channeling every ounce of my magic allowed the beast to break it left arm free from my bindings. It swiped at me even as I pushed backwards with my feet to avoid it. Throwing my right arm up to block the blow with the buckler I held.

In mid swing it opened its meaty hand, turning it’s punch into a grab, encasing my right arm in its grasp. I could feel its crushing fingers turning my flesh into a mass of pulp even as the blood oozed out between his fingers. Locking down on the pain I heaved with all my might, tearing the useless flesh off and jumping out of the way while pushing Asala behind me with my remaining arm.

I let the pain and anger flood me, channeling it into my remaining magic power to lock the beast down as long as I could. Now it was a race against time, a battle of wills to see what would happen first, the monster breaking free from my control or me passing out from blood loss. I managed to lock down its free arm using raw power brought on by the intense pain but that adrenaline rush wouldn’t last long.

Fortunately I didn’t have to find out how long I could keep this up as three heads poked over the ledges of rooftops. A rain of arrows, bullets and chemical mixtures bombarded the Gog. A female Hunter jumped off the nearby rooftop, throwing her left arm across her chest as she hurtled towards the beast. A massive shield grew into being as tall and wide as she was as she fell. Up and down the length spikes began to sprout, a massive one shoving its way a good seven or eight inches past the rest. She landed on the monsters face with the force of a small earthquake, the large spike slamming into the remaining good eye.

As she bounced backwards, another Hunter around his mid thirties jumped over my head with a sword in either hand. Each one glowed with a light blue color as he brought them both down on the creatures neck, but making only a small scratch. As he pulled one of the swords back he pointed it straight at the small cut he had made before the sound of a gun firing went off and smoke plumed up from the hilt. My bonds were starting to fade as another set of green ropes crossed over the creature. An old woman stepped up next to me, her eyes staring intently at the Gog.

“You did good boy. Saved us a lot of work. But I’ll take it from here. Save your remaining strength and stop that bleeding. There’s a Priestess on the way from the church. She will be here in a moment. Try not to pass out until then.”

With a sigh I let go of my bonds, pulling my magic back inside myself as I staggered back a few steps to sink down to the ground, leaning against a nearby car. It took only a moment to manipulate the flow of blood so I wasn’t leaking my life juice all over the place. Asala was crying as she clung to me, her lips moving but no words coming out. But I still read what she was saying.

“I’m sorry! I’m sorry!”

I put my hand on her head and stroked her hair.

“This isn’t your fault. I’m the one who made the choice to stall that thing not you. I knew the risks I was getting into. I knew the risks of being a Hunter long ago, but I still decided on this lifestyle. It’s only an arm. I can still be a Combat Hunter without it. Don’t let anyone tell you this was your fault. I’ll fight them tooth and nail if they try. The important thing is you are safe. You understand me?”

She buried her face in my chest as I continued to stroke her hair, telling her it would be all right. When my vision began to get blurry and I started seeing two of everything I closed my eyes and took a few deep breaths. I couldn’t pass out, I still had to protect this girl. The six Monster Combat Hunters were continuing there assault against the Gog, dancing in and out, never giving it time to recover or counter attack. Slowly cutting deeper and deeper into its almost impenetrable hide. Working in perfect sync while calling out instructions to the others. A Hunter mainly worked alone, but he had to be able to mesh with others at the drop of a hat. These were all professionals.

A soothing hand on my arm made me look over, forcing the fuzziness in my brain to go away. A Priestess was holding her hands over my wound, growing new flesh to scab over into a stump while burning away any infection.. Once she was done with that task she placed a cool hand on my head a moment before I became clear minded again. Handing me some magically imbued bread she told me to eat. I did so knowing it would quickly replenish my lost blood if not my magic.

“Is the girl hurt?”

“No she is fine. I protected her and she is my charge. There is no need to worry about her.”

The Priestess nodded as the Gog gave a final death rattle, the Hunters finally lowering their weapons and the ones on the rooftops jumping to the street. The Priestess quickly examined each of them, healing a few minor cuts but otherwise pronouncing them fit. She looked around at the street and buildings, seeing very little damage and no other bodies.

“Well you guys sure acted quickly this time. I think that’s the first time I have seen such a powerful monster taken care of without any corpses littered at it’s feet.”

“Thank the boy here. He had it flat on it’s back and pinned by the time we came. Made our job a hell of a lot easier. It’s not everyday you can have such an easy kill.”

The man who had been swinging the two swords around held out his hand and I shook it.

“What’s your name boy? Mine’s Mason. Mason Fullovia”

“Riktal. Riktal Zelkov.”

“Ah. That explains how you were able to stall it by yourself. Worked with your father once, glad to see his son is just as good. Any idea how it got into town undetected?”

“Not sure. I think it was summoned in. Saw it come out of a red circle.”

“Any idea who did it?”

“No clue.”

The woman who had the giant shield gave a tsk of disgust before spitting to the side.

“Damn cursed freaks. They should all just die. This world would be better off without them.”

I hugged Asala tighter to my side as she tried to shrink even further under my arm. Once I had assured her with a small squeeze that I wouldn’t giver her up I staggered to my feet, unobtrusively taking a step forward and to the side to hide the little girl.

“They aren’t all bad ma’am. They can do some good to. I’d be pleased if you held your tongue on the matter as well. I have a good friend who is a summoner I’ll have you know. If you can’t keep your tongue from wagging with such poison I shall be forced to rip it out for you.”

All the other Hunters laughed at that while the woman glowered at me.

“Kid’s got spunk, you got to give him that much Maria. Gets his arm crushed by a giant after incapacitating it single handedly before ripping it off himself. Turns around after draining himself to the dregs to throw out a challenge to a veteran like that. The hell of it is, I even think he could do it too!”

The old woman who had replaced me in holding down the monster put her hand on my shoulder good naturedly.

“I got a feeling you have a bright future as a Hunter boy. Names Suli Canala. I run a private tutoring business for those that want to get an extra leg up on becoming Hunter’s. You’ve got a job if you are interested.”

“Thanks ma’am. I might take you up on that. But right now I need to get my charge here off the streets and into bed.”

She nodded her understanding as I turned away. I heard them begin to shout out instructions to the police who were starting to gather now that the monster was slain. I figured I would be getting a visit from one or more of them later when they finally split up the spoils. But I didn’t need to worry about that now. Right now I just wanted to get home and go to bed. I’d had enough for one day.

*********

Well, that was an interesting first day indeed. Are you proud of the choices you made? Were they easy for you to make? Did any of them make you second guess yourself? What would you do if you had the chance to do it over again? Would you make the same choices? Would you change them all? Do you believe there was only one right answer in all of this? Or do you feel your choices didn’t matter? That the same outcome would happen no matter what?

In this world of possibilities who can say? This is only one possible future of the young Riktal Zelkov. Only one path his life could and has taken. Just as there are an endless number of possibilities, so to is there an endless number of futures for those possibilities. Choices and actions that are further complicated by the choices and actions of other people. And those choices and actions are then in turn influenced by yet more choices by yet more people. So you see, being a god and unraveling this tangled web is not as easy as it seems.

Our time grows short. You have interested me and sated some of my curiosity. I wish you well until next we meet. Then I shall ask again, what kind of god shall you be?
111121121112111112.title: Focus on the Gog

11112112111211112.content:
My duty to the girl came first. It was a shame, and not a decision I made easily but I had been given a job to do. I couldn’t ignore that job just because hundreds of people were in danger. What kind of Hunter did that make me then? What did it say about me?

Grabbing the girl up again after quickly slipping my arms through the straps of the duffle bag and hoisting it onto my back I ran. I could hear the sounds of destruction and the screams being cut short as the giant crushed the unknown people. The ground shook as it stomped around and buildings fell. But I didn’t look back, I didn’t falter. I had a job to do. That job did not involve me fighting a monster that was not trying to hurt or kill my charge.

Asala continued to stuff the bear against her face while squeezing her eyes shut tightly, trying without much success to muffle her wails. This must be hard on her, summoning monsters she couldn’t control that did so much damage to those around her. Perhaps this was the real reason she didn’t like crowds. Not because she was afraid of them but because she was afraid of herself and what she might accidentally do.

I didn’t stop until we were finally across the bridge and out of the main part of the city. Didn’t stop until I was shoving open the gate to my house with a solid kick. As I opened the door I hit the security code, sending up a protective wall from the outside fence, encasing us inside. She ran into the living room, curling up into a ball on the couch and rocking back and forth. I could see that she really wanted to wail at the top of her lungs but she was suppressing that urge for whatever reason.

It took a moment of thought but I ran upstairs, digging through my closet until I found what I was looking for. Sprinting back down the steps, I knelt on the floor in front of her, touching her arm gently. She shrugged my touch off and looked away.

“Yeah I know, I bet you think I should have tried to help those people didn’t you? Probably think somewhere deep down you don’t deserve to live because your power is only hurting others. I see you want to cry and let it all out. I don’t know why you aren’t, but I have something for you that might help.”

I sat an old beat up blue bunny on the cushion next to her face so she could see it. One ear was sewn on haphazardly and the left eye was missing, the hole there sewn shut as well.

“This guys name is Mr. Snuggles. He’s an old veteran of many wars. He didn’t fight monsters like I did, at least not those kinds of monsters. He fights against little girls fears and sorrows. As you can see he lost an eye in those struggles. My little sister used to be a big crybaby. But she was like you and didn’t like people to see her sad. Then I cast a magic spell on her favorite bunny here. A spell that made your wails and your tears unseen and unheard while you hold him. No one could tell anything was wrong, just seeing a regular face when they looked at you.”

“He keeps secrets too. You can tell him anything and he won’t let slip a peep. No one can hear you talk to him either as long as you are holding him. It’s part of the magic. He might be a bit old, but I think he might have a few more battles against such specialized monsters in him. But if you don’t want to hold him that’s fine too. I’ll just leave him here to help me watch over you.”
11112112111211112.title: Leave with the girl.

111121121112111121.content:
I sat on the floor then with my back to her, turning on the television and flicking through the channels. Making sure to stay away from any news stations that might have some coverage on the Gog. There was silence behind me for a moment before I saw a hand snake out from the corner of my eye to grab the blue rabbit. It wasn’t long after that I heard her begin to cry in earnest. Not even attempting to stifle her sobs. I simply kept pretending to watch TV as if I heard nothing. Asking if there was anything she wanted to watch. Her wails finally started to die down a bit after about ten minutes so I set the controller down next to me.

“My sister was a good girl. She never liked to hurt anyone if she could help it. Really wasn’t suited for being a monster slayer like the rest of us. My mother and father really couldn’t accept that, always trying to force her into the family business. We were a long line of monster hunters they said. It was in our blood they said. But Olia, she dreamed of being an animal doctor. Said she wanted to help animals that couldn’t defend themselves and were hurt by cruel humans.

“She had a gift for it too. It was like she could read their minds. All animals loved her. But like I said she was a bit of a crybaby. Always climbing into bed with me when she had a nightmare. If she had a special ability to see the future or read peoples minds or something, she never said anything. But I didn’t ask. I think that’s why she always came to me and not anyone else. Because I didn’t try to push her. I didn’t expect anything from her except that she be my little sister.

“Then one day mom took her out into the woods to slay her first monster, just like my dad had done with me and my older sister. She didn’t want to go. My mother dragged her kicking and screaming anyway, saying she had to learn sometime. I snuck out after them. I wasn’t supposed to of course, but I did it anyway. I had it in my mind that if I could, I would help her fight whatever monster she faced. I had always been her protector. Fighting tooth and nail with my family so she could realize her dreams.

“She was put up against an Antichilla, a sort of giant ant creature. I was relieved, it was a pretty weak creature, even for her skills. But my mother got a call for an emergency job during the fight. It was at that same moment that my mother had turned her back to take the call that it happened. The monster shot some sticky saliva, trapping my sister in place. Before she could use her magic to free herself it skewered her with it’s front claws. Even as I was jumping out of hiding to kill the thing and try to heal her, it bit her head off.

“My mother was never the same after that and neither was I. For a while I loathed myself for not acting sooner. For not fighting harder to keep her from being taken out to the woods. For being unable to protect her. I hated my mother and father for a while too. Because they had kept pushing her into a role she didn’t want. Trying to force her to be a monster slayer just like everyone else. To uphold the family name.

“I don’t think about her as much now. It’s not that I forget her or anything, or because it hurts too much to think about her. That’s just the way life is. Time moves on with or without us and we don’t always have the luxury of not moving with it. But whenever I hold Mr. Snuggles or any of the other stuffed animals I still have that were once hers I remember.

“I don’t remember the body as it dropped lifelessly to the ground though, I remember the girl who laughed and cried. The girl who crawled into my bed and asked me to tell her stories. The girl who said she was going to marry me when she grew up. That’s part of the trick to grieving, remembering the happy moments and the sad ones. The moments you spent together be they good or bad. It doesn’t help to only remember how they died or the regrets you had. You can’t change any of that and it only makes you feel worse.”

“But it is how they lived that is important, because how they lived reflects on who you are. I wouldn’t be as good with kids today if I had never had a little sister. If I had never acted like her big brother the way that I had. I would have never had the chance to tell bedtime stories or chase away nightmares or listen to her dreams if she hadn’t once lived and changed my life in that way."

I snuck a glance at the girl who was clutching onto both her teddy bear and the rabbit while watching me. I didn’t think she was going to say anything, but she finally started talking, haltingly at first but in a small quiet voice. I continued to pretend not to notice since she was still holding the rabbit, simply leaning my head back and looking at the ceiling.

“My mom used to bake these really delicious cookies. They made your mouth water just smelling them. She would always tell me I had to wait until after dinner before I could have one. I used to pretend to be a Monster Hunter, sneaking into the kitchen on hands and knees when she wasn’t looking. Hiding under the table or the counter when her back was turned. I’d snag a cookie and run, locking myself in my room to eat it. I think she knew though, because she always made sure to turn her back at just the right times.

“My dad used to let me sit with him while he worked in the shop. My mother always scolded him, saying I shouldn’t be around so many sharp objects but he would just laugh and let me stay. He was a really good wood crafter, people would come from the next town over and farther for his work. He taught me how to handle the tools properly and he had promised to teach me how to make things. That was a few days before he… before they… died."

I slipped up onto the opposite side of the couch as she began to cry again. As I settled myself in she crawled over to me, settling her head in my lap. I stroked her hair gently as her tears fell silently onto my pants.

“It will get better Asala. Maybe not today, maybe not tomorrow, but in time it will. Each day you find something to keep you going. Be it hate, revenge, some small goal or hope. You find that something and you work towards it. Before you know it the day ends and a new one begins. Those hurts heal and you begin to forget what exactly it is that kept you going in the first place. It is replaced by bigger and better things. New dreams, new desires. You never forget though. You never should forget. But that shouldn’t stop you from being happy.”

She finally fell asleep clutching at my pant leg while I brushed her hair with my fingers. It was a long while before I finally fell asleep. A long while before the tears stopped silently rolling down my face.

**********

Well, that was an interesting first day indeed. Are you proud of the choices you made? Were they easy for you to make? Did any of them make you second guess yourself? What would you do if you had the chance to do it over again? Would you make the same choices? Would you change them all? Do you believe there was only one right answer in all of this? Or do you feel your choices didn’t matter? That the same outcome would happen no matter what?

In this world of possibilities who can say? This is only one possible future of the young Riktal Zelkov. Only one path his life could and has taken. Just as there are an endless number of possibilities, so to is there an endless number of futures for those possibilities. Choices and actions that are further complicated by the choices and actions of other people. And those choices and actions are then in turn influenced by yet more choices by yet more people. So you see, being a god and unraveling this tangled web is not as easy as it seems.

Our time grows short. You have interested me and sated some of my curiosity. I wish you well until next we meet. Then I shall ask again, what kind of god shall you be?
111121121112111121.title: Watch TV

choices: Make up a bed on the floor
1111211211121112.content:
“Lets not risk it and go home shall we? You can hold off for about another five minutes right?”

The girl nodded her head and I could almost feel some of the tension draining from her body. With another small squeeze I led her back the way we had come and over the bridge across the river. It only took a few more minutes after that to open the gate into our large yard and then the front door. I pointed at the kitchen table as I pulled out some already cooked ham, some bread and some lettuce and tomato

“You aren’t one of those animal lovers are you? You know, with the whole “I can’t eat another living creature” nonsense. Because if you are you and me are going to have some problems. Cause I like a fat, juicy, slab of meat on my plate. Ripping into it while it is still hot and feeling the juice dribbling down my chin.”

I mimed ripping into an invisible steak, showing my teeth and making growling noises. She giggled a bit at my antics but shook her head no. I took that to mean she didn’t have a problem with eating meat.

“Good, just give me a minute and I will have some pigs on toast for you.”

I sliced the ham, throwing it in the skillet before popping four slices of bread into the toaster. While those were cooking I ripped up the lettuce and sliced the tomato. Within a few minutes I had four sandwiches on a plate sitting before her. She picked one up, biting into it with teeth bared, imitating my previous mimicking. She grinned at me with another laugh before settling down to eat more normally. I snagged one for myself as I turned on the TV, flipping to the news channel to see if there was anything immediate to worry about.

“If you don’t mind my asking, how long ago did it happen? When your powers activated I mean.”

She looked at the table a moment before raising three fingers.

“Three days huh? I’m really sorry about that. I bet you are really confused about what’s going on. Being yanked around wily-nily by people you probably barely know to places far away from anyplace you recognize. I bet no one’s really stopped to ask what you want or tried to understand your feelings on the matter.”

She nodded her head, her eyes still looking at the table as she slowly continued to eat her meal.

“People can be pretty cruel sometimes can’t they?”

Again the nod.

“I bet they didn’t even stop to let you pack anything before pulling you along for this crazy ride. That bear is probably the only thing you have left of your old life. I wouldn’t doubt you have been wearing those same clothes this whole time.”

A slow nod for the third time.

“Well we will change all that. My clothes might be a little big but I’m sure one of my old shirts will do as a serviceable nightgown for tonight. We can wash those things for you so you won’t stink like a horse stables tomorrow, and then after school you and me are going shopping. A few new clothes should do the trick. It won’t make you forget what happened, and it won’t make the sadness go away, but it will make you feel a bit better. Feel a bit more normal. Tomorrow will be your day. Go where you want to go, see what you want to see, eat what you want to eat. A real date for just me and you.”

Her head finally came up and I saw her lips twitching upwards as her eyes gained a bit of sparkle. She nodded her head in agreement that she liked that idea and I nodded back.

“I might only be with you for two or three days but I see no reason I can’t act like you are staying forever. It’s just not right. Girls are supposed to leave a place with more stuff then they came with right? It’s like that unspoken law of being a girl. Well that and having unreasonable crushes on guys that look like girls. Don’t ask me to explain how either one of those works since I have no idea.”

She finished her meal in a much happier mood then when she started. I found her a good shirt and got her to change into it after taking a bath, throwing it all into the washer. I offered to wash her bear too but she held onto it like a lifeline. I didn’t push , simply patted her head and said everything was fine.

We spent the rest of the day watching movies and playing a few games. I told her stories and cracked a few jokes that made her laugh. I even taught her some more hand language until we were talking to each other using simple words and phrases. Even though she didn’t utter another word since her first outburst, I could tell she was slowly healing a bit from her trauma. It would take her a long time to fully heal, but she would.

When she began to yawn and rub her eyes I told her it was time for bed. She didn’t complain or resist, simply nodded her head in agreement. I led her up to my room and pointed to my bed. She wasted no time in crawling into it and under the covers. I pulled out my box of stuffed animals, taking them out and surrounding her with them which seemed to make her happy. When I handed her the blue bunny who was missing an eye I felt my lips twitch upwards.

“His name is Mr. Snuggles. He was my little sisters before she died. As you can see he gave an eye valiantly protecting her secrets as she hugged him tight. He hasn’t given up any one of them no matter what kind of torture he was put under. He’s also really good at muffling tears no matter how hard you cry. When you are holding him no one around you can hear.”

As I turned to set up some covers on the floor she grabbed my arm. I looked down at her as her eyes pleaded with me. She didn’t say anything but I knew what she wanted. She wanted me to sleep in the bed with her.
1111211211121112.title: Go home

11112112111211121.content:
I let the smile spread on my face as I pulled the covers back and got into bed. She snuggled into my chest with the rabbit crushed between us. I simply wrapped my arms around her to let her know I was there with her. I laid awake simply stroking her hair quietly as her breathing evened out. I thought she was sleeping when her soft voice suddenly spoke into my chest.

“Can I call you big brother?”

“Sure. I wouldn’t mind that at all.”

She brought the rabbit up to her mouth to muffle her wails as tears flowed from her eyes. I simply stroked her hair and pretended not to hear until she finally fell asleep. It took a bit longer as I remembered my little sister before I finally did the same.


*********

“Well that was an interesting first day was it not? Did you regret any of the choices you made? Did it end up as you thought it would? Did you find out something about yourself you never knew before? How did it feel to play god? To have the power of choice in the palm of your hand. Were the decisions easy to make or hard? Do you believe there was only one right answer?”

“In this world of possibilities who can say? This was only one of many possible outcomes from a select few possible choices. But it seems our time is up now, the boundary weakens. It calls you back to your own time and place. So until we meet again.”
11112112111211121.title: Climb under the covers

11112112111211122.content:
With a sad shake of my head I pulled her hand off my arm.

“I’m sorry. I can’t. It will be harder on you when you have to leave again with my mom’s friend if you get too attached to me. I know I seem like I am doing a horrible thing, and I am. Asking you to trust me, bonding with you like I have. But you need training in how to use your powers. Training I can’t give you because I don’t understand how they work. If you get too close to me you won’t want to leave, and I won’t be able to go with you. That’s going to break your heart even more. That’s why I can’t, I’m sorry.”

I turned away, pretending not to hear the sniffling and the soft cries of loneliness as I set up my bed. Pretended not to see her pressing her face into the blue rabbit as I crawled under the covers of my makeshift bed.

I laid with my back to her, listening to her crying while remembering how my little sister used to climb into my bed when she had a scary dream. Me, not mom or dad or big sis Ulicia. Out of everyone she had always come to me when she was troubled. Always saying that her big brother Riktal scared away all the bad things. It had been a long time since I had really thought about her, the pain creeping back inside as I remembered her loss. I missed being a big brother. That was probably why I had such a soft spot for little kids. But as much as I had wanted to crawl into that bed I just couldn’t. This really was for the best.

The crying and sniffling quieted down and I thought she had finally gone to sleep. But a moment later the covers lifted and a small body slid onto the floor behind me. Her head rested against my back and I could feel her shaking, but from fear or something else I didn’t know. Her small voice was barely audible but I still heard it.

“Please. Don’t leave me alone again.”

That small plea broke my heart. My conviction melted away as I turned over and wrapped her in my arms. Stroking her hair and telling her it would be all right.

“Do you want to go back to the bed where it is more comfortable.”

She shook her head no, using one hand to talk to me in a few words of the silent language I had shown her today. With a smile I kissed the top of her head as we drifted off to sleep.

Her fingers had said Happy here. Safe. Thank you.


**********************

“Well that was an interesting first day was it not? Did you regret any of the choices you made? Did it end up as you thought it would? Did you find out something about yourself you never knew before? How did it feel to play god? To have the power of choice in the palm of your hand. Were the decisions easy to make or hard? Do you believe there was only one right answer?”

“In this world of possibilities who can say? This was only one of many possible outcomes from a select few possible choices. But it seems our time is up now, the boundary weakens. It calls you back to your own time and place. So until we meet again.”
11112112111211122.title: Make up a bed on the floor

111121121112112.content:
Protecting this girl was top priority right now. I was mostly in the dark as to just how stable her ability as a summoner was and with so little to go on pulling her around wily-nily for no good reason was just asking for trouble

“Hey Asala, I just need to make a quick stop before we go. I made a promise to someone that I am going to have to break. You don’t mind do you?”

She gave my hand a small squeeze while shaking her head no and I squeezed back. With that I headed for the classroom, catching Liz just as she was leaving. She glanced down at the child still holding onto my hand and raised her eyebrow at me.

“A job. And because of that I was wondering if you would take a rain check on meeting my friend. At least for a few days until this is all over.”

“I’ve got no problems with that. Duty comes first.”

“Thanks. I really will make it up to you.”

“Don’t worry about it. And don’t do anything weird to her.”

“Now I might have to just because you said not to.”

She smiled and waved farewell as I turned and headed towards the doors with my client in tow. People were staring at us as we walked through the halls and out the front. Well mostly they were staring at the little girl and whispering to their friends who knows what weird ideas. After leaving the school grounds I started to head towards the house when a thought struck me.

“Hey Asala, do you have any spare clothes or anything of that nature?”

She shook her head while hunching her shoulders, holding out the bear to me for a second.

“So that’s the only thing you have left from your old life huh? I bet whoever took you away just grabbed you up and left. Didn’t think much about your comforts at all. My guess is you are pretty scared of crowds right now, but if you can handle it you want to go buy some stuff? We can get you a few new dresses maybe a hair ornament. I bet you’d like a new pair of shoes too. Spruce you up and make you look prettier than you already are. I know a few places that aren’t that crowded or busy and I will be by your side the whole time. You like that idea?”

Her eyes seemed to light up a bit as she nodded her head. I had observed enough girls of all ages in my time to know most of them couldn’t resist a bit of shopping and pampering. Especially on someone else’s money. It was one of those secret rules of being a girl I guess.

I led her around town to all the stores I knew of that were reasonably priced. I wasn’t loaded and my allowance wasn’t all that great, but it was enough for my needs. She was a solemn little girl it seemed, though considering what had happened to her she seemed to be holding up well. I had to wonder though how much of that was just an act. She seemed to really be happy though as I took her to the different places to try on dresses, looking at herself in the mirror and posing a bit.

“That blue dress looks good on you. Much better then that green one I met you in. It brings out your eyes. And the cream one goes well with your hair. Do you like them?”

When she nodded her head I smiled at her reflection looking at me through the mirror.

“Well then we will buy them both. And you should pick another one as well. You know what they say, three is a lucky number.”

In the end she picked a deep purple dress with a fine flower embroidery in it stitched with a lighter purple thread. We picked up a few more pairs of undergarments and socks plus a nightgown before I paid the tab and left. We were heading to the shoe store with her sticking close to my side when she suddenly stopped to look in a window. I turned to see what had caught her attention, finding her enamored of a music box with two bears skating on ice.

“You like bears don’t you?”

Her head bobbed up and down quickly.

“I saw the price tag. It was a bit expensive for my taste but not by too much.

“Then let’s get it shall we? Little girls are supposed to have music boxes. Its like an unwritten rule.”

She looked at me in surprise, her head going back and forth but I ignored her, entering the store anyway as the bell jingled to announce our presence. It only took a few moments before the box was in my possession and I was handing it to Asala. She wound it up a few times, smiling at the sound it made. I gave her head a pet before heading back to the door. On the way I saw a small bear hair comb, buying it on the spot as another gift to her. She held it like it was some sort of treasure as we continued on our way.

“Look, I don’t want you to get the wrong idea here, I want to make sure we are on the same page. This may sound cruel, but try not to get too attached to me ok? In a few days you will be leaving again to go to your more permanent home with someone who can teach you what I can’t. I’m doing all this because I want you to trust me and because I want to try getting your mind off what a crappy hand you have been dealt so far. It’s going to hurt, and for a long time to come, but that doesn’t mean you can’t find things that make you happy even at a time like this.”

The girl looked down at the comb she was still playing with in her hands then back up at me before bowing her head in a nod. She then poked at her eyes, wiped her mouth with a finger and stuck her fingers in her ears to wiggle them back and forth.

I knelt on the sidewalk and leaned in closer looking both ways while giving her a wink.

“You forgot the eyebrows by the way, but I still understood you.”

She looked both ways as well, leaning forward a bit so as not to be heard.

“I understand. Thank you for the comb. Momma… momma gave me one just like it, but it’s gone now. Now it’s like a piece of momma came back.”

She wrapped her arms around my neck, giving me a quick hug before letting me stand up again. I had to make sure I didn’t get too attached to this little girl. What I had told her was also true for me. If I got too attached it would be harder when she finally left. But it felt good to be able to act like a big brother again.

We bought the shoes without incident, stopping at a quiet little restaurant for a late dinner. Her mood had improved steadily all day. Not a hint of sadness or that vacant eyed stare I had first seen haunted her eyes. She almost acted like a normal little girl. It was only her silence that made her different. Her muted giggles and the few words she had spoken to me in secret the only proof that she could talk at all.

It was starting to turn dark as we finally headed off home from our day of shopping, she was looking a bit tired as we walked until finally I ended up carrying her on my back. She draped her arms around my neck, laying her cheek against the back of my head sleepily. I continued to walk on in silence, ignoring the stares of the people around me.

Just as we hit the bridge crossing the river a red circle appeared in front of me. Asala gave a moan, squirming around until she dropped to the ground, backing away from the red glowing circle. Setting the bags down I fished in my duffle for a weapon, pulling out the first thing that came to hand.

I didn’t know what kind of beast would come out of the circle but I held the double bladed sword at the ready in front of me. A blue blur shot into the sky as the circle suddenly closed. Tracking it with my eyes I tried to catch a glimpse of what it was. Asala squatted on the ground, covering her head while mewling in fear. When the creature finally stopped flitting around I began to laugh heartily, putting my sword back in my bag and pulling out some of my emergency rations. Breaking off a bit of the hard bread I used a touch of magic to moisten it and let it turn into crumbs.

“Asala, come on and stand up. Hold out your hand for a moment, it won’t hurt you.”

After a moment where she looked up into my eyes she finally stood up and did as I asked. Dumping the crumbs into her hand I whistled a quick tune The Dagal zipped out of the air, landing on Asala’s wrist with dainty claws to eat the bread crumbs.

“It’s called a Dagal. Also known as mini dragons because that’s what they look like. They are quite harmless and friendly as you can see. They are great messengers and like real dragons they have their own special abilities. This is a blue one so its probably water based magic, like minor healing. They can be trained to learn new magic too. Do you want to keep him? It can be your first tamed monster.”

Her eyes were like saucers as she stared at the little blue dragon creature that was picking up crumbs with its front paws before sitting on its haunches and eating daintily. Finally she nodded her head slowly, as if afraid any movement would make the thing fly away.

“Then tickle it under its chin. It will imprint on the first person or thing that does so. He, or maybe it’s a she, will follow you and only you until it dies. But they live a very long time so if you take care of it he might be with you until you become a ripe old granny.”

Her finger came up slowly, reaching out to the creature and stopping as if afraid. But I continued to smile at her, nodding encouragingly. She closed her eyes and thrust out, scratching under the monsters chin. It let out a coo of pleasure while flapping its wings, a look of bliss on it’s face. Finally it flew into the air, circling once before landing on her shoulder and nuzzling her face.

The look of wonder that grew in her eyes as she looked at me made me laugh again. Picking up the bags I nodded with my head.

“Come on we are almost home, I’ll teach you how to take care of your new friend before you go to bed. Congratulations on your first monster taming.”

She followed me across the bridge as if in a daze. A dreamy expression returning to her eyes, but this time it wasn’t for the same reasons I thought.
111121121112112.title: Break your promise with Liz

1111211211121121.content:
After dropping my bags by the door I led the still enamored little girl into the kitchen, searching the refrigerator for something useful and finding an orange.

“Dagal’s on the whole aren’t too picky of eaters. They will eat meat, but they prefer fruits. Their digestive system can break down just about anything. But try to stay away from apples if you can help it. Something about them messes with their insides and makes them sick. They are also smart creatures. Here, try giving him this orange.”

As she took the orange from me I continued.

“They will accept food from anyone they know and trust well enough, but mostly they will only accept food from your own hand. Their noses can detect poisons and they have an instinct about people. So if your friend there acts suspicious around food or drink or dislikes a person, you should trust him over your own feelings.”
