The Dagal grabbed the orange in its nimble claws, sniffing it a moment before running a single talon around the edge, peeling away the skin and eating the meat inside.

“They actually don’t eat all that much, only about half their body weight twice a day. If you can feed him three times a day all the better. That extra nutrient will help him grow and learn new things faster. No more than four times a day though. They can go at most three days without eating or drinking but if that happens they become really weak and will most likely die.”

The Dagal finished eating the orange and looked around questioningly, I pointed at the trash can and the creature flew over, dropping the peel into the garbage before returning to its perch.

“Time will show you what kind of quirks your friend has. Each one is different. I once saw a Dagal that could play the piano and another one that couldn’t go anywhere without wearing a hat of some kind. They molt twice a year, when that happens take a damp cloth and rub it across their scales gently to help them shed the dead skin. Other than that they are very dependable creatures. Keep him away from hot water though, only the red ones like hot water, the rest avoid it like the plague. Treat him right and he will do the same to you.”

I held out my hand close to the creature on her shoulder, making it turn it’s head to the side and inspect it with one eye. Stretching out its neck the monster sniffed my fingers before giving a small coo and a nod. With a grin I reached out and scratched behind its ears, ending by rubbing a single digit up and down the valley between his eyes.

“Seems he likes me. Glad I got his seal of approval. Now it’s getting late and you are tired, grab your nightgown from the bags and get yourself cleaned up. After that it’s off to bed with you. And don’t give me no lip little miss.”

She stuck out her tongue at me but ran off back into the hallway. Soon enough I heard her feet pounding up the steps and the water running in the bathroom. While she was getting cleaned up I climbed the steps as well, opening the door to my room and pulling out my box of stuffed animals. As I set them on the bed up by the pillow I grinned a bit foolishly too myself. My mother had thought I had thrown them out along with the rest of Olia’s things. She hadn’t wanted anything to remember my little sister by after she died.

But I think the truth was, remembering was too hard for her. Seeing her things in her empty room and knowing she was never coming back. Constantly being reminded by her pictures on the walls and her toothbrush in the bathroom. I had saved these few animals and a few photos. They were the only thing left to remind me that I had once had a little sister. Sometimes holding these stuffed creatures let me remember her face and her voice. Remember the way she climbed into my bed after having a nightmare.

I pulled out the last animal, a blue stuffed rabbit missing an eye that had been badly re-stitched along its ear. This had been Olia’s favorite. I had been the one to do the bad sewing job after I had accidentally ripped it during a fight with her. That was how the eye had gotten lost as well. I never had found it again, simply sewing it up and saying it was a war wound. She used to cry all the time, but whenever I was around she tried to hold it in. I remembered how one day I had said a few silly made up words over the rabbit, telling her I had cast a magic spell on it that would keep anyone from knowing when she cried. That even if she cried in front of someone no one would hear or see it as long as she was holding the rabbit.

After that I pretended not to notice when her tears flowed in front of me. Acting like nothing was wrong. I never understood why she was always crying, she saw things in her mind but refused to tell anyone what she saw. I guessed she had the gift to see the future or something but I didn’t know. I wondered if she had seen her own death and that’s what made her so scared.

I didn’t even realize I was sitting on the floor pressing the rabbit to my face until I took a deep breath. I imagined I could still smell her on the rabbit as a few tears soaked into its colored hide. This was stupid. A Hunter was supposed to have a tight reign on his emotions. Not get sentimental after a simple day out with a little girl that made me think about my sister.

A hand on my head made me jerk a little. I hadn’t even sensed her coming into the room. I had to lock down my grief. If this had been out in town an enemy could have taken me out easily. Her hand reached down and touched the rabbit softly before she came around and looked at me, the question plain in her eyes.

“His name is Mr. Snuggles. He is a magic rabbit that can make you feel better. When you hold him no one can see or hear you cry. He was my little sister’s a long time ago. But he is mine now. But while you are here he is yours if you want him.”

I held out the stuffed animal and she shook her head, pushing it back towards me. She pointed to the rabbit and then held up her teddy bear. Her voice was soft and slightly stilted. Hesitant as if she didn’t know if she could speak without it being a secret.

“Your friend like Mr. Cuddles is mine. If I take him, you will be lonely. I’m… not lonely anymore. I have Mr. Cuddles, Blue and now you.”

“So you decided to name your Dagal Blue huh?”

When she nodded her head I smiled while getting to my feet.

“Well I think it’s time for all of us to get some shut eye. You are almost asleep on your feet it looks like. We still have to get up early for school tomorrow after all. There will be more problems to deal with but that’s just the way life is. We deal with them as they come and before you know it the day is over and the next day is upon us.”

She clambered into bed, surrounded by the stuffed animals as Blue flew up, perching on the headboard. He ruffled his wings a few times before tucking his head into his chest, looking down on Asala who was already blinking sleepily. The girl patted the bed with hopeful orbs as I stood over her. With a smile I slid under the covers, kissing the top of her head as she closed her eyes.

“Good night and sweet dreams Asala.”

I stayed awake for a bit until her breathing evened out before closing my eyes and letting slumber take me away.


****************

“Well that was an interesting first day was it not? Did you regret any of the choices you made? Did it end up as you thought it would? Did you find out something about yourself you never knew before? How did it feel to play god? To have the power of choice in the palm of your hand. Were the decisions easy to make or hard? Do you believe there was only one right answer?”

“In this world of possibilities who can say? This was only one of many possible outcomes from a select few possible choices. But it seems our time is up now, the boundary weakens. It calls you back to your own time and place. So until we meet again.”
1111211211121121.title: Continue home

11112112111212.content:
I stood up, walking over to the window to look out onto the school grounds below.

“No.”

“What do you mean no?”

“As in the opposite of yes. This isn’t my problem. Go find someone else to look after her. Don’t think you can use the whole family card here mother. You aren’t allowed to have it both ways. I won’t allow you to deny me from taking the Hunter exam, saying I need to finish school and then mere hours later offer me a job as an official Hunter when it is convenient for you. You didn’t want me to be a Hunter no matter how hard I begged, so screw you and your offer. I’m not going to take any Hunter jobs until I finish school just like you wanted. She is not my problem.”

“Riktal honey! It’s not like that! There are…”

“Mitigating circumstances? Other reasons? Not so black and white? That’s just the way it is with you isn’t it? Always a reason or an excuse that seems and sounds so reasonable. You think you an get people to do anything if you just double talk and give them some puppy dog eyes. Freely throwing around words like: because you are family, as if that is the answer to everything.”

I turned around to stare my mother in the face.

“Well not this time. I won’t let you sucker me into doing your dirty work because you find it distasteful or for whatever reason you might come up with. I feel for the girl, don’t get me wrong, But I’m not taking her.”

“Riktal now that’s not fair!”

“Fair? Fair! Who are you to decide what’s fair or not? You don’t get to use that word. Especially not with me! If you want to talk about fair, how is it fair that I’m not allowed to take the Hunter exam when you let big sis Ulicia take it at fifteen? That’s two years younger than I am now!”

“How is it fair that I can drive just about anything that moves in air, land, or sea yet I’m not allowed to have a car or a motorcycle? Even if I save up and pay for it with my own money? How is it fair that you keep shoving these marriage meetings onto me whether I want you to or not? Is that your same idea of fair that you used while raising Olia? Forcing her to be a Hunter when even a blind man could see she wasn’t suited for it?”

“Is that the real reason you took her out into the woods that day? So you could pit her against her first monster to let it kill her? Make her death seem like an accident? It seems pretty convenient how you got a call just at the crucial moment you could have saved her.. Her inability as a slayer sullied the family name so it was easier to just get rid of her is that it? Stop her from tarnishing the Zelkov reputation any further?”

I grabbed up my bag and stormed towards the door as I heard the chair scrape behind me.

“Riktal! Don’t you dare walk out that door! I’m not done…”

I slammed the door behind me without waiting for her to finish the sentence. Even as I turned to walk down the hall I reached into my bag and grabbed my Lexington double barrel, spinning on my heel and pointing it at my mother as she burst into the hall behind me.

“Give me a reason mother. Say one more word and I will shoot you. I hold no illusions that if it comes down to an all out brawl you will beat me. You have more experience than I do after all. But you are going to have to kill me to make me stop. You know how good I am. I have no problem destroying this family name right now. I have two bullets left in this weapon. The first one will be used to slow you down, the second one will go right between that little girls eyes.”

“I will then proceed to rampage through this school killing as many people as I can. Wouldn’t that be a great headline? Son of prestigious Zelkov family runs amok within Monster Hunter Academy. Sanity called into question, Can the rest of the family be trusted?”

“Fitting don’t you think? Not to mention the blow having your client murdered by your own son would be to your pride and our name. So take the girl, turn around and walk away right now. And don’t try to give me any of your mother talk. You never had time to be a mother to me before, so don’t start now. Go do your important jobs for the military or whatever country it is today. I’ll finish out my school day and return to the empty house like I always do. I’ll take care of myself like I always have, and I’ll expect to see you in a few days or a few weeks for a few hours before you are off again doing your Hunter things.”

She let out a sigh, giving me a pair of sad eyes but I wouldn’t let them sway me this time. I simply kept my weapon trained on her as the girl and her aid Inga came out of the room, finally she nodded.

“All right Riktal. I’m sorry I came. I see I’ve upset you. I hope one day you understand. I’m only doing what I think is best. When you become a parent you will see there’s no guidebook telling you what to do. I’m just doing the best I can.”

“I don’t want to here it. Just leave. And by the way, I promised big sis earlier that I would tell you she sends her love.”

She gave me a soft smile as she took the girls hand, turning and walking away while pulling the girl after. The girl turned her head back to watch me, the blank expression leaving her face for just a moment as a look of sadness crossed her features.

I waited until they were out of sight before finally lowing my weapon and shoving it back into my bag.

“You got something you want to say to me?”

The principal came out from hiding around the corner, the wheels of her wheelchair rotating noiselessly as she pushed herself.

“Perhaps it’s not my place, but I’m old and it’s a requirement that we old people be busybodies to some degree. You shouldn’t have been so hard on her. I’m sure she hasn’t made the best choices in her life, just like you haven’t. But I’m sure you know you went a bit too far with some of the things you said. I don’t know any of the circumstances, just the context, but I’m sure she didn’t want your sister to die.”

“You’re right. It isn’t your place. I’d thank you if you kept your nose out of matters where it doesn’t belong or I might have to cut it off.”

I shoved past her and continued down the hall. I only made it a few steps before she called after me.

“Would you have really rampaged through the school? Killing innocent would be Hunter’s working to learn how to defend the people?”

I didn’t even turn around to answer her.

“Yes. It would have been a faster and cleaner death then most of them would get out there in the field. And probably a better one them some of them deserve. This place is a joke of an academy for would be Hunter’s. Almost everyone still thinks this kind of life is a game. That they are still normal people. They need to wake up to the reality of things.”

“If this place is such a joke child, then why did you still come here?”

I didn’t bother to answer her, instead striding off down the corridor in silence. Wasn’t it obvious to her? The answer, like everything else, was complicated. There was no one defining deciding factor. No black and white answer.
11112112111212.title: Decline job

choices: Ask Liz if she want's to get a meal with you
Let Liz go on her way.
111121121112121.content:
As much as it was probably useless to do so, I should return to class. I was so tempted to walk out the front doors right now, but I knew if I did, I would be making a mistake that I would come to regret. The same way I came to regret just about all the mistakes I made every time I let my anger get the best of me. Besides, I had a promise to keep. A promise to the first real friend I had ever had. It wouldn’t do to break it just because my mother made me a little upset.

I slipped into the class and sat down at my desk, a few eyes watching me. Those stares were now calculating and openly scheming instead of the slight interest they had held when I had first walked in those doors this morning. I simply tried to make myself inconspicuous as the teacher droned on. Even managing to answer one of his questions when he called on me without the usual sulky attitude I had grown accustomed to.

When the bell rang those calculating eyes converged on me like a pack of starving wild beasts, all of them talking at once. All of them trying to get my attention for one reason or another. All of them trying to butter me up and make connections because of my name. Some of them were roundabout and some of them were just plain blatant about what they wanted.

My father is a weapon maker, would you come over and give your professional opinion on them?

I was wondering if you wanted to hang out for a bit? I could show you around town if you are unfamiliar with it.

I know a guy who can get you a really good deal on anything you want. Do you want me to show you to him?

Your handsome. Want to be my boyfriend?

My family is rich, if you go out with me you won’t regret it.

I slapped my hand on the desk as I stood up and grabbed my bag from the floor. Everyone shut up almost instantly at the sound. I didn’t even bother replying to any of them, letting my disdain show clearly as I ignored them completely. Walking over to Liz’s desk I nodded my head towards the door.

“Ready to go meet my broker friend?”

“Sure.”

We walked past all the dumbstruck faces, keeping our own bland and expressionless. As soon as we were out of sight and earshot we both began grinning like fools and cracking up.

“Oh man that was priceless! Did you see their faces? Their mouths were open so wide they were making drag marks on the floor! I’ll say one thing Riktal, you got style. You really know how to say a lot without saying much at all.”

“I’m sure you could have done the same.”

“No I couldn’t have and I’m not ashamed to admit it. I could have tried, but I couldn’t have pulled it off with the same kind of mixture of confidence and disinterest as you did. But I admit, it always feels good to put one over on them. They did the same thing when I first transferred in, trying to suck up to me and become my “friend”. I don’t need friends like that though.”

“So how’d you handle it?”

“Knocked all their heads together and put three of them in the hospital for a week.”

“I was tempted to do the same.”

“Why didn’t you?”

“Because I am still a bit angry right now and I knew if I started I wouldn’t stop. I’d end up going too far.”

“Care to tell me about it?”

After walking along in silence for a bit and looking around the streets of the city I finally told her about the meeting with my mother and the blow up afterwards. I cut out a lot of what was said, trimming it down to the essence.

We continued in silence, neither one of us feeling the urge to talk and she didn’t instantly spew the kind of nonsense someone who wasn’t from a generation family would spew. Words like you were wrong and you should have just done it.

“I’m not judging since I know that isn’t the whole story, but I think you were both right and wrong. I don’t know what I would have done, probably accepted the job, but you did what you thought was right. What you thought you had to do for whatever your reasons. But I think you went a bit too far in some of the things you said to your mother. Even if they were true, did it really do any good to say them?”

“As Hunter’s we will end up taking jobs we don’t like, or find distasteful. Protecting people we might personally find to be the scum of the earth. Taking jobs under false assumptions and misinformation. We can’t always be picky about every little thing. We keep the regular people in mind, or at least try to, at all times. If times get desperate we won’t turn our noses up at a job that offers us good money. We can try to live off the spoils of pure monster slaying, but even that isn’t a guaranteed thing.”

“Pointing out the obvious, saying the complete truth, turning our backs on our duty. We can’t always do these things. Not when doing so serves no purpose and might ruin our ability to be effective at our jobs. Or ruin our chances of getting people to trust us.”

“I know. Now that I’ve cooled down a bit I realize how much of what I said I didn’t need to say. That’s the way it always is. But sometimes my mother just infuriates me no end.”

“Same with mine. But my grandmother used to tell me before she died, that that was the mark of being a good parent sometimes. You can’t always be your child’s friend. Sometimes you are the villain, sometimes the comforter, and sometimes the friend. If they love you one minute and hate you the next then you are doing your job right.”

Liz grinned a bit. “Now I’m not sure how right she was about that of course. Because when she told me that she insisted the moon was just a giant window and we were nothing more than ants in a small box.”

“Well I’ll apologize to her the next time I see her. Which will probably be in four or five days. That will give me enough time to forget all about it.”

“I think that’s a good idea.”

I led her to the Pasta Palace, opening the door and beckoning her inside with a courtly bow and hand gesture. Once I was inside I pointed out my broker friend who was eating the same thing he ordered every day at this time, stuffed mushrooms and linguino. He saw me and waved, beckoning me over.

“Hey Riktal! Haven’t seen you in a while. Finally decide to listen to your mother and chose a woman from one of her marriage meetings?”

“You wish. You know I’ve got to keep my options open. I can’t be weighed down like that, after all I got to be able to steal any woman you are interested in.”

I looked around the diner, lowering my voice a bit and pointing unobtrusively to a young waitress pouring coffee for another customer.

“Like Trinity over there perhaps?”

He blushed a second before laughing a bit and eating another mushroom.

“So what brings you here?”

“Nerval, this is Liz Hawthrope. She has a heart crystal she would like you to examine for her.”

Liz pulled out the crystal, handing it over into Nerval’s waiting palm. He took out a magnifying glass which fitted over his right eye, examining the stone while he talked.

“Hawthrope Huh? As in Wilson Hawthrope?”

“That’s my brother.”

“Cousin of mine who works in the big city dealt with him a few times. Said he was one of the good ones. If Riktal vouches for you then you are ok in my books. This guy might be a bit hard to deal with sometimes, but he’s one of the good ones. So any friend of his is a friend of mine.”

He handed the crystal back to her as he pulled the magnifying glass off.

“Well just on a field test I’d say I could give you seven thousand Reul for it. If you want to stop by my shop I can do a more thorough test and you are free to get an appraisal elsewhere if you want. I’ll trade any weapon of equal value for it if you aren’t interested in the money. Or a custom job up to five thousand, the extra two being my work fee. But I vouch any custom job will be worth the loss of a two thousand Reul profit.

“Thanks. I’ll make sure to do that.”

“Come by anytime if you ever need anything! If I don’t have it I can get it.”

As we left I pointed out Nerval’s shop right next door, telling her he could always be found at the pasta place if he wasn’t in his shop. We continued to walk around town for a little bit talking about small things when my stomach growled. Liz turned to leave, thanking me and giving me a wave goodbye.
111121121112121.title: Back to class

1111211211121211.content:
“Hey Liz, you hungry? If so, want to grab a bite before you leave?”

She turned back to look at me for a moment before finally shrugging and returning to my side.

“Sure, saves me from cooking something for dinner and I don’t really need to get back home for anything. It’s not like there is anyone there waiting for me.”

“Empty house for you too huh?”

“Yeah, I get to see my parents maybe once or twice a week. Both of them together if I am really lucky.”

“You talk to yourself while you are at home too? Just to hear a voice?”

“I thought I was the only one who did that.”

We grinned at each other as we headed deeper into town. Walking in a companionable silence and watching the citizens going by. Some of them recognized us as Hunter’s, or at least ones in training by our uniform and gave us a wave in greeting. We waved or nodded back as we passed but didn’t stop to chat. We found a quiet little diner, sitting down and ordering our meal. Once the waitress left, Liz rotated her shoulders while stretching a little.

“Man I can’t remember the last time I went out to eat with another person. Or when I was actually interested in the conversation.”

“Last time I was out to eat with someone else was about two years ago, and that was with my big sister on my birthday.”

“Ouch. Well I know it hasn’t been that long for me, I just can’t remember when exactly. Don’t you just wish you could somehow get out of being in your own family? Insert yourself in one more normal, or less concerned about the family name and image?”

“All the time. But then I wonder if I could ever fit in to that kind of life. I mean being a Zelkov is all I know. Acting and reacting based on that fact. Even if I got rid of the family name, I’m still me. I would have still grown up in the Zelkov family even if I was transplanted into another one.”

“Yeah, yeah, I know. Still like to imagine it sometimes though.”

Our food came then and we began to eat, talking about a few minor things here and there. Stuff like favorite tactics, a bit about our families, and our views on different subjects. We were about halfway through our meal when Liz got a call. She excused herself for a moment, getting up and walking away to take the communication spell. I could just barely see the transparent green tinted screen hovering on her wrist as she held her other hand over her ear.

She returned a few moments later with an entirely different demeanor. She held herself a bit stiffly and less open then she had before.

“Is something wrong?”

“It’s nothing.”

I nodded my head as we continued to eat. If she didn’t want to discuss it that was fine. Private matters were still private. We all had them and the entire world didn’t need to know. If she felt like sharing or asking for my help, she would do it in her own time. If not than I wasn’t obligated to worry about it.

We finished the meal in silence. It wasn’t exactly uncomfortable, but it wasn’t the same kind of companionable silence we had shared earlier. Finally she put her fork down, pushing her empty plate away and stared t me. I raised my eyebrow as I did the same. Somehow knowing she was about to tell me what was bothering her.

“I suppose I wouldn’t mind. I could do worse and you aren’t that bad.”

“What are you talking about?”

“Marriage of course.”

“Who said anything about marriage? What made you think I want to marry you?”

“That was my mother on the spell earlier. She said I had a marriage meeting with you next week. I thought that was why you invited me out to eat and why you’ve been so friendly with me. You wanted to get to know me before the actual meeting.”

“This is news to me. I didn’t even know my mother had set up another meeting until earlier today. Even then it was just a comment in passing, she didn’t tell me who it was with. I asked you out to eat because I was hungry and I thought you might be too. I enjoy your company that’s true, but not in a romantic sense. If you remember, you asked me to be your friend, not the other way around. I opened up a bit to you because it’s been a while since I met someone who gets where I am coming from and has so many similarities with me.”

“You really didn’t know anything about this?”

“I swear on my name as a Zelkov. Truth is, if I had known I probably would have stayed far away from you. I hate it when my mother shoves these meetings on me, and I try to avoid them like the black death. I’d like to choose for myself who I spend my life with, not have the choice forced upon me. So if that is true then I’m stating right now, I have no interest in you romantically. If I get involved with you in that way it will be because I want to and because I really have feelings for you, not because my mother tells me I have to.”

She narrowed her eyes as she looked at me for a bit longer before her face split into a grin and she began to laugh.

“Ok now I feel a bit stupid. That’s one of my downfalls. I’m quick to make assumptions and act on them as if they are the truth.”

“Goes well with my quick temper then.”

“Wouldn’t we make quite the pair? I’d make an assumption and start a big argument like I always do then you would get angry and we would have a big fight over it. Only to find out I was wrong and it was a small thing I had blown out of proportion.”

“Yeah, definitely not compatible marriage material.”

“Still friends?”

“Still just friends.”

With twin grins I paid the bill and we left the diner. Before she turned to head home she looked back at me one last time.

“For the record, I agree with you. I’d rather choose who I get involved with romantically then have them forced onto me. I just got so tired of my mother forcing boys down my throat all the time I was about to just give in and choose one. But I think I can keep fighting her now. Thanks.”

I raised my hand to return her farewell wave before walking in the opposite direction. My mother wouldn’t dictate my life for me. No one would. I’d go to the marriage meeting, but we would just have a good time and a good laugh at our mother’s expense. If we ended up falling for each other later it would be on our own terms and our own decision. But right now we were just friends and that’s all I wanted to be.

**************

Well, this day had it’s ups and downs. A bit of action, a bit of drama, perhaps even a bit of blossoming romance? Did things turn out to your liking? Do you regret any of the choices you made? Was it easy for you to play god and decide a single person’s fate? Did you really wish to seek out confrontation and danger but refuse to do so because you were playing with someone else’s life? Or did you simply do what you would have done in that situation? Did you take his personality and skills into consideration? Or did you deem them unimportant in the choices you made?

This realm full of possibilities has all the answers. All the what if’s and maybe’s that are out there for young Riktal and everyone else on his planet. This was only a small glimpse at one of the many possible futures. Where the choices he made, or in this case the choices you made for him, altered his destiny. Some choices are small and do not affect much in the greater scheme of things. But others have groundbreaking consequences.

Take for example the little girl you decided not to help. That decision also altered the course of her future greatly. Cutting off the possibilities she would have been presented with and the outlooks on life she would have had if you had accepted the job. The choices you make not only affect you, but those around you. Just as the opposite of this basic fact is true: you are affected by the choices that others make. What will happen to that little girl? Will she die? Will she grow up hating everyone and everything? Will she become a great savior?

All these possibilities are possible and truth. They have both been decided and have not yet happened in this realm I call my own. Perhaps next time we meet I will allow you to gaze into the mind of yet another possibility either in this world or another. Let you play god with another life, to either bring ruin or glory. So until next we meat may the choices you make be the choices you desire.
1111211211121211.title: Ask Liz if she want's to get a meal with you

1111211211121212.content:
I watched her leave for a while, thinking that this might just actually turn out well. There was still a nagging suspicion in the back of my mind that she was after something, but that was only a small part. After all, my family had taught me to be suspicious of everything, even them. I did love them, and I did trust them, but I was still suspicious of them. Perhaps I was more suspicious of my own family than other people.

It didn’t feel like she was out for anything, but perhaps she was able to play the game of plots within plots better than I could. I wouldn’t worry about that now though, if I did I would simply end up going all paranoid and pushing her away like I did everyone else. I couldn’t do that, not to my first real friend. This was a fresh start wasn’t it? A chance to reinvent the old me. The old me didn’t have friends. Didn’t have a need for them. But the new me wanted at least one I realized.

Once she was gone I headed for a fast food place, ordering a dragon burger, the Oroni fries and a chocolate cow shaker. Finding a good booth seat by the window I sat watching the citizens walking by outside while I ate. These were the people I was going to save as a Monster Hunter. What Liz said was right, not everyone I saved or protected would be good. I’d make questionable choices in the future for the good of everyone. Sometimes that would mean having to bend my own moral code.

My job was to hunt and slay monsters. Sometimes it would involve guarding some person or other, sometimes it would involve being hired to fight wars in the place of regular soldiers. Sometimes it would be to simply kill monsters that a city or country couldn’t exterminate on their own, either because they didn’t have the firepower or the Hunter’s to do so. I couldn’t read minds, I could only go by the information I was given, body language, and my own instincts. I had to rely on those I trusted even as I expected others to trust me. A hard thing to do when I found it hard to really trust anybody.

Perhaps hanging out with Liz would show me how to do that. She seemed to have a pretty good handle on giving out her trust. I wanted to be a Monster Combat Hunter. It’s what I was born to do. I had never wanted to be anything else. I was coming to realize that even though I had the skills I would need down, I had to work on more than just the combat aspects. Perhaps that was why my mother and father had sent me to this school. To learn those other skills, like how to interact with people. Maybe that was what the principal was trying to tell me before.

As I shoved my garbage into the trash can and left my tray in the pile I looked around one last time before leaving. Only time would tell if that was the truth or not. I would continue to be suspicious of everyone and everything. But maybe I could try to work a bit harder at trusting people and approaching life with a more laid back attitude. Though I wouldn’t act like big sis Ulicia.

The choices you make not only affect you, but those around you. Just as the opposite of this basic fact is true: you are affected by the choices that others make. What will happen to that little girl? Will she die? Will she grow up hating everyone and everything? Will she become a great savior?

All these possibilities are possible and truth. They have both been decided and have not yet happened in this realm I call my own. Perhaps next time we meet I will allow you to gaze into the mind of yet another possibility either in this world or another. Let you play god with another life, to either bring ruin or glory. So until next we meat may the choices you make be the choices you desire.
1111211211121212.title: Let Liz go on her way.

111121121112122.content:
Screw this school. It seemed no matter how hard I tried to change, I was still just a hothead delinquent. They said a duck can’t change it’s feathers so easily and they were right. It didn’t matter if I attended school or not. They couldn’t teach me anything new. No one would shed any tears if I skipped out early or failed to show up tomorrow. In fact such actions were probably for the best. I wouldn’t be around to cause problems, or show everyone else up by just being me. I wouldn’t make people uncomfortable by telling them the truth they didn’t want to hear.

As I walked out the front door I remembered my promise to Liz. I felt a bit guilty about that, but I was sure she was just like everyone else, playing some angle for her own benefit. The more I thought about it the more logical that truth seemed. It was weird for her to want to be friends with me anyway. I wasn’t even sure why I had let her con me into that position. I had been a fool to be nice to her. A fool to let her get so close. Hadn’t I learned the error of caring about people? Of thinking they cared about me?

She was a fifth generation Hunter after all. She was actually more dangerous then all these first and second generation losers. She already knew how to play the game. How to weave plots within plots and hide them under innocent words. She was no different than my mother. But I refused to get sucked in. Refused to fall into that friendship trap. My mother’s recent little scheme had opened my eyes before I could fall too deeply into that pit. I needed to go home and purify my mind and body. Close myself off and return to keeping absolutely everyone at arms length. They were all enemies. Isn’t that what my family had taught me? That no one could be trusted. Not even your family.

No. Especially your family. They were always the worst perpetrators. Always expecting things from you and demanding things. Always assuming simply because you are blood they could get away with it. I was done with this family. Done with the Zelkov name. I wanted out. I had to find a way out.

I would find a way out.

*********

Hmm. Well this day didn’t turn out quite like you expected did it. I saw it of course, I see everything. Every possible outcome of every possible moment. What would have happened if he had fired on his mother? How much of the school would have been destroyed? Those are possibilities that did not happen along this timeline, but can you imagine if they had?

Did this exercise of my boredom teach you anything about yourself? I know it taught me quite a bit about you. Did it end to your liking? It should, since it was your choices that defined his life. What would you have done in the same situation? It is easy to decide for another and judge those actions is it not? Easier than deciding for yourself and not wanting to be judged in turn at any rate.

Until we meet again mortal. Until I am again bored and wish for a bit of amusement or simply to have my curiosity sated. When that time comes how will you chose to play god?
111121121112122.title: Go home early

choices: Beat on them a little more
11112112112.content:
Slipping the little stone into my pouch I waited for the group to get nearer before turning my gaze on the two boys who had stolen my gear. I felt my blood begin to boil as my teeth clenched and my nails began to fig into my flesh from making a fist so hard.

“Arena Master. Am I wrong to believe that stealing another students gear is a grave offence at this school?”

“No, you aren’t wrong. Each students gear is like a part of themselves. We don’t tolerate such things lightly.”

“Then would I be out of line to wish to punish them myself? More importantly, would I be able to without breaking any school rules?”

“Normally not. But right now you are in the arena. This is my domain and my decisions supersede even that of the principals in this area.”

“Then do I have your permission to give them a good thumping if I promise not to kill them or dismember them?”

“Only if you agree to two other conditions.”

“What’s that?”

“You don’t break more than three bones and you use no cutting weapons.”

“Easily agreed. Since I am much better than them, I don’t mind if they use any weapons of their choice. I’ll stick with my own fists and feet.”

Gregory and the other boy I still did not know the name of were both shaking in their boots. Holding up their hands and shaking their heads in negation.

“Look sorry ok! I don’t want no trouble. I don’t want to fight you. Just let us go ok?”

“I’m sorry! It was all Gregory’s idea! I didn’t want to but he talked me into it!”

“First Hunters code, all Hunters are responsible for his or her own actions. No one forces you to do anything. Each choice made is a choice the individual makes of his own will. You allowed him to talk you into it. That means you are just as guilty. And quite frankly I don’t care if you are sorry or not, or if you don’t want to fight or not. You don’t have a choice.”

I lunged forward, snagging them both up by the collar and throwing them behind me.

“Arena Master, please box us in.”

The rest of the class backed away as the Arena Master manipulated an artifact in his hand. Four walls rose around us, turning as clear as glass once they were in place. I simply stood there watching the two after sitting my gear down against the wall.

“Chose your weapons. I’m sure the good Master will be able to provide them for you. I won’t start until you make your decision and I won’t allow you to leave until I beat the snot out of you.”

After a bit more sniveling the one named Gregory asked for a standard sword and board set up. A simple long sword and large circular buckler that attached to the arm and unfolded like a fan appeared from the floor. The other boy got a quick load repeating crossbow that used magic arrows.

“Before we begin, what’s your name boy? It’s only proper to know who it is I am going to pound into the ground.”

“I-I’m Daniel.”

“Pleasure to meet you Daniel. Consider me a monster and give me everything you got.”

With that I began walking towards them. Not even trying to be quick. Daniel fired an arrow at me that I simply sidestepped. It had been halfhearted to begin with. After a moment Gregory charged at me with his shield up and his sword raised.

He feinted with the sword and tried to smash the shield into my face but the move was clumsy. He had put too much commitment into the feint, making him go off balance. Twisting to the left was all it took to avoid the sword strike. Daniel was hesitating because I was so close to his partner, a grievous mistake if I had really been a monster. As I walked past, I smashed my elbow into the side of Gregory’s head, continuing to head towards the shooter.

In a real fight where they knew what they were doing, this wouldn’t be a bad setup. A ranged person being protected by a shield bearer. But right now they were running on fear. Their training and strategy had gone out the window. I made sure to keep myself between the crossbow and the tank. That was all it took to keep him from shooting at me. I gave an evil grin as I slowly got closer and closer.

He finally took another shot when I was almost at point blank range. I saw his finger twitch, that was what I had actually been staring at the whole time. So I knew when it would fire. I did a split, letting it sail harmlessly over my head. Popping back to my feet and continuing to take deliberate steps towards him without missing a beat.

“Crossbow wasn’t a bad choice, but you are inexperienced at it, I can tell. You should have got something you knew how to use. It wouldn’t have done you any good of course, but at least you wouldn’t be so far out of your element.”

I slapped the crossbow out of his hands negligently as I cocked my fist back. His eyes went wide in fright as I dropped to one knee and spun, bringing my fist up into Gregory’s stomach under his sword strike. Spittle went flying from his mouth as the sword clattered to the ground and he fell to his knees clutching his abdomen.

“Come on. Did you really think I didn’t know you were sneaking up behind me? It was a good try though.”

As I turned around I brought my other fist up into Daniel’s gut, making him vomit a bit as he sank to the floor.
11112112112.title: Keep the crystal

111121121121.content:
I kicked them both a few more times. not with all my might, but still a few good thrusts of my foot. How dare they steal from me! To touch someone else's property without permission and then to use it as if it was their own! Not even caring that the very person they stole it from was in the very same room as them! I should kill them. They deserved to die. a good solid kick augmented with magic strength would take their heads right off.

But I had promised not to kill them or dismember them. I was allowed to break a few bones though. Three of them each. The thumbs of each hand at least, and maybe a leg bone. That would teach them. I looked down at the two rolling and moaning on the ground. They looked pitiful. Hardly Hunter material. They looked like to normal people I might find on the street on any given day. Seeing that my anger drifted away as suddenly as it had come.

“Arena Master! Drop the walls please. I’m done. They are too weak for me to even stay angry at. Punishing them just isn’t worth it.”

As the walls started to lower I turned, grabbing up my gear and leaving the arena. I was already regretting my hasty action. I knew I was stronger then them. What had that really proved? It had just been me soothing my own rage. Hunter’s weren’t supposed to act like this, they were heroes of the people, protecting those weaker then them. There was enough problems with monsters, people didn’t need to be fighting each other, isn’t that what aunt Ceflia had said? Plus I had to uphold the family name. Even if I didn’t like that name, what I did reflected on the rest of my family.

Once I was alone in the locker room I pulled off my glasses while sitting on a bench. Rubbing my eyes didn’t change the fact that I had just let my anger get the better of me. Again. But it did help me ground myself a little more firmly in reality and keep me calm. Shoving my recovered weapons back in my duffle bag I pulled the heart crystal out of my pouch.

Why hadn’t I even thought of offering it to Liz? She had done most of the work after all. I had just kept it’s attention on me while she had chipped away at the shield. By all rights she had more claim to this crystal than I did. Wasn’t that the Hunter’s code I had grown up learning? Was I truly that terrible a person? Or was it just because I didn’t completely trust her yet? She said she wanted to be friends, but I really didn’t know what that meant or how to act. I had never had a friend before.

Sitting here caught up in my own thoughts wouldn’t do me any good. The class wasn’t over yet and I needed to go back out there. I couldn’t make a bigger scene then I already had. So hiding the crystal in my bag, I threw on the mask of indifference I had learned to wear before heading back out into the Arena. It didn’t take long to climb the bleachers and take my seat next to Liz again. She gave me a small nod without looking at me as she watched the groups on the floor fighting against different monsters. We sat in silence, it wasn’t a companionable one, but it wasn’t really uncomfortable either.

“You had some pretty nice moves against that Sengwen.”

“Thanks.”

She was most definitely miffed that I hadn’t even offered her the crystal. She had to be. That was the only explanation for these suddenly weird vibes I was getting. Stop Riktal. Don’t assume anything. You know better than to assume. Find out first hand before making any judgments.

“Are you mad about something?”

“I’m not mad.”

She was mad. I could see it in the slight set of her jaw and the slightly clipped tone she was using.

“Is this about the heart crystal?”

“What do you think?”

“Look sorry about that. I pocketed it without thinking. I’m not really used to working with others so I just sort of reacted how I normally would. It’s yours if you want it.”

“Keep it. I don’t want it anymore. I didn’t really want it in the first place but it would have been nice to be thought of and treated like an equal. Treated like another Hunter. I thought we were really starting to connect. We have a bit in common and I was coming to like you. I thought we might have been able to be friends. But I see you and I think differently about what that means.”

She stood up and walked off farther down the bleachers, sitting back down and making it clear she wanted to be alone. This whole friendship thing was a lot harder then it seemed on paper. I had studied the basic ideas and the theories of how to interact with people of course, but they didn’t always react how they were supposed to. I knew how to deal with businessmen, government officials, and military types. I could play politics and speak with a silver tongue like the best of them, but dealing with people my own age like this, I just felt clueless. I wouldn’t have thought such a small thing would have made her so mad. Hadn’t I told her I wasn’t used to working with others?

With a sigh I returned my attention to watching the rest of the class fight in groups. Sometimes their teams were switched up or certain people were chosen to lead and issue orders. I could see the slow improvement but they were still far from being good enough for the Hunter’s Exam.

The bell finally rang and I wasted no time in grabbing my gear from the locker before going back to the classroom. I was the first one in the room, a fact I thought would hold true most of the time. These kids didn’t realize the importance of being early. More interested in hanging out and living such laid back lives. That kind of thinking would get them killed. If they continued to act like this was a regular high school and continued to think of themselves as just regular people, they wouldn’t live long.

When they got out into the real world they would be in for a rude awakening. Someone or something would kill them because they weren’t prepared. Because they hadn’t taken this training seriously. The rest of the class finally entered the room in their little groups, giving me a speculative eyeball or two. Liz came in alone, not even bothering to look at me before taking her seat and looking out the window.

I didn’t know if I was supposed to be bothered by her actions or not. Was this how easily friendships broke? If it was then I was better off without them. Right now I felt nothing over the fact that she wasn’t speaking to me. It was just another fact of how things were. I felt no real urge to try to make things right between us either. It was her problem not mine.

After the quick role call the teacher started in on his lesson. I learned nothing I didn’t already know, though the information was probably new to everyone else. That is, if they were even paying attention which I highly doubted. But it would be improper of me to not at least try and seem interested. The teacher was trying his best to teach them how to survive after all. He should know there was at least one person in the room that appreciated his efforts, even if that one person was the one who already knew it all.

111121121122.title: Walk away

1111211211221.content:
The bell rang and the teacher left, meaning there was only one more class before this day was finally over. But as soon as he walked out the door the talking started. People moved into their own little groups and talked about some of the most unimportant things, like their favorite band, or which boy or girl was cuter. A few brave souls approached me cautiously, I could see they had already formed an opinion of me but still wanted to be associated with my name.

“So it’s really true? You’re from the Zelkov family?”

“It’s true. Great deduction skills.”

I really didn’t feel like dealing with them right now. Asking such an obvious question only brought their intelligence into question, didn’t they know that? The slight I had done to Liz was really starting to bug me now. Having a whole class to do nothing but let my mind mull over whatever if felt like while she sat on the other side of the room giving off an aura of unwelcome had gotten to me.

The smile on the face of the girl who had asked the question never faltered. I’d give her credit, she could hold a fake grin with the best of them. Though maybe I gave her too much credit and the insult just went over her head.

“The name is Izabelle. I’m a second generation Hunter on my mom’s side. Think you could give me some tips on how to be a better Hunter?”

“You want tips? I can give you tips. Tip one: quit screwing around and take this place seriously. Tip two: Expect to die before you hit twenty one. Tip three: Invest in really good weapons. If you continue to think you are still just an ordinary high school student and not a Hunter in training then you won’t live long. Throw out any ideas you have of having a “normal” life. You chose to come to this school and learn to be a Hunter. You are no longer normal. You no longer have the option to be normal. The things you learn here cannot be unlearned.”

“Things like love and what the hot new fashion trend is? They mean nothing. If you don’t dedicate your everything to becoming a Hunter then you will die. Good weapons can make up for some of the skill you lack, but never assume you are the best or unbeatable or invincible. You can get taken out by someone much weaker than you if they have a better weapon or they catch you when your guard is lowered.”

“As a Hunter you must be ready to sacrifice your everything to do the job you have been given. And that is to protect normal people who cannot protect themselves from monsters. We aren’t in it for fame, or fortune, or honor. Those things are just side effects of what we are meant to do. If you lose sight of your main goal and chase after dreams of glory and riches then you fail as a Hunter. Innocent people will die because of that fact. You might think I am being overdramatic but I am not. I am simply stating facts. Facts you should have been told in some way when you entered this academy. If I am scaring you then good, you should be scared. This is your life on the line. But it is also the lives of thousands of others who will be depending on you.”

The small group around me looked at each other a bit worried, wondering how to respond to what I had said. I saw Liz watching me with thoughtful eyes, nodding her head slightly at my words. She wasn’t nodding at me directly, just agreeing with what I had said.

The teacher came in then and everyone resumed their seats. After making sure everyone was here he began his lesson on the Cawmacaw. Talking about its weaknesses and strength as well as it’s environment. As he began discussing common tactics that could be used the door opened and a woman in a trim business suit, small wire framed glasses and lustrous black hair came in the door. She whispered to the teacher a moment before he nodded and pointed in my direction.

“Riktal! You’re wanted by your mother.”

With a sigh I grabbed my bag and headed out the door with the woman. What did my mother want now? Couldn’t it have waited until I got home at least? The clacking of her high heels echoed down the hallway as she walked at my side.

“I’m Inga by the way, one of your mother’s aides.”

“I hope you are already looking for another job because my mother goes through you guys like an armor piecing round through paper. Longest I’ve seen one last was six months. It’s nothing you guys do wrong just so you know, that’s just how she is.”

Inga fell silent again, escorting me to a private room where she asked me to sit down. I ignored the invitation, instead standing by the window and looking outside. What was my mother up to? Where was she anyway? It was unlike her to be late for a meeting that she herself had set up. I heard the door open finally and turned with a few choice words on my lips.

Words which died out as the small white haired girl with red eyes came in the door after my mother. She stood barely four and a half feet tall and had a body like a stick. She carried around a teddy bear in one hand and had a look of perpetual vacant eyed dreaminess on her face. Even though my mother had her usual cheery and flippant demeanor about her there was something in her face that told me she was worried.”

“Riktal darling! How are you!”

“The same as I was this morning mother. So care to tell me the reason you called me here? The real reason. And can we cut through all the regular back and forth and civil pleasantries? I assume you are here on Hunter business or you wouldn’t have brought one of your aides.”

She motioned to a seat as her work face dropped into place. I took it across the table from her as the little girl sat down in another chair nearby. Those vacant eyes making me think of a puppet being pulled by invisible strings.

“Very well. I got a job for you. Protecting Asala here. Me and your father can’t ,we were contracted to clear out some caverns in Bornica, we won’t be back for a few days. Your sister is on a job now for the military so probably won’t be back for a few weeks.”

“So why me?”

“Because even though you are terrible with people your own age, you are great with kids. I also know how skilled you are. There aren’t many people I can trust with this task.”

“So what’s so special about her? Foreign dignitaries child?”

“She’s a monster summoner. But her powers are a bit unstable. She can’t always control the monsters she summons because her powers awakened early. It seems they are influenced by her mood and her emotions.”

“I can see why you wouldn’t trust many Hunters with this task. A lot of them are pretty narrow minded about those with what they call the cursed magic. Yourself included mother. You tolerate them and let them alone but you still don’t like them. But most Hunter’s would rather kill her simply because she is who she is.”

“That’s not true dear!”

“It is. I’ve heard the way you talk about them. I know you’ve dealt with them before but you are never too happy about it. I’ve heard some of the discussions you have had with father when you thought I was sleeping. Deny it if you want but it doesn’t really matter to me. It’s not a view I share. So what about her parents? Will I have to protect them too? Or did they give her up once they found out about her ability?”

“Dead. Murdered in front of her. That’s why her power awakened. It will only be for a few days. I know someone who is also a summoner willing to take her in but she won’t be able to get away from her work until then.”

“Likelihood of danger?”

“Direct threats to her life is minimal. Mostly you will be needed in case she summons a monster that she can’t control. It happens more when she is emotionally unstable; fear, intense sadness, that kind of thing. Plus any dangers once people find out what she can do.”

“And there is no one else you can trust to do this?

“Well… there is one other person.”

“Then why didn’t you ask them?”

“Because it’s Pelei.”

I nodded my understanding. Pelei was a good guy and a great Hunter. But he had strange tastes. Very touchy-feely and wanting to dress up anything he thought was cute. His obsessions could be quite scary sometimes. A girl like this would be eaten up by Pelei. He might even end up scaring her into summoning monsters. There would be no danger of him harming her or doing anything to her physically; but on the other hand he would have no problem ripping her clothes off and shoving some new outfit on her.

Looking at the vomit colored green dress she was wearing now I could only imagine that would be the first thing he did if he saw her. On the other hand my mother was asking me to do this as an official job even after stating she didn’t want me to become an official Hunter yet. That seemed a bit hypocritical to me. She would be in good hands with Pelei and he could handle anything she summoned without a problem. I wasn’t exactly needed here.

“Pelei is the better choice still, he is an official Hunter, something I might remind you, I am not because someone didn’t want me to take the exams. He has more experience than me too. So why do you want me over him?”

She looked at the girl a moment and then at the table, a small smile spreading across her lips as her eyes grew a bit distant.

“Because you’re family.”
1111211211221.title: After class

11112112112211.content:
“All right. This is against my better judgment but I’ll do it.”

“Oh Riktal darling! I just knew I could count on you!”

“I expect to be paid for this though since this is an official job. And I will still expect my living allowance.”

“You won’t do this for free? For little old me?”

“Not a chance mother. Nothing less than ten thousand Reul. I’d charge more but I’m not an official hunter yet and I’m being nice in giving you a family discount.”

“Don’t you feel any remorse at breaking your poor mothers bank account?”

“Not an ounce.”

My mother sighed dramatically before waving her hand absently at Inga who was standing against the wall.

“Transfer the money into his account for me would you please? Thanks ever so much. Oh and Riktal, I still expect you to attend school.”

“You can expect it all you want but I can’t promise it if I am going to protect the girl around the clock.”

“You are such a willful child! It hurts me that you don’t listen to your mother.”

“I’m so broken up over the fact that you are hurt. Don’t you see me crying you a river of invisible tears?”

She looked at the sky shaking her head.

“Where did I go wrong?”

“Do you want the list in alphabetical order or just bullet points?”

She shook her head again but didn’t say anything, just pushing her chair back to get to her feet. I stood up when my mother did, letting her embrace me in a hug before saying she had to get going. Before she left I called out to her, passing on big sis Ulicia’s love. She blew me a final kiss before departing, leaving me alone with the little girl. Even though I was staring at the back of her head, she didn’t turn around or move. As if those invisible puppeteer strings that had been moving her had suddenly been cut. Pulling out the chair next to her, I swung it around a bit so we were face to face.

“Asala huh? I once knew an Asala. Tasted great on corn chips. Wait… never mind, that was salsa.”

The corner of her mouth twitched for just a fraction a second and I smiled. So she knew what was going on around her after all.

“I bet you are probably really scared right now and I don’t blame you. You don’t know me or probably anyone else. All you know is you suddenly got a new power you don’t understand and your mom and dad are dead. Then I bet somebody just ripped you away from all of that and said something like you could never go back or that you had to leave. Now you are waiting for someone to come take you to yet another place farther away from anything you know to teach you how to control your power.”

“I also bet no one stopped to find out what you thought about all of this. And I’d wager no one who has found out about your ability has treated you very nicely. Even Hunter’s like my mom who tolerate summoner’s were probably a bit rude and inconsiderate. So I don’t blame you for trying not to show any emotions if you are afraid I will be like the rest of them. But I must tell you, that dead fish face you keep giving me is creeping me out. And in case you didn’t hear what I told my mother, I’m not like other Hunter’s. I have no problem with summoner’s or their abilities. I don’t think their magic is cursed any more than my own is. It’s just different that’s all.”

I held out my hand with a smile.

“The name’s Riktal Zelkov. You might have already known that of course, but formal introductions are important. Mind telling me your name?”

I kept the smile on my face and didn’t drop my hand. She just sat there staring at it and I sat there offering it. This was mind games 101 that I had learned long ago. On the whole humans didn’t like when nothing was happening. They had a need to fill the silence, or a need to take action. If you created a situation of inaction and silence that only they can break such as this while giving off the air that it won’t end until they do something, ninety percent of the time they will be unable to do nothing.

My smile grew wider as she slowly raised her hand and took mine. She raised her teddy bear to her mouth but I didn’t hear any sound come out.

“Now that just won’t do little miss. I can’t read your mind and I can’t hear you through your friend there. Unless of course you can’t or don’t want to talk. Then it’s a different matter entirely. Nothing wrong with it and I won’t push you. And I guess that was inconsiderate of me not to ask that first. Seems I’ve been doing inconsiderate things to girls all the way around today. So I guess I should ask now, do you want to talk?”

She shook her head no.

“Can you talk?”

She didn’t move for a minute but finally nodded her head up and down.

“Well that’s good at least. Could you imagine being unable to talk and trying to call for help when you really need it? Or laughing without any sound coming out?”

I threw out my hand and opened my mouth wide, miming calling for help but not making a sound. I also put my hands on my belly and shook up and down in a parody of laughter but not making a peep. Again I saw her mouth twitch, but this time she didn’t try to hide it as quickly.

I was making progress. I was establishing a bond of trust between us. One I would need if I was going to protect her. She had to believe that she could come to me with any trouble and feel safe around me. I was willing to work around her reticence to talk. Willing to decipher her body language and moods. It wasn’t the first time I had dealt with someone who couldn’t talk after all. The other secret was to try not to talk down to them. Especially ones that were around eleven years old as this one looked. If you acted like they were stupid because they were younger, they picked up on that fairly quickly. But at the same time you needed to avoid using too many words they didn’t understand. It was a fine line and a hard art to master.

“Well I’m going to ask you a few simple yes and no questions. Think you could answer them with a nod of your head? If you don’t want to answer that’s fine too.”

A quick nod of the head.

“Do you like stuffed animals?”

Yes.

“Did they let you pack any extra clothes or toys before they took you away?”

No.

“Are you trying not to show your emotions because you think that will make a monster appear?”

Yes.

I let my voice drop down a notch, filling it with a bit of compassion.

“Do you miss your mom and dad?”

She didn’t move for a moment but finally her eyes got a bit watery as her head dipped down and then back up.

“Are you afraid? Lonely? Confused?”

Again a slow nod to all of those questions as the tears finally began to flow and a soft mewling sound came from her throat. I reached out and pulled her into my arms, rocking her back and forth slightly.

“Cry it all out. It’s not good for a pretty little girl like you to hold it all inside. If some mean nasty monster appears then I’ll just have to make it go away won’t I? That’s my job after all. I’m not going to let anything hurt you while you are under my watch. I won’t tell anyone anything you tell me or let slip anything you do. To me you aren’t a monster summoner. To me you are just Asala, a little girl who just lost her family and is now all alone in this big scary world.”

She buried her face in my chest to muffle her wails as I stroked her hair gently. Finally her waterworks died down into sniffles and I pulled her away from me slightly.

“Feel a little better?”

Rubbing her eyes she slowly nodded her head.

“Good. Then how do you feel about us going out on a bit of a shopping spree on the town. We can get you some new clothes, maybe another stuffed animal or two and a few toiletries to call your own. You might not be here long, but that’s no reason I can’t try my hardest to make you feel like you are home.”

When she hunched her shoulders and shrunk back a bit at the suggestion I nodded knowingly.

“Afraid of crowds too aren’t you?”

Yes.

“Well I will be with you the whole time and I promised not to let anything bad happen to you remember. If you don’t trust me just shake your head no and we can go home.”

Finally she shook her head yes and I smiled.

“One last question before we go. Are you hungry?”

She nodded her head up and down as she clutched at her stomach. I put my hand on her head just as the bell rang, signaling the end of the school day.

“Then lets go on our date shall we?”

Yes.
11112112112211.title: Accept job

choices: Well you feel like a little sister
111121121122111.content:
“We’ve definitely got to eat first. If I know little boys and girls, you are always hungry. Sometimes bottomless pits it seems. Since you probably never said a word to anyone else I bet my mother didn’t even stop to feed you lunch. And if I know my mother she probably gave you a bowl of porridge for breakfast and thought that was enough. Come on, I know a nice little café that can make just about anything you could want no matter what time of day it is.”

I shouldered my bag and opened the door, exiting into the hall a little before the girl to make sure it was safe. I didn’t expect anything to happen so soon, but it wouldn’t do to lower my guard for anything. As we walked out the front door I saw some of the other students staring at us and whispering behind their hands. More specifically they were staring at Asala, probably coming up with some off the wall theories as to who she was and her relationship with me.

I took her to a place called The Pipe, telling her to order whatever she wanted. It took a bit of pointing at the menu but soon enough we were sitting alone waiting for our meal. she stared at the table top quietly, trying to turn invisible. I watched her for a little bit before finally speaking softly.

“I know how you feel and what you are going through. I had a little sister who died when she was about your age. That was about three years ago now. I’m not going to lie. It hurts and it will for a long time to come. That pain dulls with time, but it never completely goes away. You might not believe me now, but there will come a time when you realize you’ve just gone a day or a week or a month without thinking about them. Then something will suddenly remind you of them and that feeling comes flooding back.”

“It’s a scary thought. Thinking you are going to forget about them. Forget what they look like, what they sound like. Your memories of the times you had with them slowly blurring until you aren’t sure if it really happened or not. And I know you don’t want to forget those things. You shouldn’t have to forget them. It’s even harder for you because you don’t even have a single photo to remind you of them do you? At least I was able to keep that much along with a few other things.”

Even though I hadn’t actually asked her a question she was bobbing her head up and down as if agreeing to what I was saying. Seeing the state she was in and the way she was barely keeping it together made my heart break. She reminded me so much of Olia. I wasn’t sure what exactly made me decide to reveal my secret to her but I somehow felt she needed my unique ability.

“If I told you a secret would you keep it?”

A head nod in affirmation.

“Are you sure? You seem to be a little chatterbox to me.”

Her lips curled upwards but she nodded again.

“I’ve got a special magic just like you. I can’t do anything fancy like summon monsters but I can make things come alive. I’m not talking about just animating say your teddy bear to make it dance around. No, mine is a bit more unique than that. I don’t tell many people about it because it’s a magic most people don’t understand. And anything people don’t understand they are afraid of. They label it as taboo or cursed. My great-great grandfather had the same ability as me and that’s actually how I learned to use my power.”

“You see, if I have a picture or a favorite object that a person handled often, something that is imprinted with their essence, I can make them live again. It’s not actually real life, and it’s not like I call the souls back from the dead. At least I don’t think so. It is more like I recreate who they were while they were alive. The more of themselves that was imprinted on the item and the more I know about them, the more complete they become.”

“My great-great grandfather died a long time ago, but I had his picture and I had heard stories about him. Because of that I was able to see him in person whenever I went to sleep and I could talk to him just like I am talking to you. That’s how I found out about this magic and how to use it, he taught me in my dreams. It was a bit of trial and error in learning of course, and I made mistakes just like you will while learning your power. But I never gave up until I mastered it.”

“Tell me, that teddy bear you are holding, did your mom and dad give it to you?”

She nodded her head slowly, her eyes a bit wide at what I had just told her.

“Mind if I see it for a moment?”

She handed me the bear across the table after a moment of hesitation. After looking both ways to make sure no one was watching I cut my finger with my belt knife and let a few drops of blood drip onto the bears head. I concentrated, calling on my magic until the bear glowed with a purple aura. I began to sweat like I did every time I used this power. It wasn’t that powerful to begin with and it took effort.

My blood spread out like a thin coating across the entire bear, turning it a muddy red color. This was the hard part, giving it the unique twist of the mind needed to pull out the essence of her mother and father before attaching it to the stuffed creature again. The muddy red color began to pull back from the brown fur, moving as if being sucked into the eyes, changing the black glass buttons into a crimson to match her own. My magic rippled and twisted as I anchored it all in the state between the dream world and the real one. Finally I was done and the aura was sucked into the eyes as well, causing them to glow brightly as if they had an intelligence of their own.

I gave a short gasp before wiping at my nosebleed and handing the bear back to the little girl.

“Now you can see and hear them whenever you go to sleep. Just think about them while holding onto that bear and you will dream of them as if they are really there. There won’t be much to them right now, little more than pictures that will sometimes move and say a few words. But if you ever want to tell me about them I can add that into the magics memory banks to create a more complete essence. You can call on me anytime, even once you get to your new place with your new teacher. You have my name and you know how to get a hold of me.”

Our meal came a moment later and she began to eat with a very thoughtful look on her face. She kept touching the bear’s new red colored eyes delicately, as if afraid they were suddenly real and she would hurt it. I was suddenly ravenous. Using my ability on such a large object had burned a lot of energy. Great-great grandfather had warned me to keep quiet about my ability. He said the Priests of The One God and many people thought this skill bordered on the sacrilegious. As if I was somehow transgressing against the order of life itself. Even though this was just a unique form of magic and the spirits were simply shadows of the real thing, people still believed it was calling back the spirits of the dead to trap them.

I hadn’t believed him at first, until I did research on my own while I was awake, finding other instances of people like me. They were treated like criminals and hunted down like they were some form of new monster. Tortured by people who had once called them friends and family. It was no wonder those with this skill didn’t make it very public. I knew I had taken a chance in telling her my secret, but I also felt that she wouldn’t tell anybody.

She was halfway through her meal when she suddenly lowered her fork, putting the piece of sausage back on the plate. She looked at her food a moment and then at me.

“My… my name is Asala Heinfield.”

“A pleasure to meet you.”

“Will… will it really work? You weren’t lying?”

Her voice was small and soft. Almost pleading as she spoke a but stiltedly.

“Promise. Cross my heart and hope to die.”

“You really don’t care about what I can do?”

“Not in the slightest. Once you can properly control the monsters you summon it will be up to you to decide how to use your ability. Will you help people with it? Or will you hurt them? Now that is an answer that I do care about. My job is to protect people. Right now it is you, but in the larger picture it is everyone. If you decide to hurt people on purpose with your ability then I will have to stop you. But it wouldn’t be because you are a summoner, it would be because you are hurting people I am supposed to protect. Right now if you were to hurt someone I don’t think it would be on purpose. So why should I hold anything against you?”

“You sound like my daddy. I got my ability from my mommy’s side of the family. She didn’t have it but grandpa did.”

“Sounds like your daddy was a smart man..”

“I miss him.”

“I’m sure you do.”

“Can I call you big brother?”

“Sure if I can call you little sis.”

“I’d like that. I wish you were really my big brother. You’re different from everyone else. I feel safe around you.”

“It’s because I’m ugly. You can’t always trust a handsome face, but you can trust an ugly one.”

She giggled at that, this time her laughter sounding more natural and not like she was trying to bite down on it.

“My daddy used to say things like that too. Like never trust boys with teeth that sparkled. Or don’t go out with a boy who wears prettier dresses than you. But that’s not it. You feel… I don’t know how to explain it. You just feel like a big brother. And for the record, I don’t think you’re ugly.”
111121121122111.title: Take her to eat first

1111211211221111.content:
“Well you feel like a little sister… shrimp. Now hurry up and finish, we still got a long day ahead of us. And I won’t allow you to keep moping around all day. There’s a time and place for everything, but that doesn’t mean you can’t enjoy a few things here and there. It’s not a crime or anything to be happy even at a time like this. It doesn’t mean you loved them any less. There is no law that says you have to go around like you are at their funeral all the time.”

“Mommy said something like that too when grandpa died. That he wouldn’t want us to be sad all the time.”

“See? That proves I know what I’m talking about.”

She still looked a bit melancholy as she finished her meal but the edge had been taken off her grief. I had to wonder just how badly everyone else had overlooked her the last three days she had been carted around by one person or another. It hadn’t been all that hard to get her to open up. Any half competent person should have been able to do it if they had simply put a bit of time and effort in. But that was the nature of adults I found, always so busy and wrapped up in their own problems and their own things they forget about other people. I held no illusions, I would end up being the same way to some extent.

Once we were done with the meal I paid our tab and we left. First stop would be the clothing store. She needed new clothes, and ones that looked better on her. I had no doubt she didn’t like what she was wearing. She stuck close to me, but no longer as afraid as when we had first met. She held onto the bear though like it was a lifeline, and I suppose now it was in more ways than one.

I talked with her a little bit about small things, trying to draw her into more conversation both about her family and about herself. It was all part of the grieving process that she needed to go through. The longer she held it all in the worse it would be for her.

Even though she tried to hide the fact, I could tell she was enjoying herself. She would laugh at a joke or giggle at some private thought. She went starry eyed over the clothes in the store and posed in the mirror while trying them on. She hadn’t forgotten her grief, it was still an ever present shadow on her face. But she was slowly coming to realize I wasn’t lying when I had said making herself feel good wasn’t some sin against the memory of her family.

After about four solid hours of shopping and snacking on treats from random shops I was loaded down with four bags stuffed with new clothes, a new pair of shoes, a few pieces of jewelry, a new stuffed animal and some personal hygiene items such as her own toothbrush and comb, deodorant and perfume. Though even all this wasn’t half the weight of the duffle bag on my back so carrying it was no big deal.

We just crossed the bridge that separated the main part of the city from the residential area when a red circle appeared in front of us. A hand emerged and then a hunched over grey body. Asala hid behind my legs as the huge glowing green eyes focused on us.

“Relax, you just summoned a Spleef. Probably because you are feeling so happy and content right now. That made your power activate without you wanting it to and pulled this guy from wherever he was.”
