The creature walked over to us, its knuckles dragging the ground, hunching down and waiting.

“What’s a Spleef? And what does it want?”

“Well, I guess the best description for it is a Golem. It’s a magically constructed monster that has a will of it’s own. It’s a subclass of giant and as you can see it is docile normally. When it get’s angry it’s eyes change to blue and it gets big. About twice as big as me. And it’s powerful. As to what it wants, I think it want’s you to command it.”

“You summoned it. In so doing my guess is it latched onto your magical outburst. It imprinted on you so to speak. So now it is your pet. It will obey your orders and your orders alone, no matter what they are without question. They are a symbiotic creature. Even though they can survive and reproduce out in the wild, they need magic to sustain themselves. That’s why they usually gather around magical nodes, or carry small stones filled with magic with them when they roam.”

“I think this is a good thing, it will eat your magic so to speak. The stuff you naturally bleed off from being unstable. He will help you not accidentally summon other things when you get scared or angry or whatever other emotion you might have at any given time.”

“But… but I don’t want him following me around! And how do I even know what you say is true?”

“Easy enough way to find out. Give him an order. I told you before, they are constructed creatures. As much as they look real they are not. They have no real souls of their own like other monsters do. Their will is only a very primitive one. Tell it to turn into a ring on your finger, or a necklace or something. If it really has attached itself to you, it will do so without question.”

“Uh… Spleef, turn into a ring on my right hand.”

The Spleef’s eyes sparkled for a second before it seemed to compress in on itself, turning into a little ball. A hole widened through the ball as it shot towards Asala’s right hand and solidified into a grey ring.

“You should give it a name. That will make it easier to command it. Names have power and a magic all their own.”

“Spleef. I name you… I name you Orse.”

The ring glimmered a moment and then went still as I chuckled at the look of surprise on Asala’s face.

“Orse?”

“I had a cat named Orse once. It was the only name I could think of.”

I ruffled her hair as I got her walking again, leading her to the house and inside the gate. After dropping the bags to the floor I nodded my chin to her.

“Tomorrow I will show you how to summon and control your new monster. I really only know the theories behind it and I can’t teach you anything else about your summoning abilities, but I know monsters. Anyone can tame a Spleef… if they can find one. They are pretty hard to find though. Some Hunters spend year’s tracking down a nest of them in order to make a familiar out of one. He will be a strong guardian for you in the future. They may only live about eight to ten years but I’m sure he will get you through some difficult times. But for now, go get cleaned up and get to bed. You had a long day and tomorrow will be even longer.”

“All right big brother.”

She dug out her pajamas and some clean underwear, heading off upstairs after I gave her directions on how to get to the bathroom. I heard the water running and I smiled to myself while picking up the rest of her bags and heading up the stairs as well. It had been a while since I had heard someone call me big brother in anything but my dreams. I had forgotten how good it made me feel. I had to be careful how attached I got to her though or it would be difficult to see her leave when this was over. I had already grown fond of her and it would be hard enough as it was. But that was no reason to push her away. She needed some form of family right now and at the moment I was it. She would have her parent’s in her dreams, but she needed someone solid that she could touch as well. And right now, I felt I needed a little sister again.

****************************

Well, well. A small facet of Riktal is revealed. A facet that only appeared because of the unique choices he made. Or should I say you made. It must make you wonder, would he have revealed such a secret about himself if he had gone shopping first? Would the thought ever crossed his mind if he had never kept the heart crystal to begin with and offered it to Liz instead? Perhaps the decision all began from his very first words. From his decision to tell the class only his first name.

Just what long ranging affects does each choice have on the outcome of a situation? Is there any way to tell all the time? What small change, or what order in which information is revealed affects the thought process that ends in this or that choice? For each second there is an infinite possible number of choices. All of them slightly different from the last. Some of them make little to no difference on the course of events. But as the choices begin to diverge, so too does the outcomes.

This is why this world is so dreamlike. Why I have the ability to grant you temporary godhood. Because all choices have happened, will happen, might happen and must happen all at once. Decisions and choices made affect not only the individual but also all those around him. That in turn affects how they think and react. Even if the words are the same, the context can change depending on the choice. A cheerful goodbye in one possibility and those same words a tear jerking farewell in another.

The window closes, though it will open again. And you will be there to make new choices, to lead young Riktal down a new possibility. I know this. For I know everything. I see everything. Your return has been destined to happen for it has already happened a thousand times before and will happen a thousand times after. Good day to you mortal.
1111211211221111.title: Well you feel like a little sister

1111211211221112.content:
I wasn’t exactly sure how to reply to that so I fell back on what I knew, I kept silent. We went back to eating, some of the sadness had left her face. I could only hope I had helped alleviate some of that for her and she would see that she didn’t have to be sad all the time. That finding moments of happiness even when she was grieving wasn’t a sin.

We finally finished eating and left, heading for a nearby clothing store. She stuck close to me, no longer quite so afraid but still wary. The bear in her hands being crushed tightly to her chest as if that would somehow make my magic activate while she was awake. I had to ensure she never lost that bear, if she did she would be devastated. I also had to be careful not to get too attached to her. Doing so would make our eventual parting all the harder. She couldn’t stay here and I couldn’t go with her.

I tried to draw out a little more information about her and her parents bit by bit. To start the grieving process so it didn’t eat her up from the inside out. Asala answered some of them but still seemed a bit reserved overall. That was to be expected, you didn’t get over something like this in a day or two.

But as she tried on new dresses and posed in the mirror, hints of the little girl she must have been before poked through the veil of depression around her. It never went away completely, but I could see it was pushed back every so often. She didn’t talk much to me unless I initiated the conversation, but I could feel the bond between us deepening. She needed someone she could trust right now. Someone she could consider as family. A real person and not the parents she would only be able to see in her dreams. That was part of the reason she had latched onto me so easily. Because I had offered her that hand in the darkness when she had needed it most.

After almost four hours of shopping and snacking on treats from random stores we were finally heading back home. The bag on my back weight almost twice what the four bags in my hands weighed. Yet the ones in my hands carried the hopes and dreams of normalcy for Asala. At least some normalcy. And that weight made them feel to be the heavier burden. A burden I was glad to carry.

Shortly after we crossed the bridge into the residential district a red rimed circle appeared on the ground in front of us. Asala gave a small whimper of fear as she hid behind my leg. A large purple tentacle emerged from the hole, the sucker pads gripping the street in front of me. A moment later another one appeared and then another.

Calmly I set the bags down and looked back at Asala.

“Wait here for just a moment ok? Don’t worry, I’ll take care of this.”

I began walking forward as a fourth tentacle slapped to the ground on the side of the hole. Slipping off my duffle bag I reached inside without taking my eyes off the monster and grabbed the first hilt I could find before dropping the bag to the ground. I glanced at the blade and saw it was a modified version of an Arabian scimitar, perfect for my needs. Its steeply curved blade wouldn’t catch on flesh or bone, sliding through it easily.

As the head of the Hool rose out of the hole in the ground I negligently brought the sword around in an arc, slicing through the neck just below where the feathers ended. My strike almost took the head clean off, the owl like head not even having time to let out a gurgle as the head tipped backwards. I kicked downwards even as I brought the sword around in a backhand sweep, severing the tentacles from their grip on the ground. By the time the corpse began to spurt out ink from the wound, the owl-octopus creature was already falling back through the summoning hole.

A bit of the ink splattered on my boots and I let out a tsk of displeasure. Hool ink was hard to get off and it began to stink after a few hours. Even as I turned to replace my sword in the bag the portal closed up again. It took only a moment to shrug the duffle onto my back again and pick up the shopping bags. With a jerk of my head I started on towards the house, Asala following behind.

“Don’t worry about it my new little sis. I can take care of anything you can dish out. Until you learn control it’s not your fault.”

“But what if I summon something big and scary that could hurt lots of people? I don’t want to do that.”

“Then I will stop it and I will protect you at the same time. You aren’t summoning these things on purpose are you?”

“No.”

“Then there is nothing to worry about.”

“But people blame me when I do it.”

“Then people are idiots. Do you blame the clouds when it rains? Or the cow for producing milk? It is just a natural action and reaction. Water evaporated and gathers in the clouds until it gets too heavy and falls. The clouds don’t just say to themselves, hey it’s a nice sunny day and I haven’t rained in a while, so let me dump some water on their heads. The cow doesn’t think to itself, hey I’m tired of being milked every day, so today I just won’t produce any at all.”

I knelt down and looked her directly in the eyes so she could see how serious I was.

“Get this through your thick skull. This. Is. Not. Your. Fault. If you want to be my little sister you have to be smart. I won’t stand for having a dummy of a sister who can’t accept such a simple truth. I’ll tell you that a million times until you believe it.”

Slowly she smiled with eyes that had suddenly begun to water. She wrapped her arms around my neck and hugged me tightly. Her voice was a whisper as it tickled my ear.

“Thank you big brother. I think I can believe it when you say it. Because you make it sound real.”

I patted her back before pushing her away.

“Good, now go get yourself cleaned up. We have a long day tomorrow and you need your sleep. Besides, isn’t there a few people waiting for you in your dreams?”

She looked down at her teddy bear and grinned a bit. As she began pulling out her night wear and clean underclothes I asked to have the bear for a little bit. She looked uncertain until I assured her I was just going to add a bit more magic to it.

She ran upstairs quickly after I told her how to get to the restroom, the water beginning to run moments later. I grabbed the rest of the bags and took them to my room, leaving the door open so she knew where I was. While she took her bath I sat on my bed adding more substance to the mother and father she would meet in her dreams. Putting everything I had learned about them today into it. These phantoms were far from complete but for now it would be enough. Because right now it was more than she had to start with.

Sitting the bear by the pillow I dug in my closet, pulling out a big tattered box filled with stuffed animals. Mementoes of my sister my mother had wanted to throw out but I had rescued without her knowledge. Pushing them around I found the little blue stuffed bunny missing one eye.

“Hey sis. Long time no see huh? I’m sorry I haven’t thought about you for a while, things just came up. You know? But I got a lot to tell you.”

I held the rabbit close to my chest. It had been my sisters favorite. I had given her Mr. Snuggles for her third birthday and she was never seen without it from that day forward. It had been the first major project I had undertaken with my power. It had given me a headache for two days straight and made me sick afterwards. But every little detail of her was inside. Every strand of hair, every movement she had ever made, right down to her speech patterns and the smell that had surrounded her. Sometimes I thought I could still smell that unique aroma on the rabbit itself.

Asala came in and climbed into bed, pulling her teddy in close to her chest as she yawned sleepily. As I began making up a bed on the floor she stopped me with her soft voice.

“Will you sleep with me? Please?”

I gave her a smile as I turned off the lights and slipped under the covers with her. She closed her eyes and I closed mine. Olia’s blue rabbit clutched just as firmly to my chest as the bear was to Asala’s

*********

Well, well. A small facet of Riktal is revealed. A facet that only appeared because of the unique choices he made. Or should I say you made. It must make you wonder, would he have revealed such a secret about himself if he had gone shopping first? Would the thought ever crossed his mind if he had never kept the heart crystal to begin with and offered it to Liz instead? Perhaps the decision all began from his very first words. From his decision to tell the class only his first name.

Just what long ranging affects does each choice have on the outcome of a situation? Is there any way to tell all the time? What small change, or what order in which information is revealed affects the thought process that ends in this or that choice? For each second there is an infinite possible number of choices. All of them slightly different from the last. Some of them make little to no difference on the course of events. But as the choices begin to diverge, so too does the outcomes.

This is why this world is so dreamlike. Why I have the ability to grant you temporary godhood. Because all choices have happened, will happen, might happen and must happen all at once. Decisions and choices made affect not only the individual but also all those around him. That in turn affects how they think and react. Even if the words are the same, the context can change depending on the choice. A cheerful goodbye in one possibility and those same words a tear jerking farewell in another.

The window closes, though it will open again. And you will be there to make new choices, to lead young Riktal down a new possibility. I know this. For I know everything. I see everything. Your return has been destined to happen for it has already happened a thousand times before and will happen a thousand times after. Good day to you mortal.
1111211211221112.title: Say nothing

111121121122112.content:
“Lets go do a bit of shopping first then. I know a small diner that won’t have a lot of people but right now is their late lunch early dinner rush. Since you probably don’t want to be around a lot of people we can wait about half an hour or so until it empties out a bit. If your tummy can’t wait we can get a few snacks along the way.”

I led her out of the room, letting my eyes move back and forth as I assessed every possible potential threat. These might just be ordinary school kids, but they were also Hunter’s in training. No matter how unskilled they were, it only took a moment of laxness. But we got off school grounds with nothing more exciting than a few speculative glances and hidden whispers as we passed.

Into town we went. I tried to engage her in conversation with more yes and no questions, but she seemed to have used up her willingness to cooperate. Perhaps the prospect of going into the crowds was making her draw into herself.

We stopped in at a clothing store and she tried on a few dresses. She didn’t act much like most girls I knew while on a shopping spree. There were hints of that interest in the clothes and the jewelry, but mostly it was like she didn’t care what she wore. In the end I had to decide on a few different dresses. Though I was no expert, I got ones I thought complimented her well and were pretty on top of that.

As we came out of the store we ran into Liz. She looked down at the girl then back up at me with a raised eyebrow but didn’t say anything. I turned to walk away but she stopped me.

“Wait.”

When I looked back she opened her mouth to say something before looking at the ground a moment.

“Listen. I think I was a bit hasty earlier. I realized that our views on things are a bit different because of our backgrounds. You didn’t mean anything by what you did. It seems I’m not so good at this whole friendship and relationship thing as I thought I was. Think we could put this behind us?”

I felt my lips curve upwards slightly.

“Sure. Lord knows I’m not all that great at it either. Tell you what, I’m on a job right now and I will be for the next few days. If you want I can introduce you to a weapon broker I know after that and we can split the profits on this crystal.”

“I’d like that.”

Just then the snarling of a dog made me turn in time to see a large mutt barreling down the sidewalk, a leash trailing behind him. He had eyes filled with madness as he headed straight for Asala. She gave a small mewl of terror as she hid behind my legs. Even as he leapt at her with fangs bared I brought my arm around in an uppercut, catching it under the jaw; flipping it through the air before it fell on the ground and lay still. The owner came running up seconds later slightly out of breath.

“You killed my dog!”

“It tried to attack my client. And it is not dead, I only knocked him out for a bit. He will wake up with a headache and maybe a bit tongue. Keep a better leash on him next time or I really will kill him. Now get out of here.”

Even as the dog was beginning to shake itself awake with a whimper I was reaching into my duffle bag. I twirled, pulling the sword out of its scabbard in one smooth motion while dropping the bag at my feet, catching the blade Liz had tried to thrust into Asala’s throat on the broad face.

“Don’t do this Liz. Just put it away and walk.”

“But she’s one of those cursed summoner freaks! I saw her summon a Gorla when that dog leapt at her! I know it was her! I’m not blind!”

“Your right. She is a summoner, but she’s as cursed as you or me. She is under my protection right now and I really don’t want to kill you over this. I truly would like to be friends, but if you are really that narrow minded then I don’t need a friend like you. She didn’t ask for this power just like we didn’t ask to be born into our families. She can’t control her powers right now either so the summoning was only because she was frightened. I saw her summon the creature as well. But my priority is this girl here, as long as that two headed ape doesn’t attack her I won’t go after it. It’s not that strong to begin with so the police can handle it. If you are truly that concerned then go after it yourself. But I swear to god if you make one more attack against this girl, it is going to be your last.”

She narrowed her eyes at me as if contemplating another attack anyway. I met her gaze with one of my own that said try it and I would have her head in less than ten moves. Finally she pulled her dagger away and shoved it back into the sheath at her belt, spitting at our feet in disgust.

“All freaks like her should be killed. And people like you too who side with them. I don’t want anything to do with the likes of you.”

“Fine. I’m sorry you feel that way, I really was starting to like you. If you decide to come to your senses and quite spouting such poisonous nonsense that you probably overheard from your parents come see me and maybe we can start over. It’s sad that you would rather be content in living with such a petty view instead of trying to get to know her as a person. It is Hunter’s and would be Hunter’s like you that keep such hate alive that really need to be destroyed. The world would be a much better place without you. So I declare this now so there is no mistake, as of this moment I consider you my enemy. If you try to approach me while not under a banner of truce I will attack without hesitation and I will destroy you. You might be good, but I’m better.”

She finally turned and strode away but I didn’t lower my sword until she was out of sight. After sliding my sword back into its scabbard and picking up the bags I put my arm around the girls shoulder and led her away.

“Come on. Lets go get you something to eat. Do you want to go home and eat? It’s not that far, maybe a five minute walk from here. Or do you think you are up to finishing up our little date?”

The girl didn’t answer, simply buried her face in her teddy bear to hide her tears and muffle her wails. It looked like it was up to me to decide. Going home might be the safer choice for now, but on the other hand I couldn’t let this ruin the potential I had to get the girl to open up more. Out here in town and having her interact with people on a limited basis, experiencing all these new things would prove to her that her power wasn’t bad, or that she didn’t have to be afraid of it. The flip side of the potential good continuing to shop would do was the danger I would be putting her in.

So did I want to choose immediate safety with little gain or potentially immediate huge gain with a little danger involved?
111121121122112.title: Take her shopping first

1111211211221121.content:
“Don’t let what just happened get to you. It wasn’t your fault, both you and I know that. There are always going to be people that think like that but that doesn’t mean they are right. So don’t let this ruin our day together. Come on, let’s get something to eat and finish up our shopping. I mean isn’t that like what little girls are all about? Shopping and talking about boys? That seems to be what my classmates are all about anyway. If you want I can be your girl friend, though don’t ask me to wear a dress.”

Nothing. Not a hint of a smile or any sign she had heard me. It seemed she had retreated back into herself like when we had first met. All the hard work I had put into pulling her out of her own misery gone in an instant of bad luck and timing. It would be twice as hard to pull her out of her dark thoughts. And until then her grief would feed into the instability of her power, making another outburst likely.

As I headed off towards The Pipe, a thought struck me and I smiled thinly to myself. It was a bit of a gamble but it might work to pull her back into the here and now with little risk. Revealing my own special ability right now wouldn’t do anything except maybe push her farther away or even scare her. She wasn’t open to what I could do at the moment. But just maybe she would be open to Ginger in her current state.

So after entering the diner and eating I hurried through buying the rest of the stuff on the shopping list. I kept trying to pull her into conversations but she continued to remain withdrawn. Her body doing things like walking and eating automatically. It had been the worst at The Pipe, I had ended up feeding her by hand because she seemed to lack even the will to do it herself. But as long as I put a hand on her back, or around her shoulder, her legs would start walking when I gave her a push.

We crossed over into one of the many residential districts outside of town. Even though going to Ginger’s was in the opposite direction of my house and we had to go through a seedier section of the city, I still thought it would be worth it. Asala’s hand rose up as if on its own to grab my hand. It was only a small concession to the doll like state she had been in until now, but it was enough. Enough to let me know she at least knew what was going on around her, even if she didn’t want to be a part of it right now.

“I’m taking you to see an acquaintance of mine. I really can’t call her a friend, more like an unusual ally. She might seem a bit strange to you at first but there is nothing to be afraid of. Get as afraid or angry or sad as you want in here, your power won’t accidentally summon a monster no matter what happens. You see she has a…I guess you would call it an ability like you and other special class magic users like you have. Though technically she has no magic.”

“She’s what’s called a Void. A person born without a drop of magic in her system. But her ability creates a field around her that nullifies all other magic out. People think she is cursed just like you, afraid that if they get too close she will suck all their magic away and make them Void’s as well. Its rubbish of course, but people like to believe what ever makes them feel better. The only reason she is so blatant about her ability and doesn’t hide it like most others would is because she has connections and influence. She can afford to stick up her nose at everybody like that.”

“You are now probably wondering why my mother didn’t leave you with her instead of me. Or why you can’t stick close to her if she can nullify your power. Well for one, she’s not a fighter. Keeping you safe from threats aside from monsters is another part of my job. For two… well you will just have to see for yourself. Her name is Diedra, but everyone calls her Ginger on account of her hair.”

We came to a large house that was just this side of being called a mansion and I could hear the sounds of a party going on behind the door as e faint smell of Bora weed seeped through the cracks. That wasn’t too unusual, Ginger was always letting loose with one group or another. Before ringing the doorbell I reached into the side of my duffle bag and pulled out two small white pills. Swallowing one quickly I made Asala open her mouth and take the second one.

“Her ability might nullify all magic in the body and from artifacts, but not alchemist products. This will keep you from getting high off the fumes or if you accidentally drink something you aren’t supposed to. Most of her clients and partiers are decent enough people who just wish to remain anonymous but I wouldn’t put it past any of them to slip even a little girl some drugs or alcohol for a laugh. Or for something a little more than that. Just stick close to me and if anyone tries anything funny I will take care of them for you.”

I gave the pills a moment to start breaking down and entering our system before ringing the bell.

A tanned woman with brown eyes and ginger hair answered the door. Standing at about six foot one she was slightly taller than most women. The almost empty bottle in her hand told me she had been drinking, but I knew from experience she wasn’t drunk. Something about her ability kept her from getting drunk or addicted to anything. She looked like anyone else except for the fact that she only had one arm. Her left one had been cut off when she was in a car accident while still a child.

“Riktal! What a pleasant surprise! I haven’t seen you in ages! What are you doing here!”

“I’d like your help for a little bit if I could. Maybe a quiet room with a bit of privacy?”

She draped her arm around my neck and pulled me in close, running her fingers through my hair before kissing me on my nose.

“You finally decide you want a bit of the gingersnap? I don’t mind love, but I’m not so sure about letting the girl watch. Though I guess that would be fun in its own way and my kind of kinky.”

I grinned, pretending to lean in to kiss her before shoving her away.

“Dream on. Even if you weren’t over twice my age, I got a thing for women with two arms. It‘s kind of my fetish.”

She belted out a belly laugh as she beckoned us in.

“I’ll have you one of these days my pretty boy! Follow me, the party is in the living room area, we can get to my study without you having to encounter anyone. I’m sure you would prefer that over subjecting the girl here to their merriment.”

“Thanks. So who is it this time?”

“Oh the usual, a few dirty cops, some dirty politicians and the military.”

“What? Not a few dirty military?”

“Honey, they are all dirty, you know that. At least all the ones with any power are. It’s just that some are dirtier than others.”

Her study was more like a library, with shelves of books lining the walls and comfortable couches and chairs sitting around invitingly. Along one wall was a mini bar which Ginger wasted no time in going to; pouring herself another drink after finishing the one in her hand. As she sat down in a chair I guided Asala to a couch nearby, gently pushing her into the cushions before taking my seat. Ginger nodded her chin as she pointed at the girl.

“Shock?”

“Something like that. She is actually the reason I came to see you. I think you can help me help her.”

“How’s that? I know you love. You’re good with kids. Damn good. I don’t know how you do it but you got a knack for doing what other people can’t when it comes to them.”

“I want you to tell her about Siera. Don’t leave anything out and don’t sugarcoat my part in all of it.”

She narrowed her eyes at me as a hint of sadness crept into her face.

“Wouldn’t you be better suited to telling that story?”

“Maybe if things were different, but in this case I don’t think I’m the best choice. My words might be heard, but they wouldn’t have the same impact. A few things happened today and she witnessed me make an enemy of someone I had wanted to be friends with. That person said some hurtful words to her which made her turn in on herself like this. If I were to tell her the story she would think I was making it up or trying to make her feel better by telling lies.”

She looked at Asala sitting there with those dead eyes of hers and nodded her head.

“All right. I won’t ask any payment for this one. It’s a small favor and I still owe you one.”

She reached down and pulled out a golden locket from under her shirt, fingering it with a faraway look on her face before opening it up to look at the picture inside. That of a fourteen year old girl with the bluest eyes I had ever seen and hair as red as the sunset. A girl who had once been called Sierra. As Ginger closed the locket again and looked at the little girl in front of her I stood up to pour myself a drink. Too bad I wasn’t able to get drunk right now.
1111211211221121.title: Continue in town

11112112112211211.content:
“This all took place about two years ago. Riktal was finally coming out of wallowing in his own pains at losing his sister the year before. We met by chance much longer ago than that though, back when he was only four or five. I had worked with his father on a job, and his father helped me get settled when I moved here. Riktal used to always come over to my place and play with my daughter Siera. They weren’t exactly friends, but at the time both me and his father thought it would do both children good to interact with each other.”

“Years passed and they grew up together, becoming rivals in everything. Who could hold their breath the longest, who could take down the biggest monster the fastest, anything and everything they challenged each other over. Siera was a year younger then Riktal but didn’t let that stop her from pushing him to be a better Hunter. They were much alike and always clashing heads. In their own way they really were friends.”

“After his sister Olia died, Riktal was in a bad way. Angry at everyone and everything. Well angrier then he is now. He blamed his parents, the monsters, but mostly he blamed himself. Siera tried to console him during that year. Even though she wasn’t that good at it and the two of them were always at odds, that was just the kind of girl she was. I don’t know how she turned out that way since lord knows I was never the best mother. I really wasn’t mother material to begin with.”

“He would attack her. Both verbally and with his fists. His sorrow and pain blinded him to the world. He ended up hurting her a few times too. He had always been better at combat then she was. But always she kept going back and trying to help him. Then one day, maybe six months after his sister died, he found out that she was a monster summoner. Normally she was able to keep her ability locked down and under control. But on that one particular day she slipped and called forth a monster that attacked him.”

“He killed it of course. But then he really went after Siera. Before it had just been to try and hurt her. But this time he tried to kill her. He threw everything he had at her and she barely escaped with her life. Coming home bruised, battered, and broken. She told me how he had said all people like her should die. They were a blight on the land that created more work for real Hunter’s. That they didn’t deserve to live. That night had been the first time in a very long time that I remember her crying on my shoulder. She kept asking if it was true, and why was she alive. His words and his actions had hurt her deeply.”

“About a month later, we got word that Riktal was in trouble. In his anger he had gone out alone into the wilds to hunt monsters. But he had bitten off more than he could chew, getting into a fight with a giant that ended with him being trapped under a pile of rubble with almost no magic left. With limited oxygen he used the last bit of his magic to cast out a communication spell. He had intended to contact someone in his family but they were all too far away. His spell latched on to me instead.”

“When Siera overheard him pleading with me to send help she went to his aid. Even though he was still so angry at both of us he had asked for help. His desire to live made him stamp down his rage. And Siera, bless her soul, despite what he had done and said to her went to help him without hesitation. She used a summoned beast to track him down and then a tamed giant to lift the rocks and free him.”

“When he had asked why, she had said because he had needed help. That even though he had tried to kill her she couldn’t wash her hands of him. They had known each other too long and been rivals even longer. That it wouldn’t feel satisfying to her if he were to die without her beating him at something. From that day on his outlook on monster summoners changed. He began coming back over and playing with her again. Resuming their rivalry. He came to realize she was just another person. One with a special power perhaps, but a person just like him. She helped him end his grieving for his sister.”

“Then about six months after that incident the two of them were tracking in the woods and hunting low level monsters. Learning how to work together, to mesh her summoner skills with his Hunter skills. To become faster, stronger, smarter. They were attacked by another giant. They fought it off, but Siera was badly injured. She had taken a swing of the giant’s club full in the stomach. Riktal carried her back to town as fast as he could run, but by the time the Priests were able to put their hands on her it was too late.”

“I got to the hospital in time to witness her last few minutes alive and hear her last few words. She told Riktal the real reason she had saved him was because she thought of him as family. That she had always wanted a brother like him. That she had been really happy when they were together. That was when I told them both the truth.”

“They really were family. Siera was his half sister. Me and Riktal’s father had had a small fling and she was the product of that. His mother didn’t know though and no one ever told her. That was the real reason I had moved to this town. And the real reason me and his father had them play together. So they could get to know their family even if they never learned the truth.”

“She had whispered that she had already known. She had figured it out a long time ago. Then Riktal challenged her to a game of rock-paper-scissors. She had never won at that game with him once but she had smiled and accepted anyway. She threw rock and he threw scissors. She grinned and said she had finally won before she closed her eyes and stopped breathing.”

“Almost exactly one year after his sister had died he lost another one. I thought he would go back into his little world of pain but he didn’t. He said he couldn’t. He had to become the greatest Hunter of all time. He had to live up to the expectation of two little sisters so he didn’t have time to wallow in self pity. And every day since then he has grown stronger and stronger. He sees everyone with special abilities as people, not blindly parroting what others have said.”

I downed another shot of whiskey before turning to look at Asala for the first time since Ginger started the story.

“She always threw rock first. She never realized that. She had a set order every time. Rock, scissors, rock, paper, paper, scissors. That’s why I always won.”

Walking over I knelt in front of the little girl who’s eyes had come back into focus as she watched me intently.

“Yes it’s true. I was just like Liz at one point. I thought the same way. But I was wrong. A monster summoner just like you taught me that. A summoner who was also my half sister. If things had worked out differently I was planning on telling you this story another time. When you were more ready to hear it. But you were so far gone inside your own head after what happened you would never have believed a word I said. By the time you were ready to hear this story from me you would have been on your way again with your new teacher. And I wanted you to hear that story. To prove to you that people change. That you can make a difference as a summoner. That you are not some evil disease. Do you believe me?”

A slow shake of the head up and down as her eyes began to water up.

“Do you feel a bit better now?”

Yes.

“Do you still believe you are some sort of monster that doesn’t deserve to live like Liz said?”

A slow shake back and forth. No.

“That’s good. It’s ok to grieve for the loss of your family. No one is telling you that you can’t do that. You need to do that. Don’t hold it all inside, it’s not healthy. I know that first hand. Do you want to go home now?”

Yes.

“Ok then when we get home I will introduce you to a friend of mine you might like. He has the special power of being able to hide your tears and the sounds of your crying for anyone looking at you. All they will see is your pretty face and nothing else. Would you like that?”

Another nod of the head.

“Mr. Snuggles?”

I looked over at Ginger and grinned.

“Who else?”

“You still have that old thing?”

“Always and forever. He’s just as precious to me as that locket is to you, and for the same reason.”

She reached up and touched the locket absently, nodding her head in understanding.

“Tell that friend of yours who put the magic on this locket that it still works fine. My ability hasn’t corroded it in all this time.”

“I’m sure he knows, but I will tell him anyway. He will appreciate it. Take care Ginger.”

“Later Riktal love. Perhaps next time we could bang a few headboards together and make another Siera.”

“One of them was enough for me thanks.”

I hitched the duffel back onto my back as it slipped down my shoulder a bit before tightening my grip on the three shopping bags. Ginger opened the front door for us, letting us exit into the evening. Asala reached up and held my hand as we began the walk back to my house, smiling happily.

***********

Often seeming to contradict themselves, humans truly are a fascinating species. So tell me, did you learn something about yourself through all of this? Did the choices you made speak about who you are? Were you able to find some nugget of truth to your own personal dilemma’s through guiding Riktal’s actions? Do you regret the choices you made? Do you wonder what fate might have befallen young Riktal if you had chosen differently?

You will come again. Of this I am certain. For as master of all the possibilities I see this future in nearly all of them. I look forward to meeting you again, and in bestowing upon you the power of choice. A power you have always held, even if it is only within your own life.
11112112112211211.title: Listen to the story

1111211211221122.content:
“You know what Asala? I think we should just head back to the house. You had a bit of a fright and I don’t want to push you too far. We have a few nice things for you to wear tomorrow, we can finish this all up later. I’ll make some grilled ham and cheese sandwiches with tomato soup and tonight you can wear one of my oversized shirts as a nightgown. Then I’ll introduce you to an old friend of mine.”

She didn’t answer, not even with a small nod of her head. It seemed she had pulled back into herself, returning to the lifeless doll I had first seen walking in the door back at school. I clamped down on my bit of anger at this turn of events. All the work I had put into getting her to open up had been wasted. Now I was afraid it would be twice as hard to get her to return from the dark place she was in.

A place where she feared and maybe even hated not only her power but herself. Where she was all alone and afraid to trust anyone. It was a destructive spiral that in the end would only make her power go out of control more often as her emotions worsened. There was a grieving process she needed to go through that she just wasn’t letting herself do. For normal people with little magic they could afford to wallow in their own misery for much longer, but not people like her who’s ability was affected by her emotions and mood.

I tried to pull her into some conversation as we walked, keeping things light and a bit comedic but she continued to stay in that little shell of hers, clutching her bear tightly. I briefly toyed with the idea of letting her in on my secret and revealing my own special power but decided against it. In this state she wouldn’t be able to appreciate or indeed understand. It could scare her into using her summoning magic again which would only create another loop on her personal downward spiral.

When we got home I set the few bags down and went to the kitchen to make the meal. When I turned around I found Asala hadn’t followed me. Running back through the house to make sure she was safe I saw her still standing in the entranceway staring off into space. With a gently hand on her back I pushed her towards the kitchen and she walked.

It seemed she had lost the will to do anything for herself while hiding inside her mind. Her body simply moving automatically to outside stimulus using muscle memory. I wondered if this is the state she was in when whoever it was had first found her. If so, it might not be such a wonder that people had ended up disregarding her and simply dragging her around.

I sat her down at the kitchen table and watched while cooking as she stared off at nothing in that eerie solitude of hers. Rarely blinking and almost looking like a statue save for the small movement of her chest. Setting the plate and bowl in front of her I gently told her to eat. When she didn’t respond I ripped the sandwiches into smaller pieces and fed them to her by hand. Pressing my fingers on the hinges of her jaw to make her mouth open on its own. Once the food was in her mouth her body took over and began to chew, knowing it needed sustenance even if her brain did not.

In this way I got her to eat and drink, dipping the ham and cheese into the soup to get some of that down her throat as well. When she was done she continued to sit staring straight ahead while I cleaned up. I let out a small sigh of sorrow before sitting down next tot her again.

“Listen sweetie, it wasn’t your fault. I know you don’t believe me right now. Heck you might not even hear me at the moment. But if you do, know that I know you didn’t mean to summon that monster. And no matter what you might think, it isn’t your fault Liz thinks the way she does. Nor is it your fault that I made her into my enemy. Her decision to attack you was because of her beliefs not yours. My decision to stop her was because of my beliefs, not yours. I was given the duty to protect you and that is what I am going to do, even if it cost me everything, including my life. Even if it wasn’t my job, I would protect you anyways because you deserve to be protected. Monster summoner or not.”

Still not a flicker of anything crossed her features. Just that same lifeless silence. With another sigh I pulled back her chair and got her on her feet again, with a gentle hand on her back I led her upstairs and into the bathroom. Treating her just like a doll I undressed her and got her bathed up. Never once did she resist or seem to know what was going on. Her body just moving like a limp rag. Once she was clean I toweled her off and led her to my room, slipping one of my old shirts over her head before ushering her into bed. The only small concession I got that made me know she still had any idea what was going on around her was the way she grabbed for her stuffed animal on her own without me having to push it onto her.

I dug through my closet until I finally found what I was looking for, an old blue stuffed rabbit missing an eye and one ear sewn back on badly. Sitting on side of the bed looking down on the girl I showed her the rabbit before putting it in my lap and looking down on it. Gently squeezing it with both hands as the memories came back.

“This is Mr. Snuggles. He used to belong to my sister. My little sister. She’s not here anymore, she died just like your parents. I don’t have much left to remember her by, not physically anyway.”

I touched my head and my chest.

“Most of what I have left is in here and here. She was a bit of a crybaby but she never liked having people see her cry. She would come to me and cry sometimes but mostly she tried to hold it all in. So I cast a magic spell on Mr. Snuggles here to make it impossible for anyone to see or hear her bawling her eyes out when she held it.”

“He helped her win many battles against the scary things that went bump in the night. Fighting valiantly just like a true Hunter until he slew the monsters one by one. As you can see he didn’t come out of it unscathed. But whenever my sister held him she said she felt braver. She had me to chase away the bad dreams for her, so she never needed me to place any extra spells on Mr. Snuggles. But I think you need that extra bit of magic. I doubt you really trust me much right now, or anyone for that matter. Mr. Snuggles has been helping little girls sleep easy at night for a very, very, long time. He’s been retired for about three years now, but he is always ready to return to active service.”

I stared at the rabbit, sending out my magic until it was surrounded with a purple glow anyone could see.

“He who guards the gate between reality and dreams. Chase away those of dark and evil intent. Monsters of figment and fancy, of misfortune and woe. Create for they who hold this mighty solder a peaceful resting experience. Om nurra Kom su. Doroku ma ka fli ni-ma sa su palakama tor!”

I let the magic drop before setting the rabbit down next to the little girl.

“There. Now if you hold him, not only will no one see or hear you cry, but he will chase away bad dreams as well. He is yours for now if you want him.”

She didn’t move. Just stared blankly at the rabbit sitting inches from her face looking at her with it’s one eye. I gave her arm a small squeeze as I stood up.

“Get some sleep honey. I’m going to be right back. I just need to get cleaned up real quick and bring your things up here with us so you have something to wear tomorrow. I’m going to be right next to you all night long in case you need anything.”

I turned on the bedside lamp, tuning the magical bulb down to a low setting so she wouldn’t be left completely in the dark as I turned off the overhead light. Walking out the door I hurried to the bathroom, giving myself a quick shower and slipping on my bed clothes before grabbing the shopping bags from downstairs.

When I snuck back into the room to make up a bed on the floor I saw Asala fast asleep, her breathing evened out in a slumber of peace. She was clutching the teddy bear in one hand and the rabbit in the other. Dried tear marks making streaks on the side of her face. With a smile I slipped under the covers with her.

The whole magical spells thing was nonsense of course. There wasn’t really any magic that could chase away bad dreams. Nor had their been any real magic to mask the fact that her crying had turned invisible. I had simply made up a few words and let my magic surround the animal for a bit without doing anything with it. But my little lies had been effective both then and now to ease the minds of scared little girls.

As I settled down to sleep I saw a small smile creep onto Asala’s face as she snuggled closer to me, resting her head against my chest. Gently I wrapped my arms around her so as not to wake her up. Whispering softly into her hair as I closed my eyes.

“Good night sweetie. We’ll get you fixed up eventually, don’t you worry.”

*************

Oh what a tangled web we weave. Is that not what you humans say? Plots within plots and divergent outcomes based on the choices you make. Would he have ever found out Liz had such hatred for summoners if he had chosen different choices? Would Liz have acted the same way if she had come to know more about young Riktal or gotten to know Asala before seeing her use her power?

What if, maybe, could have, should have, would have. All of these are choices. Possibilities that lived and died before their name was even uttered. All things are possible until action is taken, once the course is set in motion, the other infinite number of possibilities for that particular second are gone forever. It is from this truth that regret is born. But it is also from this truth that experiences are made.

We must part now mortal, but I will see you again. I know this as truth, for I have seen the possibilities.
1111211211221122.title: Take her home

choices: Offer to split profit from crystal
11112112112212.content:
I stared at my mother for a while, then turned my gaze on the little girl who still sat as still as a stone, giving no indication she even heard anything we said. Finally I shook my head as I returned my gaze to my mother’s.

“Tell Pelei to go easy on her and to curb his natural tendencies. He most likely won’t ignite her power if he does. Sorry mother but I’m not doing it. You didn’t want me to be an official Hunter so you don’t get to decide you need me as one when it is convenient to you.”

I stood up, giving my mother and the little girl a small bow.

“I’m sorry Asala, it’s nothing against you, but if someone doesn’t curb my mother’s tendencies to use people however she wants whenever she needs something she will keep on doing it. She needs to learn that throwing the word family around like that won’t get her everything. There are consequences to every action. She taught me that. This is simply the consequence of her denying me the ability to become a Hunter myself.”

“Good day mother, I’ll see you whenever you get back. By the way, sis sends her love. I need to get back to class.”

I picked up my pack and left the room, letting the door creek shut behind me. I sensed the presence around the corner ahead of me so stopped when I came to the turn. I didn’t look over at the principal, just stared straight down the hall.

“Do you have a problem with me?”

“No. I think you were right to do what you did. Miranda never did think much about using others when it suited her needs. Didn’t have a problem with hiding behind her family name when it suited her either. I think this will do her good. Remind her that things don’t always go the way she wants them to if she bats her eyes and asks nicely.”

“Out of curiosity, do you always take to eavesdropping on private conversations?”

“I do when it’s on my school grounds and one of the Hunter caliber people in question has a short temper. That calls the safety of my student’s into question so I need to know if I have to protect them.”

I glanced over at the old woman as she ran her hands over the wheels on her chair. I saw the handle of a gun peeking up along the back of the wheelchair even as she smiled wistfully.

“Though I do have to wonder just how safe that little girl will be. I know Pelei too. Even if you tell him to put a leash on his tendencies, he’s going to forget himself and do it anyway. He could very well traumatize that little girl further.”

“Then in the end that is just another part of the consequence my mother will have to live with. If she even cares enough about it. Good day principal.”

I only managed to take two more steps before she stopped me.

“Riktal, one last question. Why didn’t you get angry at your mother? I’ve read your file so I know that isn’t like you. I was expecting some big blow up.”

I looked at her over my right shoulder, a half smile curving up the left side of my mouth.

“Because I already screwed up the way I dealt with one relationship today. I don’t need another woman angry at me for my own thoughtless actions.”

“Sounds like you made a friend.”

“I wonder about that. If I did, I think I lost them just as quickly.”

“Take the advice of an old woman boy. Friendships, especially those between Hunter’s, aren’t so easily lost. We all have our quirks and outlooks on life. Our views clash and we fight over the smallest things. But rarely is it impossible to mend those rifts. Our jobs are dangerous and we have a high mortality rate the first few years we are learning the ropes in the real world. That’s why we make friends fast and try so hard to feel normal. Because every day can be our last. We don’t want to regret having not tried to experience some of what the rest of the world has.”

She turned her chair away and wheeled herself off as I continued down the corridor. She was right, Hunter’s came in all shapes, sizes, and backgrounds. We weren’t carbon copies of each other and it was human nature to want to be right. It was that desire to be right that created conflicts most of the time. This small conflict between me and Liz had come about because of different backgrounds. Even though we were similar in many ways, we had been raised differently. So our mindsets on some things would obviously be different as well.

It had all started with the crystal. I needed to solve it with the crystal as well. That seemed logical. She wouldn’t accept it if I simply gave it to her. And she wouldn’t thank me if I forced it on her. She was too proud for me to do something like that to her. I might not know her all that well but I knew that much about her already. I realized I really wanted to be her friend. That right now I needed someone to talk to that understood me. I was getting tired of going home to an empty house and doing everything alone. She was the first person I could stand being around that I didn’t think was stupid or useless in some way.

Quietly I reentered the classroom, pretending not to notice the stares that were calculating how best to approach me. Trying to figure out my weaknesses so they could get close to me and be associated with my family name. New Hunter’s could get a leg up if an old family gave them some good connections to brokers, weapon merchants, and clients. Get them better jobs simply because they knew me.

When the bell rang signaling the end of school they got up to converge on me, but I was already moving before I could get trapped by them. Before Liz had a chance to escape from my sight. I slapped the crystal down on the desk in front of her looking directly into her eyes.

“I was thoughtless and I did you a disservice as a fellow Hunter. Even if you don’t have a license, you still have the skills. I would like that this small misunderstanding not come between us. I’m not very good at this whole friendship thing or dealing with people in general. But this crystal started this whole mess, so let us end it with this stone as well.”
11112112112212.title: Decline job

111121121122121.content:
Sending some magic down into my right hand I balled it into a fist before slamming it down onto the crystal. The stone shattered into bit’s, small sparks shooting out of the cloudy fragments before they broke up and disappeared into oblivion. I looked back up after finish my task, ignoring the gasps of surprise and the small cries of dismay behind me. Liz’s face was impassive and unreadable as I kept mine the same.

“I’d rather break this crystal than break this friendship we have started between us. Hunter’s have to choose who to let close to them carefully. People like me and you don’t have the luxury of having many friends or those we can trust. But I would like to count you as one of those people.”

Her eye’s narrowed a bit as she studied me. I could almost hear the crickets chirping as the kids behind me held their breath. Acting like our conversation was some TV drama they were watching. I could only imagine the girls holding their hands together close to their chest and the boys leaning forward in anticipation. But I didn’t bother to look, the answer of the woman in front of me was what was important right now.

Without warning her right fist came around and smashed into my jaw. I took the blow, not even bothering to avoid or block it. I didn’t even use magic to soften it since she hadn’t used any either.

“Now will you forgive me?”

“Yes.”

I heard shrieks go up from the girls and even a few whistles from the boys as if I had just confessed to her and she had accepted my feelings. I simply shook my head slightly while Liz grinned, understanding the thoughts that were running through my head.

We gathered our things and left the room. Stopping only briefly at her locker before walking out the front doors together. As we turned down the street she finally spoke up, breaking our comfortable silence.

“You didn’t have to break it you know. I was actually planning on apologizing to you as well but you beat me too it. I realized you hadn’t meant anything harmful by what you did after I had time to think. You might not be able to tell but I’m not all that great at friendships and personal relations either.”

“Really? It seemed like you were friends with everybody in there. You got along so well I was jealous.”

“Har. Har. Make fun of me if you will but I really would like to try to make this work if possible. I want to try to be a better friend this time then I was to someone else I once knew. Not make the same kinds of mistakes and have the same regrets. So bear with me ok?”

“As long as you bear with me. We can learn how to do this together.”

I held up my fist, looking over at her with a grin. She returned the grin and made a fist of her own, lightly tapping it against mine.

“Deal.”

We continued to walk towards town in a companionable silence for a bit before I spoke up again.

“So… I really didn’t have to destroy it?”

“Nope. You wasted a good heart crystal for nothing.”

“The only other thing I could think of was to split the profit with you but I wasn’t sure it would have worked. I went with the route I thought would have the highest probability of success.”

“I would have preferred the money.”

“I’ll remember that for the next time I do something stupid that gets you mad at me.”

“I’m not cheap just so you know, I won’t settle for anything less than five thousand Reul.”

“Ouch. I’ll try not to make you angry often then. My bank account couldn’t take too many hits like that.”

She grinned a bit evilly at me.

“I’d let you run up a tab. With a small interest fee of twenty five percent a day of course.”

“You’re not a Hunter, you’re a crook!”

“I’m a poor girl saving up for her future.”

“Girl my backside. Such tactics are monstrous.”

“Careful, you are coming close to making me mad at you again.”

We both began laughing as we came into town. She turned left, waving farewell as I continued straight. I returned her wave still grinning like a fool. It seemed the principal was right, friendships weren’t so easily broken. You just had to work at them like everything else. I had a feeling school wouldn’t be so bad after all.

*************

Well, that was fun wasn’t it? Our young hero here went from being all sulky and angry at the start of the day to being a bit of a romantic by the end of it. Are you satisfied with the choices you made? The direction you took Riktal’s life in? Did you take into consideration his personality in your decision making? Or did you simply decide how you would have handled the situation if you had been in his shoes? Did things turn out like you thought they would? Or was his actions a surprise to you? Would you have handled things differently or the exact same way?

It’s easy to look back and answer some of these questions. To judge what has been done and gone before. But it is not so easy to do so when the time for choice and action is upon you. You know not what the future holds until you take that leap of faith and make a choice. I hope this chance to become a god and decide someone else’s fate has taught you something. Perhaps about yourself, or about the way you view the world you live in. Until next time when our paths cross again. And I assure you, they will again cross, I see it in your future.
111121121122121.title: Destroy crystal

choices: Wander around town for a bit
111121121122122.content:
“I’ve got a friend who will give me top dollar for this stone. How about I introduce you to him and we split the profit seventy- thirty with you getting the larger half for doing most of the work.”

Her eyes narrowed even as I could feel the rest of the class watching us, listening to everything like we were some TV drama. I ignored them, they weren’t important. Right now Liz and her answer was important.

“Eighty-twenty and I will call us square. It was partially my fault too for being so quick to judge. I’m not much of a people person either. But if your offering, I won’t pass up free money.”

“Deal. You got time now?”

“Sure.”

As the two of us headed for the door one brave stupid soul stepped forward.

“Hey… Mind if I tag along too?”

I looked at the boy with a glare that could have made paper instantly combust. He withered into himself, taking a step back. I spun on my heel then without another word, leaving him to kick himself for his own assumptions that I was even interested in him at all.

“Aren’t we just two peas in a pod. I knew you hadn’t meant to snub me like that after thinking it over for a bit. I just sort of acted without thinking as well. I was going to try to patch things up with you after school but you beat me to it.”

“So I didn’t have to offer you so much of the profits?”

“Nope. But I won’t allow you to take it back now.”

“A small price to pay for my own folly.”

As we left the school with kids turning to stare at us she punched me lightly in my arm with a backhand swing.

“Listen. It’s been a while since I had a friend as well. The last one I could call that moved away a few months ago before I started school here. She wasn’t old blood like we are, she was first generation. I learned to loosen up a bit because of her. But that doesn’t mean I’m that much better at this whole friend thing either. To be honest, I don’t think I was that good of a friend to her. Don’t know why she liked me truth to tell. That’s why I want to be a better friend this time around then I was last time. I’m sure I’ll make some more mistakes and we will have falling outs again. So just bear with me ok?”

“As long as you bear with me. I feel like a fish out of water right now if we are being honest. The closest thing I had to a friend before now was my cousin but he is family so it was a bit different. I haven’t seen him in a few years either.”

We continued to talk about small stuff, mostly things about ourselves and our families as we got to know each other a little better. Neither one of us really wanted to destroy this tenuous relationship we had going on. There was no romance involved, I couldn’t feel any kind of spark of that nature either inside myself or in her words and actions. But I was glad of that fact. I didn’t want there to be any romance between us. I wasn’t ready for something like that.

I opened the door to the Pasta Palace for Liz before entering behind her. A quick look around showed that Nerval wasn’t sitting at his usual booth eating his usual meal. I beckoned the waitress he had a secret crush on over to me with a wave of the hand.

“Nerval’s not here?”

“He was, but he left early for a customer.”

“Ah. Thanks Trinity.”

“Don’t mention it hon.”

I led Liz back outside and right next door into Nerval’s shop “The Broken Seal.” Inside was brightly lit with an array of weapons showcased under glass windows. Everything from your basic sword and shields, to specialty weapons people had ordered that were being displayed to show off Nerval’s skills as a craftsman until the owner came to pick it up. Nerval came out the back pulling off a special glove with dozens of small screwdrivers and other tools attached to the fingers when the bell on the door jingled.

“Hey Riktal! How you doing! Aint I the lucky one? First get a visit from your mother a few minutes ago and now you! Must be my day for Zelkov’s!”

“My mother was here? What she want?”

“Now you know I can’t tell you that. Confidentiality and all that. You understand. Even if you are her son.”

“Yeah sorry, stupid question. Nerval, this is Liz Hawthrope. Liz this is Nerval. He might look like a crook but he is mostly honest.”

“I only cheat those that deserve to be cheated. But it’s against my policy to cheat a pretty lady so you don’t have anything to fear. So Hawthrope huh? As in Wilson Hawthrope?”

“My brother.”

“Heard good things about him. Glad to meet you. If you’ve gotten into Riktal’s good graces and he is introducing us then you’re ok in my book. I think you are the first person he has introduced me too since I’ve known him. So what can I do for you today?”

I held out the heart crystal which he took in his meaty hand.

“Like to get that appraised if we could.”

He nodded his head as he pulled out a three stage magnifying monocle from a drawer behind the desk. While he went about inspecting every inch of it Liz began looking around the store. I saw her eyes widening in surprise at some of the fantastic weapon work. I had done the same thing the first time I had seen the store. Nerval was a true master of his art. Able to make weapons other smiths would claim was impossible to accomplish.

She stopped in front of a full suit of armor, her eyes going dreamy over it. Enamored even. Nerval always kept one of those suits in the window, it was one of his best sellers. It was spelled so it fit on the wrist as a bracelet until it was needed. Then it could be activated and equipped in just a few seconds. With extra spells of protection and resistance against temperatures, any Hunter would love to get their hands on one. But the fifteen thousand Reul price tag was a bit steep for a beginning Hunter to afford.

“You like the suit ma’am?”

“Yeah my brother has one like it and he says it’s great. My parent’s won’t buy me one, said I have to make the money on my own. But they won’t let me work as a Hunter, so owning one is a bit out of my reach at the moment.”

“Trade you that suit for this stone.”

“It’s worth that much?”

“No, it’s only worth ten thousand. But as an incentive to make you come back with more of your business I’m willing to trade. Besides, Riktal here has done me a few good turns before and I haven’t had much chance to pay him back. I’ll pass along some of that to one of his friends.”

“I’m tempted but we decided to split the profit on that crystal so I’d only have eight thousand technically. That’s almost half the price.”

“You can have my two thousand if you want. I really don’t mind. I don’t need the money anyways.”

She nibbled on her lower lip, looking from the suit of armor to us and then back. Nerval saw her wavering so sweetened the deal a bit to sooth her pride.

“Tell you what, a friend of mine has an Ooze infestation at her house. The Exterminators want three thousand to clear it out but she doesn’t have that kind of money. Take the job for me and I’ll add that three thousand on along with the crystal.”

That seemed to make up her mind as she agreed to the deal almost instantly. Nerval reached under the counter again, pulling out one of the spelled bracelets and handed it to her along with the address of his friend.

“Tell her I sent you and you shouldn’t have any problems.”

She thanked him and went out the door, presumably heading directly to the address to take care of the job at once. Once she was gone I looked at the shopkeeper.

“That stone isn’t worth ten thousand is it?”

“Eight and a half tops. But I got a weak spot for pretty girls giving such starry eyes like that.”

“Your old enough to be her father.”

“Age, don’t got nothing to do with it. Besides, what kind of guy do you take me for anyway?”

“An old perverted one who thinks he is twenty years younger than he actually is.”

“Well I am that! You got any other business Riktal?”

“Nope. Mainly came by to introduce you two and sell the stone. I’ll be on my way now. Have a good one Nerval, and try not to chase too many skirts.”

“You too Riktal. And try to chase at least one!”

He belted out a belly laugh as he put his glove back on and headed back into the back room.
111121121122122.title: Offer to split profit from crystal

1111211211221221.content:
I had nothing better to do and I really didn’t feel like going back to that empty house just yet. What would I do if I did anyway? Sit around and read a book? Turn on the television just to have some noise other then my echoing footsteps and breathing as company?

So I walked. I had no destination in mind. I simply slipped my arms into the straps of my bag, hoisting it up onto my back and walked. Some people recognized me either as a Zelkov or at the very least, a Hunter in training. They gave waves and nods in passing or sometimes even a cheery hello which I returned before moving on. As I wandered through town I let my mind think what it would as I watched the people.

I saw a pair of little boys in a toy store swinging foam swords and claws at each other, playing Hunter’s and Monster’s. A woman was talking on a communication spell, her soldier’s uniform still crisp and pressed with that “just got it” look. A little girl was pointing excitedly at something in a bakery window and her mother was shaking her head no.

All of these people from varying walks of life relied on Hunter’s to let them keep this peaceful lifestyle. Even though they had magic just like everyone else, it was either too weak or for one reason or another they had decided not to train it effectively. We were champions of the people, heroes. With the abilities to protect them from big scary monsters that the regular military couldn’t handle. Strip away titles, fame, fortune, and lineage, that was what we were at the core. A different kind of soldier who was part of this society and yet apart from it. Trusted almost instantly simply because we were what we were, Hunter’s.

Even if we were to wear normal clothes like everyone else, they always seemed to just know who and what we were. We couldn’t hide the fact that we were monster slayers anymore than you could deny that the sun came up in the morning. Perhaps it was just how we walked, how we held ourselves. Or perhaps it was just some strange magic that fingered us as different that we didn’t recognize. Whatever the case, it made our job of protecting the people that much easier.

As I turned a corner I saw a little boy crying in front of a convenience store. A police officer was trying to calm him down but only seemed to be making the situation worse. I wasn’t sure what made me gravitate towards the situation, this was the cops job after all. But before I knew it I was whispering in the officers ear that I would take care of the boy. He gave me a quick nod as I knelt on one knee in front of the child.

“Hey waterworks. If you keep crying I might mistake you for a Warpa monster. You want to tell me what’s wrong?”

The boy cracked open red rimmed eyes, lowering his hands as he did so. He couldn’t be more than five or six years old by the looks of him. He took one look at me before sniffing a bit, telling me he had lost his mother between sobs in his little voice. I felt the officers presence fade as he went to find the boys mother, leaving me alone with the child.

“What’s your name?”

“Timmy.”

“Well Timmy, do you know who and what I am?”

He nodded his head as he wiped his the snot from his nose onto his arm.

“Hunter.”

“That’s right. And do you know what my specialty is?”

“Killing bad things.”

“Well that’s true, but one of my real specialties is monster tracking. I’ve got a special nose for it you see. I can sniff out monsters in any form. So how about I track down your mother huh?”

“Momma’s not a monster.”

“I wouldn’t be too sure about that. When my momma get’s all angry she makes this really mean monster like face with her nose all scrunched up and showing all these teeth. She snorts and growls and smoke comes out of her ears and nose. If that’s not a monster I don’t know what is.”

He giggled a bit while rubbing his eyes and sniffing again.

“Momma does that too.”

“See, what did I tell you. She’s a momma monster. So what do you say? Want me to track her down for you?”

The boy nodded his head as I grinned at him.

“Tell my Timmy, are you afraid of heights?”

“Nu-uh. I love them.”

“Well that’s good then.”

As I stood up I grabbed him around the waist and lifted him up, seating him on my shoulders.

“Because any good tracker needs a good lookout. And any good lookout needs to have a high vantage point from which to look. It’s just common scouting skill. You mind being my lookout?”

He giggled again before saying he didn’t mind. So off we went in search of his mother. I didn’t take him far of course, I was only occupying him until his mother came back. If she was already looking for him it wouldn’t do to have him wondering around. When I asked him where he lived he didn’t know. Only saying he lived on a street with lots of houses, not very useful information. I put my hand up against my brow as I looked around dramatically.

“I think I see a momma monster!”

As I felt the boy looking around over my head, I walked over to the blue postbox, knocking on it with a knuckle.

“Sorry to bother you ma’am, but are you this boys momma monster?”

I cocked my head to the side as the boy laughed at my antics. I nodded my head as if hearing some deep profound words before sighing and turning away.

“Sorry Timmy. She says she isn’t your momma monster.”

“That’s not momma or a monster! That’s a mailbox!”

“What! Why aren’t you doing your job! You are supposed to be my lookout so I don’t make these kinds of mistakes!”

He continued to laugh as I wandered around the store parking lot and surrounding sidewalk. I kept saying I found his momma monster before heading off to have a deep conversation with a telephone pole, or a stop sign, or some other random object. I even had a deep meaningful conversation with a cat.

He was cracking up and had forgotten all about being lost, which was all I had been trying to accomplish. When I saw a woman hurrying towards us out of the corner of my eye I turned to her and the boy pointed excitedly.

“Momma!”

I put the boy back on the ground so he could run to his mother, walking over silently as she hugged him tightly. I got back on my knee in front of the boy as he grinned at me.

“Seems you ended up being a better tracker than me. You found the momma monster before I did. Good job lookout. Now you make sure not to lose her again ok? Make sure to hold her hand tightly so neither one of you get’s lost.”

I was met by a very solemn nod from the child.

“I will. Thank you Mr. Hunter.”

Ruffling the boys head I got to my feet. The woman also thanked me and I made soothing words for a few minutes before turning to head home. In the end, this was what our job was about. Helping people and slaying monsters. Sometimes those monster’s weren’t big scary creatures you could see. Sometimes they were ones you couldn’t see. Monsters called fear, anxiety and sadness. To normal people, those monsters were sometimes the scariest ones of all that they couldn’t vanquish alone.

It was a Hunter’s task to take on the job of making people feel safe by slaying all the bad monsters he found. And sometimes that task was found without even going outside the city.

**************

Well, that was fun wasn’t it? Our young hero here went from being all sulky and angry at the start of the day to being a bit of a romantic by the end of it. Are you satisfied with the choices you made? The direction you took Riktal’s life in? Did you take into consideration his personality in your decision making? Or did you simply decide how you would have handled the situation if you had been in his shoes? Did things turn out like you thought they would? Or was his actions a surprise to you? Would you have handled things differently or the exact same way?

It’s easy to look back and answer some of these questions. To judge what has been done and gone before. But it is not so easy to do so when the time for choice and action is upon you. You know not what the future holds until you take that leap of faith and make a choice. I hope this chance to become a god and decide someone else’s fate has taught you something. Perhaps about yourself, or about the way you view the world you live in. Until next time when our paths cross again. And I assure you, they will again cross, I see it in your future.
1111211211221221.title: Wander around town for a bit

1111211211221222.content:
Going home seemed like a good idea. I really didn’t feel like eating out and there was nothing I really needed to do here in the city anyway. I wasn’t interested in new music or fashion or anything else so I really had no business going places like the mall. I briefly thought about going to the movies but decided against it. There probably wasn’t anything good playing anyways that I hadn’t already seen. So shoving my arms into the straps of the duffel bag I settled it on my back and began the jog home.

It only took about five minutes at an easy sprint to make it to the bridge crossing the river that separated the main part of the city from the more residential area. From there it was a blink of the eye until I was in front of the fence surrounding our property. I opened the gate to our modest ten acres of land and three story house. Personally I saw no reason for ten acres or for three stories. Sure it had been useful to learn tracking and such, but we rarely used half the land.
