As for three stories, it was all wasted when no one was ever home and we rarely had guests that stayed over. Sometimes a few foreign ambassadors or dignitaries but at least five or six rooms had never been used to my knowledge.

Making the quick hand sign to unlock the front door I entered the main hallway, dropping my bag to the floor. My footsteps echoed through the house as I headed for the kitchen, the silence enshrouding me like it always did. I didn’t feel like doing anything fancy for dinner so I just slapped some buttered bread into a skillet along with a few ham slices. While that cooked I grabbed a plate from the cabinet. Within a few moments I had three grilled ham and cheese sandwiches.

I took the plate to the table and sat down. Eating quietly, the silence my table companions just like it usually was. I turned on the TV in the corner just to hear something aside from the empty air. I really didn’t pay attention though to the show that was playing. It was noise, that’s all that mattered. After that it took a few seconds to clean what I dirtied and turn the set off again.

The rest of the evening went by in a bit of a blur. I remembered trying to read a magazine, timing myself on how fast I could put various weapons together, and setting up the magical workout dummies in the back for a level four sparring match. The quiet was depressing just like it always was. Seeming to slowly keep closing in on me no matter what I did. But I was used to it. This was how things normally were. I yelled just to hear some noise, but the roar echoed back mockingly. I sighed a bit before taking a quick shower and heading to my room.

Even though I tried to get to sleep it eluded me. I kept tossing and turning, thinking about that silent little girl my mother had asked me to protect. Thinking about her made me think about Olia. Another little girl I had been unable to protect. With a sigh I slipped out of bed and opened my closet, dragging out an unremarkable tattered box. I shifted through the stuffed animals inside until I found a beat up old blue rabbit missing one eye. With my new companion in hand I got back into bed and closed my eyes while hugging it close to my chest.

This time sleep came quickly.

****************

Well how was your day as god? Did it make you feel powerful? Helpless? Were you rooting for our hero here? Or cursing him for his actions? Did he do what you thought he would do? What you would have done if the situations were reversed? Are you satisfied with the way things turned out? Did this teach you anything about yourself? There are so many questions without answers and answers without questions!

But is that not what life is? One series of question and answers after another? Tinged with regrets and self accusation. Ups and downs and funny twists of fate. Would you make different choices if you were given the opportunity I wonder. In a world of endless possibilities why would you not if you were a god? Until we meet again my dear friend. May you choose your own fate, lest others choose it for you.
1111211211221222.title: Go home and eat

1111211212.content:
I couldn't just wait for a teacher to get to the bottom of this. It could take days if not weeks and there was no guarantee I would get them back. The danger of having those weapons out there with someone untrained in their use wielding them was too great. So I quickly dialed up a communication spell as I moved to a corner for some privacy. Putting it only on audio I raised my hand to my ear to complete the connection.

"Yes what is it darling?"

My mother's voice came in loud and clear as if she was standing right next to me. I also heard someone shouting behind her something about taking care of the girl.

"Just a quick question mother. Do you remember if I packed my Lexington and my Roller Knuckles this morning?"

"That's a silly question. Of course you did. You were cleaning them both at the kitchen table. I remember telling you not to accidentally drop any cleaning oil into your breakfast."

"Ok thanks. I was just making sure."

I was about to hang up when my mother spoke up again quickly.

"Oh and just so you know, I set up another marriage meeting for you next week. I think you will like her."

"Mother--"

"I know, I know. Stop doing that. I don't want to marry someone you chose for me. That's what you are going to say right? But just give her a chance will you? I won't ask you to choose, but you have to at least put yourself out there more and get to know them. How do you know if they are right or not if you don't at least meet them? I won't let you run away from this one. I simply must put my foot down!"

"Fine you know what? Whatever. I'll go. I have more important things to worry about here. I don't have time to stay on the spell arguing with you."

"Ok loves and kisses darling! I'll see you later!"

I disconnected the spell, turning to look at the room at large where all the boys in the class were still putting on their gear. Swiftly I walked into the middle of the room and raised my voice until it echoed back to me from the walls.

"It has come to my attention that two very valuable weapons have been stolen from my bag. Dangerous weapons at that. I have just confirmed that they were indeed stolen and not forgotten at home. To my knowledge thievery of another student's weapons is a very grave and serious offence at this academy. Since a weapon is like an extension of the Hunter."

"Whoever in here stole them from me must be incredibly stupid and foolish. But as I do not want any trouble I will give you amnesty. I will leave my bag out and leave this room. If those weapons were to wind up back in my bag by the time this period is over, all well and good. I will not pursue this matter farther. But that time limit is the extent of my grace."

"If one or both of them are still missing by the time I retrieve my bag then whoever you are had best run. Because I will hunt you down without mercy and I will dismember you piece by piece. If you are lucky I might even let a Priest put you back together. I will not stop until I find you, nor will I listen to pleas. Even if you beg for forgiveness and return the weapons later, I will show no quarter. So decide what is more important to you. Keeping your shiny new toys, or keeping your lives. That is all."

I turned and walked out the door then, not even bothering to look back. The arena master overseeing the boys locker room caught me out in the hall.

"You want me to let you know if anyone returns them and who they are?"

"No. I will uphold my bargain of amnesty. The weapons will either be in there or not when I get back. I can track them down just fine on my own. Besides, if you are not involved then you can plead ignorance and punish me with a guiltless conscience for the damage I do to them."

I entered the combat arena then, leaving the teacher to return to the locker room. Slowly the arena began to fill with my new classmates one by one. I did pay attention to the order of the boys coming in, just in case I had to track down the thief or thieves. I would have a starting point by order of who was last. The boys all looked around suspiciously and some looked a bit jumpy even. I noted it all in the back of my mind but otherwise disregarded them all as unimportant.

"Today will be slightly different. We won't be having sparring practice as normal. Today is a practical application day. You will be split up into five groups of four or five, you will work as a team to take down some monsters. Utilizing what you have learned and the skills you have gathered in hand to hand and weapons combat. These monsters have been deemed a sufficient test of your skills."

"Hawthrope! Zelkov! Since you two are already past this point you will sit out for now."

I inclined my head to the arena master before climbing up into the bleachers around the large rectangular room. Liz was right behind me as a wall rose out of the floor to cut the room in half. Two of the chosen groups entered the rings as the remaining ones waited on the sidelines in excitement. The floor opened again and a Screecher Bird came into view. I shook my head as one of the boys ran yelling headlong at the bird with his sword raised. Just as quickly he was flying through the air to land on his butt.

"I see someone forgot the basics of Screecher's."

"Doesn't everybody forget the basics the first time?"

" I couldn't. I was up against a Gorpal giant my first time. Forget the basics there and you become red jelly."

Liz whistled in appreciation of my feat but didn't say anything else. Simply watching the groups below as they switched off after finally killing their prey. After a moment she spoke again.

"My first time was against a Fabrooze. The thrill went to my head as I blew it up with an explosive potion. It pulled itself together after eating my clothes.

I chuckled while imagining her fighting the thing in her underwear.

"You're thinking something dirty aren't you?"

"Nope they are pristine white."

She backhanded me lightly on the arm before laughing along with me.

"They were blue at the time."

"I'll keep that in mind for the next time I imagine it."

The second group finally killed the three headed snake like creatures they had been pit against, vacating the ring for the last group to enter. This group had to be of a slightly higher caliber then the others because a Sengwen rose up out of the floor to meet them. The silver talon on the six hooves shone evilly under the light as the horse body shivered. The fur melded seamlessly with the human torso as its two arms pumped back and forth in anticipation. The large black eyes in the horse head glittered with its intelligence.

"I hope they don't do something stupid like use magic on it."

"Want to make a bet? A hundred Reul says they do."

"Rules of gambling, never bet against the house, you are sure to lose. You know these people better then me, after all."

She pointed out one of the boys who was flanking the creature on the left as a girl distracted it.

"See that guy? His name is Gregory. He is one of those hot shot hotheads. The ones that always try to one up everyone else. Prove that they are better."

"I'm a hot shot hothead sometimes."

"But you got the skills to back it up at least. He doesn't. He might blast it with magic just to make it transform. With the thought in mind that it would be proof that he was skilled if he took it down and made a name for himself."

"Take it he isn't that skilled?"

"Not even close. You know as well as I a magically fed Sengwin is at least B class. These guys are all barely C class worthy as it is. It would rip through them like candy."

We watched them struggling against the creature, using basic hit and run tactics against it. With the standard meat shield in front, melee on the side and ranged in the back, they would have it down in another two or three minutes at this rate. Suddenly, right before the thing was about to die, the boy she had pointed out earlier brought his hand around like he was lobbing a softball. A blue orb of energy detached from his hand and hurtled towards the creature.

Liz and I were already up and running towards the Sengwen as it absorbed the ball and completely recovered its health while at the same time going through its transformation. A second set of arms popped out right underneath the first set as the human like teeth that filled the mouth turned into blue coated fangs. It grew a set of blue spikes down its spine, making it look even nastier.

We jumped into the arena as the beast gave a roar of challenge and swiped its now clawed hands. The shield bearer was able to get his shield up in time to absorb the blow but was lifted off his feet and flung through the air.

"I'll take out the feet if you get the head!"

"I'll follow you!"

I put on more speed, sending out magic into my arms to augment my strength. External magic might feed it but internal magic was fine. When I got close, I went into a baseball slide, throwing out my arms as I skidded under its stomach while grabbing the legs. I yanked as hard as I could as I sensed Liz jumping into the air to grab the head and pull it towards the ground.

The monster smashed hard even as I let go and got back to my feet in one smooth motion. I pointed at the five people in the group.

"Get out of here now! We will take care of this!"

They ran as I took a position next to Liz, the monster slowly getting to its feet. We had a few precious seconds to plan our counterattack.

"You want to tank or spank?"

"Up to you."
1111211212.title: Handle it yourself

11112112121.content:
'Tank! Arena Master Dual shields please! Double buckler class!'

'Twin sided glaive for me!'

The Sengwen charged and we both rolled out of the way, Liz to the left and me to the right. As it tried halting its forward momentum, its talons hindered it slightly on the cement floor. Just as it was turning around, two racks came up out of the floor close to me. One holding two fan style bucklers and one holding the glaive. I yanked the glaive out and tossed it to Liz, managing to grab the two shields before the monster charged me and destroyed the rack.

Slipping my arms through the straps and making sure they were secure, I charged the beast as it began to turn for another attack. It swiped at me as I spread my legs and lifted my left arm. Taking the blow on the single piece of silver metal. As the second arm swung lower at my unprotected side I activated the shield, causing it to fan out into its more natural circular shape. The second claw bounced off the lower half of the shield as it finished fanning out.

Spinning on my heels as I jumped, I activated the gold buckler on my right arm, smashing it into the side of its head with a magically augmented shield slam. Stepping on its back, I continued to spin around its neck while deactivating the silver shield and slicing open the flesh under its eye with the sharp edge of the now refolded buckler. The small cut healed instantly due to the magic but that wasn't the point. The point was to grab its attention and focus it on me. Until we burned the magic out of it, the thing was basically invincible and invulnerable. We could cut and hurt it, but not permanently. Meanwhile the magic had made it super strong.

My tactic worked. It turned towards me and attacked with fists and swipes, rearing up on its back four legs to strike at me with its front two. I simply absorbed the blows, manipulating the shields as I needed. Folding and unfolding them in rapid succession using them both for defense and offense while at the same time keeping my arms free to move around as I pleased. Which made blocking extremely easy.

While I kept its attention on me, Liz was going to town on its flanks and rear. She swung the glaive like a staff in a figure eight, the blades on either end making quick rapid cuts in the creatures flesh. Sometimes it would kick out at her or strike at her with its razor sharp whip like tail but she spun and dodged easily, almost effortlessly. Sometimes she would jump through the air while turning upside down over the creatures back, stabbing and slicing every chance she could. I had to admit, I was impressed. She was elegant and graceful, turning her weapon of war into a dance of beauty.

In less than three minutes we made it use up all its magic and then our attacks really did damage. It only took another minute before Liz swung the glaive over her head while I did a split. The weapon missed giving me a scalping but sliced deeply into the creatures neck, nearly severing its head. When it reared up in agony I activated both shields, creating a wall in front of me as I thrust upwards, catching it under the armpits of the first two horse legs and shoving it over onto its back. Liz completed the spin of her weapon, planting the end deep into the humanoid chest where the heart was.

The creature broke apart and disappeared, leaving only a belt pouch behind. I picked it up and looked inside while the Arena Master and the class came running up congratulating us. Inside was two gold nuggets, both weighing a few ounces. I handed one to Liz who grinned.

"That's rare. At most you ever get one."

"Be grateful it dropped anything at all, they usually don't. But at least these will fetch us six or seven hundred Reul apiece."

As we both grinned to each other and slipped the bounty into our pockets, the boy named Gregory pointed at us in indignation

"Hey! That's our reward! It was our monster."

Before I could say anything in reply the Arena Master slapped him in the back of the head hard enough to make him stagger.

"Shut your trap you idiot. They earned that. First off, it was your fault it got to that point to begin with. You had it down just fine. One more hit would have killed it. But you had to go play the big shot. Second of all, as soon as it transformed it was no longer a C class monster, it was way above your skill level to handle. The only reason I gave your group that monster was because you all proved you were competent and I had believed none of you would do something so foolish. Obviously I was wrong."

"You should be grateful they both acted so quickly. I might be fast but from my position I wouldn't have made it without at least one of you taking some major damage. I hope you all learned something from watching them. They had excellent teamwork and non-verbal communication skills. Sometimes in a real fight you don't have time to sit and plan the where, how, and why of positioning or attack patterns. You have to make split second decisions and convey as much as you can with every spoken word. Because each spoken word is a wasted breath you might need later."

One of the boys came limping over holding his side. I knew he was the one who had been holding the shield even though he didn't have it with him. He was the only one who had bothered to wear his metal gauntlets, something that was sorely needed to cushion the impacts on the shield face. He stared at me with the wide-eyed wonder of hero worship.

"That was amazing! I mean what you did with those shields I never thought you could attack with them like that! And the way you used the edges like swords! Would you teach me how to do that?"

"How's your wounds?"

"Just a few bruises, nothing major."

"Then why aren't you healing yourself up?"

"Don't got much magic. Actually, hardly got any at all."

"Then why'd you chose to become a Hunter? And a shield bearer at that. That is probably the worst job of all for you because you need lots of of magic to keep yourself healed up and to strengthen your arms."

"Because I'm pretty stupid and clumsy. I really don't have much skill with any other weapons. Would probably stab myself before I stabbed a creature. So doing fancy flips and spins like what she did out there is out of the question. Intricate patterns are pretty complicated for me to remember and get down as well. So sword and board seemed like a good choice."

"As for why I became a Hunter, well I come from a pretty small town up north. We have one Hunter there but he is old and he won't live much longer probably. We don't get many monsters out that way so we manage to eek by somehow. I want to protect my home and my family. Take over the job when old Markus dies. It might not seem like much of a reason but it is important to me."

I reached over and laid my hand on his side, sending out a bit of magic and healing his bruises.

"Arena Master. Can you section off a small private arena for the two of us and get him two bucklers like mine please?"

The Arena Master fiddled with a little box he pulled out of his pocket, using the specialized magic of his office to fulfill my request. The boy looked at me dumbfounded.

"You're going to teach me! I mean I'm grateful but why? I really didn't expect you to say yes. I just sort of blurted it out without thinking."

The Arena Master handed him the two fan shields and he fumbled to put them on, unfamiliar about how they worked since they were different then the shield he was used to.

"Because you want to be a Hunter for all the right reasons. Our job isn't about fame and fortune or honor and glory. It is about protecting people who can't protect themselves. Everyday people who don't have the skills that we do. Or the kind of magic power that we do. You recognize your limits and you don't pretend to something you aren't. You chose the shield because you knew it was within your ability to master. That is why I'll teach you. I can respect that desire."

"But he is just some hillbilly hick from a no name town! And a useless first generation Hunter at that!"

I pivoted on my heel as I made the buckler on my left arm expand, smashing it into the girls face without warning.

"And who decides if he is useless or not! You! At least he had the balls to stand his ground against that initial attack! If he hadn't taken that hit it could have been you who was paste on the floor! That doesn't sound so useless to me now does it! So what if he is a first generation! My family was a first generation at one time! Somebody still taught them! Your family was once a first generation, probably your mother or father. Should they have been denied teaching?"

I turned to look at the boy.

"What's your name and what's the name of your town?"

"Jethic Yonic and my town is called Thorsbough."

Angrily I turned back to the girl who was rolling around on the floor bleeding from her broken nose. I stepped on her stomach, forcing her to look up into my face.

"You hear that? He's not some hillbilly hick. He's Jethic Yonic. And his town has a name. Thorsbough. Remember them both because when I am done with him he will be saving your useless ass one day from becoming a useless corpse!"

With that I motioned to Jethic before heading off towards the small corner that had been set apart for us. Out of the corner of my eye I saw Liz plant her glaive on the floor before bending over the moaning girl.

"I think you ticked him off. Just be glad he was in a good mood or he might have hurt you."
11112112121.title: Tank

111121121211.content:
“Don’t activate the shield until your arm is in place. Folded, these shields weight almost nothing. Extended they are still light but they weigh down the arm, which can tire you out quickly. What you want is not pure defense, but speed and stamina laced with accuracy. Now try it again.”

I attacked slowly. Having already judged his skill and speed I simply adjusted my attacks accordingly. I made sure to go just fast enough that he would feel like he was getting his shield into place just in time. Which would make him feel slow and make him push himself to get just a tad bit faster. I would increase speed in this way so he would never notice just how good he was getting. It would take time, but I was willing to put in the effort. Because he wasn’t like the rest of these people. From the little conversation we had and what I had learned while teaching him, he was dedicated to becoming a Hunter. Body, mind, and soul. I had to respond to that need.

“Don’t be afraid of the attack. You already know that since you chose the shield. That is the basics of using one. To stand your ground and take the brunt of the blow. But with this style it is especially important. When you are good enough sometimes that thin piece of metal on the back of your arm will be all the shield you have. Not a big round circle. Learn how many seconds it takes for the buckler to unfold and fold back up. The rate at which it does so. Those seconds are the difference between someone living and someone dying.”

I threw a kick out to the side and he automatically spread his legs while throwing up his right arm to block. He was doing what most tank types were taught to do without thinking, what was called entrenching. It was good for big shields like he was used to but not for bucklers. I halted my attack in mid strike, pivoting on the ball of my foot and reversing the spin while bending my knee. Turning my snap kick into a leg sweep. He fell over backwards, but had enough mind to break his fall like he had learned.

“I told you before, bucklers are not like big templar style shields. They are designed to take quick rapid hits over big beefy ones. And with this style especially, it is more for deflection than full on assaults. You take the hit and you roll with it. You turn it to the side and then you strike back. How do you expect to strike if you are standing like a wall?”

“Sorry, I forgot.”

The bell rang signaling the end of class. I offered him a hand up which he took while rubbing his backside.

“Don’t worry, you are learning a whole new mindset. You weren’t bad for your first day. But you need a lot more practice. So from now on I want you to come over to my place after school when you can for private lessons. You can have my old set of dual shields that I trained with. Keep up the practice at home and before you know it you will be well on your way to mastering the skills.”

His eyes went big and round again as if I had just told him I would introduce him to The One God himself. I could understand his awe though, just about everybody here would want to take private lessons from me or be given some of my old training equipment. Once they found out, they would all be envious of him. Which was part of the reason I was doing it as well. To snub my nose at their disdain of someone trying his hardest to be a Hunter.

As we headed towards the locker room I glanced over at him again.

“By the way, how’s the arms?”

“A bit sore, but not like they usually are.”

“That’s because you aren’t taking the full blow. With little magic like you have it will help you tank longer without the need of healing yourself.”

“Thank you for all your help. You have no idea how much I appreciate it.”

“Oh I know. But don’t thank me just yet. You will find I’m not an easy trainer. You will be cursing my name soon enough.”

He nodded his head to me as I opened the door and he split off to pack up his stuff. I headed straight for my duffle bag and found both of the weapons sitting on top of the rest inside. With a slight nod of approval I zipped up the duffle and headed out the door. Next would be History and then finally Monster Theory and Tactics. This day was almost over thankfully.

I could already see the change in power going on in the classroom as some of the other boys and girls were already gathering around Jethic with his new sudden popularity from being associated with me. Perhaps I should warn him to be careful who he trusted. A moment of contemplation made me disregard that thought. Considering how he had been treated before he probably knew that already. And it was up to him to decide who he wanted to make alliances and connections with, not me. If they were bad ones then he would learn on his own.

Shortly after class started a short squat woman with blond hair and a patch over her right eye wearing a low cut yellow dress came into the room and whispered to the teacher. I was already grabbing up my bag and standing up before he even pointed at me to let me know my mother wanted to talk to me. Seconds later I was out the door walking side by side with the older woman.

“So Hilda, what does my mother want with me now? Must be important if she is calling me out of class.”

“It’s really not my place but all I can say is she wants to offer you a job. I’ll let her explain the details.”

“An official Hunter’s job?”

“If it comes to that, yes I believe so. Though I think she would prefer it be more… unofficial considering your unique position.”

“Meaning she is doing what she always does and treating me as a full fledged Monster Combat Hunter when it is convenient for her.”

“That’s not for me to make judgments. I simply work for her.”

“Your too good for her Hilda. You’re the only one I know of that she hasn’t fired yet. That means your good at your job, but that also means you could find better employment considering my mother’s personality.”

“You’re right, I can. And I have even been offered better. But I owe your mother a debt, so I stay.”

Hilda opened the door to the meeting room and motioned me inside. I thanked her with a small tip of the head and walked in. I was met by my mother who was sitting at a table with her hands folded in front of her and a small smile on her lips. Her eyes lit up when she saw me, making her jump out of her chair to wrap me in a hug and kiss my cheeks. I ignored her for the moment and studied the little girl with white hair and red eyes who sat like a statue staring straight ahead while clutching a teddy bear. She wore a light green dress that did not look good on her at all and I could see the tattered shape of her shoes peeking out under the table from where I stood.

“So Hilda says you have a job for me mother? I assume it has to do with this little girl, otherwise you would not have brought her with you.”

I sat across the table from the two of them when she motioned for me to do so, putting on my Hunter’s face even as my mother dropped down her work mask.

“Your right. I want you to guard this girl for a few days. Me and your father got contracted for another job and taking her with us is out of the question. Her name is Asala and she is a monster summoner. Her powers are a bit unstable so she tends to summon monsters when her emotions run high from things like sudden frights. As you can see she has sort of shut down on us and no one can seem to pull her out of it.”

“We were wondering what to do with her when you called me earlier. That’s when I remembered how good you are with kids, even if you suck at dealing with people your own age. Her parents died three days ago and her power suddenly manifested because of that.”

“You couldn’t think of anyone else? I mean I understand the options would be limited since not a lot of Hunter’s can tolerate those with summoner blood, or any rare magic ability for that matter. But with all the people you know why chose me? I’m not an official Hunter because you don’t want me to be until I finish school. And honestly speaking, a job like this would require an official Hunter. Doing it under the table isn’t exactly viable. Since I can foresee there being times when I need the protection of being on official Hunter business to keep her safe.”

“There is one other person I could think of, but it was Pelei.”

I nodded my understanding.

“Yeah I can see why you wouldn’t chose him first. He could do the job, and he is more experienced than me, but his personality would scare the poor girl worse than she already is.”

“I’m willing to give you temporary Hunter status under my name if you do this.”

“But not under my own name huh? Still with the whole you have to finish school kick.”

“And I want you to continue to go to school while protecting her.”

“That’s asking quite a lot mother. Do you have any idea how much that will make me stand out? You are the one that told me not to make waves.”

“I’ve got my reasons darling. And I feel it is important for you to stay in school even if you accept the job.”

“You always have your reasons mother. And they always work out to benefit you the most no matter who else they hurt. Or benefit the family name and image even if it destroys someone’s life.”

I looked from my mother to the girl who didn’t even seem to realize I existed. The only way to tell she was alive was by the small rise and fall of her chest.
111121121211.title: Private lesson

1111211212111.content:
“Twelve thousand Reul. I won’t accept one less. I don’t feel like being generous and giving you a family discount but I can’t ask full price since I’m not a licensed Hunter either. Regardless of your reasons and whether you are willing to tell them to me or not, I won’t ruin this child’s life because of it. It’s not her fault that I have my problems with you and not her fault she has these abilities. Right now I think she needs someone who understands her more than she needs some crackpot Hunter with a penchant for dress up. I’m putting the child’s interest ahead of my own just like I am supposed to do as a Hunter. Perhaps you could take a page out of my book sometime. It might make you a better mother if not a better Hunter.”

“Darling your words cut me deeply!”

“Good. They were meant to. But I don’t even know why I waste my breath, it won’t affect you anyway. You will just continue to be you. But know this; one of these days it’s going to come back and bite you in the backside. It’s a sad day when it is your son who has to tell you this instead of it being the other way around. Now do you accept my offer or not?”

She looked at me with those sad eyes of hers but I wouldn’t let them work on me this time. I had long ago learned to ignore this fake sad face. Finally she let out a sigh and nodded.

“I accept. Hilda, if you could transfer the money over into his account for me please? I hope someday you come to understand Riktal. Things aren’t always what they seem. It might not seem like it now, but I really do have your best interests at heart. You are my precious baby boy and I only want what’s best for you.”

“Yeah just like Olia was your precious baby girl. And I’m sure you only had her best interests at heart as you dragged her kicking and screaming into the woods never to return again. I’m tired of listening to your B.S. mother. Don’t you have some job or other to do? Go bark and wag your tail for a foreign military or something. That’s what you have always been good at anyways, dumping problems on me and running off to leave me alone for days or weeks until I somehow muddle through it all.”

My mother opened her mouth to say something but closed it again without a word. With a slow nod of her head she got out of her chair and headed towards the door. I simply sat and watched her in silence until I heard the click of the slab of wood closing again. Hilda looked at the door and then back at me.

“It’s not my place to say anything…”

“And yet you still will even if I don’t want to hear it.”

“She loves you, you know. I’m sure it doesn’t seem like it but she does. She talks about you all the time and how proud she is of you.”

“Spare me Hilda. I know she loves me. That has never been a doubt in my mind. But I doubt she is proud of me. She is simply proud that I turned out to be a worthy successor to the Zelkov name. That seems to be all she is ever worried about.”

“You shouldn’t really talk about your mother like that. It hurts her deeply, even if she does act like it doesn’t.”

“She is barely my mother. She is the woman who never had much time for me. Half the time growing up I lived with a nanny. The other half the time my big sister raised me. You can’t call a woman who is home maybe once a week if you are lucky a mother. You can’t call a woman who would rather go out working to increase the family fortune when we have enough to fund a private army of our own a mother.”

“If she had a choice between spending a holiday or a birthday with her child or going overseas to do a job, she would pick the job. I know this for a fact because she does it every year. The last time I remember her being home for Christmas or my birthday was when I was five. The only time she has spent any significant amount of time with me is when she was teaching me the skills of being a Hunter. Even then she didn’t treat me as her child, just another Hunter in training. So don’t you dare say I shouldn’t talk about my mother like that. You have no right to decide that for me.”

She looked at me with a sad eye similar to the one my mother gave me before bowing and telling me the money was in my account. Once that was done she turned and left the room as well. I rubbed my eyes a few times before glancing across the table at the little girl who was squeezing her bear a bit tighter, a small indication that she knew what was going on around her.

“Sorry you had to hear all that. You must think I have a pretty messed up family don’t you? Well you are right, it is pretty dysfunctional. Even I am amazed at how we all manage to interact with each other most of the time. I bet you don’t think much of me right now after hearing me berate my mother like that. I know I probably should just keep my mouth shut but somehow when I am around her I just can’t. It’s not like I really hate her, or I don’t understand that sometimes there are circumstances beyond my control or understanding.”

“It’s just… when I see her all I can see is all the things I missed out on because I wasn’t a normal person. Other families don’t have to deal with what I do. I see normal kids with normal parents doing normal things all the time. Birthdays, holidays, normal gifts, school functions. When I was six years old my mother sent me a present for Christmas from wherever it was she was working at the time. The card didn’t even have any words on it, just a bunch of X’s and O’s. Do you know what was inside? Armor and a sword.”

“Not toy cars like other boys would get, or even some exotic candy from where she was. Not action figures or anything normal and mundane like that. No. Armor and a sword, along with an instruction book on basic stances and moves. Then she came home a month later and do you know what the first thing she did was? She attacked me. She came in the door swinging a sword at me to see if I had been practicing with the gift she had sent. Then afterwards she said I still needed to work on my form and left me alone. She was gone the next day on another job. Never once did she touch me in a caring way. No hugs and kisses or anything motherly like that.”

“Now that I am all grown up she thinks she can make up for all the time she wasn’t a mother. As if kissing me and hugging me now will somehow make me forget just how crappy she was at parenting before.”

I got up with a sigh and went around the table to sit next to the girl.

“Sorry. I didn’t mean to bog you down with my troubles or my life story. Especially when you have troubles of your own. At least I still have my mother and father, even if I rarely see either of them. I know how it feels to lose someone you care about. It’s a pretty devastating feeling. Like a black hole in the middle of your chest that is sucking everything into it. A pain in your heart that it seems no amount of medicine or magic can get rid of.”

I pointed to her head and her heart before continuing on.

“As long as you live and breath, you will remember your parents in those two places. You keep them close and they will never disappear. They might fade as you grow up but they won’t disappear unless you want them to. It’s going to be a long process, I won’t lie to you. You will end up hating yourself, hating them, hating the world. Then you will feel horrible that you hate everything. But it is something you have to go through if you want to become stronger. Time moves on without us and we can’t stay stuck in the past forever.”

“There will be a lot of crying and a lot of pain as you grieve and let it out. But there will also be good times too. It’s not all sad. You will meet new people, make new friends, have new experiences. Find people you can consider as family or as close as family as to make no difference. You will laugh and get angry again one day. Smile and joke around. It’s not a sin or a crime against those memories you hold. It’s just part of growing up and moving on.”

“But all of that is in the future. Just something you have to look forward to. Right now it is perfectly fine for you to feel the pain of their loss. I bet you haven’t had a really good cry since it all happened did you? They just whisked you away and told you not to cry or there was no time for tears right now. Perhaps they were afraid of your power and thought if you cried you would summon a monster. I don’t know how true any of that is of course, but going by what I know of most Hunter’s and people in general I bet it isn’t far from the truth.”

I reached out and pulled her in close, stroking her hair softly while she remained limp and unresponsive.

“Well I say you can cry all you want whenever you want. I won’t stop you. And if some monster appears or someone tells you to stop, I will take care of it. No matter how big mean and scary it might be, I will protect you from it. I’m not afraid of your power or of a scrawny little girl like you. You can believe me or not but that won’t make anything I said any less true.”

Slowly as I continued to stroke her hair, her arms came up to grip me tightly around the waist. Her wails were muffled at first as if she was trying to stifle them but they grew in volume until she was going off in a full blown siren mode. Her tears and snot drenching my leather tunic as I made small calming sounds the same way my sister used to do for me.

I continued to comfort her until she stopped bawling on her own and pushed herself away from me gently while sniffing and rubbing at her face.

“Feel a little better now?”

She gave me a slow nod, that devoid blank stare long gone from her eyes.

“Good. If you ever feel like another good cry my chest is always open. Though I might have to find a green tunic so the snot stains aren’t so noticeable.”

I raised an eyebrow at her before giving a dramatic sigh and looking down at my tunic with a woebegone expression on my face. I looked back up in time to see her lips twitching upwards in a grin and a small hiccup like chuckle escape her mouth.
1111211212111.title: Accept Job

11112112121111.content:
“Listen you probably aren’t going to like this, but we need to go back to class. It was part of my agreement with my mother. I know, or at least I can assume, that you are pretty afraid of crowds and new places. All those eyes staring at you, watching you as if they know all about your ability. But do you think you could manage for like forty minutes if I am right there next to you?”

She shrunk back away from me shaking her head no. I refrained from letting out a sigh, nodding my head in understanding. I had hoped it would be that easy but I wasn’t expecting it.

“Look. I understand your reluctance, I really do. Given the choice I would rather never come back to this school ever again. Those eye are always watching me too. Wondering what they can get out of me. How they can use me. I have no doubt having you next to me will cause a commotion and they will converge on us afterwards like a flock of squawking vultures wanting to know everything. But I won’t let them harm you. You have my word.”

I watched the girl as she squeezed the bear tighter but she didn’t shake her head again either way. I suddenly got an idea that made me smile as I dug through my duffle bag, pulling out a small rectangular box. It only took a bit of work to pull the siding off after finding my small toolkit. Carefully I pulled out the fragment of heart crystal inside. It was a magical battery that powered artifacts. If I destroyed it while it was filled with energy like this I could take out a good chunk of the school.

“This is a special stone filled with magic. More specifically it has protection magic in it. If you will trust me for just a moment I can put this inside your teddy bear. Then anytime you squeeze on him really hard, a magical field will surround you. If you had something like that do you think you would be willing to put up with going to class with me?”

She searched my eyes to see if I was lying before finally nodding her head and holding out the bear. I gave her a reassuring smile before cutting a small slit in the animals back along a seam and pushing the crystal inside. It took a few moments to create magical connections and wrap it in my power so it didn’t accidentally break but finally it was done. It wasn’t as high grade an artifact as the box was but she was more comfortable with the bear. Pulling a sewing kit out of one of the side pockets I got to work repairing the damage I had done along the seam.

“I used to be pretty bad at sewing you know. Always poking myself with the needle and my stitches were laughable. But I learned to get better because another little girl I once knew was always ripping her stuffed animals or her dresses. I learned how to brush and braid long hair because of her too, so if you ever feel like you want a little primping up let me know.”

Once I was done sewing the bear up I handed it back to her. She inspected my sewing job and nodded like she was saying it was acceptable. I laughed a bit as I led her by the hand out the door and back to my last class.

As soon as we stepped inside all eyes turned towards us as the gears and the whispers began. Asala squeezed her bear tightly and a light purple shield came up around her. The only reason I could still hold her hand was because it was my magic powering the shield. The stone was only activating it. I could feel the energy slowly draining from me. If I had thought I could have gotten her to use the box I would have. Then the power would come from the stone instead.

I quickly whispered with the teacher and he nodded his head as I led the little girl towards my desk, snagging an empty chair from nearby as I passed. I positioned her closer to the wall before sitting down. Now if anyone wanted to come at her they had to go through me first. The purple shield still surrounded her but I could feel the drain weakening as she slowly loosened her hold on the bear.

“Class. It seems we will be having a special guest with us for the next few days. Mr. Zelkov has taken on a job of protecting the young lady with him and due to reasons of his own, he has decided to continue attending class. As such she will be joining us until this job is over. It seems she is very shy and he asks that nobody frighten her too much by converging on her or asking her a lot of questions. That is all.”

He returned to his discussion on the Cawmacaw, transitioning over to the Cadaver Dog after a moment. I hoped his words would keep some of them away at least for a little bit but I doubted it would work for long. People were just too curious by nature. And some would do the exact opposite of what they were asked simply because they were told not to. I saw the heads constantly turning to look at us as the thoughts ran through their heads. I could see theories and reasons bursting into existence in their minds and knew rumors would be flying by tomorrow. This was one of the reasons I hadn’t wanted to bring her to class with me.

Finally the day ended and I let out a small sigh of relief. Now I could focus on the girl so tomorrow wouldn’t be so bad. If I could make her less afraid I wouldn’t have the constant drain on my magic as she hugged that bear all the time. Even as I was standing up a few of the boys and girls made a beeline towards me. Couldn’t they just take a hint and leave us alone? Hadn’t I tried to be nice and ask them not to converge on us? But they were either dense, stupid, or their desire to be associated with me simply trumped all their common sense. At least most of the class went about their day even though I saw some of them looking as if they wanted to join the group converging on us.

“That’s amazing! Taking a job while still in school!”

“She’s so cute! I’ve never see anyone with red eyes before!”

“Is she like your little sister or something?”

I felt the drain on my magic as she squeezed the bear tighter and hid behind my legs. I let my hand slip behind me to gently pat her side, trying to let her know it was going to be all right.

“She is not my little sister. Could you all please go away? It would be best to take the teachers warning to heart. Just keep your distance for the next few days. She will be gone soon enough. Besides, can’t you people see she is scared? Have a bit of common sense would you? Acting like a bunch of rabid wolves and ganging up on her like this is not going to make her feel safe. And it is not going to get you into my good graces either.”

My words seemed to have at least some impact on a few of them as they backed away unobtrusively. But the rest who were left couldn’t seem to take the hint. Funnily enough it was mostly girls. They always did seem to be a bit more dense than other people in matters like this. It had to be something about babies and little children that they couldn’t leave alone, even when told to go away.

“That hair looks like it is made out of silk! Can I touch it?”

The girl didn’t even wait for an ok before reaching out towards Asala. I felt the magic increase as she suddenly squeezed the animal tighter and was moving almost without thought. My right hand came up across my body, grabbing her wrist and twisting it behind her back while I pivoted. My left hand grabbed her by the hair and smashed her face into the desk.

“Can I smash your face into the desk? First off it is rude to simply do something or attempt to do something without asking and getting consent first. I’m sure if I had asked first you would have said no. Then why did you think it was all right to take the liberty of reaching out to touch her without her answer? I tried to be nice to all of you and get you to go away without any fuss. But it seems you are all too stupid or dense to get the picture.”

“I don’t care for you coming near me or the girl for the next few days. Stay as far away from me and her as possible or I will rip your intestines out through your throat and hang you with them. Do I make myself clear”

The girl under my hands gave a choked yes as the other girls standing around also consented. I lifted the woman I had a hold of by her hair, letting her blood drip everywhere and shoved her down the aisle towards the door before glaring at the other four girls gathered around.

“Then get the hell out of my sight before I get angry.”

Liz cam over as they ran out the door. She gave me a nod before squatting on her heels and making eye contact with Asala.

"The names Liz. I think you got a good guy protecting you so you don't have to worry. even if he does have a stupid looking face."

Liz chuckled a moment before digging into her pocket and pulling out a chocolate roll, holding it out to Asala.

“You like chocolate? It’s my last one. It might be a bit warm and soft but still good.”

Asala looked at the candy and then at Liz. Her eyes going back and forth between the two for a few moments before she slowly reached out and accepted the candy with a nod of thanks. Liz stood back up, giving me a wave of farewell before heading towards the door. Once she was gone I turned to look at the girl who was sticking the piece of chocolate into her mouth.

“See? That wasn’t too bad now was it? I guarantee tomorrow with be a bit easier. So I guess the question now is are you hungry?”

A small quick bobbing of the head.

“Well then how about we find something to eat? Think you would be up to a small expedition into town since you have your bear and me with you? We can eat at a quiet restaurant, maybe do a bit of shopping. Find you a prettier dress at least.”

The fear returned to her eyes as she squeezed the bear lightly. Not enough to activate the shield though. Finally after a few moments where her body was as stiff as a board she dipped her head slowly. So she was willing to go into town, but based on the reaction that might not be the best call quite yet. Perhaps I should leave well enough alone and not push things farther.
11112112121111.title: Go back to class

111121121211111.content:
“You know, I think it might be best if we go home don’t you? You probably aren’t all that comfortable around crowds yet, even with your friend there. We can go out shopping tomorrow for some new clothes and such. I think I got a few oversized shirts that will fit you as a nightgown tonight while I wash those things for you. Plus I doubt you will get any tooth decay if you don’t brush your teeth for one night.”

I took her hand as I shouldered my bag, guiding her to the door.

“I’m told I make a mean peanut butter and jelly sandwich. I mean, all little boys and girls like those don’t they?”

Her head bobbed up and down like it was on a spring as her eyes lit up a bit. I grinned at her as I led her through the halls. She was a lot like Olia. Dealing with her wasn’t all that hard if I thought of her that way. I wondered if she liked her crust pinched as well to keep in the jelly.

As we left the front door I saw a group of three boys picking on another one by the front gates. That seemed to be universal everywhere whether it was a Hunter academy or not. There would always be bullies who found enjoyment in picking on other people. I thought it was funny how they almost always ran in packs, you rarely saw a bully by themselves. As I got closer I noticed the one they were picking on was Jethic.

“Jethic! You’re a tank remember? Treat them like monsters and show them what I taught you!”

Jethic looked back and saw me standing there, surprise written all over his face. One of the bullies pushed him and I simply cocked my eyebrow.

“Well Jethic? Are you saying you didn’t learn anything? They are weak. Why do you think they ganged up on you? You will never make it as a tank if you get taken down by weaklings.”

“B-but…!”

“No buts’! don’t think, just do.”

I saw one of the other boys getting ready to push him from the side while he was looking at me.

“Swipe from the left!”

He raised his left hand automatically and shoved the push wide as he stepped inside the mans body while pivoting on his foot, bringing up his right forearm. He caught the bully square in the nose with the back of his armor covered hand, continuing the pivot to backhand another of the boys in the throat with his left arm. When a third boy threw a punch at the back of his head he dropped his knee while spinning. The blow flew over his head harmlessly seconds before he shoved upwards, ramming his gauntleted fist into his opponents chin. The boy was lifted off his feet and sent flying to land on his back in a daze.

With a grin I stepped up next to Jethic who was blinking in amazement at what he had just done. I slapped him on the back good naturedly before laughing at the three boys that had been picking on him.

“See Jethic? They are weak. Humans are just another form of monster. In fact sometimes we are the worse ones. We know what we are doing, the same can’t be said for all monsters out in the wild. You said you want to protect your hometown, well sometimes that will mean protecting it from people and not creatures. It doesn’t matter if they are from old families or from families that have other hunters in it. It doesn’t matter if they have political power and influence or wealth. They fall and they bleed just like everything else. No one has the right to dictate how you live your life or stop you from defending yourself.”

The two boys had run to their friends side and was helping him to his feet. I pointed at all three of them with an evil grin on my face.

“I’m sure my friend here will be glad to show you the fruits of his training again if you need a reminder. I doubt he will be such an easy mark anymore so you need to find new prey. I can’t guarantee he won’t smack you around again though, after all he is a tank who takes protecting people seriously.”

The boys offered a few empty threats before scurrying away. I let out another belly laugh as I turned to Jethic.

“I hope you learned something from this.”

“Yeah I think I did. I have no problem killing monsters, but when it comes to fighting people I hesitate. But when I thought about them as monsters like you said it was easy. Almost natural.”

He looked down at the girl who was hiding behind my legs and smiled softly. He got down on one knee before speaking directly to her.

“Hello. As you probably figured out, my name is Jethic. I’m training to become a tank. That is, someone who protects other people with a shield so they don’t get hurt. I hope I didn’t frighten you or anything. I got a little sister of my own back home. I haven’t seen her for almost a year now. I haven’t even heard from her in about half that time. I wonder how she is doing and I worry about her all the time. So I have an idea of how afraid you must be. I won’t say not to be afraid, because that’s probably impossible. But if anything ever happens, I will protect you no matter what. That’s a promise from me to you. And my dad always told me a man must always keep his promises.”

The girl stared at Jethic without saying anything for a long time. Slowly I felt the magic stop draining from me as she stopped squeezing the bear. She held out her hand and whispered in an almost inaudibly soft voice.

“My name is Asala.”

Jethic shook her hand before standing up again. I knew then he would make a good Hunter. He was already way ahead of all these other students in more than one way. Any good Hunter knew how to deal with people. Most Hunters knew how but not many actually utilized that skill. I wasn’t talking about normal everyday dealing with people. I was talking about how to put someone at ease or gain their trust quickly. We needed that to do our jobs effectively. Most times it was easy because the people already trusted us simply because we were Hunter’s. But then you had cases like Asala’s where they needed to trust the individual and not the title.

The three of us began walking towards town at a leisurely pace. I gave Jethic a few more pointers on his form and made some hand motions as demonstration. Jethic told me a little bit about his family back home and how he lived with his aunt and uncle while he was going to school here. Asala was content to hold my hand and simply walk on the other side of me.

“Did you really mean what you said back there? That I was your friend? Or were you just saying that?”

“Honestly? I was just saying that to give you more importance in their minds then was really there. But I wouldn’t mind making it the truth I guess. You aren’t such a bad guy and you were able to get Asala to speak so that’s something. I can get behind your motivations and I can actually stand being around you. Though I must warn you, I’m not the easiest person to get along with. Today just happened to be one of my good days. There will probably be times you will wonder how you could ever be friends with me. But if you really want to try it then be my guest.”

Jethic gave me a lopsided smile as he turned his head in my direction.

“You seem to have a bit of a skewed outlook on friendship. My father said you don’t always get to chose your friends. Sometimes friendships just happen whether you want them to or not. It’s not like some contract the two of you sign.”

“Yeah that proves you are from a newer Hunter family. When you come from old blood like me you can’t be so loose with your friendships. It really is more about alliances than actual friendships. You have to worry about who you let get close to you, how close you let them get, and what benefits you can give each other.”

“Glad I’m not you then. I don’t think I would like to live like that.”

“It’s all I know. All I ever grew up knowing.”

“All right! Then I have decided! I am going to make you change your mind! I’m going to show you that’s not what it’s always all about. I’m going to make you call me your friend and mean it.”

“Good luck with that. You’ve got about ten generations of conditioning to get past.”

“A paltry number. If I can get over my fear of hitting someone else then tackling this will be nothing.”

“You at least don’t lack the confidence.”

When we got into town he gave me a wave, heading off to the right while I continued on ahead. Watching him go I oddly felt that he just might be able to pull it off. I liked his attitude at least. But if he was able to put up with me then he deserved the title of friend for that fact alone. I wrapped my arm around Asala’s shoulder as I pulled her in a bit closer.

“Come on Asala, let’s go home. There is a pinched crust PB and J sandwich with your name on it.”

***********

So are you satisfied with the choices you made and the path you led Riktal down? Were they all easy to make? Did you second guess yourself afterwards? Do you think in the end the choices didn’t even really matter? Perhaps the day would have ended exactly like this no matter what choices you made.

Perhaps next time you come you will get a chance to find out. Make different decisions, open a new path, say different things. Untold possibilities and countless choices. What destiny awaits?
111121121211111.title: Go home

111121121211112.content:
“I think it might do you some good to eat out today. Besides, we need to get you some new clothes and such as well. Unless you are hiding some extras in your pocket I don’t know about. I’ll be right here with you and you got your new shield so there is nothing to worry about.”

I put my arm around her as I guided her out the door and down the hall. Making small talk to try and draw a little more information from her. What she liked and disliked maybe. Mainly just trying to keep her in the here and now while making her feel more at ease around me. It didn’t seem to have any affect at the moment, but this was a long term process. There was no real quick fix for grief.

As we came to the front doors I saw Jethic standing in the hall letting out a breath like he was preparing himself for something. Asala squeezed her bear hard enough to make a light shield come up as I approached him. But my arm on her shoulder and my closeness seemed to assure her a little bit which was a small start. As he started out the door I fell into step beside him.

“Hey Jethic, hope you don’t mind postponing our training for a few days. Right now this little girl here takes priority.”

He looked at me a bit surprised, as if he hadn’t expected me to talk to him again.

“T-that’s ok. I got a little sister back home and if she was in that girls shoes I would want someone making her a priority as well. I spent a lot of time with old Markus. He told me all these stories about what it takes to be a Hunter and how a job should always come first over everything else. He also said how sometimes it was a hard choice to make when it came into conflict with protecting the regular citizens. He taught me the basics of sword and shield and even gave me his old gear that I use in practice.”

As we went through the school gates I saw three boys slinking in the shadows and Jethic giving them a nervous look. They didn’t come any closer, just followed him with their eyes until we were out of sight. He let out a small sigh under his breath and I nodded knowingly.

“Bully trouble?”

“No. nothing like that.”

“Don’t lie. It’s written all over your face.”

“Ok so they give me trouble all the time.”

“Then knock them out. You’re a tank, you specialize in taking on multiple enemies at once. You’re not half bad either. I wouldn’t be surprised if you could put them all flat on their backs. Even if you can’t they won’t leave you alone if you continue to be a doormat they can step on.”

“I know, but I sort of have this problem with people. I can handle monsters just fine, and I can spar with people no problem. But when I think of actually fighting them with the intent to hurt or kill I hesitate. I just can’t seem to follow through with my attacks.”

“I’ll beat that out of you soon enough.”

As we continued to walk towards town a sudden urge overtook me. Perhaps it was inspiration from some half formed idea in the back of my head.

“Hey Jethic. Me and Asala here are going to grab a bite to eat and do a bit of shopping before we head home. You want to come with us?”

“W-what? Why? Are you sure?”

“Why? Well if I have to give a reason I guess you could say it’s for Asala’s benefit. She is afraid of crowds and people in general. It would do her good to interact with someone else besides me a little bit. And I’m sure she might feel safer knowing someone who specializes in tanking is around.”

“But you’re a better tank than me.”

“That’s true. But I’m an all around combat specialist. You have one job so to speak.”

“Then sure I guess! As long as you don’t mind me stopping at my house on the way. I live with my aunt and uncle and they get worried when I don’t come right home.”

“That’s fine.”

Jethic knelt on the ground in front of Asala who looked at him warily but not a lot of fear.

“I might not be the best tank Hunter out there. But my shield is yours if you need it. I will defend you with my last breath no matter what if it comes to that. You have my word on it.”

Jethic stood up and we continued walking, making a right at the first intersection. He led me to a small wood crafting store that sold hand made furniture. I was a bit surprised as he opened the door.

“You’re related to old man Gabis?”

“You know my uncle?”

“Sort of, I commissioned him to make something for me once.”

We entered the shop as a bell jangled over our heads. The smell of sawdust and wood glue met my nostrils as the man behind the counter looked up from what he was carving. He wasn’t really old, only around thirty five or so. But when I was here two years ago he said to call him old man Gabis because everyone did. He grinned at me as Jethic said hello before going through the back door. I heard the creaking of steps so I assumed their apartment was upstairs.

“Hey your Mr. Zelkov! Haven’t seen you for what is it, two years now? How’s that locket I made for you?”

“You still remember what I ordered? That’s impressive.”

“Course I remember. It’s not everyday you get such a unique order. A locket made out of Doma wood and covered in gold. Had to get an advance to buy such rare wood. That must have been a pretty important spell you placed on it though. That’s the only reason I could think you wanted such a special wood for. It holds magic so well nothing can nullify it. But it’s so rare and expensive you don’t usually see it used on something so small.”

“Indeed it was a very important spell that was cast on it.”

“I hope your lady friend liked it.”

“She loved it. It was truly top class work.”

“So what are you here for? Have another job for me?”

“Nope. Actually I’m here with Jethic. I invited him out to eat and do a bit of shopping. This little girl here needs some new clothes and such and I thought it would do her good to have someone else along.”

There was a pounding of feet as of someone running down the steps and a slightly pudgy woman rounded the doorframe.

“Bern! You won’t believe this! Jethic is going to get trained by a Zelkov!”

The woman blinked as if suddenly realizing I was there.

“I’m sorry I didn’t realize you had a customer. I’m sorry sir, I didn’t mean to interrupt your business.”

That’s all right ma’am. Though I’m not a customer right now. I’m the Zelkov in question.”

Old man Gabis burst out laughing as his wife’s eyes turned into saucers and she held her hand up to her mouth. Her cheeks flushed red right before she ducked back into hiding. Jethic came out of the back then grinning at his aunt’s reaction as well.

“She always was a bit excitable, but that was one of the reasons I fell in love with her. As you can see she can also be easily embarrassed. So you’re going to be teaching my nephew huh? Then I definitely know he will become a top class Hunter.”

He nodded with his head behind me and I turned around to see Asala running her fingers along the grain of a table and nodding her head absently.

“I think your girl must have a knack for woodworking. Not many people can spot the seam like she did. And it seems like she knows quality work too.”

She came back over to my side and gave the old man a thumbs up of approval. He tilted his head to the side in thanks.

“Glad to see I got her seal of approval. So Mr. Zelkov, what do you think of these new communication artifacts they just invented. You know, the ones they call the telephone. Supposed to be able to let you talk to anyone anywhere in the world. You don’t need to have strong magic or have the person imprint their magical id into your spell.”

“I think you should invest in them if you can. I’m sure there will be a lot of bugs at first, but I can see it taking off. I’m not sure how they plan to make it work exactly, probably amplifier crystals or something spaced out across the continent. But I can see them being in every home eventually.”

“Ah if I had that kind of money though. I wish I could invest in it, but I’m barely scraping by as it is. Just not as much call for hand crafted stuff you know. But this is the only thing I know.”

I nodded in understanding but didn’t say anything else. Taking Asala by the hand again, the three of us left the store.
111121121211112.title: Go to town

1111211212111121.content:
“So you like woodworking huh?”

Asala nodded her head as she stuck her fork into another sausage link and ate it. She still hadn’t said anything but she was definitely in a much better mood and more at ease with me. She was still a bit wary of Jethic but she wasn’t squeezing her bear around him anymore either. I gave her head a small rub as I looked across the table at Jethic who was eating an expensive steak. He had been hesitant to order it at first but I had told him it was on me. Since he was coming out here on my whim.

“So your family up north. You talk to them often?”

“Not really. I haven’t mastered the communication spell yet so I can’t call them whenever I want. And like my uncle said, we are poor so I can’t even afford a low grade artifact. Mostly I write to them. I haven’t seen them in almost a year now and the last time I talked to them was about six months ago. Sometimes when uncle Bern has a bit of extra money he buys a cheap throwaway communication spell for a few Reul I can use until it runs out. Mostly any money I make I give to them for room and board.”

“My parents nearly broke their bank accounts buying me the ticket here and enrolling me in the academy. They knew I wanted to be a Hunter but I hadn’t planned on going to school for it because we were struggling to make it as it was. But a week before school started they handed me the ticket and told me to go. That my aunt and uncle were going to lodge me for the three years of academy. So I have to become a top class Hunter not only to protect them all but to prove to them that their sacrifices were worth it.”

We made a little more small talk as we finished our meal. Asala was even smiling a little and giggling at some of our jokes. I paid the bill and we left, finding a store and letting Asala try on clothes. Jethic was finally becoming comfortable around me as well. Having lost that hero worship anxiety. As the little girl came out of the changing room to showcase what she was wearing the two of us acted like silly girls going goo-goo over what she was wearing. Giving small whistles of appreciation or throwing our hands up to our faces and shrieking in delight.

I’m sure the saleswomen thought we were crazy but they refrained from pointing at us. Simply whispering behind their hands. There was even a point where I held up a dress to my chest and raised an eyebrow.

“So what do you think? Look good on me?”

Jethic snapped his fingers and shook his head, walking up to me with one hand out to his side. He reached passed me and grabbed a pink dress.

“Nuh-uh Darling. That dress is simply so not you. Blue is sooo overrated. But pink is definitely your color! This will make you look Fa-bu-lous!”

Our antics finally elicited a belly laugh from Asala who held her stomach as she wiped tears from her eyes. The two of us shared a grin as we put the clothes back. I whispered my thanks for playing along and he gave me a wink, whispering back that he understood.

We finally left the store ladened down with four bags of clothes, shoes, accessories, and some personal hygiene products. Enough to satisfy any little girl for a while. She walked happily between the two of us as I led us to our next destination. Jethic entered without thinking until he saw we were in a Hunter’s general store. Different from the stores specializing in just weapons or artifacts or anything of that nature, these stores held stuff commonly used by both Hunters and regular people.

The owner looked up from where he was reading a magazine, the scar running from cheek to cheek across his nose standing out starkly against his black skin. He saw me and grinned putting the magazine down and standing up to shake my hand over the counter.

“Hey Riktal! How you doing man! So what kind of business you got for me today? Ivory tusks? Enchanted weapons you need appraising?”

I pulled the nugget from my pocket and slipped it across the counter towards him.

“Gold. Sengwen kill after it went to phase two. Might have some trace magic on it but I don’t know.”

He began pulling out scales and other tools of his trade to examine it closely. As he worked I held out my hand to Jethic.

“By the way, Terin, this is Jethic Yonic. Remember his name since I have a feeling he will end up having a bit of business with you in the future. Treat him good will you?”

“If he got your recommendation, then I have no choice but to treat him well. Otherwise I might lose your business.”

I glanced over at Jethic as he continued to work.

“Not that he would treat you bad to begin with mind you. But he might be willing to give you a few extra Reuls for an item or keep you in mind for jobs he might not otherwise tell you about. Just don’t let him talk you into playing cards with him or you might lose some of those extra Reuls.”

The black man grinned but kept working, finally putting the nugget in front of me on the counter.

“Seven hundred Reul. Its not quite pure but it’s at least twenty karat. You were right, some traces of magic which will make it good artifact material.”

“Deal. Also got any quality communication artifacts here?”

Jethic opened his mouth to say something but I held up my hand to keep him quiet. He did so as Terin went into the back room a moment and came back with a small box you could close your hand on.

“This is from Carpa and it’s high grade. Get’s the best reception and the farthest range out of all the ones I have. Has a guaranteed three year battery life before the heart crystal needs to be recharged. Depending on use of course. Two hundred Reul.”

“I’ll take it. Though it’s not for me it’s for my friend here.”

Terin motioned for Jethic to come closer and put his finger on the small green see through plate that popped up when he slid the bottom half to the side. Jethic seemed unsure but I gave him a little shove in the back until he finally reached out and imprinted his magical id onto it. The box glowed light blue for a moment before giving a beep. Terin handed the box and a small booklet over with a grin.

“It’s locked to you know kid. If you got any questions they are all answered in the booklet.”

Plucking the artifact out of Jethic’s hands I put it back on the table.

“One last thing. Think you could send this up north to a town called Thorsbough? He has family up there but he can’t go there himself. Get them to imprint onto it and then get it back to him? He lives with old man Gabis over on Rue.”

“For another three hundred I can. Payment for the runner and insurance on it.”

“Deal.”

Terin gave me another nod before opening his cash register and handing me two hundred Reul. I thanked him before heading back out onto the street. Once we were outside Jethic again tried to say something but I held up my hand to silence him a second time. Grabbing his arm I shoved the two hundred Reul into his limp fingers, curling them over the bills.

“This is payment for a job. You came out here with me on the town when you didn’t have to. You are helping me protect this little girl. You might not seem like you are doing anything, but this day probably would not have gone so well without you. Just shut up and accept the payment. You earned it.”

He opened and closed his mouth a few times before finally nodding his head.

“Thanks. You’re right. I don’t feel like I earned this at all. But I’m a bit selfish. The thought of being able to talk to my family whenever I want is too tempting. And this money will really help out at home.”

As we came to the corner a man in a ski mask came around the side of the building carrying a bank bag and waving a gun around. I saw a small red circle begin to grow on the ground but then Asala squeezed her bear tightly, causing a shield to pop up around her while she shut her eyes. The small red summoning circle disappeared even as Jethic slapped his right gauntlet with his left hand, causing his giant templar shield to expand out. The robber fired his gun, but the bullet bounced harmlessly off his shield as he stepped in front of me and Asala.

Dropping the bags in my hands, I planted them on his shoulders and shoved off from the ground. I flipped over his back and extended my leg to smash it into the masked man’s head, dropping him to the pavement. Two policemen rounded the corner then and saw we had taken care of the robber for them. They thanked us both and cuffed the man as Jethic returned his shield to it’s dormant state.

“Nice reactions.”

“I didn’t think. I just reacted like you told me to in practice earlier.”

“Well you did your job and you protected us. I say you earned your artifact and Reul now.”

“I’m sure you could have dealt with it without me.”

“You're right I might have been able to. But Asala might have been shot. Your shield prevented that so don’t sell yourself short. You're going to be a top class shield specialist remember?”

“Your right. I earned my artifact and my Reul now.”

I patted him on the back as we returned to his house to drop him off and then me and Asala went home ourselves.

*********

It seems your time here today has ended. How do you feel about the choices you made and the route you took? Was it easy to play god? To choice the course of someone else’s life? Would you have made the same choices if it had been you? Or did you not care what happened to young Riktal because it wasn’t you?

Come again my fair traveler and create a new destiny in this realm of infinite possibilities.
1111211212111121.title: Night on the town.

11112112121112.content:
“You know what? Let’s skip out on the rest of school today. We need to get you settled in and make your transition into the class easier. You don’t need all those eyes staring at you right now.”

I led her by the hand out the door and through the empty halls without saying a word. I had to be careful not to push her too much or make her feel I was being too nosey. Talking too much was just as harmful as talking too little sometimes. I had to give her time to digest what I said and come to her own conclusions, but not enough time to fully retreat back into her shell. It was an art any good Hunter had but few utilized.

Once we were out on the sidewalk and heading towards town I gave her hand a small squeeze which made her look up at me with eyes that had already filled with a bit of trust.

“I bet you a chocolate bar that those ratty clothes are the only thing you have. If you told me they let you grab even one other dress before pulling you away from your old life I would be surprised. That bear is probably the only thing you were able to keep.”

Slowly she nodded her head as if afraid to admit I was telling the truth.

“Then do you think you could tolerate going into town for a bit? At this time of day it shouldn’t be too crowded and we can easily get you some new clothes and a bunch of other things to pretty you up. Make you look less like some white haired monster in that fugly dress I bet you got from some aunt or uncle because they thought it would look good on you.”

Her lip twitched as she self consciously ran her hand down her dress. Finally she nodded with just a hint of fear coming to her eyes as she squeezed my hand for support.
