“I don’t doubt you are afraid of crowds since your power might activate and you could hurt them or they hurt you. Not to mention they probably scare you right now. But stay close to me and let me know if something scares you. I’ll give it a stink eye and scare it away with my looks alone. I’m so ugly I look at a black horse and it turns into a zebra.”

Again that twitch of a smile but this time I saw a few teeth. I was making progress. The most important thing was to get her to trust me. Make her feel safe as long as I was around. That way it was less likely she would be frightened into summoning a monster tomorrow while in class. It truly was stupid that my mother wouldn’t let me skip a few days for this. I was half tempted to skip anyway, but attending class had been part of the job I had taken on. In essence it was part of my contract.

We stopped in a clothing store and I encouraged Asala to go wild. I let her try on anything and everything she wanted. Making some comedic comments and acting like a girl, imitating the ones I had seen in my last school. My careful manipulation of her mood got her to loosen up a bit more and even elicited a few more giggles at my expense. I could see some of the sales ladies whispering behind their hands but I ignored them. This was all part of the job in my eyes, nothing was too embarrassing.

We left the store with four new dresses, some undergarments, socks and shoes and even a few pieces of jewelry. Not to mention a bag laden down with nothing but toiletries such as toothbrushes, deodorants and perfumes. When I asked her if she wanted to go see a movie and get something to eat she nodded her head with more confidence than she had before. I grinned in return, she was just like any other girl who liked shopping. That sadness for her parents was still written on her face, but I had managed to push it back for a little while. At this rate those emotions would come back later on tonight as the thrill of this day wore off and then she would have a good cry again. It was psychology 101. I felt a bit guilty that I was playing with her mind like this but in the end it was for her own good.

On the way to the restaurant I ran into my father coming out of a weapon’s shop. I was a bit surprised to see him since it had been three days since he had left on his last job. I hadn’t expected him back for another day or two.

“Hey son! What are you doing here? Shouldn’t you be in school?”

Asala hid herself behind my leg while clutching at my tunic. Quickly I told my father about my meeting and the new job I had been given. He nodded his head in understanding.

“Ah I knew vaguely about her situation. Your mother was contracted to clean out some caves over in Bornica. She couldn’t handle it alone so she asked for my help. I got finished with that Sandworm infestation over in Cala early so I said yes. Looks like I won’t be home for a while more. I was looking forward to having a game of chess with you too. Sorry to leave you alone a bit longer.”

“I’m used to it. This isn’t the first time I’ve been alone for a week or so at a time and it’s not like I don’t know how to take care of myself.”

“That’s true. Sometimes I think you could do a better job of running a house than we can.”

I shrugged, refraining from pointing out that what he said was the truth. They were gone so often they didn’t need to worry about taking care of bills or buying food or doing laundry. They had other people that did it for them and they simply threw money into an account and let the bills be taken out of that. Whereas I was given an allowance for living expenses and had to worry about grocery shopping and doing my own cleaning.

“So from what you said shouldn’t you and the girl still be in class? Or at least just getting out of school now?”

I shrugged again.

“I made a tactical decision. Build rapport and make her more at ease before I thrust the girl into that kind of situation.”

“Ah, I see. Makes sense. And it’s a sound move. Your mother will be mad if she find’s out though. Good thing I never saw you while I was out collecting supplies for our trip. Just stay away from Nerval’s or you might accidentally run into her.”

“Thanks for the heads up dad.”

He grinned in response to the one I gave him. Shaking my hand before pulling me into a hug.

“I promise when I get back it’s going to be me and you time. Maybe go out slaying some monsters. No, strike that. Fishing. We haven’t gone fishing for a while and it’s good to get away from the normal monster hunting. And I want to see how strong you’ve gotten so an arm wrestling match definitely.”

“Sounds like fun. I’ll make sure to grease your side of the table for an easy win.”

He belted out a belly laugh as he turned to leave, calling over his shoulder.

“How do you think I used to beat you before?”

Before he could get out of earshot I stopped him. He turned back around waiting expectantly.

“Wait a few days and tell mom I’m sorry. Say I called you on the spell or something. Tell her I said a bit too much and I shouldn’t have. If you haven’t heard about it yet I am sure you will.”

“I heard a bit son. From what I have heard secondhand, I do agree with some of what you said to her. She does have a bad habit of using people and putting the family first. But she really is a good person deep down. I’ll tell you another thing, I really didn’t agree to her reasons for sending you off to that school. It was my opinion you should take the Exams. But in the end she got her way.”

“Then will you tell me what those reasons are at least?”

He worried at his lower lip with his teeth for a moment before shaking his head sadly.

“I promised her I wouldn’t say a word. But I will bend that promise this much, one of the reasons is that she thinks you are lacking something as a Hunter. And I do agree to an extent. Though it is something you can learn with experience on the job, she thought it would be best if you learned it at this school. But keep that a secret between us ok? She would get mad if she knew I told you.”

“My lips are zipped and locked.”

He threw me another wave and headed off while I altered mine and Asala’s course just slightly. I had been planning to eat at the Pasta Palace since we were so close, but since that was next door to Nerval’s shop I would take her to The Pipe instead. I’d continue to have a nice date with this little girl and build our relationship of trust. Tonight I would hold her while she cried and tomorrow she would hopefully be ready to face my classmates. Perhaps it would help if I introduced her to Mr. Snuggles as well. I would make sure this was the best day she ever had and nothing went wrong.

Indeed the rest of the day went as smoothly as I had planned it. She cried her eyes out while holding onto me until she eventually cried herself to sleep with me stroking her hair. Only once I was sure she was asleep did I finally close my eyes and rest as well.

**********

So ends another day for Riktal Zelkov. A day like and unlike any other. Where his tongue got the better of him and he regretted his hasty words. Going back to an empty house as he normally does.

But is this truly a normal day for him? Would he have chosen this same route if you had not been there to choose it for him? Well yes he would have actually. At least one of the thousands upon thousands of Riktal’s that live in the infinite possibilities. Could he have died today if you had chosen differently? Would he have handled the situations thrust upon him vastly differently as well? Again those are all possibilities that do not exist upon this timeline of his life but do still exist.

Come again anytime and try again to lead Riktal’s life in a different direction. One that he has walked and has yet to walk at the same time.
11112112121112.title: Leave school early

choices: What do you expect from me?
1111211212112.content:
“I’m sorry, not this time mother. If you want to play that game then so will I. I won’t accept because I have my reasons. I am willing to change my mind if you allow me to take the Hunter’s Exams though and quit school. If you can’t accept that then take her to Pelei and any monsters she summons because of the way he is will be on your head for not accepting my reasonable offer. This is a consequence of your choice to not let me become an official Hunter, so now live with it. I might be your son but I am not your tool to be used and discarded as you see fit.”

The little girl suddenly squeezed her stuffed animal. A small sign that she knew what was going on around her. I felt sorry for the girl, I really did. But I knew she would still be in good hands with Pelei even if he was eccentric. I was doing this for myself. Being the good guy all the time didn’t get you anything except a few thanks and more people taking advantage of you. You had to put your foot down if you wanted to stop being a doormat. And my mother was a great user of people for her own gain even though she hid it behind kind words and a carefree attitude.

“I simply can’t allow that Riktal. It is important that you stay in school and not take the Exams right now.”

“And why exactly is that?”

“I can’t say.”

“You can never say. That’s why it’s a no. You don’t give me any compelling reason to understand why it is so important. Leaving it at just a glorified “because I say so” answer. That won’t fly with me anymore mother. It never flew with me to begin with. You trained me from the day I could crawl to be a Hunter. You pushed me and made me master every aspect of everything you could think of. I’m ten times better then anyone at this school and better then half the official Hunter’s out there! I’m supposed to be out there slaying monsters and doing my job. Not wasting my time in this school.”

I stood up and gave my mother a small bow.

“Now if you excuse me I’m late for Monster Theory and Tactics. I’m sure I will find new insight into how to fight an Ooze or some other weak monster that I killed by the time I was twelve.”

I shouldered my bag and walked out the door without looking back. A moment later the door opened again and Hilda stepped into the hall behind me.

“It’s not my place to say anything, but I’m sure your mother only wants what is best for you. I know she loves you.”

“No offense Hilda, since you are one of the few aid’s of my mothers I can stand and actually like, but you are wrong. I have no doubt she loves me. I’ve never questioned that. But my mother only ever want’s what’s best for one person. My mother. I’d be careful if I were you. One of these days what she want’s is going to involve throwing you to the wolves and she will do it without hesitation or remorse.”

“I think you don’t understand your mother all that well Riktal.”

“I understand her well enough Hilda. If you know her reason’s than why don’t you tell me yourself?”

“It’s not my place to say.”

“It never is. But you usually say it anyway. Which means even you think my mother’s reasons are invalid and laughable. I should be an official Hunter and both of us know it. Good day and try to keep my mother out of trouble until I see her again. Whenever that will be.”

I headed back towards the classroom as Hilda returned to my mother’s side. I only took a few steps before I felt the presence around the corner. They hid it well but I still felt it. So when I got to where the hall split off in a different direction I wasn’t startled to find the principal sitting there in her wheelchair.

“Come walk with me for a bit Riktal.”

“I’m late for class.”

“And I’m the principal. I think that trumps anything else don’t you think? Besides I’m sure you will be heartbroken if you miss some new insight into how to kill an Ooze.”

I turned and walked beside her as she pushed her wheelchair along down the new hallway.

“Do you always eavesdrop on private conversations?”

“I do when it could put the school and all the kids here in jeopardy. Or when the meeting involves a Zelkov, let alone two of them.”

She spun around expertly and pushed the door to the outside open in one smooth motion before completing the circle and continuing on. We walked around the outside of the building for a few moments in silence. The principal would sometimes stop to admire some flowers planted next to the building or look up at an old oak tree.

“Did you know that I don’t need my hands to control this chair? It is a magical artifact in it’s own right and I can manipulate it with just a tiny bit of magic if I wanted to.”

“I figured.”

“Do you know why I don’t?”

“Conservation. You never know when you will need your magic and using your arms keep them physically fit. You were once a Hunter. Losing the use of your legs didn’t change that mentality.”

“That’s all true but that’s not the main reason. I do it because I don’t appreciate how hard other people have it if I just use magic. I take things for granted and I’m more susceptible to narrowing my view of the world. When my arms ache or I can’t manage a hill, or I can’t get up the steps without using magic on my chair it makes me realize all over again how hard life must be for other people who can’t walk that don’t have the benefits I do.”

“I heard you gave a student a private lesson today in the Arena. Why?”

“Because he had the mindset of a Hunter. His desires were in the right place and he wasn’t concerned about my family name or how he could use me if he became a friend or anything. He was interested in how I could help him become a better Hunter, nothing more.”

“I won’t deny you got a gift. You are good. There really isn’t anything of a technical nature we can teach you here. In that much you were absolutely right. You should be a Hunter right now. This school is for those who are learning how to be one, not those who already are. But because you got a gift, you were able to teach that child how to be better than he thought he could be. It might seem a little thing to you. It might seem totally reasonable in your mind. But to him it was a godsend.”

“Not everyone in this school has come to the realization of just what it means to be a Hunter yet. They don’t fully appreciate how it is they can change peoples lives. Remember even though they grew up knowing about Hunter’s and seeing them in action, they were still on the whole normal people. Everyday people who we as Hunter’s protect. They will come to that realization in time, at their own pace and in their own experiences. We as teachers at the school try to get that across to them. Stressing such important facts when they enter the academy, and while we teach them both the practical and the mental aspects.”

“Your grandfather and I built this school. Oh I don’t mean literally. It has been standing and training Hunter’s for a long time before either of us was born. But we changed it. Before we took over, the mortality rate of students coming out of this place was almost eighty five percent. that’s eight and a half fresh faced children out of ten that would die or be crippled within the first few years of active duty as Hunter’s.”

“I was one of the fortunate ones. Within the first three years of being a Hunter I lost the use of my legs. I would have lost my life if your grandfather hadn’t been there. I was but a girl of twenty one and at the time I thought that my life as a Hunter was over. Your grandfather convinced me otherwise. He lit a fire under my backside. I mean that literally by the way. I was curled up moping in my own pity and he cast a fire spell on my bottom.”

“When I yelped in pain he said, do you feel that? That means you are still alive. Just because you can’t use your legs doesn’t mean you can’t use your brain. If you don’t want this to happen to some other pretty girl then use that brain to figure out how to change it. Prove you are more than just a pretty face and a sexy body. He was a lot like you Riktal, knowing how to make a person believe and boost their confidence even if he didn’t know how to talk to them all that well.”

“So I worked hard and became principal of this school at twenty five. Since then I have worked hard at reforming and changing everything. Now this schools mortality rate is right around thirty percent. Your grandfather was with me all the way. Lending his help whenever I needed it. And believe me those first few years I needed it a lot. He dumped large amounts of the Zelkov fortune into turning this school into what it is today. I offered to share the fame of this school with him but he always refused. Because of the accident that took my legs I was never able to have children. But this place that is my life’s work is my child. The child that your grandfather could never give me.”

“So you are a Zelkov to?”

“No. Not officially anyway. Miktal had to marry for the family. For the Zelkov name. I was just a mistress. An open secret that your grandmother knew about and accepted. She had a few lovers of her own after all. Theirs was a marriage of convenience, not of love. I’m the reason you are here in this school Riktal. I’m still kicking and I want to make that mortality rate go down even farther if I can before I kick the bucket.”

“I think I’ve gone about as far as I can on my own, so I asked your parents for help. They knew I was Miktal’s mistress. They don’t talk about me much I bet, since I am a blemish on their line. But at the same time we are in the same business of protecting the people. Ours is a bit of a weird relationship I guess. In the end they sent you here to help me. Even I don’t know how exactly you are supposed to do that but I am beginning to understand after hearing about your private lesson. I’m sure they had other reasons, but I thought you would like to at least know that much.”
1111211212112.title: Decline job

11112112121121.content:
“So what is it you expect of me exactly? You wouldn’t have told me all of that if you didn’t expect something.”

“Expect? Child, I don’t expect anything of you. Just between you and me I don’t agree with the way your parents just thrust you into this situation without so much as a hint of the reason why. Oh I have no doubt it was more your mother’s idea than your father’s. He always was the more sensible one of the two. I simply thought you deserved to know. I thought about keeping it from you but my conscience got the better of me.”

“Don’t get me wrong, I would be happy if you were able to help in some way. Maybe hearing the same words we try to tell them coming from the mouth of someone their age will make them more open to listening. Or perhaps seeing someone as skilled as you and Miss Hawthrop working together will make them apply themselves more seriously. Perhaps nothing will change but perhaps it will save one more Hunter from meeting the same fate as I did.”

“But first and foremost you are a student at this school to me, not a means to an end. If you want to do nothing I won’t try to change your mind. But you are much like your grandfather Miktal whether you know it or not. You make waves. You can’t help it. Even when you do nothing at all, ripples just have a habit of spontaneously emanating from you in such a way that you change the world and the people those ripples touch.”

“Miktal was a touch hot tempered too you know. Getting angry over some of the smallest things and acting hastily. But somehow, even at it’s worst, things just seemed to sort themselves out around him. Now run along to class. I have a few more things I need to do.”

She tipped her chair up and spun it around in a quick one eighty before rolling back the way we had come.

“Hey principal.”

She reversed a bit to look at me,

“Yes?”

“Would you mind telling me more about my grandfather sometime? I really don’t know much about him and my father never talked about him much either.”

“I’d love to.”

She continued on her way, leaving me to turn the bend and walk back through the front doors. It didn’t take long to get back to my class on the second floor and slip in quietly.

“….. The Cadaver Dog is of the same family as your run of the mill undead. Having eaten the flesh of Zombies they have a symbiotic relationship with the Gloma worm that lives inside their intestines. It is because of this worm that they have the ability to reproduce without being risen from the grave and how they have low level magical abilities. As undead they are susceptible to healing or holy magic and fire. This includes magical artifacts with these properties as well. Healing magic is the most effective against them of those three types, but getting that close to use it on them is difficult due to their vicious nature. That is why splash damage potions are an effective strategy.”

The principals words from our recent conversation popped into my head and I found my hand rising up before I realized I had done so.

“Yes Mr. Zelkov.”

“There is a viable way to get close to a Cadaver Dog and kill it with without potions. It’s a little known fact that their ears are as sensitive as a real dog’s. But where as to a real dog high frequencies are an annoyance it can render a Cadaver Dog near comatose. So if you have something like a dog whistle or are able to produce a high frequency somehow, the undead dogs will simply stiffen up and fall over. After that it is a simple matter to walk up to it and kill it with minimal effort.”

“Really. I did not know that. Thank you for that extra information Mr. Zelkov.”

The teacher tipped his head towards me before continuing on with his lesson. I just sat through it all as some of my classmates kept sneaking looks back at me, eyes filled with contemplation. Finally the bell rang signaling the end of class and I got up, moving before I could be caught by the surge of people trying to surround me. I headed straight for Jethic who was still putting his stuff away, I could feel the eyes of the class following me and listening intently to anything I might say.

“You got time today for some lessons at my house? I doubt you know where I live so I can show you if you want. I can also introduce you to a weapon smith I know who can make you some nice shields at a reasonable price.”

“Uh… yeah sure. I live with my aunt and uncle, do you mind if I stop there first to let them know where I will be? They get worried easily.”

“Can’t you just call them?”

“I told you I was a bit stupid. I haven’t mastered the communication spell yet and I don’t have any money to buy an artifact.”

“Then I don’t mind.”

“I pulled out the gold nugget I had got from the Sengwen and pushed it into his palm.

“Cash that in and get yourself a communication artifact. I can’t be bothered to have you wasting your time walking home and eating into good training time. Or being unable to call and let me know if you will be late or not coming over period. And don’t give me any lip about you can’t accept it or some crap like that. Just say thank you and put it in your pocket.”

“B-but…”

“What did I say?”

He opened and closed his mouth like a fish a few times before finally thanking me and putting the small nugget away.

“Good. If you don’t know anyone who will cash that for you or no one you won’t think will rip you off, I can introduce you to someone. Now let’s go. Time is wasting.”

He followed me out the door in a bit of a daze as I kept my face blank. Once we were out in the hall and out of earshot I began to burst out laughing.

“Ah the bug eyed stare on all their faces was priceless! I’ve got a feeling your standing is going to skyrocket by tomorrow morning.”

“Why are you being so nice to me?”

“Suspicious?”

“N-no.”

“Well you should be. Don’t be afraid to say it. I’d be suspicious if I was in your shoes. But it’s simple. Being nice to you is really only a byproduct. All of that was more about giving everyone in that class a giant middle finger. All of them want something from me. Mostly to just be associated with my name like it is some sort of trophy. I’m sure you realize by just dropping the Zelkov name, any one of them could get more money for any job they did. A substantial amount at that. Any girl who was able to say I was her boyfriend would be treated like a goddess by everyone else.”

“But I can already tell you’re not interested in any of that. So by showering my attention on you, someone they think is a nobody, while completely ignoring them; I am basically saying I think less of them than I do you. I’m basically using you for my own ends, I hope you don’t mind.”

“So you really don’t want to teach me?”

“When did I ever say that? Do you not want to be taught?”

“No I do! I thought you were just pretending you wanted to because you said you were using me.”

“You want to be a Hunter, that’s all that matters to me. Yes I used you, and I will continue to use you in the future most likely. But I am always serious when it comes to being a Hunter and dealing with anyone who wants to be one too. Those people in there need to get serious about it like you are. Otherwise they will die.”

As we walked out of the school building and he led me towards his place I thought back on my day. It had been full of surprises and perhaps not all my choices had been the best, but the principal was right. I could make a difference here if I wanted to. I just wasn’t sure I wanted to. I didn’t like the feeling of being used as a tool by my mother, dumped here to help improve the place without being told. No idea what thoughts were in her mind that made her think this was a good idea. I didn’t know what path I would walk down yet. But right now that didn’t matter. I just had to take things one day at a time.

***********

For someone who is hotheaded and claims he is not that good with people he didn’t seem to do too bad this first day. Seems like he ended up making two friends. Or at least one friend and an acquaintance. Were his decisions the correct ones to make though? At the time he thought so. But looking back, could he have done better?

Well seeing as you made all the decisions for him, I suppose I should be asking you that question should I not? How much did any one of those decisions alter the course of Riktal’s destiny? Some decisions were of great importance, such as to accept the job of guarding the girl or not. While others might not have been so great. Would you chose differently if given the chance? Perhaps we shall find out the next time you come. And you will return. I see that in your possible future.
11112112121121.title: What do you expect from me?

11112112121122.content:
“I’m not a tool.”

I could feel a bit of the anger rising inside as I said that. Just the thought of how my mother had used me so carelessly made my blood boil.

“Miktal used to say that all the time as well. But the sad truth is, yes you are. We all are. I’m not talking about Hunter’s, I’m talking about everyone in the world. Life is about compromises both big and small. No one in the world has everything go exactly the way they want when they want. We don’t always get to decide how we are used either. At the very basic level what is a Hunter but a glorified tool. We might have made the decision to become Hunters or that decision was made for us, it doesn’t matter. We protect normal people as a job. We dedicate time and effort into being forged into these tools that can do this job. We decided this is what we wanted and allowed ourselves to become tools to be used.”

“Sometimes we are used without our knowledge. Your great grandparents used me against Miktal and I never knew about it until much later. Miktal fought against his parents over the arranged marriage. He said it was archaic and needed to be done away with. He wanted to marry me even though I was just a first generation Hunter. In the end he had to compromise with them, accepting the arranged marriage in order to use the large amounts of the family fortune to help me build this school like he did.”

“When they tried to get him to cast me aside as his mistress though he refused. He said that he had married your grandmother just like they had wanted, but that didn’t mean he had to sleep with her. If they wanted a child to continue the line then he got to keep me. So in that sense he used your father before he was even born. Turning him into a tool that forced his parents to compromise.”

“As I said, Mira knew all about me and she had no problem with Miktal having me as a mistress. Thought we weren’t exactly best friends, we were still close. I was over often for dinner and the like. As long as we kept our relationship discreet all was well. When your father was born I used to baby-sit while the two of them went out doing Hunter duties. Or while Mira went to one of her own lovers for a while. Any time you have interactions with other people it is give and take. Sometimes its so small you don’t notice it. But even the basic idea of a conversation is that compromise of talking and listening. If you want to keep friends you need to learn when to be a user and when to be used.”

“It’s hard to think like that I know. And it doesn’t keep you from getting angry when you are used as a tool, but it’s the truth. It’s a hard road to travel, trying to figure out how much to allow yourself to be used before it is too much. More of a balancing act than anything else. But you are young and you got a good head on your shoulders. I’m sure you will do just fine. Now run along, there are some things I still need to do. And thank you for chatting with an old lady like me.”

She spun her wheelchair around with ease before heading off back the way we had come. I called out to her before she could get far and she spun partway around to look at me.

“Do you mind if we talk again sometime? About my grandparents and what they were like? I really don’t know much about them and I think I’d like to.”

She gave me a small smile.

“My doors always open. Just not during school hours unless it is really important. You are still a student after all. And students should be in class learning.”

She gave a small chuckle as she resumed her journey. I felt the small smile playing on my lips as I turned the corner and reentered through the front doors. It didn’t take long to make it back to my class on the second floor and slip into my seat. As the teacher droned on about Cadaver Dog’s and how to handle them I looked around the classroom at the other kids.

Tools huh? A series of compromises and a balance between using and being used. I had never really thought of it that way but it made sense. Most of these people wanted something from me, prestige by association, friendship, fame. They wanted to use me, but at the same time I had the choice of who I let use me or not in that way. I used the Zelkov name sometimes as well. Not exactly hiding behind it, but using it to make my life easier. I wouldn’t know half the contacts in the Hunter world that I did if I hadn’t been introduced to them by someone else.

Looking back so far on the day I saw that I had used and been used at least a dozen times without me noticing it. In the end I really didn’t mind any of that at all. It had just been natural. I was still angry at my mother for how she had used me and how she didn’t seem to care about my feelings at all. But I couldn’t fault her now either. I had to make sure to apologize to her next time I saw her. If she was on a job she would probably be gone for three or four days. More than enough time to cool off and be able to speak to her normally.

When the bell rang I avoided getting caught up in the crowd of people converging on me for their own personal reasons. Shouldering my bag I made a beeline towards Jethic who was still putting his stuff away.

“You ready to go Jethic? If you have time I can show you where my house is since I doubt you know already. And perhaps we can get in a few hours of combat training.”

“Uh… sure. If you don’t mind stopping at my house first. I stay with my aunt and uncle who get worried when I don’t let them know where I am.”

“Why not just give them a call?”

“I’m a bit stupid remember. I haven’t been able to master the spell yet. And my family is poor so I don’t have the money to buy an artifact.”

I pulled the gold nugget out of my pocket and shoved it into his hand, closing his fingers around it.

“Cash that in and buy yourself a good communication artifact. We will need to keep in touch if I am going to give you private lessons. Plus you should be able to get a hold of your family when you want to. I’ll make sure mine is the first magical id you imprint on it as well. If you don’t know a broker or think any one you do know won’t give you top Reul for it let me know and I will introduce you to a few that I use.”

I motioned to Liz before she had a chance to leave. She walked over with her head cocked to the side waiting for me to say why I had stopped her.

“Would you mind coming over too? It will do him good to have more than one person to spar against. Different speeds and fighting styles will help him improve much faster.”

She gave an offhand shrug.

“Sure I don’t mind. I got nothing better to do. As long as I get at least one sparring match with you. I was impressed by how you kept agro on that monster. I want to see how well I stack up if I go all out.”

“Deal.”

The three of us left the room together and managed to make it down the hall a ways before me and Liz broke out laughing.

“Those looks were gold! It was worth coming with you just to see that bulging eyed, fish out of water reaction.”

“I know right!”

“Um… excuse me. Why are you being so nice to me?”

I looked over at Jethic and grinned.

“Because I want to and because it makes the other kids in class jealous. I’m teaching them a little lesson I guess you could say. One that says I don’t care who they are or who they think they are.”

“Then does that mean you really don’t want to teach me dual shields? You were just using me to tick them off?”

“Of course I want to teach you dual shields. I never would have offered in the first place if I didn’t.”

“Oh.”

“If you want, I can help you master making healing potions. If your magic is so weak you can’t heal yourself you will be going through a lot of them. I can show you a few tricks my father taught me and I am sure Riktal could to.”

Jethic looked at Liz wide eyed, his jaw dropping until I thought it would drag the floor.”

“Seriously!”

“I wouldn’t have said anything if I wasn’t serious.”

“Thanks!”

“One more thing. Once you get your communication device, if you let me borrow it for a few days, I can send a runner to Thorsbough and have your parents imprint their id on it as well so you can talk to them any time.”

“T-thank you!”

“Don’t mention it. After all, family is important. Even if you don’t always see eye to eye with them.”

**************

For someone who is hotheaded and claims he is not that good with people he didn’t seem to do too bad this first day. Seems like he ended up making two friends. Or at least one friend and an acquaintance. Were his decisions the correct ones to make though? At the time he thought so. But looking back, could he have done better?

Well seeing as you made all the decisions for him, I suppose I should be asking you that question should I not? How much did any one of those decisions alter the course of Riktal’s destiny? Some decisions were of great importance, such as to accept the job of guarding the girl or not. While others might not have been so great. Would you chose differently if given the chance? Perhaps we shall find out the next time you come. And you will return. I see that in your possible future.
11112112121122.title: I'm not a tool.

11112112122.content:
“Spank! Arena master! Twin short swords! Stock variety!”

“Standard sword and board set up! Stock short sword for me too!”

We rolled in opposite directions as the Sengwen charged towards us. It’s skittering talons on the floor as it tried to halt its progress and turn around letting us know just how close it was. The floor slid to the side next to me and two weapons racks came into view. I was already yanking off the sword and shield before the rack finished moving, tossing them in Liz’s direction. She grabbed them from mid air, quickly slipping the shield on her left forearm as I pulled my swords from the rack before rolling away again.

The Sengwen just missed ripping into my back with one of it’s claws as it destroyed the stand the weapons had been on. It charged after me as I ran towards Liz who stepped forward as I passed, taking a knee while raising her shield and striking with all her might at the creatures legs as it ran by.

If the creature hadn’t been fed on magic that blow would have severed at least two of the limbs clean off. As it was the blow only made a small scratch which healed up immediately. Until we burned out the magic it had absorbed it was near invulnerable while being significantly stronger and faster. Luckily it didn’t get much smarter.

As the creature began to turn around Liz ran off at an angle so she would be the first thing it saw when it was ready to charge again. When the creature saw her it gave a guttural whinny as she clanged her sword against the shield in challenge. It wasn’t a full body shield, but it was bigger than your average buckler, covering about a third of her body. Your standard Aegis shield.

The beast charged again but this time she stood her ground. Bracing her legs and taking the full brunt of the attack, sliding backwards a few inches. She stabbed at it around the shield while blocking it’s attacks in a classic tanking style. I simply waited a moment for her to grab enough agro on it before I went to work. She gave me a small nod to let me know she was ready as she turned it slightly farther away from me.

With a sword in each hand I ran at the beast. Long swords would have more power because of the length of the blade but I didn’t need power here, I needed speed. Longer swords were also heavier. I could make up for length by using more power from my own body and rotation.

Slice, spin, slice, stab, twirl, stab. Never stop moving. Create quick shallow cuts the magic had to heal. Rapid succession of attacks to drain the magic quickly. When the creature swished his razor sharp tail at me like it was swatting a fly I sliced it off. and continued to attack. When it kicked out at me with it’s hind legs I jumped onto its back and rapidly stabbed downwards with my swords over and over. Seven good hits before it bucked me off and I flipped through the air to land on my feet again. When it turned to face me Liz sliced it across the eyes before smashing it in the face with her shield. It gave a roar of anger before the magic healed it and he returned to attacking Liz.

It only took two minutes to burn the magic away and our cuts didn’t heal almost instantly anymore. I jumped onto its back again, slamming the sword in my right hand into the back of it’s neck. As it roared in pain I swung off to the left while holding firmly onto the blade in my right, shoving my other sword down it’s throat. Using gravity and the rotation of my body I yanked both blades in opposite directions, decapitating the creature.

The body fell to the ground, beginning to dematerialize into dust. Within seconds it was gone, leaving behind two of it’s pure silver claws. As the class and the Arena master came running up to congratulate us I tapped my sword against Liz’s.

“Nice tanking.”

“Not good enough, you pulled agro.”

“That’s my job. But you did your’s and grabbed it back.”

Picking up the two claws I handed one to Liz who slipped it into her pocket with a nod of thanks. The boy named Gregory pointed at us with indignation on his face.

“Hey those are our spoils!”

I glared at him a moment before saying anything.

“First off: the Sengwen you fought had regular talons like a birds. Not real silver ones. Second off: it was your idiot move that transformed the beast into something you couldn’t handle. And thirdly: if you really want it that badly I will be glad to fight you for it. I’ll make sure to rip out your throat with it as well just like that Sengwen would have if we hadn’t stepped in.”

“That’s not fair!”

The Areana Master swept the boys feet out from under him while grabbing his shirt and bearing him to the ground.

“Fair! Fair! Just what kind of game do you think this is you self indulgent little slug? What was fair about how you put the lives of your teammates in danger just to show off? What exactly isn’t fair about them earning the spoils of war and saving an ungrateful pile of monster refuse like you? Being a Hunter isn’t a game! It’s not always fair and neither is this world. It never will be fair. Our job isn’t to make this world fair! Our job is to make this world safe!”

“I gave your group that monster because I thought none of you would do something so stupid and foolhardy. You all showed competence and were a step above the rest in combat training. Obviously my judgment about you was flawed. I’m watching you boy. One more screw up and I’m throwing you back with the beginners.”

“You can’t put your hands on me like this!”

“I’m the Arena Master and you are in the Arena. I can do whatever the hell I want. Besides, haven’t you figured it out by now boy? This isn’t some normal high school. This is a Monster Combat Hunter academy! If we get squeamish about not harming the students then you are all going to die. This is life, deal with it or quit!”

The Arena Master let the boy go after giving him another good shake. He looked around at the rest of the class which had gone silent as they watched the proceedings.

“All of you better keep that in mind. We told you when you entered this school that it wasn’t like other places. We are in the business of teaching you how to survive. Not teaching you how to take shortcuts and try to cheat the system. If you want an easy life where everything is handed to you, you picked the wrong profession. I hope you were all paying attention to how these two worked together. In the real world you won’t always have time for planning. Sometimes you have a few precious seconds to convey everything.”

“Did you see how they used their body language to communicate? How Hawthrope positioned the monster to make it easier for Zelkov to attack? How Zelkov waited for her to catch the thing’s attention? There were at least twenty different weapons he could have used. Do you know why he chose twin short swords? Why not long swords? Why not a pole weapon? Why didn’t they both go sword and board? They both showed you some excellent fighting and first hand experience as to what it takes to be Hunter’s.”

A boy came forward holding his side. I could tell it was the one who had taken the Sengwen’s first blow on his shield and been sent flying. He was the only one in full plate mail, a near necessity for tanks just learning the ropes. He looked at Liz with a starry eyed expression on his face.

“Thanks for rescuing us. That was amazing what you did. I wish I could tank half so well as you.”

Liz looked at the boy with a slight disinterest. At first I thought she wouldn’t say anything then her faced softened just slightly.

“You’ll get there eventually. Apply yourself to the training and take it seriously and you will make it.”

“All right enough jabbering. We still have a lot of time before class is over. Reform into new groups..”

The Arena Master continued to point out who would be in what groups as me and Liz climbed back up into the bleacher’s. As we sat down I pulled out the talon, twirling it in my fingers.

“I know someone who would pay good money for this. Pure silver made through a magical transmutation and probably still holding traces of that magic. Perhaps get around a thousand Reul for it. You got anyone you can take yours to?”

“Yeah, a friend of the family. He deals in simple stuff like this.”

“Ok, cool. Just checking.”

I pocketed the talon again and turned my attention to watching the groups continue their sparring with monsters. Paying special attention to the boy named Gregory.
11112112122.title: Spank

111121121221.content:
The rest of Combat Class went by without incident. I was already able to pick out a few of the ones that had a knack for leading. I also got a feel for each of their respective skill levels compared to mine. There were a few stand-outs, such as the boy who had taken the Sengwen’s blow. He was the best tank specialty Hunter out of all the other tank types I had seen in this class.

Me an Liz chatted a bit more about small things here and there. Pointing out our thoughts on how they were handling the challenges set before them. When the bell finally rang it felt like we had known each other for a few months and not just a few hours. The first thing I did was check my duffle bag, finding only one of the weapons I had been missing had been returned. My Lexington double barrel was still nowhere to be found. I zipped up my bag and shouldered it, looking around the room at the other boys who were glancing my way out of the corner of their eyes. I headed for the door without a word, stopping to look back at all of them before leaving.

“At least one of you was smart enough to take me seriously. My amnesty ends now. I am still missing one weapon. I will entertain the thought that it was one of the girls, but I find this outcome unlikely. If any of you knows anything about the culprit, I will gladly pay a one thousand Reul reward leading to me finding him. You had your chance whoever you are. I have no shame in you knowing exactly how I will find you. Or how little your life is worth to me. You had best be able to run far and run fast. But know that I will still find you. Let the hunt begin.”

I headed straight for History class, settling down in my seat as the rest of the class filed in. The boys watched me speculatively, some of them probably wondering if they could cheat me out of that thousand Reul no doubt. Most of the girls also had speculative looks, but for an entirely different reason. They wanted to be seen as my girlfriend and were plotting on how to go about making that a reality.

I just had to get through this day. Tomorrow would be more normal academics such as the regular math and science type classes you would find at a regular school. Then the day after would be back to today’s schedule. Even if this was a Hunter academy, they still had to teach at least basic courses. At least I had business economics to look forward to tomorrow.

The teacher had just started talking about how the Lindum Treaty had changed the balance of power in the world when a short stocky woman with an eye patch over her right eye came into the room. Her low cut yellow dress went well with her blond hair. The few streaks of gray almost unnoticeable unless you knew where to look.

My bag was in my hands and I was halfway to the front of the class by the time Hilda finished whispering to the teacher and he turned to point at me. He blinked in surprise that I was already there even as I left the room with my mother’s aide.

“So what does my mother want with me this time? And before you say anything, I know it’s not your place to say, but you will say it anyway because you’re you.”

“A job. An official job if it comes to that but she would like to keep it unofficial if possible.”

“So the usual. My mother being my mother huh? Treating me as a full fledged Hunter when it is convenient for her.”

“It’s not my place to say either way. She has her reasons.”

“She always does. Rarely does she deign to tell us mere mortals what they are.”

“Riktal, I’ve been one of your mother’s aides for a long time. I’ll be the first to admit she has her faults. I’ll also admit sometimes she doesn’t make the best decisions, but she does think about you and I can only assume she doesn’t want to tell you the reasons why in order to protect you in some way.”

“I don’t need protecting. She didn’t train me to become a Hunter just so I could be protected. Make sure you tell her I’m coming to the end of my patience with the way she is. She never seems to listen to me when I say such things. Perhaps you can make her see sense. One of these day’s I’m just going to wash my hands of her completely. Her and the Zelkov name. All because she wants to play people like puppets as she sees fit.”

“I’ll tell her.”

“What you are to polite to say is that it probably won’t do any good. Sorry to drop this on you Hilda. I know it’s not your fault. She just makes me so angry.”

“I know hon. Just… try to be nice to her today ok? This job she was asked to do might be a bit much for her. She’s getting old and her reaction times aren’t what they used to be. You know how she has a hard time accepting things like that. She will be doing the job with your father, but even then this might be the last time you see her.”

“We are Hunter’s. Every job might be our last.”

“I know that. But I also know that despite everything you say you still love her. Even if you sometimes can’t stand to be in the same room with her. She’s worried. She won’t admit it or show it but she really is worried.”

“That bad huh?”

“Yes.”

“Good I hope it straightens her out. Maybe if she lost an arm or a leg or something it will teach her a lesson.”

“How is it you became so cold?”

“Try asking that after you grew up with my mother for seventeen years.”

She finally shook her head sadly before opening the door to the meeting room for me. My mother jumped out of her chair when I entered coming over to embrace me, kissing my cheeks quickly. Behind her at the table sat a red eyed white haired little girl around eleven or twelve years old. She wore a tattered green dress that had the same shade as vomit and some well used shoes that peeked out from under the table. In her hand’s she held a teddy bear that was at least three shades of brown with frizzled curly fur. I could see the faint water marks where tears had probably soaked into the fabric.

“Riktal darling! It’s so good to see you again! Please take a seat.”

I took a chair opposite my mother and the little girl.

“Again? I saw you just this morning remember? Or has it been so long since you spent that much time with me you forgot that fact already? So what is it you want mother?”

She ignored my comment as her Hunter face dropped into place.

“I’ve got a small favor to ask of you. I want you to guard this girl. Her name is Asala and she just lost her parents three days ago in a tragic accident.”

“So? Let some other Hunter baby-sit. You know, like one that has a license.”

“There are complications.”

“Such as?”

“She is a monster summoner. You are really good with kids and you’ve stated before how you don’t mind people with that ability.”

“Just tell her not to use her power then and things will be fine.”

“That’s just it. She can’t control her power. When she has strong emotions they sort of activate. A monster summoner I know will come take her off your hands in a few days, but until then I need someone I can trust and I know can take care of anything she might summon.”

“Do it yourself.”

“I can’t. I was hired to do a job over in Bornica with your father. That place would be way to dangerous for a little girl like her. Even if they didn’t have that little war over the succession going on.”

“Interesting. So you get back from your last job last night. Stay home for less than eight hours and decided to accept another job up in the far north for another country when you don’t need to actually do so. Probably accepting the job because you didn’t want to deal with this kid just like you never wanted to deal with me as your son. Deciding to just push her off on me because it is convenient for you to treat me like a real Hunter instead of some guy you forbid from taking the Exams. I bet if I ask why me, you will say something like because you are family. As if that meant anything to me.”

I stood up shaking my head.

“Sorry not happening. You’re on your own mother. Just like I always am. Either take her with you, decline the job for Bornica and watch her yourself, or take your chances with some other sap who you can con into believing you actually care what happens to her. Don’t think I don’t know what side of the fence you lean towards when it comes to monster summoner’s. You might not want them dead on sight like most other Hunter’s, but you wouldn’t shed a tear if it happened. Probably hope she dies under my watch so you have a real reason to say I’m not ready to be a Hunter yet.”

I walked out the door, ignoring my mother’s pleas for me to wait. I sensed the presence around the corner as I headed off down the hall so wasn’t surprised to find the principal sitting there in her wheelchair.

“Riktal. Would you take a walk with an old lady for a little bit?”
111121121221.title: On to History class

1111211212211.content:
With a sigh I turned and walked alongside the principal as she wheeled herself down the side hall. She didn’t say anything until after she expertly swiveled around to open the door with her chair before backing out and going down the single step.

“You should take the job.”

“And you shouldn’t eavesdrop on conversations that have nothing to do with you. Doesn’t mean either one of us will listen. If I don’t like it when my mother tries to manipulate me into doing things, why do you think you would have better success?”

“You really are a lot like him.”

“Him who?”

“Nothing. Just an old woman talking to herself.”

“I heard about your declaration in the Combat Class.”

“And?”

“Would you mind rescinding it if I got your weapon back for you? There are enough problems going around in the world, I’d really like to avoid something like this if I can help it.”

“If you can get the weapon back that’s fine but I’m not going back on my word. Thieves like that need to be taught a lesson. They will be lucky if I don’t kill them. If it is a girl I will go easy. Not because they are a girl but because they did not hear my proclamation.”

“But you don’t think it was a girl.”

“No.”

“Why did you make such a statement at all?”

“To let them know exactly what the consequences of their actions would be. Cause and effect.”

“And why did you go about it the way you did? There was plenty of different ways to handle the situation. Even different ways to phrase your words.”

“Why all the questions?”

“Humor an old woman.”

“Because that’s the kind of Hunter I was raised to be. To speak the truth and be fair in my dealings.”

“And what is a Hunter’s job? At it’s core I mean.”

“To protect people.”

“So do you think you were being fair to that little girl? I’m not saying your mother is a saint. I’ve gotten angry at her myself on more than one occasion. But is it fair of you to deny that girl your protection simply because of your anger towards your mother? True the way she goes about things can be a bit unfair. Underhanded at times even. But is that really a good enough excuse for you to not do your job as a Hunter?”

“You might not have a license, but you are still looked upon as an official slayer. I’m sure you have your own contacts. Brokers, business partners and acquaintances in the Hunter world. Some of them you got through your family name I’m sure, but others you made yourself. I bet you’ve already done some jobs for a few people. Maybe not big ones, but important ones to them. Even your mother recognizes you as one if she came seeking your help. She might not admit it but you would know better than I that she wouldn’t have come asking your help if she didn’t think you were as capable as any Hunter out there.”

“And what are your thoughts on the girl being a monster summoner? What side of the fence are you on?”

“I’ll admit I am a bit biased. I can tolerate them but I don’t really like them. I’m not as kill crazy as some but I wouldn’t be heartbroken if one died. But then again I grew up on stories about the old wars where summoners would send their tamed pets to terrorize and kill innocent people. It’s only been in the last hundred years or so that summoners have tried to be more help then hindrance. But they have a lot of history to overcome. Perhaps that’s a mindset you can understand?”

We rounded the corner and came in sight of the front of the school. My mother, the little girl and Hilda were all just walking out the front door and heading towards the gates. The principal wheeled herself in front of me, looking up into my face with compassionate eyes.

“Are you really going to put your job as a Hunter to the side because of your anger? I don’t know if she came to you first, last or what. But the fact is she came to you asking for help. If you really think some other Hunter could do a better job of understanding that little girl and helping her than you then just do nothing. But are you willing to feel as helpless as you did with Olia if things go wrong?”

“Just who are you?”

“Just an old lady who has eyes and ears everywhere.”

I watched as my mother tugged on the little girls arm absentmindedly. Not even caring if she was hurting the girl or not. Just too concerned about getting to her next appointment or being someplace else like she always was. Yet I could still let them go. It wasn’t my problem. Just two minutes and they would be out of my life.
1111211212211.title: Walk with her

11112112122111.content:
“You think you have me all figured out don’t you?”

“Not at all. I just think you are very much like someone I used to know in some respects. He wouldn’t have been able to turn his back on that little girl. He would have hated himself if he did.”

“And where is he now?”

“Dead just like most of the people I grew up with. But he died doing what he loved and for the person he loved. And never once did he regret that decision.”

“How do you know that?”

“Because he told me with his last breath.”

I clicked my tongue in a bit of disgust as I headed towards the little group. Damn that old woman. She was right about all of it. I just couldn’t be stubborn with the girls life on the line. I would have regretted it if I had simply let them walk away. My mother saw me coming and turned to face me expectantly.

“I’m taking the Hunter’s Exam whether you like it or not as soon as this job is done. That’s my payment for taking this job. Take it or leave it.”

“Honey I told you before…”

“Take it or leave it. You have ten seconds to make up your mind. After ten seconds I walk away. If you truly think me capable enough of a Hunter for this job then there should be no problems. If you are just trying to throw your problems at me and have me clean them up for you then walk away. Even if you still push her off on me and don’t think me capable I still get my Hunter license. Either way I get what I want. So tell me, what’s more important to you? Your undefined reasons for me coming to this school or doing your job as a Hunter and protecting the innocent? In this case this girl.”

My mother looked at me a moment but didn’t say anything.

“One.”

“Riktal…”

“Two.”

“Can’t we talk this over?”

“Three.”

What if I give you twenty thousand Reul instead?

“Four.”

I continued my steady count as she looked from me to the girl and back again.

“Eight.”

“Ok you win. You can take the Exams if and only if you can get her to talk by the time she leaves.”

“No deal. I stated my price. It is non negotiable. Whether she lives, dies, talks or destroys this entire town I am taking the test. Last chance. Nine.”

She nibbled her lip a moment but didn’t say anything.

“Ten. Goodbye mother.”

As I turned to head out the front gates she called out to me. I smiled thinly to myself before clamping down on it and turning around with a bland expression on my face.

“Fine you win. It’s a deal. How can you be so unfair about all this?”

“I think I was more than fair. Fairer then you usually are with me. As you have told me time and again, life isn’t fair. If you have a problem with how I do things as a Hunter then take it up with my mother and father. This is how they raised me. Now go away. Don’t you have some civil war or something to fight? You don’t need to be yanking on a girl you don’t want any more than you have to do you?”

She opened and closed her mouth a few times but finally left me and the girl alone as my father pulled up in our car. He gave me a wave and I waved back, a bit surprised to actually see him since he wasn’t supposed to be done with his last job for another day or two. He had promised to play some chess with me when he got back, but it seemed that would be put on hold even longer if he was doing a job with my mother. Just another normal week at the Zelkov house.

Once they drove off I knelt in front of the girl who hadn’t reacted to any of what had been said over her head. She reminded me of a doll or a puppet that only moved when someone pulled her strings. She didn’t respond to my light touch on her arm or have any kind of recognition of the world around her in her eyes.

“So your name is Asala huh? That’s a pretty name. Ugly dress but pretty name. I want you to know that I really do care if you die or not. I just said all that to my mother as a bargaining tool. If you give her an inch she takes ten miles. I’d like for you to trust me. Though I know my words and actions thus far really haven’t lent themselves well to my cause.”

“I bet you are probably scared out of your mind right now. Never did really understand that phrase. How can you be scared out of your mind when your mind is inside you? Unless we were to walk around turned inside out, but that would be kind of disgusting don’t you think? I also bet you are pretty hungry. Never met a little girl or boy yet who wasn’t always hungry. So We will go home. I’ll make you something nice and hearty to eat and we can get to know each other. Maybe play a few games and settle you in.”

“Then tomorrow if you feel up to it we can go out shopping when there aren’t a lot of people around. My guess you need some new clothes. Even if you don’t my eyes are bleeding looking at that dress. It makes me want to bury it in the trash piles. I will be with you all the time and I will pay attention to only you. It’s my job to worry about you and make sure you are happy. Well maybe not the job she wanted me to do exactly, but I am making it my personal job to make you happy. So how does all that sound to you?”

No reaction. Just that same blank stare that seemed to look through me. No I was wrong. There was a slight reaction. She squeezed her bear just a fraction. But it was a start. I gave her a reassuring smile before taking her by the hand and leading her away, making sure not to pull too hard and drag her. Simply slowing down my pace to walk next to her and guiding her with a hand on her shoulders.

******************

Well wasn’t that an interesting first day? Plots and choices and twists galore. How do you think his day went? Could it have been better? Could it have been worse? Did you make the right choices for him? Would you make them differently? What far reaching affects could the choices you made have on his life or on his interactions with others in the future? How much different is his life and his future now than if he had made a few different choices this day? Or would the day have turned out the same no matter what? Was it all simply predestined?

Constants and variables. These two things rule the world. Even if your choices are always constant, the choices of those around you are variable. The environment is variable. Just a small change in any one of these things can alter the thoughts and the destiny of a single person. If both his weapons had appeared back in his bag, would he have approached the meeting with his mother differently?

Perhaps you can come again and find out. Alter his life and play god one more time. Though the possibilities as they say are endless. This possibility has finally ended. Until we meet again in another possibility.
11112112122111.title: Go accept the job

11112112122112.content:
“You think you got me all figured out don’t you.”

“Not at all. I just think you are very much like someone I used to know. He would not have turned his back on that little girl. He would have hated himself if he did.”

“That’s where I am different. The girl will be fine. She might be uncomfortable being pulled around but if my mother or some other Hunter is taking care of her she will live. As long as you live you can change. Isn’t that what they say? It’s true I might regret not going to help her, but my mother needs to be taught a lesson. I’m through jumping through her hoops. Let her deal with her own problems for once instead of pushing them off on me.”

I watched as my dad pulled up in one of our cars and the three of them got inside. They were gone a second later as I continued walking. I didn’t even look back as I called out to the principal.

“I’m not so easy to manipulate. A few soft words and a logical argument or two isn’t always enough to sway me anymore. I’ve grown up hearing enough for them from my mother I’m a bit immune to them now. Figure out another way to get me to do what you want. Perhaps by just being honest with me instead of speaking in riddles. That’s a novel idea don’t you think principal?”

I turned out the gates and headed home. Not even bothering to go back to class until the end of the day. I was done for now. Finding the thief could wait one day. I had simply had enough of it all. The walk home went by in a blur. A part of me did regret but it was easy enough to ignore.

Once home I made myself a quick ham sandwich, eating it while walking through the empty three floor mini mansion. It was always empty and quiet like this. Hardly ever any guests and when there were it was along the lines of foreign dignitaries.

The walls were littered with photos. Not your normal family pictures though like in a non Hunter house. There was big sis with her prize for best knife thrower in seventh grade. There was the picture of my first kill. A few of mom and dad. But none with all of us together. The story of being a Zelkov. Never together but always around somewhere.

All except for one Zelkov. A little girl my mother wanted to pretend never existed.

I slipped upstairs and dug out the old shoebox I had hidden in my closet. Pulling the top off I looked down into my little sister’s smiling face as I gave her a piggyback ride. Hair the color of sunset, eyes as green as the ocean with little flecks of white like foam. Big and round as only a ten year olds could be. Missing two teeth on the top that had always made her whistle a bit when she talked. These were the only photos in the house where more than one Zelkov was together. It had taken a lot of work to protect them with my magic when they had been thrown in the fire. Deceiving my mother into believing they had all burned.

I slid another big box out and dug through it, pushing a bunch of stuffed animals to the side. Yet a few more mementos of Olia’s. Finally I found her favorite blue tattered and beat up bunny that was missing an eye. I hugged it close to my chest as I stared down at the picture in my hand.

“Hey sis. It’s been a while hasn’t it? You probably think your big brother is pretty despicable don’t you? You are probably yelling at me right now from up there aren’t you? Probably wondering how I turned out like this. I changed sis. Ever since you died I’ve changed. your brother is a pretty heartless person. I had to grow up strong. So mother couldn’t roll over me anymore.”

“But your brother is going to become a Hunter. I’ve made up my mind I’m going to take the Exams whether mother likes it or not. Even if I have to give up the family name. It’s not like I was that attached to it anyway. I’m going to become a strong Hunter just like I promised. And then I’m going to take you to see the world. We will visit all the places you dreamed of going. We will dance together at the winter feast in Kapala. We will see the rare Snow Lions of the far north and we will yell as loud as we can from the top of Mt. Piniak.”

“I love mom and dad and big sis Ulicia don’t get me wrong. As messed up as it all is and despite the way we were treated I still love them. But we aren’t really a family. I can’t even remember the last time all four of us were in this house together at the same time. Or even the last time someone went up to the third floor. Mom and dad were never around for us. First big sis took care of me and then she moved out. Then it was just me and you. Back then we only had each other. I had no clue what I was doing as a big brother but somehow I muddled through. I’m sorry I wasn’t able to protect you. I should have stopped mother that day. But I didn’t. I’m so sorry.”

I rubbed the tears from my eyes as the first few drops fell onto the photo. It really had been a while since I had thought of Olia. She had been dead three years but sometimes like now it still felt like yesterday. I had learned to go on. Life waited for no one. I brought the rabbit up to my face and inhaled deeply. If I closed my eyes I could almost imagine smelling the light perfume she liked to wear.

I jerked my eyes open suddenly. I must have fallen asleep. I wanted to go back to sleep. To see Olia again. But I was hungry. And I was wide awake. Sleep wouldn’t come back so easily. So I levered myself to my feet and went downstairs to make another sandwich. The clock said it was eight o’clock but time really meant nothing to me. I went into the living room and flicked on the TV, turning over to the news channel to see if anything interesting had happened.

“…..Earlier today a Pit Lord ravaged downtown Efenbis City. Two thousand citizens and almost all the buildings in a two block radius were caught in it’s destructive rampage. Thanks to the combined efforts of Monster Combat Hunter’s all across the city, the damage was kept to a minimum. If it hadn’t been for the fact that two members of the Zelkov family were on the scene to contain it as long as they did, it’s possible the entire city could have been destroyed.”

“Unfortunately the heroic efforts of Marian and Ramone Zelkov were their last. They both died moments before help arrived. Authorities believe the Pit Lord was the work of a monster summoner but as of yet have found no clues as to where such a powerful summoner has hidden himself. Of the few survivors there was a little girl whom was found unconscious under the body of Marian Zelkov. It is believed Mrs. Zelkov protected her with her dying breath. She is currently in Janseen Hospital where doctors are anxiously awaiting her recovery so she might shed some light on how this travesty transpired.”

The half eaten sandwich dropped from my fingers as the full impact of the news hit me. They were dead? Sure I had my problems with them but I didn’t want them dead. It was the girl. She had summoned the Pit Lord. How or why I didn’t know but she was the culprit. She had killed my parents.

As if of its own accord my body stood up and walked towards the door, hitting the code on the safe in the hallway wall I pulled out a six shooter and attached a silencer onto it before shoving it into my belt and covering it with my tunic. Opening the door outside I grabbed the keys to the other car. It only took ten minutes to drive to the hospital and another three to find her room. At first the police guarding her door and the nurses wouldn’t give me any information but when I told them I was a Zelkov they let me through without any hassle

She opened her eyes when I walked in and stood over the bed. She still had the blank stare of unseeing she had earlier today. It was her way of escaping from reality I guess. I pulled the gun out and placed it against her head.

“You killed them both. I had my problems with them but they were still my family. I didn’t hate them that much. You’re dangerous. If you are strong enough to summon a Pit Lord you are too much of a threat both to this town and this world with your unstable ability. I can’t let you harm any more innocent people.”
11112112122112.title: Let them walk away

111121121221121.content:
“I’m sorry. Rest in peace. I hope you get to see your family again.”

I pulled the trigger, hearing the small pfft sound as the bullet shot through her head. There was a moment when the world just stood still and then the white pillow beneath her began to turn crimson. Her dead eyed stare of earlier was now truly lifeless. The monitoring machines beeped loudly and the police ran in followed by the nurses.

Calmly I stuck my weapon back into my belt while jerking my head towards the girl.

“I killed your monster summoner for you. Saved you the trouble before she could summon another one. I doubt my mother was trying to save her when she died. She was probably trying to kill her but failed. I just finished the job. Now if you will excuse me I need to go grieve for my parents.”

I pushed past the two nurses and two cops, heading off down the hall still in a bit of a daze. They were all dead. Olia was dead. Asala was dead. The only family I had left was big sis Ulicia. I wondered if she would even bother to come home when she heard the news. Or if she would just finish her job like the good Hunter she had been raised as.

Right now it didn’t matter. I’d just go back to the house that was always silent and always empty. Though mother and father would never show up again now. It was just another day in the Zelkov household.

Almost. But never again.

********

A true tragedy this ending. Was there anything he could have done to prevent it? If he had accepted the job, would it have been him being mourned instead of his parents? From what point on this timeline did things go wrong? Was it not accepting the job? Or did this cascade of events begin all the way back at the beginning when you refused to have him give his last name? Was this outcome inevitable? What would have happened if you hadn’t pulled the trigger?

You can always play god once more and find out. Alter the timeline greatly or just a bit as you see fit. Endless possibilities await.
111121121221121.title: Pull the trigger

111121121221122.content:
Slowly I pulled the weapon away and let out a sigh.

“I know this is the best choice. It’s the logical thing to do. And I am angry enough right now to kill you. But I already made enough bad choices today. The biggest one was not accepting the job of protecting you. Even though I know you summoned that Pit Lord, I also know it wasn’t your fault. I don’t know what the circumstances were or why it happened but it happened.”

“As long as you live there is the possibility to change. And as long as you live you will be burdened with the knowledge that your power killed my parents who died protecting you like true Hunter’s. As well as thousands of innocent people. I think that is a worse punishment than a simple bullet to the brain. If you don’t want this to happen again then change it yourself. Quit hiding inside your mind and work to control your powers instead of letting them control you.”

I snagged a nearby chair and pulled it over to sit next to her bed.

“It seems I’ve got no family now. Well I have my big sister, but I doubt she will grieve long. This won’t affect her much at all. It didn’t affect her much when my little sister died. She went back to business as usual after less than a month.”

“Right now it looks like I am in need of a family and you are in need of one too. I might not be the best big brother but I have some experience. I’ll stay with you from now on. Even when mother’s summoner acquaintance comes to pick you up, I’ll go with you. I’ve really got nothing left tying me here.”

“I won’t lie. I’m probably going to hate you for a bit because of what you took from me. But it won’t stop me from protecting and caring for you as best I can. Being there for you like I wished there had been someone there for me. I wanted to be a Hunter so badly that I let that blind me to what our job is really all about. That stubbornness of mine is also to blame for what happened. So I’ll put that on hold for now while I take care of you. Losing sight of such a simple fact so easily tells me I’m not ready for my license.”

“I promise to protect you and help you control your powers. But you need to promise me you will try to control them. You will confide in me and cry on my shoulder if you need it. You’ve got to let me coddle you and make you feel embarrassed. You’ve got to laugh at some of my bad jokes even if they aren’t funny. You’ve got to put up with me hugging you and telling you to pursue your dreams. Maybe even me kissing your cheeks or messing up your hair.”

“You’ve also got to accept random gifts from me for no reason. This includes but is not limited to clothes, stuffed animals, dolls, and accessories. Oh and you have to call me big brother. That one is a must. Even if you balk at some of the other ones, that point isn’t negotiable. And when you grow up and learn to control your power we will tour the world together. We will go places you want to go and see sights you want to see. Find the rare Snow Lion in the far northern wastes. Dance together at the winter festival in Kapala and yell our lungs out at the top of Mt. Piniak. Can you agree to all that if I let you live?”

For a while she didn’t move or blink until she finally nodded her head slowly and her eyes began to water. She rolled over to the side as I pulled her into an embrace and let her cry, feeling the tears streaming down my face too. After what seemed like forever but was only five minutes on the clock she pulled away and laid back down. I held her hand as she stared at the ceiling.

“Let me tell you about my little sister Olia. She was a lot like you. Always used to cry a lot. I really loved her. More than anyone else in my family. She had all these grand dreams for when she grew up.”

I continued to tell her about Olia as both our eyes continued to water. As long as you live you can change. And as long as you live you can forgive.

*******

Well that is a bit of a twist. Did you know that was going to happen? Or are you just a softie at heart? This was one serious roller coaster ride for young Riktal. But it seems though he has lost much, he has gained more. Perhaps this was destiny from the beginning. Things would always turn out this way.

Though would it if you had not intervened? What path would he have chosen for himself I wonder. If he had the power to do so that is. Are you satisfied with your choices? Do you regret some of them now that you look back? What would you do different.?

Perhaps next time you will show me exactly what you would do differently. What new paths lie in store for you?
111121121221122.title: Don't pull the trigger

1111211212212.content:
“Sorry. I’m not in the mood to listen to you right now. I’m late for class. After all, my mother wanted me to come here so I shouldn’t disappoint her by skipping classes.”

“I heard about your declaration in the Combat Class.”

“Don’t worry I will make sure they are off school property before I wreck them. Even if I have to drag them off myself.”

“I’d rather you didn’t hurt them at all.”

I began walking off down the hall giving her my parting comment without looking back.

“And I’d rather be taking the Hunter’s Exams right now instead of wasting my time in this school. Seems neither one of us will get what we want.”

I slipped into last period as quietly as I could, setting my bag down next to me and studying the class while tuning out the lesson. One of these people was the culprit. There was one who kept glancing back at me nervously. And a few that looked speculative. By the time the bell rang I had narrowed it down from the twelve boys in the room to only five. Though of those five I was about ready to cross of two of them simply because one had the starry eyed hero worship look when he glanced at me.
