The other I remembered as the first boy to come into the gym from the locker room which put him low on the list to begin with.

As I got up to leave the first boy I had noted who had been constantly glancing at me came up and stopped me.

“Uh- can I speak with you privately for a moment?”

“Of course. We can wait a few moments for the room to clear or we can go somewhere else.”

“Here is fine.”

There were a few lingerer’s, probably hoping to hear our conversation or maybe to find an opportunity to talk to me for their own personal reasons. A hard glare made them change their mind and leave the two of us alone. The boy checked outside the door to make sure no one was eavesdropping before going back over to his desk a moment. He returned with my Lexinton in his hand shaking a little nervously.

“Would you be willing to extend that amnesty just a little bit?”

“You aren’t the one who stole it are you?”

“No. I-I took it from the person who did. I don’t want them to get hurt for being stupid or stubborn or anything like that,”

“That’s a lie. If you are going to lie to my face at least do a more convincing job. Don’t stutter, make eye contact, don’t try to shrink into yourself and avert your face. Those are all your bodies way of rejecting your words and saying they are false. my guess is whoever had this gun put you up to this. He was too chicken to do it himself so he sent you in his place. Set you up to take the fall if things go south.”

The boy didn’t say anything, simply turned his head to the side, proving my words accurate. He finally tried to deny it but the words died on his lips. With a grunt of displeasure I plucked the weapon from his hands and shoved it into my bag after making sure the safety was on.

“I’ll take my gun back but that doesn’t change the fact that I am going to give him a beating he will never forget. You should choose your friends more carefully if they are so quick to throw you to the wolves to save their own skin. But I do thank you. Not just for giving me my weapon back, but also for making it so much easier to find him. He didn’t think about the fact that I could use a tracer spell to follow his magical essence did he? He handled this gun so his magic is imprinted on it.”

I began heading towards the door but the boy stopped me. I looked back expectantly.

“I-if your going to hurt him then hurt me too. I’m the one who took the knuckles. It was stupid and I didn’t want to but he talked me into it. But that doesn’t change the fact that I still took them.”

“My knuckles aren’t missing boy. They were never taken in the first place. I don’t know what you are talking about. Though if someone is able to talk you into doing something you don’t want to do originally, then I suggest growing a backbone. We are the creators of our own destiny, not someone else. In the end we decide to make the choices in our life. Even the act of doing nothing is a choice. To listen and to give in to someone else’s urgings is a choice. As a Hunter you need to ask yourself what your choices say about you. Do they uphold your personal values? Are they flexible to suit your needs? Do they help you become a better Hunter?”

I left the boy standing there as I cast the spell on the weapon. Three string like lines of magic became visible to my sight emanating from it. The purple one was mine, the green one led back into the classroom so I could strike it off the list as well. The light blue one headed towards the front doors and that was the one I followed.

It led me off school grounds and into town. It wandered around a bit but still headed straight for one of the middle class residential districts. I had to be just a few steps behind him, but I didn’t run. I had no need to run. There was nowhere he could escape to fast enough with the range I had on my tracer spell. It finally lead me to a small house with a little wooden fence around it. Without hesitation I knocked on the door. There was a moment of footsteps before the door opened and a middle aged woman answered.

“Yes can I help you?”

“Yes. Sorry to intrude ma’am but I came to see your son. I’m a friend of his from school.”

“Really! Hold on. Gregory just came back. Let me call him. Please come inside.”

I waited in the hall while she called up the stairs. Of course it would be Gregory. He had been high on my list already. Even though he had not been one of the last ones into the Arena, he had proven he had the showboating personality who’s ego would be stroked by something like this.

` “Yeah what is it mom?”

He came pounding down the steps while not really paying attention to his surroundings. By the time he noticed me I was already running up the steps towards him. His eyes widened as he tried to turn and run but I was already on him. Grabbing him by his shirt collar I threw him the rest of the way down the steps. As he tumbled to the floor I jumped from my position to land next to him, administering a sharp kick to his stomach that lifted him from his feet and sent him flying a few inches.

I ignored his mother’s exclamations for me to stop, backhanding her absently across the face when she tried to pull me away.

“Steal from me! Did you think I wouldn’t find you! Did you think sending someone else in your place would earn you any favors! I gave you a chance and you blew it! I said I would show no quarter and no mercy. Did you forget about tracer spells!”

I stomped down hard on his left elbow joint, grabbing his hand and pulling upwards. He shrieked in agony as the bone popped out of place and I kicked him again in his mouth. His father came out of one of the side rooms then pointing a gun at me. I simply lifted his son up and used him as a shield. He hesitated, lowering the weapon a fraction and that’s when I struck. I shot out my right hand by Gregory’s side, slamming a purple energy ball into his father’s chest. I shoved the boy into the wall before dashing over to his parents and using a stasis spell on them.

“My beef is not with you two, though I will hurt you if you get in my way. Thank your son for the predicament you are in now. In fact lets have him tell you why he is getting the snot kicked out of him while you sit here immobilized.”

I went back over and picked Gregory up by the hair, bringing my leg up and then dropping the heel back down quickly on top of his kneecap. There was a sickening pop as his leg buckled and he gave another howl of pain.

“So how about it Gregory? Why don’t you tell your parent’s exactly what kind of lowlife Hunter you are.”

He continued to howl until I brought my fist up into his gut again, causing him to spit out a bit of vomit and saliva.

“Perhaps phrasing it as a question was too much for you. Then let me make it simple. I will continue to beat on you until you tell your parent’s everything.”

I shoved my knee up into his kidney while pulling his body into the blow before letting him fall to the floor clutching himself with his good right arm. He coughed up a bit of blood before finally telling them everything. I had to administer a few more kicks and dislocate a shoulder before I could convince him to finish his story but he was willing to cooperate with me without too much hassle.

When he was finally done I released his parent’s from my spell, picking up my duffle bag where I had dropped it in the hall and opening the front door. I looked over my shoulder at where his parents were trying to help him heal with their magic as best they could.

“Next time you steal from me I will kill you. This was the only warning you will get. If you want to be a worthy Hunter then do worthy things. If you straighten your act out you could be a good Hunter. Grow up a bit and lose that ego trip of yours.”

With that I left them alone, heading back out onto the street and taking a breath of fresh air. It was almost five o’clock by the bells that rang in the distance. I could go home or go into town for a bit. Neither choice was too appealing to me right now, but I didn’t mind either one at the moment either.
1111211212212.title: Walk away

11112112122121.content:
Might as well go into town and eat out or something. It wasn’t like there was anyone or anything waiting for me at home besides silence. Perhaps some mindless walking around would help me cool my head and resist the urge to go back inside so I could continue to beat the crap out of Gregory.

As I walked, I noted the carefree way children played in their yards or on the sidewalks. How people talked happily together as if the threat of some monster suddenly coming into town and destroying things never entered their minds. It was because they felt safe. They knew that if anything happened a Hunter or Hunter’s would protect them. It wasn’t that they weren’t afraid, but they didn’t let that fear rule them. They took what precautions they could but they didn’t let themselves be paralyzed by their fear. That was one of the many powers of the animal called human, their resilience.

I spent a little time at one of the many restaurants scattered around the city, simply observing the people on the street and ignoring the waitresses who were unobtrusively pointing at me and whispering behind their hands. I had gotten used to such things over the years. It was hard not to when almost everyone knew you were a Zelkov on sight. Or at least from an old family because of all those small tells such as bearing and that invisible aura of surety.

Across the street some alarm bells began going off in the bank. I watched as a robber in a ski mask came rushing out of the building shooting his weapon back inside as he made his escape. He turned right to get away just as my mother rounded the corner dragging the girl Asala along behind her. Nearly pulling her over as she roughly yanked on her arm in vexation.

I was already jumping to my feet as my mother turned her head towards the masked man. The robber leveled his weapon and fired. My mother threw out a quick ball of purple energy just as the girl screamed and a red circle began to appear on the ground. The bullet and the energy collided over the circle and exploded, causing the summoning portal to ripple and warp. There was a shift in the very fabric of the air around me, as if the world had just cracked in half even as I ran out the door.

A hand shot out of the circle, one so massive it almost defied logic. The robber was snagged up completely and crushed into bloody pulp in seconds. Not even a hint of his head or feet showing around the edges, meaning the palm was at least seven or eight feet wide. By the time I was crossing the street at a dead run, most of the rest of the body had pulled itself through the circle. Standing at least seven stories tall the Pit Lord’s eyes burned with pure malevolence. The orbs were literally burning as it let out a roar that shook the ground.

My mother grabbed up the girl and jumped backwards as it swung its left fist down at them. The punch struck the ground and made a two foot crater, the shockwaves bringing down the two buildings next to it and cutting off the screams coming from inside. My father came dashing out of a weapons shop slightly farther down the road and ran towards the beast. I used a touch of magic to amplify my voice as I unzipped my bag.

“Mom! Dad! I’ll take top!”

Throwing the bag out wide I expanded a field of magic around myself to catch and hold the weapons as they flew from the duffle. The swords, shields and guns all floated round me as my mother shot an emergency call to arms into the air to gather all Hunter’s as fast as possible. Even as I pulled my full set of armor onto my body and grabbed two swords from the air, my parents snagged a gun and a pair of gauntlets as well; using a thread of magic to pluck them from the air and bring it towards them.

Linking the hilts with a thread of magic I threw one of the swords at the things leg, impaling it near the kneecap. It let out a roar as I jumped and swung in an arc, throwing my other sword at the small of its back while yanking the other blade out with a flick of the wrist. This was no time to hold back or play it safe. Not against a Pit Lord.

I continued to swing around it, throwing my blades one after the other and climbing its massive bulk. My father was right behind me, my gauntlets of Ogre might covering his arms up to the shoulders. He had activated phase two of the weapons from the start, a smart move. When the monster tried to attack me with a punch or a swipe my father was there to block the blow with his fists.

I was up to his elbow now, one more swing around would bring me to the face where I could do real damage. The monster swung at me with his other arm but my father wouldn’t make it in time. I prepared to yank out my blade and drop when the sound of a gunshot went off and the fist went wide while blood sprayed across my face. I spared a glance down as I thrust a blade into the back of it’s neck and saw my mother dancing out of the way of a crushing stomp carrying the girl. She gave me a quick salute with my Lexington before jumping behind a car to send it hurtling towards the Pit lord with a magic imbued spinning kick.

A quick glance around showed that the entire block was in shambles. The only building still standing was the weapons shop and that was because of the protective shields around it. But even that wouldn’t last.

As I came around the face again the Pit Lord roared. I threw one of my blades down its throat and shot a high voltage electrical charge down the connection even as I swung out of the way to land on his left shoulder.

“Riktal! Lord of the summer sky!”

I nodded my head to my father who grinned. I saw my mother giving us a thumbs up as she used a massive amount of magic to heave the road up like a giant carpet. As the creature fell backwards I yanked out my blade and jumped even higher into the sky, leapfrogging off my father’s shoulders to get more height. He smashed his fist together as he yelled.

“Soul of the boundless Ogre! Rage and thunder! Clash and smite! Lend me now your monstrous might!”

The gauntlets broke apart as the energy surrounded him. A pair of horns grew from his head as tusks sprouted from his upper and lower lips. He grabbed the handle of the sword as I tossed it down to him, yanking on it hard and throwing him even higher into the sky.

“Mistress of the lightning dance. Of Sword and blade and rabid chance! Split and sunder! Curl and maim! Become like the heavens! Create a bloody rain!”

As I fell I released the power of the heart crystals inside all my weapons. Imagining how I wanted the released energy to react. The six swords split once, then twice then three times until the sky was filled with forty eight swords in all. Pulling the two shields into me I released their stones as well, encasing myself from head to toe in temporarily unbreakable armor. I smashed into the things throat seconds before the swords plunged up to the hilt in its flesh. I felt the buzz over my body as my mother turned my blades and my armor into lightning rods, conducting thousands upon thousands of volts into the thing. As it roared again my father finally came to earth, slamming into the back of my armor and crushing the things throat.

This all could be considered overkill if this had been a normal monster. But this was no normal monster, this was a Pit Lord. It would take at least seven more Hunter’s to take it down. The three of us, no mater how skilled, could only keep it busy and minimize the damage it did.

With a roar it flailed it’s arms, shoving them through the rubble of the buildings both next to it and across the street like they were water. With a heave it bucked us off and my invulnerable armor exploded apart as the magic was used up. I saw it kick out it’s leg and my mother took the full brunt of that blow on her shield. The blow threw her backwards, causing the girl to be flung from her arms to land a small distance away. Both of them seemed to be unconscious and my father had been flung into the debris of a fallen building. He was dazed and unmoving even as the beast stood up and lifted both fists high into the air. I could see it preparing to smash them down onto my mother and the girl and I was the only one able to do anything. But they were too far away, I couldn’t save both.
11112112122121.title: Go to town

111121121221211.content:
My mother was slightly closer. Taking off at a dead run I dove forward, grabbing her up and rolling while throwing out one hand and thrusting out a wall of wind towards the girl. The fist came down mere milliseconds after I vacated the spot. The shockwave hit my back as I turned, my spine bouncing on the road before I skidded to a halt. I could feel the burn of skin scrapped raw but I ignored it. Rolling over I thrust my hands into the ground, turning the tar of the street into the consistency of water. When I pulled them back up they were coated with the stuff. It wasn’t the greatest weapon but it was better than my bare hands.

By the time I rose to my feet, Hunter’s were pouring out of everywhere. Flying over destroyed buildings. Riding motorcycles down the street, dropping off of hang gliders from the sky. First it was only ten, then twenty, soon over thirty Hunter’s were attacking the beast in a mad dance of life and death. One of the Hunter’s was backhanded by the Pit Lord, flying towards the ground. He cushioned his fall with a mattress of magic, but I could see the blood coating his face. That blood flowed backwards back into the wound seconds before it sealed itself up. A look around showed a small army of priests and priestesses coming out of hiding to help.

The servants of The One God split up into groups to form a backline defense. Healing injuries almost as soon as they happened. Sending out their power to cure cuts in mid air. A Priest came up to examine me but I waved him off, saying my injuries were minor and to take care of my mother. Letting the stolen tar drop from my hands I headed over to a priestess across the street who I assumed was taking care of the little girl.

My back burned and my left leg limped a little bit but I ignored it as I stared down at the girl. The priestess looked up at me and shook her head slowly before using two fingers to close the eyes. Even if she hadn’t said anything I would have known the girl was dead. Her blood and brain matter was splashed across the building rubble. It looked like her head had slammed into the sharp edge of one of the stones.

“I saw what you did. Your initial wall of wind saved her. She was so light she was easily pushed out from under the fist. But because she was so light the aftershock picked her up like a leaf on the wind and tossed her. The force would have been so great she would never have felt anything even if she had been awake.”

She stood up and put her hands on me. I tried brushing her off, telling her to go heal someone else but she shook her head no. The soothing warmth of her divine power flowed through me. the aches in my leg and the burning in my back subsided and she let her hands drop away. She gave me a small bow before heading off to the main battle where the monster was on it’s last leg. With forty five Hunter’s going to town on it now, it stood no chance.

I knelt there in front of the girl lifting her hand in mine gently.

“I’m sorry little one. I made a split second decision and it ended with you losing your life. I didn’t wish any harm to come to you. Perhaps if I hadn’t been so stubborn and accepted the job of protecting you to begin with, none of this would have happened. I let my anger blind me from doing what a Hunter truly stands for. Protecting the innocent and those who can’t protect themselves. I hope you are in a better place now. Where you are with your family and happy. Rest in peace Asala.”

I closed my eyes and said a small prayer for the little girl. I didn’t know if there really was someplace greater that we went to or not, but I liked to believe there was. Wild cheering went up behind me as the Pit Lord gave a final roar of defiance before dying. I ignored the celebration as the little hand in mine slowly cooled off. I heard footsteps but didn’t bother to turn and look as my mother and father came up on me.

“Why did you save me and not her?”

“Is that an accusation?”

“No. I’m just curious.”

I was silent a moment, giving the hand a final squeeze before standing up and turning to face them.

“Because when it comes down to it, you are family. We might not agree on much of anything and we always argue. I can’t help but get angry when I am around you for more than a few moments sometimes. But you are still family. You are still my mother and nothing will change that fact. Even if I change my name. Even if I lose my memory, that fact remains. You are the person who gave birth to me.”

My dad limped over and put his hand on my shoulder, his brown hair matted with blood and eyes the same color stared at me. He sported a new scar running down the entire left side of his face and onto his neck. He smiled as he gave my shoulder a squeeze.

“You did good son. It was a hard decision to make. Especially in the heat of the moment like that. No one can fault you for the choice you made.”

I shoved his hand off and walked past them both.

“You’re wrong. I fault myself for the choices I make. That’s the meaning of regret. To look back and wonder what you could have done differently. To wonder if what you did was the right thing or not. If the outcome would be different. I’m not ready to be a Hunter yet. That’s why I’m leaving. I’m packing up my bags and I’m going to leave. I don’t know where I will go or how I will get there but that doesn’t matter. I’m missing something as a Hunter.”

I shook my head as I stared at the ground.

“No. That’s not quite right. It’s more like I forgot something as a human being. I’m going to go find it. I guess in the end I’m following the Zelkov tradition eh? Go running off and not coming back until who knows when. Maybe come back once a month if I feel like it. The truth is there was never anything really tying me to this place, to that house. Just a sense of duty to the family name. but it’s not enough anymore. It can all rot away for all I care. I don’t need it.”

“We will be waiting for you to come back son.”

“Don’t make promises you can’t keep. In a day or two you will both be gone again on some important job or other. Just like you always are. You never had time for your son before, or for being a family. Why should you start now?”

I left the two of them standing there by Asala’s corpse. I had barely known the girl but I somehow felt more for her right now than I did for either of my parents. I loved them. But love wasn’t enough to keep me here anymore. It had barely kept me here to begin with. I just hadn’t realized any of this until now. I didn’t know what the future held for me, but whatever was in store I would be alone to experience it.

Just like I had always been.

***********

What is the price of a life? A single moment of hesitation? A bond of family or friendship? What life was worth more? The life of a girl he barely knew and had not yet begun to live? Or a mother he loved and hated who was barely a mother to him to begin with? Were they equally valuable? It is not so easy to make such choices is it?

As he said, regret is wondering at the choices you didn’t make. Tell me, do you regret? Would you unravel the skein of fate and reweave it anew? Riktal does not have this luxury, but in this realm of the infinitely possible you do. Please join me again sometime and create a new web of choice and consequence.
111121121221211.title: Save mother

111121121221212.content:
I sprinted and dove, wrapping my arms around the girl as I rolled, throwing out a wall of wind in an attempt to push my mother out of the way. The fist came down right where I had been a second before and the shockwave lifted me off the ground and threw me across the street. I rolled over the girl so my back slammed into the broken building before she did. I felt something snap as the metallic taste of blood flowed up my throat.

As I righted myself, a group of ten Hunter’s came out of the woodwork around town to attack the Pit Lord. Even as I sat there with my legs completely useless and my arms wrapped around the girl protectively, even more came. Hunter’s of all shapes and sizes and all specialties. Within moments there were thirty Hunter’s stabbing, jumping, blocking, spinning and ultimately killing the monster.

Priests and priestesses came out of nowhere as well, healing them as soon as they got hurt like a well oiled machine. One of the priest came over to my side saying he would take care of me. I told him to check out the girl first which he did. Letting me know she was just unconscious with a few minor scratches but otherwise unhurt. He then bent over my legs as his hands glowed white. I could feel the holy power fixing whatever was broken inside of me, the power soothing and warm. The power eventually faded, leaving a slight desire to feel it again like it always did.

“I did what I could. You can walk, but you are going to live with a limp for the rest of your life. I’m just glad I was able to make it in time. A few moments longer and I wouldn’t have been able to save your legs.”

“Less talk. Go help the others. I’m fine.”

He nodded his head before hurrying away.

Getting to my feet was hard. My legs were a bit stiff and didn’t want to bend properly. But I finally managed to do so through sheer willpower. Clutching the girl tightly to my chest I shambled over to the last place I had seen my mother. My right leg dragging along behind me like a bit of dead weight. It would take weeks, if not months of physical therapy to get it working more normally. But that was a worry for another day.

A priestess was kneeling over my mother, her hands and body glowing with that divine light. When I got close enough I saw her right arm was gone up to the shoulder. The flesh still attached was mangled and pulped. Even as I watched the Priestess cut the dead flesh off before sealing up the wound into a stump. When she was done she looked up at me and smiled thinly.

“I did what I could. I saw you shove her out of the way with that blast of wind. That saved her life. If you hadn’t done that the blow would have crushed her head no question. She has some minor cuts and bruises but I healed the internal bleeding as best I could. She will probably wake up in a day or two.”

“I’ll take care of her from here. Go join the others. They will need your help more.”

She left then to join the fight, the Pit lord was beginning to fall. with almost forty five Hunters and a squad of ten healer’s behind them, the beast stood no chance. It slowly fell to it’s knees even as it continued to fight to it’s last breath. My father came limping over holding his shoulder, sporting a fresh scar running down the entire left side of his face and onto his neck.

“You did good son. That was some quick thinking and quicker moves.”

He looked down at my mother and her missing arm and his eyes softened a bit.

“She’s going to be mad at you when she wakes up you know. Saying she would rather die than live having lost one arm. She won’t mean it of course. It’s just her way of coming to grips with the facts. You know how she is about these kind of things.”

“No. I don’t. Neither one of you are ever around long enough for me to know anything about you besides the fact that you are Hunter’s. I don’t know anything aside from your birthday’s really. I don’t even know how old either one of you are.”

“Yeah. I think it’s time we changed that. Your mother… your mother was never really good with kids. Said she just didn’t understand them. She said she could deal with them once they were fifteen and older but before that she just felt uncomfortable being around them in a non Hunter capacity.”

“Me and your mother haven’t always seen eye to eye on a lot of things. And I will admit it, both of us put our jobs first. That lead to a lot of hardships for you I guess. I suppose I wasn’t that great a father either. I didn’t know much about how to deal with children just like your mother. But one thing I did know was that you were ready to be a Hunter. It was your mother who didn’t want you taking the Exams. But after this, she should have no reason to deny you anymore. If you want to take the Exams I’ll support you and make sure it happens.”

My father picked up my mother as the Pit Lord gave one final bellowing death rattle. Wild cheers broke out among the Hunter’s as they began to congratulate each other. Absently I reached down to rub my right leg where a dull aching throb began and shook my head.

“No. Don’t bother. I’ve just made up new plans for my life. I’m going to protect this girl for the next two or three days just like mother wanted. And then I am going to leave with her when she goes. She needs stability for her powers and training will give her some but not all of that. She needs family. It seems to me I have some experience as an older brother under my belt. And honestly, you two don’t need me. You never really did. That’s why you were never home. I’ll just be following the Zelkov tradition of going off and coming back once in a blue moon. So until she doesn’t need me as a big brother I’m going to hold off on taking the Hunter’s Exams.”

“We will miss you.”

“Don’t lie. It doesn’t suit you. Nether one of you have ever missed me. At least not enough to make you put me before your jobs. Can you tell me the last time you were home for Christmas? When the last time you gave me a gift that had nothing to do with being a Hunter? Can you tell me the last time you talked to me about non Hunter things?”

I shook my head as I squeezed the little girl a bit tighter. Her arms snaked out to wrap around me as she buried her head into my chest.

“You both raised me as a Hunter and nothing else. Not a regular boy. That’s why you don’t understand children. You never tried to understand them. That’s where I differ from you and mother. I can understand them because normal children had everything I didn’t but wanted. I’m not angry. I’ve used up my anger for the day. Besides, it just doesn’t seem worth it to get angry over these facts anymore. I’ll make sure to send you something for your birthday’s though. If I remember.”

I turned and walked away, carrying the little girl in my arms. I made sure to keep my back straight even while my leg dragged behind me. I ignored the cheers and the words of thanks from the Hunter’s and citizen’s for delaying the monster. Ignored the people offering to take the girl off my hands for me. But mostly I ignored the pair of sad eyes I could feel staring at my back.

************

It’s funny how a random series of events can end in such weird ways is it not? It all started out so simple. A boy a bit angry at being transferred to a new school. With a desire to become a Monster Combat Hunter. He ends his day without anger and giving up that desire for a little girl he had originally wanted nothing to do with. What number of possibilities had to come together for this outcome? One? Two? Or perhaps as they say: it all started at hello.

Would this outcome have happened if the choices made had been different? If it were the same, would it be exactly the same? What would make him choose to save the girl over his own mother in the end? Oh I know you made the choice for him, but if it had not been your hand guiding his actions, what would be his reasoning? For even though you made the choices, this outcome has always been a possibility.

Join me again will you not? My curiosity is satisfied for now but I am not completely sated. I wish to continue to observe you and the choices you make. For it is indeed enlightening. Until we meet again.
111121121221212.title: Save girl

11112112122122.content:
Home. Definitely home. I didn’t feel like dealing with any more people today. Everyone wanting this or that from me. Expecting me to act this or that way. Trying to pull my strings and make me dance to their tune. If I went into town I had a feeling there would be more of that. Besides the only people I really knew in town were people who dealt with Hunter’s. Broker’s, other Hunter’s and the like. No one I really needed to see.

The walk home was quit and uneventful. I decided to skirt the outside of the city to go from Gregory’s house to mine instead of going the faster way through town. As I walked I saw normal families living their everyday lives. Glimpses of what normal was through open windows and inside fenced yards. Normal for everyone but me that is.

Normal for me was lonely.

I made it home finally, unlocking the spell on the front door absently. Letting my bag drop to the floor I headed for the kitchen. The old house creaked and shifted a little but I rarely heard it anymore except for the rare occasion like this. I clicked on the TV set into the wall by the kitchen table just to hear some noise while I made myself something to eat.

I really didn’t feel like making anything special. There really was no need since it was just me. No point in dirtying a bunch of pots and pans for one person. So a peanut butter and jelly sandwich did just fine. As I took a bite and left the kitchen I noticed I had pinched the edges to keep the jelly in without thinking. I smiled a bit at that but kept walking.

As I went into the living room I turned that TV on as well before turning and walking away. Going to the calendar out in the hall I put a red X in the corner of today’s date before placing a blue and green one next to it. Now that the month was almost over I looked back and saw a single circle of each color interspersed among the days. The most recent being a red one around yesterdays date.

My little way of keeping track of when my family came home and spent the night. Red for my mother, blue for my father and green for big sis Ulicia. Circles for when they were here and X’s for when they weren’t. A simple thing but a telling one. Looking back over the last six months proved all four of us hadn’t been together in this house at the same time. Father’s circles appeared more often then mother’s or big sis’. Though big sis had moved out so that was understandable. Sadly big sis’ appeared slightly more often than mother’s.

This calendar was more than just a record of when they were here or not. It was a record of our family. A record of my normal. Filled with broken promises, missed holidays, and lies.

Letting the pages drop back down I went upstairs and took a quick shower. Once I was done I hunted through my closet until I found an old blue stuffed rabbit. Clutching it to my chest like the little girl had held her teddy bear, I lay on the bed and closed my eyes. Let tomorrow come sooner, and let my dreams be filled with a little girl that had never left me alone.

*********

Well are you satisfied? Good. Bad. Easy. Hard. Do any of these describe the decisions you made? Did you simply do what you would have done in the situation? Or did you go against your gut instincts? Did you take what you knew of young Riktal into account as well? Or did you disregard him as unimportant? A mere character in some story and not a living person. Do you regret the choices? Do you wonder what might have been?

Our time grows short but I shall see you again. Of this I am certain and have no question. When we return we shall find out again, what kind of god you are and what destiny you will choose.
11112112122122.title: Go back home

111121122.content:
I was already pushing myself away from the desk and tipping backwards as she jumped over the heads of the two boys in front of me with arms outstretched. I kicked up my legs, intending to catch her in the stomach and throw her over my head but she dropped her arms and planted her palms on the soles of my boots. With a deft twist and contortion she controlled her movements to spin in a circle upside down while flying over me.

I continued my backwards roll into a handstand, so I saw how she landed on her hands and feet in a crouch. Her stance reminded me of a frog with one foot upraised as it got ready to hop. Indeed she did hop. She launched herself at me, thrusting with legs I knew could dent cement if she wanted and speed to match. I was already bending my elbows in a vertical pushup, pushing off the ground and sailing over her head upside down like she had sailed over mine.

I saw her hand reach down to her waist while her other one planted itself on the floor and shifted my center of gravity without thinking, turning in a half circle while still in mid flip. I noticed she had thrown an empty vial too late as it passed my sight. I tried to shift my center again but was unable to before big sis managed to twist her body at the waist, kicking me in the small of my back.

Even as I flew through the air to slam into the wall I was throwing out a wall of air to push her back. That gave me enough time to slide to the floor and spin back to my feet in a fighters crouch. She stood pouting at me a few feet away where my wind had pushed her.

“Riki! How dare you do that to your big sister! I need my tiki tank filled up! I must have it filled up! I will die without my dose of tiki! It’s been so long since I filled up my tank!”

She stamped her foot as she talked, throwing a little temper tantrum and acting like a four year old instead of a twenty four year old.

“That’s it! I will get my fix!”

She swung her hand out, snagging a potion and tossing it to the floor in front of me. As the green smoke shot up into the air, she launched herself out of the teleportation spell almost right on top of me. I grabbed her outstretched arm and spun, throwing her over my shoulder into the wall. She broke up into green smoke and wafted away just as I felt the back of my shirt become damp and my body stiffened up from the paralysis potion.

Big sis Ulicia spun me around, grabbing me up in a hug and swinging me around like a rag doll. She showered my cheeks and forehead with kisses in between rubbing her cheeks all over my face.

“Do you like my new potion Riki tiki! It took three years to figure out how to make it and I only have one of those fifteen second ones and a thirty second version. I call it potion of magical body double. It creates a perfect replica of the person who imbues their magic into it. So perfect even master Hunter’s can’ tell the difference. I’ll teach you how to make it next time I have some time at home!”

She finally set me back down with a sigh and threw the antidote on me. The liquid inside turned into gas on contact with the air that I inhaled before it drifted away. As my body loosened up again she grinned.

“Tiki tank fully recharged! I will be able to go on for a bit longer! Now on to class! Sit down Riki tiki. It’s impolite to keep the class waiting like this.”

“I’ll get you back for this.”

She put one hand on her cheek while rubbing at her eyes with the other one and faking tears.

“What a horrible brother you are! Threatening your big sister like that. Don’t you know I love you so much!”

“Yeah. I could do with a little less love from you. Now hurry up and get to teaching this class before you make a bigger scene then you already have.”

I kept my face a blank mask of indifference as I returned to my desk and sat down again. I could see the grins on some faces and hear the snickering behind hands. This was what I had to put up with every time big sis came home. They all thought being from an old family was easy. They could gladly take my place if they wanted, I was sure one day with my family would be enough to make them change their mind.

I listened with only one ear as my sister went over some of the basics of Alchemy and potion making. Having instantly switched from the four year old mentality back into her work mentality like flipping a switch. It was an art all Hunter’s eventually picked up. When the rest of the kids in the class pulled out their mini chemistry labs to begin making an actual potion I ended up borrowing one of the ones sitting along the back wall.

Sis walked around the room, stopping at desks and pointing out tips on how to improve their form or to comment on how they had their desk set up for ease of access. While everyone else made health potions I set about making my own things. I didn’t need to wait and be told when to add this item or that item. Nor how many times to stir the brew. I didn’t need to be told when to combine the blue and the yellow mixtures. Big sis had taught that all to me long ago.

So by the time class was over and big sis finally came over to me again I handed her a vial of paralysis potion and the antidote.

“Save you the trouble of making them yourself. I didn’t have the right grade of ingredients for the third tier versions or the time to let them seep but I was able to make the second tier at least.”

Her eyes went as round as saucers as they wavered and wobbled like she would cry. She wrapped her arms around my neck and rubbed her face against mine again.

“You really are a good brother! I don’t know why mamma and papa sent you here! I thought for sure they would let you take the Exams! I’ve got a job to do so I won’t be home for a week or so. But when I come back I’ll tell you all about what I’ve been up to! I got to run now Riki tiki! Give mom my love when you see her!”

She dropped a potion on the floor and a wall of green smoke shot into the air. This one really was a transportation spell since she stepped into it with a final wave. The smoke folded in on itself before poofing out of existence, not even leaving a trace of broken glass behind. Ignoring the stares of the few people still in the room I put my borrowed chemistry lab away, grabbed up my bag and headed for the next class.

This would be Combat training. Something I could actually get into. Even if none of these people were up to my skill level I could always practice on my own. I was sure the Arena Master would have a few monsters I could battle against in my own private floor. A Hunter could never think he was good enough, doing so was just asking to get the crap knocked out of you. Sis was able to beat me because she had more experience. Sometimes no matter how good you were, experience trumped all.

I was one of the last ones to make it to the locker rooms but I didn’t mind. Unlike all the rest of them I had no real need to gear up. While they were strapping on plate armor and specialized padding for their respective weapons of choice, all I needed was my fists and maybe a bit of leg protection. Dropping my duffle on a bench I unzipped it before looking inside for my leg armor.

My hands stilled for a moment then began pushing weapons and items out of the way with more haste. Where was my Lexington double barrel and my Roller Knuckles? I know I had packed them this morning. Hadn’t I? Were they still in my room or something? No, I would never have been so careless as to not pack them.

I looked around the room at the other boys who were putting on their gear. Could one of them have taken it? It was possible. I had left my bag unattended during lunch. It hadn’t been long but it had been more than enough time for someone to dig through the bag and take what they wanted. It could have been one of the girls as well, but this was more along the lines of something a guy would do. Women I had found were less likely to snoop in other peoples things without good reason.

They were dangerous weapons in the wrong hands. Someone untrained in how to use them could get seriously hurt or hurt someone else unintentionally. I needed to get them back but I didn’t even know for sure someone in here had stolen them. Or indeed if I had even brought them. I could inform the teacher. I wouldn’t get them back right away, but that route would at least keep me from doing anything rash and breaking even more rules, if not heads.

That is if I even got them back with that route. It wasn’t that they were incompetent, but in some things the teachers just didn’t have a lot of pull. If the thief managed to get it home that might be the last I saw of them. The other option was to handle it myself. I had a higher chance of getting my stuff back, but also a greater chance of possible killing someone in my anger. It might not come to that point, but that was a worse case scenario.
111121122.title: Avoid her

1111211221.content:
A few quick whispered words to the Arena master in charge of the locker room before locking up my duffle bag and I was out the door. After that scene with big sis I would rather keep a low profile for a bit longer. No sense making enemies I didn’t need to. Even if I didn’t think much of anyone here right now, I might have to work with them in the future.

As I waited in the Arena I watched everyone coming in closely for any hints that they might be the culprit. I wasn’t even sure what I was looking for exactly, since I didn’t know any of them well enough to know how they normal acted. But any little thing might be a clue as long as I paid attention to it.

“Class! Today we are doing something a bit different. We will not be having sparring lessons as usual. Today will be an application day to test the knowledge of what you have learned the last two weeks. When I call your name you will pair up into groups of four or five as I see fit. You will work together to combat and kill various monsters. I have judged your skill levels and will pit you against monsters within that skill range. They will not be weak, but they will not be too hard either. You may use any weapons you wish.”

He fiddled with a small box that fit in the palm of his hand and a row of weapon racks holding various weapons from shields to guns slid out of the floor behind him. Another manipulation of his magical box caused a wall to go up down the middle of the rectangular arena floor.

“Zelkov! Hawthrope! You two can sit out for today.”

I shrugged as he began separating the class into groups before heading up into the bleachers. I made sure to sit right where the wall split it in half so I could watch what was going on below. Liz climbed the bleachers and sat next to me, also watching the groups below quietly for a moment.

“So you’re a Zelkov huh? That actually explains a lot.”

“And yet I wish it didn’t.”

“I know what you mean. It can be a pain being a Hawthrope. It’s like as soon as they find out the name they know, or at least think they know, all these things about you.

The first two groups stepped into the arena to each face off against a three headed five foot tall snake creatures called Overloks. So they were around D class Hunter’s right now.

“I really hope your name isn’t Riki tiki or I might not be able to keep a straight face anytime I talk to you.”

“It’s Riktal. Only my sister can get away with calling me that.”

“Because she is stronger than you?”

“Because she is my sister. And so you know my win ratio against her is about fifty-fifty. What’s your angle anyway?”

“No angle. It’s just refreshing to have someone else to talk to about Hunter stuff. My dad forced me to attend this school and quite frankly I am bored to tears. All the girls seem to only think and want to talk about boys and the latest fashion. All the boys seem to want to talk about girls and, well, girls. They don’t seem to have an interest in strategy, or favorite weapons or the different ways you can use a weapon.”

“So you simply want to alleviate your boredom huh? Well I guess that’s a valid angle as well. I don’t mind I guess.”

“Cool.”

While we had been talking the second groups that had both gone against a Slumbog, a giant slug like worm that stood six feet tall, finally killed their prey. They were definitely of a lower class than me. It would have taken me a minute or less to dispatch such an easy creature. Though these hands-on battles were making the natural leaders and thinkers stand out. I had to admit they also had some decent teamwork. They were sloppy in places and could definitely use some work but it was passable for this level of creature.

As the fifth and last group walked into the ring the floor slid to the side and a Cluuk rose into view inside a cage. The creature looked like a giant red chicken with glowing green eyes. The wattle under its beak was spiked and poison tipped. I nodded at the five of them with my chin absently as the cage fell away back into the floor.

“I guess these are the cream of the crop in this class. That’s a low C monster easy.

“Aye. They all have level heads and this shouldn’t be a problem for them. Well mostly. Gregory there has a bit of an ego. Seems to think the world revolves around him and likes to show off. Quick to blame other people for his mistakes if he can and always feeling entitled to more than he should have. He is a good gunner though I will give him credit. And his magic casting isn’t bad.”

She pointed at the one in full plate armor with a full body shield and a short sword who stood like a wall against the Cluuk’s first charge.

“Jethic there is the best of this group though. A team is nothing without a good tank. And he is one of the best in this class. Though he is treated like dirt because he comes from a small country town and is a first generation Hunter. Hardly any magic to speak of, just this side of being a Void. Probably another reason no one likes him. But on a one-on-one basis and stacked against everyone else in the class he’d rank somewhere around fourth or fifth. That’s not including us of course. I’m confident he could take on a high level C ranked monster or even a low level B depending on the creature.”

“Daniel is a strong hand-to hand combat brawler. Magic is sub-par and passable with other weapons. Lilian might be a bit absentminded but she is a really good healer with strong divine magic.”

“Wait there is a priestess in our class?”

“Yeah a bit surprising isn’t it? Her parents are priests as well so there is no surprise she got the healing touch. But seems she decided on her own she wanted to become a Hunter. I’m not sure why exactly but she was adamant about it. I guess when her parents tried to dissuade her and get her to take the binding rituals of their faith she simply walked out the doors and came to this school saying she wanted to enroll.”

I watched as the one named Jethic smashed his shield into the monster’s side, getting it back into position to defend just in time. The others beat on it like a well oiled machine. It would go down soon.

“Well as long as they don’t try killing it with magic or use fire they got this in the bag. Though I’m surprised you know so much about your classmates.”

“Only their combat ability. I like to know what I might be up against or who has my back if things go bad.”

As I turned my head back towards the rings I saw the one named Gregory throw one of his guns into the air and swing his now empty right hand behind his back. My Lexington double barrel came into view as he swung it around and fired it sideways. I didn’t have time to even shout a warning as the bullet left the barrel, being coated in magic from the second tube even as it left the gun. The kickback from the shot lifted the boy off his feet and sent him flying.

I was already vaulting onto the wall splitting the Arena floor and running even as the Lexington flew out of his hands and into the air. Time seemed to move in slow motion as I watched everything unfold. The Cluuk took the bullet in the side of the head and fell to the ground even as it’s feathers changed to black. It’s blood and brains flew everywhere as the group began to cheer. I leapt off the wall and grabbed my Lexington before sliding into a landing in front of the group.

“Tank! Shields up! Healer back line! switch target to Cluuk! You’re main caster now! You with the staff! Switch to magical support! Defensive magic is the priority! Assist the tank and healer!”

They looked at me confused even as I hit the button that locked the magic from leaving the barrel. As Liz dropped into the arena I pointed at Gregory with my gun.

“Get him the hell out of here before I shoot him.”

She nodded her head and slung the boy over her shoulder even as the blood and brains from the fallen Cluuk pulled back into it’s body like time had rewound.

“Tank I hear you’re good enough to take on a B class. I hope Liz was right. Because this one’s your first.”

He looked at the chicken a bit nervously.

“What is it?”

“A Kloo, if you kill a Cluuk with magic it turns into a Zombie. Most magic is pretty useless against it now except for holy. We can dismember it all we want but it will pull itself back together.”

“How do we beat it!”

I grinned at the brawler named Daniel’s question as my blood got to pumping.

“Just follow my instructions and you’ll do fine. Now brace for first impact! You with the staff, cast a blinding flash on my signal. When I give the signal everyone else close their eyes. Daniel get your fist’s ready because blunt is the next best thing on an undead.”

The monster charged and Jethic planted his shield on the ground while putting his shoulder against it. Right before the beast hit I began the assault.

“Blind it!”
1111211221.title: Notify teacher

11112112211.content:
“Jethic! Upwards thrust with your shield! Lilian! Holy smite! Boe staff! Get the protects going.”

“I have a name! its Marsa!”

“Don’t care right now! Get the protect shields up! Daniel focus on the legs!”

As soon as Jethic shoved upwards I jumped forward, ramming my knee into its neck hard enough to snap it. Our combined efforts toppled it backwards even as I saw the ball of holy energy hurtling my way. I twisted and kicked the thing in its back, lifting it up with my augmented blow. The smite smashed into the creature, making it squawk in pain. It’s head snapped back into place as it repaired itself and got back to it’s feet.

Daniel started punching and kicking it in the nearest foot, his fist glowing a rich green color. Within seconds that leg had turned to dust, crushed under the blows. Throwing out my arm I caught it’s neck in my elbow and spun across it’s back, twisting the head right off and chucking it to the farthest reaches of the arena. Another rain of holy missiles shot into the creature as Daniel went to work on the other leg.

The Kloo spread it’s wings and shot poison tipped feathers in all directions. Marsa grabbed Daniel with her magic and yanked him behind Jethic who stood in front of the barrage. Most of them hit his shield harmlessly but a few flew over his head. He reached out his hand and waved it quickly, taking the hits on his own personal armor instead of letting even one get past him.

Jethic! You know how to do a hot and heavy?”

“I know the principals but never actually done it.”

“Good enough. Marsa! Cast a fire enhancement spell on Jethic’s shield. Lilia cast a nova blast on Jethic when I give the signal. Daniel, you got a special hand to hand move of your own?”

“One that my grandpa taught me.”

“Good. Once the nova goes off lay into this bird!”

I saw the shield glowing red as I tucked my gun into my belt for the moment in case I needed to assist Daniel.

“Lilia you ready?”

“Ready!”

“Then Jethic it’s on you!”

With a yell he smashed his sword into his shield a few times until the sword turned into another full body shield. Toting the two metal titan’s like toys he rushed the creature laying into it with both of them, smashing them over and over in lightning quick strikes. The flame enhanced slabs of metal burned a hole through the creature.

“Lilia now!”

The nova went off in a circle around Jethic who was beginning to smoke as his armor heated up. The nova cooled him down while invading the Kloo’s insides and melting them with holy fire. It’s outside might be protected from damage and magic but the insides were still very weak to such things. Holy magic was one of the few effective magic’s that could pierce its skin.

“Jethic back off! Daniel! You’re up!”

His feet and fist became surrounded by his green aura up to the elbows and knees as he rushed forward.

“Dance of the midnight devil!”

His arms and legs became a blur that even I had a hard time following. Moving like jackhammer strikes I could see the dents the blows were putting into the beast. And a dance it was. He spun and flipped from one position to the next striking with fist, elbow, feet, and knee until finally he struck the body with an open palm. There was a moment of stillness before the entire creature exploded. But so did Daniel’s left hand. From the palm he had struck it with all the way up to the elbow the skin flayed apart as bone fragments ripped through the skin.

I ignored his cry of pain as I searched the dismembered parts. Even as they began to start pulling themselves back together. I finally found what I was searching for, yanking out my Lexington and firing a bullet into the hardened shriveled heart of the zombie bird. The pieces stopped moving for a moment and then the body broke up into dust in the wind, leaving behind a pile of black feathers. Lilia went over to Daniel and laid her hands on his, putting his arm back to working order. As the rest of the class came running up with cheers on their lips I picked up the pile from the ground.

Dividing up the twelve feathers into groups of three I handed them out to the four who had helped me.

“Good work you guys. You did well for a B class creature. Good holy magic Lilia, and nice support Marsa. Top notch tanking Jethic, and Daniel that was a great combat ability as well.”

“Yeah, well as you can see, I haven’t really perfected it yet. It puts a huge strain on the body.”

“But it worked. Sometimes you have to sacrifice yourself to win against a monster. Those black feathers are your reward. You earned them.”

“They’re pretty but what are they? I feel some faint magic from them but I don’t know if that’s just my imagination or what.”

I smiled at Lilia as I plucked one from her hands.

“These are Kloo feathers obviously. One of the few types of undead that can use or hold magic. Since magic is how they are created.”

I glared at Gregory as I said that and he shrunk back a bit.

“My Lexington coats bullets in magic, that magic got soaked into these feathers. Now these feathers can be used for one of three purposes. The first, they can grant luck. Place one of these feathers in your hat, hair or clothes after sprinkling it with a bit of blessed water and you will find you will be extremely lucky for a day. Accidents just seem to always miss hitting you, you find the item you thought you lost last week, you guess every answer on a test correctly.”

“Second, they are valuable materials for alchemic potions. They can make some of the rarest, most sought after elixirs. If you have all the rare ingredients that is. And third, you could sell them to any good materials store for no less than a thousand Reul. If someone tries to offer you less go someplace else. Depending on the amount of magic in it they can fetch upwards of fifteen or sixteen hundred Reul.”

“If it is so rare then why did it drop so many feathers? I would think people would be hunting these things all the time for that much.”

I handed the feather back to Lilia as I answered Marsa.

“Because we killed it on the first dismemberment for one. A skilled Hunter can take one down alone, but it will usually pull itself back together at least three times before he can either find and kill it’s core or simply beat the magic animating it out. The other part was luck. I was expecting at least eight, but luck plays a factor in any monster drop, so you got twelve.”

“Don’t you want any?”

“Nope. You guys did all the work. All I did was tell you what to do and shot a bullet into it’s core. Put a little more effort into becoming Hunter’s and you’ll do fine.”

I turned and narrowed my eyes at Gregory who was trying to hide behind the rest of the class.

“As for you, you little thief. You best count yourself lucky. If I could get away with it I would put a bullet right between your eyes right now. How dare you steal from me! But seeing as I can’t get away with it, I leave your punishment up to the Arena Master and this school. But know this. If you ever come near me for whatever reason I will show you no mercy. If any of my things come up missing again, I will come after you. Even if you didn’t take it, I will still extract payment from your hide. Do I make myself clear?”

I stayed long enough to see him nod his head before asking to be excused to put my weapon away. The Arena Master nodded his assent as he turned to focus on Gregory. I went to the locker room and sat on a bench, pulling off my glasses and rubbing my eyes. I had been so close to killing him. The rage was still there inside. I had really wanted to come here to cool my temper off before I did something I would regret.

I heard the door open moments before Jethic and Daniel walked in. They went to their bags and put away their feathers, giving me a nod and a small smile. They left again and the door creaked closed with its slight booming sound. A second later I looked up to find Daniel peeking around the corner before coming over to me a bit nervously.

“C-can I talk to you for a moment?”

I really wasn’t in the mood to talk right now. If what he said made me even madder I might take it out on him without meaning to. But he seemed to think it was important or he wouldn’t have approached me.
11112112211.title: Commence battle!

111121122111.content:
“What do you need?”

Might as well get this over with. If it was something important to him that I could help alleviate without much hassle then why not listen to him. He had earned that much from me at least.

With his head lowered he went back over to his locker, opened it up for a moment and came back with my Roller Knuckles gripped tightly in his hands. His arms were shaking so much as he held them out to me I thought they would shake right off his body. I looked up at him but didn’t take them at first, simply narrowing my eyes until he finally looked up to lock gazes with me.

“I-I know it was wrong to take them. I-I didn’t want to! But Gregory talked me into it! He said a whole bunch of things like I deserved to have a good pair of fist weapons since I’m a fist specialist. And then I was holding them when Lilia came into the room and I hid them from her and I just sort of kept them. I’m sorry!”

“Why tell me this now? I’m sure you realize that I am very angry at the moment. Angry enough to kill. So why didn’t you wait until later when I might not be so angry?”

“Because I was in the wrong. It doesn’t matter how things happened. What matters is I went through your bag without permission and I stole them. Even though my parent’s aren’t Hunter’s, my grandfather was. He told me sometimes a man can only say what he truly wants to say through using his fists. He also said the true worth of a person can sometimes only be found by fighting next to them and not with them. He taught me a lot of other stuff too, like owning up to your mistakes and accepting the consequences.”

“I never really understood what he meant about a lot of stuff. I still don’t. But fighting next to you I think I see what he meant about that much. The way you had this presence that made me believe I could win even though my knees were knocking so hard I thought they would shatter. I didn’t listen to you because you are a Zelkov, I listened because of that presence. And I thought, I wanted to be like that. I thought if I ever wanted to be like that I had to fess up and give them back no matter what.”

I took the gloves from his hands then, looking down at them as I hefted them a few times. To say I wasn’t angry about it would be a lie. I wanted to knock his head off, but I didn’t. He had at least confessed of his own accord. Finally I looked up at the boy who was still shaking while waiting for my judgment.

“There is a place called the Iron Buckler down by the river. The man who runs the place is called Valoric. Make sure you speak to him and not one of his assistance. Tell him I sent you. He deals not only in weapons but also in monster spoils. Trade your three feathers in to him for a good pair of gloves without question. Even if you lose out on the deal a bit. Tell him I said to give you ones with some protection augmentations on them at least. These ones are way out of your league at your current skill level. If you were to try to use them they would eat you up and spit you out. Doing to your body what your dance did to your arm. The choice to do so is up to you of course, but if you really want a pair of good gloves then you might want to think about it.”

“Your not angry at me?”

“Oh I’m angry. Really angry. But everyone does things they regret later. Even me. My anger makes me do a lot of things I wish I hadn’t done once I cool off. But your grandfather was right, sometimes you only get a sense of the worth of a person by fighting next to them. The sense I got from you is that you aren’t all that bad a person. You might be a bit foolish and do some stupid things but you aren’t a bad person. You at least had the guts to confront me with your mistake and didn’t try to foolishly use these weapons like Gregory did. If you decide to get the gloves from Valoric, I’m willing to teach you a few tricks I know.”

“T-thanks!”

I waved him off and he ran, his eyes still full of bewilderment. Rubbing my eyes again I began a few breathing exercises to calm down. Once I was ready I shoved the gloves back into my bag and headed out the door. Back in the arena I headed up into the bleachers to sit next to Liz. Scanning the ground below I didn’t see a sign of Gregory. Liz noticed my gaze and nodded her head.

“The Arena Master banned him from the floor for a month before sending him to the principal. I’ve no doubt she will make him clean equipment after school everyday for that timeframe or some other dull task. He’s lucky to get off so easy I think.”

“He’s lucky I was in a good mood.”

“Really? That was a good mood?”

“I didn’t hit him did I?”

She chuckled but didn’t say anything else. We continued to watch the groups below facing off against different creatures, sometimes being put into different groups. I could see the quality of their movements had changed. They worked together as a team better, the instructions were clear and commanding. Instead of them being formed into a question of could you or would you, they were direct “do this” phrases instead. Reaction times were better and so was the timing.

“You’re the reason they all got better you know. After watching you they are trying to emulate what you did. The leaders and strategists are trying to have that same air of command you gave off, while the rest are more confident because of how you led the group against the Kloo. Seeing a bunch of C class Hunter’s in training take down a B class monster was a big boost to their morale.”

“I didn’t do anything. I simply did my job as a Hunter. They are the ones that put more meaning behind it then I did.”

“True. But isn’t that also part of our job as Hunter’s? To make people better and give them confidence?”

“The trick is they have to want to get better and want to gain confidence themselves. I can’t just give it to them like handing out a piece of candy. So in the end I did nothing at all. They did it all themselves.”

"I suppose. I’ll admit I was impressed though. At first I was tempted to jump back in and help but then I decided to see what you could do. Get a feel for your combat ability. I didn’t think you would have much trouble, but if you needed a hand because the rest of the group couldn’t handle it I was ready to help. Honestly I thought for sure you would need at least one dismemberment and reconstruction phase before taking it down with those guys. I guess that shows the difference in skill between us.”

“Or it just shows that those four were better then you thought they were to begin with.”

“Perhaps you’re right.”

She lapsed into another bout of silence as we continued to watch the action below. Finally the bell rang and we went our separate ways. Next period would be History, and then Monster Tactics. Once that was done with, this day would finally be over. I couldn’t wait, I was really ready to go home. Or at least to get out of here.
111121122111.title: What do you need?

1111211221111.content:
“…If it hadn’t been for Nesta and Gint Jervin the treaty would never have been a success. That is the power of Hunter’s.”

The bell rang, signaling the end of class and the teacher told everyone to study the chapter before leaving. Even before he was completely out the door, seven kids were converging on me. I closed my eyes for a moment as I mentally prepared myself. I had been expecting this ever since my sister had showed up. I hoped I didn’t have to be too rude to get them to go away, but I had a feeling I might.

“Um, I’d like to thank you. The way you led your group against that Kloo made me more confident in myself and showed me how to be a better leader.”

I looked at the girl in surprise as she blushed a bit and gave me a small bow of her head. I hadn’t been expecting that. I thought for sure the first thing out of anyone’s lips would be empty words of some kind as they tried to get in my good graces. But I could tell she was being sincere.

“If you are the leader, or at least the one belting out the orders, the biggest thing to keep in mind is everyone is depending on you. Whether you know what you are doing or not, you have to make them believe you know what you are doing. Using weak commands like could you cast this spell or would you be able to do this, makes them unsure. It makes you look ineffectual. You tell them to do what you want, even if you don’t know if they can do it or not. And those you are leading will rise to that challenge instinctively.”

“There will be times as Hunter’s where you will have to lead common everyday people. Perhaps to fight against some low level monsters like gremlins because you are the only one there. They don’t have the training or the skill you do. They may never have fought even the weakest of monsters before. They will be scared and rightfully so. If you are unsure of yourself in that situation, how do you think they will feel? You issue orders with confidence and take command of the situation. Do that and you will minimize the number of lives that are lost.”

She nodded her head while getting a thoughtful look on her face even as the rest of the group began saying how amazing I had been and saying things more in line with what I had been expecting. Fortunately the teacher came in before I got too annoyed and ready to blow up at them. It took a few moments to do roll call before he began his lesson on the Cawmacaw. He didn’t get very far into the lesson though when the door opened and a woman in a blue business suite walked in.

Her black hair glistened slightly under the light and was done up in a tidy ponytail. I noticed she wore a subtle pink lipstick and wore a pair of dark blue high heels that complimented her suit. She whispered a few words to the teacher and he nodded his head, pointing in my direction.

“Riktal! Your mother wants to speak with you.”

I let out a sigh as I picked up my bag and slung it on my shoulder. What could she want with me this time? What could be so important she had come to school with one of her aides? It could just be one of her whims, something so unimportant as to be negligible. Like what color dress she should wear. More than likely though it was to tell me she was going off on another job. She had come home last night and she had been here at least eight hours. It was time for her to leave again after all. Rarely did she seem to spend more than ten or twelve hours at home.

“I’m Inga by the way.”

“You’re new.”

“Yes. I just started working for your mother yesterday.”

“Well no offense but start looking for another job now. That way when she fires you for whatever stupid reason you won’t be floundering around. Aside from Hilda, the longest I’ve seen her keep an aide is about two months. Their hair isn’t the right color, their teeth don’t sparkle when they smile, they don’t wear the right brand of perfume. It’s always some small reason like that and you never know until she fires you. Just a bit of friendly advice.”

“I’ll keep that in mind but you’re just a child. You don’t understand how business works. I don’t think she will do that to me.”

“That’s what the last four said as well. And yet you stand here before me and not them.”

She gave me one of those patronizing smiles as if I was some unenlightened boy that didn‘t know how the world worked. Saying without words that I would understand when I grew up. Well I had tried to warn her. It wouldn’t be my fault when my mother cast her aside and left her sitting in the middle of a battlefield half the world away with no way to get home. She opened the door for me and I slipped inside, dropping my bag next to the table before going to stare out the window.

The room itself was unremarkable. Probably used for student council meetings or something like that. Just a single rectangular table with six chairs around it. A few bookcases with reference material along the walls and a single window across from the door. It was on the first floor and the window looked out over the track and field area where even now there were kids working out.

A moment later the door opened again, admitting my mother and a petite little girl who couldn’t be more than four and a half feet tall. She had a vacant look in her scarlet colored eyes as my mother pulled the girl into the room after her. A tattered teddy bear pressed against her chest seemed to be in slightly better shape then her tattered green dress. Her shoes were also worn and dirty, just this side of being worn out while looking slightly too small for her feet. Even her pure white hair was a bit dirty and tangled.

When my mother dropped the girls hand to come over to me I noted how the girl just stopped in her tracks and stood staring at nothing. As if she were some machine who’s batteries had died.

Riktal darling! How are you!”

My mother embraced me, kissing both my cheeks before letting me go. I simply put up with it, waiting for her to get to the reason she wanted me. Guiding the child to a chair at the table she motioned for me to sit as well. I ignored the invitation, leaning against the wall next to the window with my arms folded.

“So what do you want mother? Can’t decide what hair ornament looks prettier on you?”

“No, no. Nothing like that. Do you really think I would call you here for such a trifling thing?”

“Yes.”

“You wound me darling.”

“I’m heartbroken here. Can’t you see the tears? So if it’s not a trifling thing then what is it?”

“I need your help. I have to go away again on a job and I need you to protect this little girl. Your father finished his other job early and will be coming with me.”

“So you want me to take on this job as a Hunter, even though you won’t let me take the exams to get my license as one is that it? How very typical of you. Why did you think I would be interested in a job like this at all? Unless the payment is you letting me take the tests then I’m not interested. Find someone else.”

Pushing myself away from the wall I picked up my bag and headed towards the door, ignoring my mother's plea’s for me to wait. Before I left I looked over at Inga who was trying to blend into the wall like a good aide should. I felt I had to try one last time to warn her.

“Remember this Inga. This is just the way my mother is. She uses people and discards them as she sees fit. Trying to mold everyone and everything to her liking. If she is willing to treat her own son in such a fashion what makes you think you are any safer?”

I saw the slight worry in the woman’s eyes as I opened the door and left. Good, perhaps I could save one person from my mother’s uncaring whims. I turned right and walked down the hall, stopping at the corner where it shot off in another direction.

“Did you like what you heard?”

“Me? I heard nothing. I’m just an old woman who happened to get tired of pushing herself around and rested a bit.”

“Right. I’ll let you think I believed that. I’m not in the mood to play games right now. Good day.”

“Hold on Riktal. Would you mind walking with me for a bit? Keep an old woman company and listen to her ramble on?”

I looked over at the principal sitting there in her wheelchair smiling at me. It was a genuine smile, one that reached her eyes. I looked back at the room where my mother still was and then down the hall towards the stairwell back up to my classroom before returning my gaze to her. I had no doubt she would try to guilt me into taking the job. I also didn't doubt she could probably pull it off where my mother couldn't.
1111211221111.title: History

11112112211111.content:
With a sigh I turned down the hall and began walking next to her as she wheeled herself away.

“I know what you're up to. You are going to try and guilt me into accepting the job.”

“If that’s what you think then why did you decide to walk with me?”

“I don’t know. Maybe I want to be guilted into taking the job so I can feel better about myself knowing it wasn’t my mother I caved into this time. Or perhaps it’s because you asked politely and I had no real reason to refuse you. Then again it could also be because I didn’t feel like going back to class. Take your pick. I won’t guarantee any of those are the truth though.”

The old lady chuckled as she pushed the door open and we went outside.

“That sounds like something Marian would say. But I would like you to listen to a story about a guy I once knew.”

“This isn’t going to be one of those stories that is actually about you that you simply changed the gender and the name of is it?”

“No. though I am in the story. This happened a very long time ago. Back when I was still a student at this school. In fact I was around the age you are now. I was quite popular with the boys. They all vied for my attention not because I came from an old family, though I did have a bit of wealth to my name. but because I was quite the looker.

“Among those trying to win me over was a boy named Ivan. He was a shy boy with a bit of a stutter. Always blushing when he talked to me. I actually thought it was kind of cute and was secretly fond of him because of his personality. But the other boys picked on him because he was a first generation from a small town with little money to his name. And because of his timid demeanor.

“I could have stopped it. A few words from me and they would have all listened because they didn’t want to lose my favor. But I didn’t. Not because I thought he deserved to be picked on or anything like that. No it was a very selfish reason. It was because I liked the attention. I liked having the boys fighting over me. Seeing them all get jealous when one of them looked like they were getting ahead. If I had put a stop to their bullying, I would have lost a few of those admirers and some of that infighting between them.

“One day he came into class slightly late. He opened the door and began firing a gun into the room. He killed ten of my classmates, most of them innocent girls that had never bullied him at all, though he killed a few of the boys as well. He continued to rampage until he was finally taken down. In the end he shot himself instead of having to endure living anymore.

“To this day I wonder if he would have ended up that way if I had said just a few simple words instead of letting my vanity get the best of me. What kind of Hunter would he have become?
