How many people would he have saved? How much of this world could he have changed if I had stepped in and helped him.

“Regrets are what eat away at the soul. Could have, should have, would have. People spend their lives regretting. Sometimes those regrets consume them. Keeping them from moving forward, or causing them to make yet more bad choices in an attempt to fix the mistakes they made. It can become an endless inward spiral that ends in self destruction if you let it. That’s why as humans we try to live each day without regrets. But as Hunter’s that‘s even more true. Because those things we end up regretting can end up destroying lives and even cities. As Hunter’s we have the power and ability to topple nations with both our good and bad choices. The only difference is the outcome of those actions.

“You led a group against a Kloo earlier did you not? That was a choice you made. The consequence of that is everyone in the class became better Hunter’s. I’m sure you do not regret that choice. But if you had not acted as you did when you did? The Arena Master would have stepped in, but some of them would have been seriously hurt or killed. If that had happened I’m sure you would have regretted your inaction. Feeling you were not worthy of being a Hunter since you simply stood on the sidelines when innocent people were in danger.”

“You seem to have eyes and ears everywhere.”

A cat came out of nowhere and jumped into her lap. It settled down and began to purr as she petted it absently.

“I’m the principal, It’s my job to know everything that goes on in this school. From the porn magazines the boys sneak in and trade with each other to the cigarettes the girls smoke in the bathroom. The trick is to figure out what’s the most important out of all the information I know and acting on it to make this school better.”

“You really aren’t doing a very good job of convincing me to take this job.”

“I never said I was going to. That was just what you assumed. If you take it or not is up to you, not me. You just have to ask yourself if you can live with the consequences of your choice. It doesn’t matter the reason you make that choice, just if you can live with it. Good day Riktal. Thank you for chatting with an old woman.”

She spun around and wheeled herself off in the opposite direction, leaving me standing there watching her depart. Finally I turned and headed around the corner of the building just in time to see my mother, Inga and the little girl walking out the front doors. I glanced back at the bit of schoolyard behind me where the principal was out of sight before grinning and shaking my head.

I had been played and played masterfully. I hadn’t even realized I had been played until it was too late. I had even been on the alert for her guilt tripping. In the end I had tripped up myself. Looking at that little girl now there was no way I could turn my back on her. Even to simply spite my mother. I would regret not taking the job. With the grin still on my face I hurried to catch my mother before she could leave. Even without a license I was still a Hunter. And Hunter’s protected the weak and the innocent above all else.

*************

So we come to the end of the day it seems. How would he treat the girl? How would the day have gone if he had taken a different course? Those are answers to be found and decided on a different day, a different path. Perhaps though such answer’s aren’t the full truth. For they are not the same as this moment, just as this moment is not the same as the next. Words of happiness and words of sorrow. Sometimes they are the same words, simply uttered from different lips or in a different tone. Love and hate as they say are sometimes as different as the opposite sides of a piece of paper. So why too cannot the possibilities of the choices we make?

Join me again traveler of the realms of in-between. We shall again delve into the depths of young Riktal’s mind and see what fate awaits him by your hand.
11112112211111.title: Walk with her

11112112211112.content:
“Sorry old lady. I need to get back to class. I have a good idea what you are about and I have no intention of accepting that job.”

“Afraid I’ll talk you into doing something you don’t want to do?”

“You know better than that. A Hunter makes his or her own choices. No one talks them into doing anything they aren’t inclined to do already.”

“Then what are you afraid of?”

“I’m afraid you’ll make taking that job seem reasonable and right. So the only choice I feel I have is to take it. You’ve got quite a few years on me after all and I am sure you are much better at this kind of guilt tripping thing than my mother is.”

“Wouldn’t you say that would be the same thing as talking you into it?”

“Perhaps. It’s all a matter of perspective. At least right now I feel I have a choice. If I go with you that choice to say no will make me feel so horrible about myself that it becomes no choice at all. Now good day principal.”

I left her there, heading towards the stairs without looking back. Perhaps I was making a mistake. Perhaps I was letting my feelings for my mother color the choices I was making. But I was tired of playing her games. Tired of being jerked around by her whims. She had never had time for me as a son, so why should I find time to act like one? I had already had to put up with big sis being all over me today, I didn’t need to deal with her.

Slipping back into the classroom I settled myself in my chair and listened with only half an ear until the class was over. It was nothing new to me, but it was mind numbing at least. That’s all I wanted was dull and monotonous to push the thoughts from my mind. As people began to converge on me again I picked up my bag, slipping both arms through the straps and hiking it onto my back. Without a word I pushed through the crowd and headed for the door.

It was so stupid. Why did I even have to come to this school? There was nothing for me here really. I should be out killing monsters, not playing schoolboy with a bunch of boys and girls that still thought they were in a regular high school.

Lost in my own thoughts I ran into a boy with blue dyed hair on my way out the school gates. He stopped me with a hand on my arm saying I should apologize. I did so absently as I pulled my arm out of his grip and kept walking. Apparently this only seemed to egg him on even more as him and two of his cronies surrounded me. So he was looking for trouble.

“I don’t think you really meant that. Say it again with more feeling.”

I looked into his eyes and smiled before bringing my fist up into his gut. As he doubled over I jumped, grabbing his neck between my legs and flipping forwards over his back. Lifting him off his feet and throwing him end over end onto the sidewalk in front of me a good three feet. He bounced a few times and I saw his head smack the pavement as he laid still. I finished my front flip on my feet, walking over to him where he was laying dizzily.

“Sorry.”

With that I walked passed him and kept going. It seems you found bullies everywhere, And they were always stupid it seemed. I was more than happy to put them all in their places though. They were supposed to be Hunter’s, people who protected the weak. Not ones that picked on them.

Soon enough I came to the crossroads. If I went right I could go home. If I went left I could go into the main part of the city. There was nothing at home for me right now except silence and the sounds of an old house. I would have to make my own dinner again too. The city didn’t have much for me either. I could eat out at a diner, maybe go to a bookstore or something. But otherwise I’d just walk around.
11112112211112.title: Go to class

111121122111121.content:
With a small shake of my head I turned to the right. I didn’t feel like dealing with anyone else today. What was the use of going into town and trying to pretend to enjoy myself? Who would I be pretending for anyway? I had been brought up to be a Hunter. That was the only thing I knew. I hadn’t been brought up to be normal like everyone else. To find pleasure in doing extravagant things like hang out with friends or play video games at the arcade. The only books I read dealt with aspects of hunting and monster slaying, not comics and silly fantasies. So there was no point in trying to learn to have fun now. That opportunity passed me by years ago. Just like any chance to be normal.

It didn’t take long to walk home and unlock the spell on the front door. Absently I made three marks on the calendar like I did every day before heading to the kitchen to make myself a snack. I threw a bowl of instant noodles in the microwave before going through the house turning on the TV’s and the radios just to hear something other then the silence. After sitting down and eating my meal I headed to the living room and put on some random sitcom.

I wasn’t really interested in the show of course, but it was something to do. Who knows, maybe one of these days I would get interested in one of them and actually start following it. The words and the fake canned laughter began to blend together as my eyes slowly became heavy. I let out a yawn as I closed my eyes.

“Good night.”

As always, the only one that answered me back was the silence.

**********

Cause and affect. Choice and consequence. So ends Riktal’s first day. What choices influenced his thinking for each decision he made? Perhaps there was no one specific thing. Perhaps it was simply the collection of all the random happenings he experienced. How much differently would things have turned out if even one of those random series of events had fallen into place just a fraction differently?

What if he had fought the monster alone? Or with Liz? Would that have changed how he approached the meeting with his mother? Or are the two events completely unrelated? Did you enjoy being a god? Would you choose differently if given the chance? We shall see the next time we meet shall we not? Until then, may you find the choices you make are the choices you truly wish for.
111121122111121.title: Go home

111121122111122.content:
Screw it, let’s go to town. If it came down to a choice between being alone at home doing nothing and being alone in town doing nothing, might as well choose the town. At least there I might potentially find something interesting. Even if I had no desire to go to the arcade or do anything normal kids might do, there was still more things to do in town than sitting at home.

So I walked. Ambling along watching the cars driving by and the kids from the regular high school chatting with friends and joking with them. They all acted so unconcerned about monster attacks. I knew they were actually worried about such things, but they didn’t let that stop them form enjoying themselves. They all had a sure belief that the Hunter’s of the city would protect them.

As I came around the corner by the river I saw the plaque sitting next to a small stretch of wall that connected to nothing. I had read the little metal sign before. It told how that piece of wall used to be the outer section of the city a long time ago. Back before spells had been invented and perfected that were able to keep monsters out. Before the invention of the automobile and people walked everyplace. Towns had been protected by walls and were much smaller than they were today.

But time passed and like all things the city grew. The walls were torn down to expand outwards past the previously safe zones. Technology advanced and humans found it too much trouble to erect yet more walls just to tear them down again later. The spells around the outskirts did their job most of the time, though on the whole it only kept the really strong monsters away. The weaker ones seemed to slip through the cracks. But humans adapted to that as well.

The secret though to this was the town or city could only grow as big as the Hunter’s who lived their. The spells were powered by those Hunter’s, so the more in a town the stronger the barriers. This made it harder for smaller towns and cities with only one or two Hunter’s to survive. Unless those Hunter’s were extremely strong. Though if that was the case they would most likely move to the bigger cities where there was more work for them. It wasn’t a perfect system, no system was. But it worked and so we maintained it until we found a new more efficient system.

As I passed a store I saw a teddy bear hair comb in the window that reminded me of that little girl from earlier. I don’t know what made me go inside and buy it exactly, perhaps it was just a whim because it reminded me of her. I stuck it in my bag and continued on, entering a family restaurant called Hearty’s. I placed my order and set my bag down at the table, placing a small spell on it to deter thieves before going to the bathroom. I had learned my lesson from earlier. After washing my hands and exiting into the small hallway separating the toilets from the main part of the diner I heard a familiar voice from up ahead.

“….He wouldn’t even listen to me would you believe that honey? He simply walked out of the room without letting me explain anything!”

“Well can you really blame him? Your explanations usually end up making him angry at you. I’ve told you before keeping him in the dark about everything was going to come back to bite you. You toss him in that school without any explanation. You tell him he can’t take the Exams without a reason. And if we are honest, we haven’t been very good parents. Always leaving within hours of coming home. We know the reasons why but he doesn’t. He simply thinks we are putting our jobs ahead of him. And in one respect he is right.”

“Hurry up and start eating already Asala. You won’t get anything later if you get hungry. Damn that Pelei for not taking her anyway. Now what am I going to do? I can’t take her with us. And there is no other Hunter’s I can trust because of what she is.”

“Perhaps if you actually leveled with Riktal and told him some of the why’s of things he might be willing to take her.”

“Oh yes that would go over well. Riktal darling, I sent you to that school because Val asked for help. I also sent you there because we raised you to be nothing but a Hunter. I want you to be more like a regular boy. I thought sending you there to interact with people your own age would show you there is more to life than being a Hunter.”

“Or how about, Riktal honey, the reason I don’t want you taking the Hunter’s exams is because the union has become corrupted. Forcing all new Hunter’s to serve the military for at least a year if they want their license. Your sister became a Hunter so she could work from the inside trying to purge the corruption. Me and your father keep leaving lately because we are having secret meetings with other countries and making deals to overthrow the current union so you don’t have to deal with it later.”

“Don’t forget that you worry about him and are overprotective of him since Olia died. Or the fact that it makes you feel secure knowing he is there when you come home after being away for weeks at a time. Or the fact that you don’t want him to grow up because you are regretful that you weren’t a mother to him before so are trying to make up for it now.”

“That’s just my own personal desires. We taught him to be logical about his decisions. That personal desires have no place in being a Hunter. He would just wave his hand and call it useless information. If he even believed anything I said that is. You know I was never really good with kids. All that crying and clinging. I just didn’t understand them. And why is she not eating. Just between you and me she kind of gives me the creeps the way she is always staring blankly and doesn’t move or react on her own. I don’t even think she can hear us.”

“Riktal always was better at this kind of thing then you were dear. I might have been around a little more than you were but not by much. But when I was, you should have seen the way he treated Olia. He had a real knack for it. Though for the life of me I don’t know how since neither one of us were good role models.”

“The sad thing is growing up I told myself I would be nothing like my mother. Now look at me, I’m almost a carbon copy. Leaving my children to run of to this or that place. Letting other people raise and deal with them and then trying to get back into their lives after they are all grown up. Lying and scheming and manipulating even my own children because I think its for the best. I really am a terrible mother.”

“You really should sit down and tell Riktal all of this. He would probably get mad at first but I am sure he would understand. He is a Hunter and a Zelkov after all.”

“He wouldn’t listen to me anymore. It’s too late for any of that. I think I finally pushed him too far today. Just like my mother eventually pushed me too far.”

I left my hiding spot then and came to stand next to the table.

“You’d be surprised at how well I could take the truth mother. You’d also be surprised at how much leeway I’m willing to grant when I get it. As you said. You raised me to be a Hunter. So why shouldn’t I be able to think logically about the reasons?”

My mother and father both looked up at me with a bit of surprise.

“What are you doing here!”

“I came in to eat after school. I didn’t feel like going back to that empty house quite yet. I just used the restroom and happened to overhear your conversation on my way out. I‘m actually surprised I didn‘t see you on the way past.”

I looked down at the girl who sat like a statue staring straight ahead, a plate of untouched food in front of her.

“You really are quite horrible with children though. Have you even tried to get to know her? Maybe she doesn’t like this food.”

“I did but she doesn’t talk. She doesn’t do anything. Just stares off into the distance all the time.”

“That’s because she is scared. Think about it. Something happened to her. I don’t know what but she wouldn’t have run away into her head without a good reason. I bet she’s been yanked around from place to place without a by-your-leave or a care for how she is feeling. Going to places she probably has never seen before and meeting who knows how many strangers. The reason you don’t understand children mother is because you never tried to understand them.”

I knelt on the floor next to the girl, picking up her right hand in mine as I tuned out the world around me. Ignored my mother and father sitting inches away. Ignored the waitresses and the few other customers. I focused all my attention on the little girl.

“Hello. So your name is Asala is that right? I know you must be pretty scared, I’d be scared too if I was in your shoes. I bet it doesn’t help that my mother was yanking you all around and talking about you over your head like you can’t here her. Well maybe you can’t. But I think you can. You might not react to it and it might be part of the reason you are shutting yourself down, but I still think you can hear every word I am saying. Do you want to know why I think that?”

I reached out and gently grabbed a hold of the bear, beginning to pull it away. Her grip tightened on it as I smiled and let it go.

“Because you are holding onto that bear like it is a lifeline. You’ve been carrying it around with you all this time. That takes muscle control. If you had really shut down it would have fallen long ago. You recognized my hand trying to take it away so you naturally tightened your grip on it. If you can do that I’d also wager a chunk of chocolate you can hear me. So why don’t we start off with something small. Just a yes or no shake of the head. Do you like bears?”

She just sat there for the longest time before her head dipped down and back up slowly. I patted her arm gently as I stood up.

“Wait right here a moment.”

I slipped over to my bag and pulled out the comb I had just bought.
111121122111122.title: Go to town

1111211221111221.content:
Once I was back at the table I knelt next to the little girl again, holding out the comb at eye level for her to see.

“You know I saw this in a store window earlier and quite honestly I don’t know why I bought it. Perhaps it was destiny telling me that I was going to see you again. But you want to know something? I really don’t think it would look good in my hair. I mean could you imagine this thing sticking out of this red head of mine. I think it would just look silly. But I think this ivory color would fit your hair quite nicely. Maybe even help you get the tangles out of it huh? I bet that bear is the only thing you have to your name aside from the dress.”

I looked both ways before leaning in conspiratorially. Just between you and me, I think it is pretty fugly. I bet if you vomited all over it that would actually make it look better. So how about I make you a deal. You chose something from the menu, anything at all. You don’t have to say a word, just pointing will be fine. You eat it while wearing this comb and then afterwards I’ll take you out to do a bit of shopping. Get you a few nice dresses, some new shoes, a few frivolous items that might catch your fancy. Because I tell you true, I never met a girl yet that didn’t like a bit of shopping and making herself look pretty.”

I raised my right eyebrow while narrowing my left eye, puckering my lips and looking at her sideways.

“You aint one of those screamers are you? You know the ones. They put their hands up to their faces and go eeek! And say things like “soooo cute!” Over every little thing. Because you look like your are a talkative one. You look like it might be hard to shut you up.”

I saw her lips twitch and knew I was making progress.

“Wait I said I’d make you a deal. That’s about exchange isn’t it? You do something and I get something in return. So what should I ask of you for all of that huh? For me spending all that money and time on you?”

I rubbed my chin while looking upwards as if deep in thought. I let my eyes go wide as a grin spread from ear to ear.

“Aha! I know. I want you to have some fun. I want you to enjoy the food and the clothes that I buy for you and use them. Because you see. it’s ok to be sad or afraid or angry or whatever you feel like being. But that doesn’t mean you can’t enjoy stuff to. Between you and me, I enjoy a good massage every now and again, though don’t tell my parents. I think they think I’m too stuffy and don’t know how to have a good time and I don’t want to disabuse them of that notion. So do you think we can make that deal?”

I held out my hand in front of her. She slowly blinked at me a few times before finally shaking it. I gave her another lopsided grin before sticking the comb in her long hair over her ear. She reached up and touched it hesitantly as I nodded my head and asked the waitress for a menu. Soon enough she had pointed out what she wanted and I had it ordered, returning to my table for only a moment to grab my bag and return to her side.

Her food came along with mine and she began to eat, slowly at first and then with a bit more zest as I slid into the booth next to my father and stared at my mother while cutting into my steak.

“You just have to know how to talk to them. You don’t need to talk down to them or act like they are complete idiots, simply explain things to them so they can understand. Let them know that you know where they are coming from. Even if you might not know what they are feeling personally you can identify with it. That’s the biggest thing they need most of the time. So what might I need to know about this girls background so I can avoid any major pitfalls. I don’t want to say something that will send her back into her little world again.”

I took a bite of my food as my mother stared at me like I had grown a second head.

“I don’t believe it. Your father always told me you were good with kids but I never really believed. You are the first person to get her to show any signs of life or intelligence in the last three days.”

“It’s nothing special. Anyone can do it if they had simply taken some time out of running around worrying about their own problems and their own lives to worry about hers.”

My dad chuckled, clapping me on the shoulder before looking at my mom.

“I told you Marian, Riktal might surprise you if you just level with him a bit.”

My dad leaned over closer to me and said in a whisper loud enough for the two across from us to here.

“By the way your secrets out. I like a good massage myself sometimes. Though I go to a special parlor that gives a few special treatments if you know what I mean. Just don’t tell your mom.”

I grinned as I stuck some mashed potatoes in my moth as he gave another chuckle.

“Though nothing like you are thinking. Just a few extra techniques and a bit of eye candy.”

I began to chuckle too as the girls eyes looked from my father to me in puzzlement and my mother glared at the two of us.

“Perhaps you can show me this parlor sometime dad.”

“Romone, don’t you dare!”

The two of us began to laugh a bit louder as my father made some calming gestures with his hands. My mother gave him another stink eye before harrumphing and crossing her arms. The moment she looked away he gave me a quick wink an mouthed the word later. As I continued to eat my mother finally filled me in on what she knew of the girl. By the time I was finished the girl was smiling a bit at the random jokes I made and at the funny faces I shot her way.

“So you ready to go Asala? I know a few good clothing stores that won’t be crowded at this time of day.”

She nodded her head a bit enthusiastically, getting up when I did. I paid the bill and offered her my hand after picking up my bag, she took it without hesitation. Before I turned to leave though I looked between my mother and father, making sure I had their attention.

“I only have one requirement for taking this job. Both of you have to stay home tonight. I want to have a long chat with you before you leave in private.. Plus, just like you feel better knowing you have someone waiting for you at home after a long job, I get tired of being alone in that house all the time.”

“I think we can manage that son. We will just have to catch an early flight in the morning.”

I nodded my head to both of them before leading Asala out of the diner. For the first time in a while I had the feeling I might just be able to have something resembling a normal life like other kids had.

************

What a twisted web of fate. Lives come together and part again. Touching and changing with every little interaction. A million and one ways this could have all played out and a million and one directions he could have gone. What choices decided this course? Was it the very first choice you made this day? Did it start from listening to the boy in the locker room? Perhaps neither of these incidents had any affect on how this all turned out.

Come see me again if you wish to play god. To create a destiny and to deny the other possibilities this life could have taken.
1111211221111221.title: Return to the girl

111121122112.content:
“Can this wait until later? I’m really not in the mood to deal with anything right now. I’m sure it’s important but if it’s bad news or you just trying to get close to me for your own personal reasons I don’t want to hear it.”

He shook a little anxiously but finally nodded his head and left the room, leaving me to do a few breathing exercises to calm down. I had at least gotten the Lexington back. Now I just had to worry about the Roller Knuckles. I hoped whoever had stolen them wasn’t stupid enough to use them. It took a certain level of skill in regulating the flow of energy through the body and into the weapons to keep them from destroying the person wearing them. At the skill level these guys were at it could vibrate bones into spontaneously breaking or even turning to dust.

Anyone of a B class or higher would have no problems with them, Gregory had been lucky he had only taken and tried to use the Lexington. The only dangerous part about it was that kickback if you didn’t have the proper stance or locked your arm while firing. They just had to take the two most dangerous weapons in my arsenal didn’t they? Any of the other weapons would have been well within their skill level.

With another sigh I rubbed my eyes again before running my fingers through my orange hair. No use worrying about what had already happened. I needed to get back to class, perhaps I could find some clue as to who had taken my Knuckles.

Sitting back down next to Liz we watched the action below in silence. I noted how everyone had tightened up their fighting style while their teamwork and reaction times had also improved.

“Liz, you know anyone down there that might take a dangerous weapon from someone else’s bag aside from Gregory? Maybe some of his friends?”

“Missing something else?”

“Yes. Some fist weapons.”

“Well just about a third of the people down there are fist oriented fighters among other things. Only Daniel and a few others are specialized in that area. I’d say any one of them is capable of thievery under the right circumstances. Well maybe not Lilia because she is a priestess. Probably not Jethic either since he has a pretty high moral code. Even though Daniel is a fist specialist I doubt it would be him because he’d be afraid of retribution from anyone he stole from. He has a pretty good code of ethics as well on top of that.”

“As for friends, I really don’t pay that much attention to the alliances and relationships going on. From what I’ve seen he has one of those smooth tongues that lets him fit in with almost everybody. You know the type, friendly with all but being friends with none. Gregory is only out for Gregory.”

Glancing down at the floor as a group took on a Screecher I nodded my head. I knew the type well. My mother was that type.

“Speaking of the little thief, where is he?”

“Arena Master banned him for a month before sending him to the principal for punishment. He might have been ahead of everyone else but when he comes back he will be playing catch up.”

She pointed at the groups below with one finger.

“You did all that. Made them better I mean. They are all trying to emulate what you and your group did.”

“I didn’t do anything. They wanted to change themselves. I just did what a Hunter does. They are the ones that took something from it, I didn’t say or do anything special.”

“Perhaps.”

She was silent a moment, staring off at the arena floor but not really seeing anything. Finally she spoke without looking at me, her hands clasped in front of her and her voice a touch softer than normal

“I’m ashamed to say you are a better Hunter than me. I don’t just mean combat wise. I don’t know how well I’d stack up against you in a head to head honestly. But in how you reacted. If it was me alone I wouldn’t have done anything. I would have simply sat and let the Arena Master take care of it. The only reason I jumped up and did anything was because you leapt into action. I just sort of followed you without thinking.”

“The way you handled the situation impressed me. You were able to pull them together into a combat team to take on something way out of their league normally with only minimal help from you. I don’t think I could have done that either. Not because I didn’t know what to do, but because I can’t give off that same level of confidence and command you did. Plus I think my prior standing in the class might have harmed my credibility.”

“In all honesty watching you out there was admittedly kind of hot. Sexy even. It got my blood boiling with a desire to fight you myself. To want to raise my own game up to those standards. So you had better watch out. I don’t plan on sitting on the sidelines and letting you take all the glory.”

She looked over and gave me a lopsided grin then which I returned.

“A rival huh? I haven’t had one of those for a while. I think I might like the challenge.”

We continued to watch the action below, pointing out flaws or gaps in their strategy and movements until the bell rang. Picking up my bag from the locker I headed to the classroom. Next was History, and then Monster Tactics. After that school would be over for the day.

I watched as my classmates filed into the room. I had been the first one in which didn’t seem so surprising. They all gave me speculative glances. Some of them with a bit of starry eyed hero worship tinting their gaze. Others with the hungry look of starving wolves. I could already see some of the girls whispering to each other as they looked my way before letting out little giggles. So now the power struggles and the alliance making as they all tried to get close to me would really begin. I had shown them some of what I could do and they all wanted to be a part of that.

Class dragged on as I only paid it half a mind. Nothing being taught was new to me or even very interesting. I simply let my mind wander where it would. Before I knew it the bell was ringing to signal the end of class. It actually caught me slightly unaware so I didn’t notice the four girls and four boys converging until they were all standing in front of me. I glanced over at Liz who simply grinned and stuck out her tongue.

I really didn’t feel like being very sociable, but I couldn’t completely alienate them either. Even if I thought little of them now, they were future contacts and potential business partners. Should I just bite the bullet and interact with them or should I deflect until another day?
111121122112.title: Can this wait until later?

1111211221121.content:
“You were amazing in Combat class!”

“Would you teach me how to do that!”

“Are you seeing anyone?”

“What’s your favorite weapon of choice?”

I made sure to look at each one of the kids around me. It was good manners to let potential business partners and contacts know you recognize them as an individual and not just as part of the mob. It was a small thing but it went a long way.

“Thank you for the compliment. Perhaps if I feel like it I can show you a thing or two but no promises. If you pay attention in class you will learn all you need to know. No I am not seeing anyone and I am not interested in seeing anyone. My favorite weapon of choice would have to be whatever I can get my hands on. I was trained to be proficient with everything so I have no particular favorite weapon, nor do I have a set fighting style like a specialized fighter. I’m just an all rounder who uses foundations from everything.”

One girl came up hesitantly, fidgeting a bit with her hands clasped together in front of her. She pushed her way through the crowd while blushing slightly and looking down. I could see the look of veiled disgust and jealousy on the other girls faces as I turned my attention to her. As if she had somehow stolen the spotlight.

“Um Mr. Zelkov.”

“Call me Riktal.”

“Um, Riktal. I wanted to thank you for showing me how to be a better leader. I’m a gunner but I’m not really good at giving orders. But watching you out there today was really amazing. The way you seemed so confident and how you just told them what to do so naturally. I- I want to be able to do that too. So I hope you will lead some of us again so I can learn some more.”

I was surprised. She was being sincere. There was a subtle difference between her words and the words of praise the other ones were giving me. Anyone good at reading body language could tell the difference in the inflection among other things.

“What’s your name?”

“V-Victoria Raz.”

“Well let me tell you something Victoria. Mind if I call you Victoria by the way? The secret to being a good party leader is always acting like you know what you are doing and what is going on. Don’t be wishy-washy with your commands period. And if you aren’t the one calling the orders out, don’t be afraid to speak up and countermand bad orders if you know they are wrong. It doesn’t take a genius to know running headlong at an Ooze type monster with a sword isn’t the best idea. Tell you what. I’ll see if I can work something out with the Arena Master to help you get some experience at leading. Maybe a group of me, you, and one or two others.”

“T-thank you! I’d like that a lot!”

Before anyone else could get anything out the teacher came in and did role call. Before he got too far into his lesson though a woman in a smart looking blue business suit, black hair and slightly heavy on the deep blue eyeliner came into the room and whispered with the teacher. Moment’s later I was following her out the door with my bag of weapons to go see my mother who had summoned me.

“My name is Inga by the way.”

I grunted. Not really caring what her name was. This would probably be the last time I saw her anyway. I had used up most of my sociability on the kids in my class, I didn’t need to be nice to this woman. She was of no consequence.

She led me downstairs to a drab meeting room with a single table, a few shelves with books on them and a window. Nothing to mark it as different or special from any of a hundred schools. Sitting at the table I clasped my hands in front of me while I waited. Just what did she want? It had better be important because I wasn’t in the mood for her games.

She came waltzing into the room as if she didn’t have a care in the world, pulling a pretty silver haired child with eyes to match my hair behind her. I suffered through her greeting while studying the kid. Noting the teddy bear she clutched and the ragged state of her clothes. My first impression was of a marionette doll. A four and a half foot puppet that only moved when someone pulled the strings.

“Ok now that you are here you can get to the point mother. I’m sure you want to go running off to some other important place that is anywhere but here. I’ll even make it quick for you too. My guess is you want me to take care of that girl for you because you are horrible with kids. That’s the only reason you would have her with you. No doubt you even had some sob story prepared. You came to me because you always seem to come to me when you want something done for free or for cheap. You know I am a strong Hunter and you think I will do it because I am family. Does that about cover it in a nutshell?”

“I wish you weren’t so hostile towards me but yes that about covers it. So you’ll do it?”

“I never said that. I was just verifying the facts I had assumed. I’ll give you two guesses as to what my answer will be and one of them isn’t yes.”

My mother looked at me at a loss for words, her mouth opening and closing and a smiled thinly because I had gotten one over on her.

“I bet you have no idea why that’s my answer either. And that mother, is the problem.”

I stood up then, picking my weapons back up as I headed towards the door.

“I’m done being your tool mother. I’m done catering to your whims like you treating me as a licensed Hunter one moment and denying me the ability to get that license the next. I’ve come to a revelation just now thanks to you. As if everything just became crystal clear on seeing your revolting face in front of me. I’m quitting this school. I’m taking the Exams. And then I am moving out.”

“I’m getting rid of the family name and washing my hands of you and father and even big sis. I’ll be a no name person from a no name family. Simply Riktal and nothing else. I will move far, far away and never look back. I’ll make my own fortune and my own name without riding on your coat-tails. No more arranged marriage meetings, no more getting the short end of the stick. No more listening to a big old house creek and groan all night long while I am the only one in it.”

“Because I don’t need you or any of it. I haven’t for a very long time. Almost as long as it’s been since I really thought of you as a mother and not more than just a word I pay lip service to. Normally I can’t help but get angry at you every time I see you. You make me rage and my blood boil. But not this time. It’s not worth it. You’ve never been worth it. So goodbye. This will most likely be the last time we see each other.”

As I opened the door her soft words reached my ears. There was something in their tone that made me stop and turn to look at her.

“I hated you too. I hated that you were everything I wasn’t. I didn’t know how to be a mother. I was never good with kids from the start. All the crying and the need for constant attention. I didn’t know how to handle it. So I threw myself into being a Hunter. I treated you like a fully grown Hunter all the time because that’s the only way I knew how to deal with you. I felt awkward holding you or pretending your drawings made sense to me. Awkward at hearing those random I love you’s.”

“Then when I was home I saw how you and Olia were together and I admit I was jealous. I didn’t know how you were able to treat her the way I couldn’t. I didn’t know where you had learned it from. I felt like she had somehow been stolen from me. And so I grew to hate you for being able to accomplish what I couldn’t. But I have also never been so proud of you either. Because despite my failings both as a mother and as a person, you turned out as well as you did. You were able to surpass me.”

“Now you are older and it’s too late for me to change the past. I’m stuck in this rut where I only know one way to deal with you still. I want to change that. I try to change that. But I still feel fake. And I see how you don’t believe me or trust me. How you scrutinize every word and tear it into little pieces. You’re no longer of the age where you will accept what I say as truth or are satisfied if I don’t give you every detail of my reasons. Yet at the same time I can’t give you all those reasons because I am afraid it will make you hate me more. I know things must have been hard on you. Living alone in that house for so long day after day. But I really do appreciate being able to come home and someone is there.”

She clasped her hands on the table and looked down at them. I saw a drop of water fall on her skin from her covered eyes.

“Please. Don’t walk out on me like this. I know I’m a terrible mother. But I don’t want you to go.”

She sounded sincere. But she was also a great actress when she needed to be in order to get what she wanted. Hadn’t seventeen years of dealing with her proved she was a user and abuser? Only out for herself and willing to do anything to make things go her way?
1111211221121.title: Try to be sociable

11112112211211.content:
“Sorry mother, not this time. Even if you aren’t just putting on a face to try to get your way, you’ve toyed with me too often. Seventeen years have proved you won’t or can’t change. A duck will always be a duck no matter how hard it honks like a goose.”

I slipped out into the quiet hallway and turned towards the front door. I didn’t care about going back to class and being a good little boy. This place and everyone in it could all go screw themselves. I only got a few feet when I noticed the presence behind me but I kept walking. I really didn’t feel like dealing with her right now.

“Go away.”

The principal ignored my words as she wheeled herself up next to me with only a small creaking of her wheelchair shifting under her weight. I let out a grunt of disgust but otherwise ignored her. Maybe if I didn’t talk to her she would leave me alone.

“Are you sure about this?”

I didn’t say anything, simply kept walking. She let out a small sigh but continued on as if I had answered.

“Well I told Marian she was playing with fire but she wouldn’t listen. She always was a stubborn one, a bit like you wouldn’t you say? I knew it would either be this or some massive blowup eventually. I’m not saying you are in the wrong or that she doesn’t deserve a little repayment for the way she is, but is this really what you want? People can change you know, and what she said was the truth.”

Perhaps if I answered her she would be satisfied and leave.

“Perhaps they can change, but not my mother. So what if it was the truth, she only said it to try and control me. The truth is as set in stone as using an eraser on pencil markings to my mother. Besides, what business is it of yours? This is Zelkov business and you are not a Zelkov. You should be happy to be getting rid of a troublemaker. Though do you always eavesdrop on conversations that don’t concern you? Seems to me that’s quite rude.”

“It deals with the safety of my school and one of my students so of course it concerns me.”

“Well not anymore, from now on I’m not a student, so go away.”

“Don’t you want to know who took your weapons?”

“Do you know?”

“No.”

“Then I don’t care anymore. They can keep them. I won’t need them if I am getting rid of everything that links me to being a Zelkov. I might have earned them with my own money, but I got the job from a contact I got through the family. The only family I had died three years ago.”

“So you are saying you don’t love them?”

“I never said that. The truth is I do love them despite everything. But that’s not enough to keep me here. Or enough to stop me from turning my back on them all just like it didn’t stop them from turning their back on me year after year.”

“Then how are you any different from them?”

“I’m not. I’m simply the product of my environment like everyone else. This is just the natural outcome of their actions. But I do know that if I ever want to stop being like them I need to leave. I need to sever everything and create myself afresh.”

“As you said, ducks are still ducks no matter how hard they honk like a goose. You won’t be able to change that easily. You are still you wherever you go.”

“That’s true, but I have two things going for me. The first is I desire to change. The second will be that I won’t have other ducks dragging me down and trying to keep me from honking. Now good day principal, I grow tired of talking with you. Go annoy someone who wants to listen to you.”

I shoved my way out the front doors and headed down the street. There wasn’t much at home I needed. Just a few sets of clothes until I could burn them and buy new ones. A couple weapons that I had earned on my own through my own contacts, and the collection of photos of Olia I had hidden away. Of the stuffed animals I had saved of hers, I would only bring Mr. Snuggles. Clean out my bank accounts and then go see Ginger about getting away from here. By this time tomorrow I would be lost among the crowd of some far away place and no one would ever find me again.

I didn’t feel any guilt over my decision and I didn’t regret it one bit. I could finally be free.

********

A tiny difference here, a tweak of conscience there. One thought floats to the top of the mind instead of another. A single word or a small nudge from any number of sources both noticed and unnoticed. All of these affect the choices we are given and the choices we make. Would he have done the same if he had taken a deeper breath? Would he have been able to deal with his mother better if he had not tried to be sociable with his classmates? Or perhaps it started to go wrong before that.

If he had smiled and acted as if nothing was wrong, would that seem out of character for him? Would it make this scenario any less valid? If so, then which is the true Riktal? Out of all the infinite possibilities and divergent paths that could come about, which one of them is the true Riktal? All of them? None of them? Who can say for sure.

Were you satisfied with the decisions you made? Is this the outcome you sought? Did you take his personality and his past into consideration? Or did you temper your choices on the things you wished? Believing the best, or the worst, of people and acting accordingly. Our time grows short and this window closes for now. Join me again and I will be glad to lend you the power of choice. To alter a destiny, perhaps even relive this very day, simply making a different path. Because remember, time has no meaning here. Past, present, future. They all happen at once, over and over. Just be careful you don’t catch yourself coming or going.

Until next we meet traveler.
11112112211211.title: Walk out the door

11112112211212.content:
Slowly I sat back down across from her, letting my weapons hit the floor with a dull thump. Clasping my hands in front of me like she was, I watched her. It was true she was a liar and a manipulator. But maybe just this once she wouldn’t lie to me. Maybe just this once she would tell me at least some of what I wanted to know. I didn’t feel any anger or resentment at this moment, just that sense of crystal clear serenity of mind. If she lied to me again right now, or I figured out she was trying to play me I would walk out that door and never come back. When I opened my mouth I was surprised at how soft and compassionate my words were.

“Tell me why. That is the only condition I will set for taking this job. I want to know why I can’t take the Exams and why I was sent to this school. The whys of everything else can come later. But I really want to know the answer to those two things.”

I saw her clenching her clasped hands together hard enough to turn her knuckles white. I didn’t say anything else, nor did I let my gaze waver. I’m sure she could feel my eyes on the top of her head but finally she looked up at me an answered.

“Because the system is breaking down. It has been for years. It started the year before your sister took the Exam’s. The different governments had been bribing the Hunter’s union for years, Having us take on jobs we otherwise might not take. Using us against other countries. It wasn’t too bad at first, but slowly the president and his cabinet wormed their way deeper and deeper into the union corrupting and infecting more and more high ranking members.”

“It all came to a head when the union instituted a mandate that anyone who wanted to get their license had to serve the military for a minimum of one year and sign a disclosure statement that would take their license from them if they talked. Your sister decided to try to change it all from the inside. At the time we didn’t realize just how deep the corruption went so we didn’t say anything against it. But it has been almost ten years now and it’s only getting worse. We kept it from you because we knew you would try doing something reckless or end up getting yourself killed.”

“We might not have been the best parents but we still didn’t want you to die. Or get banned from ever being a Hunter or worse. You know the union has connections everywhere and has a finger in everything. We might be autonomous and not belong to any one land or government, but we have ties all around the world so we can work unhindered wherever we go. Me and your father have been working for the last ten years with your sister making closed door arrangements with rebels and political activist who want to overthrow the corrupt governments and militaries working with the union and put a new system in place.”

“People like Asala’s parents. That was the real reason I was in Liccia, to meet with her parents. I simply used the cover of doing a job as an excuse so as to not arouse suspicion. That’s also where all the money we’ve made as Hunter’s has gone over the last ten years, into funding this massive overthrow of not only the union but at least seven major governments.”

“And then you started pushing to become a Hunter and we didn’t know what to do. No, I should say I didn’t know what to do. Your father and Val and a bunch of others said to just tell you. Your father wasn’t against you taking the Exams, He said you could endure a year and then we could have two people on the inside so to speak. But I didn’t want you enmeshed in all of this. I wanted you to be able to become a Hunter after the new system was in place. So you wouldn’t have to worry about any of this.”

“That was when Val came to me asking for help. She’s been a friend of the family for a very long time. She asked for our help in making this school better. She has spent her life lowering the mortality rate here and putting out quality Hunter’s but she wanted to drop that percent lower if she could as a final mission I guess you could say. That’s why I sent you here. I thought you could lead them all by example. It would keep you out of the way for a while until the new system was in place and secure while at the same time helping out Val.”

“If I’m honest, I was also hoping going to school here might help teach you what I wasn’t able to. That being a Hunter isn’t everything. We need to be rational and logical to make decisions and to lead people, but that doesn’t mean that’s all there is to it. Because I was so bad at being a mother you were denied a lot growing up. The biggest of it was that human aspect of our jobs and personalities. You had no friends, no hobbies or interests aside from Hunter stuff, so I was hoping being here would help you gain some of that.”

“But I knew what you would say and how you would react if I told you that. So I forced it on you. I did it for my own personal reasons, even if I thought it was going to help you. I didn’t always think like that of course. But after Olia died I really started to wonder. You probably think I killed her on purpose. In a sense I think you are right, I let her die. I was distracted and so caught up in this whole corruption and overthrowing the union thing, I didn’t have time to pay attention to anything else.”

“If I hadn’t taken that call back then, I would have been able to stop that attack. I was so caught up in her being a strong Hunter that could protect herself in this violent world, I didn’t see how unsuited she was for this lifestyle. But afterwards, afterwards I had a lot of time to think. To second guess and to regret. To beat myself up over all of it. Seeing her pictures was unbearable because I saw condemnation for what a terrible person I was in them. That’s why I got rid of all her things. Every photo, every stuffed animal, every stitch of fabric. I thought if I burned them all I could burn away my guilt. Burn away the old me and start fresh. Become the mother I wanted to be but wasn’t. Now though, I want to see her face again but I can‘t. In my blind grief I destroyed it all.”

“I’ve made a lot of bad choices in my life. A lot of bad choices in how I raised you. You’re right when you say I usually do what benefits me most of the time. I use people and discard them when I am done with them. I don’t like that about myself but I recognize it. I do good for a while, fighting those urges. Then it’s like a switch gets flipped in my head and I revert to my old ways for a while. But I guess you never really saw that part of me because I was never around for you to see. I know after everything I have done to you I don’t deserve to ask you to stay. You have every right to walk out and wash your hands of us. Of me. But is it too much to be selfish one more time and ask you to stay? Ask you not to give up on me the way I feel I gave up being a mother to you?”

She stared at me so earnestly, her face more open then I had ever seen it before. I noticed her hands trembling slightly and the little girl had turned her head to watch me with that slightly vacant gaze as if waiting my answer as well. I wanted to believe. But seventeen years of conditioning and proof said otherwise.
11112112211212.title: Sit back down

111121122112121.content:
“Was her death worth it? Can you promise me Olia’s death wasn’t in vain?”

“Yes. After she died I promised myself I wouldn’t let this fail. We are so close. Just another few months and we will be ready. The Hunter’s on our side, and there are quite a few, are going to battle against the ones running the union. They might be the strongest of the strong, but even those ten can’t stand against a few hundred Hunters almost as strong and experienced as they are. At the same time there will be open rebellion in every capital of every country that supported this corruption, big or small. We’ve taken steps to take control of the major defensive fortifications so they can’t retaliate with missiles or anything like that.”

“There will be massive bloodshed and thousands of lives will be lost. Some of them innocent ones as well. But that is the price of revolutions. Our system of Monster Combat Hunter’s is still a good one, it is just the human element that makes it fallible. Val has been working with us for many years now, and just about every Hunter that has come out of this school in the last seven years is working with us. We stand as shields for the innocent and the weak. I’ve never forgotten that. Sometimes we have to play politics to do that job. If the union were to be completely destroyed and the system broke down, their lives would be in danger in the long run.”

“But you have my word. I will make this world a better one for you to live in. Her death will not be in vain, I promise you that.”

I watched her closely, looking for any signs of falseness. My desire to believe her struggling with seventeen years of being let down and toyed around by her. Finally I let out a long drown out sigh while rubbing my eyes. Just one more time. I would believe her this once more.

“I’ll take the job. Thank you for telling me all of this. Now it makes more sense to me. Perhaps I can even be more effective here now that I know the why of it.”

I got up and went around the table, kneeling in front of the girl who turned her head to watch me. Her eyes only held a slight bit of intelligence in them, but at least they weren’t as vacant as when she entered.

“So give me the details of this girls background.”

So my mother told me what I wanted to know. How her parents had been assassinated three days ago and how she was a monster summoner that couldn’t control her powers. I nodded my head in understanding as I gave her tiny hands a squeeze reassuringly. After a moment I felt a small squeeze back as if she understood even though her face gave no indication that she was aware of the world around her. When my mother was finally done talking I looked up at her.

“I want you to do one more thing for me mother. It’s not a requirement for me taking this job or anything. You don’t have to if you don’t want to, but I want you to hold off on running off to wherever you are going after this. Spend a day here at home and with me as I interact with this little girl. If you really want to learn how to interact with and deal with kids then watch how I treat her. You’ll see it isn’t that hard. Perhaps it will help keep you from making the same mistakes in the future.”

“I’d like that. Your father is in town right now picking up some supplies but he will be around with the car shortly. We can take an early flight in the morning to get to Bornica.”

The bell rang signaling the end of school as I nodded my head.

“I’d like that too. It really does get lonely in that house.”

Standing up I pulled the girl to her feet and headed towards the door as my mother picked up my bag of weapons for me. As we left I didn’t try to tug on her arm like my mother had, instead I slowed down my pace to walk next to her. Ignoring the looks and the whispers of the other kids we passed I led the way out of the building, stopping by the front gates to wait for my father. I saw three kids who looked like they were looking for trouble lounging nearby. There was a distinctive look to bullies that let you spot them from a mile away. Jethic passed me and I gave him a small wave. He seemed a bit surprised but smiled hesitantly and waved back before heading off down the road.

“So Asala, tell me, in all the time you’ve been dragged around has anyone stopped to ask how you are feeling? Did they let you pack any spare clothes besides that god awful looking vomit dress? I’m surprised you don’t get sick wearing that thing. Have they fed you properly? Or did they just pull you around all the time?”

When my mother began to speak I held up my hand and she quieted down.

“Lesson one mother, children like to know they matter just like anyone else. Talking like they aren’t there or acting like they are idiots won’t win you any points with them. Even if I can easily get the answer from somewhere or someone else, since she is right here I would like to hear it from her.”

“Lesson two, take their feelings into consideration. Right now she is grieving over the loss of her parents. The shock of that, her powers manifesting, and being pulled away from everything she ever knew to meet complete strangers in places she has never even heard of means she is also probably scared out of her mind. That’s why I am not going to push her. I’ll ask simple questions, only requiring a shake of the head. If she wants to talk then she can, if not that’s fine too. The main thing I want to accomplish is making her feel secure. And believing she can trust me, not as a Hunter, but as a person.”

I repeated my questions again as I knelt on the ground next to her. Asking them one by one and waiting for her reply. At first she was slow to respond but with patience and a comforting squeeze or smile she slowly nodded her head just a fraction of an inch.

“Do you think you would be up to going into town? We can get a good meal, some new clothes and a few other things you might like. You might only be here a few days but no reason you can’t own anything is there? It’s ok to grieve. It’s a natural thing to do when you lose someone or something precious to you. I bet you are afraid of your power going out of control and hurting people as well. I’m here to make sure that doesn’t happen. Even if it goes out of control and hurts someone I won’t hold it against you. You didn’t ask for this power or this life. You are Asala. Not some monster summoner. Just a little girl who lost her family. So what do you say? Up for a bit of shopping?”

She squeezed her bear tightly for a moment before finally nodding her head up and down. I put my hand on her head as I smiled gently at her.

“You are a brave little girl. I’ll make sure not to disappoint you.”

Just then my father drove up in the car. He seemed a bit surprised to see me but gave me one of his usual jovial greetings. It didn’t take long for my mother to fill him in as we all got into the vehicle. I could see Asala was a bit nervous sitting between me and Inga so I switched places with her and that seemed to calm her down.

“Well then, where to son? It seems you’re the boss right now. Whatever orders you give we will follow. I never thought your mother would tell you until this was all over. But then again I never thought she would agree to something like this either. If it helps her learn something I’m all for it.”
111121122112121.title: Believe

1111211221121211.content:
“ Go down to Weaver’s district. Because it definitely has to be shopping first. At least enough to get her out of this fugly dress. I’m ashamed to be seen with this thing next to me. It looks like a dog vomited and somebody turned it into fabric. I feel dirty just sitting next to it.”

I gave the girl a lopsided grin and a wink to let her know I was joking just in case she couldn’t tell. I saw her lip twitch for just a fraction of a second before my dad nodded and headed off down the road. I made small talk with the girl, joking and making funny faces at her while slowly learning small things about her she didn’t realize she was revealing. Things like her favorite color, and the types of movies she liked. It was a basic skill that had been honed for politics, but worked just as well for many other things. Anyone could learn and use them if they wanted.

My mother seemed surprised that I was using this tactic on the girl, as if the thought had never crossed her mind and I believed it. I had found people overlooked the simplest things sometimes. Or maybe it was because I tended to turn molehills into mountains that I saw all those simple things people took for granted.

By the time we finished the five minute drive I had her giggling at a few of my jokes. Even some of the purposefully bad ones. I felt it also had a bit to do with the funny faces I made, though Inga seemed to disapprove of my behavior the way she sat ramrod straight and looked down her nose at my antics. I gave her the benefit of the doubt though, perhaps she just wasn’t accustomed to dealing with this kind of thing just like my mother. But if she was going to be a downer like this the entire time I needed to get rid of her because Asala would eventually pick up on it and be brought down as well.

After entering one of the clothing stores I swept my arm out, telling the little girl to go to town, to try on anything and everything she wanted. She was hesitant at first but my constant cajoling finally convinced her. At first she picked out a cheap drab and plain dress, as if not sure how much she could spend. I quickly dispelled that thought for her as I asked the sales woman which was the prettiest most expensive one in the store. Once I had it I forced her to try it on. After that it seemed like the dam had broken and Asala began to get into the shopping.

Even though she didn’t say a word, I could tell she was happy and kept seeking my approval for each new dress. Some things were universal to all girls it seemed because Olia had acted the same way. I could see the disapproving looks from Inga as if she was counting up the money for all this extravagance in her head. I waited until Asala had gone back into a changing room to try on another outfit before hitching my weapons on my back a bit more and walking over to the woman.

“Quit glaring like that. If you disapprove then tough cookies on you. You seem to be one of those penny pinching accountant types. I see the way you are adding up the costs like the fate of the world rested on each Reul. Don’t worry your head, I’m paying for all of this not you or my mother. If you can’t unbend enough to simply enjoy yourself then go away. I don’t need you ruining this for that little girl. She might look more stable and normal to you but right now she is hanging on by a thread to sanity. Aside from that bear, she feels like I am her only lifeline of hope. If she starts picking up your disapproval she will think you disapprove of her in some way and she will retreat inside herself again.”

“This is the only warning I will give you. I don’t care if you are my mother’s aide or the aide to The One God himself. I will destroy you if I have to. Protecting that little girl to me does not mean simply protecting her from monsters, but from people of all types. That includes unseen and unspoken threats that might harm her return to sanity and feeling normal again. You have been warned.”

I quickly plastered a smile on my face as I turned to admire and make appreciative noises at the dress Asala came out wearing. By the time I had a chance to turn my attention away from the girl I found Inga was gone. I caught my mother’s eyes and she gave me a nod, letting me know she had sent her away without any words.

We came out of the store a few hours later with a few bags filled with new clothes and other assorted items she would need. She looked down at the new light blue dress she was wearing that had some white lace running along the edges and a faint blue flower pattern embroidered on it. Her fingers stroked it lightly as a smiled played across her lips.

“Do you like it?”

“Y-yes. Thank you.”

I was a bit surprised that she had spoken in that small soft voice. I hadn’t thought I would get her to talk until tomorrow at least. She blushed a bit after saying those few words and hid her face in the stuffed animal. I put my hand on her head, giving it a small pat.

“You have a beautiful voice, just like your name. thank you for sharing it with me.”

She nodded her head while still hiding her face but didn’t say anything else. But that was fine, this was about her not about me. Her stomach grumbled then and I let out a small chuckle.

“Well then I think it’s time we found something to eat don’t you?”

Again a nod. I held out my hand and she took it trustingly. When I took her to a place not far away called The Pipe, she settled in next to me only long enough to point out her order before miming that she had to use the restroom. Since the door was in sight I told her to go and she did.

“Part of dealing with her in this case is being close enough to let her know I am there but not so close as to smother her. I want her to feel she can be alone if she wants and she has some freedom while at the same time I am a few steps away. I hope you are taking notes mother.”

“I am darling. You really are good with kids. Your father told me so but I really didn’t believe it until now. I thought it was just Olia you were good with.”

“I just treat them the way I wish someone had treated me. Though I admit, after they reach to be around fourteen, I just don’t understand them anymore. At that age it’s like they go through some alien change when they hit puberty that I can’t comprehend.”

The little girl came back and I saw the redness around her eyes where she had been crying but I refrained from mentioning it to her, shaking my head at my parents to make sure they didn’t say anything either. I didn’t think they would since they had just observed this whole time but I couldn’t be too careful. I also noted the wet stain on the bears head where the tears had soaked through and smiled. Olia had liked to smother her crying with a stuffed animal as well.

Soon enough the food came and she dug in without hesitation. Seeming to have forgotten all about her grief and returning to the normal girl she had probably been a few days ago. I knew that wasn’t true of course, but everyone had to grieve in their own way and their own time.

My mother spent the meal asking me questions about how to deal with children. I was surprised she was taking this so seriously. It made me believe she really did want to change. I answered as best I could and tried my best to keep my old feelings and resentments out of it.

“Son, your mother and I have been thinking. Do you think we could start over? Put the past behind us and try to make this work? After this is all over, we want to take a break from being Hunter’s. Simply staying at home and relaxing. We’d both like it if we could become a real family. I’m sure there will be pitfalls and troubles and misunderstandings. But we really do want to try. Neither one of us were the best parents, we all know that. But that doesn’t mean we can’t learn.”

I stared at them both as I nibbled on my lower lip. Could I believe them? Or would I end up disappointed again? I wanted to believe though.

Asala tugged on my shirt and when I looked down at her she smiled up at me.

“Do it. Be happy.”

I smiled back at her as her eyes began to well up and I pulled her in close to me. She began crying on my chest as I hugged her and stroked her hair.

“It’s ok. Let it all out. I’m sure you miss them both. It’s not a shame or a crime to be sad over that fact. It proves that you loved them and they loved you. It’s also not a crime to feel happy right now either. I bet you thought you were dishonoring their memory because you were having fun today. But that’s not true. It doesn’t mean you love them any less. That’s how life is sometimes. Bad things happen but you find good things to make up for it. Sometimes those good things are the only thing that keep you going when you think the emptiness inside is about to crush you.”

“I’m sure it is hard for you to accept this right now, but you need to go through this pain to move on. Times will be tough but slowly it will heal like any wound. But it will leave a scar. One that is always there and sometimes when you stretch in just the wrong way you feel it again. It’s scary I know. Thinking that one day it won’t hurt so much, as if that too is a crime. Or it becomes hard to remember their voices or their faces. Never forget this moment Asala, or this pain. But don’t let it keep you from growing stronger because of it and moving forward.”

She finally cried herself out and pushed away from me, rubbing her eyes with the back of her hand before hugging the bear to her chest with both arms. She tried eating a few more bites of food but finally pushed the plate away. I stroked her hair a few more times before looking back at my parents who had kept quiet through all of that. I saw a few tears in both of their eyes as if what I had said had made them remember Olia.

“You heard the girl. I’m willing to give it a shot. I’ve wanted to be a real family for a very long time. It’s one of the few things I wanted aside from being a Hunter.”
1111211221121211.title: Shopping first

11112112211212111.content:
It was a little after seven o’clock, the sun was setting, my father and mother were carrying my duffle bag and the shopping bags and Asala was draped on my back with her arms around my neck half asleep. For the first time in a long time I felt happy. Really and truly happy without some distrust or anger or anything else tinting it. I felt like a big brother again. Glancing down at the teddy bear in my hand that Asala had named Mr. Cuddles I smiled to myself. She really was a lot like Olia.

When we got home I slipped upstairs to put the girl to rest in my bed, that being the only room not filled with dust. Tucking the animal under the covers with her she mumbled a bit before snuggling deeper into slumber. With a grin I lightly kissed her forehead and told her good night in a whisper before slipping out of the room, making sure to leave the door open a crack and the hallway light on.

Going downstairs I fell into the couch with a small sigh. My father came in and offered me a soda which I accepted before he sat down on the other end of the sofa. My mother came in a moment later with a tray of cookies which she sat down on the coffee table before sitting in a nearby chair.

“So you found where I stash the sweets huh?”

“I wouldn’t call chocolate chip cookies on a plate wrapped up and placed in the refrigerator a stash. I didn’t know you knew how to bake.”

“There’s a lot of things you don’t know about me. I had to learn how to cook and clean for myself remember. Besides it’s not hard if you just follow the instructions. Though I should be grateful you didn’t find the whiskey I have hidden.”

“You better not be drinking while underage!”

“And if I was?”

“I’ll give you a good thumping that’s what. I don’t need to be a mother to give you a beating.”

“Relax. The only time I drink is when I go over to Ginger’s place and then I make sure to take a nullifier pill so I don’t get drunk. Sometimes I can get away with not getting sucked into her parties, but not always.”

“And why would you go over there at all? I‘m not sure if I approve of that.”

“As if you have any right to judge. I go over there because for one, Sierra and I were close before she died so naturally I got close to her mom as well. For two, I do what any good Hunter does, I make connections. True, the ones that go to her parties might be from the seedier side of the tracks, but even Hunter’s need those kinds of connections. I might not have a license but there are still jobs I can do under the table. Isn’t that one of the reasons you sought me out today after all? You wanted an under the table job done?”

My father laughed a bit at the look of disapproval my mother gave.

“Give it up Marian. Riktal’s right. We are in no position to judge what he does. We left him alone for all these years so we should just be glad he turned out like he did. Don’t try to smother the boy with your newfound desire to be a mother all at once. It doesn’t suit you. In case you haven’t realized, he’s grown up to be a man without us.”

My father took a sip of his drink, setting it down on the table before looking at me with a slightly thoughtful expression. He glanced at my mother who gave him a slight nod before he focused on me again.

“Son, me and your mother were talking. We’ve been discussing this for a while now but I think today really brought it home to both of us. How would you feel about being an older brother again? I said before we want to stay home after this is over and done with. We have money to live off of for a longtime to come. Your mother has wanted another child for a while now, and I think seeing you at work today showed her what she’s been missing out on. But we’d need your help. Because neither one of us are very good with kids.”

“Honestly, I learned a lot today as well. Like your mother, I want a chance to be a better father. I can’t return the time I failed to be one to you or Olia or Ulicia, but I still want to try. I’m sure we won’t get it right all at once, but we both agree we are willing to apply ourselves. If you are willing to bear with us and help us be better parents. I know it sounds weird, but you are a better parent then either of us are right now.”

“I think I’d like that. But only on one condition. Mother stops setting up these stupid arranged marriage meetings.”

“But darling! That’s just the way things are done!”

“Times are changing. Do it another way. Only the old generation families still cling to that outdated way of doing things. Dump it along with the old corrupted union you are overthrowing. I’m not interested and I don’t like having these girls shoved down my throat and expected to somehow fall for them. I have no interest in a relationship right now and when I do it will be on my own terms and with someone I actually care about.”

“Won’t you at least go to the one for next week? It’s already been arranged and it would be an affront to the family to just cancel”

“No. affront the family. I refuse to go.”

She let out a sigh as my gaze never shifted from her and finally nodded her head.

“All right. But I hear she is a really nice girl that you would get along with.”

“The answer is still no.”

We ate a few cookies in silence before my father spoke up.

“So out of curiosity, is there a girl you like right now?”

“Nope.”

“No one you are even slightly interested in?”

“Nope. The closest I could come to being slightly interested in is a girl named Liz Hawthrope. But that is more along a friend basis, nothing romantic.”

My mother began to laugh and I shot her a sharp glare.

“What’s so funny?”

“Nothing. Nothing at all darling.”

We chatted a little longer about random things until my mother mentioned how my words to Asala had reminder her of Olia and how I had been right when I said it was hard to remember her face and voice. The look of sorrow in her eyes made up my mind as I told them to wait right there. Slipping upstairs into my room I pulled out two boxes, one big and one small as quietly as I could. Bringing them back downstairs I sat them down and told them to open them up.

My mother burst into tears as she pulled the lid off the shoebox, pulling out a handful of photos, each of them of Olia. I could see the wetness in my father’s eyes as he pulled out a stuffed octopus and gripped it tightly.

“You thought you destroyed them all but I used all my magic to save this little bit from the flames. I’ve kept them secret in my closet until now.”

I searched through the box until I found a tattered blue rabbit holding it to my face and smelling it as I closed my eyes.

“This is Mr. Snuggles. It was her favorite of all her animals. Tell me, have either one of you heard of Imprinter’s?”

When they shook their heads I smiled a bit.

“They are like Monster summoners in that they have what people believe is a cursed ability. An ability that they are hunted and killed over. The followers of The One God call it sacrilegious, an affront to the power of the deity. What they do is take something a person has held for a long period of time like a photo or a stuffed animal.
