And they pull out the essence that person left behind, or imprinted onto it. The more they know about the person the more realistic they can make the specter they create”

“It’s a bit hard to explain, but they don’t actually bring the soul back from the dead or anything. It’s just like a glorified video that acts, reacts, talks and responds like the real thing. You can have conversations with them and their words change based on the question or the context or their mood just like you or me. The really powerful ones can make this imprinted essence show itself like a holographic image right in front of you.”

“But I’m not that strong. I can only make them come alive in your dreams. You simply hold onto the item that was imprinted and think of them as you fall asleep and you enter into this realistic dream with them. Imprinter’s have another ability though. If they have something already imprinted with an essence, they can copy that over to another item as long as it has been touched by the imprinted person. Mr. Snuggles here has everything I know of Olia inside of him. Up until the day she died. I’ve spent weeks and weeks pouring that into him. But it will only take minutes to copy if you want. Just choose a photo or an animal.”

They both stared at me as if I had grown another head until my mother hesitantly searched through the pictures until she found a photo of Olia where it looked like she was about to jump right out of the picture to hug you. I smiled as I remembered taking this picture. Holding the rabbit in one hand and the picture in the other, I closed my eyes and coated them both in magic. Activating the unique twist of the mind needed to transfer it all over. Even then I could feel the blood beginning to drip down my nose from the massive amount of magical data I was transferring.

Finally I opened my eyes, handing the picture back before wiping the blood away. I felt a bit dizzy, but nothing like when I did a full imprinting. She clutched the picture to her chest before flinging herself around my neck and bawling.

“Thank you darling! How did you find out you had this power and learn about it!”

“I might tell you about it later. For now have some pleasant dreams..”

With that I went upstairs, leaving the two of them alone with Olia’s things. I slipped into the bed with the girl who cuddled closer to me and I held on tightly to the rabbit still in my hand as I wrapped my arms around her and fell asleep.

******

Action, reaction and even inaction. All choices and all valid. Was this the ending you desired? Any choices you regret? How else could this day have gone? Will you join me again sometime to find out? Until next we meet.
11112112211212111.title: Home

1111211221121212.content:
“Well take us down to Gozen street and we will have a bite to eat. If I have learned anything about little girls and boys, it’s that they are always hungry. And this one looks like she could do with a little meat on her bones. Any monster she summoned would probably die of laughter because of how skinny she is.”

My dad nodded before heading off down the road. My mother looked back at me a bit worried. When she opened her mouth to say something I shook my head and motioned for her to keep quiet. With a sigh she turned back around while I turned my attention back to the little girl. I knew what she was going to say, wasn’t it unwise to talk about her power like that? But she was afraid of her power, if I showed her I wasn’t afraid of it, if indeed I mocked it like it was nothing, she would feel more secure.

“So Asala. We are going to have a little game. The rules are simple. I say a word or a food type and you shake your head yes or no whether you like it or not. I know, doesn’t sound like much of a game does it? More like an interrogation. But then, you never played this game with me before. So let’s see… you look like you like eggs.”

She nodded her head slightly. I named off a few more fruits and vegetables before I looked at her sideways with an eyebrow raised.

“You aint one of those vegetarians are you. The ones that are like: eating animals is like eating people! Because I like me a big slab of meat on my plate. Why I might die if I didn’t have a nice slab of ham or a link of sausage on my plate in the morning. So do you like meats like that?”

She giggled slightly before nodding her head that she did.

“That’s good to hear. But you aint one of those freaky meat eaters are you? You know, the ones that think zombie brains are a delicacy. Or cow tongue or any number of those off the wall meats.”

She shook her head back and forth while smiling broadly.

“Good. Because between you and me I think that might be how zombies are really born. Someone ate a piece and said to themselves that’s tasty! Then that night he got out of bed and began shuffling around moaning for brains.”

I mimicked a shuffling zombie with a slack face moaning with my hands in front of me.

“He didn’t really want brains, he was probably just trying to find the bathroom because of what he ate. True story. I just made it up myself.”

She laughed again as I continued to probe her for information, not just about what she liked to eat, but also about what colors she liked, the kind of books she read and anything else I could get out of her while making her think it was all just a game and me joking around.

By the time my father parked the car and we entered a small diner I had a good idea of what she would order. The waitress recognized me and gave me a smile as she came up to the five of us.

“Hey Riktal! Good to see you again! Nice to see you not eating alone this time. Boss said you eat on the house from now on after you helped her out last week.”

“Careful, I might put her out of business with an offer like that. By the way how’s your son Reva?”

“He got better thanks to that medicine you gave me.”

“Glad to hear it. Mind scrounging up a picture menu for the little girl here? Just make sure not to give her one with zombie brains as an option.”

The little girl began to giggle as Reva looked at me strangely but she took our order of drinks and left to get a picture menu anyway.

“You make it look so easy.”

“It is easy mother. Just takes a little practice. But like everything there is trial and error and you mess up. I’m just fortunate I had Olia to practice on. She was a very forgiving girl when I messed up. Unfortunately I am the opposite of you. I just can’t deal with people my own age very well. Once they hit like fourteen or fifteen they are like aliens to me.”

We continued to chat a little bit as we waited on our meal. I was surprised that my mother seemed to be taking this very seriously, asking questions and listening to my answers. I wondered if we could have somehow done this a long time ago if things had worked out differently. It really wasn’t so bad, being able to talk to them like this. It made me feel like we were really a family for the first time that I could remember. Inga sat like a log the entire time. Saying nothing, but with her back as stiff as a board. She was becoming a real downer for this little group.

“Hey Inga, you can loosen up a bit you know. If you’re going to be a stiff collar you can just go back for the day. I’m sure with three Zelkov’s here there won’t be a problem. Besides, it won’t help the girl if you’re like that.”

“I thank you for the concern but I feel most comfortable like this. You seem to be doing just fine with the girl on your own. I am sure you can deal with any problems that might arise.”

“Inga darling, Riktal’s right. You really are being a downer. Why don’t you take the car and go home for the day? We don’t live that far and it’s not like we are strangers to walking.”

“As you wish Mrs. Zelkov.”

When she started to get up my mother waved her back down.

“You don’t need to go right this second. Finish your meal at least. There is no reason you can’t enjoy food that’s already been served.”

The woman nodded her head in thanks and continued eating. There was something about her that seemed off or strange. But then again, I could say the same about any number of people or they could say the same about me. Everyone had a different personality. I leaned over towards the girl sitting next to me and whispered in her ear, causing her to grin. When my mother asked what I had said me and the girl looked at each other before holding our fingers up to our lips and laughing at our private joke.

After the meal I grabbed my bag from the trunk of the car and the four of us began walking after Inga left. I took the scenic route around town, pointing out highlights of the city to the girl and buying a few snacks for her to munch on.

“Lesson three. People have second stomachs for sweet things. This is especially true for little kids. A small bit of candy can go a long way.”

By this time the girl was actively reaching for my hand as we walked along, sticking close to my side the same way she held her bear close. We went into a clothing store and I told her to go wild. At first she was unsure until I told her we weren’t leaving until she had at least three dresses and they all had to be pretty. Once she realized I wasn’t playing around with her she began trying on clothes and primping herself in the mirror. While she was occupied I whispered so only my mother and father could hear.

“Her power is unstable. I have a feeling some of that comes from her life being in upheaval since all this started. She feels all alone in this world. I’m showing her she isn’t. At the same time I am keeping in mind that she is still hurting inside. Right now I’ve managed to make her forget, but later on when this day winds down she will begin to remember again. Because these happy moments will remind her of what she lost. This is all intentional. It’s part of accepting the losses in a meaningful and constructive way while showing her there can still be good times.”

“And if as you said was true and her power is influenced by her emotions, if she were to summon a monster now it will either be weak, or of a more helpful nature because she is happy. Something that would be drawn to the positive emotions. I hope you are taking notes mother because when she does break down or if she does summon something I don’t want you reacting in any way. Just let me do my thing. If she sees you reacting negatively to her crying or to any monster she summons, it will reinforce this thought that she is being bad in some way and make her want to return to her shell.”

I left their side and continued to shower praise and whistles on the girl while my parents whispered to each other. They weren’t my concern though, this little girl was. Finally after about three or four hours of hopping from store to store we had five bags filled with an assortment of clothes, undergarments, shoes, nick-knacks, accessories, personal hygiene items and even a few snacks. She still hadn’t said a word, but she was now much more animated, gesturing with her hands as I deciphered what she was saying. Soon she would begin to talk simply because she would feel it was taking too long for me to figure things out. Or because she wanted to say something more complicated.

All the while my mother and father followed a few steps behind us, fading into the back of the mind while they sometimes whispered under their breath. My mother’s eyes never seemed to leave either me or the girl and a thin smile seemed to be perpetually on her face. In this way we began our walk home.
1111211221121212.title: Eat first

11112112211212121.content:
I was giving Asala a piggyback ride while crossing the river when a red circle suddenly appeared in front of us. The little girl whimpered a bit and lost some of the carefree attitude she had. She hadn’t realized yet the monster had already come out but I had seen it and I wasn’t worried. As I told her to back up a moment I took a step forward and let out a quick whistle while holding out my hand.

After a moment a small little blue and green bird landed on my palm and I brought it over to Asala, kneeling so she could see it better. She was nervous at first of course, but when the bird did nothing more aggressive than look at her sideways in that quick jerky movement of bird kind she lost her fear and looked at it with interest. I ran my finger under it’s green chin and down it’s blue stomach. It chirped happily before ruffling it’s feathers, causing the green and blue pattern on it’s back to glow in the dying light.

“This is actually a monster. It’s called a Puli-puli bird. It is a lot like any other bird you might find in the wild and eats all the same things too, like worms and seeds. But it’s different from other birds, not only because it’s feather’s light up as you can see but also because it is very intelligent. Almost as intelligent as a human. It also understand human speech, isn’t that right little guy?”

The bird looked up at me, it’s head turning almost completely upside down in a comical fashion as it chirped an affirmative.

“They have an innate sense of good and bad people. Almost like a sixth sense. They avoid people they perceive as bad and they are smart enough to blend in with other birds since they can actually change their plumage to imitate them. Do you mind showing the young lady little bird? Say a robin?”

The bird chirped again before ruffling his feathers and puffing out to almost twice his actual size. When his feathers settled he looked exactly like a robin with the red chest and dark back. Asala stared in wonder as the bird let out a small chortle at her look.

“They can also be quite vain and mischievous, can’t you little guy? They are a rare sight to see because they aren’t native to this area. You find them much farther south most of the time because of the abundance of fruit and seeds for them to thrive on. Plus the jungles help hide them. Your summoning power doesn’t always have to summon big bad scary monsters. Not all monsters are bad to begin with. In time you are going to learn how to control this power of yours and when you do you will be able to summon useful monster’s like this guy.”

“Unfortunately right now you don’t have the ability to send him back where he came from. But you will eventually. So if this little guy is willing, do you think you could take care of him until that time comes? There is this big scary world out there and he knows he can’t survive here on his own. And when you leave I’m not going to be able to go with you so perhaps he could keep you company. But you would have to treat him right, or he will go away. Do you think you would be able to do that?”

Asala kept staring at the bird in wonderment. Finally her head went up and down as if she was afraid the thing would fly away. The bird cocked an eye at her one way and then the other before flying off. Asala gave out a small gasp and inadvertently reached towards the sky as if to catch it. But the Puli-puli only circled once before landing on her shoulder and rubbing it’s head against the side of her face. Her hand came up and gently rubbed it under the neck, eliciting a coo of pleasure.

“I think he is in agreement as well. Though you might want to think of a good name for him. One that he likes as well. You can’t just keep calling him Puli-puli.”

As she idly scratched the monster her eyes went deep in thought finally she smiled while looking sideways at the creature, her small soft voice uttering a single word.

“Riktal.”

The creature chortled it’s agreement and the girl grinned even wider.

“I think that’s a good name. Now I can be with you wherever you go right?”

She nodded her head in agreement.

“I’m honored to share my name with your new friend. Now, how about we get home and get you settled in huh? As I recall you got a new pair of pajamas to break in.”

She agreed with another bob of the head and took my hand again. As we continued to walk she kept absently reaching up to rub the monster as if she were in some sort of dream. In time she would learn a few of the other benefits of the Puli-puli, such as chasing away nightmares. But I would let her find those out for herself. They would be pleasant surprises.

Once in the house I showed her the bathroom and left her to get cleaned up, going back downstairs to conference with my parents.

“I didn’t think you were right back at the clothing store, but it seems you knew what you were talking about. I would have never thought of using the monster she summoned like that. I would have just let it fly away.”

“It’s what happens when you think of someone besides yourself mother. This way she will never feel alone because she knows she has a constant companion. Even when she leaves she won’t be as scared of the next new place because she has somebody going with her. That’s lesson four. Nobody likes being alone all the time.”

My mother and father looked at each other, sharing a quick nod before my father turned his attention on me.

“Listen son, me and your mom were talking today while we were watching you. How would you feel about being a big brother again? Your mother said she wants to do it right this time. And she’d like to know if you could help her do that. After this whole mess with the union is over, we both want to take a nice long break from being Hunter’s. From running of to the ends of the earth for untold weeks at a time and leaving you alone. We have enough money to last us for years without putting a dent in our coffers, so we don‘t need to go slaying anymore.”

“I’d like that. I’m willing to give it a shot.”

I watched my mother’s eyes beam and the grin on her face stretch from ear to ear as she let out a short sob. I struggled with myself for a moment, wondering if I could trust them with my secret before finally deciding if I wanted to put it all behind me I needed to make the first step.

“Mom, did you really mean it earlier when you said you wanted to see Olia again? That you regret throwing everything that reminded you of her out?”

“Yes. I’m so sorry darling. I shouldn’t have done that. I should have thought of you more, I know that now.”

I waved her apology away.

“We will talk after I put Asala to bed. That will probably be when she finally lets it all out. You can watch through the door if you want, just don’t interrupt or let her know you are there.”

After that I heard the water turn off and headed upstairs to show her to my room, making sure her teeth were brushed beforehand. She yawned sleepily as I tucked her in and the Puli-puli settled on the headboard. Before I could leave she grabbed a hold of my tunic as her eyes began to water.

“I’ll be here until you go to sleep ok?”

That seemed to put her over the edge as she began to bawl. I pulled her into my chest and rocked her gently, telling her it would be all right. Stroking her hair as she let it all out. She finally fell asleep like that and I laid her back down, making sure her bear was tucked in tightly with her. When I was sure she wouldn’t wake up and the monster chirped as if to say he would watch over her, I opened my closet and pulled out a big tattered box and an old shoebox, carrying them downstairs with me as my mother and father followed.

I set them down and invited them to open the items. They did so with a small question in their eyes. My mother broke down as she began pulling photos of Olia from the shoebox. Even my father had tears in his eyes as he pulled out stuffed animals.

“It took a lot of magic to make you think these were all burned up, but I managed to save some of her things. I hid them because I thought you never wanted to see any of it again.”

Digging through the big box I finally found the old blue rabbit that was Olia’s favorite. Missing eye and badly sewn on ear and all. I handed it to my mother who took it like it was the most precious thing in the world, and it was in more ways than she knew.

“Have you ever heard of an Imprinter?”

When they both shook their heads no I continued.

“It’s a rare magic just like monster summoning. And just like summoners, people call it a cursed magic and hate it without cause. An Imprinter has the ability to recreate a person through the essence of things they held, or imprinted on if you will. It’s not like calling the soul back form the dead or anything, but the more of their essence and the more the Imprinter knows about the person, the more real the imprint becomes. They talk, act and react just like they would if they were really alive.”

“Strong Imprinter’s can make the essence manifest itself while awake, but most can only make their work come alive while you sleep. That rabbit is imprinted with Olia. She carried it around everywhere. She cried into it, she slept with it, even bathed with it at times. If you go to sleep while thinking about her and holding onto it, she will appear in your dreams. If you want to see her again take it. You can have it when you leave too as long as you promise to bring her back.”

“But how did you find one of these Imprinters if they are so rare honey? I mean wouldn’t they be afraid of being killed if anyone found out?”

I laid my hand on the rabbit a moment before walking past my mother.

“It was simple, I looked in the mirror.”

I headed out the door and back up to my room where I slipped under the covers with the little girl.

******

Our time grows short this night. Come again and play god. Alter a destiny.
11112112211212121.title: Home

111121122112122.content:
“You almost had me. I really did believe you for a moment. But I know you too well mother. Even if everything you said was the truth, it’s not the whole truth. I just can’t accept anything you say as believable. Perhaps that’s my failing as a Hunter, being unable to put aside the seventeen years of history I have with you. But you won’t suck me in again.”

I stood up as the bell rang and headed towards the door with my bag.

“Goodbye Marian Zelkov. May we never meet again.”

I let the door close on the three without looking back. I would go home and pack my things. I had enough money to live off of for a few months. By that time I could set myself up in a secure place somewhere far away. Perhaps Ginger could help me lose myself with a few of her contacts. I felt a few tears running down the side of my face and wiped them away quickly. I had really wanted to believe her. I had wanted so much for everything she had said to be the truth. But I just couldn’t.

I just couldn’t.

************

A twist of fate. An errant thought that floats to the top of the head over another. Such small things can lead to vastly different outcomes. Does it make every other outcome any less valid? Does it make the way young Riktal handled the situations presented to him untruths? If he gets angry on one timeline does that mean the compassion he shows on another is him being fake? Or are both timelines equally true? Equally showcasing a part of who he is. Another side of him that you would not have seen if not for that small errant little thought if you will.

How much of his interactions with the world around him affected how he viewed the events placed before him? He became angry at Gregory for his thievery, does that mean if things had played out differently he would still have that view of the boy? Would his weapons always be stolen by Gregory if such events were to fall out differently? Those errant thoughts that are as small as a pebble being dropped into a river can still alter the course of the river given time.

Come again and witness the flow of time with me. Throw the pebbles into the river and see just how much you can change the course it takes with your own hands and eyes.
111121122112122.title: Disbelieve

1111211221122.content:
“You were amazing in Combat class!”

“Would you teach me how to do that!”

“Are you seeing anyone?”

“What’s your favorite weapon of choice?”

Instead of answering any of the questions I stood up quickly, giving them all a nod of the head.

“Excuse me, I need to use the restroom.”

I pushed past them and went out the door without looking back. Well that was more avoidance than deflection, but it worked. I quickly slipped into the bathroom and looked at myself in the mirror, pushing my glasses back up a little higher after throwing a bit of water on my face. The day was almost over Riktal, remember that. They really don’t mean all that much harm. They are still adjusting to being Hunter’s. Give them some leeway. It’s only natural that they want to know more about you. They need to make connections for the future just like you do.

Even telling myself all that I could only half believe it. I was a Zelkov, it was like the core of our beings to not trust anybody, not even our own family. With as much political power and influence as we had, not to mention acquaintances in high places, we had to mistrust and look for deeper plots in everything. I wasn’t as mistrusting as my parent’s yet, but in time I would be. Even if I vowed it wouldn’t happen to me, I knew such a thought was folly. I had been brought up to be rational about the choices I made, because a Hunter needed to set aside personal desires and thoughts for the good of all. Letting personal emotions hinder me from taking a job or position that would save or protect lives was not the kind of Hunter I wanted to be.

Finally I felt I could hold myself together for the next hour, leaving the bathroom to head back to class. I hadn’t gone far when I was met by a black haired woman dressed smartly in a business suit. She strode over to me and stood at attention, looking me up and down as if inspecting some strange specimen.

“Riktal Zelkov correct?”

“That would be me. Who are you?”

“Inga Ice. I’m one of your mother’s personal aide’s. She wishes to speak with you.”

“So what does she want to speak to me about this time?”

“I’m not at liberty to discuss her business. It is for her to explain it.”

I shrugged and motioned for her to lead the way, following after her. Judging by first impressions I wasn’t feeling all that charitable in telling her to look for a new job. My mother would tire of her soon enough and find someone else. Firing her without warning and leaving her high and dry. Let her cry and fret when it happened because I wouldn’t care.

Inga led me to a small meeting room on the first floor that looked like a generic TV club room or maybe where the student council of the school met. Once her job of escorting me was done she ignored me to stand against one of the walls, trying to blend in like a good yes man should. Shaking my head slightly I went over to the window to look out at the group running around the track. Tomorrow would be the alternate classes for our group that were more along the lines of what you found in a regular school. This might be an academy for Monster Combat Hunter’s in training, but it was also an accredited high school that had to teach at least the minimum of academic knowledge. How were the kids here supposed to become good Alchemist if they didn’t know the basic periodic table or the reasons of how molecules bonded together. Or if they couldn’t do some entry level Algebra.

The door finally opened again and I turned to see my mother leading a little girl with snow white hair and scarlet colored eyes into the room by the hand. Though it looked more like she was tugging her by the arm than leading her. The girl had a blank gaze that stared off at nothing, moving more from reaction than from her own will. Her ugly green dress was a bit frayed around the edges and looked like she had worn it for at least three or four days. The only thing that seemed out of place was the brown stuffed bear she clutched to her chest with her left forearm.

She offered me a seat with her hand after giving me a quick embrace but I refused, preferring to lean against the wall with my arms folded.

“So what is it this time mother that you felt it was so urgent to call me here?”

“Riktal darling, I’d like you to meet Asala. She is going to be your new bride.”

I didn’t even bother to reply to that, simply pushed off the wall and headed towards the door. My mother hurriedly jumped up and held out her hand to stop me.

“Wait! Wait! I was only joking darling. I thought to lighten the mood a little that’s all. I know how you can get sometimes.”

“I wonder why.”

I leaned back against the wall while saying that, letting a mask drop over my face as I narrowed my eyes at her.

“So then why are you really here?”

“This little girl needs you. She lost her home and her parents three days ago and needs protecting. I have someone coming to pick her up but I can’t watch her. I have important business in Bornica and your father will be going with me too.”

“Sounds more like you need me and not her. As for your important business, when don’t you have important business? At least important to you if no one else. So why me?”

“Because you are a top notch Hunter.”

“No I’m not. I don’t have a license remember? Somebody denied me that right.”

“You still have the skills. You don’t need a license for that.”

“And yet here I am stuck in this school wasting those skills for the next three years.”

“That’s why I am offering you this job, to put those skills to use.”

“I don’t think my mother would approve. After all, she didn’t want me taking the Exams so she wouldn’t want me taking Hunter jobs as well.”

“I think I could talk her into it.”

“If you can, tell her I won’t settle for anything less than being able to take the Exams after it is over and dropping out of this stupid school.”

“I doubt she will go for that.”

“Then I doubt I will take the job. Find someone else. Maybe Pelei or Jo-Jo. They like little kids and she might enjoy being dressed up by Pelei all the time.”

“Don’t you think you are being a little unfair here? Won’t you at least listen to the full story?”

How was it she knew how to push just the right buttons. I felt my teeth clamping together as the anger slowly boiled up inside me.
1111211221122.title: Deflect gently and ignore them.

11112112211221.content:
I just couldn’t let it go this time. I had held my tongue before but not anymore. She had just pushed my buttons one too many times.

“Fair! That’s not a word that deserves to come out of your lips mother. You taint that word by uttering it! Fair to you is whatever gets you what you want! What is it you told me when I was six years old? Oh yes! Life is unfair so grow up and get over it! How exactly am I being unfair? You don’t want me to be a Hunter, so I’m not taking a Hunter level job. Seems fair to me! What’s unfair is being told I can’t take the Exams. Unfair is being thrown into this dump of a school to waste my time learning things I already know!”

“Unfair is seeing my big sister take the Exams at fifteen, two years younger than I am right now might I add, without any complaints from you or father. Unfair is being left alone in that empty house day after day while you go off slaying monsters for weeks at a time. Not even a quick call to say hey how you doing! Unfair is knowing how to take care of a house and kids better than you. Unfair is not having any childhood to speak of or seeing a mother more than maybe once a month.”

“When was the last time you were there for my birthday huh? Or a holiday? Doesn’t matter what holiday, pick one and I can tell you where you weren’t! Until Olia died she was the only one I spent my days with! No let’s call it how it is shall we? Until you murdered her. Because obviously you didn’t care about fair then either! Shoving the whole “you are a Zelkov so you have to be a Monster Hunter” mentality down her throat when she was as unsuited for it as man is to live on the sun!”

“Fair for you has always been what’s best for you! That’s why you thought it was fair to destroy everything that reminded you of Olia. Because it was too painful for you to look at it! Not because you loved her! But because she tarnished the Zelkov name! Never mind the fact that when she died it was like a part of my soul was ripped from me! I was more of a parent to her than you were. Just like big sis was more of a parent to me then you! Do you want me to go on or are you satisfied that what I am doing is fair?”

I headed towards the door with my fist clenched so tight I would probably break the skin soon.

“You shouldn’t talk to your mother like that.”

I swung around, throwing out a cord of magic to wrap around Inga’s neck, pulling her towards me as I leapt forward in a spinning kick, smashing my boot into the side of her face and sending her flying.

“You stay the hell out of this you insignificant piece of trash! My mother will get tired of you soon enough and discard you like all the others! And she will do it with a smile on her face and call it fair the entire time. Because that’s just who she is! If you are lucky she will strand you someplace safe! Where was it you left your last power hungry whore mother? Oh yes I remember! In the middle of a city halfway around the world while it was in the middle of a civil war where women were treated like property! I hear they also thrived on the sex slave trade. I bet you don’t even regret your actions do you? Never thought twice about dumping the excess baggage.”

The girl squeezed her bear as I yelled at my mother, and a red circle appearing under my feet. Skipping out of the way I avoided the large hand that burst up from the pit trying to grab me. Quick as lightning I jumped forward again, thrusting downward and punching the giant with all my might in the eye. My fist went through the orb and into the brain where I released an aura of magic that caused it to turn to mush. As I pulled my fist out of the dead creatures head I looked back up at my mother and the girl.

“Now it makes more sense. She’s a summoner. And we all know where you stand on that score don’t we? You knew I have nothing against them so you thought I would be willing to baby-sit. Yes that totally seems fair. You know what seems even more fair? I just kill her. Or perhaps you kill her. Then she no longer becomes a threat to thousands of people. You’d have no problems doing that would you? After all you barely tolerate them to begin with.”

“Riktal that’s enough!”

“Enough? Enough! No! It’s never enough with you mother! Always pushing! Always demanding! Always expecting! Well I’m tired of it all! Never getting answers! Never knowing why! And you never listening! So how about you make a choice right now! Kill me, kill the girl or let a few thousand students die!”

I created a whip of magic attached to each hand, smashing one down on the table in front of the girl and cutting it in half. The other one I snapped forward to cut her cheek. Flailing around I cut through the walls, taking out the support beams one by one and causing the building to shake.

“I’m tired of being the good little boy mother! Tired of all your crap! Of the Zelkov name! If I can’t be a Hunter then I will just be a villain! I’ll make that girl summon a giant monster to help me rain destruction down on this damn school and take everyone and everything with me if I can! So kill her or kill me! That’s the only way I’m going to stop! That’s the only fair thing isn’t it! Can’t decide! Then just do what’s best for Marian Zelkov like you always do and screw everyone else!”

I heard the door open just as a part of the ceiling fell where my mother was standing. She grabbed the girl and jumped back even as a red circle began to appear on the ground. I turned quickly just as my mother chopped the girl on the neck to knock her unconscious and stop the summoning. The principal leveled a shotgun at my chest and fired. I blocked it with a protective shield as I threw my whips in her direction. Her wheelchair tipped back on it’s own as my whips passed through the door and wall above her in an X pattern.

Flipping back up she fired two more shots, both of which I blocked but ended up losing a few inches. As I turned the whip in my left hand into a large ball of energy to throw at her I felt the blow to the back of my neck and my body froze up. I fell to the ground fighting back the darkness, using healing magic to burn it all away as fast as I could. I wouldn’t be taken down here. I would kill my mother first.

“Sorry about this Val. I’ll pay for the damages.”

“I told you this was going to happen one of these days Marian if you kept this up, but you wouldn’t listen.”

“I know, but I don’t know what else to do.”

“The thing I told you to do from the beginning, sit him down and tell him the truth.”

“I guess I’m going to have to. That is if he will even listen to me after this.”

“He is so much like Miktal. Once he calms down, he will listen and think rationally.”

I got to my knees and pushed off from the ground with my hands. I wasn’t done yet. I would destroy everything!

“Kill… you… all!”

The boot came into my field of view seconds before it connected with my face and blackness descended.

***********

So ends another day for Riktal. Is it his last? Perhaps, perhaps not. What is this truth of which they speak? Did you think it would end up like this from the simple act of not telling your last name this morning? Such is the way of things. Each choice creates a new path, a new opportunity missed.

Come again and chose a destiny for this young man ad see where else his day might end up if he had taken another route in life.
11112112211221.title: Blow up on her

11112112211222.content:
With a sigh I unfolded my arms and pushed away from the wall, sitting across the table from her.

“Fine. Give me the whole story. Though since it is you telling it I doubt it will actually be the whole truth. Just a mixture of truth and half truth to fit your needs as you attempt to convince me you aren’t lying or try and guilt trip me into accepting this job.”

“Why would you say that!”

“Because it’s the truth. And so you know I won’t be blindly fooled by your manipulating ways anymore.”

She looked at me with slightly sad eyes. Eyes that on another person might make me believe they were on the verge of telling me a big secret or clear up some misunderstanding. But on my mother they were just another form of control. To make the person she was talking to more sympathetic and willing to do what she wanted. Finally she let out a small breath before starting her story.

“You know how my last job was in Liccia right? Well Asala’s parents were very big political activists and quite outspoken against the kingdom and the dictatorship of the queen. It made them a lot of enemies as I am sure you could believe. But they also had a large following which made it hard to actually do anything to them.”

“While I was there I was contracted by the queen to assassinate them.”

“And I am sure you took the job like the good little dog you are because it was for the good of the people.”

“Your wrong. I knew and had worked with her parents in secret before that so I knew what it was they were trying to achieve and agreed with it. After declining the job, work kept me from going and telling them about the plans to assassinate them. Now I wish I had, since someone had actually succeeded by the time I got back.”

“From the reports that I got and from the private investigations I made I concluded the assassin was another Hunter. He had managed to kill them both before a monster mysteriously appeared out of nowhere and killed him in turn.”

I glanced away from my mother to look at the little girl before resuming my stare.

“Then she is fortunate that you found her. Not many people like monster summoners.

“I didn’t find her. Someone else took her away after the initial confusion. One of her parents supporters. But I doubt they fully realized what she was until after I took her into my custody and protection. It seems her power manifested when she saw her parents murdered in front of her. As such, her powers are a bit unstable and seem to respond to intense emotions the most. Though she could unwittingly summon something at any time.”

“So now after two days you’ve grown tired of dealing with her and decided to dump her on someone else while you go flitting off to some other job until you get bored of that too. Then again I suppose that’s simply the story of your life isn’t it?”

“Think whatever you want of me. Maybe I deserve some of that resentment.”

“Maybe?”

She ignored my derisive snort and single word.

“But this girl really needs your help. I need your help here. Not many people would accept her because of her ability. They would prefer to kill her on sight. We’re family aren’t we?”
11112112211222.title: Hold temper and listen

111121122112221.content:
“Fine I’ll do it. But not because we are family. We barely have that kind of bond to begin with. I’ll do it because she needs my help. And I already know you are useless when it comes to these kinds of things. She would probably starve to death if left with you. Get out of here and go do your job. That’s always been what’s most important to you anyway. You got what you came for. But know this. I’m taking the Exams after this is over whether you like it or not. That’s my payment. If you can do whatever you feel like doing and screw what anyone else wants then I might as well too.”

“Riktal…”

“Enough! Go before I change my mind. There will be no negotiations here. Go save a village or something for money you don’t need.”

She finally left me and the girl alone after another one of those soulful looks like she was going to reveal a great secret. Sliding my chair back I took a seat next to the girl, holding her hand in mine while her left hugged the bear.

“Sorry you had to hear that. I know you are probably thinking I should be nicer to my mother aren’t you. I bet you had a really good life with your parents. They were always around and told you what a good job you were doing. You probably ate together and played games together. Maybe you didn’t, but you look like the kind of normal person I wanted to be. That’s the kind of life I imagine most normal people have anyways. The complete opposite of how my life really is.”

“So how about we take it slow huh? By the way, I think Asala is a pretty name. Do you have a nickname or a pet name? I hope it isn’t Asa or something like that. Because that sounds like a bad punch line to a joke. Though I guess my nickname isn’t much better. My sister calls me Riki tiki and rubs her face all over mine. She says I have some secret energy that I give off that fills up her tiki tank to keep her going like she is some sort of robot. Makes me wonder, if she ever runs out will her face melt off to reveal the cogs and gears beneath or something? Wouldn’t that be a funny sight to see?”

I elongated my face and widened my eyes while moving my jaw up and down mechanically. I moved my head from side to side jerkily like a machine as well while talking like a robot.

“Tiki reserves on empty. Unable to refuel. Casting away outer shell to conserve energy. We are the robo warriors. We have come to suck all tiki’s dry. May the power of the tiki compel you! Neener-neener.”

She let a small smile spread across her lips as she elicited a little giggle.

“I don’t really know if a robot would go neener-neener or not, but it would have to have catchphrase of some kind right? And something like clank-clank would just be silly. But make no mistake robots aren’t silly at all. Well maybe the ones that wear pink maid outfits and do the disco. Those ones are probably silly.”

By that time she was cracking up, unable to keep that blank stare any longer. I offered her my hand as the bell rang and she took it.

“I figured you weren’t completely in your own little world. But no one bothered to stop and try to make you feel at ease did they? I know my mother didn’t. You were probably afraid of her weren’t you? But just so you know, I don’t care if you are a summoner or not. I don’t blame you for having that power, you didn’t ask for it. You are just another scared little girl to me.”

I pinched my nose with my fingers as a wrinkled my face.

“A little girl with an awful smell coming from her. I think its because that dress is so ugly even the air is rejecting it. First thing we have to do is get you a few new clothes. And something good to eat since I bet you are hungry. Just stick close to me and everything will be all right.”

She nodded her head as she stepped closer to me and clutched my tunic. I led her into the hall and back to the classroom so I could pick up my duffle bag. The room was deserted which was a small blessing in and of itself. When I walked own the aisle to get my stuff I noticed my Roller Knuckles were sitting on top of the bag with a note saying I’m sorry.

I decided not to pursue the matter any farther as I stuffed the weapon into the duffle and hoisted it onto my back. I had gotten them back, no one had been hurt with them, and I had bigger things to worry about in the form of this little girl.

On the way out of the school a few kids stared at me and the little girl but I ignored them. I took her shopping for a few hours and out to eat. Though she was scared she still enjoyed herself from what I could see. All it had taken was someone to pay attention to her. I could still see the fear and the sorrow but she felt more secure which is what she needed the most right now.

On the way home she tugged on my shirt, making me stop. We were on the bridge crossing the river with the sun setting on the horizon, turning the clear water into a mirror. She motioned for me to kneel down and I did. Once I did so she wrapped her arms around my neck and rubbed her face all over mine with a giggle.

“Riki tiki! Tiki tank charged! Clank-clank!”

I laughed along with her as I gave her a hug back moments before she began crying. Picking her up I walked the rest of the way home with her that way as she kept saying Riki tiki over and over in between sobs. I knew she was somehow coping with the death of her parents in this way. I might not know what was going on in her mind but I didn’t need to know. All I needed to know was she thought needed to do this to grieve right now.

Dropping the stuff on the floor after getting into the house I sat on the couch and held her. Her breathing finally evened out as she fell asleep like that. As gently as I could I laid her on the end of the sofa before finding a cover to lay over her. The bear dropped out of her hand as it hung over the side of the couch so I picked it up and tucked it in with her. She smiled and mumbled as she snuggled it closer to herself and I couldn’t help but grin crookedly as well. Sitting on the end she didn’t fill I leaned my head back and let sleep come over me as well.

******************

Destiny, chance, free will. Are these things illusion? Or do they somehow weave a web of confusion? Do all three exist in some symbiotic harmony? Or are they always at war with each other in a battle so vast the human mind cannot comprehend it. How free is free will exactly? Do we only believe it free? Is destiny or fate simply another word for the convergence of free will from many people coming together and interacting on this grand scale? They say fate is what is “meant to be.” if so then was this always meant to be? Was this day always meant to end up like this? Even with the multitude of infinite variations and permutations that could have happened this day? Did it not matter the choices made or the free will of everyone in the world?

Perhaps you will join me again and we shall delve into answering this question. We shall follow young Riktal’s life from the very beginning of this day and see if there is truth to everything they say. Though I give you this chance to choose and say you may return of your own free will, I see the future and know that returning is your destiny.
111121122112221.title: Accept

111121122112222.content:
Her eyes pleaded for me to accept but I shook my head.

“You almost had me. Almost. Trying to use the whole family line screwed you over. You might be the woman that gave birth to me, but you’re not my mother. We are family in name only. I feel no responsibility towards helping you. Just like you felt no responsibility in raising me. Go find someone else. I’m sure Pelei might do it. He tolerates summoners and she is cute enough for his tastes.”

I stood up and gave her a small bow before leaving the room. The bell rang signaling the end of school and I began walking towards the front doors before realizing I had left my bag in the classroom. With a sigh I turned and headed back up to the second floor.

By the time I got to the classroom it was already emptied out which was a relief. I didn’t feel like trying to deal with any more bull crap than I had too right now. When I got closer to my bag I noticed my Roller Knuckles were sitting on top with a note that simply said I’m sorry. A quick look through my duffle satisfied me that nothing else had been taken. Hefting the fist weapons in my hand I contemplated doing a trace spell on them and finding out who took them to begin with. After a moment I simply stuffed them in my bag.

I got them back, that was all that mattered right now. No use going to look for trouble. Dealing with my mother had drained all that anger away. That always seemed to be the case when I dealt with her, I just ended up feeling empty.

Hitching my bag onto my shoulder I left the school and walked home alone. That seemed to be the theme with me, alone. Silence and alone seemed to just surround me like some invisible cloak, following me wherever I went. But perhaps that could change with Liz around. She was the first person in two years to break through that bubble around me. I came to the front door faster then I thought I would, being lost in my own thoughts as I was. A quick wave of the hand unlocked the door and let me inside.

“I’m home.”

Of course no one answered. There was no one here too answer. There rarely ever was. Dropping my bag on the floor I went through the house turning on the radio and the TV’s just like I always did. If I didn’t focus too hard I could almost believe there were other people here. Throwing a microwave dinner in to heat up for a light meal I went into the hall again to mark a red, blue and green X on the calendar next to today’s date. Looking back through the month I saw one of each colored circle, that was about right. My mother, father, and sister all came home about once a month.

After eating the meal and cleaning off the single fork I had used I lounged around on the couch while watching some mindless sitcom I had no interest in. It was simply noise to fill the silence. I felt my eyes close and let them. It might be early but there was nothing else to do except sleep whenever I felt like it.

I awoke with a start as I heard the front door opening. Slipping my hand under the couch to grab the sword I kept stashed there I pulled it out and dashed towards the hallway, swinging it as I came around the corner. My father bent backwards as the blade swung harmlessly over his head and he put up his hands in surrender. Behind him my mother and the little girl came through the front door as well.

“Glad to see you too son. Though I just had a haircut, I don’t need another.”

“What are you two doing here!”

“Well last I checked we still lived here.”

“But mother said you two had some job over in Bornica”

“We did and we do. But your mother couldn’t find anyone to take care of the girl since you refused her and we can’t take her with us. So here we are.”

“Asala go get a bath and then we can find you a bed ok?”

The girl didn’t budge from where she stood. Her feet having stopped moving as soon as my mother had let go of her arm. My mother let out an exasperated sigh as she stared at the girl.

“Really! Isn’t it about time you give up this whole acting like a statue thing! I’m getting tired of pulling you around all the time! Don’t you want to get cleaned up? Do you expect me to do every little thing for you? Your old enough to take care of yourself!”

“Yeah great talk mother. I’m sure she feels more at ease around you now. At least I know you are just as good at taking care of kids as you always were.”

“Riktal darling, your good with kids right? Can’t you help me out here?”

“Not my problem. She is your responsibility. It will do you good to learn how to deal with kids. It will be a first for you. I suggest you treat her like a doll if you don’t want to actually deal with her like a little girl. Wash her yourself, dress her yourself, feed her yourself, instead of expecting her to do it.”

I returned to the living room to slip the sword back under the couch while my mother continued to rant at the little girl to snap out of it. My father followed me in and sat down on the other end of the sofa after I settled myself in again.

“Can’t you give your mother a break? She is trying you know.”

“I did give her a break. The whole first seventeen years of my life I gave her a break. She’s used them all up.”

“She’s trying really hard you know.”

“Don’t lie. It doesn’t suit you. She only tries really hard when she wants to and when she can come out ahead from it. She does her job as a Hunter, but dealing with people outside of that is a laugh. I’d give my left leg if you told me one instance where she did something for someone else with no benefit to herself whatsoever. Heck even an instance where she did something for someone else that benefited them more than her would do.”

“That’s not true and you know it.”

“Do I? Tell me, when has she ever been around long enough for me to know anything about her personally? All I have to go on is my dealings with her as a Hunter, nothing else. The same is almost true for you. You’ve been around a little more than mother has but not much. I know you like chess and fishing, and I know you don’t like tomatoes. But other then a few random facts here and there what do I know about either one of you when you tell me nothing?”

Just then their was an ear shattering scream from the hallway as the house shook slightly. Both of us dashed out into the hall just in time to see a red circle appearing on the floor. Even as a large meaty hand began to emerge I slipped forward and chopped down hard on the back of the girls neck. The summoning portal closed, slicing off the arm and leaving it laying in front of us. Blood began to pool on the wood a moment before it all turned to dust and disappeared.

“So what did you do to set her off mother?”

“Nothing! I just took the bear away from her so I could wash it.”

“You truly are an idiot mother. Even I figured out almost instantly that bear was her safety net. That’s the only reason she would carry it around with her through all of this. It was proof that she had some connection to this world. Probably quite a bit of connection to her old life as well. A reminder of her parents maybe. Taking that away from her was like ripping the floor out from under her feet and dropping her into a bottomless abyss.”

I yanked the bear out of my mothers grasp and slipped it back into the girls arms as I supported her in my own. Even unconscious her hand felt the fur and squeezed down on it.

“I’ll take care of her tonight. If I leave her with you I might end up with a case of the dead by morning. I knew you were bad with kids, but I didn’t think you were this useless.”

Slipping my arm under her legs I picked her up and headed up the steps. Since no other room was cleaned up and ready for a guest I simply took her to mine. Pulling back the covers I laid her to rest and moved to turn away after tucking her in. Her free hand shot out and grabbed mine in her sleep and gripped it tightly. With a sigh I sat cross legged on the floor and held her hand until my head dropped into my chest and I fell asleep as well.

************

111121122112222.title: Decline

1111211222.content:
The weapons were too dangerous. I had no choice but to press the issue myself, whether it caused a commotion or made me enemies. If I let this go, who knows how many innocent lives would be hurt by them in the wrong hands. If I couldn’t get them back by the end of the day, whoever took them would take them out of this school, never to be seen again until whoever stole the weapons tried to use them.

Slipping to a quiet corner of the room I quickly pulled up my mother’s magical fingerprint on the spell, setting it to audio only and holding my thumb and pinky up to my face. Her voice came over the spell as if she was right next to me, but so did the background noise. I heard something about a girl and someone talking about Hunter’s that might take her.

It didn’t take long to confirm with my mother that I had in fact brought the weapons to school with me. Once that was confirmed I said my goodbyes and shut down the spell as fast as I could. Dealing with my mother, even from a distance, could make me angry. And I didn’t need to be any angrier than I already was. Stepping out into the middle of the room I looked around at all the boys who had stopped gearing up as if they somehow knew I was going to say something by the way they all stared at me.

“I’ll make this short and sweet. Two weapons were stolen from me. I know I brought them to school. I also know it is possible one of the girls in the class took them but I find that highly unlikely. These weapons are dangerous and way above any of your current skill levels. If you try using them you may find yourself losing your life instead.”

“If anyone in here did take those weapons, I suggest you give them back immediately. I will leave my bag out in the open. If they were to appear inside my bag by the time I come back at the end of the period I will not pursue the matter farther. I will forget such ever happened. But if these items are not back in my bag within that time frame all bets are off. I will hunt you down and I will extract vengeance upon you. Run and hide, even fight back if you wish. I will enjoy crushing you. You will be lucky if I let you keep your life. So consider carefully what is more important to you. That is all.”

I left the locker room then amid hushed whispers and everyone glancing at the other suspiciously. They all knew what a serious crime it was to steal another Hunter’s weapons. It was a crime to steal period, but for a Hunter, their weapons were an extension of themselves. Sometimes being passed down from generation to generation as heirlooms. Stealing a Hunter’s weapon could be paramount to signing your own death warrant both literally and figuratively. Even if the person wasn’t killed, potential contacts and alliances would be broken as other Hunter’s distanced themselves from the person. They could find it hard to continue being a Hunter. At this stage of their life they might end up dropping out of the academy in shame.

I noted the order in which the boys came out of the locker room, many of them came in groups so as not to be thought of as being the thief. They kept eyeing me and the others as we all began to stretch before the Arena Master called everyone to attention. He said we would be splitting into groups to fight captured monsters to test our skills instead of sparring against each other. Well the rest of the class was doing that, me and Liz were told to sit this class out since we were so far advanced. So we headed into the bleachers and sat close together, watching as the groups were set up and a wall raised down the middle to split the floor into two smaller arenas.

“So a Zelkov huh? That explains a lot. Though I hope your name really isn’t Riki tiki.”

“It’s Riktal. Only my sister is allowed to call me that.”

“Well my brother used to call me Lizzy Lili when I used to live with him in Nefrot City so don’t feel too bad. I personally think its some kind of conspiracy of the older sibling league in it’s ongoing mission to embarrass their younger siblings as much as they can whenever they can. Strange nicknames are just a small part of their master plan.”

“So you’re not from around here huh? Why’d you decide to move here then? Nefrot has a bunch of good Monster Hunter academies as well.”

“It’s…. complicated. But it wasn’t my whole family that moved, just me. Let’s just say I am taking a bit of a break from them right now. But in order to do that I had to come here to this academy.”

“Yeah story of every old generation family like ours I guess, complicated.”

Lapsing into silence the two of us watched the groups below fighting some D class creatures. It took them at least five minutes to deal with them, showing how weak they were compared to me. They would get stronger eventually and be at my level, I was just at a higher skill right now. The last group stepped into the arena and a caged Cluuk rose out of the floor. I pointed at the group with my chin.

“They must be the strongest out of everyone in the class.”

“Aside from you and me you mean? Yeah. Marsa, the one with the staff. is pretty good with magic but she has this aversion to bladed weapons. Daniel’s magic is mediocre at best but he is the best hand-to hand specialist out of everyone else. He’s the one pounding his fist together now. Gregory is an all around combat type. He’s a good party leader and he has a diverse skill set of magic. His gunning skills aren’t bad either. But he is a bit of a hothead and goes on a lot of ego trips. Always thinking he has more skill than he actually does, then blames it on other people when he screws up.”

“Ah, I know the type well. They want what is best for one person and that person is the one they see in the mirror every morning.”

“Exactly. Jethic, the tank, I’ll admit he has impressed me. He’s the best out of everyone here when it comes to Hunter mentality and straight up tanking skill. Given the right circumstances he could take on a B class monster right now. Almost no magic to speak of though, barely enough to not be considered a Void. And Lilia is a really good healer. She decided not to take the bonds of servitude to become a priestess of The One God and came here to be a Hunter instead. Don’t know why, but she isn’t half bad with holy magic. Though she does tend to get a bit absentminded at times. When you are around her you get this feeling that she isn’t really “here” if you know what I mean.”

“That’s surprising. Don’t usually see any of the servants of The One God not tied to the church in some way. I actually think this is the first time I have seen one training to become a Hunter, though I have heard of a few other cases like that. You would think all priest and priestesses would want to learn how to use their power offensively instead of purely for healing and defense.”

“I know right? Never did understand that whole do no harm mentality of theirs.”

We watched the group fighting below for a bit, pointing out ways they could tighten their teamwork and other options they could use while fighting the thing, such as better positions and better orders.

“I give it another minute. They got their heads on straight at least. They didn’t do anything foolish like casting fire on it, so as long as they avoid using magic as the killing blow they will be fine.”

Even as I aid that the one named Gregory whipped out his hand in an underhanded arc while rolling out of the way of some flying feather darts. The magic orb swirled through the air, igniting into a ball of flames right before it smashed into the creatures face. The giant chicken looking bird let out a squawk of anger as it’s feathers ignited.

The bird wasn’t burning alive though, it was transforming. It grew a third leg and an extra set of wings while the poisonous comb under it’s beak split in two. The feathers took on a slightly metallic sheen as they stiffened up into razor sharp blades. It’s eyes took on a bottomless pit color of black as it threw out it’s four wings and showered the area with flaming razor edged dart feathers.
I was halfway along the top of the wall down the middle by the time the feather’s were flying. So I wasn’t able to stop the attack. Three of them impaled Gregory along his left side, hitting him in shoulder, lung and leg. The one named Jethic was able to deflect most of the dart’s as the other three hid behind him. A few of the feathers still sliced through cheeks and arms around the edges though, where he couldn’t protect.

As it opened it’s mouth I jumped off the wall, summoning the power within me as I flew over it’s head. As I landed in front of the small group I threw out my left hand palm forward, shooting a blast of ice and wind to stop the flames it shot out of its mouth. The force of it’s attack still made me slide backwards since I hadn’t been able to brace myself. While stopping the attack I busied myself making small ice pellets with my free right hand, throwing them at the bird when it finally closed it’s beak.

The pellets hit the ground around the monster seconds before I snapped my fingers, causing them to explode upwards in spikes of ice. The beast became encased but I knew it was only temporary. Such a quick attack wouldn’t stop a B class monster for long. I pointed at Gregory who was laying on the ground gasping for air.

“Liz get the idiot to safety now! Make sure he doesn’t die!”

She nodded her head before yanking the quills out of the boy and grabbing him up like he weighted nothing, running towards the side of the arena.

“Marsa! Priority on fire protection magic! Jethic! Focus on defending the healer above all else! Lilia! Keep on top of heals and be on the lookout for poisons! Daniel! Focus on speed not power right now! Follow my lead and you will all make it out alive. Welcome to your first B class monster kids!”

The Fluuk shattered my ice prison by heating up it’s body and charged at us.
1111211222.title: Handle it yourself

11112112221.content:
“Jethic Hold the line, do whatever you have to in order to get it’s attention! Marsa! Lilia! keep close to Jethic but not too close! Daniel flank left! Use ice or wind magic to protect yourself!”

I felt the slight warmth as Marsa’s flame protection spell washed over me. Seconds later I saw Daniel glow a light red as well. He veered to the left as I coated my fists in ice and veered right. He dashed forward, jumping into the air and coming around in a spinning kick. I could see the wind around his legs but he made the mistake of casting the wind outwards when he connected. On any other mob that would be fine but it just served to make the flames grow higher. I saw him fall with the leather burned away and his skin bubbling.

“Marsa! Pull him back! Lilia get him back up! Daniel! Protect yourself only I said! Be glad you had fire protection!”

Eyes on me bird brain!”

Jethic let out a commanding roar with what little magic he had that made the chicken monster focus on him again. I let the ice on my fists slide down my arm until I had blades of it coming out of my elbows. A quick slap to my knees grew another pair of ice swords from those joints as well. I jumped towards it’s right flank with my arms crossed in front of me.

“Dance of a thousand thorns!!”

Left, right, left, knee, spin, twirl, flip, jump, bend, cross slash, strike. Using wind to augment my movement speed I tore into the creature like a mini hurricane. It shot another flamethrower out of it’s mouth but Marsa pulled it’s head towards Jethic at the last second who did his job and took the brunt of the blow. As I flipped away Daniel came in from the left.

“Dance of the midnight devil!”

His dance was a sight to see, he used magical aura around his elbows instead of ice and spun in circles more than flipped and twisted like I had but it had style. He finally ended by hitting it in the side with an open palm, shoving it bodily across the floor towards me but his arm shattered. Bits of bone tore through his skin up to the elbow even as Lilia was throwing out her power to heal him from where she stood a short distance away.

I continued to pound on the creature while Jethic smashed his shield in its face and body, using his little magic to keep the monster’s eyes focused on him. Lilia stayed on top of the healing as Marsa began casting protect spells.

“Daniel! Do your dance one more time on my signal! Jethic! Send it airborne as soon as Daniel’s done! Marsa! Get your biggest ice spell ready and use it as soon as I finish attacking! Understand!”

I heard quick assent as I told Daniel to go to town. As his palm finally smashed into the Fluuk, Jethic gave a mighty roar as he braced his legs and heaved upwards under the monsters breastbone in a giant uppercut using his shield.

“Wind and ice! Earth and thunder! Become my blade and rip asunder! Beat rush!”

I uppercut the bird, sending it farther into the sky as my arms and legs were encased in the primal elemental magic. This was nothing fancy, just a straight beat down. Pummeling the underside as I took it higher and higher I finally grabbed its feathers and shoved it back to the ground while flipping over its side to begin stomping it in the back like jackhammer blows until it hit the floor.

“Marsa!”

I saw the ice hurtling towards the chicken’s head. It began to take in a breath to blow out more fire but I slammed a wall of wind into the back of its neck just as the ice smashed into its face. There was a moment of stillness before the head exploded into tiny bits and the body dropped to the ground. Even as the blood began to pool it turned to dust and wafted away into nothingness, leaving behind three glowing red razor feathers and two black marbles. After picking them up carefully I walked over to the group who were congratulating each other. I gave them each a nod as everyone else came running up, Gregory limping slightly and holding his side.

“You all did excellent jobs. Jethic, that was excellent tanking. You do your shield proud. Marsa, nice speed on the spells, you had a good mind for who to use them on first and what to use next without having to be told. Lilia great healing. Daniel, nice moves. Next time don‘t attack with the wind unless I say so.”

“It was all thanks to your orders. I didn’t know what to do.”

“Don’t sell yourself short Jethic. Or any of you for that matter. Taking down a B class like that can be difficult for anyone. I wouldn’t have been able to kill it so quickly by myself and I am an A class. But I was able to go all out without worry because all of you did your jobs. Just because I told you what to do doesn’t negate the fact that you still performed.”

They all grinned at me and my compliments even as the Arena Master nodded his head to support what I was saying. The rest of the class began complimenting me and the others as well even as Gregory limped forward.

“What are you going to do about the spoils?”

I turned towards him, about to give him a tongue lashing when Daniel stepped forward and gave him a right hook to the face that sent him sprawling on the ground.

“You’re a god damn idiot you know that! We all knew what not to do against that thing! We knew if it transformed into either a Fluuk or a Kloo it would be out of our league. The Arena Master even warned us! But you had to go acting all big and bad! I’m tired of it man! You always wind up getting me in trouble! We are done you hear me! I could have died this time! Don’t talk to me again.”

Daniel turned and bowed his head to me.

“My grandfather told me to own up to my mistakes no matter the consequences. He said if I wanted to be a worthy Hunter I needed to be worthy of that title. So I’m telling you now, I stole your Roller Knuckles and Gregory took your gun. I put them back because I knew it was wrong, but I don’t feel right not telling you. Not after fighting next to you like this.”

I clapped him on the shoulder and he hunched up like I was going to hit him.

“Didn’t I say if they appeared in my bags before the class was over I would forget all about it? We are square now, since they are back and class isn‘t over. But I thank you for telling me. That was a nice dance by the way, but it looks like it might be slightly above your skill level.”

“Yeah it is. But my grandfather taught it to me before he died. It’s the only one I know.”

“Give me your hand.”

He held it out hesitantly and I laid one of the black marbles in his palm, closing his fingers over it.

“That is an augmentation gem. It’s only a level one and not high quality, but you can have a weapon maker put that in your favorite fist weapons as a protection augmentation. Then you should be able to do that dance of yours without hurting yourself. Your grandfather was right. You need to do worthy things to be a worthy Hunter. And confessing was definitely worthy to my eyes.”

I handed the other black marble to Jethic.

“I hear you have very little magic. It must make it hard for you to tank without relying on many signature tanking spells. That was an impressive commanding shout by the way. Use this to augment your shield with a power surge ability. That should at least triple the amount of magic you can use by decreasing how much it takes out of you.”

I handed the two girls one of the feathers each which they took almost reverently.

“You probably haven’t heard much about Fluuk drops, just about the transformations. But these feathers are like magical tanks. As casters that is invaluable. Keep it on you and when you cast your spells it will absorb some of the excess magic that bleeds off. If you touch it the feather will give you back that magic it has stored up. It will pulse when it is full but you can siphon off the magic anytime. They will eventually wear out after many uses but until then they will be very helpful. Especially to lower level casters like you two.

I looked at all four of them again as they stared at their spoils and smiled thinly.

“Needless to say each of those items are valuable in their own right. You could always sell them for the Reul if you want. I’m sure they will fetch a nice price. Jethic, Daniel, if you don’t know any weapon makers I will introduce you to one that specializes in augmentations.”

“Th-thank you!”

I waved away the thanks as I turned to leave the floor but Gregory was back on his feet and standing in my way, his eyes full of greed.

“So that last feather is mine right?”

My gaze narrowed as I saw Liz slap her forehead and shake it back and forth. I also saw the disgust on many of my classmates faces as well. They knew as well as I he didn’t deserve it. Perhaps they were beginning to realize just how slimy he was. I was sure those last words had just ruined his reputation as a Hunter for life. Or at least with these people and anyone they ended up telling. Perhaps I should give him the feather simply out of pity. It might be the last spoils he ever got as a Hunter or a Hunter in training. I had a feeling his days at this academy were numbered.
11112112221.title: Attack!

111121122211.content:
Giving him a hard look and only a small sneer of contempt I tossed it to the ground at his feet. The sharp tip imbedded in the cement as the other end quivered with a slight twang sound.

“Enjoy your spoils while you can. I have a feeling they may be your last. I don’t give this to you because you earned it. I give this to you out of pity. But know this, your greed and your ego will be the death of you.”

As I shoved passed him I put my hand on his shoulder, leaning my lips close to his ear so only he could hear me.

“Just a friendly reminder, I better have my Lexington back by the time this class is over. If I don’t you won’t be waking up to see a sunrise ever again. And no one will ever find your body or know who did it. I’m a Zelkov, I can make that happen.”

Pushing him away from me I headed back up into the bleachers to take my seat again, staring down at the floor where the Arena Master was giving a small speech about what had just happened. Telling the class he hoped they had learned something from watching us. Liz came up a moment later shaking her head to sit down beside me.

“Idiot. A truly greedy idiot. Even I didn’t expect him to be that stupid. He just numbered his days here at the school.”

She glanced sideways at me before going on.

“That is if he wakes up for school tomorrow.”

“Heard my last comment huh?”

“Sins of being able to read lips. Will you really kill him if your weapon doesn‘t show up?”

“Yes.”

She nodded her head and went silent again as the groups below were rearranged and sent out to do battle again. I could see they had learned something from my fight; their movements were more confident and they worked as a team better than before. I could see how they rose up to the challenge of emulating what I had done while at the same time knowing their limits. They didn’t try any crazy moves that might get them hurt and the ones issuing the orders seemed to have a good grasp of the other members capabilities.

I noticed Gregory slipping out of the arena as soon as he could and I grinned wolfishly. So the little thief wanted to live did he? Well as long as it was back I would honor my words of amnesty. He came back in a few moments later, glancing nervously up at where I was sitting. I made sure to blow him a kiss before letting the smile spread even further across my face. That caused him to turn and run away at a speed walk.

“You are an evil man you know that?”

“I know.”

“I kind of like it.”

“So what’s your angle anyway?”

She looked up at the sky as if searching the ceiling for an answer.

“Hmm, about thirty five degrees North North-East at the moment.”

“That jokes almost as bad as some of mine.”

Even though I said that my lips twitched upwards anyway and she laughed back at me.

“Seriously though, no angle. I just find you interesting. And I understand you like you understand me. I can’t get into the talk the girls have about boys and make-up and fashion. It all seems so alien to me. I grew up to be a Hunter, that’s all I really know.”

“Now that I can understand and get behind.”

She stared at the arena for a moment before talking again.

“You were really impressive back there. I’ll admit, you are stronger than me if you really are an A class like you said. When I took the mock Exams I came in at a solid B. That would have been a tough creature for me alone. I could have handled it if it had changed into a Kloo, but sadly my ice and wind magic is slightly lacking.”

“Well we have time, I’ve got no problem working with you to make you better. I’m sure the Arena Master will give us our own little area to spar in whenever we ask. That way we don’t interrupt their training.”

“I’d like that.”

We chatted a bit more until the bell rang and I left to pick up my bag. A quick check proved that both weapons were indeed inside. With a last look around I returned to the classroom, finding my seat before anyone else even came in. As the class filed in I could already see the shunning starting. Those who sat around Gregory by at least one desk in any direction moved farther away from him. The first three were lucky and took the three empty desks around the room instead of moving their own. No one looked at or acknowledged him even when he tried to make eye contact. They weren’t doing it because they wanted to get closer to me, they were doing it because of who he was and what he had done.

The teacher came in and noted the change in the group dynamics almost instantly, not commenting on it but giving it a raised eyebrow. He went through roll call and one of the girls raised her hand when he called out for Gregory Weiss

“Mr. Ghelis, there is no Gregory Weiss in this class. It seems he stole a Hunter’s weapons from him and also almost got his group killed in Combat Training Class. On top of that he’s a slimy conniving little weasel so you should strike his name from the records.”
