The teacher looked around the room at all the heads nodding in agreement before giving the girl a bow of the head. He made a show of picking up his pen and running it through the name in his book. As he handed out papers he too shunned the boy, passing him up as he went up and down the aisles. As he returned to the blackboard to begin the History lesson an older lady with her blond hair done up in a bun that highlighted the few grey ones came into the room. The black patch over her right eye was a souvenir from a fight with her ex-husband she had won. She wore a low cut yellow dress to match her hair and I grinned as I stood up and went forward with my bag in hand before she could even whisper to the teacher.

“Sorry for the interruption sir, but Hilda is here for me. My mother probably want’s me.”

He waved me off and I followed Hilda out into the hall

“So what does my mother want with me now?”

“It’s really not my place to say but a job. A protection job to be exact.”

“Would it by chance have anything to do with a little girl?”

“How’d you know?”

“Heard it in the background when I called earlier.”

“Ah. Your mother can give you more of the details, I really don’t know all that much. I do know the child is eleven years old and lost her parents three days ago so be gentle on her ok? Even if you don’t accept the job, I’m sure you remember how losing someone precious to you feels.”

“I do. And for you Hilda, I’ll hold my temper in check. You’ve been kind to me and treated me well. You are the only aide my mother hasn’t gotten rid of after a few months and truth be told you’ve grown on me.”

“Thanks Riktal. You’re a good boy, no matter what anyone else says. But you are too much like your mother in some things. Both of you just don’t know how to interact very well on a personal level with most people for very long.”

“So you know anything else about this girl?”

“Sorry not really. I was actually going to be sent off elsewhere when I got the call to assist her. Which told me this was contract worthy. I was half tempted to send the new girl Inga, but I didn’t think you would warm to her with her personality. Well that and she only has a day under her belt.”

She led me to a room that looked like your average meeting room for a council of some sort where my mother burst out of her chair to hug me around the neck and kiss my cheeks. I pushed her away before sitting down across the table and looking from my mother to the white haired girl with scarlet eyes.

“Hilda filled me in on some of it mother, but not all of it. I assume she is special, political emissaries daughter maybe? I’d also like to know why me and not some licensed Hunter. There are tons as good as I am or better.”

“If Hilda filled you in this makes it easier. She’s a Monster summoner. You know how most Hunter’s are on that subject. You’re good with kids, you are Hunter level even if I won’t allow you to take the Exams, despite our differences I trust you, and the only other person I can think of is Pelei. With his personality, he might make the situation worse even though he is a more experienced Hunter. Will you do it?”
111121122211.title: Give him the feather

1111211222111.content:
“You caught me in a good mood mother. I’ll take the job, but I want twelve thousand Reul as payment. It’s true I’m not a licensed Hunter, so I can’t ask full price a protection job like this would normally run, but I’m not going to give you a full family discount either. I assume someone will be coming to take her in a day or two? Someone who can train her powers I mean.”

“You’re right darling. A friend of mine will come by in two or three days to pick Asala up. Though I should warn you she doesn’t say anything and you have to pull her around everywhere. As you can see she just stares blankly at nothing holding that teddy bear. She won’t eat so we have taken to sustaining her with magic, though that won’t work forever, the body needs real food. Her power is a bit unstable as well, she can’t control it and it seems to be affected by her emotions.”

“But there is one other thing I want. I want you to continue to go to school even while you are protecting her.”

“Your joking right? What if she summons a monster here in the school? I might be good, but if I have an entire school full of trainees out for blood, even I will have a tough time of it. Not to mention it will be hard to effectively protect her as it is. These kids will be all over her like vultures with their constant questions and squealing of cute and adorable.”

“I’m not joking. I know it will probably be difficult but I would really appreciate it. Think of it as some specialized training for you.”

“I assume I will have proxy Hunter status on this? If things go FUBAR I don’t want to be left high and dry here. There are things I can get away with if it’s Hunter business I might not otherwise be able to.”

“You already have a lot of pull being a Zelkov so it shouldn’t be a problem.”

I waved those words away like they were an annoying fly.

“No. I don’t want to hide behind the family name if things go bad. We shouldn’t be seen as special just because we are an old family and be given special treatment because of it. If I mess up that’s on me, I don’t want a free pass because I’m a Zelkov. That’s why I want proxy Hunter status.”

“Fine. I’ll grant it to you under my status as a Hunter, Hilda can make up the paperwork.”

Even as she finished saying that Hilda placed a sheet of paper in front of her with a grin and a wink at me.

“I might be your mother’s aide, but I know you well enough as well young man. I prepared it before we left just in case.”

My mother put her magical seal on it and handed it to me as I smiled back at the old woman.

“Hilda, if you were thirty years younger I’d marry you on the spot. You’re too good for my mother.”

“Oh I know it and she knows it too. I’ll settle for a peck on the cheek though. Haven’t been kissed by a good looking young man in longer than I care to remember.”

“Done.”

She chortled as I got up and kissed her cheek, throwing my arms around her neck for good measure before returning to my seat.

“I’ve got enough saved up and left over from my living allowance to take care of her for now, but I would appreciate it if the money was in my account as soon as possible.”

Hilda was already pulling up a see through screen with a keyboard on it and typing a mile a minute with her fingers. A moment later she set her little clipboard down in front of my mother saying the money was ready to transfer, she just had to approve it. My mother put her finger on the screen and it beeped in response.

“You really are a wonder Hilda darling. I don’t know what I would do without you.”

“Wither away and die I don’t doubt. Or be buried under piles of paperwork and suffocate.”

Hilda’s words were met with a grin by both me and my mother.

“You wouldn’t happen to have the contract made up already would you?”

Hilda sighed at me dramatically with a forlorn look on her face.

“No. I’m still working on it. I’ll send you out the paperwork later though. Is it ok if I forge your signature to speed up the process?”

“I’d only let you because you’re the only one I trust to do so. Plus your forgeries are the closest to mine anyway. Just… don’t dot my i with a heart this time will you?”

She grinned but promised she wouldn’t as my mother stood up and headed for the door. She turned to look at me with a bit of sadness in her eyes that was probably fake so I ignored it.

“I’ll be in Bornica for the next week and your father is coming with me so hold down the fort here and stay out of trouble.”

“Don’t I always hold down the fort? As for trouble, I can’t make promises I probably can’t keep.”

With a blown kiss she left the room with Hilda close on her heels. Once she was gone I moved around the table to sit next to the girl who stared at me blankly. Her clothes and hair were dirty as well as frayed around the edges. She had probably been sleeping in them the last few days and she didn’t have any others. Looking both ways as if to make sure no one else was in the room even though we were obviously alone I finally focused on the girl, speaking in a whisper.

“You can quit pretending you don’t know what’s going on now. I know you can hear me at least. You might have had my mother and everyone else fooled but not me. You’ve been squeezing that bear this whole time and that takes a conscious effort. Your fingers keep twitching ever so slightly too when we were talking about you. As if you were afraid. I’m not going to hurt you. In fact I am probably the best person for you to know right now. I’ve got experience as a big brother you see and I’m pretty good at it if I do say so myself. I won’t force anything on you, like making you talk or anything but I would like it if I saw a bit of life in your beautiful eyes.”

She squeezed the bear slightly but finally blinked and looked at me, a bit of intelligence in her face.

“There, that wasn’t so hard now was it? So how about we get to know each other a little before the next class starts huh? I’ll ask some simple yes or no answers. You can either shake your head or simply do nothing if you don’t want to answer. Is that ok with you?”

A small head nod. Good I was getting somewhere. It wasn’t that hard to deal with kids, you just had to let them know you recognized them as an individual and made them feel important. Anyone could do it, but I found adults tended to get caught up in their own little worlds, always wanting to make everything go by quickly or wanted everything done right that second. Little kids picked up on that fast, which was probably part of the reason she had shut down.

I spent the next twenty minutes until the bell rang talking with the little girl, though she never actually said a word. I had her giggling at my funny faces and antics a few times as I helped her relieve some of her stress and grief she was holding in. I made it my personal mission to help her with that grief while she was with me.

Taking her by the hand I led her to the final class of the day. She was slightly nervous but she at least trusted me enough now to believe me when I said it would be ok. I managed to catch the teacher out in the hall before he went into the room, giving him a brief rundown of what was going on. He nodded his head as he looked down at the girl and then up at me.

“Do you want to introduce her or would you rather I take care of it for you?”
1111211222111.title: Accept job

11112112221111.content:
“Even though I don’t want to, it’s probably best if I do it.”

He gave me a nod of assent before going into the room. Squeezing the girls hand and whispering it would be all right I led her through the door with my weapons slung on my right shoulder. The class eyed us with shock and no little interest as I stood in front of the room. The girl clutched my hand, half hiding behind my leg as I heard some of the girls whispering about how cute she was. Leave it to a female to go crazy over kids and cute things.

“This is Asala. Due to some circumstances, I have taken on the job of protecting her for the next few days. It is around the clock protection meaning she will be joining me for classes until she leaves. She is very shy and at the moment afraid of people and crowds in general. It’s taken me some time to get her to trust me and to act a bit more normal, but I ask that you all respect my wishes to stay away from both her and me. She has some unstable powers that might harm someone if she gets frightened.”

“If circumstances change and she so desires, I will allow you to come nearer. But until such a time you will do more harm than good by ignoring my request. Right now she is my top priority over everything else. That includes what little I might care about my reputation or my relationship with any one of you. Doubt me at your peril but I will not hesitate to apply force if need be on you. Just act like she isn’t here, she will be gone in two or three days anyways. Thank you for your time and for ceding to my wishes.”

I led Asala down the aisle to my desk, setting her up closer to the wall before snagging an empty chair for myself. I saw the teacher give me a nod and added a few words of his own about the importance of taking a job and how such things can be conducted. It wasn’t exactly about Monster Tactics, but I supposed this was a good practical lesson in action.

I could see the glances looking back at us, mostly from the girls, but there were a few from the guys as well. While the lesson went on I whispered to Asala and played a few games to keep her occupied, all the while learning more about her even without any words being spoken. I got her to communicate with me a bit using writing, though her words were misspelled at times and her handwriting a bit shaky.

I drew funny pictures and made funny faces all in a calculated plan to make her forget her grief for the moment. It would eventually spill out of course, and this was designed to instigate that event as well. It sounded cruel, but if she held it all inside, it would consume her. I was sure a part of her didn’t want anyone else seeing her give in to her tears, since my mother and whoever else had handled her had probably said things like “don’t cry” and “get over it already.” People seemed to think it was some sort of sin to grieve for too long, as if those feelings magically went away. Well they could go away suddenly with drugs and such, but there was nothing magical about those items.

If I could get her to cry in front of me that was all well and good, I’d be able to comfort her and help that process along even more. But if she decided to hide in the bathroom or somewhere else alone to cry, that would also work. As long as she let it all out instead of holding it all in.

Plus, knowing from experience with special abilities like monster summoning, part of the instability of that power came from instability in her environment. That whole mess of emotions inside that were conflicting with each other was definitely a factor, but so too was her thoughts that she kept getting moved around, she had no family or anyone she could trust, and no one caring about her. Add in the fact that the only thing she owned was what she had on her right now and you had a recipe for instability. It would be hard for anyone to cope with, let alone a skinny four and a half foot tall eleven year old girl.

The bell finally rang as I grinned over at Asala.

“See told you it would be fine, All you had to do was trust me. Now how about we go downtown to get you some new threads. Because that dress definitely has to get burned. It’s an affront to all of humanity. After that we will get a bite to eat and I’ll treat you to some of the best banana sundae you have ever tasted. By the time we get home you’ll feel like a million Reul. Will you like that?”

She nodded her head with a bit of enthusiasm, the prospect of sweets and shopping appealing to her like it always had with Olia.

“We can come too if you want. I’m sure she will be glad to have another girl there. Plus it will make buying certain things easier on you.”

I glared at the two girls lingering by the front of the class listening to my conversation.

“Stay out of our personal matters please. I didn’t ask you to come and I don’t need your help. Do you think I am not perfectly capable of taking a girl out shopping? Even if I didn’t have some sense of taste, she knows what she likes just fine. And if you were obliquely referring to things like undergarments and personal hygiene items then I still don’t need you. I’m capable of helping her get those as well without acting like a complete retard or blushing like it was the first time I saw a naked body of the opposite sex. Now is there any other opinions I don’t need from you that you wish to give?”

The two girls blushed and hurried out of the room as I glanced over at Asala with a raised eyebrow.

“Did I saw something wrong?”

She giggled a little bit before shaking her head with a grin spreading across her face. Leading her by the hand towards the door I was reminded of the way I used to walk like this with Olia. Softly, without looking at the little girl I let a few words escape my lips without meaning to.

“Thank you Asala. For making me feel like a big brother again.”

She hugged me in the side as we walked as if to say I was welcomed and I ruffled her hair. My stride broke for just a second as I looked down at the little girl who looked back up at me with those large trusting eyes. I thought for sure she had said something but it had been so soft as to barely register in my ears.

“Did you say something?”

She blinked at me but offered no comment or headshake. Finally she cocked her head to the side as if to ask what was wrong, her eyebrows furrowing.

“Sorry, I must have imagined it. Pay me no mind, it’s been a long day.”

She nodded her head in agreement as we left through the front gates and down the road towards town. Still I couldn’t get that tiny soft ghost voice out of my mind. Or the single word it had said.

Family.

**************

So ends this day for Riktal. Or at least this window of his life. Truly these windows are a fickle thing. They close and open again whenever they wish. Perhaps next time it will stay open until the sun sets, perhaps it will close after he utters only a single word. Even I who am lord of this place cannot predict the fickle nature of these windows. Perhaps it has something to do with the choices made that brought this fate to pass. Or perhaps there is a grand designer over even me who is looking down and controlling the windows at his or her whim.

Come again travel and choose the fates and the destiny of our young Hunter friend. Or perhaps next time a new window will have opened for you to gaze through. A new tale for you to see and new choices for you to make for another unknowing person. Until then, choose wisely the route you wish your life to take.
11112112221111.title: Introduce her

11112112221112.content:
I really didn’t feel like dealing with the hassle so asked the teacher to let the class know, simply asking him to point out I would like them to stay away if they could. He gave me an affirmative nod before entering the room shortly before me. The girl stuck close to me as I escorted her to the back of the room, sitting her down before going and grabbing an extra chair for myself. The teacher gave the class the short introduction and relayed my message to stay away if they could before turning to his lesson.

The girl kept her head down, holding the bear up to her face while holding onto my tunic. From the looks I kept getting I figured that might be the best bet. I kept whispering to her that it would be fine, even resorting to playing simple games of pen and paper to keep her occupied. I didn’t really pay attention to the class though, more interested in keeping her from accidentally summoning a monster.

I let a part of my mind go over the meeting with my mother wondering what I might have been able to do differently. I hadn’t been lying when I said she had caught me in a good mood, a fact I was bit surprised about. Looking back on the day it hadn’t been so bad. Putting aside some of the minor annoyances and negative things that had happened, I was feeling good. My mother hadn’t even got my blood boiling like she usually did and that was a feat in and of itself. Perhaps it was because Hilda was there. Or perhaps because my mother hadn’t been here long or talked too much.

Maybe it had to do with meeting Liz and the way talking with her put me at ease as a kindred spirit. Whatever the case, it felt refreshing to not end up arguing with my mother after only a few minutes.

Glancing over at the girl who was quietly drawing on a piece of paper I smiled to myself. It also felt good to act like a big brother again. Olia had liked to draw as well, though she had never been as good as Asala. By the looks of her picture, the girl had an affinity for straight edges and less on the curves. I thought she might make a good engineer or architect drawer since she had an eye for proportions.

Even though she still refused to speak I did get her to communicate with me through writing. Her spelling wasn’t all that great and her letters were still a little shaky in places but it was passable. So we wrote back and forth throughout the class even making her grin at the funny faces I drew for her. I asked if she wanted to go into town to buy new clothes and she said yes. At which point I drew a distorted man wearing a pair of panties on his head while pointing at a dress.

That elicited a giggle which caused heads to turn. When she noticed the stares she shrunk into herself again. I put my arm around her shoulder and gave everyone a raised eyebrow of defiance, causing them all to return to their studies. My constant reassurance that nothing would happen and the way I mocked her ability put her at ease and let her get through this first class. From tomorrow onward it would be much easier going. It was simply the first step that was always the hardest.

As soon as the bell rang a few girls converged on us. The boys at least had accepted my request to be left alone for whatever reasons, but there was something about children, babies, and cute things that girls just couldn’t leave alone. It was doubly worse since Asala was a cute kid with a small frame. A frame she tried hiding behind my legs as they came towards us while stuffing her bear to her mouth.

I held up my hand before any of them could get a word out, making two of them close their mouths on the words that never made it to their lips.

“I asked for you all to respect my wishes and stay away for the next day or two. The girl is shy and afraid of people on the whole. She doesn’t need people hovering around making her feel more scared than she already is. Right now I am on a job and my client is the most important thing to me. I don’t care if you want to get to know her better or butter up to me or anything else, just please turn and walk away. I’m in a good mood right now and don’t want any trouble. If she feels up to being around people tomorrow then that is a different matter. As it stands just drop it for today.”

They blinked at me as the girl continued to clutch at the back of my legs with her eyes squeezed shut. Finally they all just turned and left, not a word of agreement or anything which I was grateful for. Kneeling down, I stroked the girl’s hair gently.

“See? I told you I wouldn’t let anything bad happen. I’ll protect you from all the scary things, even if they are alien girl monsters like that. No one will take me away from your side for any reason. Like I told them, right now you are the most important thing to me. That includes my own personal relationships and reputation. What’s important is you.”

I poked her in the nose as I finished talking, giving her a sly wink along with the lopsided smile that crept onto my face. Finally she smiled back and nodded that she understood before I stood back up and offered her my hand.

“Come on, lets go get you some spiffy new clothes and get you out of that thing. It’s making my lips pucker just looking at it. Then I know a nice quite restaurant you will love. It has this home made chocolate banana sundae that will make you think you’ve just gone to heaven. I’ll buy it for you if you promise to eat some real food. Is it a deal?”

Her eyes lit up at the mention of sweets as I knew they would, no child seemed to be able to resist sweets. At least, Olia never could. She took my hand with an energetic bob of her head and I led her out of the room, hiking my weapons farther up onto my left shoulder.

I had a feeling everything would turn out just fine. I had no real proof to base that on, just a gut instinct. But right now I didn’t worry too much about anything like that. I felt like I had a family again, that was all that mattered. I looked down at the girl who was staring up at me with those big round eyes of hers. When she saw me looking she showed me a mouth full of teeth. I imagined she felt the same way.

********

It seems this window is closing traveler. Do you approve of the fate our young friend ended up with by your hands? Were the decisions easy or hard to make? Did you learn something about yourself while living through his eyes? Were your choices solely your own or did you chose how you felt Riktal would have chosen? In the end did your choices actually make a difference? Would fate have ended this way no matter what you did?

Or perhaps you really had no true choice at all? Perhaps the web of destiny influenced your decisions on a subconscious level to create the path you did. Creating scenarios and choosing words to pull at your heartstrings or bias you in one direction or another making it so you felt there was only one real answer.

Join me again traveler, and chose a new fate for our young hero. That is, if you can.
11112112221112.title: Let teacher handle it

1111211222112.content:
Rubbing my eyes after pulling off my glasses I stared at the girl and my mother. I could almost feel her eyes burning into the top of my head as I looked at the tabletop deep in thought. If my hair wasn’t already the color of fire that gaze would have dyed my hair for me. Finally I replaced the frames on my face and shook my head.

“I’m sorry, I just can’t. I feel for the girl, I really do. But this is where you wanted me. Though I don’t know your reasons, and trust me I really wish I did, you decided to send me here. As much as I might love to take this job, being a Hunter is all about trust. If I can’t be trusted to stick to this course then how can I expect others to trust me. This is a job for a licensed professional, not an under the table deal of convenience. I can’t and shouldn’t bend that for even you mother. Isn’t that what you and father taught me after all?”

“Won’t you reconsider darling? Please? Just this once?”

“No. if I bend just this once, what will be the next thing I bend my morals on? I’ve made enough bad choices and my temper has gotten me into enough trouble everywhere I go. I decided to make a fresh start at this school. Even if I don’t want to be here, I am working with what I have been given, another thing you taught me. I’ll admit I’ve bent my morals to suite my desires before, but not this time. If I am starting fresh I need to renew my morals as well.”

I dug into my bag and pulled out a small box with a button on the side, hefting it in my hand a moment as a stared at it in thought. Finally I nodded before clenching it in my hand. Setting it down gently I returned my eyes to both my mother and the little girl.

“But there is one thing I will do for you though before you take her to Pelei that might make your life easier.”

Going around the table, I knelt in front of the girl, taking one of her limp hands and giving it a squeeze.

“I’m going to tell you a secret Asala. One just between me and you. If you believe I am telling the truth then hand me your bear for just a little bit ok? If you don’t believe me you don’t have to do anything at all. So really there’s no downside in it for you. In the end you will still have your bear. Now for the secret.”

I leaned close to her ear, cupping my hands so no one else could hear me. I told her I knew she could tell what was going on and if she gave me her bear I would make it magical and able to protect her from all harm. So if she accidentally summoned a monster it couldn’t hurt her.

Once I was done I sat back on my haunches and waited. For a full minute nothing happened but then she finally held the bear out to me as her eyes filled with bit of worry. I took the stuffed animal like it was made of gold back around the table and sat down in my chair again. As I pulled a pair of scissors out of a side pocket to cut along the side seam I began to talk to the little girl.

“You know I used to be really bad at sewing. And I mean really bad. The first time I sewed something up my little sister laughed herself to tears. But you know what? I got really good at it until you couldn’t tell my stitches from a professionals.”

Laying the bear on it’s side while she began to reach for it because of what I was doing, I pulled out a micro tool kit and began tearing the box apart.

“My little sister was always ripping her clothes or her stuffed animals. And she would always bring them to me to be fixed up. That’s how I got to be so good. That little girl who had laughed at my sewing wanted me to fix her ripped items.”

Pulling out the shard of heart crystal and the mess of wires carefully I began inserting it into the bear, ending up taking it’s eyes off for a moment. This would be a better job then if I only had a few moments. This would be no jury rigged artifact.

“What I am putting in here is a crystal matrix. You find them in just about every artifact. These wires are made of spun gold and silver specially treated for conducting magic. This small shard is like a big old battery that holds a massive amount of magic to power the spell set into the matrix. This spell has one job only, to make a protection barrier around a single person or area.”

“I’ve spent a lot of time alone, so I’ve ended up going into town and learning a bit about all the different types of jobs out there. From weapon making to artifact appraising to augmentations. Now I’m no master crafter, but I’m pretty passable if I do say so myself.”

I went silent as I stuck my tongue out of the side of my mouth and focused on connecting the ends of the matrix to the skin of the bear in such a way that it would activate the way I wanted it to. Once I was done I began sewing the eyes back on until you couldn’t even tell they had been taken off before starting on the seam.

“Because I know how Pelei is, and I know how lonely it can be not having someone to talk to I’m going to cast an extra special magic on this bear that I once cast for my little sister. It won’t last forever though but I think you will like it.”

Finishing up my sewing job I reached into my bag for a bit of spare gold wiring I kept there. Unwinding a little of it I snipped off four pieces the size of my fingernail, closing my eyes and sending my power into them until they glowed with their own light. Once I was sure they were filled to the brim with my energy I set each sliver on one of the paws until the gold sunk into the fur and disappeared. Looking at the bear and then the girl I reached across the table and mimed plucking something invisible from her forehead.

“I hope you don’t mind but I just borrowed your mom and dad’s voices for a bit.”

Pretending to hold the struggling voices in my hand I pressed it against the bears lips, covering it with my other hand and whispering into the cupped area like I had whispered to her while the bear glowed a faint purple color. Letting out a tired sigh as I sat back I grinned at her before handing the animal back. She took it with a question in her eyes and my grin grew even wider.

“Go ahead and squeeze it around the middle.”

When she did, a dull orange shield rose around her body, pushing the table and even my mother away.

“Only things you want to come inside with you will be able to, all you have to do is think it and the spell will do the rest. But you are probably wondering what magic I put on it of my own aren’t you? Well try squeezing each of his paws.

“Don’t be afraid sweetie”

“I’m here with you honey”

“I’m so proud of you.”

“I love you.”

Each of those small phrases seemed to echo in the air, the voices decidedly not mine. They were her parents voices. Her eyes welled up a bit as she kept pressing them over and over, the voice saying the line alternating between the male and the female.”

“Now your parents will help protect you so you don’t have to be so scared anymore.”

My mother gasped at the bear and then at me. Her bulging eyes and the way her mouth opened and closed made me think of a drowning fish.

“H-how did you do that! The shield thing I understand but I’ve never seen anything like that kind of spell before! That’s her parent’s voices!”

I grinned as I got up, throwing my sewing kit and everything else back in my bag before hefting it to my shoulder.

“It’s magic.”

On my way out the door Hilda stopped me with a hand on my shoulder, whispering into my ear so only I could hear.

“Thank you for not blowing up on your mother and doing what you did. You kept your promise to be nice even if you declined. You’ve grown into a fine young man and are worthy of the title of Hunter, even if you don’t have a license.”

“It wasn’t much but I did what I could.”

“No Riktal, it was more than you think. I’m an old woman, I know the value of grieving, and that little girl can now do it properly thanks to you.”

I kissed her on the cheek before giving her my parting words, letting them barely pass my lips as I uttered them next to her ear.

“Take care of my mother Hilda. You know me better than anyone else so you know I do still love her even if she makes me so angry all the time. I might not admit it because of our differences, but I’ve never wished her dead or anything.”

With that I left the room, turning right to head towards the stairs up to my next class. I only made it a few steps when the door burst open. I turned around in time for the girls tiny frame to run headlong into me as she wrapped her arms around my waist and wouldn’t let go. My mother came out a second later, coming forward to grab the girls arm. An orange shield suddenly appeared around the two of us and my mother was pushed back, her grip being torn off by the spell.

My mother looked at the two of us and grinned.

“Well it seems the decision has been made for you, whether you like it or not.”

“I suppose so.”

“Probably shouldn’t have done that bit with the bear.”

Reaching down to stroke the girls hair I smiled.

“No. I’d do it a thousand times more if I had to. That is one decision I’ll never once regret making.”

“Take care of her darling, someone will be around in a few days.”

I considered trying to make a deal to get some money or something out of this but decided not to, I really had no footing so to speak, this girl would probably stick to me like glue regardless so I had no strong bargaining chips. As my mother was about to turn around she gave me her final parting words.

“I still expect you to go to classes like normal. With your desire for a fresh start, if you can’t bend them for me I’m sure you would never forgive bending them for your own personal ease.”

“You’re evil mother.”

“I know.”
1111211222112.title: Decline job

11112112221121.content:
“So this is Asala. Due to a few different circumstances, I’ve been tasked with protecting her for a few days. Try to act as if she isn’t here if you can. I’ll do my best to minimize the amount of trouble she causes everyone. But I do also ask you not get to close if you can help it, she has a few personal issues about who she trusts.”

I gave the class I slight bow as Asala squeezed the right paw again to hear her mother’s voice softly say “I’m here with you honey” with a distant smile on her face. I led the girl to my desk in the back, snagging an empty chair and getting us both comfortable. The girl didn’t seem to hear the girls in the class whispering about how cute she was but I did. I also ignored those whispers since they were irrelevant. Even though Asala was cute with her big crimson eyes, silver hair, and petite frame. It didn’t change how I would do my job.

She sat there hugging her bear lightly with her eyes closed. Not enough to activate the shield but enough to give her comfort. She had already found the activation point needed for her squeezes within less than five minutes of having the artifact installed. She was a very smart little girl. She kept pressing the left paw over and over to hear her parents saying “I love you” with that same far off look of bliss. I knew it probably made it difficult for the class to concentrate, even after I cast a small wind wall to muffle the noise a bit.

I wasn’t going to stop her though, she was dealing with her grief. At least a part of it. When she touched the left foot and heard her father say don’t be afraid, she finally broke. I had been watching her closely, knowing this was going to happen if she kept that up. So when she began crying I quickly cast the spell I had been setting up, melting the floor and walls around us to form a bubble. Encasing us in our own private little world away from the eyes that were beginning to turn and look. Illuminating the area I took her into my arms and stroked her hair. I couldn’t block out the fact that everyone could hear us but this little girl needed my help. I couldn’t worry about what was going on outside.

“I know, I know, it hurts doesn’t it? Losing your parents so suddenly, being pulled every which way by stranger after stranger. Thrown into places you don’t know and never even heard of while being told to do this and do that. You’ve got nothing left of your old life except what you’re wearing and that single teddy bear. It’s not easy, in fact it’s really hard. Every little thing seems to make it hurt worse and you think you are supposed to be strong, supposed to keep it all in.”

“But you know what? That’s not true. Some people deal with grief better than others. And they think that everyone should deal with it the same way they do. But grief is the bodies way of telling you what you should be doing. It becomes a struggle sometimes sweetie. Some days are worse than others, and it never really goes away. But it does get easier to bear, easier to face each day. But sometimes… sometimes that pain comes back even years later. Some face reminds you of the one you lost, some action you did together, a song, a joke. It could be any little thing and that pain comes back. So remember this feeling, because this feeling is proof that they were alive. Proof that you loved them enough to be so sad that they are gone.”

“But don’t let it consume you. Find something to live for each and every day, no matter how small or insignificant. Because life moves on regardless of our feelings. We can’t halt the flow of time, we can’t turn back the clocks, but what we can do is live. Live and do their memories proud. Live and prove that they lived. You will laugh again and smile again without feeling like you are somehow dishonoring their memory. And that thought too is going to hurt. But that pain, that pain you feel will make you grow stronger. It will make those happy moments all the better.”

“I’m sure all that time you spent with them wasn’t filled with nothing but sadness. I’m sure there was joy and other good times. Remember those times and not how they died. Because that’s proving how they lived. The fact that they are dead does not negate those facts. That’s why you remember everything. The good and the bad, because they are all precious memories that no one can ever take away from you. They are all proof that they existed and they loved you.”

She continued to bawl as I knelt there on both knees holding her close and rocking her back and forth. Bawled until she began to do the hiccup cry. Bawled until it almost sounded like she was going to choke for lack of air. But my soothing words of comfort and my soft touch finally calmed her down as she cried herself out. Gently I pushed her away from me and looked her up and down.

“There? Feel a bit better now?”

She nodded her head while wiping her eyes.

“Good, but it looks like I need a new tunic, this one is as green as that dress of yours.”

That elicited a small hiccupping chuckle from her as I gave her a wink while pulling a handkerchief out of my pouch. I created a bit of water to soak it in and began cleaning up her face.

“I learned long ago never leave home without one of these things. They come in useful for any number of emergencies. But really, we need to do something about those clothes. I think after school we go shopping. A few new dresses that look better on you, some new shoes, a few accessories and you will feel right at home. Oh and can’t forget food. A big hearty meal with some ice cream for desert. You look like a chocolate and strawberry kind of girl to me am I right?”

A quick head nod as I grinned even wider.

“I thought so. I’m partial to the spearmint twist myself. So, you think you are ready to face the world again?”

At her nod I sent my power out into the dome, causing it to melt back into it’s former shapes as I stood up from the cramped space. I looked around the room at everyone who was staring at me, giving them all a raised eyebrow as if daring them to say something negative. I saw a few wet eyes and a few dreamy looks of adoration from many of the girls. I was half expecting some of them to sigh and swoon any moment. Or maybe let out a scream with words like so romantic or some other such nonsense on their lips.

The guys for their part were more composed, but I saw a few of them holding back tears as well. I had a feeling I had just become Mr. Popular in the room. The one the guys wanted to emulate while at the same time feeling jealous of and the one the girls all suddenly thought would make the perfect father and boyfriend. Little did they know the real me. Liz grinned evilly at me since she knew exactly what was going on in everyone’s minds as well. Probably better than I did. I faced the entire room and gave a small bow before directing another one at the teacher.

“I apologize for the sudden outburst or if it startled anyone. As I said before, she is a bit unstable. Part of my job is giving her some of that stability back. I did not mean to cause such an interruption to the class and I will try not to let it happen again.”

I sat back in my chair where Asala promptly leaned her head on my side and began to play with her bear. I might understand her mind for the most part but some of the things she did or thought was still a mystery. After a few moments of staring at the two of us and me looking straight ahead, the class finally resumed a more normal pace. It took the teacher only a few seconds to get back into his teaching. He was a Hunter, this was nothing new to him.

The rest of the class went smoothly and Asala didn’t have another outburst. I could see the sorrow still haunting her eyes but for right now the largest portion of the grief had been dealt with. When the bell rang almost all of the girls converged on me saying how wonderful, moving and amazing I had been. As they began crowding closer Asala wrapped her hands around my waist while activating the shield. If the spell hadn’t pushed them all back I was sure the glare and the pinched lips she directed at them would have. Resting my hand gently on her head I grinned at the group outside the protective barrier.

“It seems Asala has spoken. She considers me her own personal property and she seems to be telling you all quite clearly to keep your hands off. I’d listen if I were you, no clue what she might do if she got angry.”

They tried telling the little girl they weren’t trying to take me from her but she continued to glare and not drop the shield until they all went away. If the grin on my face got any wider I was sure the ends would touch behind my head. I ruffled her hair again as she finally lowered her shield.

“You didn’t believe them either huh? Able to tell they wanted to sink their claws into me?”

She nodded her head in affirmation even as I picked up my bag and headed towards the door.

“I pity the man you marry someday little girl. He’s going to have a hard time keeping up with you.”

As she took my hand out in the hall she pointed at me and then herself. I wasn’t sure if she meant she was going to marry me or something else entirely. And I wasn’t sure I wanted to find out.

*********

Sometimes our destinies are beyond our control. Entwined and linked in unseen ways. Brought about by a slip of the tongue, or one thought drifting to the top of the mind over another. How easily could young Riktal have focused on the few negative aspects of his day? How differently would that change the outcome of everything? Even emotions and thoughts can be a choice, just as action and inaction. Even if they are automatic thoughts or instant emotional outbursts, they are still at their core, choices.

Come again fair traveler and make new choices to see where they lead. Perhaps those choices will tell you something about yourself you never knew before.
11112112221121.title: Monster Tactics

111121122212.content:
With a look of utter disgust and a sneer of contempt that I made sure everyone saw I dismissed him as unimportant. He didn’t even deserve what little pity I might have for him. Someone who would put his comrades in jeopardy like that even after being warned wasn’t worth any kindness in my eyes. It was best not to feed such egos even a little.

“Arena Master. You know the skills of the people in this class better then me. In your opinion who here could most benefit from and is worthy of this item?”

“You don’t want it yourself? You more than earned it.”

“I’ve already got augmentations and other items that are of a higher grade than this and I don’t need the money.”

The Arena Master thought for a moment, pulling out his little black control box and bringing up a list of stats that only he could see.

“Amir. He’s a sword and pistol heavy attacker but his magic levels are slightly lower then the others. But he still manages to hold his own against a caster heavy opponent.”

The boy in question looked surprised that he had been the one chosen. I had left the decision up to the teacher so their would be no dissension among the class or whispers of such petty things like favoritism or some power play. Everyone knew the Master of the arena was as impartial as they came. And the hardest of all the Hunter’s teaching at this school. It was his job to turn them all into fighting machines. He sent them out to ultimately live or die. If he went easy on anyone that could be the difference between them avoiding the killing blow or not.

Walking over to the boy I handed the item to him quill first and told him to use it well. After he thanked me with only a slight stutter I returned to my seat in the bleachers. Though not before gripping Gregory’s shoulder and whispering into his ear so only he could hear that I would kill him if my Lexington wasn’t in my bag by the end of class.

The Arena Master talked a bit about what everyone had seen and heard. Stressing the importance of the Hunter’s codes, both the written and the unwritten ones. Pointing out the way I had handled the situation and also why I had chosen the way I had. It was true there were a few other ways I could have handled the situation, but that one had been the one with the lowest amount of risk to life and limb. After he was done talking he rearranged the groups and sent them back out onto the field where I could already tell they were more confident and better organized.

It was around that time Liz sat back down next to me after finishing up helping the three with the feather’s attach them to weapons or shirts so they wouldn’t get hurt. Quickly showing them how to pull out the power when they needed to. Gregory ran out of the room as soon as he could, I assumed to return my weapon before the bell rang.

“So you would kill him and use your name to cover it all up huh?”

“Lip reading?”

“Lip reading.”

“I’ll make a note of that for later. But yes I would. Better if he dies than he hurt some innocent people with my weapon. Besides, he’s a parasite that should be purged. The world has enough troubles without the likes of him in our ranks.”

“I agree. It might sound counter productive to our code as Hunter’s but we have to look out for the good of the people, not just the good of the Hunter union. I mean look at the state the union is in now because we forgot that.”

“What are you talking about?”

“You know, all the corruption and the secret deals the union has with about half the world governments.”

“First I heard of this.”

“Really? I thought for sure you knew all about it since your family is neck deep in overthrowing it. Thought that was part of the reason you were here, because you didn’t want to join the union just yet until the new system was in place. Or perhaps weren‘t allowed to like me.”

“How do you know all this?”

“My parents and brother are all in on it too. They work closely with yours a lot. It’s part of the reason I’m living alone here in Efenbis. They forbid me from taking the Exam and working from the inside. And then after the assassination attempt they thought to send me away into obscurity.”

“Well this is all news to me. It makes a few things clear to me now, but it’s a shame my mother and father couldn’t trust me enough with this information. Thank you for telling me.”

“No problem. I really don’t get why they would keep you in the dark but personally I don’t agree. You’ve got a right to know the kind of world you live in. That knowledge might save your life one day. Or alter the decisions you make.”

We continued to chat a bit more after that, pointing out flaws and strengths in our classmates below. Describing what could be done differently and ways they could improve even more. At the same time we got to know each other a little better, learning small things about the other such as likes and dislikes. She also continued to fill me in on bits and pieces of what she knew about the secret war going on in the Hunter’s union.

When the bell finally rang we went our separate ways with a quick wave. Everyone was looking at me as I walked into the room and went over to my bag. There was a hushed expectation in the air as I looked inside before zipping it up and throwing it on my shoulder. Glancing around the room I met Gregory’s eyes, feeling my lip curl in a sneer.

“You’re lucky this time you little thief. But next time anything comes up missing, even a half-chewed pencil, I’m gunning for you. I don’t care if you weren’t even at school on the day it happened. I will assume you set it up and retaliate. So you had best hope there is no one here that you have really ticked off lately that is out for your blood. Or you might find them taking from me just so I can pummel you.”

I left the room then, feeling the bloodthirsty smile contorting my lips. It had been a small bit of revenge, implanting the idea into their heads as a way for them to get to the boy. He would try valiantly to forge alliances but would ultimately fail once word of his actions spread through the school. Everyone would enact Lapiiree on him, an absolute form of shunning that would ruin his name, reputation and basically any chance of becoming a Hunter for him or any future generation of his family for a long time to come. Women that were interested in him as a potential boyfriend or husband would break all ties, even if they weren’t Hunter’s themselves.

If he had enough connections and a glib enough tongue he could stop that from happening, but I doubted he had the money or the connections for such a feat. That was the way of things in our little society of heroes. Even if everyone else thought it might be nothing more than a stupid little prank done by a snot nosed kid, the Hunter world didn’t tolerate it. Not when we were supposed to be the role models for the rest of the world. Such small thoughtless stupid pranks now would grow into thoughtless big blunders when the fate of thousands were on the line.

As I passed the bathroom I felt the urges of my bladder. It wasn’t that insistent and I knew from experience it was only because I was so worked up over not only what Gregory had done but the revelations Liz had told me that my mother and father had kept secret. I just needed a few moments to calm down and I would be fine.
111121122212.title: Don't give him the feather

1111211222121.content:
Taking a few deep breaths I ignored the small annoyance. It would pass soon enough as long as I didn’t feed it. What I needed to do was calm down. Wasn’t that how you usually got into trouble Riktal? You got angry for whatever reason, then you hit or yelled at people and things, then you regret your actions afterwards. You can control it this time. This is a fresh start remember. You control your own destiny and your own actions Riktal Zelkov.

By the time I had calmed myself down while standing in the hall and gotten back to class, the shunning of Gregory was already underway. There was a noticeable space cleared around him as everyone who could had changed seats or simply shoved their desks farther away. People refused eye contact with him and even went out of their way to avoid him. Going the long way around his desk to get to friends instead of simply going straight through like they normally would. He even tried saying a few words but the other kids talked over him or ignored him completely. I gave it a week at most before he dropped out of the academy.

The teacher came in and began role call after having noted the new balance of power in the room. One of the girls shot up her hand as he called out the boys name and Gregory answered he was here. When he called on her she let a small look of sadness cross her face. She quickly told the teacher there was no Gregory Weiss in this class and there never had been, giving a brief explanation of why. Looking around the room Mr. Ghelis nodded his head.

“Thank you Emeline for letting me know. I will make sure to inform the other teachers of this fact. Wouldn’t want to be making fools of ourselves now would we?”

With great care he picked up his pen and ran a line through his book before continuing the role call. I could see Gregory getting nervous now, talking loudly to try and get the teachers attention. When the teacher continued to ignore him the boy even went so far as to get out of his seat and grab the teacher by the shirt. The teacher didn’t even blink or react, simply began his lesson an the Cawmacaw bird over the boys pleas. He wouldn’t even bend so far as to remove his hands. As far as he was concerned right now the boy was a ghost. Such was the way of the Lapiiree.

The only time this shunning would be unbent enough to give even an inkling that he existed was if he became a danger to the safety of innocent people or anyone in the class. If he decided to try and kill the teacher, he would be stopped, but that would be the only time the teacher or anyone would recognize him. He would be given one or two chances if he took that route though, otherwise he would be killed as little more than an afterthought. This level of treatment had been known to make even the strongest men go insane. It was one of the reasons why so many Hunter’s and those in training to become one kept to the codes.

The teacher had barely begun his lesson though when my mother’s aide Hilda came into the room. Her blond and gray hair done up in a tidy bun and the light yellow dress almost matching it perfectly. The low cut cleavage proved that while she might be getting on in years, age had been kind to her slightly plump figure.

Picking up my weapons I headed for the door with a slight smile for the old woman before she had a chance to whisper anything to the teacher. I let him know the woman was here for me, knowing it was actually my mother who wanted me and not her. But that was fine, I had a few things to discuss with my mother as well.

“Good to see you Hilda.”

“You too Riktal, it’s been a while. You’ve grown since I last saw you.”

“You’re imagining things, you’ve just gotten shorter.”

She gave a small chuckle as a twinkle came to her eye.

“Perhaps I have. I always have fought a losing battle with gravity.”

“So how many aides has she gone through since Selka was it? Wait no, Selka was on the Gitsune job, last time I saw you was on the Jallabin mission. So Haddy I think her name was?”

“It was Harsa, and only two. The new ones are Henry and Inga. Though honestly I can’t see either of them staying long either before she gets tired of them. They are good at their job, don’t get me wrong, just… too uptight.”

“They were all good at their jobs. I was even impressed by a few of them. Like that George fellow. He had an amazing head for analyzing things and I could actually get along with him. I thought for sure he would be more permanent after he managed to last four months longer than anyone else. Not to mention he was an ex-Hunter so he knew the job well. But then my mother got one of those flights of fancy and fired him for no reason.”

“Yes. He was such a good looking man too.”

I looked sideways at the old woman with a raised eyebrow and she returned the stare.

“What? When you get to be my age you appreciate what you can get. Even if it’s just a bit of eye candy.”

I chuckled a bit as we came to the meeting room door. Before I could open it though she stopped me with a hand on my arm.

“Riktal, you hide it well but I see you’re angry at your mother over something. Please, for my sake don’t go in their half cocked. At least try to listen to her will you? I’ve known you since before Olia died and you are like family to me. I more than anyone understand you and I know how you end up regretting the choices you make when you are like this. You might not believe it, but she really isn’t trying to purposefully anger you.”

I laid my hand on top of hers with a soft curve of the lips.

“Hilda, You are one of the few people that can put up with my mother and I have no clue how you manage to keep her from firing you like everyone else. But the best I can do is say I will try. I can’t make promises I’m not sure I can keep. But know that if she ever does fire you, I wouldn’t mind if you became my aide when I become a Hunter.”

With that I slipped her hand off my arm and entered the room to face my mother who jumped up to shower me with hugs and kisses in her usual way. I stood rigidly waiting for her to get done, waiting patiently for the right time to knock her down a notch. I didn’t even bother with the usual veiled hostility and banter, simply sat across the table and clasped my hands. She resumed her seat next to a thin girl with red irises and silver locks holding a tattered teddy bear to an equally tattered green dress that didn’t compliment her at all. Her blank stare and expressionless face reminding me of a lifeless doll.

My mother seemed to sense I simply wanted to get down to business so she dropped her work face into place as she imitated my clasped hand pose.

“Riktal darling, I want you to do a job for me.”

“What kind of job?”

“Protecting Asala here for a few days until someone can come pick her up.”

“Official Hunter job I take it?”

“I’d prefer it be under the table if possible.”

“So is that why you didn’t want me taking the Exams? This way I could do under the table jobs for you instead of working for a corrupt system over the table for you?”

“What are you talking about dear?”

“I found out mother. Maybe not all of it, but I know about the backroom deals, the corrupt union and how you, father, and big sis are all trying to take it down. So is that it huh? I’m not good enough to help you but I’m still good enough to be used by you whenever it’s convenient? How is an under the table job like this any different than the corrupt way the union does things? Is that the new system you want to put into place? Just replacing one dirty system with one you control?”

I clamped my mouth shut on what I was going to say next. Calm Riktal. Keep calm. If you lose your cool too much you lose the upper hand. You told Hilda you would try didn’t you?

“How did you find out! Val wouldn’t have told you and I was sure no one here would know.”

“At least you didn’t have the bad taste to keep denying it. There is a girl named Liz Hawthrope here mother. Does that last name sound at all familiar? I’m told it should since you work with her family quite often she says. And her parents unlike you, actually talk to her and trust her with the truth. Even if they do fight over it.”

“You mean the girl you are supposed to have a marriage meeting with next week? I didn’t know she went to this school!”

“Join the club on not knowing mother. I’ve had enough of that feeling. But now that I know about the stupid meeting you set up I can break it off without any worry. I’ll simply let her know not to expect me after telling her about it. Then again perhaps that’s why she has been getting close to me today, to feel me out before the actual meeting. I knew it was too good to be true that she would have no motive. And I was beginning to think of her as a friend too. Did you think to cement some dark alliance between the conspirators so no one would oppose your new system? “

Shoving my chair away from the table I stood up quickly, planting my hands down in front of me.

“Well I want no part of it and no part of this protection job.”

As I grabbed my bag from the floor next to the chair and turned to leave she held out her hand to stop me.

“Wait it isn’t like that at all! Can’t you let me explain even just a little?”
1111211222121.title: Go to class

11112112221211.content:
This wasn’t what I wanted. Hadn’t I said I wanted to change the way I was? Hadn’t I told myself how much I ended up regretting the choices I made while in the heat of anger? So despite every fiber of my being wanting to walk out the door at this moment I sat back down.


“Talk.”

She opened and closed her mouth a few times. As if she had only stopped me reflexively and now she didn’t know what to say. Finally she looked down at her clasped hands, picking at one thumbnail with the other.

I didn’t want to get you involved in any of this. It started around ten years ago. We got word of the union accepting bribes from different governments for secret missions. Now that’s really nothing too new, since the union is all about politics. Even though we are heroes to the people, we still have to grease a few palms here and there. But even then the union was all about bettering people as a whole. These bribes and secret deals were different. They were for personal gain and advancement of a select few that not only bent the morals of Hunter’s but also would tarnish our reputation if it got out. Such things as assassinating a good ruler for the right price, or using Hunter’s as weapons of war against weaker nations to absorb them into a bigger one.”

“When we first heard about this your sister was all fired up to become a Hunter, begging and pleading for us to let her become one. We didn’t realize how deep the corruption went so we agreed without qualms. We knew she could handle herself, and she was going in mainly as a spy. To find out how deep it all went and take it down if she could. We thought if it was only one or two that were involved we could do a quiet assassination and be done with it.”

“Little did we know just how all encompassing it was. How many nations were already part of this big conspiracy and just how many powerful Hunter’s as well. I’m not talking just strong of arm, I’m talking about strong political connections. Zarimin Kefner is the head of the union. He is a fourteenth generation Hunter and a member of one of the few families with more influence than us Zelkov’s. Of the generation families at least sixth generation or higher we found at least ten of the fifteen families are in on it.”

“You were just ten when we first began our campaign against this corruption. Me and your father decided it was best not to tell you. We hoped to have it all cleaned up by the time you were ready to take the test. Unfortunately it kept dragging on and proved more difficult then we first anticipated. Kefner is a powerful and cunning man. We would have assassinated him long ago if we could. If we had managed that the rest would be much easier. Even now if we could kill him we could be done with this at least six months sooner.”

“When you grew older and began talking about taking the test we continued to keep you in the dark because we knew how hot blooded you could be. We wanted you to become a Hunter without worrying about being forced into military service or have a gag order put on you, or any number of other things I won’t mention. So we put you off time and again. Then Val asked for our help and we sent you to this school. I purposefully forced this on you, knowing you would hate me for it but that was better I thought than the alternatives.”

“We don’t want to put another corrupt system in place that we control behind the scenes. We simply want to return the system to the way it was before. The system itself wasn’t bad, only the people running it were.”

“So what will the repercussions of this be? Once you tear it down I mean?”

“At least eight nations breaking into civil war and having their old governments overthrown. Fifteen or sixteen old houses being destroyed, or at least their reputation. Distrust of the other old families that had no involvement in the corruption, even ours. A couple trillion in damages that will bankrupt most of the old families involved and a minimum loss of innocent lives if we can help it. That’s only the tip of the iceberg that we could think of. We have no idea what else might happen.”

I nodded my head as I searched her face. I didn’t sense any lies coming from her for a change. And oddly I felt no hostility towards her at the moment. I nodded at the girl with my chin quickly.

“And her? What’s her part in all of this? I doubt she is just an innocent bystander caught up in it all.”

“Actually she really is. Her parents were activist helping us but she didn’t know anything about it until a Hunter stole into their house and killed them in front of her. That caused her latent monster summoning powers to activate. She summoned a creature that killed the Hunter in his surprise before running amok and destroying a large chunk of the city until it was put down. The only one who knows about her abilities besides those of us in this room is one of her parents supporters. They had thought she could be used as a weapon, but even I balked against that idea. That’s when I took her into my custody and left.”

“Aren’t you afraid that supporter will talk? Spread the news to everyone else?”

“She’s welcome to talk if she can rise from the dead and reattach her head to her body.”

I nodded my agreement to how she had handled the situation. It was the smartest move in a revolution like this. Now that I knew, things began to make a little more sense. The less people knew of a plan, the less likely it was to fail or be foiled in some way.

“I’ll take the job. Just give me around five thousand Reul for some expenses so I don’t dig too deeply into my living allowance. I’ll even do it under the table. If I become a Hunter by proxy, it will increase the chances of the union finding out about the girl if things go wrong and I try to cover it up. I’ll deal with it if it happens without that insurance.”

It didn’t take long for Hilda to get the money transferred over to my account and all the business was settled. My mother filled me in on a few other details as well so I had a better idea of how to handle the girl. When my mother got up to leave I asked her to wait a moment, a smile on my face so as not to worry the girl. I knew she could hear me and what had been discussed and that was probably part of the reason she had shut down.

“Hilda, can you take the girl out into the hall for a little bit please? I’d like to speak with my mother alone for just a moment.”

She looked between the two of us and my mother gave her a small nod before the woman came and took Asala by the hand to lead her out. As soon as they were gone I looked back at my mother, leaning forward over the table and lowering my voice a bit.
11112112221211.title: Sit back down

111121122212111.content:
“How much are you willing to pay to have this guy assassinated?”

“Don’t even think about it. You aren’t good enough to take him on.”

“I didn’t ask that. If it were possible, how much would you pay?”

“Up to a million Reul. I’d even pay it out of the family coffers.”

I grinned as I activated my communication spell, setting it to both audio and visual before placing it on the table. A moment later a one armed woman in a highly revealing dress popped up. She looked and saw it was me and her face split into a smile.

“Riktal honey! Ready to make the bed squeak with me? Is that why you called out of the blue?”

“Not a chance Ginger. Could you go to your wine room. Not the one you entertain visitors in, but the one with your special drinks.”

She looked at me sideways a moment and then turned her head to see my mother sitting across from me. She gave me a wink and told me to hold on. Even though I could see her walking and bits and pieces of her house, I couldn’t make out anything discernable. The party going on in the background grew louder and louder until it suddenly cut off, leaving only a heavy silence.

“Ok I’m secure honey. No ones going to hear a peep. So what kind of secret business you got for me?”

“I know for a fact a man named Zarimin Kefner frequents your parties. You can deny it if you want but I know it’s true. He calls himself Zedric and dyes his hair but I know who he is.”

“Yeah so what of it? I get a lot of people who want to hide their identity coming around for various reasons.”

“I’ll give you five hundred thousand Reul to kill him. No questions asked. Should be easy to slip something in his drink or lace some of his Boda weed or something like that. I’ve seen how he’s all over you.”

“Seven hundred thousand if it’s no questions asked.”

“Done. I’ll get half to you within a day or so on good faith and the other half when it’s done. Just take down two of those god awful pictures for a while as a cover-up. They are easily worth three hundred to four hundred thousand. I’ll make sure the contracts to launder the money reflect that.”

“I like my artwork! You just don’t have good taste! But fine. I know just the two to sell to you. It will be done within a week. He will probably be coming over for my party in two days. Lots of high rankers will be there and he loves to wheel and deal with them. I’ll just…”

“Stop. I don’t want to hear it. The less I know the better. No questions asked remember? That goes for me too. I know you will succeed and it will look like natural causes, that‘s what your good at.”

I cut off the spell after a few more exchanges and a quick farewell before looking at my mother.

“You heard her. One week, seven hundred thousand in two payments for artwork. Think you can handle it?”

“But how did you…”

“Please mother, the union isn’t the only ones that are corrupt. I’ve been dealing with the shady side of things for a long time now. Since I was at least thirteen or fourteen. I learned how to play the game since I had so much free time on my hands. Even the best Hunter has to get his hands dirty like this sometimes. Now go on and leave. I’ve got a little girl to take care of.”

With that I went to the door, taking the little girl off Hilda’s hands and sitting her down to work on getting her to trust me while my mother left me alone. I had a feeling our relationship was going to be a lot different from now on.

Looking at the little girl I was reminded of Olia and smiled. I had no doubt in my mind I could help this little girl. Just like I had no doubt everything would work out in the end. After all, I was good with kids and I had experience as a big brother. Taking her hand, I knelt in front of her.

“Hey Asala, my name is Riktal and until you leave I’m going to be like your big brother. I’m not going to leave you alone either and I’m not one bit afraid of your power. So throw the biggest meanest most scariest thing you can at me and I will make it cry uncle while wearing a pink tutu. I’m not going to yell at you or tell you not to cry for your parents. But if you do cry in front of me you better believe I’m going to wrap my arms around you and stroke your hair until you make my shirt as ugly as your dress with your snot. Now let me tell you a little story about my little sister.”

As I settled in more comfortably on my heals I saw a small bit of intelligence come back to her eyes and smiled even wider. Yes, I had no doubt I could do this.

********

The window closes, the day for now draws to an end. What kind of tale could be told of their time together? Is it a happy one? A tragic one? Perhaps a mixture of the two. With each new answer comes a new question. With each new question a new mystery. Round and round this cycle goes, never to completely end their dance. Each one intricately linked to the choices made and the path of destiny you guided.

Come again fair adventurer of this strange world where time is meaningless. Come again to begin this day anew. Make different choices, perhaps better ones. See how just a tiny little thought can alter an outcome greatly. For such is the gift, and the curse of choice.
111121122212111.title: Talk privately

11112112221212.content:
“You had years to explain things to me. Why feel guilty about keeping me in the dark now? Just go on with your life like you always do and find someone else. Maybe Pelei will do it. Not like you don’t have experience abandoning children when they need you and making them someone else’s problem.”

As I passed Hilda I put my hand on her shoulder after letting out a low sigh.speaking softly so only she could hear.

“Sorry, that was the best I could do.”

Ignoring her pleas to wait I shut the door in her face, turning to head towards class. Oddly I wasn’t as angry as I knew I could have been. I wasn’t sure why exactly, perhaps I was just so tired of fighting with her all the time. I had grown used to her callous ways and the way she treated me. This moment was just another one to be added to a long list of let downs and broken hopes.

Drawing closer to where the hall split I sensed the presence around the corner, so I wasn’t surprised to find the principal sitting there with hands folded in her lap as her wheelchair butted up against the wall.

“I didn’t destroy your precious school and I don’t plan on it if that’s what you were worried about. I’m sure you have heard quite a bit about the fights me and my mother can get into when we clash.”

“I thank you for that, but I’d actually like you to take a small walk with me. Mind sparing an old woman some time before running off to class?”
11112112221212.title: Leave

111121122212121.content:
“Why not. It’s not like I will miss learning something important if I don’t go.”

She turned and wheeled herself down the hall, staring off into space a bit as I fell into step beside her. Finally she began to speak as she pushed herself out through a side door and into the yard.

“People sometimes do things with the best of intentions but end up with the worst results. Now hear me out before you say anything. I’m not just talking about your mother here, I’m talking about people in general. There is such a thing as being too nice or too concerned. I’m sure you’ve learned this already or at least heard such things. It ties in with doing things with the best of intentions. Hiding facts for fear of hurting another like your mother did, or only wanting a person to experience the best in life without having to go through any hardships. It all comes down to one thing, caring.”

“Ha! Then you really don’t understand my mother. Or she has you fooled like everyone else. She cares about one person, herself. It only slightly beats out her care for the family name and image.”

“Then why do you think she hid this information from you? If she really didn’t care about you at all she wouldn’t have bothered. She did it because she cared. She didn’t want you embroiled in that mess. But I think she cared too much. She might not know how to show it, and she is definitely abysmal with kids, but I think this whole thing got blown out of proportion because of her desire to protect you. Because protection is an act of caring. That made her fall into the latter category of people who don’t want someone to live life with any hardships. In the end the reverse became true. You lived a life of mostly nothing but hardships and little else.”

She went quiet as we rounded the building and came on the track and field area. A big black crow that was sitting on top of one of the fence posts winged it’s way over to alight on her wheelchair. Digging into a little side pouch she pulled out some breadcrumbs and offered them absently to the bird. The crow didn’t even hesitate to gently peck the offering from her palm even as we continued to move on.

“What do you know about your grandparents on your mothers side?”

“Not much actually. It never seemed important to my training and no one ever talked about it. I don’t think it’s that odd. They were eighth generation Hunters, that’s all I really need to know.”

“Yes they were renowned Hunters. Very good at their jobs too. But your grandmother had one very big flaw, she couldn’t bear children. The line was going to die out with her. That is until your grandfather admitted that he had a child to someone else. A girl who had been born to a poor woman that had been smitten by your grandfather. That woman wasn’t even a Hunter, just a city girl barely out of high school herself and not ready for motherhood.”

“Your grandparents came in and whisked the baby away, claiming it as their own and paying the woman off with a large sum of money to keep quiet and never contact the girl in the future. A bribe the woman accepted quickly, the prospect of an easy life too good to pass up."

“So they trained your mother from the day she could crawl to take over the family business and keep the line alive. But would you believe she really wasn’t suited to be a Hunter at first? She was a crybaby and always fumbling with her weapons or her magic. On top of that your grandmother Eli never could quite forgive her for being another woman’s child. Calling her a half-blood in private. So her mother pushed her harder and harder, showing very little care for the girl. Only putting up with her because she had to for the family.”

“One day she found out Eli wasn’t her true mother and so she went out searching for her real one. She was I think eleven or twelve years old then. By that time she had learned at least a minimum of competence in her training if through sheer repetition if nothing else. She ran away from home and was gone for almost three months, searching until she finally found her. She was living in luxury off the bribe money with another man and a three year old son. When Marian told the woman who she was, do you know what she replied with?”

“I never had a daughter. She then slammed the door in your mother’s face and refused to open it again. That changed Marian. She became more cold and uncaring than those around her. Throwing herself into her training like never before and becoming the woman she is today. She was lost for a long time. I don’t mean physically of course, but lost inside her own head while her body went on autopilot.”

Her parents forced the arranged marriage with your father on her. Not even giving her a choice of any other men. Simply saying this was who she would marry. Romone was basically told the same thing. And so, both of them were married within months of that announcement. Your father seventeen and your mother sixteen. Not even completely out of school yet. Your mother had already passed her Hunter Exams the year before but back then, education was mandatory even if you already had a license.”

“She ended up dropping out her senior year to have Ulicia. But at that time your grandfather was killed on a job.
