Your mother basically severed the last of her ties with her step-mother and said if the woman interfered with her family she would kill her. Indeed, not two months later your grandmother’s corpse was found with a slit throat and multiple other wounds. But no proof that it was Marian who had done it.”

“It was fortunate that your parents actually ended up falling in love because it helped her become a little more normal. She vowed she would never be like her mother to her own kids. But through a combination of her being bad with children to begin with and being overprotective of all of you, she ended up being like her anyways. Maybe not completely, but close enough.”

“You brought me to tears over here. So what? It doesn’t change anything, she is still a crappy mother. Still going to do her own thing and do what’s best for herself. If she hasn’t changed by now she’s not going to.”

We had stopped walking sometime during the story, I didn’t even realize when exactly. One of the academic groups was running around the track and the crow was content to sit next to her face being scratched under the chin. She pointed to a window on the other side of the chair which showed my mother crying her eyes out as Hilda tried to comfort her when I looked inside.

“The point is, even crappy people have feelings. And they have reasons of their own why they are the way they are, they make bad choices and they regret just like everyone else. They try to live as best they can and hope their life doesn’t fall apart on them sometimes. The same way you are a hot head that can act and speak without thinking, regretting what you did once you calm down.”

“It’s easy to judge people based on only what you know of them, since rarely do you have the full picture. That imperfect knowledge and those judgments make it easy to hate. But as Hunter’s we seek out the best possible solution to protect the most innocent people. Sometimes those we condemn or feel disgust for are saved as well because of that. Being able to accept a persons failures and shortcomings and being able to forgive them for the choices they made. That is what separates the truly great Hunter’s from the rest of us.”

I stared through the window in silence as my mother pulled the girl into her chest in her grief. I could read her lips saying she was sorry over and over. Asking the girl to bear with her for just a little bit. In between her tears she kept mumbling that her son hated her and she had never been able to hold him like this before. So she was sorry she was using the girl as a substitute. For a while the girl didn’t react at all. But finally her hands came up and began patting my mother’s back in comfort before she began to cry too.

“Just who are you and what relationship do you have with my family that you know so much?”

“Me? I’m just an old lady that has seen a lot in her years. Who has eyes and ears everywhere and who knows the regrets and folly of youth. It’s my job to teach people how to be better Hunter’s. But in the end it comes down to if they want to learn or not.”


She spun on her wheels quickly, causing the crow to flap its wings before settling down again.

“So I guess my question to you is, are you a Hunter? Or are you a truly great one?”

She left me there alone with my thoughts for a while as my mother continued to bawl with no signs of stopping. Finally I turned and headed towards the front of the building around the next bend. It only took a few moments to find myself back outside the meeting room door feeling more anxious than I had ever felt before. Not even facing my first monster had I been half this anxious. Taking a deep breath I opened the door and walked inside.

My mother saw me come in and tried to halt her tears without much success even as I went over and wrapped my arms around her. Telling her it would be all right just like I would if she was a child that I actually knew how to handle. I felt extremely awkward as I made soothing noises and she began to break down again while grabbing me tightly. Telling me she was sorry over and over while not making a whole lot of sense otherwise. With a free hand I pulled the crying little girl into our little circle and let the two of them hold onto me like a life preserver. As anxious as I was and as awkward as I felt at the moment, I really didn’t mind the position I was in right now.

Glancing over her shoulder at the window, I saw a crow with beady black eyes sitting on the ledge looking in.

********

The time grows short now traveler. The window has decided to close on this day. Come again and alter his destiny once more and see where he ends up. Perhaps the window will be kinder and allow you a longer view into his life and his psyche.
111121122212121.title: Go with her

111121122212122.content:
“Sorry, I’m just not in the mood to listen to someone who is probably in on my mothers grand conspiracy right now. I need to get back to class and pretend to learn something new.”

Even though I kept walking she rolled after me anyways. I ignored her, she had a right to go wherever she wanted and say whatever she wanted. I just didn’t have to listen or acknowledge her.

“I knew about the corruption. Well maybe not all of it but I knew some of it. That’s one of the reasons your mother and me formed our alliance. I watch each student closely, and when it comes time to graduate I offer them a chance to join our cause and help us against the union. Your mother has formed a sort of pseudo licensing center along with many other families. It’s illegal of course, but the licenses are still valid and usable. It’s a complicated network of spies, insider manipulation and more that I can’t even begin to comprehend.

“I know one of the reasons she sent you here was to help groom future Hunter’s. I asked for her help in making this school better. In lowering the death rates of students. You were what I got.”

“Bit of a letdown for you isn’t it? Getting someone even my mother doesn’t think is worthy of being a professional.”

“No letdown at all. I heard about what happened in the arena. You showed them the value of the knowledge we teach. You led a group against a monster much stronger than them and made it look easy. You gave them confidence in themselves and a desire to become better. To emulate what you did and live up to those expectations. Higher quality of Hunter’s means it is easier to protect the cities we have built. And makes new settlements possible because they have Hunter’s to protect them.”

We came to the stairs and I started up them without hesitation. I had no doubt she had a way to get up here but I hoped she would just leave me alone. Instead she hit a switch on one of the arms as she spun sideways. The entire chair lifted up, attaching itself to the handrail along the wall, letting her slide upwards after me.

“There’s a reason I made sure all the railings and handrails were metal. Makes using this magnet so much easier. You won’t get rid of me that easily. Now where was I? Oh yes. I’m not going to try and defend your mother or her actions. And I’m not going to say I even rightly know all her reasons for everything she does. I only know a few things as they pertain to me and this school. Plus maybe a little extra here and there that’s incomplete knowledge at best.

“But keep in mind that she is human just like everyone else. As such she is fallible and capable of making bad decisions. When we do our jobs, we make decisions on what is most beneficial to the most innocent people. Sometimes bad people we would otherwise kill or simply ignore are saved as well. And though we might not always like to admit it, the same is true about innocent people. While our actions might save a thousand lives, we can’t always save all of them. What happens to the hundred we have to sacrifice to save those thousands? They can’t all be bad people.

“Sometimes we have to use our families for the greater good. I can only assume that was one of the thoughts in your mothers head for not telling you. She’s had a hard life too you know. Don’t get conceited or anything thinking you are the only one with troubles. If you ask me your whole family is messed up, with skewed notions about things and has been for a very long time.”

“So what do you expect? That I will suddenly gain some enlightenment and go running back down the stairs begging my mother for forgiveness? Begging her to continue to use me as she wishes and keep me in the dark all she wants? Sorry not happening. She can sort this out on her own. That’s what I’ve always had to do since no one was ever there I could rely on.”

“Not even Olia?”

“Not even Olia. I was her big brother. I was the one she relied on, I couldn’t shake her faith in me. And that is the last time you can use her name. I don’t know who you think you are but you have no right to talk like you even knew her. I thrust a sword through the last principal’s lung, don’t think I won’t hesitate to do so again. Only next time I will aim for the throat.”

We came on the door to the classroom so I stopped and gave the principal a small bow of the head.

“I’d say it’s been nice chatting with you but I’d hate to lie to your face like that. Go do whatever it is you do all day and leave me alone.”

She smiled sadly as she turned around.

“Fine I’ll go for now. But remember, whether you want it to be so or not, your classmates have already found a healthy respect for you because of your actions today. Not because you are a tenth generation Hunter, or because you are a Zelkov. But because you are yourself. You have the power to make them all better then they are right now if you so desire. If you don’t want to do so then that’s your decision and I will respect it. But know that I’m glad your mother sent you here even if it was against your will.”

The bell rang signaling the end of class as she wheeled herself off. With a sigh I reentered the room and sat at my desk, losing myself in thought as the four minute break ended and the Monster Tactics teacher came in. Once he started in on his lesson I tuned him out to focus on sorting out my thoughts.

I understood what the principal had been trying to say. Even though I had been sent here against my will, that didn’t mean I couldn’t do some good here. And just because it had been against my will didn’t mean it had been the wrong choice. After careful consideration of the facts that I knew, I could only concede that not telling me the reasons why I was sent here as wrong. The actual actions of sending me here had been the right choice. Now the question remained, did I want to actively help or not?

They would learn and get better on their own. I would make them better just by being me, meaning I didn’t have to actually do anything. But interacting with them and actively doing something was not something I was very good at. I had a short temper and I was easily annoyed by them. I wasn’t good at the interpersonal relationships thing either. I understood children age thirteen and younger, and I could deal with people on a purely business level. I had a few people I could consider myself close to, but they were all in the Hunter business as well so my interactions with them tended towards the business aspect of things. I didn’t really understand things like friendships and talking about non-Hunter things like girls or sports or magazines or any number of other topics.

If I tried to actively involve myself with these people there was a good chance I would make everything worse. I would do more harm to my purpose for being here than help it. If they learned more about me and saw how inept I was outside of being a Hunter their desire to be like me would most likely die out as they became disillusioned. Honestly, I didn’t want to actively involve myself with them. Precisely because I knew my own failings and personality. Though I did have to admit actively dealing with and helping them would make them better faster than doing nothing. Even if the risks were greater.

The bell rang letting everyone know it was the end of the school day. Gregory hurried out of the room but no one seemed to notice or care, even when he bumped into one of the girls. A small group of two boys and three girls came towards me as I stood up.
111121122212122.title: Keep walking

1111211222121221.content:
Before they had a chance to say anything I was already pushing past them and out the door. It was for the best if I didn’t get too involved. Actively trying to help them was too great a risk. I wouldn’t end up making bad choices like my mother had. Even if she had made them with the best of intentions as the principal had said. The fact still remained that she had ruined my life by making one bad choice after another. I wouldn’t ruin their chances to become good Hunter’s by trying to be someone I wasn’t. I knew my limitations at least. In the end I was a user like my mother. Even though I was using myself and not someone else, the idea was the same.

There was also a small space around me now that was mainly given off by my fellow classmates. They weren’t doing to me what they were doing to Gregory, it was more of a bubble because of their respect. But I still felt a bit like I was the one having Lapiiree enacted on me. Still this was for the greater good.

With that thought firmly in mind I was able to ignore the stares and the whispers. It wasn’t like I didn’t have practice at being alone. Or learning how to push away the silence. This was just how my life was. Turning down the sidewalk I headed for the cold quiet building I called home. Perhaps I would feel up to making more than a bowl of noodles for dinner even though I would be the only one eating. Riktal Zelkov. Master of being alone. That was me in a nutshell.

***********

So ends the day of our young hero. Filled with the good and the bad, how do you think it ended? What made you decide the route he took? What made you chose this instead of that? Did you second guess yourself? Think to take an odd route and hoping to be surprised by a twist of fate? Where they based on your own feelings of the issues? Or on how you thought he would react in the situation? Are you satisfied with the way things have gone?

Come again and choose another destiny. Perhaps following the same path except making one minor change. Would such a change do anything I wonder? Or was it all determined before you ever got here? Perhaps next time we shall find out. The next time you play god that is.
1111211222121221.title: Stay aloof

1111211222121222.content:
Instead of letting them corner me I sidestepped them as I headed over to where Daniel and Jethic were gathering their things. I suppose it was fortunate they sat so close to each other. Despite my misgivings abut whether this was the right thing to do or not, the potential gain was worth the risk. Even if I did screw this whole thing up, if I could make them better Hunter’s by even just a fraction then wasn’t that worth it? I sneered at my mother because she only thought of herself, how would I be any better if I made a choice that was easiest for me?

“Daniel, Jethic, if you guys have some time right now I can show you to that augmentation crafter I was telling you about. Make a few introductions for you so you don’t get cheated and start you on your road to dealing with this kind of stuff. I’m sure he will be glad for the extra business from up and coming Hunter’s.”

Both their eyes widened and their jaws dropped as they stuttered their thanks. After a few moments they both looked at each other and looked to the ground.

“On second thought I think I’ll pass.”

“Yeah me too.”

“Really? Why?”

Jethic seemed to blush a bit as he mumbled out his answer and Daniel nodded in agreement with the shield bearer.

“My family is poor. I don’t have any money to get my shield augmented right now.”

“Same with me. We got a bit of money but not that much. I was planning on getting a part time job to save up before getting it augmented.”

I felt so awkward and fake as I pushed them both in the back to get the moving ahead of me. This wasn’t me. It wasn’t how I operated. Especially since I didn’t know them all that well.

“No worries. He owes me a few favors so I’m sure I can talk him into giving you this first one free. Though after this you’ll be on your own. And lucky for you, he comes from the far east across the seas, he loves to haggle and loves to barter even more. Why I once got him to give me an augmentation for a rubber chicken, a gag arrow and an ounce of vampire blood. Not sure what he used it for but he seemed happy.”

I could see the group of five kids that had tried to corner me gaping like stranded fish. I could also hear their whispers to each other about how they wished they were that lucky. I knew some of it was just them wanting to get close to me for their own reasons, but I was sure they were like everyone else trying to make connections for their future.

“If your going to whisper, it’s a good idea to do so in a quiet voice that can’t be overheard. I mean isn’t that the whole point of whispering?”

They all blushed and looked away from me as I let out a deep sigh. Every fiber of my being was saying to let it go. That my next words were the wrong ones. That I was already in too deep by offering my assistance to the two boys in front of me. But I couldn’t. I had already jumped into this headfirst, might as well screw it up royally if I was going to screw it up.

“You guys can come as well if you want. I’m sure he will be glad for all the extra future business. Just try not to make me look bad since I still have to deal with him. That’s the catch to having someone else introduce you to the people they know in the Hunter world. Your actions can also affect me and ruin my reputation and credibility with my contacts.”

The five kids looked like I had just announced I was from another planet and wished to be taken to their leader.

“You serious! We can go with you too!”

“Is their an echo in here? I wouldn’t have said anything if I wasn’t serious. I’m not going to wait up for you guys so make up your minds quickly. And keep down on the inane excited babble if you can. It’s not like this makes us friends or anything. But if you really are serious about becoming Hunter’s, you need to start dealing with this kind of stuff sometime. Best if you start early before you really need it.”

I turned away then and went through the door into the hall, pausing only long enough to make sure Jethic and Daniel were following me. Interacting with people like this felt weird just like every other time I had tried to do it. And I had a feeling that also like every other time, it would fail.

Then again perhaps not. Even if they acted like regular high schooler’s, unlike my last school they were also Hunter’s in training. That already gave them more in common with me than anyone at the last school. That had shown they had a desire to honor the codes and learn the skills to protect innocent people just like me. Only time would tell, but I had to at least give them a chance to prove if this was a mistake or not didn’t I?

*********

A slip of the tongue, a wisp of thought becoming more important than another. A thousand different variables as to the who’s, how’s, and why’s of the choices we make. And yet there are a thousand and one more that decide which thousand variables we are given at any given moment. That is what makes it so difficult to tell if we truly have free will, or if such a thing is an illusion and we are all guided by some grand hand called fate. Our lives predetermined for us.

Perhaps free will and destiny are actually two names for the same thing? Perhaps even as we speak our words are dictated by something or someone greater, forcing us to go down a path of it’s choosing. You are free to come again and play god, seeing what else might have happened this day.

But then again, maybe you’re not. Maybe such is simply your fate.
1111211222121222.title: Actively participate

1111211222122.content:
No, I had better use the restroom. I knew that if I didn’t go, this would be the one time I actually would need to use the bathroom later. That was the law of coincidence. Always double check and expect the unexpected, that was how I had grown up thinking. Having to take care of my little sister all the time and living on my own I had learned this fact through much trial and error.

Looking at myself in the mirror after washing my hands I tried to calm myself down. But that anger was still boiling inside just under the surface. Did she not trust me enough with information like this? Did she not think I was a good enough Hunter? What were her reasons for keeping me out of the loop?

I could see my reflection clenching it’s jaw as my hands gripped the edge of the countertop tightly. With my curly red hair and the slight narrowing of my eyes it looked like my gaze had ignited my head. My thin framed glasses felt like they were holding that dark glare back from burning everything else around me. What was wrong with me anyway that I didn’t deserve to know any of this? How long had it gone on and did big sis know about it? If she did then why hadn’t she told me? Just how far did this conspiracy to keep me in the dark go? Obviously my father knew about it, but who else? Was everyone around me in on it? Were they simply hiding behind fake smiles under my mother’s orders to keep me from finding out?

With a growl I punched the wall next to the mirror, making the porcelain tiles crack and fall away and leaving a small crater after I pulled back my hand. Damn that conniving woman anyway! She didn’t want me to be angry at her yet she pulled crap like this. She wondered why I was always so hostile and refused to act like a good son when she thought keeping secrets like this was a good idea!

Calm down Riktal. It did no good to work yourself up. It would just make you do something you would regret. Don’t feed into it. That’s what she wants. She wants you to keep blowing up over every little thing she does so she can use that as fodder against you later. You're too violent to be a Hunter right now, with a temper like that you can’t be trusted to do your job effectively. Weren’t those some of her words before she forced this stupid school on me? Prove her wrong Riktal. Shove it all back in her face the next time you see her by keeping your act together.

Even though I told myself that it didn’t seem to help too much. I just couldn’t get the anger to go away. The best I could manage was to bottle it up for the moment. Later on I would slip out of town and go slay monsters until it was all gone. A bit of mindless killing was just what I needed. Once I was sure I could keep myself from exploding on someone in the classroom over something small I left the restroom.

“Riktal! You were just the person I was coming to see!”

I turned to see a slightly plump old woman in a yellow dress and a black eye patch over her right eye coming towards me down the hall. I felt some of my anger slip away and a smile spread along my lips.

“Hilda, I can honestly say I am glad to see you. You are one of the few people that I can’t help but smile when I see.”

“Trying to bottle down your anger over something again?”

“How could you tell?”

She shrugged as she absently gave me a hug and a quick kiss on the cheek like we were long lost family. Apart from a handful of other people, she was the only one I didn’t mind when she was so familiar with me.

“You know me, I can always tell. You get a certain look about you when you are in one of your moods. Let me guess something to do with your mother again?”

“When isn’t it about my mother in some way? I take it you’re here on business as her aide though and I probably won’t like it one bit am I right?”

“Got it in one. Come on, let’s talk on the way.”

She turned and began walking back the way she came while I fell into step beside her.

“On a scale of one to ten how much am I not going to like this meeting?”

“In the state you are in now? A seven or eight probably. I’m sure it’s a bad time and what she wants is only going to make it worse, but would you please try to hold it in with a little extra while for me? From what I know there is a good chance this might bring you two to blows again and I don’t want that. I might be your mother’s aide but I’ve known you for years now and I can’t help but want to take care of you too.

“On top of that there is a little girl involved. I don’t know much about her but she has been through a lot already. I don’t want that poor child to suffer seeing a parent and child trading fists. Not after losing her own parents only three days ago.”

Hitching my bag of weapons up on my shoulder a bit higher I looked over at the old woman that I had more feelings of family towards than my own mother.

“That bad huh? But you know I can’t make such promises. The best I can do is say I will try.”

“That’s all I can ask for.”

We walked in silence a few moments longer as we went down the stairs to the first floor.

“This girl. What kind of state is she in?”

“Now that’s a funny question to ask. Not what she is like or why she is here?”

“Not really. If she just lost her parents three days ago and has probably been yanked around everywhere meeting a bunch of strange people in strange places, depending on how old she is that can really damage the mind. If I know the state she is in I can guess at what she is like based on how she reacted to all these changes. I already assume she is here because she has something to do with either why my mother wants me or part of a job she is on. I tend to think the former since my mother doesn’t do well with kids at all. Preferring to just abandon them to grow up alone.”

“She’s a strange one. Silver hair, crimson eyes. She hasn’t said a word for the last three days. Refuses to eat or move on her own, so your mother has taken to using magic to sustain her life. That won’t work for long though, the body needs real food in order to survive. She just clutches a tattered teddy bear to her chest and stares at nothing all day long, barely blinking. She will sit for hours on end not even moving, as if she was a puppet that only moved when someone else moves her.”

“And my mother has probably just grabbed her arm and dragged her around everywhere.”

“Pretty much. I’ve told her the girl was in shock and needed some attention but she is always so busy, she simply left such things to us aides. I’ve done what I could but I didn’t have much time to focus on the girl the way your mother runs me around and the other aides are pretty horrible at dealing with this kind of thing. I even heard the new girl Inga tell her to just get over it already, her parents had only died and it wasn’t that big of a deal. Henry was a bit better, but he’s a real man’s man if you know what I mean. Great for the strong arm stuff, but not so great when handling women and little children. Has the mindset that the woman should stay at home with the kids while the man goes making the money.”

“And he managed to get a job as my mother’s aide? How’d he pull that off?”

“If you figure that one out then you let me know. But I don’t see him lasting more than a month. Your mother has a new job and she can’t take the girl with her. We were at our wits end trying to figure out who we could get to take her, then I remembered how good you are with this kind of stuff and little kids in general. Admittedly I remembered after you called your mother earlier but still, I’m the one who told her to talk to you about it.”

We came to the door and Hilda stopped to look at me with soft eyes before opening it.

“Please help that poor girl with her suffering will you? Even if you have your differences with your mother don’t take it out on that little girl. I know you can help her. From what little I know of how she used to be before her parents died, she sounds a lot like Olia. She needs you, and I think you need her more than you realize right now.

With that she opened the door and stepped aside, allowing me to enter first.
1111211222122.title: Go to bathroom

11112112221221.content:
As my mother got up to shower me with her hugs and kisses which I knew were fake from start to finish, I held up my hand. Completely ignoring her I went over to the little girl who was just like Hilda had described. Kneeling in front of her and staring into those dead blank eyes I couldn’t even see a flicker of intelligence. Granted this might not be the best move as it would make any bargaining chips I had with my mother weaker, but I couldn’t let this little girl suffer. Even if I hadn’t already decided to take the job before even walking in the door, I couldn’t turn a blind eye to her. My anger was at my mother, not this little girl. In the end she was just an innocent I needed to protect as was my duty as a Hunter.

“Boy Hilda was right, you are creepy. Those dead looking eyes, that starved body, those ugly green clothes that look like someone dug them out of the garbage after a dog vomited on them. Yeah I think they made a mistake. They brought a zombie along with them not a little girl.”

I made a show of sniffing the air like a hound catching a scent before plugging it up with two fingers.

“Yep you even smell as ripe as an undead. But you know, I got a special magic that can bring zombies back to life. It’s a super secret magic I came up with myself. I bet if I use it on you I can get you to return to normal.”

My left hand began to twitch sporadically and I gave a look of surprise. I tried to stop the shaking with my right hand before it too began to shake quickly. Soon my entire body was twitching.

“I feel the magic coming! It knows there is a zombie girl in front of me and I can’t hold it in much longer! I feel the power building! If you don’t break free of the spell yourself I will have no choice but to unleash it!”

I knew she heard me. All the small tells said so. No matter how deaf and dumb she played to the world, she still held that bear. That took a bit of conscious effort and knowledge of the world around her. Otherwise it would simply slip from her fingers and she wouldn’t even notice. With a small fake scream I shot my left and right hands out to tickle her sides and under her armpits.

She held out for a good thirty seconds before she began to squirm and giggle trying to escape my fingers. I wouldn’t let her go though as I continued my assault until life came back to her eyes. Only then did I let my fingers fall away.

“Restoration magic complete! Your still a scrawny girl in a god ugly dress but you’re no longer a zombie. My magic never fails. If you start slipping back into that zombie state my secret magic technique will activate again you understand?”

After a moment of silence she blinked her eyes at me and nodded.

“Good. I’m sure you are pretty scared right now. I would be too if I was in your shoes and had to stick close to this old woman here. I’ll admit, my mother can be pretty scary at times. Just between you and me, I think that’s how she got her name as a Hunter. Not because she is so good at killing them, but she scares them all away with just her looks and attitude. Could you imagine her storming up to a big ugly troll and grabbing it’s arm to drag it around everywhere? Telling it to do this and do that? I bet the troll would even end up doing what she said!”

She gave me a small smile as I winked at her quickly. The bear in her hand getting crushed to her chest as she watched me.

“I’m Riktal by the way. Would you tell me your name? If you don’t want to talk that’s fine, I’ll just call you squash. Why name you after a food you might ask? Simple, because it was the first thing that came to my mind. I could call you zombie girl if you prefer.”

She stayed silent, refusing to answer me, simply shoving her face into her stuffed animal and closing her eyes. Seeing her reticence I suddenly got an idea.

“Well squash. How about this. I have another special magic I created that will allow your bear there to talk. It can answer my questions if you want. But for this magic only you can hear the secret words and how to activate the spell. So I am going to whisper them into your ear right now.”

True to my words I leaned forward until my lips were next to the left side of her face, cupping my hands around them so no sound leaked out.

“Simply put the bear up to your face and close your eyes while thinking about what you want to say. Then open your mouth and the words will come out. I’ve already put the magic on you to make it happen.”

Sitting back and looking at her I gave her another grin which she returned hesitantly.

“So let’s try this again. I’m Riktal, what’s your name?”

She looked at me and then at the bear before hiding her face in it’s back. There was a moment of silence before I heard a small soft voice coming through the muffled fur.

“Asala.”

“A pleasure to meet you Asala. Are you scared right now?”

She nodded her head.

“Are you scared of me?”

A quick denial back and forth.

“Then how about I sit next to you for now? Would you like that?”

A bobbing of the head as I pulled my chair closer and she leaned against me. I wrapped my arm around her before turning my attention to my mother. As I switched gears, I still had a bit of the anger still under the surface but no desire to explode on her.

“Ok now you can talk. It’s a wonder I was able to do this much so quickly since you were the one taking care of her. I guess I should be lucky she didn’t go completely comatose with your tender treatment. What kind of Hunter are you anyways that you can’t see she was in shock and just needed a little attention? Even someone as inept as you are with kids should have been able to manage this. Hell a half retarded, blind, deaf and mute person could have managed better than you. Hilda even told you she needed a bit of care. What do you have to say for yourself?

“I’m sorry. I just got so caught up in work.”

“You’re sorry. Well not like I expected you to say anything else. That was always your fall back answer where I was concerned too. As if the word’s sorry and work justified everything. And why is it I am the one lecturing you? You’re the parent you should know better! I hope your work toppling the union is worth all the I’m sorry’s mother. Because from where I am sitting it isn’t.”

“What are you talking about darling?”

“You really want to play dumb mother? Just give it up already, I found out about the corruption in the union and the secret dealings with different governments. I heard it from a girl named Liz who’s parents work with you. It seems they at least trust their daughter with this information even if they won’t let her help them. You going to keep denying it?”

“Fine it’s true. I’ve been fighting against it for the last nine and a half years. I’m going to be going to another job where I will be continuing that fight. I want you to take care of that child until someone can come pick her up.”

“Why me? There are hundreds of Hunter’s out there who could do this.”

“Because you have nothing against monster summoners. Her powers are unstable and you are strong enough to deal with anything she could most likely summon. Most other Hunter’s would want to kill her on site. And you’re good with kids as you have just proved. You’ve gotten her more active in the world around us then anyone has in the last three days since her parents died.”

“What if I say no?”

My mother shrugged as she looked between the two of us.

“After what you just did I doubt you will. Even if you do I’d be surprised if she didn’t stick to you like glue anyways. But even if she doesn’t I was thinking of Pelei, though you know how he is.”

“Fine. I’ll do it. I want ten thousand Reul’s though.”

“I’ll give you five thousand. You’ve already shown a willingness to help her and her a willingness to trust you. I could leave now and you’d get nothing out of it.”

“Seven thousand and me and you have a long talk after this job is over where you tell me everything. Even if you leave you should know me well enough to know that doesn’t guarantee I will protect her for free. Plus I need some spending money and a bit extra for myself.”

“Agreed. But only if you continue to go to classes while you protect her.”

“If and only if doing so won’t endanger her or the students at this school even more because of her powers.”

“I can live with that.”

“Then have the money transferred over to my account and get going. The sooner you get this job done the sooner we can have our chat. And I am really looking forward to that mother so you had best be prepared. Just thank Hilda for calming me down before I came in or things would have gone much differently.”

My mother let out a sigh as she gave me a last long look and left the room. Hilda also glanced between me and the girl before leaving.

“You planned to take her from the start didn’t you?”

“Perhaps. Only someone who knows me well could answer that one.”

She gave me a conspiratorial grin and a wink before nodding her head in my direction and leaving the room. Once she was gone I turned my attention back to the girl who was looking at me with those big trusting eyes.

“So Asala. Let’s get to know each other a bit better shall we?”

**********

The window closes on this timeline. Thought there is more to the day, we do not know it at this time. Are you satisfied with your choices? Do you wonder where else his life might have ended up? Come again and find out. Sate my curiosity again and answer more of my questions as you tempt fate and take up the mantle of god. Until we meet again fair traveler.
11112112221221.title: Go to girl first.

11112112221222.content:
When my mother jumped up to give me her normal treatment of fake hugs and kisses like she actually cared about me, I held up my hand to stop her. The girl was just like Hilda described, sitting as still as stone while everything went on around her. As much as I had thought about dealing with her first, I needed more information from my mother. I had a feeling she was going to ask me to watch this girl while she went running off to wherever. If I showed concern for the girl I wouldn’t have much leverage to make a good deal if I even decided to accept such a job.

If it was any other person I might easily accept without question, but because it was my mother asking I might decline just out of spite. I felt sorry for the girl but that wasn’t a reason to shackle myself to my mother’s whims. There were other Hunter’s out there that could do this job. And right now I wasn’t feeling too generous towards my mother to begin with.

“What do you want mother? I’m sure you are busy since you are always busy. So lets not beat around the bush. Tell me why you are here, leaving out the truth like you always do of course, and I will decide whether to walk out or not.”

"Darling, do you really think that little of me?”

“No. I think even less than that. Now can we get on with this?”

She looked as if she was going to say something but slowly shook her head instead before pulling her work face down into place.

“Fine, if that’s the way you want it. Can you protect this little girl for a few days until someone I know can come get her? I’ve got an important job in Bornica and I can’t take her with me. She is a monster summoner who just lost her parents three days ago, causing her powers to activate suddenly and go out of control. She’s unstable at the moment and needs someone that won’t hold her ability against her. After you called earlier I thought of you and how good you are with this kind of thing.”

“I can see why you couldn’t go to just any Hunter. But have you forgotten? I’m not a Hunter. Apparently my mother didn’t think I was good enough to be one and she sent me here instead.”

“Riktal darling, that’s not true! I think you are a great Hunter! I’d rather have you at my back then any dozen experienced ones I know!”

“Then why? Think I couldn’t hold onto my temper if I took the Exam and helped you take down the corrupted union from the inside? Think I wasn’t smart enough to understand the wide scope of your plans? Or that I wasn’t worth being let in on the grand secrets?”

Her mouth fell open slightly and her eyes began to widen as I gave her a small sneer.

“That’s right, I found out. Did you think you could hide it from me forever? I don’t know your reasons why but I’ve been filled in on many of the facts. All thanks to you sending me to this school. So if you tell me why, then I might actually accept this job.”

She was quiet for a few minutes as she studied my face and looked down at her clasped hands. Finally she gave a small nod and looked back up at me.

“I wanted you to become a Hunter after it was all over. It wasn’t that I didn’t think you were ready, or lacked anything you couldn’t learn with experience. I just used your quick temper as an excuse, another in a long list of things I did to force you to go along with my wishes without being given any worthwhile reasons. Your sister has been working from the inside for a long time now. Since she became a Hunter herself in fact. And it has changed her. She doesn’t show it to you when she is home, but we see that other side of her.

“She’s done many things already that she found distasteful, both as a Hunter and as a person. Even some she found distasteful as a woman. All for the sake of our cause. I didn’t want you to go through any of that. I knew the things I did made you angry at me. Indeed I knew I could control you with that anger and so went out of my way to cultivate it. Making you do things simply as a way to spite me. I knew if I told you not to do something you would do it anyways. It wasn’t that I didn’t trust you, I simply wanted to do something right as a mother after all the things I’ve done wrong. I guess even that desire backfired on me.”

She looked at me with eyes that pleaded with me to believe her. I found that anger that had been simmering under the surface all this time slowly slipping away. I’m sure there was more to the story, there always was. But I believed her words. Even though I knew how much of a liar and a conniving woman she was, I believed her.

“All right. I’ll take the job. It doesn’t make us square and it doesn’t mean I forgive you, but I’ll take the job on one condition. Me and you need to sit down and have a very long talk when you are done with this mission. I want to know all of it. Every last detail and what I can do to help. Because now that I know, there is no way I can sit on the sidelines anymore.”

“I suppose that’s inevitable now. I really thought you would take this a lot worse. I thought for sure this would end up in some shouting match at the least.”

“It could have. I was even thinking about it. But in the end you trained me to be rational in my decisions. I might not always be able to apply that when I deal with you, but I’m still rational when given the facts and not treated like an idiot or a fool. Plus you have Hilda to thank for me holding off coming in here screaming my head off at you like I was originally going to do.”

“I do want you to do one other thing while you protect Asala dear. I want you to continue to attend this academy. I know it doesn’t seem fair but it’s important.”

“Part of some scheme to let you come out ahead you aren’t willing to tell me about?”

“No. I’m just helping out a friend. I won’t say I don’t get some benefit from it, but my reasons for sending you here are to help her more than anything.”

“I don’t suppose you will tell me why would you?”

“Next time. I’ll tell you next time.”

“Still with the secrets huh? Fine, whatever. Go on with your business and leave the girl to me. I’ll continue to go to class if and only if I deem it safe for the girl. If I feel there is more danger to either her or the class because of her power I won’t hesitate to skip or leave early.”

“I can live with that.”

My mother stood up then giving me a soft smile and a softer thank you before heading out the door. Once it closed behind her Hilda smiled at me as well.

“Just so you know, this next mission is really dangerous. She won’t say anything, but there’s a real possibility that she will die. That’s why she said she would tell you the reasons next time. To give her extra incentive to stay alive.”

She looked at the girl a moment then back at me.

“You were already planning on taking the job before you ever entered the room weren’t you? Otherwise you never would have asked about her.”

"I'm shocked you think that Hilda. You know me better than that."

"Yes I know you."

She gave me a conspiratorial grin before heading out the door after my mother. Once we were alone I got up and went around the table to sit next to the girl. It would probably take a good three or four minutes to get her to respond to me and then another fifteen to twenty to build up some trust. Perhaps more depending on how closed off in her mind she was.

But I would manage. I was horrible with people in general and anyone between the ages of fourteen and twenty three in particular. But not children. They were the one kind of people I was good at dealing with.

“Hey Asala. I heard your in need of a friend and a family. Well I got some experience as a big brother. Let me tell you about it.”

I settled down more comfortably in my chair as I began to speak, picking up one of her tiny hands and holding it in my own. She didn’t respond at all but that was ok, she would in time. When I gave her hand a small squeeze I smiled a bit when I got the slightest of squeezes back.

*********

The window closes on us for now. I have learned much while watching you. I have come to understand some of the answers of which I seek. Thought there are still many more blanks that needs must be filled. Feel free to come again and choose a different path for young Riktal. I will be more than happy to observe and learn yet more of that which I desire to know. And more than happy to give you a portion of my power to do so. Until then, may you find the answers you seek from the choices you make.

info.brief_description: Become a god and chose the paths that will alter the course of destiny.
info.description:
My name is Adivino. I have been named The Seer. He who can see the future. Right now we are within a pocket between reality and non-reality. Where every possibility exists. Time both has meaning and no meaning here. Possibilities and opportunities happen, have happened, will happen.

I observe the flow of these possibilities. I am a god here, though at the same time I am nothing more than a figment of imagination. All powerful and powerless. I have no face, no form, no identity of my own. Save for that which those who look upon me may desire to attach unto me. Man, woman, young, old. These words have no meaning to me as I am all of them and none of them at once.

I have existed here for an unknown number of years. Or perhaps it is mere minutes. is this the first time we have met or the thousandth? I do not know. I brought you here because I was curious. What path would you choose if you were given the ability to alter the course of someone’s life? I have found it is easy to make such decisions when it is your own life that you alter. But when given the power over another? Will you charge into battle without regard to his or her safety? Or play it safe and avoid confrontation? What do these choices say about you? Would you put them in danger simply because it is not you in this situation? Or would you value their life as you value your own?

So for this span of time as you are within my domain I shall bestow upon you this small gift. The power to alter destinies. To guide a person to glory or destruction. Delve into their innermost thoughts, see what they see and feel what they feel. And then let you chose their path for them. Of course I may or may not tweak the thoughts of those around you slightly to vastly alter the outcome. I doubt you would wish to return to these days again and again if the differences in the timelines were only slight as to be non-existent. Come pick a window, your destiny awaits. Or perhaps I should say someone else’s destiny awaits.
